reviews.review: Must see Temple in Bangkok . Though currently under construction you can still experience this amazing temple and gardens travelling by river taxi to get there.

Under maintenance. Best seen from the river, this temple used to be the tallest structure in Bagkok for centuries. Unfortunatelly during our visit the tallest stupha was covered by scaffolding for maintenance. We will have to come again to capture the beautiful picture.
amazing. a definite must to see, wonderful experience, worth the journey. Good photo shot place. Just make sure you have some baht t pay the deposit which is refunded
Althought they where restoring a wow place. A must see if ever in Bangkok, especially with sun rise. Take a boat and go. Even when they where restoring we trully felt like we witnessed greatness.
Just wow. Wat Arun is another temple you have to go to. The ferry crossing takes 3 Baht per person. The temple take a security deposit which is refunded during exit.

Very nice place to visit.. Visited this place via private long boat trip.
Definitely recommend this place for a good temple picture.

Unfortunately this is covered with scaffolding at the moment. We didn't go in or climb this attraction as it was covered with scaffolding and we were exhausted after a trip around the palace. That said it still looks like an amazing place, very beautiful

Undergoing renovation !. We went there by taxi rather than crossing the Chaophraya river by boat. The river looked quite murky since our last trip to Bangkok.Unfortunately the temple is undergoing renovation so we were unable to go inside only climb the steps and go round it and take some photos.The entrance ticket is 50 bahts and open from 8am-5pm only.There are some very nice shops near the exit.

Beautiful temple !. It took only 3 bath to cross the river from Wat Pho to visit this temple. The ticket price is only 50 bath. It is much smaller than Wat Pho but still a nice one to visit. It was a shame that we went here when they are having a reconstruction so we couldn't climb up to the top to enjoy the view :(

Beautiful temple. We saw this temple from across the river 2 years ago and sadly, it was closing for the night so we never got the chance to visit. This time around, my thai girlfriend drove us there and it was still as beautiful as I remembered it to be. Unfortunately for me, the temple is undergoing restoration so there was scaffolding everywhere. I believe the restoration should be completed by Dec 2016.
Amazing. The only dissapointment was that the temple was being worked on so scaffolding surronded it, nit really the best for pictures.

Nice temple. Beautiful architecture, lots of details, worth the visit.
The boat experience was not the best. You need to bargain the price of the ride.

Wat Arun / The Temple of Dawn. As the name of the Wat calls temple of dawn, so it should be preferable to visit during dawn. Haha, it's not so, you can visit at anytime as you like. The opening hours is 8.30-6pm everyday. At N8 pier, you only have to spend another 3baht for the fee of crossing the river (one trip, return another 3baht) as the wat is located at the west bank of Chao Phraya River.Wat Arun has been the Royal Temple which dedicated to the 2nd reign of Chakkri Dynasty. Here is the most elegant pagoda, landmark of Thai. There are some formalities of visiting Wat Arun Rajwararam: dress code, not to climb the rail, not to dangle any doll, not to drop cigarette and waste on the floor. The entrance fee is 50baht, inside there's another 50baht fee for another wat visit (optional). For man, short pant is allowed. For women, short pant and shirt sleeve shirt are not allowed. But you can find certain stalls that sell long pants or ever the admission provide clothes rental service with additional charge. When I visited the wat in October'16, it is under minor renovation.

Very Impressive. The pictures are always better than the temples but it is saddening how much the scaffolding surrounding the temple hurts the majesty of it. It's a great site and an awesome thing to look at from across the river on a rooftop bar.

Concrete statues. Always amazing in a country this old to show up at one of their premier temples and find all the statues to be made from cement. (funny actually). It's just not worth the visit, there's really nothing to see - but as a tourist you do your best to capture what's there with the most artistic photo you can so you can stick it up on Instagram and make those back home think you're having a wonderful time in 'exotic asia'.

A temple with beautiful artifacts. I like this temple because of its location, right beside a river.. You actually have to get on a boat to visit this place.. The statues are very old and yet are admirable... Stairs to the main temple are very steep and it is an adventure by itself.. Going up is easy but coming down can give you goosebumps, especially if it is raining.. Yup I visited when it was raining..
Large temple. A very large temple on the banks of the river. nice place to visit but not on a sunny day. A must visit in bangkok
Nice at Night!. Very great view from the river. many restaurant by the river to chill out dining. The temple is very fantastic.
Beautiful Temple. The beauty of the mosaics is amazing, so intricate and creative. The use of porcelain chards is colorful and creative.

Under Renovation. The temple was under renovation, so you just can climb until the 2nd floor. The place was awesome, huge and clean but the river was brown and dirty. The market was small and very crowded, but cheap.

Best temple for me. This is my number 1 temple in BKK followed by the reclining Buddha. Really looks great and you can climb up the stairs to the top. Unfortunately when I visited there are some repairs being done so climbing up is not allowed. We still did enjoyed the view. Best to visit during sunset. You would have to take the boat going back to pier 8 before you can take the boat taxi going to pier 1. There are those special boat taxis but they are expensive.

Beautiful. Needs to be seen during the day and after sunset.. This wat is easy to find, everybody knows where it is and it has a nearly directly ferry to the location from downtown Bangkok. The evening view is dazzling and highly recommended to be viewed from a boat as it is all lit up. During the day, the 50B fee to enter is cheap compared to others. We found it on foot without a problem, arriving from a more northern location. The wat was smaller in square feet than expected but much taller than we thought it would be. The individual tile work is amazing and looks pain staking. When we were there they were doing some reconstruction work; we saw most, not every inch, but it was nice to see that our money was going directly to reconstruction. Despite the residential location and the surrounding alleyways, we felt no reason to be worried about safety upon arriving nor leaving.
Temple of Dawn. A bit unique when it comes to a cultural site. The temple of Dawn might have you thinking of locations to film a movie. The intricacies of the craftsmanship is amazing.

A good place to visit for an hour or two. If you have a couple of hour to kill, you might consider this place as an option, but since the weather in Bangkok is too hot, think twice if you're taking children as the area is mainly outdoor. Bring plenty of fluids, apply sunscreen and wear a hat for sure

Beautiful . I don't normally write reviews for places but the temple of dawn was breathtaking. This was by far my favourite temple I visited during my stay in Bangkok - the colours were spectacular and the view across the river was lovely.

Nice. Nice and old.Looks like indian style.U should cross the river from Wat Po side to Wat Arun.Only3bhats.Always be careful from pickpockets.Eat only inside designated areas and restaurants.Don't eat street foot.I can recommend only one lady opposite of Wat Po which is making nice Thai pancake with banana and chocolate.Other don't dare to eat.Food look weird

Nice!. Wat Arun, or temple of dawn is dedicated to the sun God. It is a short ferry journey away from Rattanakosin island. Unfortunately, during our visit there was renovation work that was going on and hence we could not enjoy the splendour as much. But it is still a beautiful structure and we would love to visit it again.

Distinctly different temple across the river. After taking in Wat Pho (the Reclining Buddha) and/or the Grand Palace, a quick & cheap boat across the river to Wat Arun is rewarded with a Thai temple that differs to Wat Pho and offers the chance to climb the towering construction to discover more of its design intricacies and look back across the river to the more well-known destinations. There are also a number of small traders selling the usual street merch, chances to dress-up and explore the number of other spiritual buildings and statues in the surrounding area.

Beautiful temple by the river. Wat Arun is also known as the Temple of Dawn, as it was named after Aruna, the Indian god of dawn. Architecturally, the wat is said to represent Mount Meru, the centre of the Buddhist universe. The main structure at Wat Arun is currently undergoing repairs, so it is covered in scaffolding and not looking its best. But it was still worth a visit, with an entry fee of only 50 baht (less than $2).The easiest way for me to get to the Chao Phraya River from the Sukhumvit area was via BTS Skytrain. An interchange at Siam Station allowed me to switch from the Sukhumvit Line to the Silom Line. I then rode the Silom Line to Saphan Taksin station, which is adjacent to the main Central Pier on the river. From Central Pier, I caught an orange flag water taxi up to Pier 8 and then jumped onto a ferry to get to Wat Arun on the opposite side of the river.
huge and beautiful pagoda. must see Buddha temple after grand palace.it is near the pier and it can accessible via metro as well

Quite a religious place. Temple of Dawn. Name itself gives you a curiosity to visit. Good place to be peacefull. Awesome example of fine art architecture. When I visited this place, it was being renovated. Even then it is a good place to visit. Most important thing its free to visit.
Nice temple. Paid a fee of 50 baht for this. Not very big but good architecture. You travel by boat to reach it .

Beautiful . This temple is under renovation right now (Set 2016g, so you cannot take the best pics. The main tower has scaffolding outside. The temple is by the river, so you can get there by boat (it is an excellent experience!) Inside there are many beautiful places, but majority of them are under renovation too. The maintenance of the temple is not very good.... I liked more the Thai temples!

Always wanted to visit this Wat - finally got the chance this time.. Took the ferry across the river to visit this Wat - impressive place! It was a pretty hot day, so we stopped at a beverage/ice cream place on the grounds here. Much to see, great way to spend the day. The temple is still being worked on - so you may want to visit once the restoration work is completed.

Still (a bit) under construction but beautiful!. Wat Arun is very beautiful and has been under (re) construction for a longer time. At the moment it's just minimal so you can see Wat Arun again. Amazing and how precise they have restored it.

A Top Three. Even though the main spire was covered in scaffolding, I was glad I stopped here. The golden statues just pop against the stark white of the temple. From all the photos I saw, I though it would be yellow.

Wat Arun Temple sunset. Really nice experience, so many people around during the whole day - but everything is functioning. You get a bottle of water with your entrance ticket. It could be very useful, as it gets really hot around noon. They are recycling the water plastic bottles on the spot, at the exit! Very commendable... would like to re-visit one day.
Amazing. Even though was being in restored, it was amazing. I did a meditation with the monk over there, and, at the end of it, he gave me a bracelet and cold water.

Lovely temple. If you are so inclined you can walk to the river, take a boat for 15 baht and walk to the temple from Khao san road. The temple was beautiful, but under construction at the time. There are other temples nearby as well that are worth checking out. The detail on the temple was astounding and the size was impressive, entrance was only 50 baht each.

Worth a visit. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the area. It was a shame that during my visit the temple was covered in scaffolding though, definitely spoils the sight. I made my way to Wat Arun by boat. Excellent ferry ride across the river, don't be afraid to try this, great way to get around.Beware of steps at Wat Arun, there is a lot of climbing involved making this temple not suitable for those who struggle with walking or stairs.

Peter Borneo. This is a must place to visit when in Bangkok.
Great experience and one of the highlights in town
Lovely, beautiful and peaceful.

Exceeded expectations. . A beautiful, unique temple in the web of gold plated temples in Bangkok. It's fairly small in area but the depth and detail of the temple makes it beyond worthy of a visit. Watch the typical sunrise from the opposite side of the river or get up close and personal and watch the last beams of the day's light illuminate the temple towers from within the grounds for an seeing evening activity. You won't be disappointed.

wat Arun. it was good visit. we have gone there in a cab and then took the ferry. the waters were dirty. there were many shop's. temple was beautiful. nice view. peaceful. we had snaps taken with traditional thai dress. overall wonderful experience.
Peaceful. With the beautiful backdrop of the river and sky...it is majestic as well as peaceful after the throngs of the grand palace. Its currently closed for renovation.

under renovation so looks ugly at the moment. visited during the afternoon, so no beautiful lighting from the sunrise or sunset which meant the temple looked kind of plain. the worst part was the scaffolding, it ruined the whole view. not that I would go again, but i would advise anyone visiting to visit around sunrise or sunset and when the renovations are over.
Beautiful Khmer style temple. Different architecture from the other temples in Bangkok. Looks more like one of Angkor what temples. Very lovely.

A must see. Wat Arun is one of Bangkok's highlights. The temple is situated on the banks of the Chao Praya River. Quite near the Grand Palace which is on the other bank of the river. You can cross the river for 4THB per person. I have visited the temple multiple times.

Great place to go :). But currently under renovation. So avoidable. A great place to go in the evening . The temple is by the river and its refreshing to go there during evening time. Dont miss it when in BKK
Under restoration. From the river boat, Wat Arun was under restoration. There is a big scaffold encompassing the giant spire. So I give it a miss and plan to visit the next time in Bangkok.
Majestic view spoilt by scaffolding (Sep 16). We went in the hope of seeing a nice sunset but there temple was covered with scaffolding. Nonetheless, when the sun set, it was still a very nice view.

Great!. Wat Arun is a beautiful temple, and is much less crowded than the other main attractions of the city. The restorations works didn't allow us to go up (which is supposed to be the coolest part of the attraction), but we definitely enjoyed our time there and will go back once it's done.

looks better from the other side of the river at nigth. but climbing it, is not as nice, plus is always full and the grounds are very dirty. we went since they said is a must, we would not recommend it

Quiet in the morning. We visited first thing in the morning, it was very quiet, only few tourists. Unfortunately the temple was under constructions, so could not get to the top and visit the whole site. Ladies do not forget to cover shoulders or take a scarf, otherwise can rent one at the entrance for 20 Baht.Entrance fee is 50 Baht and opened at 8.30am.

Wrapped in scaffolding. It is really an excellent temple to visit. THB3 to cross the Chao Praya from the pier next to the Wat Po and the Grand Palace.As of September 2016, Wat Arun is wrapped in scaffolding for repairs and maintenence. Not the best time to visit.

beautiful in the afternoon. Almost every Tourist does visit the WAT ARUN, but mostly in the morning.Charter a longtail-boat in the afternoon and drive for an hour through the klongs, then to WAT ARUN.To save Money, you can take the regular boat from Taksin-Bridge, but without the Klongs

Circus. Rule number 1: cameras not allowed;Rule number 2: limited number of people inside the complex. If Thai authorities have the courage to implement this 2 rules than the experience should be amazing. Right now it's a nightmare of Chinese trying to take selfies with the Buddha.
Easily seen in 30 mins.. very attractive small temple, reached by short boat trip Possibly not necessary to go to if you have been at the Royal Palace or the Reclining Budda.

Temple is closed. Not worth to pay. Temple is closed,you cannot go inside as all builing is under refurbishment. I was really dissapointed,because we paid 50 THB per person just to see the courtyard around the temple. Definitely NOT WORTH GOING especially that its far from city centre and you need to take boat to get there.

My favorite part of the temple areas in Bangkok. The steps were high and a bit challenging. It was fun to climb. Among the temples in the area, this is my favorite because it sends a bit of adrenaline rush to climb those steps and reach the top! :D
One of Monuments. As the restoration work was in progress could not get through. But manage to go places around the monument.
Nice temple. Wat Arun.Just opposite Wat Pho and opposite side of the river.Very nice architecture.Try to visit at sunset.Highly recommended.
Superb . A must visit spot with full family. Beautiful architecture with marvelous craftsmanship. The adjoining river view makes it even more beautiful

Great but under renovation!!. The temple is very nice and the texture is great for background in photos. Due to renovation work we were not allowed to go on top. Still the view of other parts of temple was great. Evening time makes it more peaceful , beautiful and relaxing

Under construction. Took ferry to there. 14baht from SapanTaksin and 3baht to cross the river.It was under construction. I should visit again sometime later. I saw several places where you can try on Thai traditional clothes and they take picture for you for only 100baht, but i got there at almost 6 which is closing time so they were wrapping up so i couldnt get the picture.
My favourite spot!. Of all the Wats in Bangkok, this must be my most favourite of all! At night, it illuminates the river bank majestically with its lights! Truly magneficient!

An architectural marvel. Wat Phra is a shiny, colorful ode to religion. Symmetrical structure, glistening cut tiles, magnificently colored frescos all transport you to a bygone era. If you could only see one thing at Bangkok, pick this.Tips: take ferry from the central pier- they leave from the left- at 14 baht per person. Avoid the long tail.
I made it!. Not just seeing it but walk through it, the steep steps going up and down. Thought I couldn't make it it but I did. Not just fulfilling a dream but conquering my fear.
Wat Arun. The Dawn Temple of Bangkok. Good structure with superior views. Once you complete Wat Phra Kaew you can travel to this place by boat ride approx cost 3 bht.

First light of the dawn. Wat Arun Ratchawararam Ratchawaramahawihan or Wat Arun is among the best known of Thailand's landmarks and the first light of the morning reflects off the surface of the temple with pearly iridescence. Wat Arun can be easily accessed through the Chao Phraya River, and ferries travel across the river towards the Maharaj pier.

Wat Arun. A decent excursion to a landmark Buddhist temple. Impressive architecture, landscaped gardens. Getting there vis water taxi is quite an experience on its own. Currently the temple is undergoing renovations so it wasn't as impressive as it could be. A worthwhile visit nevertheless.

Under repairs:(. It was under repairs when i visited this place.it still is i think.when the renovations are done i think you could climb the stairs to get a nice view.there is not much to see on the ground level during renovation.

Don't miss this attraction in Bangkok.. I visited Wat Arun Temple during Sept first week. I opine visiting this temple, during evening is good. Spent at least hour or two to see this expansive temple complex, reclining Buddha . The entry fee is 100 THB.
across the river. From the deck restaurant ...across the river the temple was shrouded in scaffolding so we took a river boat ..local ..instead .up river
Temple of Dawn under repair. A bit of shame the temple is covered in scafolding at the moment. Still a great location on the river but not so great for photos at the moment.

My favorite BKK temple. A beautiful and serene place. Get there early to miss most tourists and the hottest hours and get better light for photos. please wear respectful clothing and talk quietly while inside the temples.
Spectacular temple. Spectacular temple to see. Jump on a boat that takes you across the river to the temple covered with shells

Tranquility & splendor . My favorite in Bangkok. It was pity the area was under construction. It could stay there for hours and listen to the music of bells hanging over the columns coupled with the wind. It is a place for releasing the stresses of a hectic lifestyle. I loved the architecture and the white color.
Boring, like all the rest . None of the temples in Bangkok are memorable, in my opinion. All have an entry fee, which seems bizarre for a place of worship.

Under renovation but still beautiful. Went there after seeing Wat Pho with my family, crossing by the Chao Praya by boat and finally seeing the temple. Currently it was under renovation but still the beautiful side of the place is not missing. There's a small market as well inside the area that sell souvenirs with reasonable price
Beautiful!. Get a boat to visit the temple, as early as possible, so you won't be bothered by other tourists. It's a great complex, with a nice view of the river, if you are able to climb the stairs!

Wat Arun. We went from Wat Pho and we'd to take a 5 mins boat to cross the river. We almost couldn't recognise the temple which is undergoing maintenance/repair as it looked so different from the googled photos.

Beautiful view and must visit. Good for people that loves historical places. Each temple tells a different story. And the temple is going to vow you with it's historical notes and the sculptures of it

Currently under renovation . This is worth a visit if you are in the area. It is currently under renovation and will be for some time. So couldn't really see anything.. unless there's nothing much to see anyway...

Gorgeous Temple: Wat Arun. From Grand Palace, I walked like 10-15mins to the boat terminal to Wat Arun, it is a great experience to rude the Thai's boat to Wat Arun for only 3bht then get off and walk the views around it. For 50bht entrance you can see the beauty of Wat Arun or they call the Temple of The Dawn. Shops, food stalls around it, clean bathroom. But during my visit there are scaffoldings around it so you cannot realy appreciate the beauty since it was under preservation.

beautiful temple with view of the city. You can club wat pho and wat arun as a one day activity. You can walk from wat pho to the pier and pay 3 bhat to cross the river. There are cruises across the river but all you need is to cross the river to visit wat arun. Beautiful structure but was under construction and visit to the top was banned..
Looks amazing!. It looks amazing, but too bad we were not able to see anything, the temple were under maintenance... Luckly all other temples are nearby.

Should pay a visit!. Temple was under renovation but remain accessible. Will need at least an hour to explore the temple. Went there on a tuk-tuk and we took a boat back after touring the place. The temple is situated just by the river.
Beautiful from the river / at dawn and sunset. See Wat Arun from the river and at dawn and / or sunset. Not the place to visit midday. One of my favourite Bangkok temples.

Not worth it. Take a picture from a pier.. I was a bit disappointed about this place. You pay 100 Thai Baht as an entrance fee and than 50 Thai Baht to go inside the Wat Arun. I didn't go close. Not worth it but just tourists scam.

Impressive . Unfortunately for me, it was still covered in scaffolding, but as they are doing renovation on it I'm sure when the scaffold comes down, hopefully next yr at some point. I only saw it from outside the gates, as I had only a brief visit.

Lovely temple complex. The nice thing about Wat Arun is that it is located across the river from Wat Pho. These two temple complexes are only separated by a 3 baht ferry ride and offer a very efficient use of time to see two splendid temples. Some refurbishment is currently occurring in Wat Aru on the tallest stups but it is still a satisfying visit.

Currently being renovated. This temple is covered in beautiful mosaics and its second claim to fame is that the outside can be climbed for a magnificent view of Bangkok. However it is currently covered in scaffolding for renovation work and you can't climb it.
Under renovation. It is my second time to come here, it is beautiful, but under renovation. Outside shopping store is good in pricing.

Nice but under renovation. Had I nice morning travelling up to the river to this temple, it really is beautiful however disappointingly was under renovation when I went so you couldn't climb it for the views. Still had a nice day. Get there early if you don't want to be stuck on the boat when it's supper busy.

Under construction at the time.. Don't know if it's done yet. Admission is cheap - like 20THB...Amazing art to see... Take the river taxi (9THB) to get over there - or take the river taxi up the river to see the sights and a free tour!!! and then come back!

Great to see up close. I visited Wat Arun last week while I was walking around Thonburi. Although the main chedi is still being renovated and has scaffolding so you can't walk up it, you can still scamper up and down the steps surrounding it. It's right next to the river so you can see some nice views. For me, 50 baht well spent. It's beautifully carved and whiter than it looks from afar.

under construction. seemed like a great temple, very quiet in comparison to across the river, not much to do in area that we could tell, will allow you to use a scarf to cover shoulders, small market near the river by the temple but markets in Chang Mai are better.
A magic Temple. WatArun is for me a magic Temple. If you can appreciate the Thai culture and/or is interested in Buddhism a visit is a must

It was a really hot day!. Visited the temple (wat) in the late morning just before lunch and it wasn't that crowded probably because it was a very sunny day and the heat was kinda oppressive. My tip is to remember to wear the appropriate clothes since this is a temple and they will no let you enter if you are dressed too liberally.

Stunning. The statuesque pagoda of Wat Arun is stunningly beautiful and a must see when in Bangkok. Wat Arun is also known as The Temple of Dawn. It is believed that Wat Arun was built during Ayutthaya era. Ayutthaya was a Siamese kingdom that existed from 1351 to 1767.The temple is undergoing restoration so parts are still clad in scaffolding. That aside I wouldn't have missed the visit. The small statues surrounding the temple are lovely. It's always a shame that beautiful places like this are surrounded by gift shops. That said, I couldn't leave without buying something

Covered in scaffolding. Was so excited to see this temple and climb the stairs and see the view across the river. Once there found the top half covered in scaffolding. Extremely disappointed to say the least, still is worth the trip on the boat. Best 3 baht spend on a boat trip

Beautiful temple located on the west bank of Chao Phraya River. Amazing structure, the temple is impressive to look at, beautiful and intricately built complex. The temples was quiet and not too crowded.

Nice. Since it is right across the river to reclining Buddha so one should visit it. There are many ferries between both the temple. Well my timing of visit was not really good as it was really hot and humid. Both these temples all most open so the weather can ruin the fun.
Magnificent temple on Chao Phraya bank. The tower was closed for maintenance and hence could not climb up to have the aerial view of Bangkok and sunset.
Magnificent. Right now it is under construction but still worth the trip. A magnificient structure. You should definitely check it out.

beautiful and original. if you are affected by the temple syndrome and think you saw too many and they start looking all the same to you... go to wat arun. Its unicity and beauty will reconcile you with the world of temples :-)

not worse the trip. At the moment the Wat Arunis under renovation and very little to see. If someone want to sell you a trip there deny it. On the Klong tour they offer to stop there but do not waste your time

Quick site visit. We had to come here as we were told by local friends. The main mast was under repair and entry was $50 baht. We walked around, took some pics and enjoyed the structures. Not much more to do. We spent an hour and we saw it all. There many adjoining sites that need your visit.

Currently Under Construction. Still a beautiful temple, but is currently undergoing restoration, which affects the aesthetics of the place. Nonetheless, I was glad that I got to visit the temple and witness a monk blessing a family as they offered a donation to him in goods. The water taxi, although short was a neat experience for only 3 baht.
Classic on the river temple, under renovation. Can only see from the street or river level as it is undergoing renovations in August 2016. A classic temple and still a must see from the river.

Must see place. The temple complex is very beautiful and you can just walk around and no matter where you sit or stand you get a beautiful view of the temple. Unfortunately, when I visited the main temple was under reconstruction and covered, but the whole temple complex is still very beautiful and definitely must see place, especially once the renovations works are completed.

Lovely temple. Beautiful temple in Bangkok. There was some renovation work going on when we went but it's still a great structure to see with golden Buddhas everywhere. Best way to get there is by boat.

Impressive. What an impressive building and beautiful grounds and gardens too- excellent to be seen at sunset. It was undergoing repair when we visited and there was still scaffolding on, so can only imagine the impact when seen in all its splendour.
Nice place. This is also another gem of bangkok.i visited bangkok last year with family. This place is very good in city tour.visit must.

Under construction. When we visited, wat Arun was under construction and we cannot clibm the temple. We visited this temple after seeing wat Por. We took a boat, 3 Bahrs to accross the river and reached the wat Arun. I think it would be better and more beautiful to see this temple from the other side of the river.

Quiet temple away just 10 mins from the busy Palace. Great temple architecture across the river from the Grand Palace. We took a ferry from pier no. 8 for (I think) 30bht (1 adult and 1 child). The grounds were pretty empty only approx 25 tourists. While the Palace had hundreds (felt like thousands) ! It's currently being renovated, but that doesn't stop the feeling of magnitude of height. Great little out door coffee shop outside for a relaxing drink / ice cream in the shade with fans that spray a cool mist!!

Last Holiday. It was my first time visit Thailand. It was very wonderful holiday. Wat arun temple is the beautiful temple in there. But when I visited the temple was on renovated and it was 90% finish. You can see many shop and the price so cheap.

Amazing ceramic work. The wat is currently covered with scaffolding as its being restored. The ceramic work is very detailed and painstakingly done. Very nice topiary also. Not too many tourists and a good place to come by river boat.

Nice temple but still under construction . Loved how they built this temple, with all those broken pieces of Chinese ceramic. I really wanted to climb on the summit of the main pagoda for the view but it was still under construction. Still worth a visit in my opinion, as it is nice to see all the ceramic details from close by. The entrace is 50 baht, but you have to pay some extra if you need to cover up your legs or shoulders (I paid 120 baht for legs only, but you get 100 baht back when you give the clothing piece back).
Under Renovation. The temple is currently being renovated - so, the views are not nearly as impressive. Still interesting grounds and worth a visit.

Why not. If youre in Bangkok check it out. The boat costs 3 baht to get across the river. Yes 3 baht if you get asked for more then you are at the wrong pier ask where the 3 baht boat is. To get to the boat youll first have to go through a small market kind of thing. The temple is free to visit and is an interesting place to look around and further your insight in to Thai culture and Buddism.
Excellent. Wat Arun has the reclining Buddha. A lot of tourists go there to visit. Apart from that, there are many other architectural marvels to see in the same premises.
Great place for visit but is renovation. Paid for 50baht for get in and is was closed for renovation. And just took few photo and use the boat going back again. Boat cost 3 baht per trip.

one of my favorite temple in BKK. I like to visit the temple. This place has many tourists attraction spot. You can go up with the stairs to see the view of BKK from the the top of the grand pagoda. Sometimes it is under construction. It is better to check the info before you will visit there.
Nice for picture. it was not busy when my visit. The temple is pretty. If you want to buy souvenir just go inside! Go around to get good spot for pictures!

Well, nice... . Nice temple area but few things to see. Unfortunately, the main pagode is scaffolded now and the place is comparably overcrowded with souvenir booths. Best commuted to via water taxi, road travel tends to be cumbersome.
Super Historical. I love the boat ride to the temple. The architecture and history behind this temple were mesmerizing. I love the aura there...

Worth the visit!. This temple is under construction, cant walk all around but again, the detailing desings but just to see it and touche its walls was a great experience. We also saw how the workers do their job and were impressed by their pulling up of material system they were working very high on the padogas;we were also impressed by women working as same as men.By the way from the taxy boats you will get a great view of Wat arum.

Wasted Money . Great temple but we paid 50 bhat to get in and most of it was closed off for building works so we couldn't climb the stairs. It was a bit of a disappointment as we were not told about it being closed before we paid.

Stunning at sunset. Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn is both stunning at dawn or sunset. The Grand Pagoda is especially lovely when lit up at night. Located on the banks of the Chao Phraya River. the colourful spires stand majestically over the water. The grounds are quite peaceful with few crowds and there are nice murals, a main Buddha image and some impressive mythical guardians. It is possible to walk a little way up the main tower for a view of the river. The Wat looks better from a distance though with best views at sunset with the sun setting directly behind the temple. Entry to the temple is 100 baht and appropriate dressing applies.
Nice if you like tourist crowds. A bit underwhelming if you've ever been to the temples in Siem Reap but nonetheless an inspiring little excursion for an afternoon in Bangkok.

Under contruction, so far. So far the place is under construction, so you cannot visit the entire place, but in my opinion it is still worth a visit. Very beautiful place where to spend an hour before the sunset.
Stunning temple . Loved Wat Arun with its wonderful location on the river. Pity it was covered in scaffolding when we visited but that can't be helped!

Amazing porcelain details. The temple is across the river to the grand palace, you can cross the river with a special boat wich goes only between the two sides for 3 baht. Unfourtunately the highest tower was under construction when I visited but it was still impressive. It's a little bit different from the other Wats, since this one is left white and the colors are all given by broken chinese porcelain mosaic. It is required here to dress properly (shoulders and knees covered) but in case you are not, at the entrannce they give you skirts or pants for around 20 baht rent fee. The entrance fee is 50 baht what you have to pay at a little cabin across the entrance. The area of this temple is not that big but the building is very impressive and interesting. You can also walk up and down of the big stairs leading to the towers. It' a beautiful and one of a kind temple.
Great visit. This is a pleasant place to visit for half day or even full day if you have enough time. A good tour around would do a good visit.

August 2016 - restorations. Just be aware that in August 2016 there were restorations going on so Wat Arun was covered in scaffolding. It's an iconic spot but we hope next time we come the scaffolding will be down.

Under construction. I didn't really like this temple as much as other ones.. Maybe because it was under renovation when we went there. I also went there after we visited the grand temple which is much nicer. It's worth visiting after renovation if you are already in the area.
Great temple. Great boat ride to get to the temple. Excellent walk around the peaceful temple. Very Worth visiting!
The great place must go. This picture are at the backside of Thai coin surronding are very beautiful they situated oppositr to grand palace

under renovation. reading a lot of good reviews of the temple, we were anticipating our visit but was a bit disappointed as the temple was under renovation. didn't spend much time, took a couple of snaps and went.

Beautiful from the water. Another jewel in Thailand's crown. You can get there by taking the ferry to cross the river at the same pier where you get off for the Wat Pho which is N-8. there are two booths that collect money, facing the water coming from the market, the booth on the left is the one you want. Can't go wrong, there is a clear sign that indicates it crosses to Wat Arun. It's 3 bahts/person one way. Coming back is another 3 bahts. Up close it is still majestic but with construction ongoing it kinds of puts a damper on the overall effect. The best I have seen Wat Arun is from a river cruise or even just from the Chao Praya tourist boat at sunset and at night. The place is lit up and it looks like an exotic fairy tale castle. Then you can say, wow you are really in Thailand! There is a fee to go inside the temple but the grounds are free. So get your camera ready.

Temple Under Construction - You Can see from the Outside - Don't buy tickets. Wat Arun is under construction so it doesn't make sense to go there by ferry and see the construction site. Still, if you want to enjoy the ferry ride then do not go inside the temple, just take look from the outside. It will save your 50 Baht.
under scaffolding atm. You can tell that it is normally worth a visit but it is currently under renovation so you can't see much.
under construction work. It's under construction and we don't have a chance to visit, maybe due to the refurbish work the ferry service skip the stop.

Small trip due to construction. Wat Arun is under construction currently so it took less then 30 minutes to see the whole thing. Tourists weren't allowed inside so seeing the outside was still pretty neat since the structure has so many artistic details. I wouldn't recommend coming here till renovations are all done since other temples offer more. Also you have to pay an entrance fee to see the temple even though it's under construction.
Wonderful small temple. What Arun is a beautiful small temple which is made of old porcelain. It is undergoing renovation but do not let that put you of.

Temple Tour. Very interesting site. Went on an organised tour. However, if future I would arrange my own transport. The organised tour while getting to the site spent a lot of time picking up from hotels in a very crowded road system. In future I would avoid organised tours to get to sites such as the Temple of Dawn.

Wat Arun. You can get to this temple by taking a short ferry trip from the Wat Phra Kaew side of the river. Alternatively, you can take a taxi to Pinklao and enter the temple grounds from there. Just say "Wat Arun," to the taxi driver. There is a steep climb to the top of the temple, so you will need to take care climbing up and down it. The view of Bangkok from the top is jaw-dropping. It really is picturesque and the temple should be visited to experience it. The artwork on the temple is also extremely decorative and attractive.
Disappointed . I went to visited the temple I was exited but the temple is getting fixed . I was disappointed not much too see compared with other temples in Bangkok.

Dawn? Read the history of it!. It has a great history behind this temple, before seeing it. Please do read up about it! Went during repair works so it was covered with steel rods everywhere. But it's nice to see and just a ferry away!

Under construction. The temple is not big and it was under construction, but their art work of the temple is amazing. The steps are narrow. Not suitable for elderly to walk the steps. Near by there is a shop provide the traditional Thai skirt, you may rent it to take photos.

postcards here!. Wat Arun, locally known as Wat Chaeng, is situated on the west (Thonburi) bank of the Chao Phraya River. stunning temples n you're advised to take those tourist ferries that take you from one point to another. remember to buy postcards from this place!

An incredible temple. I visited the temple just before the closing time. The sunset made it even more pretty. A nice and unusual temple to explore with your kids. Many stray and tame cats are around the temple. Just one issue, when i use the ferry 3B to cross the river, i gave her 11B for two persons to get 5B back. But she did not give me the change. I don't know why.

Interesting place. Sadly it was coated in scaffolding when we visited however nonetheless it was very interesting and there was lots to see! We reached it via a boat tour which you can get from the central pier (next to a train station too) Would definitely recommend this place as well as getting their using the boat trip (but barter!!)

From far and close.... ...impressive and not much crowded as we expected. It's a small temple ground and less people were there when we arrived after crossing the river. Especially the detailed designs of the main parts are awesome. Take your time to check out all the different figures.From close it's as impressive as it looks from the other side of the river.
Day tour. Took a 1/2day tour and the weather was very hotThere's some shops selling some souvenirs, price are quite cheap for some items...Remember to bring sunglass and hat/cap

Amazing temple alogn the riverside. Amazing old temple alogn the riverside with very nice history story.Steep steps to climb the Wat to the top, you can use the ropes along the stairs to climb it up more easy. Nice view over the river and city. A must see attraction in Bangkok. travel by boat along the river.

One not to miss.. Caught the skytrain to Saphan Nonsi and from there a ferrry for 14b -pay onboard. Don't fall for the 100b tickets on offer. You might also consider a 40b express ferry also They will call out Wat Arun #8 stop. A small ferry takes you over for 3b each way. Plenty of food and drinks available. Great photo opportunities. Ferry back and follow the crowds arond to the Grand Palace. It's an easy walk. No need for a tuk tuk which will be on offer.

Accessible by boat. The easiest way to get to this temple is by crossing the river by boat. The temple is a different structure and architecture than the other Bangkok temples making this one pretty unique. It resembles more the Khmer temples as found in Angkor What.
Fantastic. One of the best experiences I ave ever had,it's a lot of temples but loved Angkor Wat,even the local town with all its restaurants was enjoyable.
Beatiful temple. A beautiful temple, however due to renovation work being done currently we did not see it in all its glory.

beautiful wat with porcelan. I love visiting this Wat. It's beautiful and I love the simplicity of it. It's on the other side of the river where people usually stay in Bangkok. Take the rivertaxi....it's a lovely ride. Unfrtunately a lot of time there is preparework so not always possible to see it completly

Great detailed but it was under renovation. Cheap souvernir inside the temple. Bring sarong or rent one in the entrance.
You can rent traditional clothing to take pictures.

Another Beautiful Temple. Another one of Bangkok' beautiful temples. Again very impressive but I've taken two stars off as it isn't the most impressive of them all and it is currently undergoing renovation work. Again many beautiful golden Buddhas to be seen. Hopefully the renovations will be complete soon soothe Temple of Dawn can be viewed in all its glory. One of Bangkok's must do places.

Nice. Under reconstruction so looks not perfect, but it was nice to see one of Thailand's symbols up close. The ticket on the ferry boat costs only 3 BHT one way and 50 BTH entry fee. Don't overpay to get there. There are many touristic ferry station, that want you to pay 200 BHT and more. But you always can find extremely cheap public transport.

Great temple get a water taxi!. This is for me one of the best temples in Bangkok amazing works we saw it in the process of being restored the detail!Because of the restoration we could only get half way up will probably revisit when we return.got the water taxi across the river for about 2.5bht.
A normal first time visit. It started with a boat ride to cross the river and then walk a few metres to reach the temple.. the architecture was really good and well maintained.
Must see in Bkk. I always take friends here when they come to visit me here in Bkk, just a must see that can't be missed when visiting this beautiful city

so nice. t is a shame that it was cloudy; as it seems that sunrise and sunset from this temple is an experience!! Very impressive and beautiful even under refurbishing... It is one of the places you must visit in Bangkok

FANTASTIC STRUCTURE.... Even if the weather is too hot, My mom and I took the river taxi to visit WAt Arun Temple(Temple of the Dawn). River taxi is the cheapest and fastest way to go there. The main temple is under renovation right now but it never stop all the tourist to visit it. I Love the Temple.
Wat Arun. Need to take a short ferry ride to reach Wat Arun. Renovation work was going on at the time of my visit
Beautiful despite the partial renovation. Very nice place, decorated in beautiful way. A lot of stairs which makes the visit a little sweaty, but the view is worth it.
Not to be missed. It is one of the best known landmarks and one of the most published images of Bangkok. We loved every bit of this place, not to be missed.

Wat arun on the river banks. You will have to take a boat to cross the river in order to reach the wat. Boat charges 8 bahts per person, it's a 5-10 min ride to cross to the other side. It's a local speed boat and tickets can be obtained once you get there, there will be a small queue.Part of the temple is still under renovation. King Rama's statue in the old capital is captivating.Very scenic place for photography. The old capital is a must watch.Thanks,Shyam
Beautiful amazing Wat Arun. definitely a must see nice beautiful reflects history in Bangkok is a dream monument come true I highly recommend to visit this place in your visit
Amazing view of sunset. Very near to wat pho and grand palace. Take ferry for 3 bhats to cross river and visit Wat Arun. Scenic and peaceful.

Absolutely worth crossing the river - don't use tourist ferries. It was a pity that the top of the main tower was hidden by scaffolding. But there was plenty left to admire. The whole site breaths harmony, colours and peace. The guardians of the temple really impress. A must see in Bangkok! When you cross the river, don't take the tourist ferries. The normal ferry (CPX) is much cheeper, about ten times cheeper in fact (3 bath). You'll find it at the end of Thai Wang Alley (Maha Rat Road) after you entered a sort of gallery-market with shops.

Simple all just the same.. I just think its all the same. No amazing feeling or what. But entrance is cheap though. But beware private boat they will charge you 3000 baht. For the river ride to one small floating market. We regret it super. We just found out that you can ride at the tourist public boat you just pay 50 baht each.

Worth the time to get there. A lot of people see this from the boat and I think most don't make the trip over, as you need to catch a different boat. It worth the effort though. A unique temple for Bkk. Fair warning, it's under construction at the moment. Not sure when it will finished.

Under construction. I was very excited about this temple. But it is currently surrounded by scaffolding and you can't climb the stairs to the top like you used to be able to. It's still worth it I guess but the scaffolding takes the magic away.The ferry over to it is only 3 bhat and entrance fee was only 100 so not too bad.

visit during renovation. nothing nice to see.. title says it all. by the time of visit, the main temple was under renovation. however since already got there might visit also.
it is free to strolling around however to step into the main temple need to pay. overall complex is good. better choose late evening for more friendly weather.

Renovations ongoing but still fantastic temple. I've seen the temple many time as I pass along the river but hadn't had time to stop and explore. I finally went and I'm very glad I did. There were ongoing renovations but the scaffolding didn't take away too much from grandeur of the temples. Well worth it to spend 3 baht to get across the river and check it out.

Under construction, but still gorgeous. As of August 2016, much of the temple is under scaffolding, which means that you have limited access to the upper parts of the temple, and your photos won't be quite so lovely. However, it's still definitely worth a visit, as it looks totally different from the other wats in Thailand.

Beautiful. Beautiful temple and structures with some maintenance construction works going on but much better than the Grand Palace.Lots of room to walk around, beautiful grassy setting.Took the river tour to get to the temple which was nice.
nice place. Wat Arun temple is the oldest interesting and beautiful temples and ancient Buddhas.So beautiful place and good place for travel in bangkok
Wat Arun . Beautiful place nice view river side Good for photographer And who love Thai culture Easy to get there One of the best place in BKK

wait till construction is complete. the temple is undergoing extensive renovation and is covered by scaffolding. Consider timing your visit when it is complete. Notwithstanding the construction, it is lovely lit up at night from accross or on the river.
Good art work. Ferry service available from the tha tien to wat arun for just 3 bahts. It would have been better if we had visited this place after few weeks. Renovation is happening in full swing.

The only Temple to see twice...or 10 times.... The Temple of Dawn is the coolest temple to visit..! You don't just walk around it...you climb it too! At least part way up. The stairs are about 40* angle, great view over river. At night one of the highlights you see from the dinner cruises leaving River City shopping complex. Beautifully lit in evening. Its the only temple I've been to more than twice in Thailand. I live here, so a temple's a temple, except for Wat Arun.......great tiles all over it!n.

Thailand trip 2015. Be careful on your way to this temple. You will be stopped and asked where are you going. Once you mention this temple the person will tell you that it is closed but that they can take you on a tuk-tuk ride and bring you back once its open. Do not fall for this scam. Unfortunately during my visit the Temple was under construction but still enjoyed the visit.
Amazing work of art. The ceramic finish of this template is one of a kind and painstakingly beautiful! Best time to see this is at dawn or sunset.
Thai culture. Beautiful temple with lots to see. It took us nearly 2 hours to visit and enjoy this place. Highly recommended to all tourists.

Close to reach. If you spend the night in Bangkok, this maybe a must visited place as. It's a beautiful place actually but when I visited it, it still has the restoration. But that didn't reduce the beauty at all. Wish to come here again. Oh and you can buy Bangkok souvenir here.

Beautiful temple in Bangkok. It is a shame that it was cloudy; as it seems that sunrise and sunset from this temple is an experience!! Very impressive and beautiful even under refurbishing... It is one of the places you must visit in Bangkok

Enjoyable.. We visited one morning whilst there was an ordination for monks going on. Out of respect we were not allowed to go into the temple but it was lovely to see the temple being used for what it was intended rather than just as a tourist attraction. Teens enjoyed seeing the monks go in and come out having been ordained to put their saffron robes on. Many older monks were meditating and praying.

Still on restoration. When I got there, they are doing renovation so i couldnt go up. The temple itself is very good, if you wanted to take picture like the postcard, dont cross the river, just find a good cafe / coffee shop that have clear view of the temple at sunset
Wonderful. You should visit that temple at a first place when you arrivd to THailand. It is full of temples and need time to visit.
Beautiful site. One of the best views of this beautiful temple can be had by sitting across the river at at one of the bars and watching the sunset with a refreshing beverage in hand

Beautiful temple at day/night. Wat Arun is a huge temple complex and definitely worth a visit. It is beautiful during day and night. I would recommend going close to sunset because everything gets golden touch and your pictures will look amazing.You are probably coming from the city centre so I would recommend taking the ferry across the Chao Phraya River. It is a nice ride and very cheap.Unfortunately it is still undergoing some restoration.
Majestic Wat Arun. Perfect at any time of day and being gloriously restored with intricate detail. The scaffolding didn't detract!

Beautiful temple.. The view of Wat Arun is mesmerizing.Even if you visit this temple in evening this looks stunning because of the lighting they have done.It can be easily accessed via the river cruise.
Wat Arun. You need to take ferry to cross the river from Grand Place, ferry is damn cheap just 3 Baht, nice architecture of temple

Beautiful temple (but currently covered in scaffold). A short trip across the river from Wat pho (3baht on the ferry each way). It is currently undergoing refurbishment and is covered in scaffolding. This prevents you from climbing the stairs all the way to the top. You can go up a short distance and look out over the river. The stairs are pretty steep, not sure what it would be like coming all the way down from the top. The ceramics on this temple are simply amazing and beautiful. The grounds are very well maintained, and there is the usual market stalls to buy anything you might, or might not, need, including drinks and icecream. Would love to have seen it without the scaffolding, so I might be back. To the people who advise you not to go over, but to admire it from the other side: you are doing a dis-service. You cannot admire the beauty of the building from that far away. Get off your butt and go over there! I agree with another comment about the 150baht tourist ticket, it's not worth it. Just pay for individual trips, unless you intend to visit enough places in one day to make it worthwhile.

Under Construction. I'm not sure if it's under construction in the rainy season but it was when we stopped by. That day it was closed to the public and you couldn't really make pictures because of the scaffolding. Recomend coming here in the good time of the year.

Under wraps. We crossed the river to take a look at this temple from the Wat Pho side. The crossing was interesting...the temple, not. It is being refurbished so there is not much to see with all the scaffolding. You will not be able to climb it either. Nonetheless, you can still see the ceramic tiles/cladding around the temple.

Kind of templed out. This was the fourth of five temples in one day so we were kind of tired on this one. Still, it was worth it. We got to see the temple monks at lunch. Lunch was being prepared by a family in honor of a deceased family member. Nice custom. As a bonus, for $200 baht you can dress in old style outfit for photo purposes. Worth it. If only for the blackmail potential.

The most romantic wat. It is situated on the other side of the Chau praya river, so you have to cross it with a ferry, which costs 3 tbh each way.The wat is currently under reconstruction. But it still has it charm. It is wonderfully decorated with ceramic tiles, so it is very colorful.

Commercialised Temples. Temple up keep is good and its must go on a visit to Bangkok. It was under construction when we visited the temple.What I found really bad is that most of the places of interest in Bangkok has an entry fee. Even if you have to use washrooms. I understand need to have entry fee for monuments but then they can afford to have free washrooms.

Best from the other side. It is a nice basic temple... our advice is not to visit it but to look for the nice coffee shops at the other side of the river and enjoy the sunset with a nice Ice Latte and the views of this temple. You will be tired of temples in Thailand, enjoy the views after 18:00 from the other side ;)
awesome and peaceful. one of the prettiest wat in Bangkok... beatiful , scenic and peaceful.. Enjoyed the boat ride to Wat arun ......
Great view of the river. There is only one tower, but once you climb up the view will amaze you, bring the camera with to get some great shots. The stairs are stiff, so please be careful.

Probably cool..... Was excited to see this place, but it was undergoing some facelift procedures while we were there. Good on them for keeping it fresh, but kinda sucked for me.
Beward they charge you an extra fee if you come off a boat. Rude.

An oasis of peace in the middle of kaos. If you wish to take a break from Bangkok confusion, please enter this temple (20 THB) and enjoy a relaxing walking in the monastery, visit the lovely temple, meet the friendly monks for meditation, visit the school and the little cozy mini village around the area. No hurry you are in a real Buddhist place.Few tips: you need the ferry to cross the river but the pier on the other side is really crowded, then or you arrive with a private boat from another pier or simply take the ferry from the pier before that one everybody use. This pier is in front of another nice temple (I don't know the name) and it is 5 m walking from your final destination.If you like strange curious pictures don't miss the photo in traditional Thai costumes just after the entrance of the temple. 100THB for person and lol...

Really cool!. This was a really Beautiful attraction. Coming from Siam Square you need to take a tuk tuk to the river and from there take a very short ferry ride over to the temple. There is a small and beautifully located cafeteria below the temple. Perfect spot for a coffee. The scenery is Amazing and this is surely a "must do" when in Bangkok.
Spectacular Temple. The Temple of Dawn looks spectacular during the day and specially during late evening or night, amazing view and peaceful and calm feel, positive vibes.

Cheap Price. Shopping with cheap price. I can use Indonesia Rupiah here. Most seller can speak Bahasa (not much, just enough). Artistic temple. I interested in some shops in front of the port. Cheap enough, many variant. I prefer to shopping here for some snacks.
Scaffolding. In its glory, this is superb. But right now (see date) it's a mess of scaffolding. Has to be done, but kinda sad if you haven't seen it at its best.
Place for Peace. Must visit if you are going to Bangkok. If you want to know about their temple architecture, and Thai peoples Buddhist attachment.

Bangkok and Thailand in one nutshell. Close to the large central river the ancient temple is placed. Without gold, but with intresting figures you can climb even to the top and view Bangkok. Here you vire the town from the other side and having the history right beside you.

Beautiful temple even though under construction. The Chinese porcelain covering this temple is amazing, it's fun to take the ferry from central Bangkok to arrive here. While this temple is less well maintained than its more grand neighbor across the river, it is well worth the visit.

BEAUTIFUL. I appreciated it a lot once I was close to it, because from the other side of the river, during the daytime, it is not as impressive as when you are inside.There is a main high tower and four minor ones decorated with ceramic tiles and fragments of multi colored porcelain. A monk also blessed us and put a white bracelet on us!There were construction works on July 11th.

Under construction, but still cool!. Although I've already been at this temple, I couldn't help going back there during this trip. It's just so intricate, and so beautiful to look at! The grounds are so well-kept, everything is well-organized, there are little shops where you can buy ice cream and snacks just outside, everything is clean, etc. The temple itself was undergoing renovation, so I wasn't able to climb the steps like I did last time, but I had a great time walking around and looking at all those beautiful architectural details. Highly recommend a visit! Oh, but don't get the hop on- hop off ticket; it doesn't seem to be worth it. the hop on/off ticket costs 150 baht, and the individual trip is 40 baht. It takes QUITE some time to walk around all these venues, and you just don't take enough rides in the boat to justify the cost or make any savings. Just pay for the individual rides.

Wonderful experience. Less busy than the temples on the other side of the river as harder to access. Try to visit in the morning when crowds are at their minimum. We visited one of the temples to the side and received a blessing from a monk, very special experience and highly recommended. At the time of writing in August 2016 there are some repair works ongoing, but still a very special visit.

Must See if you went to Ayuthaya. This is Bangkok's first temple before everything moved across the river. The style is the same as Ayuthaya but here you have all the plaster maintained. This is what Ayuthaya would have looked like.You won't spend more than 30 minutes here.
Under construction. Worth a trip to check it out, when they are done!I have been when it was not being worked onOnly takes about an hour to visit!

Very pretty temple best approached from the river. It is under construction but it is a very pretty temple. It is best approached from the river. You can walk around the complex and get up close to the spire. This is a nice example of using porcelain as the decorative surface of structures. Its basic white color gives it a pearly shine in the morning sun, probably where the temple of dawn name comes from.

Peaceful and tranquil. Just by taking the 10 baht ferry ride across the river it is a different world from Wat Pho and Grand Palace crowds. Could relax and enjoy the spiritual ambience of the temples.

Scaffolding!. Apparently an amazing temple but is covered with scaffolding at the moment. Ignore the Tutor tut drivers who want to take you there as sadly you can't get near it. View from the river instead of a special journey!

Currently under renovation but worth it. This was my second visit to Wat Arun. Though a little disappointed that it was under renovation, I enjoyed my visit. There werr quite a bit of things happening such ad monks blessing etc. Worth a visit.

Covered with scaffolding. The main structure was covered with scaffolding so we did not see the views that everyone was raving about in the previous comments. I don't think it is worth the entry fee if the scaffolding is still there, as you can only climb up to half way up the structure. They have a nice small garden outside the temple, and it's accessible to everyone. We took less than 30 minutes to go around this temple, I'm not sure it was worth the hassle of crossing the river, again only because it was under renovation and the top parts of the temple was not accessible.
I loved. I love temples so much and my husband know about this. We go this place whit bike tour. That's was fan. I like tai people and Coulthard.

Under construction. We visited it in the morning. It was crowded but we enjoyed it. Very nice temple but it was under construction and we couldn't go to the top. We'll have to visit again!
The best way to get there is by boat, a 100 bhat per person from Saphan Taksin BTS station.

Amazing..Must See!!. Any visitors to Thailand should visit this site. A beautiful Theravada Buddhist temple that we visited as part of a river trip in a longboat. Well worth seeing..highly recommended.

Don’t wear sandals. You will be very tempted to wear sandals during your excursion in Bangkok. Do so, but bring a pair of tennis shoes when you visit Wat Arun. There is a lot of very steep climbing up to the top of the pyramid structure. It looks steep and it is, so hold on tight. I do not recommend this climb unless you are in very good health. My wife was feeling very shaky after the climb and descent (which is actually worse) but she doesn’t have great coordination. The views of the river at the top are amazing and well worth it if you can handle it.

Wat Arun under reconstruction. Nice place, but recently (and already for a while) it is under renovation. Knowing the history it's important, otherwise it's just one more temple you can visit in Thailand.
Awesome architecture marvel. Construction and restoration was on when we visited the temple but nevertheless it was breathtaking..
Temple of dawn. On west bank of the river, take the train to saphan taksin to get a ferry ticket. Very stunning temple. It's currently under renovations, so you can't climb it, but worth the visit!

Very hard to climb :). It is a very good place to visit in terms of history and architect, the only downside is that it is very hard to go up to the top as the stairs are very straight and not inclined. Also for women, advice is not to climb if wearing short skirts.

Renovating but still authentic!. They are doing renovation for more than 1 year now so dont expect what you probably saw on the pictures.That being said, the temple and his garden are truly beautiful! There is a lot of small "rites" that you can do with a small donation (if you want to). The main temple is really amazing because its rare to see the old architecture (like Ayutthaya) in the center of Bangkok!Enjoy it! Btw there is couple temples around this area so try to arrange a little tour with a taxi or tuk tuk, you will save some money!

Temple with a great view and magnificent architecture. Wat Arun is a Buddhist Temple with a great view and magnificent architecture .It is said that first rays of sun falls in this temple and hence its a special temple . lot of positive energy around this place !
What a cool place!. We saw so many places on our trip to Thailand but this one was particularly cool. I found it interesting that it was colored differently then the rest.

Daytime viewing. I viewed this temple during the daytime but it was still a marvel to look at. Although it was undergoing some scaffolding and construction work it was still worth a look.
It can be viewed from the long boat tours on the water that head towards the Grand Palace.
Wow..... Just wow! . Great! Awe inspiring! Detail......precision, the whole experience was amazing! We arrived by boat along the river and find Bangkok a crazy place
Unique Temple in BKK. Recommended must visit and will visit again. Feel so relax and peaceful after visited many attraction.

So cool place and easy acces. . My favourite temple is wat arun in bangkok. The location is cental just next of river. And you can use boat which is nearly 4 baht per person. The entrance fee is also ok. But you should not wear short shirt or skirt. Otherwise you should rent from entrance of temple. You can have a drink cold beer opposite of wat arun with an amazing view at the end of your visit..

Beautiful!. My first temple to be seen in Bangkok! Ancient and full of culture and history - some of it is under renovation,but there is plenty you can see. You can go right into the temple and experience the culture and see the people taking part in prayer. Something to see for sure.
excelent. just a amazing construction in the heart of bangkok, one of the top five places you must go in bkk for shure

Beautiful and unique temple. The climb up to the stupa /pagoda was a challenge for people with big feet. It's really a steep walk. Entrance fee is 100 baht for tourist and we had a great walk within the premises. Nice to come around evening for the sunset.

Spectacular Must Visit whilst in Pattaya. An awe inspiring Temple built on the sea visited by Queen Elizabeth the II. This is a half a day tour and well worth the visit. Apart from the temple itself which can take about 1-2 hours to walk around inside, there are elephants, Thai dancing, Thai sword-fighting and the usual food and souvenir shops.

Currently closed for renovation. This is definitely my favorite of all temples in Bangkok. I love looking around the city from top of this temple - mornings and evenings are particularly beautiful! If you want to visit just a couple of temples, I would suggest this and Wat Pho, so that you can check off the temples from the list of touristy stuff you can do in Bangkok. To reach there, you can take a ferry. Its a very short boat ride from Wat Pho.However, it is currently closed for renovation so check before heading out to the temple.

Temple of the Dawn. As a photographer this Temple is fantastic as its different to most we see around BKK , with its main stupa in the middle surrounded by several other minarettes shrines all in white makes the Wat a magical place. Its beauty of the coloured tile in lays and intricate workmanship, is just amazing. I have been here many times and was a shame this time the main part of the Wat was being repaired so was covered in Bamboo and workers (also interesting shots) try throw money in Buddahs bowl for good luck...Its a great place located on the river so you can see enormous fish there...GO

Ancient Beautiful Temple. I love Buddhist temples. This is definitely one of the best. The architecture is amazing. Take the boat ride, and visit this temple along with Wat Pho, and Grand Palace. This was the best part of my BK trip.
Interesting . A wonderful place of serenity and culture. Tge tree was a fair bit of construction of the main wat but stil a sight to behold.

Some structures are under renovation but most are not.. Excellent, and well worth the visit. Although some structures are under renovation, the majority are not so you can still get some outstanding photos and videos if you want. A lot of history here, and the views are stunning.

The best way to get to 1.Wat Arun(Dawn)2.Wat Pho( Reclining Buddha)and 3.The Grand Palace. From Sukhumvit area,get a cab to Tha Thein Pier(8)...board the river ferry to Wat Arun.Tour Wat Arun n board ferry back to Wat Pho.Tour Wat pho n then proceed to the Grand Palace.the only expensive entrance fee is 500 baht to the G Palace but the tour ticket includes other places of interest around Bangkok.the taxi fare there is 180 bahtsfor pax 4 and total entrance is 650 bahts and the ferry boat is negligible which I think is 30 bahts each crossing.on the return trip to Terminal 21 we went by Tut Tuk....150 bahts for pax 4.Going by BTS from Asoke or Nana will take you 40 minutes.By cab ,it is only 20 mins depending on the traffic.Try it and give me a feedback.
Amazing. The temple itself is interesting especially with the gardens outside. We feel the asian culture in each part of it. I totally recommend it.
Under renovation. Suggest u skip this place. Its under renovation..major..cannot go all the way to the top. This was end July 2016. No indication when it will be completed.

Nice, but under renovation. This is a nice temple, but we wanted to go up but no go. It is under renovation so there isn't much to see at the moment.So until the renovations are done there isn't much point in going.
Beautiful . One of the highlights of our trip to Bangkok, a beautiful temple where people seem to live, work and conduct business within. You will take some memorable photos here!

Stunning. Something about this Wat intrigued our imaginations, it was really stunning and definitely something that we enjoyed going to see.. so much culture and so many things to learn about this fascinating part of Thai history
Better to see from river. The temple is under construction at the moment so make sure you check before going as we have to come back from outside

An absolute must do- and it is clean now!. We went here about 10 years ago and were actually disappointed. It was dirty and not much to look at despite the nice view from it and onto it during sunset. So, we did not expect much but wanted to "tick it off" on our day tour with a boat. Are we glad we have done this! It has been and still is being renovated and it looks marvellous! It takes you about 3 hours to fully appreciate it though, but most boat tours only allow for 30 minutes. you still get the idea and can be considered enough, especially when it is very hot, but if you have the chance to stay longer, do so!

beautuful. Wat Arun is the main attraction among the tourist attractions of the Bangkok city. You can get down from the sky train, walk a little and catch one of those tourist boats. From the top of the temple you can see most of the city of Bangkok. During night the lights make it more beautiful

Currently under restoration works. One of the most important sights in the city, amazing views over the River and Royal Palace Complex. Women shouldn't show their shoulders (it must be a strange fixation in Thailand with the shoulders of women). Currently under renovation works but is still worth visiting it.

Under constuction. The whole temple was under massive construction when we visited it last week. Do research before you go. I was a bit disappointed because it wasn't mentioned anywhere that the place was under construction.

Under re-construction. Since its being rebuilt and pretty unattractive encased in rebar from the river boat view it's not too crowded. Still worthy of a look and was able to capture some great photos of the lower intact sections.

Completely different than the other temples. The architecture of this temple is different and more simplistic than the other temples in Bangkok. It has a true ancient feel to it and makes this one very unique. We crossed the river by boat witch gave it an extra touch of special to it. Great sightseeing.

Exotic art. We have across the river to go to this temple. Once you arrive, you will find such an exotic art in front of your eyes. Every corner was a nice spot to take picture. And as a woman, I found another paradise inside......shopping arcade with a reasonable price since they're controled by the goverment. Unfortunately we can not reach all part of the temple as they had renovated in some area.
Wat Arun is very unique. Did you know that it is decorated with dutch china? The china broke and the king decided to decorate the temple. It's so beautiful close by and far away and by nighttime too.

Dawn at Sunset. Although Wat Arun ( temple of dawn) is a spectacular scene as the sun rises over Bangkok and the Chao Phraya river, it is also a beautiful site to behold at sunset and just after darkness falls. At night it is delicately lit up with tasteful arrays. It's best viewed from the deck of one of many boats which ply the river at night offering trips to visitors and residents alike

sophisticated. the boat ride is a must when visiting this temple. it's part of the beauty. the details of the temple is AMAZING!! It's just so sad when I came, the temple is (still) under renovation :(and the plus point is there's cheap market on there! they have fix price, but it quite cheap compared to the other shops. for Indonesian, the seller can speak Bahasa well, and you can use Rupiah here. so you can keep your bath to shop in the other places :Ddefinitely coming back!! ^^

A majestic view.. It was quite a tall temple despite not being able to climb up due to their renovation works. Would love to visit there again for another chance to have the view that many have said is nice about it.

Surpisingly quiet- worth it even with scaffolding. Wat Arun seems to be under extensive renovation but after waiting a few years of living here we decided to finally visit despite the scaffolding that can be seen and were pleasantly surprised. Although the river was busy, the temple was quite quiet (11am Sunday morning) and once up close it is a very relaxing place to visit. The decoration is very intricate and up close it is understandable why it is a long project! Fully recommended amongst the temple and tourist visits. Small coffee shop at the entrance can be good on a hot or rainy day and usual conservative clothing guidelines apply. Ferry stop is Tha Tien to change boats.

It is worth it!. You can do two temples in one crossing of the river if you cross in the pier near the Palace and after visiting the temple across you take a Tuk Tuk that took us to the Wat Arun for 50 bat. Both temples are worth it.

Fantastic experience, but a bit of a trek from central Bangkok. We visited this place right after going to the Grand Palace. It's a bit of a trek (30 min cab ride about), so I'd dedicate a good half-day to a day if you plan to temple hop. Personally, I'm not a fan of big crowds and super touristy areas, which is the feel of the Grand Palace. Wat Arun is great because it's a little more low key and less crowded, so it feels quite peaceful visiting there. I would definitely opt for taking a cab rather than taking a tuk-tuk, who charge outrageous fees and tried aggressively to persuade us to take an expensive boat across the river.

Great half day getaway in Bangkok.
