Now for those that don’t know or have never been, its an exceptional half day out with many sites to take in, we were staying in a hotel near Soi Cowboy so from the Asoke BTS in front of Terminal 21 Shopping Mall, we boarded the sky train and got off at Siam. The total one way trip to our last destination being Saphan Taksin was 42 baht a head although they have day passes for unlimited rides. At Siam we went down a level and got onto another sky train to get to Saphan Taksin, this is all a little confusing, if you don’t look at the train line maps on the walls, you could end up getting on the wrong train or going the wrong direction, which we did on the return leg. Once at Saphan Taksin, it’s a 50 metre walk to the Pier, which is also Pier No.1 , our intended destination was Tha Tien Pier No.8 but the girl on the ferry gave quite a bit of info before every stop.The one way trip cost 40 baht a head but you could get a full day unlimited pass for 150 baht, if you wanted to stop off and see other attractions such as King’s Palace, Chinatown, Floating Market, Flower Market, Wat Pho (Reclining Budha), River City Mall and many other stops. For Wat Arun, when you get off at Pier No.8, you just go next door and hop on another boat for 3 baht which takes you across the river and you’re there. We also wanted to climb up the Wat for its exceptional view which Ive done before but it was a first for the miss's, unfortunately it was closed for renovations and I was quite annoyed that the farang (westerner) had to pay 50 baht entry but nobody advised me that renovations were taking place,all in all, a great day out, the river ride and the breeze a welcoming change.

Must see when in Bangkok. This is one of the best places to visit in Bangkok. We went there after very intensive sightseeing of other historical places, in the evening. Hearing the chants of Buddha monks, and watching the sunset from the temple grounds was quite an experience for us. Highly recommended!

Cheap market. Near a temple .. There are market, they gave cheaper price souvenir than the other market at bangkok. The seller can speak bahasa, because i came from indonesia so easy for me to hv a negoitation price. Rent for the boat is 2500 bath for 7 person add 30 bath for boat parking

Interesting but hot!!!. It was under renovation so there were scaffolding around the structures. It was also extremely hot and humid when we were there so we did not really feel like climbing up. Go when the weather is cooler - maybe early morning or late evenings. The journey there along the river was nice.
Sightseeing, religious . Here you will find other different kinds of budha. Depending on your preference and beliefs people pray there for specific days and come to request for thier ambitions.
Renovating. We visited in July 2016. The temple is still renovating and hence couldn't have a chance to see the full attraction. Need to take the cross river boat from Tha Tien Pier N8 to Wat Arun.

Pleasant experience to visit this quiet place and should visit early morning. If you visit this temple in the morning you will be surprised. It was really worth to get up early in the morning. You should sit and pray and do meditation. Visit it in the morning so it wont be crowded
Under Rennovation. The temple was good and could have been a good place for sunset. It was under Renovation so did not spend much time there.
Divine!. You can combine visit to Wat Arun with the reclining Buddha. It's beautiful and amazing. Even more beautiful in the night.

Landmark in Bangkok, it is for those who love architecture. It was under renovation when we visited in May. Saw this from across the river, so did not even cross the river. Those who love architecture, might love the place. Not sure about others. Seems it looks beautiful when all lit up in the evening, but we did not see this. Perhaps due to the renovation work.
Great, Smaller Temple. It's not one as big as the Grand Palace or Wat Pho but still very cool! It's also a nice ferry ride to get across the river

Beautiful . Amazing and unique place.Unfortunately it was under construction but it does worth visiting it if you're in Bangkok. Take the blue line to si lom, then the boat from there to another sea station( I think the fourth one) and then another boat to cross the river. The entrance costs 100 or 50 baht. It's really cheap (you won't pay more than 5€ for all those!)

This is a masterpiece!. Even if you been in Thailand many times and don't think of that country as of a hub of fine arts like Italy, for example, you are probably right, but it turns out that you had no time to dig deep.  In past it was beautiful, and Thai people made significant efforts to conserve the best artifacts of past. Give it a try, seriously! I was deeply impressed by ingenious and skillfull appearance of Wat Arun, although it's famous steepest staircase is closed for renovation till 2018 ! Most people visit this place solely to make a crazy selfie in the top of this temple and get disappointed when they realize, that steep staircase is closed.But let's just take a closer look and you will find out, that it's very magnificient : just imagine ( and take a look at the attached photos ) -- it's white walls are covered with numerous plates, which were made from Chinese porcelain! And at the top of this Wat there are gem stones, embedded in handrails! Everything look very fresh like if the time have no power here and the temple was built yesterday.Pay special attention to little stone figures, which are put along the perimeter of the wall. They are very expressive and unique ( their faces and poses never repeat and have deep symbolical meaning ).Also internal garden is in very good condition and it worth to have a little walk, if you like.Pay special attention to the fact, that it's not simple to get an express boat back to Central pier from here, you better ask local policemans for help or just pay 15THB and use regular boat, which will make a couple of stops along the way ( but to me it's still reasonably fast ) I traveled alone using BTS from Central world and express boat from Central Pier and paid funny 40 THB for a boat. Be careful! Locals are extremely misleading everywhere and you can obtain ticket for 100THB and more ( even 800 ) and in fact be a victim of local microbusiness. If you wanted to travel in 'official' ( i.e. municipal ) express boat from the Central Pier, then look for blue counter with 'Express boat' plate and expect to pay 40 THB there. When in boat listen carefully and when they will announce, that the boat is approaching to N8 -- leave here and take a boat to the opposite side of a river ( another 3 THB ).

beautiful temple. A must visit place. the view from above over the river at sunset is wonderful. best place for most beautiful sunset over the river. Also light up at night. view from both side are superb. try to book a dinner along the river with a view of the temple. So romantic and peaceful.
Under renovation. The main tower is currently under renovation and is in a scaffolding. Still cool to see...especially the bottom portions...but just know there is scaffolding.

Beautiful complex of tempels. To get to the temple you have to cross the river by the boat it costs 3bath.
Great idea is to take around the temples and after that have a chill in the shadow in one of this.

Waste of time and hmoney. Under renovation as on 27/06/2016. Complete waste of time and money (50 BHT) per adult. During renovation the top part was inaccessible so couldnt see the place. Visit only if you love architecture, best to drop if you are short of time.

Beautiful place but under construction. Absolutely beautiful place, especially if you go at sunset and take a boat across the river. The view from the river as the setting sun hits the temple is stunning.
Spent an hour or so walking around taking in all the history.
If you go here remember to dress appropriately.
Only downside is its under construction at the moment.

Great temple to visit on clear days. Wat Arun is a very big and beautiful temple. it was under reconstruction when i visited so many things inside were not accessible but its a marvellous place to see. the ticket is 50 baht, and the place can be reached from wat pso with a across the river boat ferry service for 5 baht. a great place to see

Nice short visit. Best time to visit is in the morning. The weather is too warm. Always hydrate yourself and bring some extra clothes and washcloth to keep you cool with your water. The temples are being maintained. Short stay less than one hour.

Beautiful temple right on the river. A must see temple in the city of temples!
A short but quaint boat trip across the Chao Phraya from the jetty.
Be daring and climb to the top!

nice temple. The temple has nice design but during the time I visited it with my friend renovation is on going so the highest temple isn't good to take picture. But still this temple is a must see while in bangkok.

Scaffolding (June 2016). Such a shame that the whole temple was buried under scaffolding during our visit. Typical! Unfortunately maintenance has to be done so can't really complain but I was disappointed as photography is my thing.
Oh well, will have to go back one day!
Beautiful and intricate temple (as you would expect) so worth a trip up the river to visit.

You only can see outside. This place takes not much time to visit, just around 30 min. If you are woman you need to cover your legs and sholders. But if you suddenly came in shorts local workers will lend you clothes to cover your legs and sholders.After visiting temple, you can sweem on boat to the other side of the river for 3 baht. From there you can take another boat just to travel around city by river. It is not tour, its public transportation which cost you only 5 baht for a ride. Cool!
Nothing to see. Restruction on progress. Nothing particular to see. Do not exist inside. You can see it by the river is the same.

Must Visit When Arriving Bangkok. "Temple of Dawn" or "Wat Arun" is printed behind the postcard representing the beautifulness of Bangkok. Millioms of travellers would not like to miss when they visited Bangkok each year. The main highlight of Wat Arun is undoubtedly the grand pagoda, or prang in Thai. Influenced by Khmer-style pagoda, the 67-meter-tall pagoda is made of cement covered by million pieces of China porcelains. It is surrounded by four smaller pagodas.Wat Arun is also involved in the Royal Barge Procession as the temple is where the king would travel by river to deliver new robes to the monks at the end of the Buddhist Lent period.Opening hours: Daily, 8.30 am. to 5.00 pm.Admission: 50 Baht
Under renovation. can't really be disappointed by renovations because you want to see stuff maintained. Really cool site.

Beautiful temple. This is an iconic temple by the river and a very beautiful one. Even though it was under renovation when we visited, it did not stop us from enjoying the location, taking in the scenery and exploring the rest of the temple grounds. Must do activity!

Worth a visit - presently being renovated on main stupa but is not an issue. We crossed the river for 3 bhat from the Grand Palace - a good photo opportunity up and down the river.Wat Arun is different in style again - more Cambodian like Angkor Wat - but ceramic finish!Nice and tranquil and a good end to a day of sight seeing

A Must See. It is one of the oldest temples in the area. If you have the energy and your not afraid of heights, you can climb the temple 2\3 the way to the top. It's a VERY steep climb with nonstandard stairs.

Beautiful Temple.... Visited Wat Arun using water transportation (motor boat). On the way to the temple, we passed many interesting place, there is a place that we can feed the river fish, Thai people believe there are sacred fish and not allowed to be fished, killed or eat. And also we saw a place that kept Royal Boat. Anyway Wat Arun is a beautiful temple, decorated with millions pieces of ceramics. I love Thailand !! Enjoy !!

Beautifully architectured . This place is one of the most visited tourist attraction if you are visiting bangkok. The architecture of this temple is just beautiful and one may find this place too peaceful to be

Different with a good location. What I liked about this temple, it his location, beside the river, with a little park next to it. The temple isn't very common and very beautiful. Unfortunately I saw it in rebuilding, but it don't change the beauty of the temple.
Beautiful Temple. Despite the temple under restoration one can see that the temple is an architectural marvel. The best way to reach Wat Arun is by ferry, its cheap and fast.

Magnificent grounds but a closed Wat. The gold, the glass, they amazing construction was absolutely a must-see, however the Wat is undergoing restoration so suck it up and get over that! You will not see anything else like the rest of it all. Enjoy!

Lots of construction work. Couldn't really go in as there was loads of construction work. If you don't want to walk around, the boat is only 3 baht from near Wat Pho from Tha Tiem. Cool buildings but much like other temples too. I think night time views are better, particularly from the river.
Obligatory to see if in Bangkok. You will climb those difficult stairs , and when your up ....the view it's amazing , you can see a long way on the river and also a nice view over the Bangkok.

Looks great from distance but was under renovation in March and April 2016. Great mythological stories of Wat Pho and Wat Arun. Very interesting to see the similarities in the some indian mythology and thai mythology. Great architecture of the place. Would have loved to see the views from the top but the place was closed for renovation.
Restoration work. Very disappointed to find that the temple is undergoing restoration at the moment so cannot be climbed! Nice to walk around but I'm sure climbing it is the main attraction really.

A very grounding experience. We visit here with a thai friend so the assistance with the lingo helped though not needed. You will always get people trying to get a dollar out of you though not here. Take plenty of water with you. Be careful of the steps to the temple, they are very worn and steep you must climb to the top if you go.

Impressive spire and riverside views. Went in July 2016 - unfortunately, the stairs to and the top level of the temple was closed for renovation, but the 1st tier was open for a walkabout. The meticulous level of detail is something to look out for. Well kept temple grounds/gardens, and easily accessible from Wat Pho by following the tourist trail southwest to the river where you can cross on a barge for 3 baht
under construction/repair. the main temple is under construction, didn't get to see much. the rest of the sites are great for photos

Must see if you are visiting Bangkok. By no means the busiest temple/tourist destination in Bangkok but we thought it was impressive without trying to be. Okay so there is a huge Reclining Buddha! but the nice parts of this temple are grounds: the waterfalls and trees and open spaces. We liked the lack of tourists!
My favorite Temple in Bangkok. A beautiful Khmer temple. Visit it and also pass it on the river and also see it at night when it looks spectacular.
Must visit!. This palace is symbol building like the others too. Near to other attraction temples so you should walk. Definetly worth to visit.At the evening, you can amazing photos tht place's.

beautiful sight but under renovation again. this is my first time going to wat arun after many trips to bangkok, but found out that it is under renovation when arrived. Tourists can still visit it and the neighbouring sites, but unable to climb up the pagoda.

Temple Under construction. This temple has a nice architecture but they did not allow us to go inside the temple and it was also under construction when i visited. it looks amazing in the night light. Not worth paying 50Bhat and going in as they did not even allow visitor inside the temple. The temple is best when viewed from far.

Interesting. Worthwhile. Easy to access via Chao Phra. Caught the public boats on the river to access Wat Arun. So easy to use. 3 baht to cross river. The Wat is under repair but close up you realise how tall it is. Shopping at the stalls for usual suspects was surprisingly cheaper than central Bangkok.
Nothing Much To see. When we visited the temple in first week of July 2016, the temple was under renovation , so there was nothing much to see from the temple.

Wat Arun. Wat Arun is different from what we see in the night-photo. Day view is totally different. It is a large structure with a deep archeological flavour. I climbed to the last stair. The stairs are steeper as you go up. It becomes scary/ dangerous at one stage as it becomes very steep. It is a must-see attraction of Bangkok.Be careful: Wat Arun is beside a river. When we arrived on the the opposite side of the river the boat-men was asking very high price to cross the river. Don't worry, just try to find ferry port. It costs around only 2 Bahts to cross the river.

Good temple. This temple is one of the most famous in Bangkok. I'd say it is not as fascinating as The Reclining Buddha, nor as grand as the Emerald Buddha, but it has it's fair share of qualities to make it a distinctly different experience. It is located across the river from other famous historical landmark so you need to take a ferry there (very cheap). Definitely visit this place. One of the essentials.

Peace and respectful. It is old temple. If you want to climb up to the top, should be careful. I recommend teenager to go up not old people. On the top, you will see a beautiful view of Joapraya river.

Boat ride and visit this place. If you are in BKK, please take a boat ride, and make sure that you visit all these temples and places as per your wish. No need to take any agents. Just go directly to the jetty after visiting Golden temple. Guide is not required if you have a good map and little bit of pre reading materials on this.

Beautifully located on riverside. We arrived quite late and therefore avoid the normal crowd. It was closing time so we could not get in most of the building in the temple. The main temple is under construction so the view was not perfect.Other than that, the outdoor area is very pleasant. It is mixing with the scene from the river water.
very nice. another must see that is across the grand palace and is accessible by the river boats. There is an admission fee to go inside.

Wat Arun. A stunning temple. I was so impressed with the look of it when I got up close. However, we were charged 300 baht to get in which wasn't worth it. Wat Pho is cheaper and better. The square surrounding the temple is tiny and you can see everything in about 5 minutes. Getting there by boat is also time-consuming and expensive.

A temple in barren side. The temple located barren side of chao phraya river. Hot weather and its been under restoration. We cant find any information here if we dont hire a guide. No leaflet, no brochure, no information about history of the temple.For me Wat arun is more interested than wat pho.

Get the best view from the river by taking Chaopraya boat ride. Usuallt the Chaopraya express boat to the central pier will pass Wat Arun, so prepare your camera ready and you will get the best view of Wat Arun from the river.
Under scaffolding now. This impressive building has always been more interesting to see from a distance than to actually visit. Alas, it's all under scaffolding now so the view is a bit obstructed.

Absolutely beautiful. . Another stunning temple in Thailand my personal belief is this is best visited at night time to truly appreciate the beauty. With practicing monks living and working at this temple, observing them about their daily life is fascinating. Through the beautiful gardens there is a great view across the river where you can watch the lit up tour boats float past.

Amazing clay works. It is alittle bit far away from city center and took us nearly one hour to cross two rivers on Saturday morning. Return was more jammed. But decorations of ore and gods plus pagoda full of detailed flowers and curvings in white clay painted with coloful ones made the visit a good one.

Good architecture. From what we could see the architecture is beautiful, but it was under construction so a lot of the architecture was hidden. Maybe we'll go back and spend more time there once it's finished.
Under restoration. Not much to see right now as it's covered in scaffolding. I'm sure it's going to be awesome but for now it's not much.

Stunning - A must visit. Stunning temple that is a must see if your in Bangkok.The steps to the top are very steep but there are ropes to hold onto going up / down. I recommend you made the climb as the views from the top are worth.An entry ticket is very cheap about $1.

Traditional Thai costume dress up photos!. Get your family photo dressed up in traditional Thai costumes! There are multiple stalls at the front of the temple near the river where they will dress you up in fun outfits and take your photo.We bargained it down to 300 baht for 4 people. They put you in the costumes, posed you and used your own camera to take photos. They took multiple poses of both individual and group. The don't do make up. The costumes are out over your clothes.

Not impressed. . We were not impressed. It is on the other side of the river so you have to take a boat there. The locals try to rip you off and give you random prices for the boat. Don't pay over 3 baht. That's now much it costs to go to the other side. Once we got there it was under construction. It's big but nothing that would wow you after seeing the other temples in Bangkok. Maybe if it wasn't under construction we would have a better experience with it.

Under refurbishment . Covered in scaffolds currently. According to guide, the temple had been under refurbishment for the last five years. Unsure of date to be finished. Nice but disappointing not to be able to climb stairs closer to top. Still amazing and ornate.

Ceramics-covered temple, worth a boat trip.. This temple has been under restoration several times we have visited and so access is limited. The shops near the temple are good but close early; schedule is erratic. Be sure to bargain.
Woke up to the view every morning.. Certainly worth a visit very impressive any time of day. We was lucky to be staying straight across so had fantastic views.

Nice temple and grounds. We took the boat across the river to walk around and view this temple. We'll worth the price as it is beautiful and interesting. They have a nice little snack stand and picnic tables to take a break from the heat.

Wasn't as Impressive at the others near by. I visited Wat Arun first before heading to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho, I have to say that it was my least favorite. It was being restored and under construction while I was there so maybe that was why, but it still was just average. I would not bother to pay to get inside cause there really isn't anything special to see once your on the other side of the walls (unless i missed something) that you can't see from the outside.One big suggestion is to take the water taxi across the water, its only 6 baht per person and is far easier than trying to walk to the bridge.

Good place to know the Buddha culture of Thailand. It is one of the most visited Wat (temple) in Thailand. It also good for others to admire the magnificent building art and the land sculpture. Buy the tickets before you enter the main temple where you will greet by a gold smiling Buddha. Since the temple in under repair but it didn't stop us from admiring the building. Beside the temple, there is a stall that sell duck meat noodle, but eat with your own risk. A tip for eating in foreign country, always drink their local yogurts, to build up your digestive system defence.
Beautiful temple. Went there but the temple was undergoing reconstruction and maintenance. It was still possible to see how intricate the architecture and design was. Truly a piece of art.

Beautiful. This is one of my favorite temples, it's not too crowded and the view is mangnifique. If you come by early enough, you can watch the monks chanting, starting their day. Wear appropriate clothes, they will ask you to rent a sarong if your skirt is above knee length :) There's also a quaint cafe in the garden, perfect for a rest break.

Under construction - but enjoy the detailed ceramics... Wat Arun was fantastic and must be seen up close to be appreciated - as you approach by ferry across the Chao Phraya river, but is a majestic looking temple - but the divine is in the details!Our guide mentioned about the Chinese porcelain which became popular at about the time Wat Arun began construction when the King of Bangkok lived here on the WEST side of the river - something about a sunken ship if memory serves me correctly..In any case - when you get close to the temple - it really comes alive with beauty - the only reason I did not rate 5 bubbles is due to large scale maintenance and scaffolding coverting the main central "stupa" (spire/tower) at the middle of the structure during our visit. When you see the detailed ceramic work however - it is understandable this will require almost constant maintenance and repair...We did not get to enter the central temple during our visit - We did however visit a shrine out by the entrance near the river where there is a venerated figure of the King of Bangkok - (from before the reign of the current Ramas) with his sword across his lap - we participated in the fun tradition of climbing under the bed in front of the king - and then as you pass under - you look to the king for favor and kindness - neat - You will enjoy Wat Arun - there are THOUSANDS of temples in Thailand, but this was much unlike any of the others we visited during our stay. Don't forget your sunscreen if you are light skinned - the sun can be very intense reflected by all that white ceramic.

Animal Lover's Paradise?. It does however have a large population of homeless cats, some of whom are friendly as they're fed by the monks. This was a definite plus for me as I love animals. It also has beautiful gardens outside the temple complex and some beautiful architecture.Not Bangkok's prettiest temple, but if you have time spare it's worth a visit.

Wat Arun, Bangkok. Wat Arun is Bangkok's most iconic and visited temple, second to the Wat Phra Kaew complex across the river. A temple has been at the site since the kingdom of Ayutthaya (c. late 17th Century) and originally held the Emerald Buddha. The most identifiable part of the temple is its Khmer-style 'prang' which is unique for Bangkok and reminiscent of the architecture of Angkor. This tower and its four smaller sides represent Mount Meru and the corners of the Earth which is central to Buddhist and Hindu cosmology. The prang is decorated with faience creating a strange mix of color in the large grey structure. It is a unique and worthwhile building to visit whilst in Bangkok. Wat Arun is probably the only site you will want to visit in Thonburi unless you enjoy a walk or bike ride to the unremarkable temples and parks to the south. Access to the temple is via ferry which has a station directly at the base of the temple. There is a adjacent temple complex with an ordination hall to explore after visiting the tower. Temple hours are about 7:30 to 5:30. The entry fee is 50 baht. The climb up the tower gives a great view, but is quite high and the stairs remarkably steep, so it is not for the faint of heart or those with limited mobility. Keep in mind that the temple experiences frequent restoration works - it is, after all, a very old structure.

Sacred destination. The corners are surrounded by four smaller satellite prangs, which are dedicated to the wind god Phra Phai. The prangs are decorated by seashells and bits of porcelain which were used as ballast by boats coming to Bangkok from China.Wat Arun("Temple of the Dawn") in Bangkok is a Khmer-style Buddhist temple and major landmark on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River.The front entrance of the has a roof with a central spire, decorated in coloured ceramic and stuccowork sheated in colored china.Two temple guardian figures in front. Characters from the Hindu epic Ramayana, the white figure is named Sahassateja and the green one is known as Tasakanth.Traditional Thai costumes available for rental. Worth trying!

la plus belle vue de Bangkok, mais....the most beautiful view of Bangkok, but ..... Son nom signifie "temple de l'aube".sans contexte mon temple préféré à Bangkok (qui en compte des milliers), une situation exceptionnelle au bord du Chao Praya, en face du Grand Palais, du Wat Pho,Une arrivée en bateau-bus, une boutique de thé glaçé à l'extérieur, des "prangs" (stupas) au nombre de 4que vous pouvez escalader par des escaliers très raides le plus grand vous emmenant à plus de 80 mètres d'où vous aurez une vue imprenable sur les monuments en face et sur le Chao Praya, des mosaiques de porcelaine par milliers, des pavillons adjacents faits en granit vert...une merveille, vous dis-je...Mais en travaux actuellement et donc impossibilité de gravir les prangs..quel dommage...ne faîtes pas comme moi, vérifiez d'abord si les travaux sont finis !!!!His name means "the dawn's temple."Without context my favorite temple in Bangkok (which has thousands), an excellent location along the Chao Praya River, opposite the Grand Palace, Wat Pho,An arrival by water bus, a Iced tea shop outside, the 4 "prang" (stupas)? the highest prand you can climb by steep stairs taking you to more than 80 meters from where you have a great view on the monuments in front on and on the Chao Praya river, porcelain mosaics thousands, adjacent pavilions made of green granite ... a marvel, I tell you ... But now works on and therefore unable to climb the prangs..what a pity!! don' do like me, first check if the works are finished !!!!

Another attraction in Central Bangkok on the bank of Chao Phraya river.At present the temple under a massive renovation but it will give you a traditional thai touch,Cross the river by ferry with a just 5THB per person walk from Grand Palace.A very attraction place for travellers.I enjoyed a lot and suggest other to visit if you are in BKK.

Undergoing renovation. We went to wat Arun in the end of November 2015,and unfortunately it was undergoing renovation then. We couldn't see the details of the sculpturing due to the scaffolding, and we couldn't enter the temple structures either, though we walked around the temple grounds. There are a number of small shops selling food and souvenirs here, but the place is clean and nice to walk around. I bet the temple is much prettier when renovation is done, but i would say that if you gave seen wat pho and grand palace, with the emerald Buddha, you can skip this one. It isn't likely to be radically different!

So different. If you are "over" temples then this is the one to visit for its sparkling exterior of white plaster inlaid with colour. Very different and great photographic opportunities. Across the river from Wat Pho with the giant laying Buddha.

Hidden by scaffolding but still nice. Currently a work in progress for renovation, it is impossible to climb the temple up to the top. It is still nice however to walk around in the district, and to have dinner or a drink at sunset/night on the other side of the river. The temple is indeed illuminated at these hours, which makes you almost forget the scaffholding!

huge structure on the river bank. Huge white, beautifully designed monument on the river bank. Take a ferry after a few minutes walk from the Grand Palace. M. Unfortunately, it was under renovation when we visited. So couldn't go inside. Must visit

The Wat on the coin. This is the Wat imprinted on the coins. Take the boat from the pier and across the Chad pra river lies this beautiful Wat. However it is now under construction and we could not enjoy it. The ticket to enter this place felt a waste. Please do visit after the scaffolding is removed and the Wat is back in its beauty.
Beautiful Thai Temple. We loved touring the Temple of Dawn as part of our day temples tour whilst in Thailand. As you can see, the architecture is simply stunning! A must see when in Thailand!

Worth a visit. At Chao phraya river take ferry from central pier(14 baht) get of at pier 8(approx 20mins).then take another shuttle ferry which takes u right across to a pier on the opposite side (5-7min tkt price 3baht one way).the temple is right thr whn u get off.u can see it from pier no 8
Impressive thai architecture. Its a huge masterpiece of thai architecture. Take your time and walk around this building and be impressed by the dimensions.
Temple of Dawn. I toured 4 of the great Temples of Bangkok and thought this one the most beautiful . Years ago I caught a water taxi past it and always wanted to see it . It was a spiritual moment.

Looks more beautiful at night!. I love the location! It's right by the side of Chao Phraya River! Entrance fee is THB50. It's too bad it was under reconstruction when we were there so we can't really take pictures of the main architecture, only the ones on the side. It's still beautiful though. There are stairs so we can go around the structure and the steps are too steep. It's kind of scary. Some of the other tourists were hesitant to go around and went down instead. LOL. We passed by Wat Arun while on the ferry from Asiatique back to Khao San, it's sooooo beautiful! I wish I was able to take a photo.
Great. Love this site. Wander around this amazing architecture. It was on some renovation during my visit, but yes, it is still beautiful

must see. According to our hotel was near to the river, we cough the boat to tha tien pier then cross the river to get in to the temple. Beautiful and peaceful with the blessing of monk when we got in their. Walked around with lots of photo. Unfortunately, the main pagoda is under the renovation and we can not go up there. But overall, great to see this place.

A Work of Art!. Definitely worth a visit when in Bangkok. Sadly there was scaffolding surrounding some of the buildings but there is still plenty to admire with the temples being covered with mosaic tiles and each of the statues different in appearance. Along side the Chao Phraya River where a boat can be taken to the otherside for a nominal charge. Women should remember to cover shoulders and knees!

Beautiful, Intricate works of art, Must see!. I have been in Bangkok twice, and both times I have visited Wat Arun and spent a couple of hours there. It's definitely worth a visit, to admire the beautiful carvings, the various sculptures, murals on the walls etc. The rows of Buddha's statues in various poses is lovely to see. The best part of the visits were climbing up the central Prang. Entry to the Prang area is ticketed (100 Bahts per person) The climb up to the third level of it is quite steep, the stairway is narrow. But the view of the Chao Phraya river and the neighborhood is worth it. When i visited in January 2016, the third level was closed for reconstruction.Strict dress code is to be followed, no shorts/short skirts, no sleeveless tops. Spend at least an hour at Wat Arun, meditate at the prayer halls, get the blessings of a monk, pour oil into their huge lamps. You will definitely like it..
Nice place. When we visited this place it was under construction and we did not see much. Getting there is a real adventure but I would recommend visiting this place.

Restoration of Temple of Dawn. We had visited this attraction 15years ago and it is is so nice to see that the temple is being restored with many artisans cleaning and restoring the tiles and paintwork. Also the grounds are so much nicer. Only downside was the toilet facilities. The newer ones were closed and the only available ones were to say the least "Gross".

One of Bangkok's landmarks. We visited the place in Nov 2014, there were still some building/renovation works being done but thankfully it was open and available to the public. We were allowed to climb up to see the view of the river and surrounding temple complex. Climb is quite scary (really steep), going back down is a real challenge. We're into all cultural heritage sites so we liked it, it also looks good at night with all the lights - we took a night cruise down the river and saw it from a different angle again. Can't imagine going to Bangkok and not visiting this site, but obviously if you're into partying more than sightseeing - you'll probably skip all the temples anyway!Overall - happy that we had an opportunity to visit it, pics look great in our album :)

Good from Far. Our Visit was a bit disappointing. We spent more time crossing the river after seeing Grand Palace just to see Wat Arun. Even when we paid the entrance fee of THB 50 per person they did not tell us its under repair and restoration. We could not see it from inside. We ended up seeing only the same thing which we could have seen from outside.
Underwhelming. The temple is underwhelming. You just walk around the building, not a whole lot to see. Not worth the money.

Under construction. We were there at mid May, however what we could see was limited due to the construction. The temple was still a beautiful sight to see. The cost to enter was 50 BHT, and you do need to be covering your shoulders and knees if you would like to enter. The art was is something to admire, there are small tiles that make up beautiful mosaic frames that cover most of the temple, and the statues each one is different from the next. We were still able to walk around the grounds, and walk up the stairs for a small portion of the temple to see the elaborate painted structures, the monks, and what looked to be stone guardians standing watching gaurd at each entrance.

Temple within a river width.. Just travel by chao phraya, change the boat to cross over to the temple of dawn which is quite accessible. But remember to buy the ticket and queue up, can be rowdy at times, as boat trips can be pretty irregular.

RELIGIOUS MARVLE. A nice and tranquil place to be, now a days it's flocking with tourists but if you come just before sunset it is absolutely magnificent, but do bare in mind that the entrance closes at 6pm for tourists and there is a 100 bath entrance fee for foreign nations. It is amazing how Thai people value Their religion, the day I visited there was a prayer going on the main yard and watching it was so peaceful. Buddhism plays a huge role in Thai Sociaty so please be respectful while you are inside the temple, please do read the instructions which are displayed at the entrance and the main yard. The best way to travel to the temple is to take BTS Sky train to Siam station and walk 5 minutes to the river boat taxi and take a local river boat for only 20 bath. There are also some tourist boat taxis that departs from the same station and they have someone on board describing every single stops, it's history and the attractions. A single journey on the tourist boats costs 40 bath and a whole day pass costs 150 bath.

So hot!. Was so hot that like an ice cube under the sun, was melting so bad. Bring along your umbrella or use hat. I know it's a stunning place but I was busy finding place for avoiding the sun. Go to shopping market the tour guide told us to buy typical Thailand from here because cheaper. Indonesian ppl also can use rupiah. But found out is way cheaper to buy typical souvenir in MBK lol..

Everyday temple. Nothing special about this place except that it's cheap and less busy than the Palace. We chose to do it and did not regret it, but I would only suggest it if you're simply looking for something to kill time and you're not temple'd out.

Under Construction . Wat Arun is a beautiful place to visit, however it happened to be under construction while we were visiting (May 28 2016) so our sites were limited and we have scaffolding in all of our pictures. Otherwise a small fee (100 baht) to enter and it is well worth seeing!!

you'll be amazed by its stunning design. This is one of the three must-see temples in Bangkok, and can easily be combined with Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaew (in the Grand Palace complex). If you only have 1 day in Bangkok, I suggest that you finish all three, and you're good to go! Wat Arun is the most photographed structure in Bangkok (especially during sunset), and understandably so. It is simply gorgeous up close and from afar. I took the Chao Phraya "cross river" ferry from the Wat Pho stop. The maps for Chao Phraya is everywhere in Bangkok so it's impossible to miss this. I also have my Lonely Planet: Thailand book which has good recommendations on walking tours, which includes this temple. When you enter the Wat Arun compound, you'll be amazed by its stunning design. It's simply majestic! And, you get to climb the temple too. Be careful though, the stairs are pretty narrow, and steep. However, your effort climbing up won't be left unrewarded. The views from the top is amazing and gives you a panoramic view of the Chao Phraya river and the old Bangkok. This temple should definitely be a part of any itinerary in Bangkok!
My favourite. What can I say ,it took my breath away .its being renovated as its all mosique.and all been hand done by hand .take time to view sit

One of the best temples of Bangkok. One of the temples on the other side of the river, being on the river bank makes it unique. Didn't visit during the best of the times. It was under renovation and it was raining, but it would be a site to see during a quite night.

Beautiful Temple. I went here just after I was from Wat Phra Kaew (Emerald Buddha). I went here via boat that crossed Chao Phraya River.Probably because I was from Wat Phra Kaew, so I think that this temple is so beautiful, amazing, marvelous, and peaceful, and so great!! Compare to Wat Phra Kaew, this temple is much better and quiet, there aren't many visitors here (maybe because of the reconstruction), but still worth a visit! :)
Another amazing Bangkok Temple Complex. Very stunning and interesting. Loads of eye candy. I probably took over 300 photos. Highly recommend.

Spectacular but construction works ongoing. This is indeed a must see and visit place. Although the temple is under construction at the moment, it's still spectacular especially coming from the Chao Phraya River.
Gorgeous Temple. We didnt get to enjoy the site because the main temple was under construction. We went there May 25, 2016.

Temple of Dawn - truly an inspiring place to visit. Dawn brings the light of a new day our life.this temple is a beautiful piece of architecture and is very inspiring bang on the banks of river.You cross the river and can go to Reclining buddha temple.Although when i visited some parts were under renovation.Still the visit inspiring and satisfactory
Very beautiful. Was under construction but was still very cool to see. Make sure to have shoulders and legs covered if female.

Under construction but still worth the money . The entry fee is low but that isnt the only reason to go to this temple. It offers great views to the other side of the river and you can still climb the steep steps. There were not a lot of people here.

Under restoration . We visited in May 2016 and there are currently restoration works being carried out at the moment which does impact on the overall feel of the place.However we jumped off when on the tourist water taxi (40 bht- one stop off) and got the ferry across to see the temple (3bht). Nice to go across the river and definitely worth doing and remember you appropriate dress!!
Love the thrill. The biggest reason of coming to this temple is the climb of the stairs. Nice architecture and many interesting carving. At present, you can't climb up due to renovation.

Nice temple. It is Very small if you compare with wat pho or the grande palace. It is nice to see. I took a boat to see the river and a some temples near wat arun but it was a weaste of time. Save your money and your time. Go to wat arun only for 3bat in a community boat.

Beautiful from afar. My family and I got to see this temple while we were on a boat tour. It was being renovated when we went by but despite that it was still absolutely beautiful. I would highly recommend seeing this temple.

Beautiful temple architecture. Beautiful temple on the Banks of the River. Best place to visit in the evening and them you can see from opposite side , Illuminated. When we visited the place was under renovation and yet it was very beautiful to visit. It is Clean and Peaceful. Travel by Boat from Tha Thien ( This is near to the Reclining Buddha Temnple) to this place and return. 5 THB per person. Nice place to be. Also be careful some Tuk TUK people will tell you cannot get into the place with Half Pants and Slippers ( DO not trust them). You can visit the palace also.

May 2016 - now being renovated. This should be a really fantastic view. But now (May 2016) it's being renovated so the view is not so good since the chedi(pagoda) was covered from the top. And now it's very hard to find car park since the authority now banned all the car park in the nearby alley. The temple ca park itself is very limited. So I recommend to visit by public transportation.
nice place. wat Arun very interesting place.the building have caving different style they make for Buddhists and for the monk stay in side .a lot thai people go to pray like culture .
Nice architecture. A worth visiting place in Bangkok. You should definitely allot some time to go there. Beautiful temple and located close to river.
Wat Arun. One of the best temples in Bangkok. Was under construction while we were there. Great view of it from the local ferry!
Enough to see from afar . Everything was in renovation and we felt stupid for paying to go in. You can see enough from the outside anyway. Nothing worth while with everything covered.
Really pretty at night. Worth a visit. Take the water taxi from the pier oppersite. The boat runs often. Also try to see it at night. Its stunning all lit up

Sightseeing . Worth a visit! Few other sight seeing places close by too. This is currently under renovation so most of the main part is covered in scaffolding. There is a few shops sell souvenirs and refreshments.Do you own research before coming down as there is loads things to do around the area. Watch out for the Tuk Tuk guys they tend to go off track to shops who will give them commission for bringing you them.

Worth seeing. Work going on when we visited in may 2016. So many parts not accessible. But good feel to cross the river in a ferry (3 THB per person) and then go around the premises (entry fee 50THB per person). Should visit in a time wherein you can see the day part and also in the late evening when the lights shown on the temple give a good effect.

Again a must see, but.... Badly managed site and unfortunately covered in scaffolding when we visited. This is a place to see, but not as impressive as others.
Cheap entrance and very easy to access if you use the riverboat.

Worth Seeing, but Do Research. When I was there, they were doing an extensive renovations/cleaning, so parts of it were obscured by scaffolding, etc. Still, it was amazing to see this colossal structure up close! Early mornings are the best time to go for photos, I've heard, but it was still lovely in the afternoon. It can get rather crowded, and in the heat, the narrow stairs are tough to climb, but it's very worth doing.My warning/advice, though, is to do your research. First, figure out how to get there before you leave your hotel so that you don't get misled by scammers who prey on tourists. They'll try to "take" you there, for a fee, or say that it's closed when it really isn't. They may also take you to souvenir stands where they get a kickback for the tourists they bring.The other warning is that you need to dress modestly, as with most temples in Thailand. Cover your knees and shoulders, regardless of gender. If you forget, they do have scarves or other outerwear available for rent, but it's time consuming to stop and get it.

Magnificent. Worth going to. Free entry and beautiful close up and from afar. Nice at night or day visit ! Not too busy either. Drinks and fruit is cheap in there tooThere are stops all along the way to china town, Siam centre, river village etc where you can jump off The price of the two ferry's is the cost for staying on one end to the other of the river or for each stop We used the boat trip initially then tried the tourist boat to get information and the next day used the local 14 batt boat.
still on renovation. Unfortunatelly the Wat Arun still on renovation, so you can't get a good photo. Plenty of souvenir stalls. Not so many people came if you compare with Grand Palace.
The best. The best temple in Bangkok ..Its huge and beautiful . About 260 ft high with a huge climb but fantastic views of the city & the river

Under construction . Beautiful temple but the main stupa was under construction. We waited on the other side of the river after sunset to see the temple lite up! This was a bit disappointing- don't bother waiting- easy to get to from the Ta Tien pier- which is near the grand palace and Wat pho.
Amazing place.. Currently undergoing the final stages of renovation, but a fantastic place to visit and experience. Really beautiful.
Beautiful Area to visit. Quieter than the other 2 temples I visited, the outer area around the temple was really impressive & beautiful. Worth at the very least checking that out.

Nice cultural tour. Great experience to take the boat to the temple. Visiting the temple and feeding fishes was a good experience and we did enjoy it. A bit boring if you already have visited a temple unless you are religiously attached. If you are religious it is a incredible experience.Definitely worth a visit.

Worth a look.. Nothing like the Grand Palace or the Reclining Buddha, but worthwhile to have a look around the peaceful grounds. You can take a public boat down the river for about 20/30 baht then get off at the stop opposite, then catch the boat that goes to the other side for 3 baht.. You can get a private boat to take you, it's faster and no crowds but it'll cost about 1500 baht. The public boat is a much better option!As of June 2016 when I visited, the main Temple was undergoing maintenance work and there was no access to the top of the building. You can still walk around the lower section. Entry to the main temple is 50 baht.

I think best at sunset. Very nice visit that you may combine with the Royal Place across the river. I would make Royal Palace in the morning and the more relaxing Wat Arun in the afternoon. After returning to the other river sidde, stop for a large 660cc beer in the pier bar.
Grand temples . All the temples are beautiful in Thailand. Try and see as many as you can in Bangkok particularly if shopping is not what you want to do. This is a beautiful temple

This temple is in renovation...so not much to see now. It is spectacular but not at this moment because it is in renovation. So look at it from far away but don't pay to see inside because you won't be able to do so.

Soooo Beautiful. This temple is so beautiful. i would recommend to go to a bar and restaurant right across the temple on the other side of the river and look at it from there. The view of the temple you get is amazing and its personally for me one of the best sight in bangkok!!

Loved it . Our guide ( from Siloma hotel) took us there on our way back from the floating market to Bangkok. If not him we probably wouldn't even think of going there on our short stay. It was my favorite temple- beautiful scenery, cheerful monks and such a peaceful atmosphere.

Under renovation . Very beautiful
Peaceful
But now currently under renovation.
I didn't go in so didn't know how much is the ticket.
Just took some picture opposite the river.

Best temple in Thailand. Its a gorgeous little temple, reached by crossing the river near the Grand Palace on a little boat for a just a few baht. It's less frequented than the major complexes such as the Grand Palace, but you can get up close. It's beautiful, and usually an escape from the crowds. The temple is very different in design, and unique - a must visit temple in Bangkok.

Being renovated by May 2016. We didn't get to see much although we were there right on time just before the sunset. The temple of dawn is currently under renovation but still the surroundings are making a good scene.

Under renovation in May 2016. Disappointed . When I visited it (May 2016) it was under renovation so no one was allowed to climb to the top of temple. If you are travelling around this time confirm b4 visiting. You can take a boat from Tha Thien Pier (opp Wat Pho) for 3 thb to go across.

Amazing views, great experience. Monks reside on this temple ground and you have to take a boat to get there (like 3 minutes from the Temple of the Reclining Buddha) and the cost of the boat is minimal was 3 baht at the time of travelling. You will be able to witness (and experience, if you so choose) to get a blessing from a Monk. Views from the staircase is amazing.
still underconstruction (may 2016). unfortunately the amazing wat arun is still under construction when I visited. but still worth it to visit, the wat arun usually shining beautifully at night
Lovely temple. Small yet well looked after temple with good detailed works on the buildings. Go before sunset then cross other side to watch amazing sunset.

Under construction & hidden under scaffolding in late April 2016. A 3 baht (yes, only 3 baht) ferry ride over from the area near the Grand Palace gets you right up next to Wat Arun. Lots of steep steps to climb if you want to get a good view up and around the temple and the surrounding area.Unfortunately it was under construction or repair in late April 2016, so not as much to appreciate. Check to make sure the construction is finished before you go, otherwise I'd say skip it.

Bangkok highlight a must see and river cruise.. After taking the BTS to Sapan Taksin a short walk to the the Chao Phraya river ferry terminal. A 15 baht ride takes you to Tha Tien pier where you can cross the river on another ferry to the Buddist Wat Arun for 5 baht. Here is one of the most beautiful temple complexes in Thailand with elegant gardens. Great care must be taken if ascending/ descending the iconic and ornately tiled prang(spire). This coupled with a visit to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho (reclining Buddha) followed by lunch in Chinatown make for the most full day for any traveler on a tight schedule wishing to take in the most sites. PS lunch at Hong Kong noodle restaurant in China town will delight for an authentic experience.

Beautiful. This is one of the most beautiful temples I have seen. It's a must see. Wear a long skirt, dress or trousers as you have to cover your knees if you want to go inside. Shoulders as well so maybe have a scarf or something with you. In front of the temple there are ladies who offer to put you in their customs and you can take pics. It's totally worth it. Can't remember how much it costs but you can always bargain.
Beautiful. Beautiful place, and not so crowded as the Grand Palace. Be careful with the open time.They are under reform for a long time.

Awesome . I'm going there when songkran festival first day, so there's have ceremonial for clean Buddha. Awesome, if you go there. You must take a boat, it's around 30 THB one way and for ticket in wat arun its free.

Great exploring. A beautiful place to explore, you can climb the steps of the Wat although they are very steel so not for everyone but the views from the top are fantastic over Bangkok. It is very exposed so hardwalkingaround in the heat of midday.

Beautiful. This temple is lovely even though it is covered in scaffolding at the moment. It looks over the Chao Phraya river and is beside another temple. I would recommend visiting but I think there is charge to get closer but I think you are close enough without paying as there is only a little fence that covers it. The temple beside is it beautiful and it is free to see

Beautiful!. Even though all the structure of Wats look alike they have their own charm individually. Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn is such structures with small beautifuls domes all around. Very peaceful and positive vibes!
Good view. Nice place to visit. We lost our camara during our to border. But we still happy even we can't take picture but we remeber all our happy times. Wish could visit here more

Renovation progress. When we were there the temple was under renovation so we can't explore the temple. I thought this temple was big as Wat Pho. But it still look pretty for taking a picture and I suggest people who want to rent Thai costume to go to the stalls near the exit door. They rent it for 100B more cheaper than the other near the entrance.

4 stars due to restoration and closed main Prong. The main prong is closed for now so you cannot climb the steep stairs to the top. However, they lowered the entrance fee to 50 baht to compensate. Bring handkerchief, hat, sunscreen, sunglasses and water. It is mad with beautiful pieces of porcelain on plaster.
Temple is good. You have to cross river using a boar, 3 THB per head. The temple is nice, but we couldn't go inside as it was under renovation.

Temple. temples in Thailand are mostly unique to one another, they some what get boring. but the scenery and landscape is amazing along with details to the art and building. Visiting 1a day is better and less boring

Nice. It's a nice temple but it's not as spectacular as the other famous one such as Wat Pho and Grand Palace. It's currently under construction so we couldn't climb to the very top to get a sunset view. Probably spent 20 minutes there because there really wasn't much to see.

Great temple and awesome views of the river and city. This temple is located at the riverside of Bangkok it is very beautiful as of may 2016 it is under mainteinance youll see it in the pictures that i post within this review.To get to the temple you have to travel by boat it is cheap and fast to cross the river it takes no longer than 2 minutes and the views of Bangkoks skyline are very good you even have the opportunitty to see the rooftop building where the movie hangover 2 was filmed.The temple is small yet its a must see in Bangkok
Under renovation. It was under renovation when we visited on May 5, 2016 so we didn't bother to enter the temple. We just roamed around the park and took pictures outside the main gates.

Make it part of a river trip. The temple is a superb structure and it contrasts with the conventional temples in the rest of Bangkok. It is a peaceful oasis in the bustle of Bangkok and can be reached easily by public boats or by part of a tour that includes the Klongs and the Royal Barge Museum.

visited but restoration work going on. Art work at the exterior is very beautiful and mesmerizingwe avoided visiting inside as the restoration work is going on for the temple. it is also visible from the ferry or boat while travelling to Grand palace
Stunning Building. The building of temples are amazing, pure white body with delicate carvings. This is one of most beautiful Buddhist temple.
Excellent Photo Opportunities. Get here during the first half of the morning. Best visited with a guide. Beautiful Structure with some good photo opportunities.

Very interesting and worth the visit. It is across the river but worth the visit. If possible avoid taking taxis because with the traffic it became very expensive. You might want to take a public bus over the river and taxi it from there. DEF no tuk tuks...they are more expensive than a taxi. I thought the temple was unique and really admired the detail. One of my favorite attractions in bangkok

unique, loved the detail!. under construction/restoration right now, so not quite as impressive as I'd expected from photos, but a beautiful temple! I loved it as I found it unique compared to all the other temples we'd visited. Loved the detail and tile pictures in all the walls. river taxi to get there was very cheap and easy to take.

Beautiful Temple of the Dawn （Wat Arun ）. Took a public boat from Sathorn Thaksin to Pier maintenance4baht). There are a few attractions at Pier 8. You can visit the Grand Palace and/or Temple of the Reclining Buddha （Wat Pho ）.Since i have visited both during my previous trip, i decided to give them a miss and choose Wat Arun instead.To go to Wat Arun, take a short ride across Choa Praya River for 3baht. Since I was blessed to visit the temple during Songkran, the surroundings were abuzzed with activities. You have to pay 50baht to enter the temple. Please wear proper dress code(applicable to all other temples and the Grand Palace as a mark of respect to Buddha and the Royal). They offer you a cloth to wrap around if you didn't, so not to worry.A little regret though during my visit. The stupa was under maintenance/ renovation. Otherwise, I could have climbed up the steep stairs to the top to view the surroundings. I went during the morning. It wasn't so hot and humid. Hope to visit again in the near future when the maintainence/ renovation of the stupa is completed.

A pleasant respite from Bangkok city.. Take the ferry across the river and enjoy the beautiful surrounds of this wonderful temple. It was very devoid of the usual crowds that ruin other tourist sights. A chance to just enjoy peace and quiet whilst visiting one of Bangkok's holiest shrines.
Impressing temple. An amazing huge temple area. Impressing lying Buddha.With the entry fee there was free drinking water included.Come by boat!
Very nice. It's unfortunate that it's under renovation when we visited . They still charged 50 Thai bath anyway still worth a visit . It's just a boat ride near the reclining Buddha

Try a night cisit. The buildings are closed at night but the way the buildings are lit is beautiful. I stopped here as part of a night bike tour. We arrived about 7p, in time to see and hear the monks chanting followed by meditating. Very peaceful.
Great views of the city from here.. The highly decorative pagoda is nearly 260ft high and has a steep climb to get fantastic views of the river and city.

history of the city. its a temple of ancient time.
it was under construction when we visited it. some renovation work was going on.
but those who interested in architectural art must visit it.
the location is good as its right on the river bank.

Its across the River. Again a stunning piece of Architecture but unfortunatly it was under going some restoration, so no photos of the main building.
We were glad we didnt get up before 5 to see the Dawn rise from the Temple as it was covered in scoffolding! However another lovely attraction

Temple of Dawn ..Blessings with love. The temple is not only a Temple of Lord Gold Buddha but a Blessing for you forever.When we visit Bangkok we always try to visit places unwanted..may be not for all but 90 % Thai believe and adopt Buddhism,pray Lord Buddha.Lord has conquered Enemies with Peace a lesson world should have ,its need of hour era .what u can call. Gold Buddha was known when the statue was shifted or else people was Praying Lord.Some people release birds from cage to relieve sins and achieve peace for life its a great moment for us birds flying away towards the sky..Thanks to people to who perfrom it.Visit and get what u get and share
A must visit . Structures are amazing. Visit to Thailand wouldn't be fulfilling without seeing the famous reclining Buddha. My family and I fell in love with everything this place has to offer
worth a visit. Another temple to visit while in Bangkok. we took a boat over from the reclining Buddha which is very cheap. was being re-painted while we was there but still beautiful.

Its underconstruction. When i went to wat arun, its still under construction. Honestly, im dissapointed because i just can see one of the beautifull temple in bangkok from the outside. Cant go inside the temple
Wonderfull at sunrise. On the other side of the river from grand palace. Taxi boat is only 3 bath to cross the river. Different style from other Wat of the city.

Beautiful. Finally visited Wat Arun on our 5th trip to Bangkok, just a pity they are busy restoring so there is a lot of scaffolding up but still plenty to see and still well worth the visit if you have the time, is going to be really beautiful when the work is completed.

Even under repair its an attractive soght. The main temple has scaffolding all over it at the moment, but the temple and its grounds are still well worth the visit, and worthy of several snapshots.The boat rides to get there are fun, not hard to coordinate with virtually no planning, and cheap.

Great but under repair on. One of the most revered places in Bangkok, but unfortunately it is under repairs and the main Chedi was off limits. Difficult to get to and hard to get around narrow roads and byways which are not well sign posted. Must wear appropriate clothing - or hire at entrance - 50baht fee.

very hot but quite an excellent visit. eventhough, its by the river but summer in Bangkok brings heat waves. make sure you put sunscreen when u visit here, the temple itself is iconic, they have just renovated this temple, u can see there is still some minor renovation going on there. I think this is the tallest building in Thailand a few hundred years ago.

Beautiful Temple. Visited Wat Arun on the eve of Songkran. The temple is huge and beautiful. There were some reconstruction works going on in the Pagodas so I wasnt able to go in there. How ever the rest of the temple is accessible and I had an enlightening visit. I was lucky enough to be able to bathe the 5 Buddha's kept at the entrance as one of the senior monks explained to me about the different Buddhas and the history of the temple. Truly a wonderful visit.

Temple is Bangkok landmark. The Temple of Dawn is a Buddhist temple. It is one of Bangkok's most famous landmarks. The spires reflect the first rays of the rising sun at dawn. The temple goes back hundreds of years but the Temple of Dawn's distinctive spires date from the 19th century. If you visit, please remember that this is a place of worship

Temples BKK. Excellent time in Bangkok visiting one the most famous cities in the world.The Buddhism is the main believe in Thailand and spreads to several Asian countries what it makes the Buddha Temples simply awesome.
so pretty. Sadly they are doing a little construction, but regardless it is amazing and any pictures you see do not do it justice. It is a definite must see

Under construction . Not a good time to visit as its under some form of upgrading or servicing. Not enough time to complete the visit of reclining Buddha, grand palace and the temple of dawn within a day. If more food joints are set up within the attractions will be good.

Beautiful temple. When we visited Wat Arun was under refurbishment so a portion of temple was covered in scaffolding. Despite this it was beautiful and climbing up the steep steps to see the temple and the river from several different angles. The sun was setting when we visited and the temple looked beautiful in the golden light.

Not very accessable on my visit. Visited this early May 16 and unfortunately their was much refurbishment taking place so access to inside the Temple was not possible and some area were closed off.They do not tell you this outside thoughDress code was still enforced with no short sleeves or shorts, clothing is provided for a fee which is very small 20 baht and 100 baht deposit. backs on to the river so its a nice position for many pictures, this is a popular tourist point although at my visit not many locals probably because they knew most was closed off

The most beautiful temple in Bkk!. For the Wat Arun you have to go to the opposite part of the river, paying a 3 bath taxi boat (one way price), and just arriving on the other riverside it seems everything different, like no more being in Bangkok!! You can enjoy silence, peace, monks praying and the atmosphere is very peaceful. The ancient pyramidal constructions are extremely beautiful, you can take lots of beautiful photos. There is an elegant garden also, with lots of beautiful bonsai and typical flowers.A must see during your stay in Bangkok!!!!

Pretty even when scaffolded. Unfortunately was under repair when we were there. Scaffolding certainly made it harder to appreciate the full beauty of it, but it was still really pretty. We were there a bit later in the day so there wasn't much in the way of crowds. Nice contrast to the much busier temples across the river. Grounds here are nice to meander through as well. Overall, we were here less than an hour and felt like that was plenty of time.

Beautiful!!!. The wats are all over Thailand, and each is wonderful. Be warned that shoes come off when you enter the wat, so try to wear ones that will come off and on easily. Also, this is a religious area, and some do have a dress code (no tanks, no shorts, etc.). Wonderful place to visit, though--all your senses are engaged. Incense, the beautiful tile work, wind chimes help to make it a treat.

Not that grand as compared to Wat Pho. To be fair, I felt conned by the bunk boat that took me to this temple; Hence, I didn't have enough time to really explore the temple (20 minutes) and the temple was also under renovation.As compared to Wat Pho that I visited a day before, this temple looked dull; The colors of the tiles are completely washed out.

Lots of stairs to climb but Beautiful temple complex. Took a boat from outside the wat pho temple to reach here for 5 baht and it took just 5 minutes.But unfortunately the main temple was closed for maintenance when we visited in March 2016 but we explored the whole complex and it was very beautiful and different to the other wats of Bangkok.Its located near the chao praya river so the gardens were gorgeous.We climbed the stairs till they were open to visitors and they were very difficult to climb and get down without the support of side beam.
Under repair. The temple is beautiful it was just under repair when we arrived which made it hard to see and hear what it was all about. It is lovely piece of history.
Under renovation. Visited in 2012 and now visited again, it is under renovation now. Cannot go to the top but still enjoy the sightseeing

Use river taxi to visit . I struggled to find a meter taxi that would bring me here because everyone gets to this beautiful temple by river taxi. Once there, make sure you visit the temple and beautiful gardens rather than just going into the enclosed area with the "wats". Very impressive especially as all the ancient structures are being renovated. They seem to be almost finished and the splendour of the restored colours and gold paint. Strangely they don't re-gild the previously gilded Buddhas
Morning time. Climbed up to the high of this pagoda once you get there What a view. Get good exercise in April day. Try.

Beautiful. It's amazing to see, when traveling several Buddhist countries, their take on how to build a pagoda. Even though quintessentially they are the same, the Thai ones have a specific colour and uniqueness that make them so remarkable. The details and the multitude of colours used are simply astonishing, you could recognise Thai architecture wherever. A must see for every traveller ti Bangkok.
Temple of awn. Worth a visit but at present doing work on the main temple so slightly disappointed . But worth looking round the rest of temple.
Under renovation. The temple and the view from above looked wonderful however it is under renovation. Be careful in climbing up and down the stairs. The entrance fee is 50 baht

Picture is decisive . We were bey upbeat to visit this temple after seeing the pictures .
The temple is few min walk and a very short boat ride from reclining Buddha . The ferry takes 3 Bhatt each side
When we went the temple was under restoration so could went inside

unfortunately, under repair. A beautiful temple to visit, just a short trip across the river from the area of Wat Po and the royal palace, unfortunately when l went there was a lot of scaffolding as there are major restorations being undertaken, l look forward to visiting this temple again when these are completed

Still under renovation . Sadly, at time of writing, the Wat is still under renovation. However, despite all the scaffolding this is still worth the visit. It's only 3 Baht to cross the river and 50 Baht entry fee. While you can't climb the main stupa like in the past, it is still a beautiful Wat and complex to visit. Take some time to visit the entire grounds.

The least of Bangkok's treasures. I found this temple disappointing. It's decoration seems to have been done on the cheap, and so it looks tacky to my eyes. Despite having a guide to explain things to me, it falls short of the other Bangkok temples. I wouldn't go again.
Under construction. We took a Chiao Praya cruise and stoped there. The temple of dawn was under construction so there were only few important things to visit.

Should have been a great place to visit. The temple should have had a great view of the entire city at its highest point that you can go. However, during my visit, the higher areas were under maintenance. The temple costs 50 Baht to enter.
Main stupa under repair but marvellous. The place was under restoration and repai work was on in most parts of the architure.The place is marvellous and full of peace along chao phraya river.

Under Construction. We want there with our kids a week ago. I remember the place from last visits to Bangkok an excellent place to visit. This time it was a big disappointment as it is under construction. Avoid visiting it !!!!!
impressive. Our timing on this one was unfortunate, since it was under construction those days we visited Bangkok, still we been able to get in and walk around.

Amazing Temple. The temple was under renovations when we got there but it was still so majestic . You have to imagine what you would have seen many centuries ago when this is your first sigh that you see when you entered the old Bangkok - it really was amazing

Temple of Dawn - Wat Arun a must see. This temple was just 15min drive from Ibis Riverside. When we visited this temple, renovation was under progress and we could not visit the main temple. There were many souvenir shops around the temple. Also one pier was available for boarding he boat and crossing Chao Phraya River which costed barely THB 3.5 per person which was also a good experience as we pan through high raised building and Wat Arun as such.
Amazing Temple. This amazing temple is breath-taking in its complex beauty. Worth going up all the steps (so hot), and admire from above.

Historical Temple not to be missed. One of the many Grade 1 Temples in Bangkok, this was the temple built by King Rama 3 and one of the most historically rice heritage sites in Thailand, not to mentioned Chao Phraya River. I was immersed and wowed by the rich history behind this temple.The interesting part is that we got to take a bumboat across the river to the temple which there are plenty of sightseeing to be seen.A place nobody can miss when in the City of Angels.
Sad it was under construction. When I was there, the temple was under construction or rather renovations. Still got to see it. You need to take a boat ride to that side of the river.
good Temple. good location best time to visit in evening, it is on bank of river, good location of photography , if you hired on private boat.

The central temple with the highest attraction rate. Wat Arun is really an impressing temple. Unluckily the main building was just under a cleaning process, so that it was impossible to admire all these great works on it. But, I guess, starting May you will be able to see everything shining and clean.Not really acceptable was that they charge a boat docking fee - we did a tour with a longtail boat along the river, and the last stop was at the Wat Arun. Also not really well described is where to get a boat to the other side of the river. I mean the cheap version. It is all a calculation to make money from tourists.
Sunrise at wat arun. best place to watch the sunrise in Bangkok city is the wat arun temple. Stunning view of the sun over the wat arun pagoda.

Lovely temple. This is one of the most iconic landmards and must visit if you in bangkok especially if you came for the first time. My advice is please come early as this spot will close around 3pm even i came here pretty early around 8.30am but a bunch of ppl was already around this area. There have many temple surrounding that you can visit. If you are hungry ariund thus area there have a lot local hawkers store to fill your stomach empty. Trust me is was a fantastic food around this area. Just be careful with a tuk-tuk scam around temple. They maybe trick you and saying the temple is close before taking you to another place for the comission. This place is open everyday. Please walk further if you decided to leave this place if ask for the taxi.
Breathtaking and worth the photo shoot. Nice day out and worth the trip to this Wat. Priceless photo shoot to take and relive the moment of Thai history here.

Scaffolding up - disappointed. Went to see this temple and they had scaffolding up whilst trying to renovate the temple itself. This meant the grounds were sparse, the areas we could go in were limited and we definitely could not go in and up the temple itself so felt like a wasted trip. I'm sure if you were to go inside you would see much the same as the other temples in BKK but for us, not very impressed based on what we saw, which was very little unfortunately.

Worth a visit!. Despite currently being under restoration (with the main building covered in scaffolding), Wat Arun is still worth visiting. Being on the opposite side of the river to the other main attractions (although easily accessed via a shuttle boat costing only 10 baht), it was significantly quieter and therefore more serene than the other sites I visited. There were still plenty of details to admire amongst the buildings, and it was peaceful sitting in the shade and taking it all in. I look forward to revisiting when the restoration is compete and the buildings can be seen in all their glory!

Awe inspiring. This was my favourite temple in Bangkok unfortunately it was currently under repair so there was a lot of scaffolding around the temple. Best to take a tour guide or read up beforehand so that you are aware of the history of this temple.

Under construction, only level one accessible. My hostel pal and I walked to Chinatown then took a metered taxi to Wat Arun (THB60/£1.20).Entrance for foreigners is THB50/£1.00. It is a small Temple complex, compounded by the fact that only one level was accessible. We spent half an hour here taking photos and sitting in the shade from the sunAfter we took the river boat for THB3/£0.06 to cross the river to Wat Po.

Crazy-cool and meaningful place. Should definitely make your temple short list. Unbelievable tile work, and a completely unique tableau. Steep, though optional, stair climbs. Otherworldly and meaningful. Very hot.

Main temple under construction. We took a small ferry across from Wat Pho (just outside the complex) to Wat Arun, which was very cheap and quick.Wat Arun looks absolutely stunning from the water but the scaffolding was a real let down (although we understand that it's necessary in order to preserve the site).
