The many buildings and smaller temples are beautiful; and the architecture is fantastic. Tourists pay a small fee to enter the site and walk around at their own pace. We met a monk who was friendly and tied a small ribbon around our wrists, which was fun. Highly suggest taking a bottle of water with you and a hat to protect you from the sun. Wat Arun was a lot less busy in comparison to Wat Pho and we highly recommend that you visit both places.

Lovely nightview. The Watt is most breathtaking when seen from across the river at night. We found it dull and not as beautiful during the day. The time we went, there were maintenance construction works ongoing - this could have also been the reason why.

Beautiful sight both from Inside and outside, do dine or drink on the opposite side of the river. As of now its covered in Scaffolding for renovation. When I visited it before in August 2013, it was very much free from those scaffolding and present to us in all its glory. Magnificent site both from across the river, on the banks and from the inside. The view from the top,after climbing the main pagoda are beautiful. Go there like 3 or 4 PM, explore the temple and get done from it by 5 Pm then cross the river on the boat and goto one of the roof top bars across on the opposite site from it. Cafe Amorosa, Cafe Sala, and the one beside Cafe Sala are recommended for a drink with sunset view and post sunset view of Wat Arun, when its lighted up.One of the key highlights for me in Bangkok

dams sight. best to se this serene Wat at dawn I reckon ... grab a khlong boat and motor past and take a few snaps. Nice to take your yoga mat there and practice at dawn and meditate too :).You can doa joint tour thing around the area and se other sights like floating markets as part of the package tours. All a bit touristy I reckon for me. I prefer to get there in a more local way and do the early morning alms experience with the locals and monks.I'd recommend Pandan Tours if you'd like a small intimate and lovely day of khlong tour. Most enjoyable, quiet and personal trip with them.

Very Beautiful!. Less crowded than other attractions but there were many different things to see although it was smaller than a few of the other temples. Gardens, landscaping and statues were all very beautiful. We reached Wat Arun by boat, just a simple, 5 minute ride, literally across the river which had some great shopping!

Under construction. The temple was under construction, so we just walked around without going inside. I would not buy a ticket until they finish renovation. You could observe the Wat either from another side of the river, or from the Wat Arun’s side. Taking a 3 THB shuttle boat across the river is a fun experience.
100 Bath entrance fee. Nice temple, but under constructions work when we had visited it. Very easy access by ferry (3 bath) from/to Wat Pho/Grand Palace.
Amazing!. Unfortunately there were men at work but we enjoyed it very much. Entry doesn't cost a lot (maybe 4-5 US dollars) and the temple is simply beautifull.
It's under restoration.. Wat Arun is currently being restored. It's still lovely to have a look at though. You need to cross the river to get to it.

Worth a visit. Beautiful temple,it's under construction but still a lot to see. We managed to see a monk giving blessings to people. Very relaxed atmosphere,they give you a skirt and scarf if you are dressed "inappropriate".
Meh. If you like temples or you are a Buddhist then its probably majestic. But for me the boat ride there was better than the temple itself which is a walk around it grey building.
Essential Visit. Wat Arun is one of those places that one should check out during different times of the day for a different experience every time!

Beautiful! . 3rd time in Bangkok and the 2 previous i hadn't been able to go. Finally, this time i made it. I love Buddhist temples (well most religious places), they simply never disappoint. We had a fabulous time with the children walking around and exploring. The main pagode is in renovations at the moment but you can still walk around it. In the main temple there was a priest doing blessings and we walked out with a cotton bracelet. It is very hot so bring water, there is a small market though if needed. Easy accessible with the ferry from Tha Tien (3 baht one way).

You can consider. The temple is under construction so you cannot go any where inside. Make sure you wear pants and not sleeveless shirts when you go in any temple or else you need to pay extra for the cover they are lending.

Temple of Dawn scenic architecture by the banks. One of Bangkok’s most famous landmarks , the Wat Arun is best known for its massive prang, a tower on the Chao Phra river bank built in Khmer architectural style. The prang with its height of more than 80 meters is the highest in Thailand. The Wat Arun, commonly known as “the Temple of Dawn”, is one of only six temples of the highest grade of the first class Royal Temples, and therefore one of Thailand’s most revered temples.There was renovation works going on when I went this Feb 2016 so I jus walked around the temple and took some stunning views snaps.Wat Arun temple can be better enjoyed in the evening. The prang or the tower was raised to its current height of over 80 meters. The Khmer style tower is decorated with millions of small pieces of colorful Chinese porcelain, which in those days used as ballast on ships from China.A steep stairway on the side of the prang leads up to a terrace. You can climb the stairway giving a nice view of the river and surrounding area. Because the stairs are very steep and narrow it is not possible to go all the way up. Around the main prang are four similar smaller prangs. Although the Wat Arun is known for its impressive prang there are other buildings that are worth investigating. The main prayer room holds the principal Buddha image of the Wat Arun. Around the central prang are four mondops or pavilions enshrining Buddha images representing four important occurrences in the life of the Buddha,namely birth, first sermon in Sarnath to five monks, enlightenment and passing into final nirvana. The cloister of the temple complexbcontains more than 100 Buddha images. A mondop houses a copy of the Buddha’s footprint. A number of very large guardian statues in the Wat Arun are very similar to those in the Grand Palace. On the river side you will find a number of salas (open air pavilions). The Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn is located on Wat Arun Amarin Road on the West bank of the Chao Phraya river,opposite the Wat Pho temple and the Grand Palace. The best way to get there is by boat. Take a Chao Phraya express boat to Tha Tien pier at the Grand Palace on the East bank of the river. From there, cross the river with the Tha Tien express boat. During the short ride you will have excellent views and photo opportunities of the huge Wat Arun prang.

SKIPPED It this time!. I decided to skip visiting this temple when I saw it covered with "scaffoldings" as we passed by it during our boat ride along the Chao Praya River. There are so many temples in Bangkok that are not undergoing renovations, so I suggest visiting them first if you're so inclined to visit as many temples in Bangkok as possible.

Worth a visit if you like ancient ruins. Very interesting. Similar to Anghor Wat style in Cambodia but smaller and more ruination. Be warned though it can be very hot there in April, with little shade.

Stunning, one of my favourites. I do not know what exactly captivated me here, but this is definitely one of my favourites in Bangkok. So beautiful, serene and peaceful.One big "chedi" (the Thai word for "stupa") with four other main temples around, each one with a little shrine with a Buddha statue at one of the various stages. The reclining Buddha is the stage of all knowledge and "nirvana".The pieces of broken colorful pottery and the various ornaments and statues are so beautiful and unique, very pretty.Walking around is about an hour and then I walked onto the river side and crossed the river to Wat Po and the Palace. It was a lovely short crossing and the cost was 3 Baht (around five or ten pence). The crossings are regular and are the best way to get back to the old city.Stunning place, I would grant it number two attraction in Bangkok, the Grand Palace being number 1.The main Chedi is being renovated and will be done by "Fall 2016". However you can still see all the detail, just not climb to get a view from the high steps.Highly recommended to visit.

nice place. Wat Arun, the Temple of Dawn, is Bangkok most famous landmark next to the Grand Palace, located on the Thonburi west bank of the Chao Phraya River. It consists of a high central prang (its height is reported by different sources as between 66 and 86m), surrounded by four smaller prangs. All of them are all decorated by seashells and bits of porcelain which have been previously used as ballast by boats coming to Bangkok from China. The ashes of King Rama II are buried in the base of a presiding Buddha image.

Under restoration. Currently under restoration, so a bit of a disappointment, but like most temples in Thailand, worth seeing. Near the river, so just the experience of getting to it is sort of an adventure.

under construction when we went. This wat is on the other side of the river bank, a THB3 boat ride from the Wat Pho pier. It was under construction when we went. The inside is pretty and outside there are souvenir stalls as always and local people selling food and drinks. This wat is actually the one pictured on most Bangkok brochures and it's like the Eiffel Tower of BKK.

Beautiful temple in the middle of Bangkok. Beautiful temple in the middle of Bangkok. Very colorful and peaceful. To add to the experience, take a boat to get there (tip: take the commuter boat which is cheaper than the tourist boats despite going to the same stops). Note: The main temple is undergoing restoration in April 2016, so there are scaffolds up all over the place.

Beautiful place. I went during one maintenance time, but even like this i saw a lot of beautiful things. Its important to read a little about before so you will appreciate the structure better and enjoy more the beautiful location next to the river. Like in the other Buddhist place remember to avois the use of short and little shirts. use confort and fresh fabrics covering your arms and legs.Impossible to skip :)
Amazing. Very interesting and just beautiful, cheap to visit and a enjoyable few hours. Great little cafe for refreshments.

Restoration work was taking place. Restoration work was taking place and the temple was surrounded in scaffolding and tarpaulin. We did still walk around the grounds and managed to get some good photos

A nice temple, however still under renovation for the two coming years. The temple of dawn is so called because of its ingrained decoration which is supposed to make it shimmer in the sunrise or sunset. Sad to say, but I have been several times to shoot pics of the sunrise at dawn, and I cannot really agree that there is a shimmering. I would however recommend being there by 5.30 to shoot some of the wonderful dawn skies.if you go around 5.30-6 Am, you will be rewarded with wonderful pics (the very first time I had been there, I had been able to shoot young novices going out for alms collection, but never saw them again). Some times, Wat Arun has some colored lightings (but honestly, they just make ugly a building which is ok by itself). The temple itself opens towards 8 AM, and you must pay to enter the pagoda itself (I didn't do it) if you are a foreigner. Right now, the temple is filled with scaffolding which take away a lot of the beauty of the monument, and these renovation works are going to last for another 2 years. Depending on the moment of the year, you might This being said, pics of sunrise over the Chao Phraya are lovely to shoot, and if you linger in the area, you may find monks receiving alms from the locals.

Beautiful temple complex - must see. The Temple of dawn is the most impressive and beautiful temple complex I saw during my visit in Bangkok.It's one of the oldest temples around the city and offers a lot to explore.Various areas in the complex have information to absorb and historic facts to indulge in.Like all other temples it's worth coming early if you wish you have a little less of a crowded experience.However, the temple itself is most beautiful during sunset hours and with its illumination in the hours without daylight. This is a decision to be made beforehand - or two visits to be scheduled.In any case, this temple is an absolute must-do on any Bangkok visit.Easily reached with taxi - or best with a water transport (either a private one or one of the public transports).

Absolutly Beautiful. The Temple is breathtakingly beautiful. beautiful view from the bottom and top of the temple. You get a view over a part of Bangkok and the river. entry tickets are cheap. we were lucky to come at a time where there were not to many people.
Beautiful. What a stunning temple. Really loved this one. Most beautiful at sunset. And great to just stroll around with your loved one.

Iconic Temple in Bangkok. Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) is one of the most important temple in Thailand, located near Choapraya river and Royal Thai Navy Headquater. It's not far from Hotels area (Bang Rak district) at the opposite of the riverbank ypu can either go here by Taxi or Ferry. Foriegners come here to take picture with this iconic pagoda and also can enjoy wall arts and observ Thais praying here. Nearby area have many Temple, วัดประยูรวงศาวาส (Wat Prayoonrawonsawas) วัดกัลยาณมิตร (Wat Kanlayanamit). Food and drink are easy to find and still cheaper if compare with Bang Rak around here. If you come to Wat Arun by Taxi it's okay just walk from the main street into the little alley, headed to the riverbank or google map it, but not recommend if you drive, no parking. Enjoy your photos, Enjoy history, Not many traffic in neighbourhood, And it's not far from Royal Barge pier, nearby Siriraj hospital, can go there by taxi or tuk tuk, just tell them I want to go to Royal Barge pier (โรงเรือพระราชพิธี) to see Royal Barges closely.

Kinda small. Honestly could have saved the entry fee as there isn't too much to see here. Pay the 3 baht to cross the river from wat pho and then just walk around to see the temple. No real reason to enter.

Amazing view in evening with lights on. By the time i could reach the temple it was closed. But i managed to have its night view. Wat Arun is on the riverside and you need to take ferry to visit the temple. When i visited in January 2016 it was under maintenance. There is an entry fee of 50 Bhat. The nigh view is awesome. If you have opted for a dinner cruise on the riverside side this temple looks stunning.

Impressive Temple. Another impressive Temple in Bangkok. Currently (April 2016) it is under repair/renovations, but this only detracted a little bit from what is an otherwise impressive building and precinct. I recommend a visit, and ticket prices are not overly expensive.

Nice place to visit. I've been here a couple of times and it never fails to mesmerize me. The temple is made of all the broken Porcelain which came as a present to the King. If you visit this temple, remember to bring a camera to photograph the beautiful scenery around the temple.

Beautiful Old structure (temple) . Different facade with compared with other bangkok buddha temples. Restoration and preservation is going on. On the bang on the river of Bangkok. Delightful, must visit.

Amazing!!!. Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) is on the riverside, and it takes a ferry to visit from the other side of river. The temple itself is really astounding and pretty. It's hard to imagine how they built it at first, and their vision for the future.

Still under construction . It may be the best temple in Bangkok,but this was not my impression because all of those scaffolding and workers on almost every of its steps. It is beautiful, but all of its beauty is shadowed by the renovation working that started a long time ago. Take care of those who want to trick you in the streets of Bangkok telling you that "today is the only day that the temple is oppened to visitors(the inside of the temple they mean) and you should hurry to see it" and they offer to call a tuk-tuk for you for a low price and then reccomend a place where you can take a boat just for you and your friends for a small amount of money (3500 bht) taking into consideration that the other boats cost about 6000bht. It's a big trap. A cruise on the river shouldn't cost more than 800 bht/person(and you can easily negociate it at 600)if you want a private boat, or max 100 bht if you take the ferryboat. I enjoyed more the Great Palace and the Wat Pho Temple.
Nice to look at and walk around. Cost 50bt entrance, plus they have long skirts for rent 20bt for girls to cover their legs. This plus Wat pho are a nice afternoon out. Do them both together!

Best in Bangkok . Best in Bangkok as fat as temples goes. Located on the river and easily accessible by boat. Normally a bit quieter then the rest with good view. Unusual colours make this time stand out from the rest Read up on it before visit. Not far from Koh San rd
A Must See. This temple is a short boat ride across the river. Good to do with the Temple of the Reclining Buddha.
Wonderful cultural. Coming from India, we live temples & ancient architecture. I've visited Wat Arun twice. This is a very beautiful temple complex. Definitely worth the visit for culture lovers.

Under construction . Unfortunately we visited when the temple was all under construction. Therefore we couldn't walk up and see the views. I think the tickets might have been discounted for this reason.I'd put it at number 4 of the 4 temples we visited in Bangkok (after wat pho, wat traimit and wat kalayanamit)

Go By Boat!. If you want to see the temples of Bangkok this one is a must & you can get there easily by boat. It's a very impressive temple & if you have the energy you can climb to the top (if dressed appropriately) There are nice gardens surrounding it too & some ATMs if you're running low on cash, plus it is also a short hop to China Town on the way back.

Nice place and view!!! Beware of some locals.... In the middle of water...nice view from outside. Construction work was going on so we could not see much :) You can visit either by road or take a boat. Be careful as there are some people near Grand Palace who pretend to be helpful local and explain you everything, will try and get a tuk-tuk to go to the boat pier, and say that you can take a boat to wat arun and then a 1 hour boat ride (including 20 mins at wat arun). They say it is 800 THB per person which i think is not worth.

Amazing Temple...!!. I was in Bangkok for 5 days in 1st week of April 2016.I found this place to me very impressive and pleasant.Do not miss this temple if you are really interested in exploring Thai Culture along with temples.From my opinion, this temple was even more impressive than the Reclining Buddha Temple.Due to intense heat in Bangkok, always save yourself from Dehydration by drinking water regularly in short intervals and eating less food specially during afternoon.Specially when you are on a city tour, Grand Palace or temples. You might get a hard time struggling to bare the temperature.

Another amazing temple!. You can walk around for hours!!! The architecture is fab and there's a coffee shop that make delicious (typical) Thai ice coffee!!! I got the ferry ride across from the bustling market place where you can, also, pick up some excellent food at a very low cost.

Just another Thai temple. Found this place ok. I visited this place after visiting couple of temples before so found it peaceful and fine. Only thing I did not appreciate is Thai govt has commercialised all temples. For every temple one has to pay a fees. So choose wisely

The climb up and down must be experience!. First: Make sure you wear a pants, one that covers your knee when you go to Wat Arun. It is for respect and also the fact that the very steep stairs that we need to climb up doesn't reprimand us to wear anything shorter. Breathtaking view at the peak. It is easily accessible from the Pier and at a very low cost too. You can travel along the river without going for the Dragon Boat Package. It was a scam as we were charged 1500bht/pax for 1.5hours ride which was book via our hotel. That the MRT to Saphan Thaksin MRT station and get ferry rides from there.

A must see but still third place to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. One of the three sites you probably must see when visiting Bangkok. Most likely you see this on the other side of the river when you visit the Grand Palace. Indeed, you might even think it is part of the Grand Palace as you approach by river and catch sight of its prominent central tower (or prang as it is called in Thai). There's actually a lot more to see than this and it is well worth a visit. The architecture is very detailed and beautiful up close, and you can usually climb at least part the way up, unless the place is under renovation as it was when I visited. The steps are very steep mind you.

Very Interesting Temple Along the River. We took a longtail boat from our hotel to see Wat Arun. It's magnificent structures along the river are very interesting. Everything is covered in mosaics! Very detailed and fun to see.
One of the wonders in the world. This is one sight you must visit if you are in Bangkok. Even now after my visit there I still wonder how they manage to build it.

Been renovating for the past two years. Overtime I have been to this temple for the past two years there has been scaffolding up all around it which kind of destroys the beauty of it all. Other than that, there are lovely gardens around the temple
Great views of the river. Must do.. Definitely stay for the sunset and grab a drink at Eat Sight Story for the complete experience of Wat Arun.

Very cheap to get to and lovely to see. Get the boat form the city across the river to wat arun for 3 baht, only takes a few minutes and they are quite regualar. Its a very beautiful temple although half of it was being blocked off when we were there. I think the work finishes in May? Cheap to get into, best to see at sunset as it looks so pretty

Under Construction :-(. We enjoyed the views of the temple but it is hard to feel the energy of the temple with it all being under scaffolding, it is an OK visit but not worth going out of your way for it until the renovations are complete

Rita and Shirley, UK. Used the ferry boat to cross one side of the river to the other, which cost equivalent of 12p. Interesting place full of vibrant colour, however, the Temple itself is closed the public for repair, but the area is still fabulous to look round.

Under Construction. Still under construction but stll worthed to visit. Been there twice and i think the temple looks better then before even there is still massive construction in progress.
You can go by Taxi or by Boat from Central River Station (dont forget to apply sun cream before you go)
The ticket cost around 50THB
Under Renovation. The temple is under renovation from outside.. It affects the photographs of the structure taken from the river or across from the grand palace
Summer Holidays. Worth Visiting a Place during Bangkok Tour. Recommended to be covered along with Grand Palace and Wat Pho

Shame about the scaffolding. This temple is high up on my list of places to see but the extensive renovation works seem to be going on for ages. I took the ferry from across the river (from the Grand Palace stop, 3 baht one way) and paid 50 baht to see some of Wat Arun. I will try again in a few years when it's ready, it must be really beautiful in full splendor.

Beautiful Very hot but worth it!. Wat Arun is the tallest temple in Thailand, It is very sophisticated how the ancient Thai people build it and I cant believe it has been built more than a hundred years ago. Love it!

A temple you have to see. Great temple to se while on a boat trip. Take a boat that stops here. So fun to climb up the stairs, and had a hards time getting down because it was so scary. Do not take small children up the stairs. There is no emergency exit if you are to scared to walk down.

The temple of dawn is an absolute must. The iconic temple of wat Arun is perhaps thailand's most famous landmark and a must see for any visitor to bangkok.The distinctive architecture and mosaic covered spires which reflect the sun give the stucture a unique luminescence. Set along the river arriving by boat is a wonderful way to arrive at the site

Undergoing Maintenance. We visited this a few days ago. You can imagine it in its full glory, it's huge! However it is currently 80% surrounded by scaffolding and the surrounding areas are a building site. It's a shame we still had to pay to have a look around. Maybe this review was a little unfair. I'll let you decide! Better know before you go, right!

Breathtaking views. This temple is worth seeing. At the top of the central element of the temple, we have a great view of the Chao Praya River and the Grand Palais. Just on the other side of the river, when you visit the Grand Palace, it is easy to access and is not very long to visit. To see the sunset for photos breathtaking.

A landmark oin the Chao Praya - Wat Arun 2 hundred yeras of history. Yes, March 2016 Wat Arun is a big working place. But it's a beautyful temple with lot's of interesting Details, when works are finished. Best to reach with the boat. Nice when illuminated in evenings or at sunset. A must on your first trip to Bangkok.
Good but under renovation. This temple is amazing but it's under renovation in 2016. It has been decorated with the broken ceramics brought from China during 18th and 19 th centuries.

Over the river from Wat Pho. Travel on the Express Boat to Pier N8 and take a very cheap ferry across. This temple is being extensively restored at the moment and many parts were not available. There is a reduced entrance price of 50 bahts.
Awe inspiring views. I have to say that the Temple of Dawn is amazing. I loved everything about this adventure and the tour guide we had hired to see it and to explain what were experiencing.

what Wat. If your spending time at the Grand Palace just pop across the water on the ferry to see Wat Arun unfortunately at the mo it has a lot of scaffolding errected carrying out repairs so that will spoil the photo shots but still nice to walk around and doesnt take that long either .

Amazing design. When I visited the place, it was under repair so I didn't have the chance to climb on the temple. I was, however, able to roam around the gardens surrounding the temple. Nevertheless, the temple's architectural design is still amazing!

Poetic and simplistic temple architecture . Wat Arun is located across the river from Wat Pho but is extremely different in style and impression. You can easily reach the site by ferry across the river from Wat Pho (only 3 Baht). The site consists of a simple temple ground with statues of Buddhas in vestibules surrounding the temple hall. These are burial sites with pictures of the passed family members under each Buddha statue. A monk was sitting on a raised platform inside the temple giving blessings to the devotees. Adjacent is the temple ground with a central enormous stupa which is a spectacular architectural statement, unfortunately currently under major renovation. Smaller ceramic tile decorated stupas surround the large stupa. Both areas are worth a visit and provides quite different impressions and experiences.

good. After the Wat Pho and Grand palace (wat phra kaew) if you have time this is the 3º most important place in Bangkok. Absolutely worth it. Some structures aren't reconstructed, and is nice to see how used to be.

Wait until the reconstruction will finish. At that time in November 2015, the temple was under renovation, so, actually you can not climb the temple for the views. Every way was blocked, so tourists can only walk close to it.

under renovation but still worth a visit. the fact that we didn't get to climb up to the top :( most of the main parts in the temple was under construction so be careful when walking. still we climbed to one part of the temple which wasnt under construction and from there the view was amazing. it was about 5pm and the sun was starting to set. sky was really beautiful and had it been no construction view would be nicer. id be back
Old place. it was so great place to see and visit you feel the history there you can take a look from inside and take photo as well

Spectacular. We visited temple while it was being renovated, scaffolding etc. Even in that situation Wat Arun is in credible. The architecture is so incredible! Walking up to the different levels and reviewing this unique building and it's fantastic views is fantastic. Lovely garden area, small temple to make offering and light a candle. You will remember this one for a very long time.

My favorite in Bangkok. The 'temple of dawn' the Wat Arun is the country’s highest. Its built in the Khmer style of architecture, but what I love the most is the colourful porcelain pieces--millions of them--that were apparently imported from China. I've never seen anything else like it. It's a steep climb, but worth it to see the city from about 60 meters above the river! It's under renovation at this time (2016), but go anyway and return on your next visit to see it in all its glory!
A must to visit. Perfect riverside location and a intresting place to visit.Take the ferry across the river for a interesting view and visit, climb to the top to get a even better view.

Restoration ongoing but still stunning. As with many temples you will need to cover yourself (available to hire on entry - inexpensive) and its a super place even with the building work. Have a good wander and check out the priests quarters, fascinating.

Under renovation :(. The cab driver we flagged down didn't seem to really know where the temple was, which was funny since this was one of the most famous landmarks photographed in BKK. Regardless, we found our way there, and he was patient enough and nice enough to ask for directions from other locals... Only for us to realise the temple was under renovation since february. We couldn't climb up the whole temple but was able to make some prayers and be blessed by a monk. This is definitely on my friend and my "to-return" list.

Temple . Another must see in Bangkok. Rember to where pants and dress respectful at the temples. You can fit the Grand Palace, Wat Po and Wat Arun all in one day. Get all the Thai history and culture you could want. Warning** where comfortable shoes, walking walking and more walking in the heat!

Awe and simple. We got ever so slightly ripped off by tuk tuk drivers and boat person, if you take a boat they will charge you a docking fee, don't let anyone tell you that the bridges are shut and that the only way to the temple is via boat, this is simply a lie! Other than that the temple is breathtaking!!
From the river. We only saw this from the riverside, because it is under renovation. Nice view from the river, but the work is very visible..
Peaceful. This temple is on the other side of the river and is a very quiet place to visit. It is under renovation currently so could not go inside but you can roam around in the area.
Genial. Really nice place. It was under construction when we got there, but even though it was really cool to visit. It is easy to get there by the public boats

Just across the river. Unfortunately, most parts were under construction when I visited, but I could tell why it was such a popular place for watching the sunset.You can take the steps all the way to the top and watch the sunset over the Royal Gardens, which is simply gorgeous!
Peaceful and different. Nice place, quiet and no crowds. Unfortunately can't climb Stupa now. Not a lot else to see here though.

too bad to miss it due to renovation. we really wanted to visit the place from inside but reaching there by the ferry we saw construction work going on from outside, surely its for making it much better. We gave it a miss and did wat Pho and the palace instead. Would love to see this on the next visit.

The second best in town. Very special place to see when you reach the river bank. For very low boat fare (5 Bt) you face the majestic temple. Unfortunately under reconstruction during my visit but still impressive.
Stunning view, cool breeze.. The temple situated on the bank of Chao Phraya river. The view from the top of the pagoda is totally stunning. Love it!
Worth the visit . Take a long boat from the Taksin pier. You can also incorporate a sightseeing tour as well and hire a private boat. Have lunch at a floating market during the tour well worth it.

Beautiful coloured porcelain on the temple's exterior. Wat Arun, or the Temple Of Dawn, is a temple that lies along the banks of the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok. The temple gets its name from the rising sun and dates back to the 17th century. The central tower is made from coloured porcelain. One of Bangkok's prettiest temples. One can climb up the steep steps and go up the tower. However, if one is scared of heights, going back down is a scary experience!

Renovation in progress. This could have easily been our favorite temple we visited, but there were extensive renovations underway when we visited in early March 2016. The ticket price should have reflected that, but there was no discount. That being said, what we could see and do was stunning. Exquisite carvings and craftsmanship. There were very few people there because, I'm sure, they knew what we didn't. If you're going from the Grand Palace, take the boat for 3baht across the river.
Worth a visit if you're on the river. Worth a visit if you're on the river. It was under repair whilst we were there. However, the mosaics on the towers are very impressive.

Under renovation at the moment. Visited Wat Arun in March 2016 for a family vacation and came to kknow that the temple is under renovation. So we decided not to visit the temple.But as I wanted to capture Wat Arun, I went to the park beside Chao Phraya River , opposite to Wat Arun. I got an amazing view of the temple during sunset and got some superb clicks.There are restaurants like The DECK in Arun residence, where you can get good food and a good view :)But we decided to enjoy the local street food which are available in plenty near the park, and enjoyed the cool breeze of the river and offcourse the sunset from Wat Arun. Really a breathtaking site to see.
Under Renovation but still Majestic. Looks great from the outside. The whole thing is under renovation. It's still a sight to see. I wouldn't advise trying to go in until it's finished.

Under construction but still amazing!. Let me start off by saying I want everyone to have a great trip so please message me if you have any specific questions! I just to Bangkok March 12-20, 2016.We did this tour along with our long tail boat tour and it was great! Again, it was a private tour. But because it has just one main building, doesn't need that much time.Our tour guide gave us maybe a 10 minute talk about the temple and then gave us another 30 to hang out and take photos. As of March 2016, it is under MAJOR RESTORATION. They are repainting the entire monument by HAND! I would NEVER suggest to skip something just because it's under renovation. Most of the temple is still open and it is still worth it. You are able to climb the temple still. just not to the top as I hear you're able to. Absolutely stunning! I'm sure it will be even more amazing when it is completed, especially at night!Time: About 30 minutes.

The temples are amazing!. The most interesting thing right now is the construction going on at the attraction. Not only are doing repair work, but they are cleaning the outside of the temple ...the years of dirt and grime that is being removed is fascinating.

Unfortunately under construction (March '16). We were really disappointed when we visited Wat Arun because there were construction works going on meaning we couldn't climb up and also the overall distinctive look gets lost of course when covered in construction scaffolding.

A must-visit temple. Wat Arun is one of the temples that I enjoyed the most in Bangkok. It is located away from the tourist center and you can reach it by boat. The temple is decorated by bits of multi-colored porcelain and it also looks wonderful at night, when it is lit up.I recommend you to enjoy the climbing and the scenery surrounding! It is worth climbing as you can admire the city from above and the Chao Praya river.

One of the hightlights of river boat tour. Go early, before tourist groups come, it is easy to plan your temple tour via good ferry boat system like hop on hop off self guided tour. Very nice mosaic works in early sunlights.

It will be really lovely when it is completed. You need to pay 3 baht for the ferry to bring you to across the river from Wat Pho. The temples are still under renovation so you may not be able to go inside. But there still look lovely from the outside. It will definitely be very beautiful when the renovations are completed.I liked the dress up station outside the temple. I paid 150 or 200 baht (can't remember), and they dressed me up in their traditional Thai costume. The man even helped to take many photos, both on my phone and camera. And even taught me how to pose. It was a very nice experience.

Iconic Bangkok. A visit to Bangkok MUST include a stop at the Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun). Imposing architecture and vibrant ambience. Unfortunately, the main 'tower' was under construction when we visited, so the temple was not lit up at night...it is supposed to be very beautiful...
Under renovation so avoid in 2016. Went there in march 2016, but the temple is under renovation, so you are not able to see or climb it. The rest of the ground are worn down and not worth the time.

Great by the sunset. Amazing view from across the river (i.e. same side as Wat Pho) during the sunset. It is all lit up. Great time to take photos. Do take a sarong to cover yourself if in shorts/tank tops.

Temple undergoing renovation. We had planned to visit the temple but decided to skip it when we realized that it was surrounded by scaffolding. From a distance it is like any other Wat in Bangkok and would definitely be worth a visit on another occasion once the renovations are done.

Extremely Beautiful . It was very busy when I arrived here, many tours. The outside walls where part of what makes this place special, the many outstanding structures within the walks made the visit worthwhile
Under construction. We where unlucky and the whole thing is under repair and couldn't see much.. recommend taking the boat instead of driving
nice temple. if you want to visit this temple you need to take the tourist boat across chao praya river! nice exerience, but the temple was under maintenance.

The beautiful 'Prang' with 67 meter height. This temple is located on Chaophaya river bank. Once you visited 'Wat pho', you should walk from 'Wat pho' to the jetty name "Tha Tien" ride the boat across the Chaophaya river to "Wat Arun" (fee 3 THB/person)

Temple under renovation. Visitors are only able to view the Temple of Dawn as it is currently under renovation, hence not able to climb the stairs to view the design and architecture. Still worth a visit though.

Much less crowded than other places. Beautiful to see from afar at sunrise/sunset, and less crowded to tour during the day.It's an easy and cheap boat ride after talking around the Royal Palace/Wat Pho areas. Make sure to use a map app as it was a little difficult to find the correct road for the entrance. The architecture was beautiful and intricate. Maybe only about 20 people walking around the temple. Not a very big area but alot to see.Maybe not as exciting during the day but worth a tour to get away from the crowds.
Under construction. Probably would have been very nice and cool to see but it was under construction the day we was there! Disappointing, but I guess it needs to be done
A brilliant Temple to see!. A short trip across the water on a river ferry, cheap at 5tb each. A large site with plenty to see and a lovely cafe in a park where you can rest and have an ice cream.

Lesser visited?. This temple is wonderful to see. The biggest tower is currently under tarp for renovation but don't let that deter you. It is up river (take the river taxi from Oriental Hotel Pier) and on the other side. So you will see a bit more than you thought. What I liked the most is that the Chedi Towers are mostly mosaics from China plates and saucers of the royal family (?). The river taxi is fun and cheap. Have some coins with you for the fare. Just get on the taxi and sit down. Some surly person will soon be standing next to you shaking a Pringles type container in your ear. Ha. That's your cue to pay up.

Good considering the ongoing work!. The main wat here is covered in scaffolding at the moment for maintenance work, which gives it an extra interest to see the painstaking work that goes into cleaning these things up. What has been completed looks so white and shiney. It was a pity not to get into the main wat, and the view from our hotel across the river was nowhere near what it is when it is clear. The small temple with the emerald buddha was my favourite of my whole trip to Thailand, there is something quite humble about him compared to some. The market stalls within the enclosure was a bit disconcerting....all selling the same things...I don;t know how they are all surviving. This Wat compared to all other we saw actually had more sellers than any within the grounds....I wonder if it is to pay for some of the work but couldn't be sure. There were massive incense sticks burning as well, and decorations seems to be up with Chinese New Year in mind.Overall a lovely spot, and the boat trip across the river fun!
Under construction.. This would be a great place to see but at the moment it is under some sort of construction. Not sure how long it will be like this.

Take a ferry over and do explore even though there are ongoing renovations!. The ferry is extremely cheap and an interesting experience but make sure to arrive at the right pier! Although the temple is under renovation, one is still allowed to roam around and climb the stairs as only certain parts are shut off!
Quite different from other temples. This is really interesting as the tempel is completely different than what you usually see and you have much more space and less visitors

Peacefull temple. If you want to go to this Temple, you have to take the boat to cross the river! The boat is only 3b and is a shortcut if you come from the royal palace. You see another side of Bangkok as well if you take the boat. The temple was under construction when I went there, but it was still absolutely beautyfull! It's really peacefull and quiet here, something I didn't expect to find in Bangkok. The biggest part is free (rare in Bangkok).

nice temple. Wat Arun..its Located on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River, this temple can be reached either by Arun Amarin Road or by boat from Tha Tien Pier, near Wat Pho. The Tha Tien express boat pier, at the southwest corner of the Grand Palace or Wat Phra Kaew, is diagonally opposite Wat Arun and boats ply at very frequent intervals. You can get to Tha Tien on the Chao Phraya River Express boats from any other pier, or take a taxi to it. The temple is open to the public daily from 8.30 a.m. to 5.30 p.m.

Renovations, but still worth the trip!. They are currently renovating, so you can't get to the higher levels, but it was still worth a trip. The day and time we went (a friday mid afternoon) was not crowded at all and it was a very pleasant temple trip. I was able to rent a skirt to wrap around my shorts, which was very convenient.

Temples and more temples!. Started our sightseeing trip here. Walked around he grounds and got some great pictures. Since its across the river from Wat Pho just take the boat taxi for 20 baht and continue to explore all the beautiful temples Thailand has to offer.
spectacular. Like most Thai temples, this one is over the top but what a top!!!! The spires are truly inspirational.

Beautiful !. I enyojed looking at such a beautifully ornamented place, the surroundings places are also full of beauty and generation for the Buddha. After a short ferry crossing the water, you have very nice areas to enjoy. I recommend to stop by.
Nice buildning. Unfortunetly they are renovating the building for the moment until end of 2016. So dont be dissapointed if the buildning doesnt look like in pictures

Grand temple with splendid pagoda. This place was under restoring when we visited this Febuary. But we were still shocked at the splendid pagoda, which is decorated with colorful glass, ceramics and sculptures. I think it deserves the reputation of Thai Eiffel.
Bangkok's landmark. I cherish the place. To me it epitomizes the essence of Bangkok. Sadly the higher levels of the building are now out of reach due to the refurbishment process.
What arun. Stunning icon very tall best part of the temple of dawn main attraction here with other buildings surrounding it

Must Must See. Our guide just about had apoplexy when I said I was getting tired of temples - the same but different she said (I also don't visit churches in Europe anymore). This is an amazing temple to visit - even with the main structure mostly covered up for restoration work. No matter how templed out you feel - go see it!
nice temple. currently temple is under construction (upper levels) but still it is nice view . good placement, in front of Wat Pho - You can get there from Wat Pho by ferry for 3 BTH

Nice temple.. This place is currently being restored so it is impossible to see it at it best. Still worth take time here you have time. If you are tight for time there are other temples in the same area which are equally impressive.
Beautiful. We took a boat ride on the river to arrive at the Temple of Dawn. It was very pretty. Unfortunetly there was a lot of construction when we were there but it was still a great sight to see.

Nice place to visit. Beautiful scene.. There is enterance fees 50 Baht. When I go visit the temple is still under maintenance. After maintenance, I guess it will be more beautiful. The temple will still on the golden light during the night time. It is good place to visit. During the visit please dress up politely. There is some rules you need to follow. It is a respect for local culture. I will visit again in future.

My favourite temple in Bangkok!. Just go! Amazing temple, great location, cheap and really beautiful! Great for sunsets. Find a place on the other side of the river and watch the sunset with Wat Arun in the background!

My favourite Temple. I love visiting this temple. It's across the water from the other famous temples and it's worth it. I would recommend getting a river taxi across, lots of fun and very cheap.
Climbing the sides of the temple is lovely.
It's nice and quiet so gives you a good bit of downtime from the hustle and bustle.
Good. Good to see. It was way too hot and crowded when we went there and also very confusing. However The place and its architecture is breathtaking.
being renovated. we went up the river and saw that the temple is being renovated and has a lot of scaffolding around it, will look great when finished though!
Nice to visit. It was very nice to visit this temple again. It was a pity that the chedi was under construction. Now you can not visit the highest level. It is still a very nice temple

Under construction. My husband and I visited Wat Arun on May 14. The site was under construction and the bottom layers of the temple had scaffolding placed around it. However, it was still worth a visit. We took a lot of pictures of the architecture. If you are into art and architecture, it is a must see!

Way less crowded than other temples in Bangkok. Very nice and quiet temple in Bangkok. In order to get the you have to take a boat over the river for 3 THB. They leave every couple of minutes. Unfortunately the main part of the temple is under construction until early 2017. Otherwise it is a nice place to watch the sunset over the city.In any case I highly recommend visiting this temple if you only have time for one since it is barely visited by tourists and nice and quiet.

Visit during the day but get a view of it at night. We knew ahead of time that Wat Arun was having work done on it when we would be visiting Bangkok. that did not deter us from visiting the grounds as part of a tour where we chose what we wanted to see (check out Your Thai Guide on tripadvisor). the company also informed us about the temple work. our guide, Nina, even recommended during our visit not to stand too close to the scaffolding so as to avoid any possibility of falling objects. Luckily we did not see or hear any falling objects. Due to the modifications taking place the grounds are not as busy. Despite the scaffolding you still can appreciate the shape and construction of Wat Arun. The temple grounds are not large and as many people realize you must traverse the Chao Phraya River to get to Wat Arun. As this was our first foray to Bangkok I do not know if the innards of the temple are normally open to the public or not. There is a smaller temple on the grounds closer to the river's edge where you can be blessed, for a small donation, by a monk who will also apply a colorful wristband on you. One can also catch a longboat in front of the temple. Now let's talk about the night view. As with many of the temples in Bangkok they are lighted at night and Wat Arun is stunning in its orangish glow. Alongside the river there are probably many places to be able to view Wat Arun at night but we were fortunate to view the night version of Wat Arun from The Eagles Nest at Sala Arun, which is a rooftop bar directly across the river. Absolutely a view to die for. For all the temples in Bangkok I wanted to see Wat Arun and Wat Saket.

Nice surprise. This monument was one of my favourites to explore in Bangkok.First the river crossing was a very nice experience. To see all the water traffic so close was great.Being close to Wat Arun you can see all the magnificent details in its construction, and then you can climb the big steps to the top and see the city from a higher place.Finally from the other side of the river it was really enjoyable to watch the monument at dusk until its illumination comes on and turns it a golden marvel.

Beautiful and historic. An extremely popular attraction! go first thing to avoid the crowds and take full advantage of the architecture. Dress conservatively otherwise you will have to borrow clothes from the hire office. Reasonably priced and worth a couple of hours walk around to fully appreciate.
Lovely but under renovation . Stunning place, no doubt. We happened to visit while temple underwent a large revocation, which took away some of the impact for us.

Currently being renovated. Since the main structure is being renovated, there's not much to see here. The weather being crazy hot right now, you wouldn't even enjoy much of whatever's there. Check up or find out about the renovation before visiting this temple.

Lovely, peacefull place. We had to cross river with the boat which was an atraction itself, it cost only 3bhat.
You can walk on temple grounds, loads of space, most important its not crowded so you can enjoy beautifull temple and garden surrounding it freely.
Amazing temple - under construction. Amazing structure of course but lots of construction underway at the moment. Were unable to climb steps. Lots of scaffolding.
Impressive to look at, not much to do. Wat Arun is a nice stop before or after the Grand Palace. The temple is impressive to look at but the attraction didn't offer much else to do.

Being renovated . It's a beautiful and intricately built complex, however be aware that the main stupa is undergoing a much needed renovation. This means you cannot climb to the top and you will not be able to enjoy the main sight of the attraction to its fullest

Under Renovation. To get here, you have to cross the Chao Phraya River using a boat from nearby pier. We got there from Tha Tien Pier and paid for 50 minutes visit to Wat Arun. The temples was quiet and not too crowded. Unfortunately it was under renovation when we visited the temple. But still, it was a good visit for us. There are some tenants outside the temple area that sell souvenirs and foods.

Sadly under construction . Visited the Temple as part of an arranged boat trip from our hotel. It was the first time we had visited a Temple. The details are beautiful however it was a real shame that there was a lot of construction happening. Of course this can't be helped but check before hand. In order to avoid paying extra for a sarong make sure you are wearing long sleeves and either jeans or a dress/skirt below the knees.

beautiful place to visit. the ticket 50B. On the entrance you can hire scarfs to cover arms and legs if you are female. Beautiful temple located on the west bank of Chao Phraya River. After visiting the temples, on the way at the end is a shopping market and boat stop. We took a boat to see a floating garden. They left us in the place we wanted to stop (Wat Pho). The price for 6 people was the cheapest. the single fare for one person was much expensive.

Closed but still must pay???. The grounds of the temple are open but once you get into the temple area, you have to pay to get in, which is fine but the temple itself is going through restoration and won't be completed until mid next year. So not sure I would pay to go in. But it is one of my favorite temples in Thailand.
Renovation is going at present . Not worth to visit as we can't enter in the main temple. Near to reclining temple. Just across the river. But a small place to spend one to two hrs.
Under reconstruction . Beautiful place but unfortunately it's undergoing construction so you can't walk up in the tower or take the great photos since it's all covered in scaffolding.

Under Maintenance - March 2016. It's under maintenance so there are construction structures all around the temple and you can't go up. There's a ferry that take you to the other side of the river ($3,00 baht) to the wat pho and grand palace station.
You can also dress have a photograph taken of you in ancient clothes.

Unusual Wat. You can see this wat from the river, but it's worth a trip. The artwork is really unique and beautiful and so are the grounds. You can climb the stairs and get a nice view of the river also.

Incredible detail.. Wat Arun was undergoing restoration work but was still great to see. The amount of work and detail put into the buildings is incredible and it s a short boat ride across the canal from the Grand Palace or Wat Pho.

Nothing special, better looking in a night time. The temple looks huge, and it really is, but it is nothing inside. So it is not worth to get to the opposite side of the river just for visiting Wat Arun. In the night time it is well illuminated, and it is nice to see it from the river bank.

Under construction. It is easy to get there by local boat, for 3 bahts. I think, we get discount, pay only 50 bahts fir the entrance, because the wat is under construction. The wat is small, than it is enough only 15 min to see it. If I know, I do not come here, the wat pho is more more more better, even the best in Bangkok.
Very grand. Best to reach by river tram/boar. Currently some renovation work taking place. Nevertheless attractive place to visit.
Supurb. A fantastic temple, with some wonderful photographic opportunities, I recommend taking a zoom lens to capture the detail of the architecture.

Wat Arun (still on restoration) BEWARE THE BOAT FARE!. Beautiful temple with ceramics detail on the wall. It's too bad the main temple is still on restoration.You can go there from Sathorn pier near saphan taksin BTS station. Get on boat from there and stop at Tha tien pier. THIS IS IMPORTANT! There's 3 shuttle pier on Sathorn. On the left it's pier for free shutle boat to Asiatique. On the middle is where you can get a public boat that cost only about 13 baht per person, you will PAY ON THE BOAT. Don't pay a ticket from the pier, it's expensive and its for a tour with longtail boat. On the right side, its a pier with a 100 BAHT TICKET PER PERSON! So remember to take the middle pier, and PAY THE TICKET ON THE BOAT!From Tha Tien pier, you can get a boat to cross the river (because Wat Arun is on the other side) for 3 baht per person.Have a nice trip y'all!

Under construction. This was under construction when we went so we just stayed in the compound outside of Wat Arun itself but you can see it pretty clearly, the temple is amazing. wished we could have gotten inside.

Great time in Temple of Dawn - Wat Arun. By boat, I LOVED TO CLIMB IT :)
GREAT view from up, great spot very on the river, awesome structure and atmosphere.
Dress like royalties. The main temple is undergoing construction but some parts are open. I enjoyed dressing up in colorful and fancy Thai national costumes and pose doing their finger thing

Nice temple. We came here during early December 2015, it is very nice especially during sunset time. However, during my visit, the temple was under renovation, lots of scafolding therefore we could not take a nice picture of it;

Too busy to be enjoyable. Unfortunately this should have been a fantastic first introduction to Thai culture and history - we had an excellent guide but it was simply overrun with predominately Chinese tourists - with whom it must be very popular. However with no limit on entry numbers there was very little chance of seeing anything. Large groups of other tourists together are very noisy and stampede to get the best view - avoid unless there is a quieter time.
Wat arun. Very interesting and pleasant site. Better to organise the visit at early morning to avoid the heat. Definitly worth a visit

Under renovation. The entry ticket is 50 baht . you can get a boat to arun from the wat pho for 3 baht. Wat arun is under renovation and was a complete let down given its rating now. There was a small shopping area inside which was decent
A temple must to visit. There are two ways to appreciate this this temple1. By visiting temple during the day2. Sitting at some restaurant across the river during the sunset

Great buildings. Easy to get to across the river from the main travel boats.You can see lots of the buildings but worth the 50 bht to go into the inner courtyard. You can climb part of the temple but when we were there there was a lot of restoration. It was also Chinese new year and it made for a good atmosphere with lots of decorations and lanterns.
Nice. Impressive monument by the river, was a little bit of time to come here but was worth the effort as very beautiful.

Must visit. After a small trip with the boat, we stopped at Wat Arun. Was about 5pm. Really good time to enjoy the lovely color of sunset and it was not busy with tourist. Temple is small and different to others.

Beautiful. Lovely temple with so much history.
Ensure that you are covered (no revealing shoulder or legs above knee caps).
Don't miss visiting. Right by the river you are best to visit by using the water transport, massive structure very impressive but be careful when walking up the outside steps they are very steep.
Lovely temple. This temple is great. Currently it's under refurbishment so not photogenic at the moment but still a great place to visit if you like culture

Steep climbing temple - Currently under renovation. It is on the other bay of the Chao Phraya River and has really steep steps. The temple is currently under renovation and is not open for tourists. March 2016 Update.

Well worth a visit. This Wat is a "must see" in Bangkok, easily accessed from the river. At present it is cloaked in scaffolding, but it is still well worth visiting. It is quieter I imagine because of this, we found it fascinating. The scale of the central tower is impressive and it is surrounded by quiet gardens.
Beautiful monunent. Went here by boat. Beautiful monument that rises high. Great details, worth a visit if you got the time.

Pointless . The whole place is under construction and you basically pay to walk around the outside because they won't let you in anywhere....only you can walk around it for free outside the gate! Paying gains you a few feet closer which makes no difference.They know it's closed to the public, they don't tell you and charge the same. Very disappointing. It's pretty but you can't see most of it due to construction work. I appreciate the work needs to be done but to charge the full price for a tenth of the experience is wrong.According to hostel staff it will be like this for another year.

in construction when we went there. it looks like a beautiful place but unfortunately when we got there it was under construction. I would have loved to see it without the scaffolds but even so it was impressive.

Very Pretty!. We were definitely glad we stopped to see this temple! Unfortunately it was under construction/renovation so the main portion was hard to see. But we were able to explore around the temple grounds and by the river. Would recommend coming before it's too hot in the day!

Really beautiful temple that you have to visit when in Bangkok. When you are in Bangkok, you must visit this temple. It truly is one of the better temples in the city. Be advised that when your legs are not what they used to be, you best not go up the steep stairs.
Good but not amazing. It was part of our temple tour but it wasn't the highlight it was made out to be. They were still doing some renovation work when I was there. It had only recently reopened

Do you like visiting temples?. Take this review with a grain of salt. I am the type of person who prefers being active to visiting a monument.When I do go to a monument, I typically want to get in, take pictures, and get the hell out. The exception would be when I have a really good, fun tour guide.Unfortunately the first time I went here my tour guide was really boring. And the second time I went I skipped getting a guide.I'd recommend getting a guide and hoping for the best. Otherwise get in and grab your photos.To be honest, Wat Arun is really pretty . Unfortunately the main attraction is still under renovation. But even so, it's worth visiting.Also, keep in mind that this is a temple, so dress appropriately.
Beautiful. Amazing, but it is so busy that you cannot wait to get out. Best to get there early in the day. Tae water with you and a cover up

Intricate Details.... Wat Arun is one of those temple you just cannot forget!And as well a very nice boat trip on the other side of the ChaoPraya River! But beware as of the first months of 2016 it is under repairs and not to be visited!
On renovation. Too bad the place is on renovation so not much to see. But still good experience to get there. Quiet and nice garden.

Beautiful Temple. A quick boat ride and you are there, I have visite this a few times and love the fact its a proper old temple with really steep steps and the architecture is breathtaking.A really old temple that is being restored ,it is not very big and would only take 30 mins to visit the whole site so don't bring a picnic :)

Beautiful attraction altho under construction. The temple is a beautiful landmark of Bangkok, but at that time of our visit (Feb 2016), it is still under construction and we were not able to climb up. Enjoyed the cross-over ferry ride from the other side.
Under Construction . Currently under construction so you can't see it, you can get an amazing view from the eagle bar a cross the river on the other side

Beautiful but still under renovation... This temple is beautiful, a landmark of the city, but unfortunately still under renovation when we were there (February 2016). This meant we could not climb up. Still fantastic to see the Chinese porcelain tiling up close. Easy to visit with the cross-over ferry.

Great attraction but spoilt by current scaffolding. Asia regular visitor to Thailand I've been a few times as its a nice attraction to show work colleagues on their first visit. Unfortunately the renovation work take away one of the highlights which is climbing the very, very steep steps to the next level. These have been closed off for over a year now.Just 50 Baht entrance so still definitely worth the visit especially when you look at the 10 times more entrance fee to the grand palace, although both can be done in the same trip because of how close they are to each other.Women must cover their arms but it's ok for men to wear shorts.I'm back again in April so will take my wife their on her 1st visit so that says to all that it's worth a visit.

amazing!!!. visited after sunset, even if closed and could not visit inside, just walking around and by the river was already pretty amazing. Actually after sunset it is much more fascinating given it is very well lit. Recommend to walk by the river and then take the ferry and admire the remple from the opposite bank.
Highly recommended visit!

Serenity, Tranquility to its Finest. . A definitely to go place. The place should be visited during the hours when there are few people. mostly during the Lunch hours (12pm-01pm). Its a place where u can great colonial architecture, colorful backgrounds, the paintings, the sculptures, the various story depictions that tell a story, You Seriously cannot find anything as mesmerizing as this place. Apart from the Grand Palace where its Crowded, you may want to visit this place in the timings mentioned by me above to avoid crowd. Beware of your personal items and commodities, wear full covered clothing on your body, as the entrance is restricted to the people who wear shorts, or sleeveless tops. To avoid getting dehydrated carry a energy drink as I did.

What a nice place on day and night BUT.... This place is the place to see by taking ferry at day and also when night is coming ... But right now it isexpensive visit and all temples are under rework ... Have to wait to enjoy this amazing place. Sorry

Tourist attraction. Cost about 100 baht for the entrance. A place that must visit in Thailand. Full of history and interesting fact about Buddha in Thailand. May spend up to half day if you explore the whole temple. As this is one of the famous tourist attraction beware for the tuk tuk and taxis that may con you for a ride in high price.
Renovation going on. I visited it when renovation was going on. This place is good and since you are in Bangkok, you should do it but I don't feel it stands out as much as the other reviews say.

Under reconstruction. I think currently it is better seen Wat Arun lit up across the river since it is being reconstructed. From farther away it is harder to see the scaffolding and easier to see it's beauty. This was taken from the Eagle's Nest later on and it is my best picture of it. It would be free just to see it from here too.

Should visit. By the time I visited Wat Arun, the temple was redecorating so I could not climb to the top. It was so pity. However, this temple right on the side of the river, so if you take the river tour you should come and visit the temple. I hope now it's done for repair.

Just so beautiful!. Many temples to visit but do not miss this one.It is busy as most temples but well worth the time.The shoes must be removed as all temples. We ended up carrying them in our bag during the visit.

Don't leave Bangkok without seeing !!!!. Take a baot (orange) flag on Chaopraya river and go until Tha Tien ( where you can visit the fantastic Wat Pho. Just take the boat that is crossing the river to the other side and you arrive to this magical place.Nothing to add! You have to come here!Maybe just one thing : behind the Temple an interesting and typically local Bangkok feeling awaiting for you. Take a short walk in the neighbourhood, it's completely different than the other side of the City....
Scaffolding. When I visited in August 2015 the temple had scaffolding on it, therefore couldnt really see the temple and also could not go up it.

Renovation. I still visited Wat Arun (even after reading all the reviews saying it was under renovation). If its on your way (just across the river from Wat Pho/Reclining Buddha), then I still think it's worth it. The central structure is under construction, but the rest is still open and you can walk around the complex. From the Wat Pho side, the boat ride take a few minutes and is 2.5baht. There is a public pier on the Wat Pho side so you can catch the boat back to Saphin Taksin station or other attractions. The Tourist boat also stops at this pier.After the renovation, Wat Arun would be a definite must-see in Bangkok! I would also recommend seeing it at night when its lit up.
Don't Miss It. This is one other do not miss in Bangkok. It is famous, and once you go there, you will understand why. The details everywhere are just amazing.
One of the most importanplaces. It's one of the oldest tourists attractions in Bangkok. It's worth to visit it and see an amazing view from upstairs but the stairs are pretty high.

Under Reconstruction. The almost complete temple has been under reconstruction and is for the time being not worth to visit. Whenever you are in Bangkog City with kimited time, I would not recommend to visit this temple as Long as reconstruction is not finished!

Must see!. The architecture is stunning. I believe the entire temple is hand painted. Please note, women must cover legs and arms in order to go inside. They rent coverups if you forget to wear your own.

In the middle of restoration. Impressive site, and will be amazing after they finish restoration but spire is covered by scaffolding and not accessible to climb or walk around base. Still charging 50 Bart entry but with a look.

Under renovation . So the temple is currently under renovation . The entire upper structure is covered in scaffolding. The lower half of it is however very beautiful . Currently you're not allowed inside the structure. Lovely porcelain covering all of the structures on the small compound . The temple is located across the river from the Grand Palace .. And is easily reached by river taxi for 2.50 Thai bhat each way. At present , I'd say no need to pay the entry fee as you can see all from outside the compound .
Appreciate it more from afar. There's really nothing to see in here but you may appreciate it more when you are across the river specially at dawn.

Currently under renovation. Wat Arun is a nice tower Wat that can cimb to half way point. View from there is nice and have ornaments around the view area that are often used in posters and commercials. However, currently as of Feb 2016, Its closed and covered in scaffolding. So you can see it from outside, but the actual site is closed.

Pretty high strairs. Wow! Rent a national costume in front of the gate and take pictures of it. Climb the stairs up to the temple and see a lovely view. The stairs it self quiet hard to climb but no worry it worth to climb.
Under construction. Visited in Feb 2016, but this was still under construction. Nobody can go up this pagoda at present. It seems to take more time to complete the construction.

Incredible structure. This is the smallest of the temple compounds in the area, but is well worth the short boat trip across the river. It is an imposing and impressive structure which can be partially climbed. There was some renovation going on when we visited which meant certain areas were inaccessible, but this was only a minor inconvenience.

Good place to visit eventhough its under enovation. You will be required to take a small long tail boat (25 baht each way) to cross the river and reach the temple in the blink of an eye. The temple is under renovation, we din get to see the whole area. i believe it will be very beautiful after the renovation and therefore i will definitely come back again.
Temple of Dawn, Thailand. Pretty good hike up to the top. Great view. It took a while to get in. Very clean and pretty hot that day. Lots of architecture and history.
Good visit. A very good visit will take you about an hour or 2 to see everything, theres so may different styles of architecture , its very beautiful and serine

Still nice to see... under construction. I would imagine this place to be absolutely stunning without the construction. I went close to sunset. Took a ferry then a small transfer boar to get there. It's still beautiful.

Unfortunatelly is under rehabilitation. Giving the fact that it's under rehabilitation there are not too many things to be seen here, although the complex itself it's interesting and somehow different from other temples.

amazing building. The temple is along Chao Praya River, downtown Bangkok.It is nice to cross the river with a special small ferry, after descending at ChaoPraya Express stop.The temple is very steep, and the sight from the highest point you can reach is really interesting.
The true Dawn. Just across the river from Wat PO. This is the temple of Dawn. Great architecture and the unique Thai design adds to the reasons to visit this place.

Visit at sunset!. It is a pity most of the facades were wrapped up and being worked on by maintenance staff at the time of our visit. Still it is worth the trip by ferry (2,50b) to have a look (entrance 50b). Especially good looking at sunset.
Still beautiful. Currently under some repairs when I was there. But despite that still worth a visit for the views alone.

Temple. When we visited, the temple was having multiple construction works. Please remember that steps of this temple are pretty steep. We spend sometime around the temple complex. Unfortunately we missed the night lighting.
Not to be missed. This is a huge Wat and is indeed beautiful. We reached via ferry across Chao Phraya.There are a few other Buddha temples apart from Wat Arun within the compound.
Scaffolding!. Need to take the boat to get across the river. Repair work was being done so it was closed. Impressive structures

Beautiful Architecture. The Temple itself is undergoing upgrading when I visited it. Even so, it still worth the visit. Stepping into it brings you back in time with the intricately-sculpted statues around the temple. Ensure that you wear a full-length trousers or skirts when visiting and t-shirts, no shorts, knee-length trousers nor sleeveless. Otherwise you may loan some skirt at the entrance at a certain deposit (which I think is a bit of a hassle). I'd love to be back when the upgrading is finished.
One of the most visited place in Bankok. You can plan this place along with the Grand Palace visit. This is just back side of the palace. You will definitely enjoy the art and colors used

Under construction at the moment! . I've been to this wat(temple) any times. Too bad this time is under construction. Normally they allow people to walk higher and you see a better view of what's going on around. Steps are very steep not recommended for people that's scared of height or elderly. You can also check out the river view behind what allow quite nice
Beautiful at sunset. This temple is well worth seeing. It's a very beautiful peaceful location on the banks of the river. We got a local ferry across.

Nice area. Beautiful area as a whole, there is a few things to see here if you have a wonder around, in my opinion you may as well as you have to get a boat over the river to get there and back if you are coming from the east of Bangkok or you could get a taxi but for 2.50 baht it's alot cheaper to cross the river.

Must see!. Among all the beautiful Wats (temples) to visit and see in Bangkok, this was my favourite. The intricacies of the tiling, stone work, walls and towers is breathtaking. While the Wat was under restoration, with some areas inaccessible, you can see the level of dedication and workmanship required to build and maintain this site. If you plan well you can see several culturally important sites on the one day by making use of the many transport options around Bangkok. And this Wat is one of the 'must sees' when you visit this city. Simply stunning.

Very nice. Quite a nice temple and a must see if you like this kind of stuff.
This is a big temple where you can walk around for some time and take some nice pictures.

covered with scaffolding. was supposed to be one of the three temples to visit in bangkok but wat arun is on the other side of the chao phraya river. the other two wat phra kaew and wat pho are located on the same side with the grand palace. you have to cross to the other side with another ferry at another pier and knowing that wat arun is covered with scaffolding, we opted to skip it. a day after, we were on board a dinner cruise on board apsara by banyan tree. the boat approach close to the pier of wat arun and we had complimentary pictures taken. that was the closest i got to wat arun. although it had scaffoldings, it still looked amazing with strong lights shining on it at night.

Being renovated. Wat Arun has a modern taste of culture art. Colora, materials, and shapes are very different from the ancient temples. To reach here, we need to take an open boat to accros the river and very cheap.No BTS skytrain in this area so you might need other public transportation or book a group tour.

Iconic Temple. Another of the iconic temples in Bangkok, one that you see in most of the tourist magazines. This was worth the visit just to see how much workmanship goes into these temples, as this temple was undergoing restortation. You could see the level of dedication being displayed in the intricate work required to attach the very small tiles and stones to the walls and towers.It is easily reached either from the river by boat or from the road by taxi or tuk tuk.

Covered in scaffolding & annoyance at dock. We were disappointed to pay full price to see this temple with so much scaffolding obscuring it's main spire/beauty. That was after we were abused at the dock getting off a long boat and told we had to pay a docking fee? No one told us that when we hired the boat and it is extortion. He literally grabbed my arm and I am an older person. Are you kidding? Couldn't wait to leave.

Under Construction...... Get off the Ferry and Stop #8 (Wat Pho) and either before or after that visit, take the ferry across the River to the Temple of Dawn. Looks beautiful in the pictures but it is totally hidden with scaffolding at this point.
Under renovation. The place is definitely one the highlights of Bangkok. Unfortunately it was closed when we were around. Do check before you plan for it as the works might still be going on.

Waiting for the final renovation. This is a wonderful temple....parts are,fully restored and the huge main tower is now closed for the renovation......The halls of Buddha lined in rows make for some wonderful photos...I have one framed in my house in Vermont, from another visit....do the visit on your own.....a easy stop on the water taxi....it might cost you 15B to get there on the river.....half the fun.......

Beautiful Buddhist Temple. Wat Arun is walking distance from Grand Palace to the small pier where the boat to Wat Arun goes and the boat trip is less than 10 minutes are really cheap.
