Evenings is the best time as at night the surrounding is all dark and though the place is beautiful. There are some cheap souvenir shops around the temple but always remember to bargain.

What a sight when travelling on the river.. We have been here on several trips but it is always under some form of renovation so have never had the chance to see it all in its entirity. The buildings are wonderful and the ceramic detail outstanding but would not recommend seniors to try the climb up the steep steps as they are very narrow and very steep!

Amazing to see, worth a visit. Make sure you are covered up in order to get in, if not you are able to hire coverings for approximately 50thb a piece. At present there is scaffolding on the tallest part of the temple, however this didn't spoil the trip as the real treats are in the buildings to the side of the main temple. Here you will find numerous Bhudda statues and ornate decorations covering every available surface.Leave at least an hour to have a good look around!

Stunning!. Offers something slightly different than other main temples in Thailand, although I am not sure what. Just get a different vibe here. Easy to lose interest in the vast amounts of culture in Thailand but I would recommend this place. Just avoid peak heat and your good to go!

In februar is it renovated. I just wanted to inform that if you pay a visit to this wat around the end of February 2016, you will be a bit disappointed. At the moment it is renovated and it got a all around. I didn't go close it, just drove by, but the scaffold ruins the popular silhouette pictures anyway. Just wanted you to know ;)
currently being renovated. because of renovations you were unable to climb to the top but in saying this it was still nice to walk around and climb to the first level...the market area quite nice

Nice temple by the river. Wat Arun is on the Thonburi side "the other side" of the river almost opposite to Grand Palace. It's not as grand as Grand Palace and not as big but it is interesting and well worth a visit. The pagodas are high indeed and you can climb up to the second level if you dare toI recommend to do Grand Palace and Wat Arun on the same day, it's walking distance from Grand Palace to the small pier where the boat to Wat Arun goes and the boat trip is less than 10 minutes are really cheap. Do not take the private boats

Beautiful Even at Night. We saw Wat Arun as part of Grasshopper's evening tour of Bangkok. At night, the place exudes an erie beauty. We had a chance to walk around without the bother of large crowds and get a better appreciation of the art and wonder of this temple.
Temples. Another day another temple. There are many temples to visit in this country. This one is quite interesting & worth a visit. We enjoyed this temple. Check it out.

Under construction. The temple is under construction at present. But they still charge you the full 50 baht to enter. I would suggest to wait till it gets completed as at present its not really a pretty sight.I did see stupas with similar characters on it when compared to the grand palace so i did like it. But could not really explore as the entry was limited to a few areas only - could not enter inside and were restricted to the first level.One should also plan to get pics of wat arun from the tan tien pier. Thats the picture that one can find mostly on google when one searches. Evenings is the best time as at night the surrounding is all dark.Tan tien pier runs local ferry to get to wat arun side. Use it as it adds to the charm. Plus there are other piers as well from where there is access and some piers are close to the bts or metro.There are some cheap souvenir shops around the temple. Remember to bargain.
Great architecture. One of the greatest places I have seen. The architecture is prodigious. I was really amazed and highly recommend to visit it.
Architecturally Stunning. When we went main temple was under scaffolding - so waste of 100 Batt. Just walk round the outside, Also no signs in English - so sense of what you are seeing.

Stunning!! Even with the scaffolding! . With a cheap and quick boat ride across the river it's costs 100baht per person to enter. Women must have shoulders and legs covered but men can wear shorts. Wat Arun is so very beautiful even with some restoration happening to the main temple. The grounds around the temple are very pretty and the small market is very cheap. We would recommend to see!!

Visited during evening but could not access due to VIP visit. Visited Wat Arun as part of an evening bike tour. Managed to get some photos but could not enter the temple due to a vip visitor. But I would certainly visit again.
Under Construction. Went there at beginning of February and it was under construction. Not worth paying the money to go inside. Better to just walk outside and do some street shopping.

A nice temple, but not as exciting as expected. The ferry ride was half the fun. This is a short stop visit, as there is not much to do once you have seen the temple. The gardens around the temple are beautiful. The temple has great architecture, but a warning to those who do not like heights, the climb up is on very steep steps. While I was at the top, two girls were so terrified of the steep steps that they were stranded at the top until a nice, older gentleman helped them down.

Beautiful but covered in scaffolding. The temple is undergoing needed renovation and there is scaffolding covering a lot of it. The upside is that the before and after are very visible and there is still plenty of detail to see. Thai artists are restoring the temple and it is interesting to watch them work.

TEMPLE UNDER WORK-YOU PAY TO SEE WORKERS. I was there at the beginning of February. We bought the ticket (not expensive) and when we entered the temple we could see that it is under works. Impossible to visit it, to climb to the top of it, which was our purpose. To get there, we took a boat paying a lot of money just to cross the river, and nobodw told us that WAT ARUN was being restored.

Great. Amazing venue, great architecture, the only bad thing with my visit is that the palace is under renovation and I couldn't see to much. The position near the river that splits Bangkok is very nice. Entrance is 100 bht.

A new dawn. Think of a temple and I think the Temple of Dawn is the type of thing you would expect. At the moment there is a fair bit of scaffolding around the tower as renovations progress, but you get good access - close-up and with not too many crowds! It's great that it is a place of worship and respected by visitors who were much less intrusive than those to the Grand Palace. We visited as a part of a tour including the canals and the Grand Palace and this was one of my favourite parts. We also saw it illuminated during an evening boat trip, though the visibility from the river is restricted by trees.

Short stop on a trip on the River. Was undergoing restoration while we were there, but even under the scaffolding it was beautiful and impressive and the areas that had been completed were gorgeous. Definitely worth checking out

Amazing place in the middle of this hectic city!. The Watt Arun area is definitely a great place to visit; it is a pretty quiet and relaxed spot in the middle of the hectic city. The architecture is amazing and one will be astonished by the love and work that has been put in the decoration of the buildings.

Under extensive renovations. A fascinating temple and very different to all the others we visited. Currently and for some time into the future this Wat is being renovated. Major areas around the site are therefore not accessible.
More to do!. Okay, you've read good reviews about the temple, and now I wanna tell another thing you can do. Take a picture with Thai traditional clothes with Wat Arun as the background.

Impressively High Ornate Temple. Unlike the monuments on the other side of the river, Wat Arun is a real historic monument. It is impressive.The colours appear to be being "restored". This makes for an impressive spectacle. Whether this is the right thing to do is open to debate, but I have to say, it is truly spectacular. Well worth the visit.Transport backwards and forwards across the river was very reasonably priced (3TBH = 6p) and 100TBH to get in (£2).

Temple of Dawn.. This extensive and massive comples known as Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn, is situated on the West bank of the mighty River Chao Phraya, which flows right through Bangkok. The Temple has 4 outer facets, whilst the main part of the Temple is ornately inscribed with a plethora of carved plaques. At the moment much of the complex is under re-construction and cannot be accessed, but it is still well worthwhile a visit.
Another beautiful temple. This is another beautiful temple amongst many in Bankok. The splendor in all of these is unforgettable.

Temple ofDawn in reconstruction!. By our previous visites of Bangkok we always climbed this Temple to enjoy THE beautiful views from upthere. This year we did not visit iT because of THE metal construction around THE Temple !Hopefully iT wil be ready next time!

Good place to visit. I visit in this place with my college while i was in Bangkok and i like the place in this temple very nice statute on their good and one building of the temple is very nice to see from outside well design and look different.
Feb 2016 Under Construction. Much of the main temple was under construction. The grounds were lovely. We attended a monk session and received a blessing.

Grand Palace. The Grand Palace is basically the second half of your visit to Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). Once you have finished visiting the temple, the exit will lead you to the Grand Palace. It is quite nice and well worth a bunch of photos. I went in to some of the buildings as they are basically mini-museums and also interesting.
Currently under renovation . While the Wat is currently under renovation- it is still worth the trip across the river to see it. Usually you can climb to the top, it is closed at the present time.
climb it till end. Oh my climb till end, and wen you come down from top, its absolutely steep, its like almost straight stairs...

Peaceful despite big crowds. It was a pieceful temple despite the crowds. Loved the huge Buddha statue. Please wear modest cloths but be mindful of the hot weather. Its sunny so bring your shades along as well

Beautiful temple but not a must see if travel with kids. Travelled with 2 kids and 2 elderly. Took a scary boat to cross the river to Wat Arun. For me it is pretty much the same with any other temples in Bangkok, but it is consider sacred for local. A bit upset cause the temple is still under renovation and when we took pictures with the temple as a background what we see is pretty much the scaffolding. Probably best to visit at dawn to stay away from the heat.
massive scaffolding covering up the building.. amazing details, but they're currently refurbished the building so there's a massive scaffolding covering up the entire temple.

Dawn is the Name but Sunset is the time for this Wat (Temple). We recently saw it and even with the construction and restrictions, it is worth the 3 bhat ferry ride across the river (Chao Phraya) and the 2.5 ferry ride back to the Tha Tian (Tien?) pier. Of course wear enough clothing to gain entrance after paying 100 bhat fee. Otherwise you pay 20 bhat more to rent clothing to be covered properly. Get there before 6 PM gate closing. When you cross get in the smaller line and look for the small overhead sign that says ferry to the temple. You have to go through a turnstile after paying the fare first. Unfortunately the person who takes your 3 bhat may direct you to the larger public ferry nearby that many use to get back to there hotels or other places. You may have to persist to get on the proper smaller ferry. Otherwise you may take a longer ferry ride only on the east side of the river without the results you desire. A lot less crowds at this temple and we found the monks more engaging. From the nearby park you can watch the lights slowly advance up the temple as it gets dark. May have to wait until as late as 7PM to see the temple fully lighted. Awesome sight every with the scaffolding around it. Last ferry back leaves at 9 PM.

Incredible mosaics. The temple is covered with intricate mosaics that were being refurbished when I was there in January 2016, so they were really amazing to see. One of the temples you don't want to miss in Bangkok.

Under renovation 02.2016. It would be beautiful but its location is not the best. It was under renovation during february 2016. The signs warn tourists that there are some people who try to get money for selling tickets before You could reach the entrance. The entrance fee is 100 BHT but we payed 50 BHT 15 minutes before closure. It closes at 18:00, but they do not let You enter from 17:50.
Family Holidays. One of the Wonderful temples of Bankok.The view from the river is a treat also.We would recommend to visit this temple along with others if time permits.

sanctuary in the city. getting to this temple is a large part of its appeal, from most places in the city it will involve crossing the Chao Phraya river which is part of the adventure. the temple is unusual compared to the many other temples in Bangkok so that in itself makes it worth a visit, but where its located gives a good view back across the river of the city.unfortunately at the moment it is being renovated so the higher tiers are closed off but i think its still worth visiting.

Simply Stunning. The Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) was by far my favorite temple visit in Bangkok. It starts out with a boat ride to cross the river which in itself was a great little ride to get a different perspective from the water.When you get off of the boat you are free to roam around the temple at your own leisure in to which ever direction pulls your attention. Take as much or as little time as you want to see all of the architectural amazement of this beautiful place.There are many buildings and structures that surround the main attraction and temple to keep you awe inspired. Some of the temples you can climb right up and walk through!* Bonus entrance fee is only 50 Baht

Mind blowing. The temple is a place everyone should visit the gold gilding is amazing the peace of mind you feel the workmanship just blows me away you have to see it your self to get the true feeling and that inner peace love it

This ancient temple was on my list of places to visit. The older it is in Thailand the stronger the spiritual energy. This temple was incredible, I really think it is good to have a guide so you understand the historical significance and contemporary use of the temple. I fell in "love with this temple and would go back again.

Thailand has such a diverse range of beautiful temples.. If you are visiting any of the temples, barter around for a good temple guide. Their knowledge of the temples are invaluable and they make the experience 120% more interesting.
The major temples of Bangkok are definitely excursions to put on your list whilst travelling Thailand!

Another must see. You can't visit BKK and not stop in at the Wat Arun. It may not seem all that spectacular compared with some of the glories of the palace, but viewing it from the river as you approach is part of the beauty of this temple. Avoid paying for special private visits to "secret chambers" which are a scam. Peaceful oasis away from the malls and traffic.

Perhaps the most beautiful Temple of them all. The most archetypal image of Bangkok, or at least one of them, and as a result, most photographed and appears on travel film, magazine and guide book everywhere still needs to be visited and can be admired from every vista.Currently shrouded in scaffolding, it's still stunning !
A musst. Really enjoyed our visit. Great view during the river. Take the ferry from what po and visit this magnificent temple just 50baht..

Incredible structure. This was a quick stop of from the river taxi on the return trip from the grand palace. But, it's really worth stopping for.The architecture and carvings are superb. There's lot to observe and meander around. Bring comfy shoes, knee length clothes and covered shoulders. It's easier than not being allowed access to shrines etc.

Completely under construction. I actually love this temple and have been a few times, but there is so much construction going on right now you can't really appreciate it.Lovely to see it being looked after though. The entrance fee should be reduced, whilst construction continues.Good that you can get there on the 3baht ferry though.

peaceful. we took a boat from wat pho to wat arun. it is the cheapest and the best option to travel to wat arun. do not use tuk tuk or taxis to travel to the other side. we sat inside the temple for about an hour and it felt very peaceful and calm. the temple is not crowded as the others.
Awesome is the word. Its so beautiful, you can take some great pictures here. If you are planning to go Bangkok, don't miss Wat Arun
History heritage . The landmark just beautiful and the statues are the valueble history heritage for current generation to see. Thailand so lucky to hv many historical heritages

stunning at dawn from across the place . This situated opposite Grand Palace and Wat Pho another temple behind the Grand Palace. You can get to this temple using the boat crossing the Chao Phraya river.This temple is one the amazing temple in Thailand according to most people on online review. It's situated by the river of Chao Phraya and the most interesting about this temple to me is the architecture work. It is just majestic and unique than other temples. Hence it is one of the most captured on screen temple in Thailand . Most photographed. I went here the second time on Sunday and it was closed at 6pm. So we ended up sitting at the park across wat Pho waiting for sunset. You can watch slowly day turns into night , with beautiful reflection on the water of boats crossing and the lighting of the temple seem amazing it's how they built the temple it seems like the light starts to turn on from bottom to top. But if u look carefully they only place the lights on the one the few at the most bottom level but the sunset and how it's built made it lighten up from bottom to top. It's amazing. Heres some of the poor photos I took during my last trip. It won't help much but it will give you rough idea on how the place look like. Be sure to come earlier to at least go to Grand Palace first then walk to Wat Pho then spend ur time waiting for sunset

Great views and ambience. One of the "big" temples in Bangkok. It was being restored during our visit and it was covered in scaffolding.Travel over from Tha Tien pier (our favourite place on thr river)

Can be skipped right now as this temple is under renovation . You can easily skip this temple as this is under renovation and not worth spending your efforts to cross the river and go to opposite side of palace. Also spending 50 THB is not worth when you can't even climb the main temple building right now.
Great views from above. I've been several times to Wat Arun. In July 2015 it was covered with scaffolding. When it's accessible the views up and down the river are great.
Nice. Its beautifull.. But unfortunately when i go there, its under renovation.. So i cant go to the top to see bangkok view :( hope i have chance go there again and go to the top :)

Beautiful temple but outside has scaffolding at the moment. Best seen at night from the river as beautifully lit up. During the day it does not look as good from the river as it has scaffolding over it as it is under repair.

Lots to See - Worth the Trip. We were on a jaunt down the river and canal system via longboat and made this one of our stops. Though we only had a short 20 minutes to enjoy it, the grounds are beautiful, the smaller garden temples had gorgeous and interesting details, and you didn't need to go inside the main temple (a 50 Bhat fee for those who did) to revel in the antiquity and architectural details. There was plenty also going on if you want to get involved in chanting or hear a "sermon" or just rub a big gold Buddha's belly. My Aunts got some ice cream, I went around taking pictures like a madwoman, the children in our group tromped happily around the grounds and everyone was happy with this stop. Though the place is beautiful, it was not the easiest for tourists to find restrooms and such, which is why it is not a 5 star.
Beautiful Buddhist temple with great view. Must see. Walking all the way up is well worth the effort. Take the river boat there instead of road transportation.

Awesome. One of the "big" temples in Bangkok. It was being restored during our visit and it was covered in scaffolding. The crowds are quite heavy so be prepared and be patient. Wonderful place with LOTS of history, a MUST DO while in Bangkok.

Worth A Visit. Under renovation when we visited so a little disappointed not to get the full effect of this impressive temple. Having said that the bamboo scaffolding itself was worth seeing an amazing feat in itself. Interesting not being another Golden offering but white render covered with mosaic tiles. Unique in style and construction. Looks simply stunning at night but my camera couldn't handle the shot sorry to say. Easiest and cheapest to get there is by river ferry.

Pretty temple at the end of a boat ride. We visited at the end of the day and it was still pretty busy.In the first room we were told that going under the King's old bed was good luck. So my 2 year old and I took the challenge of wiggling on our bellies under the bed. Bring on the luck!!The main temple is under repair, so there is scaffolding up on some of it. Still lots of photo opportunities though. As always covering shoulders and knees, for women, is a must, to be respectful.

Bangkok - Beware of being cheated. We had an unpleasant experience during our trip. Retrospectively thinking, we should not have been so gullible....We were at Rama VIII road (near Khaosan) trying to head towards Wat Pho, when we were approached by a man claiming to be a teacher at a nearby school who mentioned that Wat Pho, Wat Arun and Grand Palace is closed until 3pm on that day since it was "Special Buddha day". He wrote down on a piece of paper list of five places that we should visit through a tuk tuk instead, namely Big Buddha, Wat Ben, Lucky Buddha and Export – having special promotion by Thailand Government. He added saying that tuk tuks will only charge 40 baht since gasoline was free on the occasion of Buddha day. He also told us that the Lucky Buddha temple is opened only once in the whole year on the occasion of Buddha day and we should miss the chance to visit the temple. We thanked him for the information and within a minute were approached by a tuk tuk who charged us exactly the same price for covering the 4 places. After visit the ‘Big Buddha’ temple, we were taken to the ‘Lucky Buddha temple’. Upon entering the ‘Lucky Buddha’ temple, we found all the temple doors to be shut so we went to look for another entrance and to confirm that the temple was closed for the day. In the meanwhile, while we were trying to find our way around the temple, we were approached by a respectable looking Thai man who shared that the temple was closed for the day and was open only in the morning. He started to speak to us about his new business in Australia and shared some stories of his work abroad. During this conversation, he spoke about the Thai export week and how he had gone the previous day with his wife and daughter to purchase sapphire jewellery at a low price. He mentioned that the jewellery is offered by the Thai government without any tax for only retail purposes through government controlled shops. He highly recommended that we visit the Thai export and reassured to us that only the best quality gems would be sold there. Post this, we got back into the Tuk Tuk who took us to Ban Thai Gems Co. Ltd. Saying that this is the government controlled shop for Thai Export. The shop is 3 floors high and looks very lavish in appearance. Looking at the variety and gems and seeming authenticity of the shop we decided to purchase a ring. We purchased a ruby ring worth 26,400 Baht. And were given all the certificate of guarantee and the receipt. We left the shop and got the tuk tuk driver to drop us off at MBK. At the end of the day, we realized that all the temples were open for the whole day and there was no such thing called Buddha day or a Lucky Buddha temple. We also very soon found out post some online search that there were no Thai government export promotions on gems or free gasoline on that day. Further, on checking the internet we found full details on similar scams associated with Ban Thai Gems and the Lucky Buddha scam. We suspect that the piece of jewellery sold to us is a fake. We reported to the police (Tourist Police near boxing stadium - Lt Winya Peter Thengnimitr - 0813422150) and also to the Indian Embassy, who were supportive. The police however, told us to negotiate a refund instead of filing a compliant since there was no hard core proof. Lt. Peter accompanied us to the shop. Since we had paid by credit card, we did manage to get a 100% refund.I would advice that as tourists, it is important to not not let the guard down, have access to GPS maps and not be bowled over by sweet talking polite strangers! Also I have noticed that the sweet talk soon changes to a stubborn refusal to understand " English" when the tables are turned against their favor - so take care!

Great place to be at- a must in bangkok. This place has some charisma- at dawn , it's simply beautiful.I guess the place is also named as temple of dawn.Here the priest perform the rituals and it's so soothing to watch them bless the locals in a very unique way.The steps are amazing.The walk all around shows you the superb architecture.Simply loved it.

A must see attraction - part of our private city tour. we combined this with a trip to the Grand Palace as part of a half day city tour. A short (and incredibly cheap ferry ride across the river from the GP. simply an unmissable sight

Lovely!. This is our first stop in BKK. We stop in and wander about, getting settled in our hearts and minds after the stress of travel. Its also our last stop before leaving. coming and going, we make sure to stop and get a blessing from the monks. We are not Buddhist, but find this a respectful way to start and end our trip.
Must See at Night. We visited by boat during the day but we had dinner across the river in the evening and it is absolutely beautiful!!

Striking Wat on the river. This Wat was under full restoration when we visited which is great to see Thailand keeping their historical culture intact but I admit I was slightly disappointed I was unable to get the full impact of this striking Wat after the work had been complete. The Wat is basically white plaster covered with tile mosaic and was being cleaned to remove years and years of dirt and pollution restoring the white plaster. What a sight it would be to see at night fully restored and lit up.
Great view. You catch a boat to get there, and once there you can climb up to the top. From there the view is great, you will enjoy the breeze from the river and will have great pics of bangkok.

Lovely, but partly closed due to renovation. The temple is definitely worth a visit even though parts of it are closed and covered with scaffolding due to renovation. Actually it is good to see the painstaking work needed to clean the ornaments. Some say it is free, but at least officially it is 50 Thb for foreigners. Plus you need to rent clothes if you are not sufficiently modest.

under construction . this place is under construction these days
other than that this was a nice place
use ferry service from wat phao to get here
ferry only charge 2.50 bhats
you could take it back to go too

Very ok types and pretty expensive entry fee for not even allowing entry to the temple. Visited Bangkok in Jan and this was the only wat on my itinerary . Took a boat ride from saphan taksin choaphraya river station to this place! The boat drops you on the other side of the river and u need to take one more boat to reach that side! The entryfee was expensive at 50 THB per person! The temple was closed due to renovation and thePremises were pretty ill maintained. Avoid if possible would be my genuine advice. Rather the wat at grand palace though quite expensive, would be my choice.
beautiful. it's beautiful temple great experience and the architecture is really great. recommend to wear good shoes

Hot but worth it (if not under renovation). Just like other temples, you cannot go inside with sleeveless and shorts so make sure to wear a pants or something longer (below the knee) or you can bring your own sarong or rent outside.

not from this world. Unless you happen to be on the right side of the river, where Wat Arun is situated, the temple is best approach by boat from Tha Tien pier. I would suggest to visit Wat Phra Kaew and the Grand Palace first thing early in the morning, then Wat Pho nearby and then Wat Arun across the river. The crossing costs peanuts. If you are tired after visiting the first two sights, have a break in the cozy, unassuming, air conditioned interiors of Gloria Jeans Coffees in Tha Thien Rd. close to the pier. Ice tea with milk there is just glorious. Or for a few bahts have a snack from the outdoor vendor-the real McCoy. At the pier crowds can be intimidating for the uninitiated but in spite of the hustle there will always be someone willing to help and direct you to the right boat that will ferry you across (2.5 Bahts per person one way). Wat Arun is yet another iconic treasure, that will take your breath away. Again, details can easily be found in any guidebook. Suffice it to say that one hour and a bit should be enough, maybe two if you are keen. Needless to say you have to behave and dress appropriately: cover your knees and shoulders, sarong being a good choice for women. The ticket costs mere 50 Bahts and crowds are negligible by comparison with say, Emerald Buddha.

A must to visit while in Bangkok. We went on a guided tour to visit the Temple, I would suggest this is the best way to go. if you decide to book an organised tour, make sure you check the time available at the temple, take some water with you. An amazing place to visit.

A must see. Well worth a visit if you are in Bangkok. We accessed it by riverboat on a free ferry service from the opposite bank having just visited the Reclining Buddha thereEssential restoration work was taking place during our visit but this did not distract from the awesomeness of the site.
simply beautifull. you don´t even have to go inside to see how beautifull this temple is, It is situated in a really nice garden with lot of small shopping stand on the side

Very interesting.. The temple is beautiful but is being restored at this time. The scaffolding detracted from the view. The upside was that it was gratifying to watch the workers repairing the detail to the temole.
Beautiful temple. This is a small but beautiful temple. The architecture and decoration are gorgeous. Wear comfortable shoes since you will have to climb up a few stairs.
Meh. Similar to a lot of the other temples, and it's much smaller. Was undergoing some restoration work so we couldn't climb up the tower.

Scaffolding up. Unfortunately scaffolding was everywhere so it was a tad disappointing. But it's only 50 bhat to get in.
Ladies mist have legs & arms covered as with any temple
under renovation. The temple has been hidden in scafoldings for a number of months; should reappear in the next two to five months.

Good view at sunset. This is another old temple near the Chao Phraya River. As of this posting, the part of this site is under renovation but you can still enjoy the view. You can visit this site after your visit to Wat Pho as this is just the opposite of the riverbank, you’ll just have to ride the ferry crossing the river for a small fee. You can get a good view of the surrounding as well as the river by climbing the steep stairs.At the entrance there are souvenir stores as well as Thai costumes you can wear for souvenir photo, of course this comes with a price. Entrance fee is 50 baht.
Amazing!. though there were renovations happening, but nevertheless, the temple was amazing and majestic. we wanna see more!
Architecturally a can't miss. If you're going to Bangkok, you'll regret not visiting Wat Arun. This location holds marvelous buildings and examples of Bangkok only architecture. It's an amazing gem.

Covered in Scaffolding Jan 16. This must be seen at night as its a totally different look when the lights are shining on it. This Temple is undergoing a huge renovation and if you visit during the day you'll see the difference.

Construction currently going on. Not much to see.. The temple is lovely, but so are all the other ones across the river. It isn't worth crossing the river and paying to see due to all the work that's going on. I will however say the gardens are very nice and peaceful and you can see Wat Arun from there so there is no need to pay, although it is only 50bhatt. I was in and out of the temple in 10min as you cannot go inside (due to the construction work).

Wonderful to see the temple in the night. Wat Arun is being lighted up in the night. The scenery of the temple is very attractive, mysterious and even romantic.It is recommendable to look the Wat from a boat on the Chao Phraya River and/or the opposite side of the bank , of coursein the night.
Partly renovated, still enjoyable. Although it is still renovated, it is a must see in Bangkok. Unique architecture in a peaceful environment beside the river
Temple is in maintenance. Beautiful place and cheap tickets (50 baht per person) but it was a shame it is under maintenance so we couldn't enjoy it as much.

The monument is awe inspiring but the tacky shabby vendor stalls around it are insulting.. Take a nice boat taxi trip to tour this temple. It is radiant and inspirational. However the spirit of the moment is totally besmirched by the messy, trashy, price extortionate, vendor stalls around it with their aggressive touts pestering you while you try to reverently gaze at the structure. Why the Thais allow this kind of awful environment to spoil their monuments is a mystery.

Trip to Bangkok. The Temple is so beautifully done. The surrounding is so serene. If you want to view the interior of the Temple you need to remove your shoes.There is a market around the other side of the temple that sells cheap good cotton T-Shirts.

Beautiful temple. Don't gotta say to much. It's a must see on a trip to Bangkok. In my opinion there are so many temples it gets boring after a few so make this your first stop. Chances are you will take a water taxi which means you also get to see the Chao Phraya River!!
Impressive temple. Although it is under some renovation, it is a temple that is a must to visit. Impressive architecture.
An ancient temple. Wat Arun predates Bangkok. Grand in size, it is nevertheless a much simpler temple than many others in Thailand and worth a visit for being different to most the Wats we saw.
Wat Arun. One of the must see's in Bangkok I found it very impressive, if you enjoy seeing the sites in cities, you should see this.

Wat Arun. We spent around an hour here. It is lovely, such a shame it had scaffolding around it. A lovely peaceful place and not as busy as some of the other temples we visited in Bangkok. Went across the river on a boat for 10 baht.

Very good place. If you like to visit a structure of art and to relax your mind , Temple of dawn is a great place to visit. You can take boat across the river to The Reclineing Budha temple for Bahtt 2.50 only.

Fascinating temple and construction. When you come by boat and enter the place you feel like being on an island. Immediately the energy of calmness captures you. The buildings around the temple and the main temple are pieces of art. If you don't visit this place you will have missed something.

Beautiful temple worth a good few hours.. I love this temple. Been back after a few years and it is still a beautiful place to spend some time exploring. It is being cleaned currently and they are doing a great job! It gleams in the sun.

Cool place, nice surrounding gardens. We got the boat across the river (2.5 baht - 10 cents) to visit Wat Arun. Its a cool temple but unfortunately at the time of our visit it was under construction. But the surrounding Bonsai Gardens were very beautiful and it only takes up maybe an hour of your stay, definitely worth a visit.
Amazing craftsmanship and the size is fascinating. The amount of work that goes into each of these temples - both for construction and maintenance is amazing. The artistic work is truly fascinating.

Affordable. I had high expectation but when we visited last year (July 2015) the temple was under renovation. I heard it's best to visit it at dawn so you can see it lit. But if you're in the area (from What Pho), might as well visit since its just a hop and a skip away.

Wat Arun visit . You can reach Wat Arun by crossing the river in a boat from the pier near Wat Pho. For one way they charge is 2.5 Bhat per person . The entrance ticket for Wat Arun was 50 Bhat per person . It looks huge and nice , but not much to look around .
Serene. The wat is calm and serene . Getting to the top is a task but very well worth it . Good for travellers

Under serious renovation avoid for the next year or so. Because of the renovation, the upper levels were shut of. You could see scaffolding and small parts of the facade.
There's a ticket charged for foreigners and I feel if the attraction is under renovation, the least they could do is waive the fee.
But the place has possibilities and I would return once the renovation was completed.

Great architecture.. We really loved the place. Please be there before 6pm. You can see Great architecture temple. The travel to the temples is fun in the boat. You can take pictures with traditional dresses.

Great Photo Opportunities. It's one of my favourite temples in Bangkok for taking photos. Lots of cool places to pose photos and it's a lovely site to visit too. Beware of the touts charging for photos by the cardboard cut outs! Climb to the top and get a great view of the river.
Currently under construction. I am not sure what this site is normally like but a lot of it was closed off. It is still stunning and I will have to come back one day.

An Amazing Site. Getting to this temple is half the experience - by water taxi. But the structure is amazing. Not just one temple, but a series of temples. Incredible architecture, shrines, and buildings. Do not miss this one.

I WAS BLOWN AWAY.. We were really looking forward to seeing this temple but in real life it is beyond your wildest dreams, The work that has gone into this temple is mind blowing we watched some workers renovating part of the temple and the small part of a column that they were repairing took 20 mins so I cant imagine how many workers and hours went into the building of this fantastic monument. You have to see it to believe it photos do not do it justice.

Cultural sneak peek . Wat arun is amongst the top tourists attraction and hence we decided to visit..the decision proved to be insightful!This is a relatively huge temple and the exterior is much fascinating as it is made of intricate patterns out of colourful glass.. It was a bit scary to climb up the stairs to reach the higher levels of the temple as the Stairs were steep ..people with vertigo must avoid climbing .. Its a pleasant site amidst the chaos of the city life
Must See!. Beautiful attraction, if you're in Bangkok you have to go there. Just keep an eye on your shoes when you take them off to go in the temple I heard a few peoples got stolen!

Serene and Scaffolded. An easy ferry shuttle from Tha Tien across to west side of river leaves you in a mixture of pavilions, shrines, small gardens, vendors, and the huge center spire of Wat Arun. Great place to relax, spend an hour or two, and head back across when you're ready. Currently the main spire is scaffolded, and you cannot access the upper levels. But even the first level gives great vistas and first hand views of this incredible work.

Don't bother going whilst construction and scaffolding is up. Tried to head here only to see Wat Arun completely surrounded by scaffolding. You can't go up to the top and scaffolding makes the temple look unsightly and doesn't make a good photo opportunity. Avoid for the time being.

wonderful temple. Water taxi gets you to and from this wonderful temple, and it's well worth your time. Intricate carvings and statues, amazing colors, and unreal architecture. It's currently under scaffolding and renovation, but this did not take anything away from the temple's attraction.
Beautiful. Beautiful temple.The temple is renovated. Lots of tourists. The temples here expect visitors to be dressed properly.

Under construction. This is one of the places that I was anticipating to see. After seeing the Reclining Buddha, went straight to the pier in order to get a glimpse of this temple. Sad to say, the place was under construction when I went here last January. What to do? Stroll around the area, take lots of pictures and try to have a little conversation with the locals there. After Wat Arun, get in a little cruise in Chao Praya River and head to Asiatique.
Highly worth seeing. Very neat, and peaceful part of Bangkok!. Went there recently, and had a very cool experience. No complaints. Easy to take the boat ferry from the Taksin stop off the BTS train.

TOTALLY UNDER CONSTRUCTION - DO NOT GO NOW. Went to temple of dawn this morning. Traffic was unbelievable even at 6am. We were attempting to get there before sunrise. No way with traffic. Uber said 10 min it took an hour. The entire complex is under massive construction. Scaffolding wraps the entire structure and is laying on the grounds. Do not recommend this. You cannot climb up past the first 20 steps. It is all sealed off. From the looks of the work and the work effort it looks like this is going to be months if not a year before you should think about going. Check out the photos I took this morning it says it all.
Surrounded in scaffolding. Seen it from a long boat tour and didn't feel it was worth my time with all the scaffolding surrounding it

Sign of bangkok. Wonderful place to see and also sign of Bangkok.Under repair and you can just visit it some place but it's colorful and beautiful to visit it.Close to grand palace just exit grand palace and cross the road toward Chao Praya river and take ticket go by boat . Its so shiny at night i go there one hour before sunset to see it on daylight and nightlight.

Must see Temple of Dawn. You have to use boat to reach this serene place. Power boats give you thrilling experience. This temple is still under renovation but gives you very good glimpse of glorious past.

Iconic. Although some restoration work was being carried out when we visited, you could still get around the temple and is still worth a visit. Looks great lit up at night. This is certainly one of Bangkok's iconic structures.
Very impressive!. Very impressive! Investment going after 6 p.m. as there is no entrance fee and the temple looks amazing being illuminated.

On renovation. The day i came to this place, it was still being renovated so there was nothing much to see. The tourist also not as many as we saw at the wat pho and grand palace. But they say you can go up to the highest temple and see the view from the top, unfortunately i didn't get the chance to do that. But this temple is a must go combo with wat pho temple if you come to Bangkok. Just take the ferry to cross the river from wat pho, it costs 2,5 baht each.

Temple closed for renovation . As others have aforementioned the temple is closed and will be closed for the next 3 years. Very disappointing as I looked forward to seeing it but of course the work needs to be done. Be warned!
Under renovations. The temple was beautiful but many parts were under renovations in late January 2016. I'm sure it would be much more impressive if you could see more.

Beautiful temple and less crowded.. Breathtaking view when sunset. Part of the Sthupa is being undergoing some renovation. And tourist can't climb up the steep stairs anymore. Marvelous porcelain China work are everywhere. You can get blessing from the Buddhist monk and make sure you wear long pants and cover your body properly to show your respect.

Good experience.. . Recommended if you traveling to bkk for first time..
Temple was busy with tourists around..
It was nice experience..
Another temple...pretty. Nothing spectacular...another temple in a country of spectacular temples...under construction when we went...a bit commercial

Under scaffolding, but still worth a short visit. It only costs around 100baht to get in, and despite most of it being under scaffolding, it's still worth a visit. I found it fascinating just standing back and watching how the workers were renovating it; the detailing in the tiny tiles they were placing back on just amazed me!

A must see attraction. You have to go across the river on ferry to get there, three Baht each way.
Temple a short walk from ferry. A beautiful temple which is held in great regard by the Thai. No charge, no touts, no crowd. Currently being worked on but isn't a distraction.

Dosappoinying. We watched this from our hotel room and we're excited about visiting. Got the ferry across the river and when we got there - very very hot . There was nothing much to see except walk around the outside covered with scaffolding.
It is stunning mosaic temple - huge but to travel across town to see - maybe not.
Another masterpiece . The Wat Arun which is across Wat Pho is another place one should visit. It's beautiful gardens to its temple are awesome. Worth a visit.

Interesting Structures!. The design and structures of the temples was really unique and the compound was humongous. I don't think we managed to finish seeing the entire place before we had to head back to the tour bus.

The Sunrise Temple. There nothing much to see actually in here, but it's worth seeing the great building and the sea view from the middle of the temple, although i wish i can climb till the top but they only allowed till the middle base.The entrance cost 100 baht but there not much of tourist here, there nothing much to do. the complex is small you just need an hour to explore everywhere then you're done.
Impressive sight. This is an impressive sight (can go to visit it or look from a boat as we did). Quite an iconic symbol of Bangkok.

A waterfront icon. This iconic temple is in the midst of being renovated. The entire temple was covered with scaffolding and the whole thing was behind fencing. We were unable to see much as a lot was covered up

Well worth the trip. With the big three in Bangkok being the Golden Palace, Wat Pho, and Wat Arun, I would have to say Wat Arun is the one to leave out if you can't do all three. Still...it is worth the trip and the buildings are amazing. There is even an area where people sell pretty nice handicrafts.
Temple ofo Dawn. By. the river , one of the most impressive temples. I only had one scary exprience last year - was inthe cafée and having a coffee when suddenly a snake went right under the table.

Looks great in the pictures but entire temple was under scaffolding.. We visited this temple in November 2015 and it was one of the sights I was most looking forward to however when we arrived it was covered in scaffolding. Still an interesting temple and area but taking photos of it wasn't the same when it looks like a building site.

One time Ok to visit. One of Thailand main attraction. If 1st time visit Thailand worthy visit here. You can reach here from chao praya river. At this area also have market to buy clothes, souvenirs, etc. Tips: Buy out side temple area (near the river) price cheaper

Under construction December 2015 -- locals say "don't go; most of it is closed.". We didn't go. Looked pretty from the river. But lots of scaffolding was visible and we were told by locals that much of the temple was closed and not worth visiting.
Visited the wrong time. This time of the the large stupa was under restoration so you can not excess to the top of the stupa. The landscape of the surrounding wat is nicely manicure.

Nothing impressive. Note--Wat Arun is currently under construction. I would suggest seeing the Wat from the river in the evening when it is lit up--that's the most impressive view. Going to see the temple up close is a disappointment. It is quite small and you cannot go inside. Compared to other temples in Bangkok, the decoration is quite simple and not at all impressive. There is nothing to do in the neighborhood around Wat Arun. Overall, it's not worth a vist.

One of my favorite. This temple been decorated with porcelain pieces all around. This place is just fabulous. If you visit this temple, be prepared that you won't be able to stop to take more and more pictures. Every time I visit Wat Arun I feel the peace of this place, however it is getting crowded sometimes. Unfortunatelly this year the higher level of the temple been closed, you can not climb up on the crazy high steps, but I still recommend a visit.
Very special place!. The temple is truly beautiful. What makes it so special is the decoration with the pieces of chinese ceramics.
Average. During my trip, wat arun is under renovation. The details of the architecture of wat arun is wonderful. This place is suitable for those who loves architecture

Temple with a good view. Quite a big temple with a good view across the river. Had to climb rather steep steps to reach the top, so do wear comfortable shoes. Closes at 6pm. We went to a cafe opposite the temple to watch the sunset after.

Very stunning architecture. One of the must sees for travelers in Bangkok. Not too difficult to get to, especially with a tour guide. The temple impressive and very distinctive. The views are great and there is a lot of detail in the construction.

Beautiful Temple on the Riverside. I went to this temple on the recommendation of my driver and I was not disappointed. It was a really beautiful example of southeastern Asian architecture. I would definitely recommend a visit to anyone vacationing to Bangkok
Loved it!. We got there by speed boat. Dressed up in traditional clothing took a walk around and enjoyed the experience.

Not that special. This temple is quite out of the way...
Also it was under construction at the time we visited so you did not have the opportunity to make good pictures of the temple because of the highworkers... we payed 50 baht to get in, also used the ticket to visit the toilets.
Very nice. Best at sunrise or sunset of doing a cruise on the chaopraya river. One of the landmark of bangkok. must see!
Great at sunrise. This is an excellent site on the Chao Prya river in Bangkok. The Wat is functional with many monks and it is a quiet respite from the clamor of Bangkok.
Beautiful both day and night. This temple was interesting to visit. Lots of stairs. There is some tourist stalls to purchase good if wanted as well as drinks and snacks available for purchase.

Most impressive porcelain tower. You would not guess it (if you haven't read it), but the central tower is covered in bits of porcelain. Imagine the colours when the sun shines on it. A must see on the side of the Chao Praya river

beautful. this is a beautiful WAT, take the ferry from the port of Wat Pho, costs 2,5 THB runs until 21.00
the entrance fee to Wat Arun is 50...but don't pay until they are ready with the renovation... it is a waste of money to pay for it, if you can not climb up...

Beautiful building and park. Just 50 baht admission and 2.5 B each way on the ferry, it's a bargain. It's being restored at present but you can climb up some of the steps to see the architecture. Also interesting is watching the workers repair the intricate mosaics. Very nice gardens with bonsai trees. Ladies need shoulders covered, no shorts nor short skirts. Men seem to be ok in long shorts.

Nice place to visit in Bangkok. This place was easy to reach. hop off at Saphan Thanksin BTS and continue with Chao Praya Boat (N8) and cross a river by using little boat about 2,5 Bath. walk around inside you will see a great temple with an unique structure. its so different if we only passing it by boat.

Active buddhist monks.. Not the most extensive but certainly the "reallest" Visit the buddhist monks or see them at meals and prayers.Take a 10ct 5' ferry across the river. Behind the complex are a few very original eateries, mostly visited by locals. Excellent!

A unique Wat, worth the visit in Bangkok. Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) is a beautiful structure which is architecturally quite different to Wat Pho which is just across the river or other temples in Bangkok. Would recommend to allow for around 1 hour at least, to enjoy the details of the temple and the river / city views. Entry to the temple is 100 Baht (c.3 USD) and a visit can be done right after a visit to Wat Pho across the river. A boat zigzags between two riverbanks every few minutes, for less than 10 US Cents per person. The temple is made up of colorful spires, which have been decorated with pieces of colorful glass or porcelain pieces. Around the spires are various warrior figures with intricately crafted details. Be careful of the steep stairs in Wat Arun. I understand it is possible to climb the main spire normally, however it was under restoration during my visit so only had the chance to see around in the open areas.

beautiful, but currently partly under renovation. Beautiful old temple, definitely on "must see" list, currently (January 2016) some parts of it are being renovated so it is not as great as it should be. You cannot enter inside, only looking from outside, but you need to be dressed properly (there is a cloth rental, clothers are not rented for free).
stairs are closed :/. the stairs which you were supposed to climb and see the view were closed for renovation. easy to access from the port at wat pho area for 2,5 baths.
Beautiful architecture. Very beautiful looking structures that you can climb and see Bangkok from a unique vantage point. Highly recommended and a must see while in Bangkok.

Love this Unique Wat. I particularly enjoyed this wat because you are allowed to hike up to the top and get a breath-taking view of Bangkok. We were able to get in for free, not sure if that is unusual or not. It might have been a special deal, but I cannot remember. Sorry!
Very good. Just go and enjoy.. Dont need a guide.Just take your time and enjoy. Its crazy how much work went into thee type of sites. Yes go to see it.
Worth seeing. You can go there during your boat travel on the Chao Phraya River. amazing park area around. Clean and well-keeped.

Most gentle restoration. Wat arun has great view from the river. But even if you see it just by passing through by boat, it is not enough so take a stop over there and see the details. It is a masterpiece which is touched by the broken porcelains! At home we just throw away, right? So, just gain new diy ideas;)

Loving all the art, architecture and beauty of Bangkok. I. What a beautiful place, even while under reconstruction and scaffolding up. I wish I could have climbed the steps to the tower but maybe next time. I also enjoyed watching the young artisans apply fresh costs of cement to the pagoda and apply the tiles. They were doing a fine job.

A must for lovers of architecture. Wat Arun is nothing short of an architectural masterpiece.The main stupa glistens in the sun welcoming visitors on the bank of the Chao Phraya opposite the Tha Tien pier.Access is by a cross-river boat from the aforementioned pier (2.50 baht) which is usually full at most times.Once there, do take your time to take in the beauty of this Wat from all angles(not to mention photos!).It was undergoing restoration work at several places during the time of my visit but this did not diminish its beauty much. The main structure is a wonder in itself with alternating layers of marble and masonry in a circular structure being "held up" by a ring of Garudas at each level.We can just about make out a group of long-tusked elephants near the peak of the structure standing like guardians facing in (?2; correct me if I'm wrong) different directions.Be advised that there's a strict dress code as with any other Wat. Magnificent!
Nice temple. One of the best preserved temples in the city. Go at sunset for a magical view over the river. Very steep stairs so be sure to watch small children

Fantastic. Part of a private city & temples tour. It was incredible. Note that you have to be prepared to climb stairs, but I believe there is an elevator in the back. Go early in the morning to avoid the heat and having to climb stairs. Wear modest clothing. No shorts, tight clothes and bare arms.

Beautiful From Afar - Amazing Up Close. You can see the temple from the river, or even from the many tourist publications of Bangkok and Thailand - but that doesn't compare to seeing it up close. As others have noted it's currently under renovation, meaning you can't walk fully up the stairs, however I was still in awe walking around the open areas.This is a must-see in Bangkok, and a quick hop on the river ferry to get to/from it.
Night stroll . Walked to the Wat Arun from Baan Wanglang hotel. Short nice fun walk. Scenic Temple was closed but the grounds are still beautiful at night
A Khmer-style Buddhist temple. You must take a water-taxi (an experience itself) to cross the river to see this temple. It's style (mosaic) is called the "Temple of Dawn"

Amazing temple area; a must once again when in Bangkok. Visiting the Wat Arun temple by using the ferry boat for getting there is a must when in Bangkok. Great place, stunning cultural sides of the history. At time of visiting in January 2016, some of the buildings were being renovated and that by itself was amazing to see. Will take some time so don't expect to have all pictures without construction-stuff on it. The area is great to see and the experience of getting there by ferryboat for jus 2,5 Baht is fantastic.
Amazing. This is the most impressive thing we see in Bangkok, most Bangkok is modern but have some nice temple and this one is best.

Difficult to rate at this time. Hard to rate something that you weren't able to fully visit. You can tell that in its prime time it must be quite impressive and beautiful, but we were not able to enter the temple inside or climb the many stairs it is famous for. What we were allowed was to visit the grounds and the lower level and observe the many workers restoring with plaster and paint, very slow and miticolous work. Had fun getting there by water taxi and then ferry though.
VISIT . This is another beautiful temple.The temple is renovated. Lots of tourists. Worth the visit.The temples here expect visitors to be dressed properly.
Interesting place. The temple was huge and we are able to shop on outside of the temple. Had a very good photo and it is a good spot to have a look.

Busy but worth it. Very beautifull temple. You can only get there by boat. We hired a longtailboat for a private tour that included a couple of temples and the floating market. We didn't had much time at Wat Arun. That was too bad but still very impressive to see and if you have a chance go see it. You won't regret it.

Ah-mazing!. We went to this place around sunset on the first day of our tour and I must say it was the best time of day to go. It was hot but not as hot as the day time and the sun behind the temple looked absolutely amazing. We climbed the very steep and scary steps to the top but it was well worth it. There is so much intricate detail on this temple.
So many tiles. This is a must see Temple,We were amazed at the buildings, the time taken to build with so many decorated tiles is awsome...!

a work in progress. A must to see if you want to see craftsmen at work. At present the whole Wat is being cleaned and renovated, don't be put off by scaffolding there are areas that are finished and you can see what wonderful work is being done. Look closely and you will see that all the flowers adorning the walls are made from pieces of broken pottery. Again respect the Temple and were clothes that cover your shoulders and no shorts.

beautiful in itself. was taken for a ride literally by locals saying it was closed for renovations and no way to get from one side of the river to the other which meant we were extremely tired by the time we saw it however it did look very impressive

Breathtaking!. A stunningly beautiful monument! If the Wat Pho was doused in the colors of red then this one has green all over it. Has a nice park adjacent to the river, if you want to take a break. Currently undergoing restoration to the eastern facing parts.
Peaceful place. Very beautiful and peaceful temple. Located near by the river. The architecture is outstanding.You have the stay until sunset to enjoy and feel what's the mean of the temple

Awesome experience. This Temple is right on the river bed. You have to climb up to the top available level to appreciate it. Stairs are steep (about 9-12 inches high). Not recommended for seniors. I'm afraid of heights but it didn't stop me since you can't climb all the way up. Great place to take pictures and learn a little about the culture and religion. I believe the entrance is only 50 baht which is like $1.50 U.S.

Incredible!!. I went with my friend and was expecting the temple to be bigger than that. It's not as big as Wat Pho, but for someone who would like to see the style and building, I definitely recommend. Just amazed by its design and how it looks.

Amazing place. It is currently under restoration, but still amazing and 'must see' place in Bangkok... However, it is trouble to reach it if you are on the other side of the river. It took more than hour to get there and additional hour to get back... Traffic is awful and it may be easier to cross the river by boat..

Beautiful, but visit affected by construction. The temple itself was probably the most beautiful religious construction in Bangkok, but we were disappointed that we were charged the normal entry fee when the climb to the top was closed off due to construction. We found out that this was the case by walking into a railing that stopped us from going any higher after the first level :/. Worth a visit though, and it is really nice to relax by the river front after the tour at the cafe by the temple.

Temple beside the river. So nice temple. Very close with the city. To reach there, we can use the boat through the chaopraya river. The temple is maintain well. Dont wear the mini skirt to enter the temple. Other interest thing is the gift shop around the temple. The price is so cheap. We will serve with indonesia language speaking seller. And they also will kindly receive indonesia rupiahs beside the thailand bath.

Covered in scaffolding. We were disappointed to find Wat Arun covered in scaffolding when we went as it didn't make for the best photos, but still very cool and easy to get to along the river in Bangkok.

Cool. I really like this place but a great deal of it is being refurbished now, and that will probably take a couple of years. It takes a little bit away from the overall effect but it's still an awesome Temple.
The Stairs Are Under Renovation. Paid THB50 to enter to the temple but cannot get up to the temple as it is under renovation. Not worth the ticket. Check before buying the ticket.
Go Early. Wonderful place. Under construction in some areas. Go early to avoid the tourist crowds. Worth the trip and the entry fee is cheap.

One of the most spectacular Wats in Bangkok. Wat Arun is one of the most spectacular Wats in Bangkok, either during the day or more especially when it is lit at night. At present it is under restoration works so there is less photography opportunities but it is still very much worth the visit.
Construction. I went during the time of construction so the temple was all covered up. I really looked forward to checking it out!!

A must see!!. Incredible, for it's beauty and scale.The shapes, blend of colours, the people... If you're in to temples this one is a complex with several ones in side. Each one as it's beauty, from the white to the golden one, just great. Wall paintigs that look 3D...everything in very nice care condition. Try to see the change of the gard that are inside of the Palace. Word of advise for male and female, must dress long pants, if you don't have, they will borrough ones... it's part of the fun.

The most beautiful temple in Bangkok. Say no more. If you did not visit it, you must. The river taxi is fun, too. A small advice - choose a sunny day, the stones shine and nake it even more special....

Lovely buildings of Wat Arun. We took the ferry across to Wat Arun on a Sunday, and there were plenty of activity with the Buddhist monks taking donations from devotees, giving blessings. Part of the temple was closed for refurbishment, but that did not spoil our enjoyment. Clean toilets were a bonus!!

9th Jan 2016 . We took a walk around at 8.30 - 9.30 pm, although the Wat was closed ( cant go inside) it was worth a visit just to see it under lighting and the views across the river. No tourist, just 2 other couples, security guards and monks walking around.

Interesting Wat. As we visited Wat Arun it was a renovation site. Interesting to see parts of the Wat before and after renovation. The scaffolding is just not great for holiday pictures. Still, it was worth the visit.

A beautiful slice of religion. This temple is a short boat trip away and easy by river taxi. Beautiful in the early morning or late at night when it is all lit up. The best of all major temples in Bangkok and filled with Monks, it is a sight for rich eyes.Beautiful for photo's and meditating. A must-do in Bangkok!

Must visit for temple lovers. One of the main temples for tourists in Thailand, this one is bears a remarked difference to Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaew in its greater resemblance to Hindu temples of South India. For Facebook photo enthusiasts, there's also a stall that lends a traditional Thai costume and takes your photograph in it.

Another key site in Bangkok. You'll probably need to approach this Wat from the other side of the river, by ferry (just 2.5 THB - 5p Sterling). It's very different from the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and Wat Pho on the east side of the river, but an amazing sight nonetheless. It was being restored when we visited, with new skilled plaster work and fresh white paint - interesting to view in itself. Recommended.
Well worth a visit. We took the boat ride there. Lovely. Got a monk to do a prayer service for us. Well worth the trip. A must see.

A favorite!. Located on the river, it is easy to get to by water taxi, and gives a good view of the area. It's beautiful in the morning. At night it is lit up in a full spectrum of colors, and is highly visible and beautiful to see from a rooftop bar nearby.

A Must See in Bangkok. This is everything I imagined a temple to be...a beautiful, peaceful place to marvel, meditate, worship...whatever works for you. This was my favorite of the three major temples in Bangkok (the grand palace, wat pho, and wat Arun). It is the only temple of the three that I saw monks. It is also significantly less crowded. It was the smallest entrance fee, too: 50 Bahts I think (about 2 dollars).It is currently being renovated so you cannot climb the stairs to the top, which was disappointing but understandable. The renovations require scaffolding and tarps and workers, so you might see some of that as well. I still was able to take plenty of pictures so that you couldn't see any of the work going on. The renovations will be so lovely when completed. You can see a huge difference between the dark, old stone, and the new white. Definitely go see this while in Bangkok!
Beautiful temple- A watch at sunset. Do wait to watch it from across the river at sunset! its a sight to watch..take the boat to Tha Tien pier. Entrance fee is 50 Baht.

Don't miss it.. This temple is very beautiful, with a number of small houses around it, and also a small market in front of it where you can pick up souveniers and drinks etc.The view of Wat Arun around early evening is magnificent with the sun setting behind it. Picturesque. Ferry from N8 pier costs 2.5TBH per person, and goes every 10 mins. So its easy to access.
One of the best sites. Special feeling when climbing the tower and seeing the sun going down. And the feeling of climbing such an old building.. Loved it.
Amazing. My favorite temple in Thailand! Absolutely love it! You have to climb to the top tho, which is super scary!
Amazing temple. Every day a lot of people visit this amazing temple so it's better to go early in the morning. Nice view from there!

Interesting but not incredible. Way arun is worth going to but it isn't as spectacular as other available options in Thailand. They have recently renovated it with lighting which is worth looking at at night

The best known temple in Thailand. The Temple of the Dawn has appeared on countless posters advertising tourism to Thailand. The best way to get there is by boat, from the pier it is just a short stroll, there is a fee to get in.The temple area consists of a main ower (a prang), surrounded by four smaller towes. The decorations are special: a layer of plaster was laid over the brick structure which was decorated with bits of Chinese porcelain and ceramic tiles. The effect is dazzling, You can admire the structures from the ground or you can start climbing steep steps to get a bit higher (some parts are closed). There is lots to see, the attention to detail in the decoration is amazing. You can stroll about at your leisure, there are places to rest tired feet - and for somthing spectacular, watch he sun set over he temple from the other side of the river (there are a couple of restaurants which offer amazing views).

Stunning temple is peaceful oasis. Wat Arun is one of the most famous symbols of Thailand. On a warm sunny afternoon it provided a calm place for contemplation, iced coffee and shade . I took the local boat, did not go with a tour group, and did not get lost on the way. I was staying nearby so walked to the pier. Anyone can fairly easily get to the pier by BTS. The pier is a two minute walk from the BTS. Warning, the BTS is mostly unsuitable and inconvenient for those with limited mobility but taxis in BKK are cheap. The first boat takes you to the pier for Wat Pho. Then you pay a small amount again and quickly arrive pn another boat at Wat Arun. I visited it with my 84 yr old mother and we wete delighted to find several places to rest in the shade during the afternoon. An inexpensive, accessible, and tranquil experience. The expected Christmas holiday crowds did not appear that day. Another warning- we had fun dressing up in Thai traditional clothing but the man we paid 100 baht each to take our pictures was a terrible photographer and he uses your own photographic device. Still fun though.

Beautiful, but wrong time of year. Easily one of the most beautiful temples in Bangkok, but alas when I visited it was undergoing some extensive renovations. The experienced was lessened, but hopefully on the next few months it will return to us former glory!

The landmark of Thailand. Wat Arun, the Temple of Dawn, is one of Bangkok's best known landmarks. It stands on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River in Dhonburi. Wat Arun is best seen from the opposite bank of the river; it glistens in the sunlight during the day and stands dark and noble at dawn or dusk.A visit to the beautiful, peaceful monastery complex surrounding the familiar towers is very worth-while. These towers, the “Phra Prang”, although best known, the only part of Wat Arun.From here one can see the Grand palace, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the spacious Wat Po. The towers of Wat Arun are built of brick covered with stucco. The decorations are unique; thousands of pieces of multicolored Chinese porcelain. In niches in the central tower are green figures of the Indra God seated on Erawan, the traditional Thai three-headed elephant. Niches in the smaller towers contain figures of the Moon God or Phra Pai (god of wind), on a white horse. The multi prongs extend from the top of each tower.

One of BKK's must see temples. Took my overseas friends and their families to visit this temple. Located on the West Bank of Chao Phya river and you could actually combine this temple to the same day trip to the grand palace, wat pho and other temples.Bring your hats and umbrellas along as the weather could be hot and humid.This temple features exquisite principle prang which has bits and pieces of ceramic stitched together. At night some times , there are events with light and sound .Very good place to see.
beautiful. we just pass this on boat trip but its so beautiful, next time in bangkok we will go to have a closer look

The pagodas will take your breath away!. This Wat compound is gorgeous! Each Buddhist temple looks similar, however they all have their own design. I loved seeing the different colors, and the themes. The compound offered a voucher for a free COLD bottle of ice water.
Great gardens. Defo worth the visit, has beautiful gardens. Disappointed that could claim to the top. When travelling to the temple don't buy your ticket at the pier, pay on the boat as it cheaper.

Construction . Although the admission price was fairly inexpensive, there was no warning that the temple and grounds are being renovated. This is not a temple to enter and the stairs on the outside of the temple were closed most of the way up. Photo opportunities were difficult to come by with all of the construction.
beautiful temple. the temple was under maintain so we couldn't climb up to the very top, it was really a pity. it's really beautiful and special, wish next time i can climb up to the top!

Nice in sunset but in work. It was easy to go from the wat pho just walking to the river and crossing to the other side. The wat arun is very beautiful if possible go in late afternoon with sunset and orange colors (it closes at 18h). The only bad part was that it was under work so lot of things disturbing the view
Amazing historic place. I think it is one of the most beautiful temples in Bangkok, not only because of its architectural design but also for what it represents.
Temple of Dawn. This temple like Chinese temple.This is also beautiful to take photo.I took many photos for this Temple.This temple can't go inside.In Myanmar can man go inside of the Temple.
My Favorite Temple in Bangkok. A very beautiful temple located near the river. Enjoyed my visit there because there were not many tourists like in The Grand Palace.

Nice place, but not for differently able & elderly ones!. It has historical structures and people with that interest would love to explore. I'd say a must visit place if you have extra time in Bangkok and need a break from night life etc.

Pride of Bankok. It is most beautiful temple of Bankok, which is situated on the bank of river. We reached in the temple by using the local boat . Brightness and Architecture of temple is more unique. Almost temperature is very hot there so visit evening time. i recommended my all friends and cousins to visit this Beautiful Location ..

Humbling. A Buddhist temple had existed at the site of Wat Arun since the time of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. this Wat is a must see and I prefer it to the grand palace. A simple ferry trip up the river and you are there. The Mosaic tiles are astonishing and the gold leaf paint makes this a special looking place

STUNNING!. Wat Arun - Temple of Dawn.....one of my favourite temples to visit in Bangkok. Tour usually includes a long-tail boat ride along the klongs of the river. Beautiful temple to explore. Snacks, drinks and toilets available as well as souvenirs.
Magnificent . I visited Wat Arun twice, it a beautiful temple, vertical stairs take up so you can have a 360 degrees view around the area

Beautiful Architecture. Wat Arun is a Buddhist temple, situated on the bank of the Chao Phraya River. It is one of the most stunning temples of Bangkok, not only because of its Beautiful Architecture, but also because the kind of its design which is very different to the other temples you can visit in Bangkok. though when i have visited the temple the renovation work was going on.Wat Arun is opposite Wat Pho, it is easier to get to from Sapphan Taksin boat pierby ferry boat that stops at pier 8. From here a small shuttle boat takes you from one side of the river to the other for only 3-4 baht.Beautiful place to visit.

Best temple in Thailand. Simply put, there are a ton of temples in Thailand. If you only visit one, visit Wat Arun. It is simply stunning. Additionally, be sure to go early to avoid the throngs of visitors.

A temple by a river. Yes, the location is by the Chao Phraya river. It's in the heart of Bangkok. To visit it we must cross the river using small boat. The temple is small but quite high with very steep stairs. It's different with other temples in Indonesia or Kamboja that were made from black stones, this Wat Arun temple made from ceramic pieces. It's unique! Nice to see in detail those ceramics especially which still has a complete shape like small plates. The quite bright color of the ceramics pieces made this temple shiny brightly comparing to common temples.Don't forget to climb to the top if you can to take pictures of Chao Phraya river & Bangkok as background. May be it will not be easy to take pictures at noon because it's very hot there. We also can take pictures from across the river so the temple will be taken in a complete shape.

Cool Looking Temple. This was one of my favorite stops on the temple tour. The architecture is old and storied, and very different from all the other Temples we stopped at. On a hot day- buy a coconut by the vendors near the base- 50 baht.

Under construction. The travellerguide wrote that this Wat opens at 08.00. The true opening hour is 08.30.
Unfortunally was the great tower under construction. The location of this Wat is beautiful: close to the river. Be early (as all the Wats) for a quiet walk.

Very beautiful, renovation works going on.. This is a lovely temple and well worth a visit. It is a little different to the other temples in Bangkok in terms of the design so it does offer a bit of variety if you are starting to suffer from "temple fatigue" after visiting several. Unfortunately when I visited you could not go up the steps to the higher levels and there appeared to be some renovation work going on.
Under renovation. It was under renovation when we visited, so not much to admire or appreciate. May be some other time!
Nice architecture. One of the coolest temples you'll see in Thailand. The architecture and attention to detail will blow your mind. Entrance fee is okay at 50BAHT (around 2$). Really worth the visit!
nice . my first trip to Thailand and visited all the temples, it was lovely but not as big as the other places. cheap and a nice day out :)
nice views from the top. best to access by ferry or by longboat. great view from the top of the temple. maybe a bit overrated but still a treat.
