A different style. This is worth a short visit for 30 minutes. The steps to climb up were closed(no entry allowed). So we just wandered around at the ground level and took pictures. The temple also looks great at night from the river.

Scaffolding. Hello Again Readers, Went on a boat trip to The Temple of Dawn but we were unable to access the steps up the Temple due to Restoration Work going on. However it was still a Magnificent site to view.

Amazing carvings but so loud. This temple has amazing carvings and architecture. It was definitely a fest for the eyes. Some of the decorations look like tea cup plates and tea cup bottoms which made me wonder if they had a "recycle reuse" program back then. This place would get a 5 start but for the blaring Buddhist monk speaking at an unnecessarily large decimal from load speakers throughout. It got to the point that we had to leave because it was obnoxiously loud and definitely not a relaxing place for reflection. That being said if you bring ear plugs you will definitely enjoy the view.
Unfortunately was under reconstruction. Unfortunately was the temple under reconctruction so we didn't go on the top. We just stayed around but it looks nice.
intersting from a distance. interesting to see but i would prefer it from a nice slow boat from the river than to really go there...Still quite impessive and unique

Unique . One of the best temples in Thailand, I visited lots of temples in Phuket and in Bangkok and I can say that Wat Arun is one the best I've seen there, it's structure is just wonderful and unique. 50 Baht entrance to this place, you can take the boat from the pier to arrive there. Wonen Should wear long pants and something to cover the shoulders.Can't miss visiting this temple of dawn when you are visiting Bangkok.

Im preside, A must see Temple in Bangkok. My first time in Wat Arun was impressive, I wondered how people could create a such beautiful thing, so fine, so beautiful. The temple is located along Chao Praya River in the different side of Wat Prakaew (Emerald buddha) A beautiful weather in December allowed us to enjoy our walking. It is recommended for everyone to visit when you are in Thailand.

Wat Arun . Closed due to renovations so we were unable to climb the stairs to the view point. It's a temple made of tiny tiles so intricate and beautiful - was a little disappointed we couldn't climb it if we could it would be a 5

Beautiful serene temple complex. Worth crossing the river to see (ferry 3 baht!). Set in pretty grounds overlooking the river, this Wat is quieter and more serene than those in the city centre. Beautiful, largely in white & gold, the figures of monkeys & demons are stunning.
Very buautiful. I am not a religious person, but didn't matter. The whole facility was very peaceful and beautiful with a very nice view on the top

So much detail. I suggest taking the canal trip first, then you will be able to see the Temple from the water. Some of the Temple was still under renovation when we visited, but it was still amazing. They pay so much attention to detail while building the temples. Simply awesome!! Also, there are several street carts selling food, I strongly recommend stopping and trying it out. It was yummy!

Beautiful Thai Wat. This was a much more laid back attraction than other temples and the ability to climb it added to the experience. It's worth adding in some fun ferry rides and other sight seeing on your way there. It's the perfect place to get a sweeping view of the riverside Bangkok and is a beautiful mosaic covered temple.

Just another temple. I was very disappointed that one could not go up the stairs to the top of the temple. This would have made this temple different from all the other temples. Save the entrance fee and take pictures while passing it on a ferry.

A must include in your bangkok city temple tour. This will be last in your tour after grand palace. Its pretty hot but the khlong crossing is pretty nice and the temple is very unique compared to the others.

Incredible old temple on the river. Look at the temple from across the river then use one of the big boats to cross the river and climb to the top of Wat Arun. You get a pretty cool view of the city from the top. The steps are very narrow and steep.
Great Climb. This is my favourite temple in Bangkok. A great steep climb which is rewarded with nice views. easy to get to by river or taxi. I have been twice and would go again.
Nice. Next to charopraya river this temple is very beautiful its very tough to clime but since you got tgere you have nice views

Great and quieter than nearby temples. Good option to avoid crowds at grand palace. Just across the river. Would recommend this one and reclining buddha across river. See grand palace early or late to avoid mass of tourists
Sadly Covered by Scaffolding. Unfortunately this temple will be covered by scaffolding for the next three years so I'll have to revisit in a few years to see how it turns out.
Majestic. Beautiful temple off the river, easy to get to, cost is low. The ground aren't very big, there was a lot of people there. Amazing structure.

Best seen from the other side of the river. This is a complex (ane enormously crowded) monument best seen really early in the morning, or better yet, from a distance from across the river during sunset.

Beautiful temple on the other side of Chao Phraya River. We visited this temple during the night (didn't make it on time to watch the sunset) and it was really peaceful and calm. A good place to take a break from all the noise and chaos of the city. The boat to cross from the other side of the river is really cheap (3THB).

Such an experience. 2nd time visiting this attraction. Pretty easy to visit. Alight at Saphan Taksin bts, go to the pier and alight at no. 8 Tan Tien pier station. Paid less than 20 baht for the ferry ride. Another few baht for another boat to Wat Arun.

The most beautiful temple (imho). This is, in my humble opinion, the most beautiful temple in central Bangkok. They were restoring parts of the temple at the time we visited, yet we could still enjoy the beauty of the intricate paintings on its walls. Although we were not able to climb up the steps to the higher parts as restoration works were underway, we could still get quite a view of its surroundings at the lower area. Definitely worth a visit!
Just WOW!. Amazing sculptures! Walls of temple are made from tiles. I never saw this style of décor in Thailand! Very nice atmosphere and not to many crowds! Must see!

Interesting temple. The Temple of Dawn sits on the river and is easily accessible from the off-on Chaya tourist boat via a ferry from pier 8. its design is different from the other temples and well worth seeing. The entrance fee is 50 Baht or about $1.50 US.

Beautiful Place. We took a private tour boat there but you can get a really chea public boat across the river. It was such an intricately built temple. You only walk around it and you can't go far up. When it's lit up at night it's beautiful. Please cover up too.

Amazing capture. This temple is so amazing that the artistic work is so detail and is a must to see and just too beautiful to describe. You will have to experience it. By the way the public toilets are very very clean and you will just need to denote any amount. Very satisfying for nature's call :)
Gorgeous Archaeological Experience. One of my best experiences on the trip - then again, I'm a fan of archeology, so I may be a bit biased ;)

Beautiful!. We visited here on our first full day in Bangkok - it was one of the temples we only saw from afar on our first trip, so we made sure to go first thing in the morning. It was pretty empty to be honest, around 10am on a weekday - they've been doing some work on the spire so you couldn't climb to the top, which was slightly disappointing. The architecture is stunning and you can really walk anywhere in the small complex, touching the walls and the designs (which I rather feel we shouldn't do, to help preserve it). I wish we'd read up on the history of it or hired a guide as I think you'd get so much more out of it having that - but it was gorgeous to see and I'm glad we did it! An easy walk to the Grand Palace once you take the boat back over the river, so we headed there afterwards. I imagine it can get very crowded at Wat Arun because there's not that much space to maneuver, so I definitely recommend getting there first thing!

Great inexpensive/close temple. This temple is close to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and The Royal Palace-- you just need to take a very cheap ferry (a few baht) across the river. It's worth it as it's not too expensive. We spent about 30 minutes or more on the grounds even though the upper parts were under construction. I do wish we would've seen the sunrise or set.
Under Renovation. We have visited before and although interesting the ceramics it is covered in were very dull. When we went past by boat this year it was covered in scaffolding.
Excellent tourist attaction. This Buddhist attraction is a great place to visit.It is a very quite place.The view of the temple is quite impressive and imposing.

Not worth it. Since it is being renovated, I wouldn't suggest going until it is complete. I was looking forward to climbing the stair to the top to see Bangkok and the skyline. We were disappointed that they had the stairs taped off.

elegant and genuine. The beauty of this temple is underrated and under-appreciated among Thais. I took my in laws to cross the river from Tha Tian to Wat Arun, and we watched sunset across from one of the fancy hotels. I really like the decors because it's one of the most unique temples in Bangkok.

best to view from a far. I have not actually entered the Wat, but I was told by many to go to the restaurants facing the Wat at evening time, and enjoy a wonderful view from a far. Yes it is true. During my visit in November the place was being renovated,

New years eve was great. New years eve was a special event and it was packed with people so we didn't get to walk and round much. But the lighting was great and the fireworks spectacular.
This temple is also worth a visit on an ordinary day.

Different style Temple. Enjoyed this temple because it was unique when compared to the other more famous temples. Enjoyed the statues and carvings on the temple and spires and their corresponding stories and religious importance.

Beautiful Temple in Bangkok. Wat Arun is a big and important in Bangkok. You can go to temple by boat. The easiest that you can take boat is go to BTS Tak-Sin and it have pier behind there. Take boat from Center Pier to Tha Tain (N8) 14 Baht and take boat to cross to Wat Arun 2.5 Bath. This temple is very beautiful. I should ware trousands ( Do not shorts and short skirt ).

Under renovation but still enjoyed it.. The only draw back really is that you can't climb to the full height. There are plenty of other places in Bangkok where you can get a view from on high!! It cost THB 50 each.
Wonderful All I can say. Such a wonderful display of art and the serene atmosphere makes it a wonderful must visit place.We can spend hours there and still feel was not enough.

beautiful view from a river boat - MUST SEE. Originally constructed after the fall of Ayutthaya, when first Thonburi and then Bangkok became capital city, the temple of dawn is a MUST SEE.Take the small ferry from the Tha Tien Pier (Wat Pho).Of course best seen at sunrise or sunset.There are a few bars opposite from where you can watch the sunset.

Wat Arun - Temple of Dawn! Stunning . A stunning place. Likely on your Must See list when travelling to Bangkok, Thailand. Aside from the sheer amount of people when you stand amongst the temples and monuments it easily muffler the chaos. Zero regrets and we loved it! @2travelers1backpack
A historic place. A must see interesting temple with infrastructure that is one of its own. They are undergoing some refurbishments. Try climbing the stairs, not for the faint hearted.
Easy and fun!. This is a great place to have a relaxed day trip. It is accessible by boat or by walking and more! Great scenic trip!

Tour stop in Bangkok. Visited as a family with two teenagers. Also used the services of an excellent tour guide whose local and historical knowledge was invaluable a brought the whole experience to life. A must see in Bangkok

Renovated and Spectacular . Now Bangkok's jewel has been restored to its majestic glory. Absolutely spectacular! Admire it's beauty and climb the stairs to have an unrivalled view of Wat Phra Kwae and the Chao Phraya River. Entrance fee is only 50 Baht.

Must see. Wat Arun is a must see place on a visit to Bangkok.
It's easy to get to via the river boat. Visit both day and night if you get the chance.

Do see this on river tour. The very lengthy restoration is nearly complete and most of the Wat is available to tour. It is a gem. Try to see it from the river at night but take time to tour in the day.

Travel with friends. The temple is accessible by taxi or boat at chao phraya river. If you go by boat. You can go to saphan thaksin station, take a boat and disembark at pier 8 (tha tien) then take another boat to the other side of the river t Wat Arun
Beautiful! . I loved this temple the most in Bangkok, it is very spiritual and you can walk up the steps on the temple and see the view. Highly recommend.

Different temple architecture but under construction. I wanted to explore the different architecture and craftsmanship of the temple and get a view from the top.
Was disappointed as restoration works was in progress and we could not go to the top.

December visit . We accessed this by boat, you pay 30 Bart for entry, woman have to have there legs and shoulders covered up
You can hire clothing while you are there for 20 Bart
Worth a visit would like to have seen it st night lit up
About 20 minutes you have seen everything to be seen

Worth looking. The best part is taking boat (2,5 bat) to cross the river. Very beautiful high Wat. Nice to look how monks are "selling" blessing to local people. You can not climb up, it is still closed for renovation.

Worth a visit. Keep in mind that they are renovating this temple so you cannot go to the top. it is still worth a visit. I went by boat and even though I was a bit disappointed not to be able to get to the top I still think it was worth a visit. I would definitely still recommend it.

My fave temple in Bangkok. I love this place. One of the reasons is it is has a reasonable crowd not like Grand Palace (with million people) and it is considered small but you will get amazing pictures nonetheless.

Worth a visit. After the crowds of the Grand Palace, it was nice to visit this smaller temple with relatively fewer people. It was possible to find a quiet place to sit in the shade and enjoy the architecture and sights. We accessed Wat Arun via the public boat. Total cost of the ferry is 3 baht per person so make sure you have some loose change. We only had a larger note which caused a problem for the ferry ticket lady.

Great afternoon activity. This is a must see - we'd recommend going in late afternoon, cross the river by boat, explore Wat Arun then cross back over and visit one of the rooftop bars nearby and watch the sunset over Wat Arun with a drink.

Fun but... Disappointed . This temple was enjoyable. Nice location right on the river. Disappointed because we were told we could walk up to the top of the temple and then when we got there it was all blocked off. Besides that it was nice. You could tell they were renovating it.

Lovely temple. Note that you can get to the grand temple and wat Pho without using the boat. It can be accessed by bus. The number 1 bus takes you there, which you can catch from the Golden Buddha or Chinatown area. From the grand palace entrance you can walk approx. 15 mins to a pier where you can catch a boat directly to wat arun for a mere 2.50 baht. Rather than pay 40 baht one way at other piers. This boat is literally opposite wat arun. So be sure to keep walking up the road until you find the correct pier. Such a great cheap option. Directions from grand palace: turn left from outside of main entrance of grand palace, walk to end of the road and make another left, then keep walking until you get to the wat arun pier. Remember there are other piers along the way, where travel agents will try to get you to pay more hiring a boat etc. Just ask them where the wat arun pier is and they should point you in the right direction.Entrance into the wat arun as of 29th December 50 baht.

Closed for repairs . We went in December and saw he reclining Buddha. Took a short very ride over to the temple of dawn and it was unfortunately closed for repairs. I have been in the past and it was very much worth seeing.
Nice place to visit. One of the top most attraction of Bangkok. The temple is located near to the river and offers best view around evening
must be visted in night. I had visted this place during day time with lights it will be a great vie,here too restoration work is going on

Magnificent. Its exterior is more magnificent especially viewed at night time. It can be reached via Chao Phraya river at one of its pier. For your information, if you happened to visit Wat Pho (Temple of Reclining Buddha), Wat Arun is directly opposite to it (except that you need to take a boat to cross the river first).

Nice architecture but under construction. I wanted to go Wat Arun as the design of the temple is much different from the other Wat in Bangkok, but as I reached there and pay the ticket (50B) I realize its under construction and you can't climb up Wat Arun, I was quite disappointed by that.
Amazing!. We toured Wat Arun as part of a canal tour. The river/canal tour in a "long-tail boat" was enjoyable, Wat Arun is amazingly beautiful.
Holiday. Actually from the distance we wasn't interested this place, but when you coming closer and closer you can say it's absolutely amazing like whole Bangkok.

day trip to eat arun. we tried to get here the first night we arrived in bangkok. we could see the amazing lights from our hotel anantara santhorn which was still quite a distance from wat arun. by the time we got to wat arun in the night the lights were already turned off. so the next day we visited the temple during the day. we had to get a ferry to cross the river and reach the temple. there is not much to see at the temple at all as the top half is closed off. so we decided to wait until the lights were turned on to see the temple of dawn - for what it is known and popular for. but we were told later that the lights would not be turned on today. when we asked why not, we were not given a reason. this was disappointing.
Nice arcitech and desain. U can buy cheap t shirt here. Best price as far im in bangkok. Can feed the fish ariund the temple also
Under construction. currently under construction but still worth the visit. Very peaceful place to visit. Love it there.

Must visit. A hotel staff from France who is now working in Bangkok recommend this temple. We went there by boat. The temple is amazing. Very different to Wat Phra Kaew. On our visit, ghe inside of the temple was not accessible, the outside was still being repaired by local artists. The temple was surrounded by stone Buddhist gods. Wat Arun is a complex of 2 sections. Make sure you visit both locations (side by side)

If missed, it's OK. This temple is very disappointing, it's basically just a big tower which you can nit go inside. You go around take a couple of pictures and that's it. The ticket is 50 baht, even you can't go inside, women have to cover up. To get there from the other side of the river you also have to get to pier 9 and pay 3 baht to cross, it take for ever even though they only cross through.
Cool. If your at the grand palace why not just take a ferry boat for a dollar across the river to see this temple. Just amazing the things humans have built.

Good place, but very hot during mid day. Good place, but was under renovation when we visited. So could not climb upstairs to enjoy the view of the city from the top. We had taken the tourist boat and then the ferry to the temple, and was a good experience. Try to cover it early in the morning, or in the evening, as it can get very hot in between.

Best to go during Sunset. We had visited during the evening hours as suggested by a friend of mine and am happy that I took the advice - the sunset clicks at this Temple opposite the Grand Palace is amazing.

Very beautiful building. Unlike other "gold" stupa and prang, the simplicity of white color spire adds a sense of purity and sanctity to this temple. Despite the name "dawn", it looks even more magnificent under the sunset

GREAT VISUAL . Was closed partially for some renovation when we went but still worth a visit as it is magnetic and symbolic of bangkok. Just take a ferry from the wat pho stop for 3 bahts to cross over.

Quiet and more beautiful than grand palace. This temple is very nice to visit even if there are some works on the temple. We preferred this one than grand palace (too crowded and the details of the temple are unachieved)
Under Renovation. If you like temples that are full with iron rods and construction equipments, you can visit it. Located on the other side of river, you could take a public ferry.
Beautiful. The wat is beautiful the gardens are well maintain. U need to take boat to the temple. Good experience. Nice view

A must. If you stay in Bangkok for more than one day, Wat Arun is beside Wat Po and The Grand Palace one must to visit It is one of the most famous Temples in Bangkok. You can see it from the river and reach by boat. It is located opposite Wat Po on the other side of the river. You visit Wat Arun for its towers and tiles. Also interesting are the small statues around the tower.In case you are daring you can climb the stairs out side the tower. They are difficult to climb for they have different highs and some are smaller and it is steep. But you will be rewarded with a beautiful view.If you want to avoid taxis, some drivers try to take advantage for it is a tourist attraction come by boat or with a private car.Without climbing the stairs the visit will take about one hour.
beautiful. the best way again is the skytrain to saphan takesin and take the river boat.it looks very beautiful from the river in the evening.
Under reconstruction. Unfortunately the temple was just under reconstruction, so we did not see so much of it, except of lot of scaffolding.

Visually impressive. Visited this attraction just after 5pm-sun was starting to go down behind it,which made for some excellent photo opportunities.It really is impressive structure and worth the visit/entry fee.Most of the scaffolding has been removed after the renovations. They close at 6PM,so be sure to get clicking before that.BEWARE!!!!!-I costs 3 Baht for the boat across from Grand Palace Pier,the man on ticket counter tried to short change us.

Time's effect on kingly intentions. Abandoned before the US became a nation, the temple sites at Ayutthaya now have the appearance of the kingly struggle against time and exterior forces; straight lines made crooked, level walkways become warped and wavy, and settling foundations tilt the towering spires and columns higgledy piggledy throughout the temple grounds.To quote my wife, "Thailand's Buddhist temple ruins are more interesting and amazing than the active temples we've seen in other places [Japan, S.Korea, Beijing, Taiwan, Hong Kong]."To quote my son, "These ruins are cool because they're ruined."Really interesting to visit after you've seen the active temples and shrines in Bangkok or Chiang Mai.

Wat Arun. Just opposite of Wat Pho and the Grand Palace across Chao Phraya River.Cross river boat cost only 3 Baht per person (please prepare small change).One of the must visit destinations in Bangkok.
Wonderful temple!. I went to a ceremony at Wat Arun a few years ago. The temple was wonderful. I also climbed the stairs. The stairs were very steep. I had great views of Bangkok and the river.
maybe the most beautiful temple in the whole Thailand. pity that most of the temple renovated in early December, but what is "discovered" dazzles its splendor
Temple under renovation. This temple is under renovation when we visited. Can see the scaffolding surrounding the stupas. Nevertheless, still a grand and magnificient temple.
Still renovation. Not much to see here because the Wat Arun still have renovation when going there. So many souvenir here and much cheaper.
Beautiful Dawn. Reached there about dawn and yes... We can see beautiful dawn from here. So calm and peace. Admission fee is also cheap.

Impressive but under construction. The temple complex is great but unfortunately at least when I went they were doing major restoration on parts of it. I still went back three times and when I'm in Bangkok again in February l plan to go again it's not the most spectacular temple but I like the feel and orientation of it. There was also a monk there blessing people the first time I went so that was fun to watch and participate in.

Wat Arun "Temple of Dawn" is My Favorite Temple in Bangkok. I first visited Wat Arun in 1985 and was enchanted by it. I later read Yukio Mishima's book "The Temple of Dawn" which made it all the more intriguing and significant to me. I just rode past it the other day by boat and realized how amazing it is.It has actually been chosen as Thailand's 2016 New Year countdown site because it embodies the Thai spirit.

A Beautiful Temple. Currently, this temple is under renovation and it will become more attractive after completion. The sculptures and artwork are being repaired and repainted. This temple is only accessible via river boat.

Very good. Very good despite the Restoration work but it's worth it.
Incredible carving of the Temples features.
Well worth the visit
landmark of thailand. with strong iconic of the temple of dawn (wat aroon), it bacomes as most memorable landmark of thailad.

Still worth a visit despite restoration work. If this temple was out of the way, I'd say don't bother visiting. But because it's in the area of other attractions and because it costs mere pennies (when converted to USD) to go across the river to this temple, I would say it's worth a visit. There's a fee to get up close to the temple and climb the first level or so, but you can't go all the way up like you used to be able to do. Once you get up close to this temple and you see the intricate details adorning the outside of it, you'll understand why they're doing restoration work. It'll be beautiful when the restoration is completed. So if you won't be in Bangkok again, definitely visit Wat Arun. If you will be in Bangkok again in a few years after the restoration is complete, skip it for now because there are plenty of beautiful temples in Bangkok to amaze you. And of course, dress respectfully.
My favourite temple. So beautiful and peacefulIt was my favourite temple I saw in south east Asia I loved the white and all the plates and only cost 100 baht

Okay to see currently. Very interesting place to visit if your into temples; though 2 of the largest structures are under renovation with massive scaffolding, takes away some of the allure. Wear shorts and a t shirt at least; I wore a singlet and though it was disrespectful to enter the temple, so I missed out a lot.

Fine wat. We took a canal ride and it is right off the canal. Very convenient location. However, as you have to dock, they give you 20 minutes! we didn't pay to get in. Not needed. However, had to pay to dock and they give you only 20 minutes. Weird.

Not worth it if you can't go to the top. It's ok compared to Wat Pho. If you're short on time, it's ok to miss it. It's under renovation anyway, so you cannot go to the top to get the amazing view. I enjoyed the shopping outside wat arun than the temple itself. Once you cross the ferry, so many more street vendors. Don't get the imitation shrimp. Squid was good.
Breathtaking. Absolutely marvelous with its ceramic decorations all over. At the time we visited it was still being renovated but it's possible to see the amazing ceramic work.
Amazing Temple. We visited temple of Dawn as part of our Bangkok trip. Amazing , must visit temple. Distinctive design from other temples. There are renovation happening at that time when we visited.

A Must See. Wat Arun is currently under renovation with scaffolding on a number of the structures which are still be worked on. However, this didn't really detract from our visit because it gave us a very interesting insight into its before and after appearance. The level of detail of the renovation is amazing and it was fascinating watching the artisans work on the small details with what looked like dental tools. Very fine work, indeed. For visitors who visit Wat Arun next year it should be a stunning sight.

Being renovated. When I visited this temple in October 2015 it was being renovated. Apparently they have to perform a full scale renovation every few years, which is understandable. Even so, it was a beautiful sight and well worth the visit.

Impressive and different!. A friend of mine took me on a sightseeing tour (chao phraya river) and we had a stop at that temple. If you have bin in Thailand already,- most of the temples look all the same after a while and you get kind a "tired" of it,- except this one! Very nice artwork and different! This one is a must see!

Under remodelation when I got there. Got there and was in remodelation. I entered anyway because it was free of charge. It is very peacefull and you can see many Budist monks walking around. Very good trip. Must go by boat and then take another flat boat to cross to the shore were Wat Arun is located. Very nice experience.

My most favorite wat. Simply amazing. People would love Wat Pho more but I just love this place. It's beautiful. The ticket price is only 50 Baht per person. Go there when you're in Bangkok. You won't regret it.

Beautiful spot. I visited this place first time in my life. The temple is so delicate and very beautiful, especially the night time with the spot light. You can't imagine how amazing it is until you come and visit by yourself.

Under restoration not renovation. Seeing a few people complain, it's clad in scaffolding how can you not know it is being worked on from across the river? It's and old building that needs care. Instead of moaning that a photo won't be perfect, it's a great opportunity to see the continuity of Thai artisans maintain the buildings. It was very interesting and beautiful. While the tourist hawkers really deflate the ambiance it's really worth a visit.

A short boat ride to awesome. A short boat ride from Wat Pho, yes the top half is under renovation but definitely worth the trip. You can still walk halfway up the temple and see and feel the magnificent splendor of Wat Arun. I would've been nervous climbing to the top as it looks steep and slippery. Went around eleven am and the place was nearly empty, I guess they stayed away in droves. Lots of scaffolding on the ground.In the main hall there was a priest doing blessings and people leaving in tears as they were moved by the Monk.Very glad I took the boat ride to witness this Temple.

temple nearby the old buildings. I took a boat. I threw some bread and a lot of fish came to eat it. When I was there, some parts were under renovation. It was wonderful to see Bangkok when I reached the top. I could see the river and the village.I visited the village and saw the old buildings and the statues of budhists.

Under maintenance but worth a look. Every trip for years I said I would visit and climb. This trip I made it and it was under maintenance. However it was still great to see it and enjoy the calmness of its grounds and presence. Take a walk through to the other side and stop at the café on your left across the road - I had THE best iced coffee ever and a small coconut to feed my thirst - and had a great conversation with the lovely lady who owns the café, called Lek and one of the old guys who lives nearby. They attempted to teach me Thai which I failed at miserably except I remember the number 3 as this is how many the THB's it costs on the boat to get across from the other side where Wat Po is. Im heading back for another coffee in 2 weeks.
Afternoon visit. Even though the temple was closed for construction, it was worth it going to see this beautiful Temple (WAT - in Thai). Steep stairs though. But built so well
Under Renovation!!!!. There were no notice informing tourists that the temple was under renovation until we reached the jetty.
Fun place to visit. Makes for a good visit as there is a lot to walk around and glance at. Good view from the top and very steep to walk up!
Construction. Looks cool in pictures but it's been under construction forever. You can see it from the riverboats and its looks quite impressive I just wish they would finish the work on it already.
Under renovation. Disappointed, place under renovation, wasted time to visit. Should advise tourists, so as to avoid disappointment.

Pretty but don't go during noon. Went there around noon, like 1~2 pm, super hot! Unfortunately, some spots were being repaired or reconstructed. Din't get to see the complete one! The entrance fee was okay. Don't buy things outside the temple, super expensive.

Experience getting there!. It's a very enjoyable Temple to walk around, and quieter than many of the others - although I don't know if this is just because when we went it was under construction. The trip across the river makes it a great experience, although the place to take the boat can be very difficult to find if walking, I'd suggest getting a tuktuk there.
Under renovation. Not recommended to visit due to under renovation (Dec 2015). I believe afternoon visit is better compare to morning visit.

For your inner zen. From all three main Wat(s) of Thailand (the other two being Wat Phra Keo and Wat Pho), Wat Arun feels the least commercialised.. which I like very much. I went there around 4PM after previously scorched in Wat Phra Keo and Wat Pho. Wat Arun is currently under restoration, so I think it will be ideal if you just go there around that time as the lights won't be on at night during these times. Not so many people when I was there (partly because of restoration) but personally I like it with less people. Chao Praya at sunset was really beautiful and it felt really zen. If you're looking for inner peace maybe you can try going here and sit during sunset time. well worth my 50 Baht :>PS: Be sure to try some foods along the streets before boarding the boat. They have a lot of selections (and the 10 Baht grilled pork is out of this world delicious!)
"Spell bounding". So mush to look for and a divine place. The architectures of the building and the sculptures were just so authentic and precise. It has a lot of learning and religious valued story.
One of my favorite temples in Bangkok. Whenever I go to Bangkok I make a plan to stop by the Wat Arun temple. The architecture is amazing and you can just wonder around without people bothering you.

Amazing, even during construction. This temple was not lit up at night during our visit due to tons of construction and scaffolding - but this temple should not be missed. A great opportunity to see all of the intricate little details up close and personal. Comfy shoes are a must. If you get hungry, walk ca. 15 minutes north on the main road and you'll hit the local outdoor foodie district - so.good.
Way less crowded. a beautiful place by the river. Less crowded. marvelous temple. Best travel to with someone who understands the history part
Awesome view. Make sure you climb to the top of this place and take a photo. The stairs go straight up basically so if you have trouble walking this may be a difficult attraction.

Combine with a visit to the King´s Palace. I recommend visiting Wat Arun when you are already in the area for example for visiting the Grand Palace. At the moment (Dec 2015) the main structure is surrounded by scaffolding but this worth a visit, I think.

Place should be visited. The Temple of Dawn was build for the King Tat Shou who was the first king of Chinese immigrate leading the Thai people flight back to the Bummer occupant. It is ease to reach by ferry or taxi.

Stunning. Visited here yesterday. It is covered in scaffolding which stops you from being able to walk up the steps. However, if you try to ignore the scaffolding, the temple is absolutely stunning. The detail is amazing. Hope the construction finishes soon

Different architeture. Wat Arun the only temple located on the other side of Chao Phraya river, and it is reason enough for you take the effort to get there. The architeture of this temple is very different from the other ones (Wat Phra Kew, Wat Pho and Wat Tramit) and despite of the fact it is under reform, me and my wife enjoyed it a lot. It has nice gardens and big statues.

Loved this. Wat Arun was very empty when we arrived so it allowed us to leisurely walk around and not have to fight crowds. It's a bit hidden down an alleyway, but when you arrive you'll be mesmerized by the spires. One of the best Wats we visited.

When Will the Renovation Be Done. The Temple of Dawn is exquisitely beautiful, but it is presently covered with scaffolding which makes it almost ugly. No charge for the moment, but under the circumstances it is hardly worth crossing the river. Normally worth five stars, at the moment two.
Pretty average. It was under construction and the entry inside the main complex was not allowed. From the outside, it is not really breathtaking and not worth the effort to reach there.
Historical place. one of the oldest temples and beautiful Buddhist world, with an original and colorful and exciting architecture, near the Chao Praya River, the rare spiritual beauty
Best place to go in the evening. Although the name says Temple of Dawn but the best time to go is around 6pm in the evening when the sun is just above the temple and lightning is amazingly beautiful.

Disappointed due to construction . Like others have said there is construction taking place.
I'm sure once it's completed it will be a must see again. We were on the other side of the river so it was easy enough to hop over on a boat. Best to check construction status if you are going out of your way to visit.

Amazing must Go Palace. Its one of the most dominant (although at the moment its under scaffolding for renovaton) and vast area to review.
Very peaceful grounds too
Best way to visit in via a river trip with a stop here..

Great to see. Great monument to see, however, no one told us when we paid to get in that the monument was actually closed and under extensive restoration. Spent most of the time looking at scaffolding. Still worth a visit once the work is complete
Beautiful temple. It was an exhilarating climb to the top, and a great view of the river side. Stairs are very small and steep. You must be careful, because you may die from falling.

One of the Must visit in Bangkok. It is now inder renovation so it was hard to get amazing pictures.
The compund has beautiful gardens and a great view of the river.
I would recommend going early in the morning or near the end of the day.

Songkrand Fastival. Good Fastival in Thailand. When you visited to Wat Arun, your felling happy, relax and funny together with you love one. Now on the temple are on renovation but not worry about that they do safe for all. Guaranteed beautiful all time; morning & evening (sunshine / sunsets)

Under construction :(. There is some maintenance work going on because of which you cannot climb the stairs to the top of the main building. That kind of spoils the charm of an otherwise great place to visit. Nicely locate right on the river side. Reaching there from my hotel was interesting though. Didn't use taxis .used a combination of train + boat + ferry . more fun
Beauty. This temple was so nice - lots of open grounds and not too busy. The details were incredible. Remember to wear pants!

it is under reconstuction. Untill end of 2016 it is under reconstruction, so you can't go up to the top, but still it is good to see it. It was interesting to see the different stages of the reconstuction!

Wat Arun. Not as impressive as the palace or Wat Pho. A lot of renovation was going on when we visited and some sections were closed. An entry fee of 50 Baht was charged for a section that was only partly open and it was not worth it. Get down at pier 8 and take the ferry across. Maybe good to visit if one has covered all other attractions.
Wonderful temple. It's one of the amazing temples in Thailand. It's not as big as the Grand Palace temple but it's worth the visiting since people can just get in without any fee.

Celebrated Loy Kratong here. This is a special and festive place to spend Loy Kratong. The chedis are currently being repaired so there is scaffolding all over it. Still a neat spot to be. During Loy Kratong, there are monks participating in donation ceremonies and food stalls. Great to go with family and friends during this celebration to see Thais giving offerings.
Temple of Dawn in Bangkok. This impressive collection of chedi is at the moment covered in scaffolding and much of the finer detail is obscured, in particular higher up on the monuments.

Fascinating must see, but renovations limit access. This Temple is much older than those at the Grand Palace and Reclining Buddha compounds, but is an amazingly intact Old Siam ere temple, fascinating in its own right.It's carved stone construction is spartan and functional, but the carvings are amazingly detailed and extensive. There's major renovation works there in 2015/6 which restrict access. I was there 4 years ago before the renovations ad climbed the almost vertical stepped face of the temple, which in itself was a challenge, but amplified the style and nature of the temple.It's located barely 10-15 minutes away from the Grand Palace across the river. Worth seeing, but with the renovations, the Grand Palace / Reclining Buddha compounds are better if your time is restricted.
Renovation going on. With a lot of scaffolding around but you still can look at the beautiful structures and mope at the IMMENSE dedicated work that is done in renovating it.

Absolutely stunning scenery! . I've been to the temple on the 1st of year. It was so crowded, people made a merit and pray. My sister and I tried to reach the top of chedi. It was great on top! Absolutely stunning scenery up there but not suggest to acrophobia.
Must see.. Really ancient temple, right in the middle of Bangkok. It's worth a look. A bit of climbing involved, but it's worth it.

Nothing great but HYPE !!!. I seriously did'nt find anything great about this place, except that it is the most iconinc symbol of Bangkok.
Th nearby stalls and markets offer a very good shopping experience and some bargain friendly vendors.

Under remodeling/construction but still nice. I rated it average after seeing wat pho and wat phra kaew and because there are construction sites going on right now. It is a nice spot still on the other side of the river but it can get very hot. You can buy souvenirs, drinks and ice creams in the area easily.

Must See but Undergoing Renovation. Our local host took us to Wat Arun at twilight. The area has interesting Chinese statues in addition to the temples. A very interesting idyllic place especially at night. Unfortunately in this visit, the temples were undergoing renovation and were not lit up. But I had seen Wat Arun at its best in a previous visit - an absolute MUST SEE. A lit up Wat Arun offers the best image of Bangkok, but you need to take the photo from across the river.
The 'Wow' factor. This is one absolutely beautiful Wat. I never dreamed that it would be so fabulous. I'm so glad that we visited here.

Beautiful but right now marred by renovation.. Wat Arun is one of the most beautiful sights while on boat f on Cho Phraya river in Bangkok.but do check before visit because renovationActivities are on.

Peace of mind. Close to the royal grand palace is one of the most beautiful place you can find in Bangkok.. incase you would like to explore some temples its on the top list.A nominal entrance fees of 100baht will be charged and you can explore some beautiful Buddha statue's including recling Buddha..which is one of the biggest Buddha statue's

A Must See Temple. One of the landmarks of Bangkok. You must see this temple. You can find related information on the internet. All you have to know is that you cannot enter with shorts, mini skirts, or with sleeveless shirts. Good news is you can rent one at the entrance by depositing cash. You will get your money back when you return it at the end of your visit. However, there will be long ques for getting it and for returning it. if you do not have enough time, you better go there properly dressed.

Must see! . It's in close proximity to the Royal Palace, you can take an express boat from Royal Palace for 3 Baht one way. Very beautiful, I spent easily an hour and a half here walking around and looking at what was here.

Stunning. All of the buildings at Wat Arun are so ornate and intricate. It's fascinating to walk through the courtyards. It is so large, expect to spend a lot of time there or to not see everything. Also, your ticket comes with a free bottle of water, which is clutch! Wear flip flops or shoes that are easy to slip off, as you have to remove them to enter temples.

No different to other temples only this is covered in scaffolding.. It is accessible by getting a boat at Pier 8 which is located close to the entrance of Wat Pho, the boat costs 3 baht each way and takes about 2 minutes. The entrance to Wat Arun is 50 baht and though this is only small money it is too much because the towers are covered in horrible scaffolding. I understand the importance of maintenance but close this part then and don't charge people to see nothing.
very scary to walk up. it was fine on the way up, but i trembled so bad on the way down hahaha, not recommended for family with small children
My favorite!. Amazing view from the top!!!!very turistic so make shure u go in the morning or in the sunset..buy the ticket inside the temple..dont buy outside its a scam!

A Great Landmark of Old Town of BKK. I travelled around Old Town of BKK, around Grand Palace and Chao Praya River, and Wat Arun of Temple of Dawn is located just opposite side to the Grand Palace and very attractive to visit, due to its architecture. And never feel disappointed, coz it's so amazing to climb up there with high step, ...and got great shots of photos !! Search for Tha Tien Pier and it's just the cornor of the Grand Palace's wall and Wat Pho... you can see a small lane..beside the beautiful park. Take Boat service 3 Baht fare for 1 personFor foreigners, need to pay for the entrance fee at 50 Baht. This place is mentioned that the most elegant pagoda and a great Landmark of BKK with 70 metres high and decorated with tiny pieces of colored glasses and Chinese porcelain. Temple opens 08:00 am till 05:30 pm. Don't miss it. If you can't visit, it's absolutely stunning view at sunset and especially, when it lit up at night.... !!

Bangkok must see. There are just so many temples to see in Bangkok that tourists are it off before they are too exhausted. In my opinion, this is in the top five of the must see places in town. One tip maybe is to go to the shangrila hotel jetty and get a tour of the river which takes in the temple. Sadly it was covered in scaffolding when I went in November 15.

Under construction Nov 2015. When we went to visit, this temple was under construction. We saw it from the ferry boat but we didn't even bother going over to try to get in. Hopefully it will be done soon so people can enjoy it again.

Amazing building in an amazing city. Whilst under the cover of scaffolding, we were able to see the level of detail applied to the construction of this temple. It is such a decorative building that uses recycled porcelain. A must see!
Beautiful. Wonderful temple near the rest of touristic activities in Bangkok. It's a must see in the city. If you like art and history, you have to visit this place.

Is presently under restoration but still worth a visit. Some of the temple is under restoration but this is still worth a visit. The temple is situated on the west bank of the river and is a lot quieter than other temples we visited. This came as a nice break from the crowds elsewhere.

Beautiful architecture . The temple itself is breath taking. Looking at the architectural artwork is fascinating, however, I agree with my recent fellow reviewers that the construction work takes away from the visit. From what's not hidden under tarp and ladders is mesmerizing. You really do feel like you're in a different time. It costs about 50 baht to enter and 3 baht to get to the temple on a boat from across the river. The surrounding area around the temple is very cool to look at also. I spent about 40 minutes walking around the premise and taking photos. You don't necessarily need a tour guide if you google the temples history before hand.

Beautiful buildings, undergoing renovation. Beautiful buildings, undergoing renovation and therefore much less busy than the temples. To reach this temple, you need to take the water taxi from the Grand Palace side
Beautiful. Lovely temples with brilliant views of Bangkok and the river. Steep climb to the top so wear good shoes! Beautiful gardens surrounding

Under repair but still a visual treat.. Its right on the river so use the local ferries to go here and just walk around taking in the sights. Its not even necessary to pay to go in as the other buildings are also full buddhas, nagas, and wonderful statuary and stories of kings, An active monastery and temple complex, its great to people watch.

I love to see this place from the other side of the river at sunset time.. I love to see this place from the other side of the river at sunset time. the view is incredible, so beautiful and worth your time.
Beautiful but in reconstruction. Beautiful temple on the river but currently under reconstruction. Climbing monuments is not allowed.

Reconstructing. This was also my second time being here, the first one is on 2013. But now I don't get a chance to climb up, the renovating the temple. At my first time there, me, my brother, and my mom climb up at the highest spot (I said climb, but actually we use stairs but since the stairs are too steep it can consider as climbing the temple). The view from upstairs are awesome, you can see Chao Praya river, and Grand Palace from afar.This temple was said look the best at night. So go here at night. The entrance fee is 50thb. And you can use the boat from the pier in front of Wat Pho (after you take some delicious food at the way to go to the pier), it only cost you 3 thb to cross the river.

Cheap temple tour.. I normaly Inc this with a trip up or down the river. Once you seen a couple of temples, you've seen them all. Some quite beautiful things to see. Climb to the top but only of your reasonably fit and not afraid of heights. The last section is unbelievably steep and not for the faint hearted.

Wat Arun A Stunning Temple.... Wat Arun is one of the most famous tourist attractions in Thailand. Wat Arun is not only nice because of the Buddha, but the surrounding is very marvelous. Wat Arun is surrounded by the Jao Praya River. If you look from the other side of the river, you would see the whole view of the temple.  I recommend you to go in winter because the winter weather in Thailand is a comfortable. You should enter Wat Arun at about 7:00 because people wouldn’t be too crowded. People who love to see the nice view should know that Wat Arun has a stair that you could climb up to the top and see the nice view. Although I really enjoy seeing the art and design in the wall, but I have to point out that they are construction going on. If you like seeing the nice view, the river and the Buddha then Wat Arun is a place you should visit.

ferry to get here is 3 thb, major reconstruction when we were there. beautiful temple but so much construction going on that took away from our visit. they rent you a sarong for 20 thb with a refundable 100 thb deposit. I might try it again after construction is done.

It's under restoration!. If it wasn't under restoration, I'm sure it would be beautiful. However, at the moment (Nov/Dec 2015) the outside is covered in scaffolding, hiding it's beauty. We took the ferry (3TB) to it, had a wander round the outside, and then came back. Never mind!
Currently a construction site. This site is currently under contruction. The building is surrounded with ugly scaffolding. Not worth going to see at this time.

Impressive view, especially at night. The temple itself is not so special to visit, but the view it provides is very nice, the surrounding neighborhood is special as well, you should walk around and interact with the localS! At the river promenade you can book private boat tours through the canals, this all together makes it a very nice location to visit

Under construction, but still worth your time.. While, as many have pointed out, this site is currently under construction, this does not mean that it's not worth visiting. We took a boat across the river from the restaurant at which we had lunch. The cost was just a few bhat, and the view from the river was great. Of course, I am planning to visit again on a future trip when the construction is complete, but I urge you to visit even with the construction. This is very different than the Buddist temples, more of what you would see at sites like Angor Wat. We'll all look forward to the end of construction, but I hope this brief review has been helpful to you in planning your trip.

Ear of corn. You can tell Cambodia influence on this temple because of the "ear of corn" style.It pays to do a bit of research before visiting. A quick bit of search and your visit will have more meaning to you.

Wat Arun. We came here as a part of klongs canal tour and sadly it was very short visit. I like to spend little more time than 20 min on this kind of places. Architecture is amazing and you should climb a lot of stairs to get on the top and enjoy a view - Bangkok panorama. If you can get up early and go there before sunrise, you will be able to enjoy full beauty and understand why is it called Temple of Down - these are the words of old traveler who was here in 60s and did that. Also, you need to have covered legs, it is possible to rent skirts/trousers there. If you have only 20-30 min to spend there, And if you are also happend to be there do not waste time, buy ticket and go inside.

By far the the best Wat in Bangkok. Great escape from this awful city and wander through old times. Its easy to get and one can find peace and tranquility there. Stay for sunset and see the image of the temple against the suns rays is beautiful.

Under construction . I've only given this a 3 as it is currently being renovated. It looks great but it's beauty is marred by the scaffolding and construction that is going on. I'm not sure when it will be ready again but I'd hold off on visiting as there isn't much point. It's pretty easy to get to though, we just took a boat from Pier 8. There's plenty of them and they are regular. Just don't expect to be able to see it in its entirety.

Beautiful Temple on the river . We took the ferry across the river after visiting the Grand Palace to Wat Arun. The ferry drops you off right outside the temple entrance. It was under construction when we visited. They have scaffolding going up the top two thirds of the temple. It was still nice to see even with the construction. I can only imagine how beautiful it will look after the renovation. I would recommend visiting this temple.

Relaxing, not crowded, and free. Good spot to stop if you're looking for a cheap spot in Bangkok near all the tourist destinations. 3 baht each way to ferry across the river, best impulse decision I made.

The Icon of Bangkok. This beautiful structure is just right for the river. When it's lit up, it adds so much to the atmosphere, and just belongs right where it is and compliments the whole soul of this historic river. It's also a must-climb when I have friends in town and they want to see the sights on the river. It's like BKK's Eiffel Tower.
Very nice. We've seen Wat Arun when part of it was under reconstruction works but still the temple is impressive as well as the ride with the boat towards it. Would love to see it in the night.

Too bad it was under construction!. One of the most amazing temples but unfortunately during our visot it was undrer construction so we were able to reach only certain level and not go on the the top to enjoy the panoramic view of Bangkok. But i will definitely go again.
Nice Temple. The temple was under construction. Very peaceful. It was free tour from Asia-travel. Must go to this temple if you are at Bangkok.

Pretty!. When we went it was undergoing restoration. It's a nice temple, and worth visiting probably. There are tons of temples everywhere though, so I don't really know why this one is necessarily better or worse than others. Just pick a few that are convenient for you and explore!

Temple of Dawn-WAT Arun. Across the river (Cho Praya) from the Grand Palace stands the ancient Temple of Dawn-Wat Arun. This was the main Wat in days of yore (17th century) and stood on the grounds of the old Grand Palace. A new Grand Palace has since been built and stands across the river but Wat Arun is still one of the most significant sites visited by all in Thailand. Do take the river ferry ride up/down the Cho Praya river on a day pass as you can hop on and off indefinitely for the day. Enjoy the sights and sounds of Bangkok and don't forget to SHOP!!!
Slightly Disappointing. Currently being renovated so plenty of workmen and scaffolding around. however worth visiting for the history value. Easy to get to via river taxi
under renovation. Unfortunately Wat Arun was covered with scaffolding and not open inside to the public. We did view it at sunset form across the river, stunning

Temple Visit . It's a bit disappointing because the main temple is undergoing renovation when we visited. But still beautiful and quite dramatic because before u get to the Wat Arun we need to take a ferry from the other bank of the river. And it will only cost you less than 5Baht for a ride. ”Arun-is the name Wat- means temple Just to let you know incase Ure wondering why they all name temple Wat something”
Amazing Landscape. It was renovation when we came. But it still amazing. There are mini shopping area for souvenir and cloths. Cheaper than in Bangkok market

Under renovation . Don't waste time trying to see the magnificent Wat Arun in its current state until renovations are completed in the next few months. Once completed it is the most impressive of Bangkok's 650+ temples
One of the best temple. When you guys wanted to visit temples in Bangkok just remember to bring water and a hat. The heat is just like there are two suns up there.
Awesome temple. One of the most importand and awesome temple in bangkok, you can reach by using ferry boat by paying 3 BAHT per person and you can enjoy the beauty of this temple.

Hard to get to. This was a disappointment after looking forward to visit this place. We were told by many taxi and tuk tuk drivers that it was "impossible" to get to without taking a 1000 baht river boat. We didn't want to cruise to it by boat because of choppy water. From Sukhumvit, we took BTS line to central station and then a tuk tuk to this place. We eventually did get there but we were disappointed, place was under construction and wasn't really anything special. It had some nice archetecture but nothing too crazy.

Under Renovation. This might not be a fair rating since Wat Arun was undergoing renovation and was covered with scaffolding. And I visited after a long day of seeing a lot of other temples. However, it is worth a visit, although because of the construction, you might want to just view it from the river.

Under maintenance. I downgraded my rating only because much of the temple is under renovation (a good thing long-term, not so good for visitors now). Scaffolding surrounds many of the towers. There is one tower without scaffolding that you can visit and enjoy.
So quiet. This is a lovely Temple, we went fairly early in the morning before it got really hot. Take the opportunity of travelling via the water, it is incredible.

Worth a visit in spite of scaffolding. This Wat seems to be perpetually under renovation. Considering it is very different from other temples in Thaikand and the fact that it is across the river from Wat Po and the Palace complex it is still worth checking out. There is also a complex of buildings behind the main temple that are worth a wander.
A stunning location. This beautiful temple is well worth a visit when in Thailand. The sense of majesty and scale helps to place Siam in context.
My favorite site in Thailand. This is my favorite sight in Bangkok. I love taking a longtail boat to the temple, and gawking at the elaborate sculptings. It is breathtakingly beautiful.

Another must when in Bangkok. Took a short shuttle boat just across from the Wat Pho (a few bahts per person). Wat Arun is under (much needed) renovation (cleaning mostly) thus there were scaffolds around it. But the place still has a special feel.

Temple of Sawn (Wat Arun). This temple is located across the Chao Phraya river and requires a ferry (from Pier Tha Tien) to get to. This is a stunning place with amazing architecture. One can climb up the very steep 70 metre high spire and get a great panoramic view. From the top you can get a view of Wat Pho as well as the Grand Palace. Inside there is a golden Buddha and detailed murals on the walls.
Wat arun. We have been there twice, once last year but only a fast visit. This year we had a private guide. Amazing! It's a really wonderful tempel and soo much to see if your not afraid of heights.
Restoration. Currently undergoing some restoration, understandably. Not the photo opportunity you might hope for, check before travelling, as shrouded in scaffolding at present.

Temple on west side of the river. Currently has a lot of scaffold up but still worth the trip and wandering around the area. 5 baht to cross the river on public ferry. Think it was 100 baht for entrance ticket.
Covered in scaffolding. The temple is still being reconstructed when we visited the site. Some areas are not covered in scaffolding and look very impressive including in pictures.

good place to watch sunset. this temple is on the opposite side of the chao phraya river to wat pho and grand palace so you need to take a ferry to cross the river. right now some construction activity is ongoing so we couldnt explore it to the best but i have been told it is one of the best spots to watch sunrise or sunset.
Wat Arun is a beautiful temple. Wat Arun is a beautiful temple of Bangkok. I was most impressed with the decoration hips tower - see my photos.

Renovation in progress. Price, 50 Baht, to enter has not changed even though you can't access a large part of the temple. Don't bother hiring the shawl or leg coverings because you won't need them just yet. Not sure when this Wat is likely to be completed. Lovely to walk around the temple area and gardens next door, then jump back on the ferry to cross the river.
Nice temple. The temple was on renovation in some part when i came there. But it's still have a unique design. One of the landmark in bangkok. U should go by the boat.
One of biggest attractions in the city. Strongly recommend visiting it in the evening or at night when it is illuminated and makes a spectacular site.

Disappointed. I had looked forward to visiting the temple but was disappointed as most of the temple was closed from the public and covered in scaffolding. This is necessary to keep the temple in good condition but it would have been better to have been told this before purchasing a ticket.What was available to the public was great.
Beautiful oriental architecture !. Alas part of it was being renovated and thus scaffolding spoiled the opportunity for good photographs. The building, the decoration and the colour are impressive.

Beautiful. One of the most magnificent temples I ever saw in my life. You can get an incredible view from the other side of the Chao Praya river. This visit is a must if you are in the capital of Thailand !

Amazing!. This Temple is amazing ! So gorgeous and the view from the top. is wonderful too! The Temple of Dawn is not to be missed. We took a ferry up and down the river visiting Temples and it was a blast! Do it!

Beautiful but under renovation. Even though the temple is being renovated, it is still quite beautiful. Because it is being renovated the spires are all covered in scaffolding. I still recommend at least taking a boat ride by the temple to see how pretty it is, but I'd wait till they're done repairing it to plan a full trip to the temple.
Review. Temple is under major renovation, so you can not access the temple, but the grounds and views are worth the visit
Fabulous. Fabulous place. I love it. You can go to this amazing place via river. From lebua hotel to river just few minutes. Easy to go via river.
Awsome!!!!!!. When i visited Wat Arun in Oct 2015 it is under Conservation. so could not enjoy the wat arun. but its fully decorated.. so its very great architectural monument.

Wat Arun Temple Opposite Grand Palace Bangkok. Went there on a free tour from Asia travel. However paid for the private boat ride to Wat Arun. This Temple of Dawn have normally THB 50 as a entrance fee but nowadays due to construction work at the temple its free entrance. After completion this temple will be a tallest temple in Thailand. Good place from photography. Due to hot weather of Bangkok early morning or late evening visits are recommended.

Not as Expected. I was just there last week with my husband and to be honest, we were kind of disappointed because pretty much the whole thing is under construction. You can't climb to the top yet they still charge you the same price for the ticket. The other architectural elements were still pretty but my husband and I must have stayed there for about an hour before leaving. To be honest, I wouldn't go out of my way to come here at least while it is under construction. I'm sure once it is complete and you can go to the top, you will have breathtaking views of the city and will be more worth while. I also wanted to wake up early one morning and watch the sunrise near Wat Arun however, I ended up not doing it because didn't think it was worth it with all the construction in the background.
under renovation. one of the most famous temple u have to visit.... but unfortunately when we were there.. is under renovationcannot take a good photo with a whole temple.

Under eternal construction. I liked this Temple and I understand its importance in history however full with workers, dirty and very small. if you are in the area and can get a glimpse, it will take you 10 minutes to look around and try to get a pic without platforms and scaffolds.

Scaffold surrounding it. Couldn't see the Temple of Dawn it has scaffold all around it. Went in the shrine to the last King of Thonburi, it was made interesting because I had my own guide. I watched 2 Thai people prey at the end of his bed (definitely not a Slumberland bed in fact just a wood top) once they finish preying they crawl under it so as to remove any dark shadows from their life. We then took the locals ferry across the river. My guide then took me through a food/goods wholesale market, you must look for this place, as there is a restaurant called Eat Side Story very good with views across the river to the Wat Arun. Couldn't locate reference to this restaurant in Trip Advisor but didn't have a complete address. Worth seeking out my guide said not many people know about it, even Thai people from Bangkok.

My Favorite Temple in Bangkok. Wat Arun is my favorite temple in Thailand. Unfortunately it was being restored during my latest visit, but I can't wait to come back for a visit once it is fully restored.
Great . I departed from Bangkok with a small group and the guide and we visited all the temple, it's better then go alone, and the price are cheap.

Nice of Temple. Wat arun. So very long time all people still no In Rajchawong Charkgi.. from me I visit first in 5 year old with my parents.. when you wlak go to top in temple you can see around Bangkok area

Under construction..... I visited knowing it was under construction and some reviews said it was still worth visiting so I went anyways. I was very disappointed - there is A LOT of construction and we just stayed about 30 minutes. If you have extra time I say go and see it, if not, I don't think it's worth going out of your way to visit :-(
A Amazing Temple. Wat arun in BKK is a truly amazing temple to visit, u understand the local culture at its best, great place to take some good photos, best to visit in evening

Temple rewards attention. "Wat" is the Thai term for "temple." The Temple of the Dawn (Wat Arun) rewards attention, but unless one has a particular interest in Therevada Buddhism, the visitor may feel "templed out." In this case, pick your destinatons with care. Remember that this is a house of worship and behave appropriatedly. Some may quibble that Buddhism is not a religion, but that is up to the observer to decide.

Amazing place to see in bangkok. The best place I been in bangkok. The day tour is very exhausted but worth it. We went to multiple tourist spots in north side of bangkok. Too hot during the tour and need to bring water. River cruise is included too and lunch buffet.

Not very appealing. We have reached their after taking a round boat ride but found it not so worth....entry is chargeable and there is nothing to do...however the structure in itself is made good but there are far better things in bangkok to see.

Insensitive renovation. The Wat Arun is under renovation, which is time to time needed and fully understandable. But the thing is it is not closed but still actively promoted, though it is all covered and you cannot see anything. Hopefully next time.

Under renovation. The temple is undergoing rehabilitation so the scaffolding takes a bit away from the experience. The work being done will certainly bring it back to its stunning self. Worth the visit. We visited on a bike tour so our guide explained the existence of the site to us. Pretty good overall.

One of the top tourist sites to visit.. Any trip to Bangkok is not complete until you have visited and cruised on the Chao Phraya River, which is where you will find this temple and grounds. If you are visiting Wat Pho, it is an easy walk to the boat pier. Pay your 3 baht for the short boat ride across the river to Wat Arun. While you might not feel like walking up the short/steep stairs of this temple, it can still be enjoyed.

Under construction . Currently under construction. We also waited to about 730pm and they lights weren't on. There's two rooftop bars they are great to view the canal and wat arun. We went to sala bar. Beer price is a bit more but still ok. 330ml glass of Chang draft was 160 baht with 10% service charge and 7% tax.

Under renovation. Stopped here on one of the boat trips. Twenty minutes was sufficient. A pretty little temple with a lovely spot of grass outside. Unfortunately much of the brickwork was hidden by scaffolding. Quite a bit of renovation work underway currently.
Awesome and Fascinating - a real Thai experience. This towering structure is easily spotted from the other side of the river, and it is worth crossing the river to spend some time here!

Thing of beauty. This is a very famous landmark of Bangkok, unfortunately it was under major renovation. You could still see the smaller temple and some time exploring the surrounding. It's a stop when you are doing the river cruise.

holiday. The temple is very impressive with a big Reclining Buddha and it attracts many tourists each year.To get in, you have to pay a fee and its not free entry, but paying to go inside is worth every cents.To get to the temples , you can organize a tour to get there, or you can use water taxis, skytrains, tuk-tuks or metered taxis and Buses.When using metered taxis, be sure that the meter is on, because if you are a tourists , you can get ripped off, and when using Tuk-Tuks, make sure that the Tuk -tuks Drivers take you straight there, because they can convince you to go to other places and try to sell you gemstones, and other items which you did not budget for, and sometimes if you refuse, they get a little bit upset.You just have to put your foot down and haggle for prices especially that they sometimes take advantage , if you are a tourist.

Nice. The temple still under contraction (for 2 years) so we can't make a tour a round the temple. But in this temple area, there are a market (souvenir market) that take rupiahs (Rp) for the payment and it's cheaper than Baht.
Bangkok beauty. Very nice and interesting, Big pitty that now it is under construction so all it is covered in poles. That's why we looked it only from outside, not entering
Great but under construction. It is beautiful in theory, but covered in scaffolding when we were in BKK so make sure you check ahead

Architecture marvel with shells. Wat Arun is a very beautiful architectural masterpiece. It is very unique that it is made with sea shells. You need to take a ticket in the local boat for 5 bahts to go to the temple. The view of temple at night from any river cruise is just stunning.
Renovations. All the Temple is presently surrounded by workers, you cannot go everywhere, it will be very nice next year!

Beautiful temple.. This temple is another example of the Budhist culture and the
quality of workmanship in its building and decoration.

Amazing place to see. I highly recommend a visit to this marvel. You'll need to take a boat to it and then there is a steep climb with excellent views over the city. The intricate carvings and structure of this temple is very interesting.
Excellent attraction, a must see in Bangkok!. This towering structure is often seen from the other side of the river, but it is totally worth crossing the river to spend some time here!
Worth a visit. Worth a visit. Ladies make sure to cover your arms. You can hire out something to put around your shoulders if you forget. Need a head for heights if you wish to climb up.

Do not miss !. The history and religious significance combined with unique architecture of this brick/plaster temple make it a definite required visit for the Bangkok area tourist! Surrounding property enables pleasant walk about and the site has a functioning monastery. Be certain to observe the monument, shrine to the roosters at the back wall area.

It's just as billed - magnificent!. Though partially hidden as a result of maintenance scaffolding during our visit, this is still a stunning site.
Few structures are more memorable than this - seen from across the river or within its walls.
This should be included in one's itinerary if visiting Bangkok.

Wat Arun. This place was also part of our tour. It was a very photogenic place we were told by the tourist guide that the locals use to scatter the ashes of their loved ones to these tower like temple... so dont touch it.

Currently under renovation. I read this place was beautiful and that a steep climb up the steps would have amazing views. Unfortunately it's currently under construction/ renovation and scaffolding is placed everywhere. Costed 3 baht to cross the river then I had to rent a sarong (whereas some other wats such as wat Pho let you borrow for free) and then the 80 baht entrance fee. Once inside I realized I couldn't really see anything and the steps were under construction so I only walked around for 20 mins . So felt I like this was a waste of money and time. However I'll give it a chance I'm sure this is beautiful when not under construction... unfortunate timing on my part. Apparently will,be closed in Feb 2016 onward for completion of restoration. But my advice after this experience is no point in visiting now until restoration completed

Stunning place, would recommend a visit in the evening with no crowds. Amazing architecture and history, worth a visit if in BKK. We went twice in the evening and day, both on separate tours. The reclining budda is closed in the evening, but there is a great atmosphere and your by yourself.

Under construction. Completely under construction. Instead of doing the construction part in different stages and one side at the time it is completely surrounded by scaffolds. Not the way the right way to do maintainance on such a city attraction.

Unique design place with quite a bit of a climb. You will need to get on a boat to go to this place, it cost 3bath. There are sooo many street snacks in this areas, juices, fried food snacks and many more. The temple is currently under construction, you will need to climb up to see some of the pretty view. There is a small stand inside selling cheap" souvernirs to buy. Can pay with Bath/ Indonesian Rp.

Quite a Place with Quite a Climb. As I was huffing and puffing to climb to a spectacular viewpoint on Wat Arun, I suddenly realized the ornamentation was made from broken pottery. Words cannot describe this beautiful temple, so you will just have to go see it yourself.

OK...but not as good as some of the others. They are doing some restoration on the temple and while we enjoyed the temple, there just isn't as much to see and it is not as impressive as some of the other sights in Bangkok. If you are near it seeing other sights, it is worth stopping in. If not, skip it.
Currently under construction . You need to cross over the river , the ticket price is around 3 thb ?Currently was under construction....Near this area still have one temple which is Wat Tho.

Ongoing building work ruins the place . Scaffolding and work being done - we could hardly see anything, no one told us this was happening - too busy making money of ripping us off! a waste of a pricy boat trip

Fantastic venue, now covered in scaffolding. This Wat is not just in an amazing position but is so beautifully and fascinatingly ornate, it is definitely worth a visit. Just now there seems to be a lot of scaffolding about.
Dont go atm!. Scaffolding all around it at the moment which is a shame as it looks really cool! Easy ride to get to by taking the boat over for 3bht

Evening photos across river. Visiting in day requires boat from mainland 800mtr across chao phraya river. Take the long tail boat for a thrill ride. At the temple expect many tourist sales pitches and if your templed to climb the temple be well rested. Evening photos on sunset from mainland are premium and super popular so plan your hospitality table. Google more at Bangkok achiever Wat Arun

Beautiful and historical.. It was beautiful. Allthough you can not go to the top, it is still beautiful to hear the history about this place and about all the plates that were broken for the temple to be done like it is today. Be careful of the people who will try to take you for an hour long drive with the boat to the "floating market"; they take you to ONE woman on a boat and tell you that this is the floating market. And you pay them absolutely too much.
