Disapppointing as covered in scaffolding..... Yes I know....these monuments/ temples all need restoring, but on this visit it was about the only Wat that I really wanted to visit. Still any excuse to go back is a good one.

The Ancor Wat of Thailand. Extensive construction and colorful structures are sure to impress the most "jaded" traveler. Take note of colorful broken dishes and pottery used for decoration. Tours allow sufficient time to explore the many Temples and grounds. Guides are excellent, knowledgeable and accommodating. Somewhat overwhelming.
Amazing. Wat Arun is very ancient temple. When i put my legs in ferry port, i felt overwhelmed. And climb at the top, i can saw interesting view, really really awsome

Under Construction . Was so disappointed that this temple was closed. We took a water taxi to see Wat Arun not realizing it was under construction. Not necessary to pay for admission since its under construction!!!! You can see just as well outside the temple. Once the temple is finished with renovation I know it will be very very pretty!

Night View. When I got to Bangkok I decided NO MORE WATS. My friend booked a 4 hr bike tour and this temple was one of the stops. This place is magnificent at nights. So peaceful, majestic and also regal. Each temple glisten as the light hits it. I'm glad I was able to see this.
Excellent . Recommend to all travellers. Majestic. Felt at peace there. Return again next time on my visit to Bangkok.
Very nice. Very nice and a must see when you are in bangkok. Really enjoyed it and I think we should have taken the English tour guide . Maybe next time

Nice change from other templed. As mentioned by others the upper sections are under scaffolding so you can only walk up to the first level which does not give great views of Wat Po. However it was still nice to see up close. Entrance fee is 50 baht and the ferry across the river (Wat Po to Wat Arun ferry) is 3 baht. If you're going to Wat Po you should visit this to.

Temple Under Construction. We were not fortunate enough to see this temple since it was under construction. Only able to see it when we were in dinner cruse in the night with scaffolding around it. Still very nice view.

Closed at noon . I understand it is a temple but it was closed at 12when we went there at 12. Moreover it was under constructions. If you plan on visiting it make sure it is open at the time you go before you go. You have to take a boat shuttle from the other main shore ( only 3bahts!)
It is under construction. Unfortunatelly, Wat Arun was under construcion when we were in Bangkok. We could go only on first level. It is amazing but scaffoldings ruined the view

Great Temple. Fabulous if you get there early. Climb up for lovely photo opportunities. Cheap entry compared to other places nad only a few baht to take the ferry across to the temple. Well worth a visit.

More Thai culture. Wat Arun was under repair/restoration when we visited - lots of scaffolding but it is still a very cultural place to visit. We enjoyed it and will look forawrd to visitng again when we go back to Bangkok at another time.

Scaffolding abound. Looks amazing still from across the river in a lovely park with a stepped viewing platform where everyone congregates from the boat in to watch the sunset. Shame it's under scaffolding which put us off visiting, but needs must as these Wats are really beautifully decorated with ceramic shards when you get up close.

Beautiful temple ! Splendid climb to the TOP. Visited wat Arun after visiting wat pho, wat Arun is somehow different from wat pho as one has to climbs up a steep flight of stairs to the TOP for a scenic view of Chao Pharya river. Great location for a windy quiet view of the river and overlooking wat pho. Best time to.visit is early in the morning or sun set time for best photo taking.

Covered in scaffolding. I had read the Temple of Dawn was being worked on before we went. I dont think it detracted too much from the beauty of it. We went just after lunch when the sun was up high in the sky. We had to pick the right angles for photos.Not as many people there as i expected. We were alone for parts of it.  I would have liked to have gone when the sun was setting like everyone said but the timing didnt fit in with us.

Worth the 3 baht boat ride across the river.... Yes, this is under heavy renovation but it only costs 3 baht (6p) to take the boat across the river from Wat Pho. Entry fee to Wat Arun was 50 baht so very cheap in the overall scheme of things. You can still walk around the temple and there are plenty of photo opportunities despite the scaffolding. Nice to visit at sunset so get there by 4.30pm/5pm before the ticket office closes.
Nice place. Though the temple was renovating and we could not climb up, I enjoyed the serene view of the river and surrounding places.Must go plac ein Bangok
Under repair. The markets around the Temple Wat Arun are full on. The peddlers here are a little aggressive. The temple is under repair at the moment but will be very pretty once completed.

Not worth the fees . I was looking forward to see this but unfortunately it's under construction/renovation. It would have been nice to climb up top for the view. You can still take the boat across & walk around the grounds but I wouldn't pay the entrance fee to go in.

Lovely day but beware of scammers. My first day in Thailand on my first visit was spent here. Beautiful temple with great views of the city. Just remember to use the public ferry and not a private long boat. I get ripped off big time, but I only have myself to blame for not fully researching. Beware!!!!

Very nice but under construction. Couldn't see everything because it is under construction these day.
Why they still charge 50 bath entrance fee if you can't actually see anything.

Under Renovation. Much scaffolding when we were here so not as picturesque.
I didn't think this was a "must see" given the quality and quantity of others to see in Bangkok.
Great Temple on the River. Well worth a visit on the Beautiful Thai River - Get the boat from the riverside where there are plenty of food places to eat

under construction :(. On my recent trip to Bangkok I went to see Wat Arun - a temple located across the river from Wat Po. Unfortunately, large parts of the temple are currently under construction/renovation, and were not accessible - and the main temple spire has scaffolding all around it. Still, there are many picture opportunities on the grounds, and quite a few statues to look at. Also there is a vendor in front of the temple who will let you dress up in traditional Thai costume and take many pictures of you with the temple as a backdrop, very fun!

Temple of Dawn - wat Arun Under resoraation/construction. We took a ferry to the Temple of Dawn. The temple is currently being restored & under construction. Nevertheless, still very beautiful.Very Hot! Loved the coconut ice cream

Undergoing restoration . Situated on the western bank of the Chao Phraya river, this temple is currently undergoing extensive restoration. So its full glory is hidden for the moment and so was left a bit disappointed. Also felt that the entrance fee was unjustified as visitors can't climb to the upper reaches of the prangs. But the place overall is beautiful though and I am sure that Wat Arun will look fabulous once restoration is complete.
Amazing. If you want to travel BKK you have to visit there. Enterence is 50 thai baht. And photography is not aviable.

Beautiful temple with a great view. Don't forget to climb up when you visit Wat Arun to get a view of the city and the Chao Phraya River. Climbing up and going down can be tricky because of the very steep steps. As this is a temple, observe the proper dress code. Tip: Although long dresses or long skirts are appropriate, they are not suitable for climbing. We saw ladies who were wearing long dresses having difficulties going down the temple because the wind was blowing their skirts...so, if you're planning to climb up the temple, wear clothes and shoes that will allow you to do so with ease.

Beautiful Buddhist Temple situated on the bank of Chao Phraya River!. Temple of Dawn which is also known as Wat Arun is really a stunning place to visit in Bangkok. Being located in the river side, made it even more beautiful. Sunset is amazingly beautiful from there.
Wat Arun After Grand Palace. This Tample was beautiful.. but unfortunetly when i was there this tample in fixing condition. so i can't explore more only downstaire.we also can buy sovenir here

Probably stunning but under restoration so could not tell.. There is no doubt that this is a must-see, however it's also undergoing restoration (October 2014) Si there is not much detail to see and the temple is shut! Pay the entry charge and enjoy the riverside setting.

Peace assured. In the midst of hustle and bustle of an ever throbbing city of bangkok this is a sure shot place to catch ur breath and be with urself. amidst serene atmosphere and situated in the lap of chayo praya river, u can gaze at the other side and feel that now u r a part of a different world. Beautiful gardens surround it. Sad it was being repaired the day i visited. So have to unwillingly give 4 stard
Under Construction. 50 baht and under Construction. Wait until its finished. will be a nice place after fixing. Easy to reach by ferry.
Nice, and open. The staff were very helpful, and provided outer wear to those who did not dress "appropriately to visit a Buddhist temple. Very nice. Lots of bargaining...

Undergoing renovation. The temple is currently undergoing renovation. Would definitely give it a strong 4 out of 5 if it wasn't covered in scaffolding. A 3 baht ferry from the other side of the river. 50 baht for a ticket to enter the temple. Pleasant stop along the river.The water transport can be a little tricky. Definitely tried to avoid the tourist boat but somehow ended up purchasing a day pass (150 bht) -- thinking that it was the public ferry. Public ferry is 15 baht per trip and actually preferable. The public ferry tickets are purchased on board.
Not worth as a tourist place. I did not understand why it is called temple. There is nothing buy stairs. We walked almost 200 steep stairs up to see nothing. Not worth as a tourist attraction.
Stunning at night. Lovely visit when no one else was there. Beautifully lit up and interesting facts related by Jib at Expique.

Landmark near Chao Praya River. A must if you travel in Bangkok, the tall stupa 66 meters above in the opposite site of The Grand Palace across Chao Praya river. A must is climb to survey at the top to see river view from top of stupa and fine art which decorated by chinesse ceramics and porclain to be mythical animal , giant and deva in Thai style. The most beautify door guardian tall 3 meters above at the gate of temple and the Chinese doll decorated around which it been ballast at the ancient time. Current it on construction and it might take time around 3 years above but still being such a "MUST" to visit ...Don't miss it

The "Angkor Wat" of Bangkok. Arriving from the Chao Praya river and seeing Wat Arun is quite beautiful, and definitely a good photo op. The temple is easing to spot on the River as it is tall and on a prominent location near the river. Climbing the Wat is not for beginners, or the elderly as it is quite steep. There are vendors along the side of the grounds that sell food, water, clothes, and trinkets. But the day I was there the vendors were very rude. Maybe because there were no tourists, or that business was slow that day. So don't expect to see very many Thai smiles there. It can get very hot so ware a hot of some kind and stay hydrated.

good temple. wat Arun is one of the 3 must-see temples in Bangkok. The best way to reach it is via ferry to Tha Thien Pier. There are frequent.As the name says it already go at Dawn and you will be mesmerized by the beauty of this temple
Good. Same with Wat Pho, you need to take a boat to go there. So impressive, the stairs it self it's so high and steep . you have to be careful while going up.

Under renovation! Is better to wait until full re-opnening. . We went to the temple via a small private boat, which was actually pricey about1500BHT each, but i found out later that there are cheaper transportation ways. Temple is under renovation since February '15 and most areas are closed for visit. I wasn't impressed as i was expecting it to be one of the best temples in Bkk but it is actually small an you can finish the visit and photos in about 10 mins.

Interesting site to explore!. We took the ride on across the river to see this attractions. Lots of fairly big temples, very unique architecture and we were able to hike up a few of these and enjoyed the views of the city. Definitely a must see while in BKK!

Wat Arun and Temple Cats. Wat Arun is a "must see" and easy to get to from Wat Po and a good reason to take a boat (the boats with the orange flags cost only about a dollar!) to Wat Po. From Wat Po you can take a ferry across the river to Wat Arun. I'm always surprised how many foreigners I meet in Bangkok who NEVER take a boat on the river. It's one of the easiest things to do in the city. I would have given Wat Arun 5 stars just for the views of the river and cityscape, but because of some refurbishing in parts of the temple, I can't right now. I took several photos of the temples and temple cats while in Thailand (including Wat Arun). If you're interested you can search for it. The slideshow is on youtube titled "Morning Cat Temple".

Temple Renovation is on at Wat Arun!. Wat Arun is one of the 3 must-see temples in Bangkok. The best way to reach it is via ferry to Tha Thien Pier. There are frequent ferries.We took a ferry from Sathorn Pier (as we were in Shangri-La) to Tha Thein . For tourists the ferries with blue flags charge 40 baht one way per person. But if you manage to get the ferry with orange flag the rate is 14 Baht one way per person. For the 14 baht ticket, you will need to buy the ticket on the ferry itself.then the ferry across the river for 3 Baht to Wat Arun. There is extensive renovation work going on now and hence we could not see much of the temple but whatever is already done, is pretty impressive.Please carry an umbrella or raincoat as the rains are sudden and torrential!Temple timing: 8.30 am to 6pmDress code - please cover your arms and legs.Temple does provide you with a sarong /Stole to cover up on rent at a cost.Ticket cost : 50 Baht /person.

Amazing. Didn't tour ,just viewed the temple from the Chao Phraya River. Such a contrast with the modernity of Bangkok. It is across the river from the Palace so you have to pick the appropriate boat to get there. It is really a destination, not sure if there other other sights to see on that side of the River.

A must see!. As the name says it already go at Dawn and you will be mesmerized by the beauty of this temple!! But at a great day with cool sunsets it is as nice. Make sure you see the view from the other side of the river!
Temple under construction. Temple is undergoing some renovations & most areas are closed. Not worth the visit at this moment although the cross river boat cost only 3bhat.
Lovely place. This is an amazing looking template and its beautiful and peaceful. Take your time, enjoy the river near by and enjoy the food.
Arun Kumar Tiwari. The temple is situated right on the banks of river and just opposite to it on other bank is Royal Palace. A panaromic view of the city at the sunset is worth the visit.

Must see. Take the local boat early
This is one of my fave temples in Thailand . So impressive. Not crowded. I like to spend time here just sitting by the river and temple

Very pretty and traquil. You can pretty much do most of the main temples in Bangkok in 1 or 2 days. Wat Arun is accessible via the river, don't make the mistake like we did and get off the ferry too early as you'll be in for a bit of a walk. You can also climb up the temple but the stairs are pretty steep so wear decent shoes! Very pretty detail across the temple, set amongst some lovely gardens too.

Not Much to See, Run Down. The silhouette of the Temple of Dawn is iconic. But no need to see it up close. Compared to other temples, it is very plain and run down. The structure is crumbling, and growing weeds. It is currently under scaffolding and undergoing restoration. However even the restored parts are not that spectacular looking. It just isn't that colorful, and there aren't many carvings or images to see.

Not up to the mark as expected. I had an huge expectation from this place as I have seen in many photographs, but it has been broken.Due to renovation we could not enter at the top. But the crystal work at the wall is really nice.

Small and under construction. This temple is interesting to get to. You have to go down to the boat dock and get on a ferry that takes 3 minutes to cross a river for about 3 Bhatt and do the same on the way back. The temple it's self is one of the smaller ones, but the it is call temple of the Dawn because to walk the stairs to the top your practically rock climbing. When I visited it in early September 2015 it was under construction, so even though you could still walk up it, (which cost money), it was not as nice of a view through all the scaffolding. This temple is really for more fit people if you want to climb it. I would not recommend for children or older adults who have health issues. I found the trip back and forth from the temple to be fun. With a great stop at the fish market for lunch, which was delicious.

Temple of Dawn. pretty much like a relics. old and majestic. i would it say its within a budget sightseeing worth the money. even tho boat rides cost 20baht back n forth and the visit the monument you have to pay basically 200 baht per entrance but current they are undergoing a renovation on the monument.

Every Temple is the same general idea BUT.... How many temples do you need to take a boat to in order to see it? Okay a few, but in Thailand? In the Middle on Bangkok? come on, totally interesting!The boat driver's will try to knock you down dollars, if you speak Thai or no a bit, you can bargain a decent price, but there are a couple different tour options, depending on how long you want to be on the boat, may not be worth the time-money ratio but still quite interesting regardless.
Stunning temple a true must see. Absolutely amazing stunning temple, a must visit if you are in Bangkok and have a interest in temples, steps can be a bit of a killer but well worth the work out
very impressive - must see!. This is one of the most impressive temples we have seen on our trips to Thailand - be sure to go there early, so you can enjoy the view without the crowds!

must see in Bkk. when you are in Bkk, this is not to be missed
visit the temple during day time ( its acros the river) and
see the temple at sunset from the othersite of the river great
Worthwhile. Take the boat from the other side of the river to visit this spectacular attraction. Even though it is undergoing renovation it is still worth the visit.
See the beautiful sunset from the top. Wat Arun is a famous tourist attraction that should be visited when you came to Bangkok. You can see the sunrise or sunset from the top of this place.

nice but steep stairs!!. Absolutely stunning temple, a must visit if you are in Bangkok!! Make sure you are well trained to go all the way up, the stairs are so steep!! And make sure you go mid afternoon, going in the morning there is pure madness as it is full of tourists and too hot.

Stairs are too steep. I would definitely not take my parents here, as stairs were too steep and the buddha statue is also not so great, but you would get a good view of the city, especially at sunset.

Stunningly beautiful. Visit this temple via the river boat. It's a good experience. This temple is a good place for photography. Do advise to wear long pants as short/skirts are not allowed cause it is a religious place but you can rent a scarf to cover your leg. Do aware that there are lots of visitors and it can get very cramped on the stairway and do visit in the evening to avoid the hot weather. If you do visit during the hot weather, there are lots of stalls outside the temple area for you to quench your thirst in the soaring heat. Chilled coconut drinks are recommended.
Same with other temple. This temple was under construction/renovation when we go there. Its accessible through boat by the river. If you have been to some of the temples, its almost the same.
Marvellous. It's my second or third time to go here but it is always a great experience and moment. This time unfortunately they were maintaining it so we couldn't climb up. A must see in BKK

See it. The temple is under construction and did not lend to the experience of other temples in BKK. We accessed it from the river which was very easy to do, though our day was ruined and did not help with our tour due to the rains. I suggest visiting the temple as it is of great significance

A beauty. This temple is just by the riverside on Thonburi side of Bangkok. If you come from city centre you first have to take a boat from Saphan Taksin to the Wat Pho pier and then another boat across the river. Wat Arun is Khmer architecture, a real beauty. Unfortunately it was under renovation when we last visited it (Sep 2015).

GREAT TEMPLE DAY AND NIGHT. I suggest you check this place both day and in evening. They have this aura of magnificence and gives you an awestruck feeling in both ways. I like this place during the night better though. So if you're schedule is hectic try visiting this during the night, but you can also check this out after you tourgrand palace
Beautiful. Almost wanted to see this beautiful temple and pleased to have finally seen it in real, although it was smaller than I expected.
Great Day. Very fun experience for the whole family. We ate and walked around the temples. Overall its worth the trip
Truly impressive place. The tiling details are spectacular, as is the array of impressive buildings. Also, worth visiting at night as well as daytime, as it is beautifully lit.

Good to check out of list. Nice temple with good views of the city but nothing special. The stairs are bit narrow and steep. I almost twisted my back while walking up with backpack.
Better is to sit across the river and take nice pics at dawn or dusk.

Serene. Took a boat and went to see Wat Arun, The temple of dawn. Quite a nice place, but currently under renovation and so views of the temple were partially paralyzed with grills structures. People come here not only to visit but pray. I went with some young Thai friends who prayed and the Monk sprayed Holy water on them. Apart from statues of Buddha, there were statues of the King. Many old stone sculptures. The garden was also lovely. Lots of cats around. Food was a bit expensive.
So hard to get up there... but worth it!. Very difficult steps to climb - a real challenge! - interesting architectural construction, amazing view!

Old temple on the river. If you have the chance, do a river trip to include Wat Arun - This way you will get to experience and see life on the river as well as explore the temples. The temple of dawn looks great at night time when it is lit up.
Wat Arun Trip. Excellent trip and Love it so much..very nice sea view from the temple. Took a lot of photos about the temple and fell in love with the place and history

A good exercise!. Be prepared for the long, tiny and steep staircases up to the top. It is certainly not for the faint-hearted (like me). However, I fought my fear of height and conquered the Wat Arun. I am sure it has that breathtaking view once you are on top of the temple but unfortunately, I have to look at my feet only..huhu

A long long stairs to the top. A temple beside the Chao Phraya river!!!
It is a big tower with a long long stairs!!!
it is so popular by local Chinese, go there to pray!!!
Say in truth, just go to see & nothing for feeling!!!

Romantic temple. Climb the stairs on this stone temple to reach the top wich have an amazing view over the river. A fresh aired sweet spot where you can get some nice shots or just relax and take a walk or feed the fishes. Definitely worth a visit during the beginning of dawn

Under renovation. We went first to Wat Pho then took a boat going to Wat Arun. The pier from Wat Pho to the pier is a walking distance though and it only costs 3baht for the boat ride. But we were a bit disappointed when we reached Wat Arun because it was under renovation and full of scaffolds. And yet you still have to pay 50baht if you want to go inside.
Being restored. Could not experience the true magnificence of Temple of Dawn as it was shrouded in scaffolding being restored. Still a nice place to walk around.
Lost in transition in Bangkok. Unfortunately, the Wat Arun temple was under reconstruction/rehabilitation during our visit. However, the temple would have been a good sight especially at night.
Good place to see the traditional Thai architecture. Good place to see the traditional Thai architecture. Could not say more about this as it was closed for restructuring works when I visited there.

Great temple, currently under restoration. Unfortunately when we there they were currently repairing the outside of the temple, so we could not see much of it.But the entire area looks great! There is much to discover when venturing around, the monks are really friendly and the small temples and figures look amazing. You have to pay a fee to enter the main one, though, and we did not do it due to the renovations. But when we will travel back to Bangkok, I will surely visit it again and try to get a closer look!

Temple of Dawn. I love this temple as it provides great view of the Chaopraya River. It is accessible by taxi and boat. Worth a visit if you are visiting Bangkok. Always take my foreign friends there.

BEING RESTORED. Under restoration for the next few years; Scaffoldings all around.
Better being avoided for the time being.

Under restotration... the temple is under massive restoration and hence couldn't see much of the temple. The scaffolding around the temple and the fact that we couldn't go up the stairs to see the view was such a let down.

Sun and Moon. I took a cheap boat over from the ferry terminal, and I climbed the temple of dawn. I managed to go there before sunset and saw both the sun and moon in one frame. It was a very interesting sight and it becomes more beautiful at night as they close the attraction and switch on the orange glowing lights to light up the entire temple.
Nice temple. Went there during construction.The temple is soo talland clean but it is hard to find some drink in the area. The entrance fee is not so expensive( 100 bath if I am not mistaken)
glowing temple. climbing this temple is quite a challange. the temple will "glow" at around 5-6 PM. So best time to visit is 3-4 PM.
Very nice . Nice to visit at sunset and if you can go to the top! Was under construction when I went so we did not expierence it! Laying Buddha is worth seeing!

Average trip to an amazing temple. My friend and I hired a boat and went over to this amazing temple. The detail was incredible but most of the temple couldn't be seen or accessed because of restoration work. As soon as you arrive there are merchants pushing you to buy souvenirs. we had to buy our ticket to park the boat then a ticket into the temple then we had to pay to cover our shoulders, it adds up quickly. The temple itself was fantastic, although all we wanted to do was climb to the highest point but it was blocked for restoration. The statues, sculptures and architecture was awesome.

Land mark of Bangkok. This temple is almost include with the canal tour, but also very easy to get there on your own, just only take a ferry across the river from Tha Tien pier then, you can visit one of the most amazing temple in Bangkok or you can plane your visit two temple at the same day like Wat Pho and Wat arun

Nice but Under Maintenance now. This temple is across the river and pier to get a ferry is walking distance from Grand Palace. Fare is 3 Bhat per person. Tuk Tuks are also easily available for 10 Bhat. When we visited this temple last week it was under maintenance so could not witness its beauty fully.

Renovation is Underway. This is an amazing sight, but be aware that it is currently undergoing restoration and you cannot climb it. Usually, you can climb up at least two levels, but no now. I do not know how long the restoration will be on going. Nevertheless, you can see enough of it that a stop is still warranted.

Beautiful, Even During Construction. Beautiful temple!
I noticed more of the intracate tiles at this and building decoration.
It was under quite a bit of construction but still gorgeous.
Culture, historical and fun!. Fun to arrive by water taxi. Worth a little side trip. Part of Thai culture. Great views of the river and the city skyline
Very nice. There are a lot of construction and reparation workd done at this timem but never the less we could see the impressive temple

Top Attraction for Moi!. This place is awesome. I've visited it multiple times due to the beautiful art on the temples. Bring your best camera and if you're serious about taking great pictures, expect to spend some hours here as there is plenty to take pictures of.

Beautiful temple. We visited Wat arun in september and it was being restored so we didn't see it fully.
The temple is beautiful and the ferry ride is also fun. It is not as crowded as Grand palace and Wat pho which is a big plus!
Under maintenance. Unfortunately was covered in scaffolding when we visited. Will be quite spectacular when/if the maintenance is finished.
Renovation!!!!!. You can't really enjoy tge beauty like that. Too bad we didn't know it was quite a disappointment. But there is a nice lady that does palm reading. She's great

Different Architecture. Wat Arun is worth the trip across the river, the architecture is different from many of the other temples. More along the style of the temples in Siem Reap, Cambodia.
It's quite small and doesn't take long to go round, but the river crossing adds to the enjoyment.

Beautiful Views. The view from the top of Wat Arun is not to be missed. While the climb to up is not for the feint of heart you will not want to miss the stunning view of the mighty Chao Praya River. The mosaic stylings on the chedis and temples are so intricate it is hard to imagine the painstaking care that was used when decorating these temples.

Under Restoration, But Still Worth It.. This is a remarkable, historical place that is thankfully getting restored. Much remains visible and can still be sufficiently explored. One reviewer complained about the boats. Those are the best way to visit and see another side of Bangkok unless you're handicapped.

Very peaceful. Amazing historical site on the bank of the river depicted to the Sun God, very beautiful architecture, the temple is like a breath of fresh air far from the crowds, a must visit for any tourist in Bangkok.The steps are very steep and difficult to climb for elder people, currently the temple is undergoing renovation and many parts of it are under construction. This temple is definitely there in any picture that depicts the skyline of Bangkok.

Under construction and surrounded by scaffolding. visited this site by boat as part of our tour. To get on and off the boat was a little scary as it was quite a rough day on the water. Upon arrival on land, it was hard to see much of the Temple due to scaffolding.what could be seen, it was okay. There are market stalls surrounding the temple, which offered Thai souvenirs. You do not need a long time here, and that is lucky as our boat driver only gave us 20 minutes anyway.
Amazing historical sites, with friendly guides.. Discover an amazing piece of Thai history, with a friendly local guide - and even get your palm read to tell your future. A photographers playground.
under construction. this is under extensive construction... we skipped it... and also it is not lit up during night which is supposed to be awesome... really disappointed...

Mmmmmmm. Since February 2015 the temple is closed without possibility to go inside. But very beautiful to see also from outside. Opening hours from 8 a.m till 6 p.m. Very easy to get to the place by using boat from the river station by paying only 3 bat. As this temple located on the other side of the river in the city centre. Don't buy river trip for 800 bat, as the people, even on the street, can offer you and tell you that is the only possibility to get there.

Wat arun. I absolutely love this temple and the views of Bangkok when you make the steep climb. In May on this trip we were unable to climb as it is undergoing extensive renovations. On previous visits I have been able to climb. I am afraid he renovations and the bright white colour they are using is changing the overall look of the temple. However, the size and complexity of the construction and the views will still make this a must see destination in Bangkok.

Covered in Scaffolding - Sept 2015. This was the main thing I wanted to see in Bangkok, but unfortunately it was covered in scaffolding as they are doing repairs. I was disappointed with it due to that. I think it would have met expectations if not for that.

Renovation works in progress. Was disappointed not being able to enjoy this magnificent Buddhist temple by the Chao Prhaya River as an extensive renovation works was going on when I visited mid September 2015.

Beautiful temple. I have been to Thailand many times but failed to visit Wat Arun until now. It's got to be one of the many sights that tourists should visit whilst in Bangkok. For me the highlight was the demons and stories behind them.

Must see if you come to BKK. This is a must see if you come to BKK... there is so much history here... catch the boat to zip across and enjoy some amazing history... wont say much, explore it yourself and enjoy..

Temple is majestic but under repair and out of bounds . This temple has a huge landscaped lawns overlooking the river. It looks grand in architecture with huge pyramidical structure surrounded by colorful minarets.
Since repairs are underway visitors are not allowed to go inside.
watarun temple. this place is so amazing and beautiful and the architecture is wonderful. it's not expensive. and you have to take the ferry to get there.

Afford to miss till the renovation ends. I visited Wat Arun after my visit to Wat Pho which is just a 2mins ride across the river.Due to the renovation I did not enjoy the experience and would recommend fellow travellers not to waste time till renovation is complete.Much was left to the imagination of how the lighted Wat Pho and Grand palace would look from Wat Arun across the river on any other day which would have made the visit complete.

Go if you have some extra time.. It is a beautiful place, but after you have seen Reclining Buddha, this looks a little pale. I went in September 2015 and it was under renovation (for two more months). If you can climb up to the top, you get a nice veiw. The temple lawns are quite and peaceful, sit here and take a break.
Amazing. Amazing craftsmanship, Ayutthaya in the central bangkok region. easily acessible by river boat from sathorn if you come by bts.

Not much to see at the moment. The main reason for my rating is that the temple is currently under renovation, and there is not much to see there. but it was fun to get there by the boat ride for 3 Bahts.
Look from tha Tien pier, you will love this temple. A symbol of Bangkok, look same shape of Eifel tower of France. Always look gorgeous all day and night. Should not miss.

Wat Arun Beautiful at night. I think now Wat Arun Closed.because Renovate new build.but if you go you have to come when night time.so beautiful.Wat Arum close between my home.Siam(Thonburi)Arun Temple have story many year made from Ayutthaya to first King at Ratanakosin to King 9 more 200 year I think.Have two Giant green one name "Totsakan" white one name "Sahadacha"

The one temple I visit EVERY TIME i go to thailand. Apart from the sheer beauty and serenity of this place, Wat Arun is just perfect to get away from the city life for a while and relax. Taking a little river ride and climbing the temple to get an amazing view. It is a little tricky to climb due to the steps and its much longer than one feels when beginning the climb but the view from the top is beautiful.You can start off early too, capturing some images of the temple during sunrise...its called temple of dawn for a reason after all.Best part of this place, not a lot of people around so its a perfect spot to capture some good photos of the sculptures around the temple. A must visit if you are a fan of heritage sites.

Wat Arun- Must visit for the temple Spire. Wat Arun is one of the must visit places. More than the main buddha, the temple spire is the main attraction here. It is around 79 meters and is intricately designed. When i visited, some portions of it were being renovated and hence the many portion of the spire was closed. I combined Wat arun and the bangkok canal tour. The Chao Phraya river is located just beside the temple

Visit at night. This attraction is currently being renovated and according to my tour guide, it has been going on for at least six months. I went here at night (around 7PM) where there were less people (just me and another group).
Thai culture!. The scale of this structure reflects its importance to Thais. Situated on the banks of the Chao Praya river it's magical by day or by night.

Worth the visit a must. Also by night viewed from across the river. If you have the stamina to climb the extremely steep stairs it is well worth it for the view from the top. I made the climb up with no problem but the climb down was something else. At night it is worth seeing it from the other side of the river when it is all lit up. Beautiful.

Beautiful view!!. The view is so stunning, though i was quite scared when i climbed up. It was very steep and the steps were quite narrow. Be careful when you climb up, but the view definitely worth it!!

This place is huge and mythical!. Had so much fun exploring this temple with intricate designs and sophisticated facades. This temple is really huge and you can climb up to the top but careful with the steps as they're Asian size. Haha. People also pray below it and the view is amazing from the top or even when you're having a meal by the river. It's even romantic at night.
Interesting. The place was undergoing renpovation when we visited, and when finished will look fantastic. Nice grounds to wander round. Well worth a visit.
Be aware. It is under renovation now.Make sure it is finished.I can't add more information because it was covered.
Under renovation. since the temple is under renovation at the moment , not much can be seen - nor were there any signage to guide on how and where to go view the sunrise/sunset
Nice monument. Nicely located by the river, is one of the places you should meet, as you can take the boat in the river and end up there. Recomended.
Completely under renovation. One of the most spectacular Wats in Bangkok, but was totally under renovation so not possible to visit, very disappointed

Great temple to view. After spending a month in Thailand, it is very easy to get "templed out", but this one is well worth seeing. The history of this temple makes it very very special. Highly recommend to all to see this. !
Undergoing Maintenance. The temple is under going maintenance so we were unable to climb to the top of Wat Arun . that being said so glad we visited and so this amazing place of worship and culture .

Worth a quick visit. It's definitely worth the visit however you won't need to spend much time here as there isn't too much around it.
There is a little boat that takes you over from the pier where you go to the grand palace to this temple so it's worth tagging it on to that.
avoid taxi, take boat.. Most of the tourist attractions are on the bank of the chao praya river. Just get a boat ride to all these destinations.avoid the taxi.
Amazing porcelain patterns. Unbelievable colors and figures on the most beautiful tempel of Bangkok on the bank of the river. A must to visit.

Stunning place in in the middle of Bangkok.. Stunning place. Just a cross the river (you can cross it for few bahts) there is this magnificent temple. It is a huge contrast to the busy city, as it is very quiet there. building itself is also magnificent. And the facts that it is few hundreds year old adds to it's magnificent. Unfortunately for us (but fortunately for the temple), when we have visited it, it was under the renovation, so quite few parts were covered by scaffolding. But also straight away you could see difference between un-restored and restored parts. It is definitely worth. And also gives you something to come back for. Definitely highly recommended.

Being Renovated but Worthwhile . As always, the temple is awesome and peaceful. If you going for the first time, you will not enjoy as there is a major renovation underway. Suggest that you look to see when renovation is over for an awesome visit.
Go next time. Not worth going to because it is completely covered with scaffling and not much to see. I would wait until the renovation is complete.
Under renovation for a long time. Before going better google if it is still under renovation or you will lose your time by going there nowadays
under repair. It was neat to see but under repairs. if you don't mind scoffolding everywhere visit it. if not view it from the otherside of the river
Nice climbing around. Looks like a collection of many small tiles. Great location by the river. See at dawn to get the full effect.

Under construcrion. We took the ferry across which was really fast but nice. Unfortunately it is under construction, so you don't get a sense of the true beauty of this place. I'm sure once restoration is done it will be a great place to visit.

Under renovation. Maybe this time is not the best to have a glimpse of Wat Arun. Renovation in ongoing so you'll basically see scaffoldings rather than the details of the structure. Went there late in the afternoon so the crowd was gone. Since Wat Arun is located across the river from Wat Pho, you need to take a 3Baht boat ride (one way). I was waiting to see the lights at night, but in vain. Left the pier past 7 and it was still dark. Was actually disappointed.
Nt kinda place I wld recommend... Although the temple is good and definitely shows gr8 artwork.. the way to it through a boat is not a good option.. try to get d minimum time in d boat..

Tiring but worth the visit. The view from the top was nice but we had to take steep steps to reach the top. Not recommended to go with the elderly. It was hot in the afternoon but in the evening, it will not be hot. Recommended to go near to the evening.

PORCELAIN WONDER. One of my favorites in BKK! Although still under construction (there are scaffoldings and the entrance to higher parts of main wats is closed) it is still a wonderful place to visit. The porcelain mesmerising decorations on wats are very unique. It is on the other side of the river so the number of tourist is smaller (in comparison with Wat Pho for instance) and you can really feel the atmosphere or a Thai temple. There are small bells on those buildings making your contemplation better and deeper. A bonus: even thoug under construction, the Wat is beautifully lit at night, a view especially worth observing from the other bank of the river.
Stony temple!. Part of the tour we were in and brought us here! A different construct from the temples in the area!
Nice temple. This is also another nice temple having great view in the night and also need strong person to clampThere is better choices if you don't want to climp
temple of dawn. after short trip on the river u ariived at wat arun, absolutely divine place!!! the view on the top is an amazing experience!!!

Beautiful when not under construction. A wonderful place, lit up at night, great to view over dinner from across the Chao Phraya river. Unfortunately it is being restored right now, so scaffolding is everywhere and you can no longer climb up the taller spires to grab those wonderful views. If not for the reconstruction, a 5 star Wat for sure, but not in its current state.
Extremely Steep But Beautiful. This was a beautiful temple, however it is very steep and hard to climb. This is a great area to take photos. It was scary how steep it was.

Just okies. Its just okay. Its under construction and renovation. So no point wasting time and money on whats still not fully clean and visible. If you have been through many parts of asia, then this is no big interest.
PEaceful and divine!. Queit and serene. This place is absolutely divine! Its peaceful and has an amazing aura and peace! Marvellous views form the top
Must see. The Tempel of dawn is a must see in bangkok. You can see the real beautiness just if you climb up the stairs which are just not easy to climb.

Wonderful temple but slightly disappointed. The reason for my 3* review which could just as easily be a 5*, is due to Wat Arun having scaffolding all over it! A temple as large and beautiful as this should be presented as such, however I do understand that reconstruction and care needs to be taken with a relic such as this.But it was just very disappointing that I couldn't see it in all its glory. I was very humbled to hear / see the monks praying and singing at about 9am.The entrance fee was 100 baht each. Not bad price to see such a lovely temple if it is able to be seen in all its glory. The best way to get to it is by the locals taxi boat and then taking the locals ferry across the river.

Under renovation until next year. We went to see it without knowing it was under renovation. You cant go upstairs and the most you can see is the budda inside. Everything is covered with dust and all the temple has scaffolds. The interesting part is that all the renovation is done free hand and you can see the workers doing it.A security guard told me it will be ready next year.
pure beauty. A wonderful experience, unspoilt and truly worth the long trip. Unmissable in its pure beauty. Go here to view this ancient wonder.

Under construction. Visited the temple with my friends at the morning. This place is literally not available since its under construction. You still need to pay 50 baht to enter the temple and as for me its totally not worth of money since we can't climbed to the top. What a wrong timing for us since it could really be the highlight of this trip.
.... We walked a lot to there and were so disappointed. It was under renovation and almost all the buildings were closed and covered and they still tried to sell us tickets. Can't say much about it
HINDU TEMPLE !. This is a must see place in Bangkok. During night time i.e late evening you take a boat trip it is fantastic. It is a Architectural marvelous.
must visit. very nice attraction and nice adventure to go upstairs which is very high heheheheh i love it so much and it's never to Wat Pho and to khoasan Road
What a Wat!. Quiet Temple worthwhile a visit, not as touristic as others. you can reach by boat taxi. Closes before 5 pm.
Beautiful temple. A must see in Bangkok, very beautiful temple located in the bank of Chaophaya river. Take the shuttle boat and be able to walk to the Wat Pho and the grad palace. Amazing site.

Beautiful architecture, under construction.. Worth a visit, me and a friend went up to the middle as it is being worked on at the top.
Still worth a visit if you take a canal trip from the peir by China town.
Great place to visit . This was one of the nicest temples that I've seen do far.. The compound is quite big and there are many think to see and photograph.
Wat Arun's Marvelous Architecture. I admired its unique and marvelous architecture. I scrutinized every corner and it's a thumbs up. It made me appreciate more of Asia's culture.
Temple with stairs. Personally I dislike small stairs that goes to way up with 45 degree slope. But the temple here is pretty good and one of the must see if you are in Bangkok.

very appealing to look at. just a shame while we were there there was some refurbishing work going on, so we could not climb all them steps to the top and see it all, so just had to make do with seeing the grounds of the place.. we still had to buy the ticket for it which was a shame as we never got the full experience

Nice place to visit. Its under renovation currently, bought some good clothes here. Make them as good souvenirs. when you buy inside the price given is fix , when you buy outside probably u could get bit cheaper

when in bangkok, visit this wat,without fail........ A most mind boggling visit to this wat (temple). be prepared to climb a "few" steps, the view alone will be worth the climb....there are probably thousands of wats in thailand, but this one is special........dont forget your camera...as already stated above, get a very small ferry boat. opposite temple,,,about 10/15 minutes to cross over the Chao Phraya River......think it was about 10/12 baht one way, wont break the bank...

Worth a visit even though it was being restored. We took a quick boat trip across the river to see the temple of Dawn. Although it was closed for renovations it was still worth visiting the grounds and seeing it up close.

Beautiful Temple.. Best to go here towards late afternoon or early morning as the weather is HOT! Accesible via the River taxi only. Great photo ops. Did not go inside as the view from the outside was spectacular enough.
Wat Arun. Wat Arun was repairing and maintenance season when i saw it. Wat Arun is a standart temple. It is located coast of Chao Praya river.
Reparing. I visited in early morning to see sun rising. But wat arun in under repairing. River ran quietly and the landscape was nice.

Deffinitely worth a visit. Unfortunately we were dressed incorrectly on the day we visited so could not enter. Also renovations were taking place when we were in Bangkok so it was surrounded by scaffolding. That said what we could see was amazing and i 'd deffinately go dressed appropriately in order to gain entry if we ever visit Bangkok again. Awe inspiring

An absolute must. The most exciting temple so far in terms of constuction. The intricate mosaic tiles will blow your mind. Just amazing!
Do not go to Bangkok without making the effort to visit.
Must visit. One of the best attractions of Bangkok. The ancient temple has its own charm. Plus, you climb up to the top ans see panorama view of Bangkok and river. So worth visit.

Make sure t isn't being restored before you take the trouble to get there. Is very nice to see. However, in March 15' this Temple was being restored, so we could not walk all the way to the top after crossing the river by fairy.

Spectacular craftmanship. Well worth a visit. Mind you you have to have a good head for heights to climb up the steps but the views are spectacular. I did have a lot of difficulty in the amount of money that was being poured in to renovate. The temples around are very beautifully designed.

Ok. Nothing spectacular. I can.t say I was impressed or that we had a great time, but I will certainly not be keen on returning any time soon. I can define something I did.t like probably it just wasn.t for me.

Climb to the top - The steps are not like normal steps- more like a ladder. Very steep and spaced oddly.. Worth the look to see this historic Bangkok site. Take your time climbing the steps. The steps are not like normal steps- more like a ladder. Very steep and spaced oddly. Be careful and take your time. Be careful it is not too much stress on your heart.- take into account the heat of the sun and time of day. Also if it is crowded be careful climbing. Once on top you will enjoy a beautiful view form both levels. I have been here sever times and am always amazed. Do take the time to see this… allow at least 45 minutes~ you will not be disappointed

Beautiful. i went to the temple with my friends and to reach the temple we need to cross a river. The temple is right next to the river and it looks so beautiful from the distance.Going inside and top of the temple shows another side of thai art beauty and culture altogether. This is one of the place everyone should visit once.

Beautiful old Temple. Entry to temple is protected by Thawetsuwan (Northern Gods) tall statues, like local Thais are saying. Beautiful temple, old and take you back in time. Lots of restoration made in past years to keep this beautiful temple open to public. If you dare you can take a step of stairs or climb up to one high rising tower.

Back in Time. Lots of ongoing restoration work but still plenty to see. One of the Iconic images of Bangkok, especially when viewed from the River. Plenty of steep steps, so wear flat shoes. Not as busy as some of the other temples and not so ornate, but plenty of fine detail. Plenty of catfish in the river by the temple too.
Awesome fun.. Arrived by boat after cruising down the river. Climbed to incredibly steep stairs to get an awesome view of the surroundings. Quick and fun.
Beautiful! . One could not help but marvel at this building. However, it is currently under restoration works. A must visit in the future.
Wat Arun's view from Chaophraya. The best way to see Wat Arun, is onboad the Chaophraya Dinner Cruise. The changing hues of light exhibit the temple in all its glory.

Surely beautiful but under construction. Worth a visit, even now.The trip across the river (3 bath!) is already nice. The complex is impressive and seeing the workers busy as well. What an eye for detail
Amazing stairs. I was thrilled by its steep stairs but made it to the top! The environment around the temple is nice. The architecture of the temple itself is amazing.
Beautiful from Afar in the Evening. Under construction now so there are supports on the structures. Gorgeous still viewing this from across the river, especially in the evening (colorful lights).

Majestic Thai Temple. This is a must visit venue for first-timers, simply because it's a riverside temple that you can gain access to via a boat ride across Choa Paya River. Have fun watching cat fishes let into the river, I was told they are sacred, if you are lucky, you'll be able to spot albino ones too.
Go and see. This is must see in Bangkok. You can see it pretty good on the river but get a chance to go see up close and personal.

Amazing temple... It's a pity it was on renovation when we visited. The temple is in similar style as the temple with the emerald Buddha. It has beautiful mosaics. Just impressive. There is a 100 baht fee if I remember correctly. The highlight of this specific temple is its height, and under normal circumstances you can climb up the stairs and have a great view of Bangkok and the river. Unfortunately, when we visited it (Aug 2015) the temple was on renovation, and therefore we couldn't go up.

Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) review. One of the truly outstanding temples in Bangkok, and well worth a visit (entrance fee only 50 Baht). Unfortunately, the temple is currently (September 2015) encased in scaffolding as it is being refurbished (repainted or cleaned, I'm not sure), so some upper areas are out of bounds. Beware of the gift shop as prices can be exorbitant (I was asked for 200 Baht for 4 postcards, which is outrageous and blatantly taking advantage of foreigners). I offered 100 which was immediately accepted. On the Bangkok side of the river, the same postcards are on sale for 5 Baht each!). Beware!The community to the rear of the temple is also interesting. Quite a contrast from Bangkok - its quiet, relatively traffic-free, and worth exploring the local laid-back community, numerous inexpensive Thai cafes, coffee shops and art shops. The temple can be reached via the ferry from Tha Tien river station for a princely 3 Baht). Also on the Bangkok side is Wat Pho, so both temples can easily be visited on the same day. Plan for a day trip and enjoy...
One of the Thailand symbol. Just take a boat across the Chao Phraya river from the Tha Tien Pier. Wat arun, the temple of dawn. should visit once.
Under construction at time of visit . It was covered in scaffolding so my experience in April 2014 was not great unfortunately. Perhaps you will have a better time.

Amazing Destination!!!. Despite its ongoing renovations; it didnt stop us from seeing the famous Wat Arun.Need to travel by Ferry to get to this amazing tourist destination. Unluckily, there were ongoing works during our time of visit but then we were still fascinated of this attraction.

Enchanting Place .... Enchanting place full of mystical atmosphere! many buildings with Buddhist constructions incredible, beautiful colors and materials, and the temple of Buddha lying wonderful !!! Inside the temple also the traditional Thai massage school to visit and even to try right away with little expense and considerable charm !! one of the top destinations to see in Bakgkok
Maybe next time? Under Reno. Under renovation- so disappointed as this seemed to be the most glam of all the Wats....don't make special trip as most is under serious scaffolding.
Great view. Climb the ancient spires - for exalted feeling and some great snaps and views . Peacefull precinct.Steps are narrow to be carefull
Temple. Currently under restoration. We took the boat across the river after Seeing the Palace and the reclining Buddha. The temple of the dawn is very old and not worth the ride across the water.

Impressive but unfortunately some parts under renovations.. Set opposite to/near the Grand Palace, one can expect it to be grand and it did not let down. Having been to and seen so many wats from Chiang Rai down to here, this one still impressed. Unfortunately, part of it was under renovations.
It's having renovation work done. It's currently under scaffolding as it gets some TLC from the conservation people which doesn't make for any photographing

Amazing!!!!!amazing. It is worth visiting .breath taking!!!
To go up the stairs
was so tiresome out of combined heat and humid of thailand!!! but who doesn't want to see what is there !! Once you have seen the biggest statue made out of gold you will much interested in seeing more.

Proceed with caution. A very nice place to visit. Just be aware that it completely covered in scaffolding at the moment. It's a shame because its a very nice looking temple, but the construction work needs to be done. You can even see the scaffolding at night when the temple is completely lite.

Would have been amazing but scaffolding everywhere.. We knew this was being maintained and expected scaffolding before we went however we were unaware that such a large amount was scaffold despite seeing no evidence of some of these sections being worked on. Really they should work on this section at a time if possible unless there is structural damage as it did make it a little disappointing. fortunately we still got the gist with a bit of imagination. Well worth a visit when completed and its only a short river taxi ride away from most hotels on the river.

unfortunately covered in scaffolding. Would have rated this Wat higher if not for the scaffolding covering most of the structure. Easy to get here along chaopraya river. From central station on the river travel to Ta thien stop (14 baht on local boat,40 baht on tourist boat) then 3 baht across the river to the Wat. Check your change as ticket seller on boat short changed me (accidently of course I am sure). Overall happy I visited. Would be more impressive without the scaffolding.

Intricate carved temple !. We took a boat and it took us to this amazing and very intricately carved temple. From afar, it looked interesting and up close and personal, it became more interesting with its very steep stairs. This temple is carved to perfection and it also offers a great view from the top. It's beautiful and it's definitely worth the visit !

Climb up there for unbeatable view. The pagoda looked unsimilar comparing with others I've seen in Bangkok. You can walk around and also climb to the top part. Be careful, the step is steep, but the view from there is beautiful. You can see the river and other temple or even the grand palace from here.
amazing place. Got some amazing pictures here!!!! The stairs to the top a little dangerous, but once you are on top there is a really great view.

Impressive, even with scaffolding. Wat Arun is extremely impressive and set in beautiful grounds on the river. Although unfortunately the top half was covered in scaffolding for what I guessed to be restoration work, it is still a grand location and well worth a few photos. There is a small ticket charge to enter but not much. Many beautiful Buddha shrines are located within, plus a few shops selling trinkets and refreshments. With other notable locations such as Wat Pho and the Grand Palace nearby, this can easily be combined with a visit to these.

WIP. The Thai government (or somebody) is refurbishing the big Pagoda right now. Not the best moment to visit the temple, but the viewings of the river and the city are good. TIPS: Join a fast boat ride through the Bangkok chanels, really exciting!!!

Beautiful but closed for renovation. The structure is beautiful, the view from the top is great and is on the banks of chao phraya river. But when we went, work on the structure was going on and only restricted access was allowed. Check with your travel agent before you take the pain to go there in late 2015 and early 2016. Its a photographers's delight however.

Interesting place. This temple is related to King Taksin the great who moved our capital from Ayutthaya to Thonburi. If you get a very informative guide it will help you to know better about Thailand. Not only nice spot for tourist but also know our root.

Amazing views intricate decorations. a quick stop over on your water journey, took about 1h to see it all around quite quickly, you can spend more if you want to, soaking up the sun and the views of the city over the water ways.

Must see. The attention to detail is impeccable. Got some amazing pictures here. The stairs to the top are very steep and a little dangerous,but once you are on top there is a really great view. There are other cool temples surrounding the area that are free as well. Highly recommend
Simply Beautiful. Even though the temple was being renovated at the time, it was still beautiful to look at, especially at night when it was all lit up.

One night stand with Bangkok. What do you do when you have 1 day in Bangkok and want to make the most of it, how to come up with an itinerary that makes full use of the time. Not having the luxury of too many days leaves from work, me any friends planned a 5-6 days trip in Thailand, a perfect break! According to our itinerary we had 1 day in Bangkok! And trust me we made the full use of each minute! So here we go.. The Flight:We had booked an early morning flight, well early in the true sense. Kolkata, India to Bangkok flight, departing at 12:05 am. We had a Spicejet flight that cost us really cheap, but this was the worst flight experience in my life. To start with the seats were unusually cramped up. For a 5feet 4inch figure too it was extremely difficult to sit properly due to excessively less leg space. The flight somehow managed to have all the unruly passengers at once. There was a huge group of middle aged men who were the loudest and the most uncouth, lets blame the mid-life crisis for that. Anyways the flight was on time never the less. We arrived at 4:00 Bangkok time. The flight duration was 2 hours roughly. After a smooth Visa on Arrival process that roughly took us about an hour, we were all set to step out into Bangkok. The Taxi ride:The taxi service was pretty smooth, after having booked a pre-paid taxi we were utterly pleased to be directed towards a striking Pink Taxi. What more would be so pleasing for a bunch of girls at 5:00 in the morning, more than a hot pink taxi. That just set in the right mood. The roads were empty, clean and the sky a gloomy blue. The taxi driver was a pretty old man with wrinkles with a very warm smile. Yes he did not understand a word of English. So we have to wake our sleepy brains up to try and explain him where we needed to go. We had a hotel reservation near Khao San road. Unable to understand us and vice-versa we showed him the hotel reservation printout, although he was unable to read it. He did take help from a passerby to read him out the direction. He had lovely Thai music playing, we did not understand the language but it calmed and relaxed. Our first pic in Bangkok was one with the pink taxi taken by the driver!Morning in Khao San road:We arrived at the hotel which was perfectly place on the main road, no alleys or hassles to find out the hotel, since we had reached early at around 7:00 am. And the check in time being 12:00 pm, we had a lot of time to laze around until we got a room. So instead we munched on a few freebies kept in the waiting area, had some fresh coffee and headed out to explore what was around. The morning walk felt lovely, fresh air, empty roads, it was just the best start to a lovely day. We kept walking by closed shops, eateries and banks until we met a guy, whom we asked if there was any market place nearby. Fortunately we were a stones throw away from the famous Khao San road. We fastened our pace. And we knew we had reached Khao San the moment we could see restaurants with lazy tourists like us and colorful eateries, roadside stalls selling local food. The road sides were lined up with tables and chairs, with empty, some full with people busy enjoying there morning breakfast.We walked across the several restaurants admiring the various unique decors, names and themes that each place had. The entire stretch of the road somehow had a unique freshness and warm feeling to it, very welcoming and bright.We decided upon a unique place that caught our eye. It had a very welcoming living room type décor with super comfy sofas and waitresses dressed in pink, by now pink had already seemed to become the color of Bangkok. We ordered continental food but to our surprise it was lipsmackingly delicious. There were a couple of there tourists too who interacted with us, clicked pictures with us as well. Well the one think I loved about eating in Bangkok. You do not need to pay taxes J what a relief to be able to pay for exactly what you eat, also that almost all of these places offered free wifi. On our way we could not stop having a few tall glasses of freshly made fruit juice. By the time we were back in the hotel it was 11:00 am and were allowed an hour early check-in. Chao Phraya River ride:At the hotel we all took a quick one hour nap while the other was in the shower, that way we had our share of power nap while utilizing the time. We were ready in sometime and also set to explore the traditional side of Bangkok, also referred to as Old Bangkok. We asked the hotel receptionist for directions around old Bangkok, and they were really helpful to guide us with all necessary details and a map.And we took off, admiring the many shops on the way and after making our self a quick coffee and ready to eat noodles easily available in the departmental store. Within 10 minutes of walking we reached the Chao Phraya River side. The hotel guys were so helpful in advising us to not take a tuk-tuk (local 3 wheeler transport) which would cost us around 100-150 thai baht, and instead go via the quickest and cheapest transport, the ferry which hardly cost ur around 10 thai baht. Not only that the ferry ride is too beautiful. The river side if full of big fishes which is amusing to watch.Imagine yourself in a ferry and any direction you see there is heritage and tradition and the culture of the Bangkok. The ride itself seems like an attraction. One of the local guys helped us identify the ferry with a reddish orange flag as the one that would take us. Old Bangkok: Old Bangkok is mesmerizing with architecture that is intricate and colourful. Old Bangkok is house to most of the famous attractions like, the Grand Palace, the inspiring beauty of Wat Phra Kaew, the traditional learning centres Wat Pho and Wat Mahathat, the latter widely considered one of Thailand's first universities and a centre for meditation. Sanam Luang, a historic park next to the Grand Palace traditionally used for important Royal or Buddhist ceremonies, and the National Gallery. We deboarded from our ferry at the Grand Palace.Grand Palace is an epitome of wonderful thai architecture. Its intricate detailed work and maintenance is commendable. It still hosts important ceremonies today. After Grand Palace we headed to Wat Pho. Wat Pho or better known as the Temple of the Reclining Buddha is a must visit just to witness the magnitude and massiveness of the place. Please be aware that all these places have strict dressing rules, women are required to not wear short or revealing clothes. Although Wat Pho has the arrangement of a robe incase you are not dressed appropriately for the place. But yet it is advised to either carry a cover up change or clothes like we did as advised to us by the receptionist or be dressed in not revealing clothes. You are also required to take off your shoes before entering. What strikes the most about the place is the massiveness of the reclining Buddha. The figure is 15 metres tall, 46 metres long, so huge it would make you wonder how it even got inside the building. The Buddha's feet are 5 metres long and decorated in mother-of-pearl illustrations of auspicious 'laksanas' (characteristics) of the Buddha. 108 is a significant number, referring to the 108 positive actions and symbols that helped lead Buddha to perfection.* The rest if the area too is big enough and worth taking a walk through. There are many English speaking guides but I felt its better to gain knowledge about the place online than waste 200-400 TB unnecessarily.While these 2 attarctions were on one side of the river, the next place Wat Arun was on the opposite side of the river. We again took the cheapest and quickest way out to the other side of the river by the ferry at 3TB, it opposite to Wat Pho. Make sure to keep Wat Arun at the end of the list since it looks stunning during sun-set when it lights up. When we arrived it was still sunlight. Same dressing rules apply. Wat Arun is not only beautiful but adventurous too. The Temple has a unique structure and architecture. As you start climbing up the stairs of the temple the stairs start becoming steeper and steeper, and the stairs gets narrower. It does get scary at the heighest point, we did muster up the courage to climb up but trust me looking down the stairs was pretty scary. There is a railing to hold onto for sure, I would suggest don’t miss the climb. BY the time we got down, it was just about sunset, as we made ourself comfortable on the lawn on the banks on river Chao Phraya, the temple lit up. It was so inspiring as symbolic to us to be present there to watch it light up against the setting sun. Khao San at night:After we were done soaking in so much tradition and beauty of Thai architecture and culture we knew it was time to enjoy the night-life. Since the ferry services last only till around 7:30 pm we had to make a quick chase to get back to Khao San via ferry, we were lucky to get onto the last ferry. The river ride is even more beautiful at night with the spires of the Thai architecture lit up all around. We go of and headed towards Khao San. Its transforms into a different place at night. Unlike morning it was bustling with energy and tourists of all kinds and places. The energy is infectious that it gets onto you. After an entire evening of walking and climbing we settled down for an obvious foot massage, very easily available at evry 10 minutes distance. Trust me the foot massage acted like an energy bar for me. As it it took away all the exhaustion. We set off to explore almost the entire stretch of Khao San, it has amazing clubs and eatries. We tried the local pad thai noodles and must say it was cooked to perfection. You can also find many vendors selling fired crickets, flies, scorpions, cockroach, but incase you are not a fan of fried insects you can click a picture of them or with them for 5-10 THB. Now that’s business! You can see restaurants, bars, clubs of all sizes, colors and styles, and most of them seem pretty inviting with great continental or local thai cuisine. Indian food is usually expensive there. For shopping I would suggest this is not the best place as its on the more expensive side. Shopping for souviniers is easy though as bargaining is possible. With this we ended our one day in Bangkok, we made the most of it and loved every bit of it.

My favourite Temple in Bangkok. We arrived soon after rainfall and had the whole grounds almost to ourselves, took amazing photographs and we go to appreciated the steep staircases and intricate tile work. also the temple grounds were beautiful and well kept, the view of the old city was spectacular.
Under restoration and covered with scaffolding. This monument is currently under restoration and is covered with scaffolding. It was a work zone and I did not enter.

One of the three ABSOLUTELY must-go-to (in my opinion) temples in Bangkok. There are three temples in Bangkok (among LITERALLY like a hundred of them) that, in my opinion, every tourist should get to, and they are Wat Saket (Golden Mount), Wat Arun & Wat Pho, and the good thing is that Wat Arun and Wat Pho are in a close proximity to one another (just across the Chao Phraya River from each other), so the two can be done one after the other in just one morning or afternoon.This temple is essentially consisting of a tall main prang surrounded on each of the four corners by a shorter prang, and the faces of the prangs if you look closely are mosaics of colorful ceramic or glass pieces, and so it's indeed quite amazing if you think of how much time of manual labor must have required for such an assemblage on these five giant prangs! The main prang can be gone up to about halfway along its vertical length (the last set of stairs needs a bit of caution as the steps get smaller compared to the ones near the bottom). But the going up is totally worth it with spectacular views from up there such as those of the Chao Phraya River, the city and the roofs of the Grand Palace a little upriver.Also, don't overlook the little temple past the market area that you'll see once you get off the cross-river boat (go straight through the market area to get to that temple). It's like an open pavilion with four covered corridors around it, and inside each corridor is a line-up of Buddha statues with some interesting statues (probably Chinese-influenced statues) outside in front of the corridors. The market area outside that little temple has all kinds of food, so there's no need to rush back across the river for food after an arduous climb up the main prang and coming back down because the food is readily available on the temple grounds :).The best way to get here, in my opinion, is by boat on the Chao Phraya River which will also give you a chance to enjoy the views along the river banks and of the river itself with floating vegetations and such. Take an orange-flag boat from Saphan Taksin Pier (the central pier) and get off at the No. 8 Pier (Tien Pier) after about 15 to 20 minutes which costs like 15 baht, then take the cross-river boat for a mere 3 baht which will bring you in just about five minutes to the pier beside the temple on the other side of the river from Pier 8. The temple's admission was quite reasonable at like 50 baht that I paid as a foreigner. One more thing about Pier 8 (either before taking the cross-river boat to the temple or after coming back from it and before going back down river to the Saphan Taksin central pier) is that it is great for small souvenir shopping with postcards available for like 10 or maybe even 5 baht each, so be sure to check out those gift shops at the pier (No. 8) either before or after your visit to the temple although there are also similar shops on the temple grounds on that side of the river as well.
Under Construction. Currently getting renovated. You can not see it in all its glory. It is 50baht to enter and you can not take pictures with all the construction happening.

Climb the steep steep stairs!. Been to temple of dawn twice, the recent one with friends. However, Temple of dawn is currently undergoing some renovation, therefore visitors were not able to climb to the stair to catch the view of the area.

The beautiful ancient temple in Bangkok in the river banks of Chao Phraya!. Beautiful ancient temple in Bangkok, Thailand, in the near of Chao Phraya river. If you could reach the top of the stairs (though its a little bit scary and you must be careful to prevent a misstep) you could see the beauty of Bangkok city and all the river activities. Very recommend to come in the afternoon, and bring your sunglasses!

Amazing experience. You have to work out very hard to climb it, but, it does worth, normally you can visit the temple while you are having your river cruise, just ask the man to stop and wait you for a while, dont miss it.

Beautiful but under restoration. It's still under restoration and will only be ready by next year. Spoke to the staff but she can't give us the exact completion date. Though it's a small place but its really beautiful. Entrance fee is at 50 baht. To get there you will need to take a ferry taxi from Tha Tien pier to the opposite which only cost you 3 baht per way.

Under work but more quiet. The temple is under refurbishing but that means that it will be less busy and I really enjoyed visiting it for this reason. The ceramics are amazing and you get nice views on the river from there

majestic. majestic temple. great place to take photos. This is the temple that is almost everytime used to depict/promote Thailand tourism. easily reachable by boat, and the travelling experience there is itself a memorable journey. majestic
massive restoration work in progress.. nothing to see until the restoration is done. pls check before visiting. the entire structure is covered in scaffolding.

DONT GO THERE!. It is in restoration, there is nothing to see, you need to pay the entrance and also give a deposit to get a scarf and cover yourself. I can't believe they charge to then see nothing at all.

Stunning buildings and gardens. We only had a short amount of time, but 25 mins to wander and admire was ok by me. Was not crowded either. Lots of buildings to admire - only gripe was the scaffolding on the Wat but then it does have to be looked after. The Ordination temple was pretty special too.

Beautiful Architecture. Wat Arun is one of my favorite temples in the heart of Bangkok City...It was under construction but still worth a visit.its our 5th visit to Wat Arun,we just loved it,,,, ..every time we feel its an amazing place to visit.

Another temple.. Not one of the most spectacular temples. There are plenty to go and see around the river part of Bangkok.
Sorry not a great revue.
Amazing place. amazing place, we want to visit here again with our kids next year. after Ramadan in shaallah we will come again.
Under renovation now. Didn't visit this place as its under renovation now. Not sure if it's still open but definitely not suitable for photo taking.
