There is a coffee shop outside which serves good shakes, thai tea etc. If you are visiting place by taxi or tuk-tuk, negotiate with them in advance and tell them not to take you to gems museums on the way (takes a lot of time otherwise).
a must see. Wat Arun had somehow been missed out in my previous visits to Bangkok and i am glad we did it this time. excellent atmosphere and nice Buddha images. worth a visit
A landmark to visit. Mesmerizing view in the evening from Chao Praya River cruise. The temple is a landmark for travellers.

Impressive. Visited when is was being restored however still really impressive. Lots of little stalls about for shopping which was ok but kind of spoiled the area a little (seemed to commercialised). However there was a charge for getting of the pier which just seemed like a money making scam.
Great view. Hard work climbing to the top with people going up and going down all together on a very narrow set of stairs great view from the top

Nothing much to see.. For me personally, there is nothing much to see here. Just a temple with historical architecture.So if you are not a fan of any historical place or building you can skip this attraction.

Nothing special in person. The temple is under construction/being renovated and thus not as attractive as one might expect. Women should wear long sleeves since the "renting" of clothes is more expensive than the entry ticket.

Under construction/restoration . Note that wat Arun is under construction at the moment. But for a cheap entrance fee of 50 baht, it is still worth a visit. If you're visiting the grand palace, there is a 3 baht ferry that is available.

Scaffolding!. We were looking forward to some nighttime photos on our boat cruise but the complete outside is covered with scaffolding right now. Seems to happen on all our holidays (Italy, France).What can you do!We didn't go to the grounds as our time in Bangkok was brief so a visit there may be still very worth while.

Stunning. The temple by day is quite touristy but for good reason. Climb to the top and get gorgeous views of Bangkok. The temple itself is beautiful with very intricate tile work. At night there are several restaurants on the opposite side of the chao praya with beautiful views of the temple lit up. The Nest is a personal favourite as one side has a view of Wat Arun and the other side Wat Pho

River Wat #!. You will need to take a small, cheap river taxi from the east side to the west side of the river where Wat Arun is located. The entry fee is minimal. Quite a nice spot and you can climb to the upper levels of several of the temple structures. Very close to Wat Po and the Grand Palace and Wat Arun is by far the least crowded. There are several other holy sites close by on the west bank. Unique chances for exceptional snaps. You can go up & down the river all day getting off and on as you please on the Tourist Boat … which costs a bit more than the regular river boats, but the flexibility and duration make it the best choice.
under renovate. the place is under renovation currently, so nothing much to view.May be could try again later.but quite near to other nearby attraction, so worth to drop by.

In Restoration. Was looking forward to our visit, but currently under restoration, so surrounded by scaffolding. Still worth doing and two pieces have been completed so you can see examples of the final restoration.Also passed in the evening on a Dinner cruise and looked great all lit up.Be prepared for the cash grab - 30 baht landing fee, 20 baht for shoulder cover, 50 baht entrance fee, Donation boxes everywhere, and the people trying to get you to purchase products, photo opportunities etc

Beautiful cultural heritage. In addition to cross the river with the typical river transportation in Bangkok, you should visit this beautiful cultural heritage. In addition, you will also find a typical souvenir shopping Bangkok at this place.

Even during restoration need to be visited.. It's just a post card kind of place. Beautiful, different, representative. The detailed work on the walls is impressive and the sunrise picture with the river in front it's something that no one should miss. Just don't pay the 50 bath entrance until restorations are completed. You can see basically the same from outside without paying.

Beautiful series of Temples. There are many temples in this area. It's several temple structures intricately designed with various motifs. It has many pathways lined with trees and plants. The temple complex is in Thonburi west bank of the Chao Phraya River, so you need to take a ferry boat from the Sapphan Taksin boat pier. Boat fee is very minimal.

Characteristic Temple with great view of the city. This temple is a MUST SEE. Cross the river with the public taxi boat for 3Bht and there you are. SImply amazing structure.The stairs are sooooo steeep, some people were freaking out! (please see the photo).

Renovation. Not much to see but I climbed up a tower to throw coins and make wishes. Most of the temple buildings were under construction. In the main hall, monks were meditating. If you want to take photos in traditional Thai clothing, you can do so by renting the whole set of attire for 200 baht and take photos backing Wat Arun.

Stunning view. One of my favorite temples in Bangkok is the Wat Arun. The climb to the top might be a little steep and tedious but it's all worth the trip. You'll enjoy the sight of mosaics and stones, and the stunning view from the top of the temple. Make sure you don't have much stuff with you when you go up and down the temple.The temple is littered with interesting statues of gods and demi gods. Best time to go there is during sunset. Simply amazing.

Definitely go. Worth the trip, go early in the morning so it isn't too hot. Women, bring a shawl for your shoulders and wear a long skirt or pants. If you don't have these items, you can also rent there. Good idea to take the boat ride across the river, check out the market. This temple is also gorgeous at sunset, just check what time it closes so you don't miss the chance to climb the steps up and explore. Bring a camera. :)

Richly decorated. Wat Arun or Temple of the Dawn is located on the west bank of the Chao Phraya river. The best way to get to the temple is by boat since the city side entrance is in a narrow street.The temple itself comprises a very central spire surrounded by several smaller spires. There are very steep stairs to climb up the central spire which is worth the effort since the views over the river are spectacular.The riverside entrance to the temple is through an ornate gateway guarded by some chinese statues with some souvenir shops to one side. The temple and the spire are built of several levels each slightly smaller than the previous one giving a pyramidal appearance to the structure. Each level is richly decorated with floral motifs and there are mythical figures holding up the temple. The platform below the spire has rabbeted edges and statues on the four sides. The spire itself is almost vertical and very tall.When I visited, renovation works were in progress in the temple which offered a rare glimpse into the way the temple is decorated. The temple itself is painted a blinding white color. However it is so densely covered in decorative motifs, one things it is multicolored. The motifs itself are not painted but are made of colored porcelain pieces glued to the walls. There must be thousands if not millions of these pieces covering the walls of the temple which is a testament to the effort spent in decorating the temple.It is said the best views of the temple are at sunset from across the river. Unfortunately I could not stay for that. The temple is also lit up at night and looks beautiful from aboard a dinner cruise on the river.A must see if you are visiting Bangkok.

TEMPLE of DAWN (Wat Arun), Bangkok. The Temple is one the most popular icons in Bangkok. Many local travel agents offer packaged tours to the Temple at high price. The temple can be reached easily by oneself at much low cost. There are many stalls selling all types of local items for the tourists; and food stalls around the outside compound of the Temple. The temple is currently under renovation and most parts are closed to visitors. Reckon give this sight a skid, until the renovation work completed.
viewing the way arun. You get the best view in the night when the temple of dawn glows with lights and that too from a boat

Maze runner. Its not that easy to get there from other parts of the city. Scam tuk-tuks are waiting for You. And it is quite confusing using a ferry uptown (the Wat Arun station is hella confusing). But You would get there eventually. Temples are well kept with great views from the top. Avoid visiting during midday hours as it is incredibly hot and climbing countless stairs can make You dizzy. Best visited during dawn or sunrise, as the weather cools down slightly.

Wonderful. I took a group of guest staying at my hotel here for a morning tour. Its very accessible and always beautiful to visit. If you have time, try a night cruise as they past this temple with its lights on for a truly beautiful photo experience.

fine Temple. Wat Arun , it is located in bank of Chaophaya River and it is one of the famous Buddhist Temple in Thailand very attraction place for tourist must go and see if you come to Bangkok ,from there if you cross by ferry boat its have grand palace very interesting !!!!!!!!!!!!
Worth seeing!. Worth seeing at least once, as any way we are visiting Bangkok. Old structure and great maintenance and design.
Ms. Chrystyl. Beautiful place. Lots of high steps without handrails. Difficult to enter for anyone with compromised ambulation,

Unlike other BKK Temples. Climb up for the wonderful view of the (dirty) river and the Royal Palace in the distance. If you must hit the souvenir shops in front, bargain like hell - start at 50% and never cross 67%.
Beautiful and quiet temple. It's pretty better then another famous temples. It's more quiet. You can cross the river paying 3 THB only.

Under maintenance. I expected so much from this place but didnt really see anything spectacular as the place was under construction/maintenance when we came around 1st week of June. It is located close to the grand palace and wat pho so you its good to check it out when youre around the area anyway. Besides from that nothing extra special compare to wat pho and grand palace. you have to pay entrance fee for like 50 baht (If i can remember correctly). The steps up the temple was very limited due to the maintenance. We couldnt climb the peak as it was not allowed at the time. was very disappointed as we wanted to see the view of the river and the city.

Too bad it is under restoration. Fairly easy to get to, just followed the advice of other travelers. Went around 4 o'clock so there were not too many people there. Interesting place but with the majority of the Temple covered, it really was not that spectular. I would like to return once it is complete.

The most beautiful temple in Bangkok. This is a must do when you are in Bangkok together with the river cruise. The sight is breathtaking at sunset so better choose a cruise at sunset or have a drink from the other side of the river. In my opinion is the most beautiful temple of Bankgog as is all about the architecture.

Impressive. It is currently under construction- but even though it was amazing to see. Really beautiful and it is cool to see the restoration efforts- you really see the before and after of all the work they are doing. Can't wait to go back one day when they have finished.

Beautiful. This is a very beautiful Temple. It is usually viewed from the river or the opposite bank. It is unique in architecture. If you visit it the steps to go up are VERY steep. Many people will probably have a problem with this. However, the view from the top is great. It is a very unique and beautiful monument. I loved it.

Interesting Architecture. After paying for the boat ride and only have 10 minutes to view the temple before having to return I can say it was still worth the time. We climbed the temple to get a view of the city and to see just how steep the stairs are.

Beautiful, watch for pushy tourists!. This is one of my favourite places to visit in Bangkok. The temple is so beautiful, the view is great. Just try to avoid peak times or times when there is a Chinese tour group in there. They will literally knock you and your kid off your feet. Very pushy and rude.Take a long tail there and just spend some time looking at the beauty and feel the peace!

A relatively small temple but with lot of Historic significance.. This temple is comparatively small when compared with other temples in Bangkok. The renovation work was in progress and parts of temple was not open. Externally it has beautifully set porcelin marble works which looks beautiful. We went by a boat crossing the river and the boatman cheated us with his price. I presume you can drive across instead.
Breathtaking temple. Astonish view at night and breathtaking during the day. It is along the river, you can reach it with the water taxi.

Check it out at night. We stopped by Wat Arun during a fantastic bike tour (Just Nok) during the evening. It's all lit up and looks pretty amazing at night, and there are almost no other tourists around so it feels much more special. Note that it is currently being renovated so a lot of the temple is covered in scaffolding. One side of it has been completed so you can take some cool pictures, but it will be a lot better once the scaffolds are removed.

Will be good when scaffolding removed. . Impressive, but nearly all covered by scaffolding. June 2015 Cost 50 bhat entry per adult. Taxi from grand palace around 80 bhat. Tuktuk drivers in general seem to be ripping off tourists.
Wat Arun must do. This temple is on the opposite side of river,either take a boat or better to take a night cruise and watch the magnificance of this hugely popular monument.
Better at night. I was disappointed seeing the temple during the day but seeing the temple at night with all the lights on...beautiful instead.
Nicest Temple in Bangkok. A must visit temple. Climb up at top to see the view of the City. Wear pants or you will have to rent a sarong if you are just wearing shorts.

Under construction in June 15 so not much to see. only portion of Wat is open due to heavy construction... not sure I would recommend it until construction ends as very limited what you can see and climb up.

Shame it's covered in scaffolding!. What a shame! Totally covered in scaffolding for renovation. They could earn tourists about this! Because of this we didn't pay to go in just watched from afar and made friends with some of the many many cats mooching around. We spotted some monks too. And a group of school girls interviewed me for a school project haha!

Should check if temple is up for maintenance!. Went on 18/6/15 in what must be their low/off peak season as Wat Arun was up for maintenance. Saw construction bars neatly stacked around the temple, couldn't really see the details of the temple, however not many tourists at all which is always relaxing :) Would have been a good sight at night without maintenance.
The 10baht landmark. THe temple is amazing, and the view is great, but the density of the tourists, the heat and the ladder like stairs makes it tough.

Closed for restoration. Yes, we read ahead of time that this place was closed for restoration, but that didn't stop the ferries from running back and forth charging you money for nothing to see. Nearly all of the spires are covered in scaffolding and there is a wire fence around the entire complex preventing you to get in. Maybe it will be nice again when the restoration is over, but for now, view it from afar and save your baht by not going over.
Views, stairs and boats. awesome views, terrifying stairs. Watch for shifty boat guides trying to overcharge you to get there.

temple. when i visited this place, it is still under construction, however, the temple still look amazing. inside the temple u can try to take picture using thailand traditional clothes and u have to pay for that. inside the complex there is also market , u can buy gift for your friends or relatives and there are also some clean toilets next to the market. don't forget to wear your hat and bring your water.
impressive landmark. We took the ferry over the river in the early evening. Impressive and interesting but very busy. We had been past on the ferry on other days
temple. it is diagonally opposite to grand palace. open till 5 pm. under renovation during march 15. take the boat across the river and enjoy the bangkok scene from top tier of the temple.

Astonishing!. With more than one building and an abundance of statues; this attraction is well worth the visit. If you look closely, you can see the intricate detail and plethora of colors used to create some of the most beautiful works of art. You can takes stairs to the time which gives you a panoramic view and may even catch a glimpse of a wedding party on the grounds. The attention to detail and amount of time it took to create such a wonder is truly amazing. Well worth the stop.
Under Construction. There's not much to see, its under construction. They still light it up at night but there's scaffolding all on the top

the classic must see sight of Bangkok Wat Arun. Unfortunately the temple is under massive restoration and it is not possible to climb the steep steps up. There is a scaffolding around each Prang at the moment. It will probably take at least one more year to finish.
Wat Arun Under Retrofitting. Well. I did not enjoy that much because scaffolding are everywhere the wat arun stupas... But the place is nice and clean over all...

Peaceful Place. We enjoyed our time at this temple. Is was under renovation during our visit and covered with scaffolding but we enjoyed it none the less. There is a very peaceful energy about this place even if you are not familiar with the religious tradition here.Very worthwhile visiting.

Beautiful. Saw this temple as part of a lunch river cruise. Would have loved to have gone inside but ran out of time. Looks like they are doing some construction work to the exterior as this was covered I. Scaffolding which was a shame

Worth the climb for the view!. The most iconic part of Wat Arun is the central prang - which is well worth the climb for the views. Sadly it was raining heavily when I went - so views not so good and the stairs were slippery as well as narrow and steep. Plenty of other things to see around the ordination hall including the yaksha guardian figures.
Construction. Because the Wat Arun is currently under construction, a lot of it was closed off. Great detail in work. Quite mesmerizing, just wish I was able to see it without all the coverings.
Very nice. I like Thailand temple,very beautiful,very tourism come here,very clean and big temple,i will go there again

IN the Mood for Meditation...!. ITs actally quite busy at this location, ideally if you are with family,plan a trip during winters, around December, as in Summer its too sultry during the day and you might feel uncomfortable in the Heat! well if you dont have an option, go for it and keep downing loads of their amazing Chilled and super sweet Coconut Water which is unique to Thailand. The Temple is beautiful and if visited in the evening makes an awesome spot for taking Family Snaps. Enjoy the Thai Experience (Sp ritual Side) lol!

Worth a visit. Wat Arun is currently under renovation, and covered in scaffolding. Not ideal for anyone wanting to grab a photo moment, but still worth a look, even if just to walk around the grounds in front and enjoy watching the water traffic on Chao Phraya.

Great in the afternoon. It's not called Temple of Dawn because it looks better in the morning :D It's called Temple of Dawn because Thais first came to this place in the morning. So it's good to come anytime, take photos, feed the catfish on the canal, that sort of thing. We came in the afternoon, near sunset. Way less tourists, still lots of light. You can take a boat to cross the canal afterwards and watch the sunset and how they lit up the place from across the canal. Beautiful
A Must see while your there. Travelling from Australia it was a delightful eye opener. We don't have places like this and I found it beautiful and helped me understand some of their culture.

Under renovation. I was very excited to see Wat Arun, after taking the BTS tram to Saphan Taksin station and then the boat that takes you there. However, as we approached, the entire base of the temple up to about 1/2 way to the top, is covered by temporary construction beams, making it unappealing and not photo-worthy. Hopefully this renovation is going to be completed sooner rather than later.

Great View from Another side of Bangkok.. Haven't been there at night. It was great place.The people around there are particular clothes you are wearing - wear decent attire.I haven't been way to up because it was too high and the stair steps are way too small. - so please where jeans or pants that's not over size or baggy. Great View though!

Under Renovation. A little disappointing.Saw it from the river last time we were in Bangkok but ran out o time to visit.Mistake.This time, the place was covered in scaffolding due renovation. Nobody's fault, just one o those things.Nevertheless, worth seeing.

Currently under renovation. Not much to see because they have renovating equipments planted on the main attraction. I wish I knew it before because I wish I did not go here. Consider it if you plan to visit this month.
A must while there. Wat Arun is pretty amazing. If you go later in the year remember Thailand is a warm country. Be respectful in your dress in these temples, please.
Nice old temple. Unfortunately the temple is under a major renovation and therefore is not as beautiful as normal. It is covered with scaffolding. It should be on your don't miss stop.

great temple. A must:
Travel by boat though Chaopraya river :)
Try Thai food , Try dinner cruise
Nice photoshoot there, people lovely
dislike about heat :(

Feast for the eyes!. Amazing attraction and a must see if sightseeing in Bangkok. This is such a beautiful structure that's tiles are so beautiful and intricate. All around this temple is awe inspiring.

Impressive even under restoration. This is a very beautiful structure. You can still see through the scaffolding. It would be great to actually go inside. Located on the Chaophraya River and across from the Royal Palace.

Not able to climb due to scaffolding. I have visited Wat Arun before and without the scaffolding. Due to the restoration work you are limited to what you can see and do. It takes a lot away from visiting it but it is good to see the restoration taking place. It looks like it may take a while before it is finished. If you are pushed for time it would probably be better to visit the Grand Palace or Reclining Buddha instead. If you found the review useful I aways appreciate a helpful vote.

Must watch. Very beautiful and must watch site of Bangkok.you have to get ticket for boat or you can hire individual boat as well.you can even climb this temple there is some entry fee for this I think something around 50 baht.you should definitely visit this site.

under construction guys!. I spent the whole day walking around Bangkok during a very hot Bangkok, crossing the river and there was construction at the temple, closing the whole look of the temple T.TSo for you guys who's planning on visiting during this time, please dont waste your time

Lovely temple on the chao prayer. Lovely temple on the water side. Worth a fist. At the side of golden palace.Water can be dirty on the boats but I didn't mind.Rent your own boat for 1 hour £15.Great experience.Good views from temple.

Covered in scaffolding!. This probably would be more impressive when it is not covered in scaffolding! Be aware that the renovations are going on for a while and are covering the main bit of the temple which was a shame. We visited from the water taxi across from the Maharaj pier which cost 3 Baht each. We had already seen the Grand Palace etc which blew our minds so this was a poor second!
Restoration. It would have been nice to be able to view this landmark of Bangkok, but it is currently shrouded in scaffolding!

Beautiful pagoda on river front. This temple is on riverfront a short walk from public boat pier. For 50 baht, you can see the lovely temple and craftsmanship. Much of it was under reconstruction but I was still able to appreciate the beauty.
Please visit in evening. Please visit in the dawn and be on the opposite side of river the view is breath taking. When I visited some restoration work was going so could not have a up close view

Excellent temple, very well maintained. Wow, very good temple and big complex. You can spend good 2-3 hours and do some shopping too. They are doing some refurbishment now, but you easily get amazed by the work and the way it is preserved. Close to river, so easy access to palace by boat. Must see....

inspiring and mysterious. inspiring and mysterious. This is a must see attraction. See it from a boat at dusk, it is simply stunning. Don't forget the camera. Take the ferry across and walk up the steps, not for the faint hearted as the steps are steep and narrow but well worth the effort.

Beautiful, But Under Construction....... I was so anxious to visit this temple since i made my plans to travel 7-months ago. What a surprise to see it under construction, i was so upset. I was looking forward to taking some amazing night pictures and was really disappointed to see all the scaffolding. But it still has some charm to it even though its getting work done. All in all we had a nice time looking around and all the other attractions in the area made it a lot easier to no be upset. Go and enjoy it, it still is an amazing attraction......

Amazing complex of temples. When we visited the main Wat was having some work done to it so had scaffolding around it, somewhat spoiling the experience. Still, there are many other temples in the grounds and we were lucky enough to receive a monk blessing and string bracelet in one of the outer temples.

Temple under renovation yet magnificent. The temple is under renovation yet it is magnificient. The structures adjoining the structure, the pillars and steps all make the place very beautiful. Hope to see it again after completion and at night when it is light or early morning.
LOVED IT. I loved all the temples in Bangkok! All of them were super nice ( but at ssome point, they all look the same haha). Worth it, go see it!

Under renovation. Visiting Bangkok at month of June is challenging. Very hot weather! A short trip on the boat to visit this well-known Wat Arun Temple did not wipe my sweat. So I looked for a bench under a tent to cooling down. What I saw is the pagoda still under renovation.Not much to see here except souvenir stalls and everybody busy bargaining. Surprisingly many sellers can speak Bahasa Indonesia and they can accept Indonesian curreny (Rupiah).For you who want to buy many souvenirs, this place is worth for a bargain. I bought 2 dozen mini metal elephant and there is no price could beat it in other places.

River cruise. Took an all day river ticket for 150bht. Hop on hop off at as many stops/piers. Cross the river to this temple for 3bht! Beautiful to see up close. Under restoration at the minute covered in scaffolding but other surrounding structures are restored and worth a look.

Beautiful - Under renovation. We visited this temple, but unfortunately it was under renovation. We wasted our money buying tickets in two different entries. Please check whether the renovation is done and then step in.The exterior design is very nice.

Interesting to find the ferry, but fun to explore!. This was my favorite temple in Bangkok! It wasn't nearly as tall as I expected it to be, but the stairs are pretty funny. Almost like normal stairs (just steeper) at the base, but the higher you go the steeper and farther apart the stairs are! Loved the ceramic detail all over the temple. The ferry across the water (starting by the Grand Palace and the Reclining Buddha) is easy enough to find. Enter the little wooden buildings with food hawkers and it's in the "back" by the water!
Good view across river. Very detailed work on the temple structure. Some work was going on and hence we could not see much. But and must visit for any traveller in Bangkok.
Lovely at Sunset. One of the must see attractions in the city, the temple is beautiful viewed from across the river especially at sunset.

Still under restoration. They reduced the entrance fee to 50 baht per person (instead of the usual 100?) but you could only walk around and to 1 level up. No view from the level that we could reach. I visited during Vesak day so there were activities going on and added to the atmospher but I personally wouldn't suggest going until the temple is fully restored.

Under Construction. I visited Wat Arun in February. It was beautiful but the only down fall was that it was under construction while we were there which was a little bit of a bummer. Still worth a quick visit though!

Great experience. Wat Arun is very good temple to visit. It is remembered by its size. During recent visit, it is noticed that repair and painting work is going on. I would like to go again to see improved look.

Iconic Temple. The view from the east bank of the river is beautiful, but the temple was covered in scaffolding. We did take the 3 baht ferry over from Wat Pho, which is very convenient if you want to see it. The structure is beautiful but the scaffolding makes it just a meh in my book.

Dr yutthana. Despite see how picture perfect Wan Arun or temple of dawn is currently this temple has been in a major renovation and covered up its beauty with wood ladder structure and you cannot see how beautiful it is at all. This is temporary , but ll take a few weeks . For those who want to make Wat Arun as their destination during day trip should know this even though no movement as closed , but look like you won't get a scenery you expect and want to head to Wat Pho or somewhere else FYI.
Under construction..... I went there in early June 2015 and it was under construction. Therefore it was not a pleasant experience. Don't go there this summer, the construction will not be finished.

iconic temple. Wat Arun has become an iconic temple. When standing on the West Bank with the Grand Palace, you can watch as the sun sets gloriously behind Wat Arun. It is a magnificent sight in the evenings too, called the Temple of Dawn

Looks beautiful from the river. ...yet under refurbish until 2016, the whole area is covered with construction structures, hence not much to see. A cruise trip along the river will give a different view.
Wat Arun. This is the most sophisticated looking temple out of the premiere Bangkok Temple Trio (Wat Pho, Wat Phra Khaew). It will need a short hop across the river to visit.

A worthwhile stop along the river. Wat Arun is definitely a must-see location for visitors to Bangkok and is easily accessible by train and riverboat. If you're lucky, you can still find a taxi driver that will take you there from the center of Bangkok. The 50 baht entry fee was a bit off-putting and surprising, considering it used to be free to enter and walk around the grounds...times are different. Gone are the guys holding pythons for visitors to take pictures with (at least on the day we visited), and a portion of the grounds is full of tourist trinkets. Despite this, the temple itself, although under reconstruction/refurbishment, is still an impressive sight. Visitors can walk around the temple grounds and take photos of many beautiful things. The neighborhoods across the street are worth visiting as well if you want to walk through and get a sense of life in Tonburi.

Similar like other temple. I went today alone, walk from khaosan about 20 minutes and took a boat with 3 Bath cros the river less than 2 minutes coz juat go to other side of them. Temple was under constructions so ididt come in coz we have to pay 50 Bath but actually u can see the temple from outside and its free. Many shops could speak indonesia and really friendly. Recomended!

Fantastic historic place to visit. Wow, this is a superb place to visit. Be warned the stairs are steep and not for those scared of heights. However you can still get a good view with your feet firmly planted on the ground. Certainly worth a visit
Wat Arun. Another must see but it was too hot to stand in the sun and listen to our guide. We looked for some shade and just enjoyed the impressiveness of it all.
The biggest steps in the world. You need to be reasonably fit to climb this Temple....it also helps if you are not afraid of heights. Great views from the top.

Nice temple. I didn't like very much it, very small. If you want to go is just cross the river in the boat (6 bath) in front war pho. Maybe is better so see first .. because after grand palace everything look small hah

A stunning place. I have visit Wat Arun a few time and i just think it is one of the greatest place on earth when in Bangkok one sure should forget to visit it a great time is the Sunset or at Evening Time it sure can make one speechless
Place of worship. One of the best temples in Thailand. Beautiful and peaceful. What you can say more about a temple ....

Excellent. We went to the temple about evening time and we were speechless. Words can not express how beautiful he temple is. (most of the part are under renovation but once it's done I am sure it would be one of the most beautiful temple in Bangkok). We are already planning another trip next winter so we would be back, hope it's ready by then.

great attraction. have been to it many times, love to hike up the very steep stepsand look across the chao phra river, a word of caution they aredoing big time construction on it as of march 2015, so check it out, you can easily see it on a river taxi..
Golden glow after dark. Another Pagoda, but it really looks good, especially at night with the golden glow which is created by all ligthning.

Currently under renovation but still worth a visit. The temple is currently under renovation(May 2015) but it's still worth a visit. To get it, one needs to take a boat ride on the Chao Phraya river. We went with our Thai friends and were lucky to get blessed by the resident abbot.
More wonderful in the sun set. One of the best please in Thailand specially for Buddhist. Evening is the best time to spend. Wonderful rever is also nere by.

Work in progress. The Temple of Dawn is one of the premier temples of Bangkok, situated adjacent to the river and incorporating several lovely structures. At the moment, a major rehabilitation program is in progress, undoubtedly to restore it to it's former glory, but making it difficult to admire at present. Save it for a later trip!

Covered in scaffolding. We visited Wat Arun as part of the boat trip we hired. The structure was covered in scaffolding so disappointing. Every thing there is geared to take money. We even had to pay to get of the boat (landing fee) Then you pay again to get into the structure. It is in need of renovation. The steps up are very steep so the less mobile cannot get up to the top. I for one would not hurry back again.
loved it,, even with the restorations it was peaceful and serene. This is the temple to see, even with the restorations it was peaceful and serene, well worth a visit

will be worth 5 bubbles - after renovation. Was fascinating to see and explore such artwork by monks of the past very steep stairways great view - pity that it was under renovation at the time of my visit, surely next time I will see it in all its splendor.

Amazing temple, good point for photographers. Watarun is the one of most amazing temples in Bangkok. We crossed the river with a ferry , and took some time for photos in front of the temple. Climbing to higher levels was a bit difficult and dangerous.

look great in the middel of the big river..!. wat Arun minning,Dawn Tample.reise your curiosity when sailing on the chaopraia.good to see the statuse from behind..cost only 3 baht to crose the river from station 8- the Tien.the best to come at dawn or evening.need to pay contribution.
Nice Temple.. The stairs were very steep, made for a scary climb! Beautiful views when at the top. Had a monk give me a blessing which was incredible.
Great sight seeing. I took friends there during their visit, gorgeous architercture and views. Just be mindful if you want to walk up the stairs they are very steep and the descent can be tough
Undergoing renovation. Still worth a visit as it is such a beautiful stupa. This can also be a great place to join a canal tour.

A must for visitors in Bangkok . It is a marvelous structure and a piece of beautiful architecture. The boat ride to the temple is fun. Be aware of boat owners trying to cheat you. Just take the water taxi for 80 Bhat each way.
The temple was under construction when we went there.

Good looking when sunset. Need renovation temple and clean all around wat arun
Kurang terjaga kebersihan nya
Tidak perlu dikenai charge ticket karena tempat low maintanance

Renovations going on !!!. The boat ride to Wat Arun was awesome costing just 8baht each from the pier oppsite, we went on 19.05.15 after visiting Grand palace and Emerald temple , we went to pier 9 from there took the water taxi and reached the next pier costing 15baht each. Wat Arun is just opposite.Before reaching the pier 9 , many agents trying to sell separate boat ride for 1 hour priced at 1000baht, so be careful , the water taxi ride itself is more than enough to enjoy the Chao phaya river.Restoration work is going on , it will take some time to finish it , so we can't reach the top of Wat Arun.Must visit for all age groups when you are in Bangkok.Thanks a lot for everything...Loving you so much...Peacefully yours.S M Bega Raaj.Happy travelling...
Gorgeous!. Stunningly beautiful. Intricate craftsmanship in every inch of the Temple of Dawn. So much culture and beautiful scenery around it as well
restauration. unfortunately we couldn't see a lot of wat aurun, as the best part was covered in plastic and caffolding. the boat from wat pho was just 3 THB

Unique and interesting site in Bangkok. After visiting the Marble Temple, you can take a short water taxi ride across to see Wat Arun, it seems to be nicely lit up at night. During the day it's interesting but not as dramatic. It's worth looking at the construction and walking up the very steep steps to the mid levels of the structure. There are some vendors, stores, and snacks for sale outside the temple grounds as well.
icon to understand thailand. love the way to get this place, cross the big river with the boat,the temple so beautiful and easy to get nice and valuable souvenir on the market back of the temple

Temple At Night. We visited the Temple in May 2015 and it was a night tour. It was so different at night. It was like the Temple came to life and the textures were even more beautiful. It was much more cooler and we could take even more beautiful pictures.It is a must with the night tour.

Temple of the Dawn is most beautiful at night!. Wat Arun is able to stand up to the grandeur and glamour of the Grand Palace and Wat Pho despite lacking a coat of shiny gold and decoration of dazzling jewels. Wat Arun is beautifully outfitted with ceramic mosaic pieces. From a distance, its structure is imposing, but, up-close the ceramic mosaic pieces are inviting and familiar. Although it is under renovation until 2016, I didn't think it detracted much from my visit. There's a nice little market surrounding the exterior of the temple. Although Wat Arun is the Temple of the Dawn, it was definitely made to be seen at night. There are plenty of transportation options to get you down the Chao Phraya River, I opted to take the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat from roundtrip from Sapham Taksin. For only 80 Baht roundtrip and an hour roundtrip, it was definitely the way to go
Under Renovation. I go on May 2015 but when i'm in the boat, i saw the temple is under renovation. But i'm pretty sure they have a very good view there on normal condition.

Bad Timing on Visit. When i was visiting this place earlier this month, they were doing this construction so there was nothing fancy to see. Cos we visited The Grand Palace and Wat Pho prior to this visit, so it was really not like what we were expecting to see when arrived to this place.Better luck next time I guess.
One of my temple favorites in Bangkok. Great place to visit and one of the few temples you can climb to the top of. You need a little patience as it gets a little crowded but well worth the time.
A great visit to the sculpture made of porcelain. The temple is fully made of porcelain from China and unique on its own. Beautiful from far at night as it is lighted up.

Stunning architecture. Amazing work of art, sadly it was under construction when i visit so could not go up the steps on close to the pillars but it looked beautiful and i will definitely return to view it in all its glory.
Supposed to be stunning but covered with scaffholdings. Currently in renovation. You cant see much. Felt like a tourist trap. Wat Pho was more peaceful and inspiring

Beautiful, especially at night with the lights shining on it. During this trip the temple was under repair. I have gone to this temple at least three times during previous trips to Bangkok and it is worth an hour or so of your time. Each time I climb the stairs to the top to see the surrounding area. The steps are steep but worth the climb if you are able. The view from the river at night is fabulous.
April 2015 - under constructions. It is very nice to cross the river to get to wat arun, which is in a very nice green gardens, but was very disappointed that it is under constructions....

under renovation. disappointed totally as the place is under renovation . we paid for the ticket and entered then we reached a construction site , wat Arun I am disappointed as they took money for closed temple and wasted my time by visiting this place . Go to this place when its renovation works finish .
! Awesome !. The temple is very nice .. Especially the steep staircase . My wife and me climb to to the top . Nice view if u going to take pictures
great and informative. plenty of temples and ruins a must even if you are not into these things getting dresssed in the downs were a laugh

always worth a visit. Try to view Wat Arun at sunrise and at sunset from across the river- the colors are fantastic. It's quite a climb to the top, but well worth it once you get there. If you go out the back of the compound you will come upon a nice little iced drinks stand - try their mango smoothie.
Under Construction .... It was under construction when we visited ...Anyways, the river taxi was a nice experience ... best to go in the afternoon, after 4pm, to avoid hot sun ...
Beautiful. It was a short trip to the temple, but worth the visit. We were able to climb all the way to the top. Amazing views. We loved it!

Under renovation (May 2015). We visited as part of our boat tour only to find it covered in scaffolding. Pity as it very impressive right on the river. If you intend to climb, the steps ate very high and steep.

Construction. Temple of the Dawn would have been much more impressive on this visit had it not been under so much scaffolding. The construction appears to have been going on for some time. Restrooms ask for a 5 baht "donation" and toilet paper is found outside by the donation box.

This place is under repair.. When our family visited, this place is under repair. So I did not take ticket. I just watch outside of it. I recommend you not to buy ticket. Instead of it, I suggest enjoy scenery. and if i can have a chance to visit this place after repair is finished again. I will buy ticket.
Enjoy your trip~

Impressive structure even though mostly covered up for renovation. Wat Arun is a beautiful landmark structure that is visible from far away along the Chao Phraya River, especially at night when it is lit in vivid golden hues. (Indeed, the best way to get to it is by boat.) When the temple and grounds are open during the day, the view back towards the east bank from the from the riverside landing is impressive as is the view from the boat back and forth as it looms larger or recedes into the scene depending on which direction you're headed. My friends who had climbed on up to the top level on their previous visits to the wat before renovation construction blocked about 3/4 of the facade including the steep and narrow stairs past the first level, say that the view from the higher vantage is even more exciting.The wat is not only an imposing and impressive architectural attraction, but is also an active center of worship, and appropriate clothing is required for all who would enter. Tip -- even though it gets rather hot in Bangkok during the day, wearing long pants and sleeved shirts will make it easier to come and go from various attractions including the Grand Palace as well as the wats in the area without having to rent "cover up" clothes at each location.Well worth the visit and worth allowing some time to look around even though much of it is covered up, rather than just taking a selfie and hopping on the next boat back.

Looked amazing but we couldn't see hardly any of it.. I am sure this attraction would have gotten a five from us if it was opened properly. We were just unlucky that it was being restored. It is understandable as when you see the detailed structure you can imagine the care it would need! We paid to get in even though we knew most of it was closed off because it was a once in a life time visit and we didn't want to miss a thing.

under renovation. As the name implies it is best seen at dawn when cruising down the chao phraya river.you can even climb up the stupas.but this time around we saw that there's some renovation work going on
Very beautiful!. The view from the river to the temple and vice versus are precious, especially in the dawn. I was struggled to go down because of the height :D

Good to see. Weekend, We go early and have the time to see it with out the masses we where the first at 8.15 a days later in thailand. It s interesting to read about it before you go there. We took a guide he was good hard to understand but he took his time and made sure we did see the whole place. We need more time to see anything
Temple by the River. The temple is on the banks of river Chao Phraya. Do take the boat ride to the experience the local travelling and visit the temples on the other end of the river.

Great experience!. Fast boat trip across the river for 3 bath only! Ladies make sure you wear slacks or long dresses to enter the temple. It's nice view from the top of Wat Arun. Stairs to the top looks like inclined ladder which makes quite a stunt to get on the top. Well you have been on the top now so you can get down and take a boat back because there is nothing else to see.
Such detail.... although it was under construction when we were there it is a beautiful temple with such delicate details really pretty... you don't need a lot of time for this temple... enjoy!!! ;-)

It's steeper than it looks. Another great temple experience. Unfortunately, the temple is being restored so there was a lot of scaffolding. Fortunately, it's a good example of the benefit of restoration; you can see side by side examples of the work that is being done. I was so impressed by the craftsmanship.

Under renovation. Despite being refurbished it is still a very worthwhile visit.
Best seen earlier or later in the day otherwise it is busy / crowded.

The magnificent on the river side. If you have a chance to visit Thailand, you must not miss the opportunity to visit Wat Arun also known as Wat Jang. In the eary dynasty, The reason why they call Wat Jang because once upon a time when King Taksin relocated the main capital from Ayuthaya to Thonburi, by the time he got to Wat Arun is in the eary morning, of cause the word 'Jang' in English means dawn. They changed the name from Wat Jang to Wat Arun in the later years. You will be amaze with the original Thai' architecture on the golden stupa specialy at night time. The light is so great and made the stupa stand out from bangkok sky line, you can see it from the far distance. While you are at it, you can enjoy a boat ride on the Chaopraya River, many things to see along the river side. You will love it for sure.
Lovely. What a beautiful temple. I really enjoyed this one for all his beauty. Situated nicely. with all the beauty in its

My personal favourite tourist attraction in Bangkok. At the time of my visit, and writing this review, the main Pagoda is encased in scaffolding. However it is still easy to appreciate the beauty and workmanship which went into creating this spectacle. The setting alongside the Chao Phraya River is gorgeous and the tranquil gardens offer the weary traveller an oasis. I visited twice, and highly recommend sitting in the gardens sipping iced tea or coffe freshly made at the garden coffee shop. there is a small market selling a good selection of gifts ao reasonable quality and value. This market being less hustle and a little cooler than many other Bangkok Markets, appealed to me.

impressive and a must place to visit on the Chao phraya. must to visit, easy to access by river boat, combined with a visit to the grand place. Wat Arun is a beautiful place, of historical importance. in a relaxing environment, be there a dawn
The beauty that captures your heart. Still on under renovations yet still you can se the beauty and uniqueness designs on each single details.

Must visit when in Bangkok. I liked the Thailand culture,people,beaches in Phuket,it's economic development,it is almost comparable to Europian countries. Being strict vegetarian we did not like food there. Over all we enjoyed our tour to Thailand

Heavy renovations but worthwhile a visit. Was there in March and was a little disappointed to find it was under heavy renovations. Looked like it will be under renovation for quite a while as well but once complete will be beautiful and well worth it. You have to get to the pier to go across by boat. It is literally on the opposite side. You can see straightaway it's under renovation so don't expect beautiful photos from afar. If memory serves me well it was 3 baht for a return trip. Once there it's 50 baht. Was a nice visit but the not the most impressive place I visited in Bangkok. I did however love the opportunity to dress up in traditional thai clothes. They'll dress you up and take photos for 100 baht. Overall, go if you have time but I wouldn't recommend it if you have only 1-3 days in Bangkok.

Under construction right now. still nice to visit but they are renovating the temple. when we went the top part was covered with scaffolding. =( But you can still go around it and walk along the bottom area to see it.

Temples to see in the evening is fantastic.. Temple of Dawn(Wat Arun) is the most famous tourist destinations in Bangkok.Arun is the meaning of the Akatsuki. Also become a stage of Yukio Mishima novel "Temple of Dawn", figure Nestled along the river of the Chao Phraya River have also been counted in the landscape representing Bangkok. The Wat Arun is pictured in current 10 baht coins. Generally, it is also known by the name of Wat Arun. And it is also referred to as the Temple of Dawn is in English, but this is believed to have been the origin of the Temple of Dawn of Yukio Mishima.Yukio Mishima is the famous literary person of Japan. However, he would have committed suicide after the political activities organization.Light up the temple is visible, you are accustomed to the romantic mood.To rise to the pagoda, you need a 50 baht entrance fee.

Bad place to visit until it finished its renovation. It really not worth your time because you spend 50 baht on the tickets and you can't go inside the temple at all. Only around the temple ground. Wasted 5 minutes of my life coming to this place. It will probably be a nice place to visit if it is not under renovation.

Amazing Temple.. Really a temple that you should not miss. If you want to avoid the heat go at 4pm...you can see an amazing architecture and if you decide to climb to the top you can see a magnificent view of Bangkok

A Place to see !. This is a place to visit !, it involves a short river crossing first, from one bank of the river to the other, the cost is a couple of pennies, the sheer size and history if great.Always a busy place, many many people want to see, what you want to see, so be patient. If you want to go up to the two levels of Wat Arun, PLEASE wear trainers or flat sole shoes,certainly NO HEELS, because the steps are S T E E P !, it's like climbing the wall of your house, and feels even steeper coming down, so take care. Once on the 2nd level, you get good views of the chaophrya river.
Great views of the city. It was so rare to be allowed to climb such a beautiful building. Located by the river it commands great views of the city and is easy to get to by river bus.

A Bangkok Must. The temple is beautiful. Some of the rooms have amazing collections of old Buddha statues. I would suggest to take a private riverboat tour. You can start at the Oriental Hotel Boat dock - go through the Klongs of old Bangkok and then to Wat Arun.

Love this temple. This temple is my favourite in bangkok, head over there early to avoid crowds, it's very peaceful and you can climb to the top for stunning views of the bangkok river. Highly recommend visiting

Do not miss it!. The view of the area from the top is nice, and climbing it is also an adventure. A calm and quiet place near the river makes it the perfect place to relax after the sightseeing day. Before the sunset cross the river to the other side to enjoy the view from a bar or a restaurant.

Under renovation. It was unfortunately a rainy day but this didn't bother us too much- and of course is nobody's fault. However, had we known the temple was under renovation (for 12months) we would have preferred seeing another temple (our guide did not warn us of give us the opportunity to see a different temple), as there was not a great deal to actually see under all the scaffolding- it would have been a marvellous experience to walk up the crazy steep stairs towards heaven, but alas we never got this chance. You do get some idea about what the temple looks like, it's quite an artwork really, and would be amazing to see at dawn.

Beautiful under construction . From Sala Daeng Station, I took the BTS Skytrain to Saphan Taksin station. Took the boat at 15 baht going to Tha Thien. Along the cruise, you can see some wats and buildings along the Chao Phraya. When you reached the port, a boat will costs you for 3 baht to cross going to Wat Arun. The temple is still under construction, might be finished by November, but still you can see the intricate details the temple had and it's stupas. It's quite hot with the scorching heat of the sun. There are a few shades and a coffee shop. You can dress up and take a photo wearing their traditional dress. But the temple was perfectly lit up during the sunset.

Amazing!. Make sure you visit it early in the morning to avoid crowds and weather. Weather was ridiculous, but breeze in the morning made it bearable. The temple is going through a restoration face, so a lot of it is now closed to the public.
Works in Progress. Unfortunately the temple was covered by scaffolding and we couldn't climb to the top either. Oh well it was an excuse to cross the river on boat :)

Disappointing. It was disappointing bec the temple is under repair and you get to see nothing. However when you buy the ticket they don't tell you that. We circled the whole complex to realise that. What was to be seen was the small Buddha outside for which there is no ticket.

Too Hotttt!. I went there at 2 o'clock, the sun was so brigth. It should be nice for selfie n photo shooting, but since there was really HOT and NO WIND, so me and my family were sewating like we were in the sauna room. I looked around, and realized almost everybody was in the same sauna like situation.We imediately bought hats and a cold coconut water there to survive. Haha...I hope the government would plant more trees there. We really need it.Besides, unfotunately the main temple were under maintenance. So it was disappointing. For real.But the boat and river experience was quite unique, and we were enjoying the view.

Mesmerizing Wat Arun. Wat Arun, the Temple of Dawn was undergoing construction when we visited, so only managed to look around the complex and was not able to go up to the 1st floor of the temple. Will definitely return to visit when the construction works are completed to see how the place looks during dawn and dusk, especially fully-lighted up.

Not a good time to visit. This is obviously a lovely temple but we couldn't see much under the scaffolding and still had to pay to enter. We could only walk around the bottom. A bit disappointed but understandably the work has to be done!
Different Architecture. Wat arun Temple is a nice place to go, if you are looking to see different architectures. It ha the visibility of rich culture.
Must see from the boat. What a beautiful Architectural work? Love to see it again and again. bargain for boat riding, they will come down to 1000 Bhatt for whole boatReally amazing.

Must visit. It is one of the most stunning temples in Bangkok, not only because of its riverside location, but also because of the design, it is very different from other temples you can visit in Bangkok.
A must visit!. When in Bangkok, its a must visit especially in morning hours if visiting in summer months. Culturally very significant.
Must go!!!. When u come to Bangkok, Wat Arun is a Must Go place!! it is so beautiful!! You can climb up to see pretty views but please watch ur steps because the staircase is very narrow..
Amazing sight. When we visited, Wat Arun was undergoing works and had scaffolding around it. We didn't go inside but had a look around the outside which is very impressive.
under construction. It was under construction so not much to see at this time. It still had some nice areas to take photos. This location was on ly 50 bhots.
Not to visit at this moment. Not so nice to visit at this moment due to renovation of the temple and not possible to visit first floor

Beautiful temple. Be prepared for the climb. Another amazing temple. So beautiful. We visited the place before they began restoration and put up all the scaffolding. Its one hell of a climb to go top, the steps are very steep. Being acrophobic I had some trouble getting on top and even worse coming down. But it was worth the trek. Another must vist place in Bangkok.There are plans to club the temple visit with a boat ride which is a good idea. You can take pictures in the local ceremonial costumes for a decent rate. make sure you bargain as with every place in Thailand.

passed on the boat. maybe we should've gone at Dawn/dusk?Sooooo many temples but even more shopping to be done... Bangkok is just fab, didn't want to bore the kids too much though with too many temples!

Beautiful Temple. My friend and I visited the temple earlier this week and quite enjoyed it. The only downside is that part of it is covered in scaffolding. The parts that have already been restored looked fabulous. The temple is a gem and the slightly out of the way location meant that it was a little quieter. My friend and I were able to walk there from our hotel near the Democracy Monument. Be forewarned that if you are walking there from across the river, it's best to do it on an overcast day (if you can), and if you are going to take a short cut rather than following the river, be careful because it will take you through some poor local neighbourhoods. Just be careful and stow away your cameras and gadgets.On the river side of the temple, there is a small area with street food and vendors. The selection is very representative of what you will find in most other tourist markets.

Gorgeous Temple but under construction!. We took a long boat ride that included a tour around old city and a 30 min stop at the temple. It's a gorgeous temple, however, it was under construction so most of it was covered. Some wasn't and those buildings were absolutely stunning. Make sure that ladies are wearing the appropriate outfit otherwise they need to borrow a wrap-around for 20 bath.
Grand Architecture. Ancient Temple with huge heritage & architectural design. Temple is under restoration when I visited. Surrounding buildings are worth spending half a day roaming around.
The unique Temple.. It is very beautiful unique architecture which set perfectly by the riverside, The detials of the temple are breath taking, you ,ust see.
Under construction. Visited in early April 2015, couldn't see much. The temple was under sever construction. I'm sure it's going to be pretty but there's not much to see now.

NOT worth it right now..construction ruins it. With the construction you cannot walk up the stairs to get the beautiful view. There is no point in paying to go in right now. Even from across the river it doesn't look good at night because of the construction.

One of the famous temple in Bangkok. This very old temple is interesting. It's so colorful and well-maintained. A nice one to visit when you are in Bangkok. At the top, you can see the Chao Phraya River.

Beautiful temple on the river. We visited this temple this time and also back in 2012. Unfortunately this time they are renovating the main body of the temple so you can't climb to the top, but it is still a great place to visit.

Overlook Chao Phraya river from the top of the temple. Very nice temple complex,so many colorful details.From the top of the temple can see the Chao Phraya river.The stairs are steep,up one side and down the other side.We took the boat from Saphan Taksin pier and got off at pier number 8.From there we took the ferry to the other side for 3 THB / person.The temple is open till 5:30 pm.I also was close to the temple in march 2015 and I've seen they renovate the place.
Beautiful antique temple decorate by bowl and dish. I like this temple the last time I went because I made day trip tour for my guest.it's beside chaopraya river just cross boat from tha-tien

Interesting archietecture. Very old temples and very interesting to see structures so old still standing, even though they have had to render in the bricks within the last 5-10 years to make them still stand

Beutiful but lots of renovations going on right now.. You'll see much more at Wat Po and Wat Phra Kaew. Heavy scaffolding detracts from the temple but still very important and worth seeing. Visit as part of a 2 hour boat trip along the river and canals via the floating market.
renovation at all of the places. Wat arun is a good place to visit. But this time visit is a disappoint, just waste my time, renovation all of the places, no exception.

Would have been more impressive without the scaffolding!. The temple is very impressive to look at with beautiful intricate designs covering the whole building but was spoiled on our visit as it was masked with scaffolding and it was difficult to get to as we had to cross the river.Even though there was maintenance happening on our visit i would still recommend to visit this temple as it is very beautiful and unique. The view from the top is worth the climb.

It was under renovation, but still thumbs up.... Well being the number no 1 attraction in Bangkok, I won't say more about it, you have to come here.... and to tell you the truth.. even if you are having a boat ride in Chao phraya river, the temple would steal your attention... and you wouldn't keep your eyes off it... the best time to go there is either early morning or late afternoon....
This was part of an inclusive tour of the Grand Palace and the Temples. Same comments as for the reclining buddha. Very busy, noisy and packed out. Still if you are in Bangkok you have to see it.

Not imoressed while in construction.. It's very complicated to understand how to get there. Some tour companies send you in a canoe that is very difficult to board. They take you through local canals which are very messy and dirty. It's nice to see the other areas on Bangkok that are very poor but it gets tiring. There is s nice boat company that I saw in one of the piers but without knowing what pier, it's difficult to ask taxis where to take you. The government should create a better way and more standardize to get to this temple. The temple being under construction during 2015 makes the visit worthless. No good pictures. It's A waste of time.
An amazing temple. An amazing temple dedicated to Aruna, the Hindu goddess. The climb to the top of the tower and the breathtaking view of the city and the Chao Praya river are not to be missed.

More beautiful from a distance at night. I took a boat trip dinner and it was my plan to just watch this beautiful temple from boat. I had an experience to see Bangkok city from a tower so nothing to see from the top of this temple rather it was more attractive for me to see the gorgeous lightings of this temple and yes its truly amazing at night.

Beautiful decoration of pagpda. I love the little detail that they put on the pagoda as decoration: little colourful mosaic, old chinese plates and sculptures. However, the way up to the padoda quite steep. You must hold the handrail tight because the stair quite steep and its has very small steps. (It might not suitable for seniors citizens)
Under renovation. The buildings under renovation and you will have to buy a ticket for 50 Bhat to see this. Unless it would have been a good attraction. Not good for pictures.

Renovation in progress . Pictures of the temple look fantastic, but keep your expectations low as renovation is in progress!! We went towards evening to view sunset- scaffolding over the marvellous structures were a bit disappointing. Walked around the temple in the evening breeze from Chao phraya river.Only best thing about the evening was the shop outside which rents out Traditional Thai costumes- we got dressed up totally & clicked dozens of pics!! Do check the out to make a memorable Wat Arun memory.Must definitely visit once renovation is over..

A big dissapointment. And this is because the wat was in total rennovation and no one, and no where is this fact announced. So, we took a boat, walked, couldn't wait to go up on its steps and... when reached there... you could see only some construction scaffolding. And before this, of course, you pay the ticket. I'm not sure what for...
good. Renovation is going on at present.So scaffolding through out the structure.Looks great at night. Cross ferry is convenient.

Officious signage and a temple under wraps. Our tour guide decided it was worth the two hour detour to visit this temple, but really there was nothing to see here as the temples are all cloaked up and under renovation.The only thing of interest really was to see how every little piece of tile was photographed and cataloged and stored in crates, but this wasn't what we paid bt50 to come and see.We only stayed a few minutes but the heat was so intense that my partner got sun stroke. I also found the signage a touch offensive, making up rules about where it's ok to put your buddha etc., and what you should be wearing. Don't waste your time coming here, there are many nicer temples in town.

Renovations make it not ideal. The temple was nice but the current renovations definitely take away the experience of this place. We were a bit disappointed as we did not know it was undergoing renovations currently. I would suggest getting a glimpse of it from the river rather.

Being Restored. This places is quite stunning to look at from afar, and even when you get up close it is hard not to appreciate the architecture. Unfortunately for us, a good part of the temple was being restored and therefore there was not much to see. We spent maybe 15 minutes at the temple itself. Nonetheless, it is something that one should see as it is different enough from many other temples that one finds in Thailand.

Under construction. the temple was doing some kind of renovation. I was so excited wanting to go up the steep steps but was unable to do so. the management should not charge the tourist if we are not allowed to go up the temple. otherwise it is a good and peaceful place.

climb up!! Its worth it!!. Don't forget to check Wat Arun when you visit Golden Palace and Wat Pho. It located across the river, only cost 3 THB for boat crossing. The temple are beautiful as well as the scenery. Take a climb to the highest level of Wat Arun and you can see beautiful river and city. For shoppers, they have several stalls in Wat Arun complex that offers you high quality shirts with reasonable price as well as other souvenirs. I find the shirt quality here in Wat Arun much better than in MBK for the same price.For Indonesian, run out of money? or simply want to buy more? relax...they accept Rupiahs as the payment. Me and my friends went crazy here lol

Beautiful view. The ride to the temple on the boat is much more exciting than the temple. Since the temple is under renovation its not worth paying 50 baht ticket for entry. The temple next to it is indeed beautiful and a must visit.

Under Renovation. This beautiful temple is currently under renovation and covered with scaffolding so that was a little disappointing. However, you can see how stunning it will look when completed and the temple is along the river with a lovely park. It costs only 3 bhat to cross on the ferry from Thien Pier. Just walking past the vendors at the pier is an experience.
Amazing. Wow wow wow!! Must visit and try to go up to the highest point of building. It's nice. Recommended to everyone. Can be access via boat from other site of river.

Impressive temple. Wat Arun is currently undergoing renovation and the main tower is surrounded by scaffolding. Despite this it is worth a visit. Parts have already been renovated and this allows the visitor to appreciate the scale of this task. The flood lit temple should also be seen after dark - either from a river cruise or one of the restaurants across the river.

Just Beautiful!. Saw Wat Arun many times during our visit to Bangkok while cruising up and down the river. Looks beautiful during the day while going past but looks spectacular at night time! Didn't actually find the time to go across and see it in person however, which was a shame. Not sure if I could have hiked up to the top but looks like a fun challenge! Next time It will be at the top of my list of things to go see!

iconic sight. despite being under renovation it was still well worth a visit to this iconic temple with its five towers mimicing Mount Meru. It's in Thonburi on the west side of the river. The carving details are fabulous and the view across the river to the city from the very very steep climb to the top is worth it. Don't go up if you suffer from dizziness.

Really Impressive but under renovations. The short boat ride and the overall temple visit was a nice experience. However, there were scaffolding all over the place, and major renovations are undergoing so it is not the ideal time for a visit.
A sure visit in the late evening. It's a beautiful architectural building with a lot of visitors..don't miss out visiting it in the late evening when it is all lit up..looks totally mesmerizing

Under renovations . Bit gutted really on this visit as some work was getting done to it so we didn't get to see the temple in its full glory! Have seen it previous visits and was great. Not sure how long the work is going on for ?

Сharming temple in Bangkok, which is located on the banks of Chao Phraya River. Wat Arun or the Temple of the Dawn. From the height of the main 79-meter tower Wat Arun has a beautiful view of the waterfront and the Chao Phraya Bangkok.As you climb the ladder to the top of the temple, and will be able to see the beautiful picture of the Chao Phraya river, the boat, the roof of the temples. Very nice place. You can listen to the monks chanting during certain hours.
Was expecting more!. Less to see due to the construction which is going on. Evenings are the best to see the lights around. One needs to take a boat to the other side to get a complete view.
very impresssive. Just short ride by boat on Chao Phraya River to Temple of Dawn. Been there few times on each visit to Bangkok. Climbing to the top is fun than you can have amazing views.
Amazing view. Stunning view at night! It is one of the icons and must-visit-place in Bangkok, but better to bring hat or umbrella when visiting wat arun at day time.

under major renovations. went here with a group tour last april, 2015....didn't see much since it has alot of scaffoldings around the templesi think that the place has great heritage since the materials used were ancient and great bangkok culturewill be back to see the outcome of the renovations
Amazing. All the temples were breathtaking , the architecture was amazing , your camera won't stop clicking but the photos won't do them justice

Under renovation. You need to take a boat across to the other side to get to Wat Arun. Not much to see as it was under renovation. Wished to see how beautiful it really is. Some souvenir shops around the compound.

nice but under construction. I went in April 2015 its under construction so you cant fully see it as its meant to be seen. The area around the temple is nice with places to have a coffee or buy a gift.

Looks impressive from afar, less so on closer view. Wat Arun is one of the most prominent buildings in Bangkok, clearly visible from afar on the Chao Phraya River, looking very impressive. Visiting the place however is somewhat of a disappointment, particularly as it was under renovation on the day I visited and it was not possible to explore it much. Architecturally it wasn't that interesting or impressive on closer view.I'd say enjoy the view of the building from afar. If you really want to visit it, travel on the ferry (a very cheap ride) from across the river after visiting Wat Pho or the Grand Palace ground. The ferry ride itself is probably more interesting.
Under renovation. It is open, but only half of the temple, and the construction protections do not allow you to enjoy his architecture,

Under renovation. This is across the river and one can take a ferry for 3bhat per person to the pier. Unfortunately it was under repair when we visited so could not see the real beauty of it. Also, the floors to go up were blocked so did not get a view of the city. Their is an entry fee of 50bhat

Majestic. We had an amazing time taking photos of the temple. It had spectacular details being restored at the moment. Entrance fee was 50THB. We stayed for about 1 hour. It would also be amazing to visit at night. Read more on my blog: http://katmeifucan.blogspot.com/2015/03/a-short-visit-to-bangkok.html

Under renovation in 2015. Wat Arun will be terrific when the current renovation is complete. Currently there are many scaffolds up that detract from the view. That said, it is very interesting to see the before and after work and the artisans who are doing the renovation. The ride across the river costs a few cents and is pretty interesting on it's own.

excellent.. Wat Arun is a temple that sits proudly on the banks of the Chao Phraya River. the Temple of Dawn, is named after Aruna, the Indian God of Dawn. The Khmer-style or tower is 104 metres tall and decorated with multicoloured Chinese porcelain that was used as ballast by boats coming from China. IWat Arun is open from 8.30am to 5pm

Name is Temple of Dawn but i enjoy seeing the temple at dusk. This temple is one of the royal temples in Bangkok that has Khmer shape stupa influence! Located right across the river from Wat Pho(Temple of reclining Buddha, only a 5 mins boat ride away)the great stupa is standing tall, almost a landmark of Chaopraya River if you are cruising through! You can climb the stupa to enjoy an excellent view up top over looking the river and the horizons! I like going around the place to watch sunsets! Perhaps the best option is once you visit the temple in the late afternoon, plan to hop back and have dinner on the other side of the river, magnificent sunset, watching the sun goes down through that ancient ruins!

Under renovation but another temple nearby. I prefer taking local boat to n8 Tha Thien dock (15 baht) near Wat Pho then pay 3 baht for ferry across to this temple. Because of renovations, not crowded but nearby temple is beautiful with free entry and more Chinese style statues. Plus you can take photos from near area across river! Because of closed areas you may not want to pay 50 baht fee to enter as 1st level closed.

Awesome Place. interesting place to visit in Thailand, because this is one of Thai's icon,, Then, an unique way to get here, we have to use boat accross the river,, please be prepared to have a hat or umberella, because it's an open place, hot,, and be careful with kind of photo booth there, because when you finished take a picture, somebody will come over you to take money,, hahaha

Amazing place to visit. I live close to this temple so I did not have to urge to visit until a group of my friends visited me in Bangkok. I have to say that the temple is great piece of work. It is really beautiful! The view at sunset is also amazing. You can also climb the "Chedi" if you are not scared of height and relatively fit. The view at the top is quite nice. Now I understand why it is regard as one of Bangkok's icon.For visitors, it is quite difficult to get to this temple as there is no BTS stopping close to the temple. The easiest way is to take the ferry from Saphan Taksin BTS station and get off at Tha Tien pier. Or you may want to take the Taxi from Wong Wien Yai station.
Renovations are spoiling the visit. Renovations are taking place so you have to put up with scaffolding but the temple is great non the less.

Undergoing a renovation. We saw this Wat each morning as our hotel was directly across the river from it. It was a quick, easy boatride across but the scaffolding limited viewing. (We did marvel that any worker would be brave enough to ascend the rather precarious looking scaffolds.) The grounds are pleasant and the small open market had a few possibilities for take-home gifts.
Great views at sunset!. Favorite temple in Bangkok. Visit at sunset if you can for best views! The steep stairs to get to the top are worth a climb for a great view of Chaophraya River.

Currently being renovated. Wat Arun is regarded as one of the must visit places in Bangkok. We took a BTS to Saphin Taksin, and hopped onto the Chao Phraya river boat. One needs to get down at the Tha Tien pier (No.8). A 3 Baht ride takes you to the Wat Arun from the Pier no.8.However, at the time we visited, the temple was under renovation, thus covered by the scaffolding completely. I don't think its worth at this moment to pay the 100 Baht entrance fee. We rather, albeit fortuitously, visited a small temple at the side of the entrance, wherein the resident monk was kind enough to help us offer our respects to the Gods.Would probably be a better idea to take the Chao Phraya river cruise or something at night, to see the temple lit.
