Another cool temple. Only 3 Baht to crossing the river. Unfortunately, when I was there the temple is under construction. So, I just see on the ground. It's not best place to visit but its cheap enough to complete your day in Bangkok.
Restoration. Great to see but restoration work in being done so photos of the exterior are not so good. Still well worth visiting.
under construction. at the moment not worth seeing because it is under construction,so you cannot really see the beauty of this Wat
wonderful. It was being reconstructed but do not hesitate to visit this temple.It is more than a common temple and it has a wonderful architecture and atmosphere.

Amazing to see. Although a little pricey to get in well worth it. Remember to take plenty of water with you (a lot of the kiosks inside had sold out).
There are not a lot of shaded areas so an early morning visit would be best, there is a big area to cover but the buddhas, temples make it worth while.

Touristic spot. Deffinitely as a first time tourist you need to visit the wat arun temple. Take the time to pay the ticket and walk around wat arun. Too bad the temple was under constructionworks when i was there (april 2015). Deffinitely a to do !

Wat Arun. Best to visit very early in morning to avoid heat and crowds, extreme shame that under refurbishments.
Take the ferry to Wat Phao for 3 Bhats.
Construction ruined the view. FYI they are doing construction so the temple is pretty much covered in construction equipment and you can't really touch anything or climb to the top.
Scaffolding covered!. Unfortunately, during our trip, the Wat was covered in scaffolding so we were disappointed. It must surely be stunning at night when viewed from across the river.

top of the tonburi world. exquisite temple to visit in Bangkok, no giant golden Buddha statue But an enormous temple with stairs to give you vertigo and wish you had never make it to the top!
the way down is far more riskier than the way up!
under refurbish. shame the temple was undergoing construction works. the external view compromised by scaffold. otherwise an interesting place to see if in bangkok

Steep steps but worth a visit.. An interesting visit, We marvelled at the materials used to decorate the Temple - Anything from broken bottles and coloured plates, shells, etc. A point of interest was the rope ladders which were obviously used to scale to the top for repairs (?). A word of warning is to be prepared for the number of steep steps required to appreciate the Temple. It can be viewed from ground level but it's not the same. The site has its usual stalls selling 'trinkets' and souvenirs.
Good but not open. It was very good from outside but we could not see it from inside as the renovation work was in progress.
Best Place For Sunset And Sunrise. Cheap ticket price, Great view,you can whole area of Bangkok and Chao Praya. Stunning sunset and sunrise, just try climb up till the top of pagoda. Clean location

Beautiful despite renovation. From Wat Pho you can cross the river by boat to Wat Arun for only 3 bath. The entrance fee is also very low. The tempels are beautiful decorated. It is good that they renovate the complex. Only for me it was a pitty. Could not make nice pictures. Despite everything I was glad that I visited it.
Ongoing refurbishment. I visited there in end of April, and unfortunately, most of it are under refurbishment. I hope I could visit there after its refurbishment.

Brilliant!. This is another must place to see in Bangkok. Unfortunately at the moment it is being restored so much is covered with scaffolding. Don't let this put you off as its interesting to see the marvellous work that is being done. You can certainly appreciate the before and after white colouring of the prangs. It is easily reached by catching the boat that goes across the river from the nearby Grand Palace. You can buy an ice cream here and some tasteful souvenirs.

Enjoys a beautiful location on the river, but under construction. This temple is very impressive, but would clearly be more so if it weren't covered in scaffolding at the moment. I heard this will only be for another few months (rather than years), so don't assume it will be this way when you go. Even under construction, the location on the river and views from it are impressive and lovely.

great temple. when we visited wat arun on April 18, the main temple is on renovation... so sad we cannot see the beautiful temple at dawn. we can rent Thailand traditional dress for 100 baht.. however the view from there is beautiful,, and the temple is beautiful also

Great place with beautiful garden. Great place with beautiful garden. Unfortunately we were late for the sunset. The temple was closed and under renovation. Anyway, you can take a boat for a 0.18 euro cents to cross the river Chiao Praya.
Lots of steps !. Fun to climb, careful on the way down, the view from avobe is great. I recommend early in the morning or late evening to avoid the heat.

A must-see of Bangkok!. Another great work of art temple in Bangkok. What makes it different from the rest, here you go. It is situated right at the bank of Chao Phraya River and is said to be one of the oldest temples in Bangkok. You have to take a ferry from other side of the river (not even 5 mins for a very minimal charge). You can also enjoy the glittering temple at night while you are on the river cruise. It is beautiful. Though it is seen being repaired (one section or another) almost all year long, its quite a spot for travelers who like to climb. Yes, you gotta climb. The steps are pretty steep and thin which take you to a higher platform on the temple where you can enjoy the view of the river and surroundings. A sure take if you are a temple and like-a-nice-view-from-top person.

Beautiful temple excellent location under renovation. This beautiful temple is located on the bank of the main river in Bangkok.Unfortunately the temple is under renovation and one is not allowed to climb up the steps of the temple.There are benches inside from where you can take in the beauty.The entry fee is 50 baht(less than a dollar). You are not allowed in with shorts.There are two smaller temples at the entrance in front of which you can burn incense sticks for free. Inside these small temples there are many a boxes for offering your donation. Interestingly all donations seem to be in notes and no coins.In case you come to the temple by road and not by river be prepared to walk a little to the main road for hiring a taxi.Inside the temple premises there are stalls where you can purchase coconut water and fruits at reasonable rates.
beautiful. one of best place to visit in Bangkok, twice in here and always crowded but glad i can have good picture here :p
Ok. Since some repairing was being done when we visited, this does not offer something extra as compared to other temples. If you are not a temple person you can let it pass

Climb the steps if you can.... This landmark of Bangkok is on the 10Bhat coin. When I met a local coworker on Monday, I was glad I was able to say "yes" when he asked if I climbed it. You don't go that far up the outside, but the steps are quite high and very steep. Be careful as there are no handrails!The temple was undergoing restoration, but it is still impressive to see the details on the exterior.

Construction work. We went to see the supposed beauty of Wat Arun but was disappointed because it was under construction. We heard from a bystander thst the construction has been going on for a while now. There's really nothing much else to see in the area.

Key Attraction. Entrance fee is 50baht. One of the famous temples in Thailand. Very nice architecture. But the main temple is currently being renovated so there's scaffoldings and construction. But still a must see if you're in Thailand. You can pay 3baht for a very short boat ride to cross the river going to another temple (Wat Pho).

Unique temple. Amoung many temple in Bangkok this temple is not very big but is unique and great work of architect. Was under major renovation work during our visit but can amazon, when finish, will look amazing. Steep steps to climb as you will find in many very old castles.Wonderful
Better than reclining buddha. It looks new, and looks it's the tower that on the back of coins.Can't remember clearly, but, I think only the tower is worth to have a look at, and it's free.

Very nice temple over the river.. Great temple you can visit at sunset or after you visited royal palace and Wat Arun. You can enjoy the view of the temple from the Chao Praya river from riverboat. Recommend to go at sunset.
A Hot Wat. This temple is undergoing major renovation, however it is still amazing to see and very cheap to go into. Easy to get to from the river boats (an experience in itself). Wonderful!

Nice temple tower. Bangkok has several Buddha temples and this is one of the famous temples. Currently it is under major renovation and we could not see the shrine,but went around the place to see the structure. very nice architecture, steep stairs to climb.

Amazing. I loved the location, the views from the top, the area around it! We just took our time and soaked all of that beauty in... It was at sunset and the light made everything more special. We are not hard people to please since we're always positive and so eager to see new places when traveling, but this was special for us.

TIRED OF CLIMBING. It is situated on the banks of the river so was a fun ride reaching there.To get a scenic view of the city you have to climb up the temple and the steps are very steep so be careful while climbing down.

interesting. Passing the white fence of the Royal Palace, you go to the local "flea market". Here you can buy old coins, household items and stuff that Thais carried out of their homes. Then in front of you will be a river on which boats are willing to carry you to the other side to the temple of Wat Arun. But do not immediately sit down in them. A little further there is quite formal urban crossing, which costs much cheaper than that offered by the enterprising locals. Goes the ferry boat, quite often. Somewhere every 10-15 minutes, so do not wait long. Use it as the locals and tourists alike. On the other side you sail almost to the very entrance of the temple. To appearance here are more relaxed. Lavna what would shoulders and knees were covered, and only what is your business. As there is a rental of clothing, but it's not insist.People in Wat Arun is much less than in the Royal Palace. Here you can easily walk around the area, climb to the weather and not be afraid that you breathe in the back of the crowd of tourists.Schedule all the attractions can be found at the hotel. When we were not working Tuesday Royal Palace. As for everything else, there is also the city booth marked with "i" - information, where you will be able to advise.

Under construction. The place looks amazing, awesome details, but was under construction at the time of our visit. Constructions are planned to last a few years, but am not sure when they will be done.

Temple closed. We went to Wat Arun during Songkran so it was extremely busy. The main temple was closed and building works mean it was covered in scaffolding so that detracted from our experience. We got dropped off in a long boat and got charged for landing.

A temple with a difference. This temple looks so very different from most of the other temples in Bangkok. You should see it from a boat on the river and particularly at night. But do also visit it. It's a little less crowded than other temples because you have to cross the river to get to it, but well worth the visit.

A beautiful temple. The elegant Temple of Dawn, built over 200 years ago, stands majestically on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River. It is a beautiful temple which looks most striking at sunset when it's reflection glitters on the flowing river.

Beautiful (shame about maintenance). I would have given this a 5 if it hadn't had been for the scaffholding. Still enjoyed seeing this sight and being able to look around it and the amazing intricate work of the Wat. We also enjoyed watching the sunset behind the Wat from across the water at a rooftop bar which was lovely.

Let down. This is something I had really looked forward to seeing while in Bangkok. After seeing the beautiful Wat Pho we got on a water taxi to cross the river to see Wat Arun as I really loved the look of the architecture. Unfortunately, it is currently covered in scaffolding (apparently a 2 year project) and a lot of the beauty was hidden.

Worth a visit. We visited Wat Arun just before sunset and it was beautiful! It was so cheap to get in (I think around 50 BHT) and although there were a few tourists there at the time, it still felt like such a quiet and peaceful place. The only negative comment I have is that at the time of visiting (January 2015) there was a bit of scaffolding as they are restoring the mosaics. We were actually in Bangkok again in March and they have seemed to put up even more scaffolding which is a shame for anyone visiting it. The stairs are also very steep so if you have mobility problems it is probably not a very good idea to climb up to the top level although it is still just as a pretty from the bottom. A definite must if you are in Bangkok!

Serenity and beauty. This temple is beautiful with a great history - go as early as you can to appreciate the lighting of the morning sun on the architecture - spectacular lit up at night and viewed from the river cruise.

Ignore the scaffolding and it is still an amazing sight. It is easy to criticise this temple because it is currently covered with scaffolding and some of the majesty is lost. However, it is still an awesome spectacle. Wat Arun – the Temple of Dawn is 79 m high and towers above the Chao Phraya river. At the entrance one is greeted by two mythical giants which lead one through to the temple which is beautifully decorated with ceramic tiles and colourful fragments of porcelain ie broken cups bowls and plates some of which were donated by the locals. The main tower is surrounded by four smaller towers with statues of the God of Wind – Phra Phai. It is possible to climb part of the temple for amazing views across the river to the Grand Palace and beyond but the steep and narrow steps are not for the faint hearted. Be aware that the higher levels are currently closed as a result of the on-going building works. This is disappointing but the temple is still very much worth the visit.Situated on the more inaccessible bank of the river the temple is relatively easy to get to if one knows the route. Simply take a water taxi to Tha Tien Pier (near Wat Pho) and cross the river using the boats cross the river. Do not confuse the boats that serve only to cross the river with the tourist boats that run along the whole length of the Chao Phraya. Accessing the river from central Bangkok is easiest via the Saphan Taksin station on the Skytrain. A short walk brings you to Pier O (CEN) where one can catch a tourist boat up stream to Pier 8 and cross the river using the river taxi. The temple is open from 8.30 to 17.30 each day and costs 50 THB (about £1GBP) for tourists and is free for locals.

Fantastic. We travelled by boat on the Chao phraya river from the port. Checking out the sights along the way. On arrival at the port you pay a small disembarking fee. The temple is being renovated at the moment but it is still stunning. Well worth a trip to see. We even watched workers cleaning and plastering the temple. This was fascinating to watch. Then we took the ferry across the river to the Grand Palace all for the sum of 3 bahts each.

Very Unique and Inexpensive . This is the most unique temple of the city, according to my limited experience. It was only 50 BHT or so to enter and I took the klong, the little boat to get across the river for three BHT. The temple is almost Cambodian, even though it's under construction right now and the scaffolding is somewhat distracting, you still get 90% of the experience.

Beautiful even with the scaffolding. Wat Arun was interesting to see, especially knowing how the decorations came to be, but there really isn't much now that it is mostly covered with scaffolding. The accessible area is quite limited and it took us longer to get there than we actually spent viewing it. Still a worthwhile morning

Well worth a visit to Wat Arun. Wat Arun is across the river from the Grand Palace stop on the river bus. It is well worth the short excursion across the river. It's a temple built in the Cambodian style and it is absolutely gorgeous. While I was there the temple was being renovated and it was convered by scaffolding. Nonetheless, I could clearly see the intricate artwork on the exterior. You can clim the very steep steps--calreflu if you have any fear of heights. The view is lovely and the trip down the steps preacrious. There are reminders here about not using the image of the Buddha as an adornment/statue in the yard.

Grand sights n grandeur architecture!. A lovely cruise down the Chao Phrya river takes you to the grand temple of dawn. The river cruise itself is a highlight away from the hustle and bustle of new Bangkok, taking you through the glimpses of the old and traditional city. Be prepared to walk. Climb the steep and scary stairs of the temple to get a panoramic view of the city.

still the same. its been a decade seen i visited the place yet surprisingly it is still the same. unfortunately, when my family and I visited the place, it is under renovation and most of the temples are close due to local holiday.

lovely place to visit. second time in Bangkok and finally made it, very disappointed as it was restoration job going on so I couldn't go up which I believe is the best part, any way interesting place to visit, toilets nearby and some food and stool with nearly everything on sale :) (ferry at 3baths)

Majestic. I've been to the Wat Arun twice and I never get tired of looking at the intricate figures and designs on the stupas..........The area fronting the river with the landscaped gardens and souvenir shops make the are place typically Thailand......the view of the wat from the Chao Phraya gives it a majestic appeal............there are lots of photo opportunities especially when wearing traditional Thai costumes (can be rented)

A passing view. We were on a boat ride along the Klongs (canals) of Bangkok and viewed the very impressive Temple of Dawn as we sailed past. It is on our list to take a closer look next time we are in Bangkok.

A must visit!. We came upon Wat Arun from the river side, only way to get there. It's majestic. Like an alien space ship or a fairy tale ceramic tower. I climbed part of it. The upper echelons are very steep. Easier to get up than down. Latter I did backwards, to avoid mishaps. Take your time to admire the many mosaics. All different. We were told they were made by ceramic bits and pieces, discarded by the many Chinese ships coming to port. Seen by night it's even more mysterious. A must visit!

The best place to see sunset. I came here in the afternoon after finishing sightseeing in other temples, such wat pho and grand palace. Actually this place was not included on my itinerary during my trip in bangkok. But, unexpectedly, this temple was really great and the arcitecture was really good enough. Come here to see a sunset is also a nice plan!

Must stop!. This is just one of those places you have to stop and see! It's interesting, though, how different it appears from far away, versus close up! The detailing close up is amazing, and I loved being able to see it up close. It's also beautiful to see it in the dark all lit up....it's unfortunate that my camera failed to capture how beautiful it really is!

SHUT as scaffolding is on it. OK to see it but beware it's shut and you can't climb up the temple inside because it's shut. Building works all around it. How they still charge for it is a joke!! I know it's cheap in our money but still....shouldn't have to pay if it's closed to walk up it. Good luck!
So Memorable, Don't Miss it.... So many things to see, be sure to wander around all the nooks and crannies,,, will be surprised what you will see… Really… Lots of good photo opportunities...
Gorgeous old temple on the bank of the river. It's not the glittering gold of many of the temples but it has beautiful mosaic of porcelain and seashells. Do not miss this!

Under construcion. We made a 45 minute journey to view the temple and I was disappointed as the majority of it is under scaffolding. I completely understand that renovation is required however, it would be good if this information was publicised as we had planned to have dinner watching then sunset over the temple but cancelled this as it wasn't exactly picturesque. Without doubt this is a beautiful temple and definitely worth visiting when it is restored.

Better from distance. we took a boat across the river to have a closer look at the Wat Arun temple. You get better view and photos from a distance and there was not much interesting detail on the chedis. We found the monastic compound nearby more fascinating.

To Visit is to take a step towards Heaven. To visit this highly spiritual location is akin to taking a step towards Heaven itself. The temple reflects the varying degrees of difficulty associated with the human condition and the aspirations of reaching some earthly equivalent of reaching heaven. By making the boat trip across the Chao Phraya river to the temple grounds, making offerings of gift and prayer, as well as ascending the steps to the dizzying heights of the temple, one creates merit which influences our karmic profile, and enhances our being.I promise that you will feel this way after a visit to this amazing location! :)

Temple of Dawn / Sunset. Temple of Dawn is a beautiful historical place to visit, right next to river. I took the tourist boat at Saphan Taksin BTS station and enjoyed around 15mins boat ride along the river where you can get on / off in several docks to explore. Temple of Dawn is one of the boat stops. The temple is very colorful and you can climb up to the top to see the slight of the nearby area. Best time to go is around 4 to 5pm (temple close at 6pm). You can take some lovely photos with sunset as background.

Under Construction. Wat Arun was under construction when we went, so some of the areas were blocked off. It was still impressive and worth the visit, but it lacked the size and variety of it's nearby neighbor Wat Pho.
Currently covered in scaffolding.... It's worth visiting (it only takes about half an hour to look around) but be aware that the main part of the temple is currently covered in scaffolding.
Working on it. They were working on it, so I just took some pictures from afar and didn't go to it. I've been there before and enjoyed the site.

beautiful temple to be visited at sunset. We went there by boat, as part of a long tour around the river and the canals. We arrived early in the morning, with less tourists on the premises. The central tower (rang) symbolizing Mount Menu, was shining.
👍. I didn't find the construction to ruin the temple. It was cool walking up the steep steps and had a great view!! It was very different than other temples we have seen in Thailand and I enjoyed it.
Very high, and nice. Good located, very ancient, and nice.But quite big challange to go to the top of the temple because of the steep stairs.

Best temple in Thailand. Don't miss this. I recommend taking a long-tailed riverboat tour (either from Saphan Taksin BTS stop, or the water by the Grand Palace), and then have the tour drop you off at Wat Arun. It's especially wonderful at sunset.

a beauty at night !. i didnt go in the temple..but what i like about this place is the beauty of it ( but u have to view it from the Chao Phraya river) that i went and view it 2 times ( 1 during the day : took a boat on the chao phraya river and snap a picture with the temple at the back and im on the boat ) :)At night , went to a place across the temple ( across cho phraya river ) and the picture at night is much more beautiful as this place light up at night in a goldish colour view )..

Under renovation. We did not actually visit the Wat Arun temple, but got great views of it (see photo) during a river cruise which was part of our combined Bicycle-Boat tour from Co van Kessel. It is clear Wat Arun is under renovation because it is high up in the scaffolding.
Under Refurbishment. Wat Arun was a big disappointment because the entire thing is being refurbished and so you really can't see anything. Wait to go until the work is done.

Quite disappointed. Temple is under construction and we visited the temple in the afternoon. It was hot and the temple don’t look like what we expect it to be.I guess u all really have to visit this temple at dawn and not in the morning or afternoon.

A very different temple all together.. A must for every traveller going to bangkok.very unique and different experience.as it is close to the grand palace so one can combine the visit .one ticket is used for both the temple and the palace
Best seen at night. See this temple and many other sights of Bangkok at night. Use Grasshopper Adventures for evening bike ride. No crowds and cooler temperature makes the experience more enjoyable.

Under Construction. This temple is presently Under Construction, it is religious place and it's not worth rating such place. You can enjoy ferry/boat ride which is very very cheap. If you are in Bangkok and visiting Grand Palace than you can have a look at this place too.

A beatiful temple with a view, a MUST see when visiting Bangkok. The Temple of Dawn ( Wat Arun ) is a large beautiful Buddhist Temple that is located on the West Bank of the Chao Phraya River. However, Wat Arun, is named after the Hindu god Arun. The tall and unique central Khmer tower with lots of spires is surrounded by 4 smaller towers decorated with sea shells and broken pieces of porcelain. At the base of the smaller towers there are many demons and monkeys. When entering the pavilion there are two giant figures (demons ? ) guarding the gate. As this is a popular site you need to be sure to have tennis shoes on not flip flops, plenty of water, and to be sure to put your money and credit cards in a pouch under your shirt or blouse as it gets very crowded. The large crowds is a perfect place for pick pockets to apply their trade. In order to avoid the rush and pushing of the large tourist groups, it is also suggested to let the crowds go by and then you can enjoy the site and take good pictures. If you arrive early you can also avoid the crowds. There is a commuter boat that travels along the river and you can take great photos from the river. There is also a dinner cruise that affords you the opportunity to take great evening photos. There is so much to see and enjoy at Wat Arun and it is a Must see when visiting Bangkok. A day visit and an evening boat ride when it is lit up is well worth your time.

Wow.....Incredible!. This temple is stunning! As we approached, I couldn't stop staring at it. It is truly a sight to see. We did climb up, and it is very steep, but worth the views. Worth a visit on your Bangkok itinerary!
Under construction. It is an amazing architectural piece, but unfortunately it was under construction and we weren´t able to go up.

Wat Arun. Nice place to visit, you will have to go on a ferry to reach this place. The temple is made of all the broken Porcelain which came as a present to the King. this is one of the nice place in Bangkok. You will have to climb steep high. Senior citizens cant climb to the top.

Exploring ancient temples Thailand. I love to travel to visit the temple with a boat ride across the river.The monastery has a high tower. A t the upward pagoda overlooking the capital city of Bangkok Riverside has come to this temple to pay homage to Buddha for good luck.If you visit this temple, remember to bring a camera to photograph the beautiful scenery around the temple. Inside the temple Available souvenirs available If you're traveling in January - April, heat a little. Do not forget to bring a hat or sunscreen.The most popular is to a high of Jaydee's sights.If visiting a temple afternoon sun light. Suitable for up to Jaydee to view.

Impressive even if it's being restored. Like previous reviewers we took the ferry to get to Wat Arun...great value and shows the gulf between the wealthy and the poor with the ramshackle houses cheek by jowl with the plush shops and hotels...we could clearly see the scaffold around the wat from the river....but we still visited...it was also very clear at the booth that we could not access all the higher levels....an obvious notice....and in fairness you only had to look at the wat....One of the highlights was the incredibly kind monk who gave our kids a pastry and drinks as we sat under the shade reading our guide book....This is not as grand as wat pho or the emerald Buddha....but it has a unique charm....with the flower details hand- crafted from pottery donated by the locals....the plates and cups sculpted into flowers....we could even watch the restorers working on these....There is a small market around the outside of the wat....yes v touristy....but good for the odd souvenir...particularly for the kids to pick up a few bits...

Beautiful. I've been here a couple of times and it never fails to mesmerize me. The temple is most beautiful when viewed at night from across the river or from the boats cruising the Chao Phraya River.

Bit of a disappointment, must go at sunset. I think it was just bad timing but the temple was under maintenance when we got there at about 4 pm. Though we bought the tickets, we weren't allowed to tale the stairs due to the work going on ( they conveniently did not inform us at the ticket counter )Tiny little souvenir shops around and on the other side of the river from the reclining Buddha. I would suggest heading there at sunset for a better experience
Beauty on the river. The super cheap ferry is ideal for a quick visit over.Very well kept, slightly less touristy than the main temples yet just as beautiful.

Most unique temple!. After backpacking Southeast Asia for 3.5 months and seeing hundreds of temples, Wat Arun was my favourite because it was different than the others. Climbing up the steep steps and seeing the view was a lot of fun :)

Scaffolding. Could see from river trip that the temple had lots of scaffolding to und it but went anyway. Although the scaffolding naturally hid a lot, it was also fascinating to see how difficulty it must be to keep these temples in a fit state.

The most magnificent after-dark spectacle in Bangkok. An array of delicious restaurants sit across from Wat Arun which is where I suggest you view this masterpiece from. Light up by night on the banks of the river, it truly is a remarkable sight. My restaurant suggestion would have to be 'Arun Residence' where you can book your preferred view.

Wat Arun-ific. This was a great place to visit in Thailand. I had the pleasure of meeting an old high school friend and her husband who were gracious in being our travel guides while we were in Bangkok.We visited a lot of places and this was one of those temples that we visited. I like how this place was in the middle of the city and what I really liked about this place were the:  1.) statues of the 12 Chinese Zodiac signs 2.) we got to wear Thai traditional outfitThe climb up was challenging since the steps were very steep and my legs were wobbly when I was going down, well, I attribute that to my fear of heights.Overall, this was a nice place to visit.

Favourite Temple. This was my favourite temple in Bangkok. Unfortunately it is undergoing restoration works so parts of it are covered in scaffold. Despite this the style is something I appreciated and you can see how beautiful it is in the areas that they have restored. You can't currently walk to the top of it but you could walk up to the first floor for an added view. There are markets in the grounds selling clothes and drinks and it's worth making the trip over here. A ferry from central pier to Wat Arun would be the cheapest option and/or you can combine with a longboat tour and have them drop you off here as your final point.
Wonderful but pity. As i seen from postcard should be really nice, but at the moment they are doing some maintenance on it so most of best view, also from river, is ruin by activities.

Postpone in You Can. OK, go see Wat Arun if you absolutely must do it right now. But in a city full of sublimely beautiful Wats, this should be low LOW priority right. Of the iconic chedi complex you see from the river, the large central stupa and three of the four smaller ones around it, are covered with scaffolding and tarps. You can still pay 50 baht to get in, but you cannot actually climb anything or see much. Renovations began February 11th. Until they are complete, you would be much better off going to any of a number of other Wats. If you haven't ever been to Wat Sukhat and the Giant Swing, go there. If you haven't been to Wat Saket in over a year, go there. Whether you've been to Wat Arum before or not, if you go there now you will be terribly disappointed. The small minor buildings to the west of the main chedis are interesting, but do not justify any effort to get there. The promenade in front of Wat Arun, where you can contemplate the river traffic, with your back to the Wat, is still wonderful. But with so many exquisite alternatives, why waste time on this one? Don't get me wrong, Wat Arun is awesome and I am delighted that they are doing this work. Get there as fast as ever you can, once the scaffolding comes down. As for what it looks like at the moment, see photo.

Nice temple, but lack of profesionalism and infrastructures. I visited this temple October 2014. quite nice, however, be aware of the boat admission, it is cheap but the ticket counter officer seems unfriendly, and the exchange payment is not appropriate, every one of our group admitted different price. Because it was a long queue so it is not enough time to complain about the exchange payment. It was very disappointed. not about the money value, but about the professionalism particularly for foreigner tourist.However around the temple, there were a nice traditional costume rental. They were very helpful and nice. We rent traditional Thailand clothes for photo session. :)
Big renovations going on at the moment. Took the water taxi (3 baht) from Wat Pho. The temple is covered in scaffold and not very photogenic at the moment.
Eh. Scaffolding sure hurts the experience.. The temple is almost surrounded by scaffolding, so that takes away from the beauty. Hope it's gone by the time you go.

A temple you shouldn't miss.... Wat Arun is one of the most beautiful temples in Bangkok, in my opinion. It is currently under restoration, so parts are scaffolded (I'm sure we have seen scaffolding all over the world on just about every main tourist attraction by now!)The plaster and tile-work is beautiful, and dont forget to walk through and have a look at the gardens and temple behind, It is a major tourist area, but the markets are pretty good. You can get here by boat or taxi. The local ferries stop here but we just hired a private longboat. The boatman will wait for you and take you back to whence you came. Dont worry. He'll recognise you as soon as you step onto the dock : ))

A must see in Bangkok. It was on our to-do list after The Grand Palace. We took a tuk tuk till the Pier Tha Tien and then took a ferry across to the Wat Arun. Also, called the Temple Of Dawn, I found it to be a reflection of the Thai era bygone. The turret over looks the entire city and faces the Grand Palace on its opposite. It was worth buying the entry ticket and climbing up to the temple. Those not keen on going till the top can park themselves in the coffee shop at the entrance.P.S Be prepared for sore leg muscles once you climb down!
under renovation. so not really much to see or do at this temple - looks fairly spectacular from across the river. Not the best temple to visit under these circumstances

I can't forget it.... It was on our second day in Bangkok, we took a long tail boat for a 2 and half hours trip on the Chao Praya, I was very surprised when after a couple of minutes the " captain" suddenly stopped in the front of some stepes and a beautiful gate.It was the famous Buddhist temple, " Wat Arun" ( The Temple of Dawn). We had 30 minutes to wisit it, I was simply delighted what I saw here, I liked especially the main pagoda, but I was afraid to see how people climbed up and down the steps...especially the higher was almost vertical!At the end of our visit we fed the fishes with a special food offered by our captain, then he took us to the chanels ( floating market) . It was an unforgettable afternoon!

Interesting. Near hotel - good for an afternoon, but you want to have someone who knows some history with you. You also find some places to do shopping across the street. And restaurants to take a meal.

A good reflection of Thai culture. The place is not as glamorous as the Grand Palace, but it is still an excellent reflection of the Thai culture. Definitely worth a visit. It is not that big in size. 45 minutes would be adequate for the visit. Bring a binocular so that you can see clearly the figures sculptured on the upper parts of the towers.

for us the drive by on the water taxi would have been enough. As been said the temple is surrounded by scaffolding right now. Of all the temples this was our least favorite. I'm not sure we would have felt differently even if the scaffolding was not there. For us seeing it from the water taxi was enough.

beautiful but scaffolding dissapointment. If you are visiting Wat Pau in Bangkok (The Temple of the Lying Buddha you must pay Wat Arun a visit too, it is just across the river and worth a trip. It really is very beautiful and have heard that the views from the top are something to see, you can see all up the river bank. However currently there are maintenance works going to so we could not go up to the top. We only saw the surroundings and the grounds areas. Disappointing but our own fault not for checking before we went. I think the works are going on for a few months so I would check before visiting!

Best enjoyed from the outside. The temple itself is beautiful, but since a lot of people come and try to climb the steep steps, it became rather dangerous, especially if a group tour from certain country came to this area. Plus, it is now under renovation, so all you see are scaffoldings. Thus, it is better to spend more money having evening drinks from restaurants across the river and enjoy the Temple basking in the lamplight
Dissapointing Construction. Seems like it could have been very cool, but it was mostly blocked by scaffolding. Put off a visit until it is complete!

Amazing temple. Beautiful grounds. Nice temple on the river. Good place to relax and watch the river. Easy to cross the river by ferry for three baht. Temple being renovated so scaffolding obscures the temple now.

Loved the view!. I loved climbing Wat Arun, the stairs are very steep so you absolutely need to wear solid shoes! And be sure that you have enough water to drink with you cause the heat on top of the platform at Wat Arun is even more hot and you absolutely feel the difference between the ground level and the higher ones...

It didn't wow me really. I am Thai so i don't know whethe rmy review would help. I live in America now i was visting family and friends in Thailand with my husband. My husband is American so i wanted to show him around and what are the highlights in Bangkok including Wat Arun. For foreigner will have to pay 50 baht fee. The temple was under renovation, stairs were closed so you can't claim up. It was a little bit disappointing. We didn't spend lots of time there just take pictures and leave.

Scaffolding Disappointment. Unfortunately on our visit the Wat was surrounded with Scaffolding due to work being carried out on the main temple area. This meant that apart from walking around the outer areas we got to see very little of the Wat.However what you could see looked very impressive and we plan to return to Bangkok one day and revisit. The surrounding grounds of the temple are a real oasis in the centre of a teaming busy city, with lush well maintained gardens.Do visit, but just be aware that at this time, March 2015, the temple is covered in scaffolding.

Breathtakingly beautiful. The temple of Dawn is best visited in the early morning. Easily accessible by ferry, the chants by the Buddhist priests coupled with the peace and serenity in the temple premises leave you feeling calm and energetic. The steep stairs in the front of the temple offers a challenge to the adventurer in you. Not difficult unless you have a fear of heights! But be careful on the way down. the view from the top is breathtaking. Unfortunately, current restorations do not permit the climb currently.The shrine inside in adorned with beautiful ceiling to floor murals and you can see Buddhist monks at prayer. A must visit in Bangkok where the throng of tourists have not destroyed the spirituality of the temple yet.

Hot Sunny Temple. Again, just to see the ruins. Nothing much to do as u will be under the hot sun all the time. Overall its just OK. Not much historical culture goes behind this except during desperate times people started stealing the bricks and sell them off?

The Best Temple in Bangkok. This is a magnificent temple in every way. It's certainly not for the weak of heart if you want to climb to the top as the stairs leading there are extremely steep. I have seen people make their way to the top only to get too fearful to come down (they do eventually with some coaxing). The views from the top are spectacular. The area around the temple is also well kept and inviting. There is usually something going on that you can see. Early morning or late afternoon is the best time to see this temple.

Very interesting to watch the restoration in progress.. This is across the river from the Reclining Buddha temple. It is undergoing restoration, which appears to likely last forever. Very impressive structures, and temples. If you are at the Reclining Buddha, you might as well catch the river taxi, (3 bhat- 20 cents), across to this temple. The grounds are perfectly landscaped and make a beautiful frontage to the temples. Well worth the admission, 50 bhat, I recall.

Wat Arun: Beautiful. Beautiful temple, undergoing renovations.Steep steps but so worth the climb, beautiful view from the top; be extra careful coming down, don't panic, just take your time. Worth visiting even if you don't want to climb or steps are closed.Easy to get to by the river boat; can take ferry from central pier, get off at pier for grand palace, take a cross river ferry to Wat Arun.Popular for sunrise and sunset viewing; can take a night river cruise and view the temple from the boat.Since Wat Arun opens before the Grand Palace and can be seen in a short time, if you can, get here before opening, then take the cross river ferry to the other side and head to the Grand Palace; after that walk to Wat Pho(Reclining Buddha) Done!!!

Amazing..but make it there early morn. This is the most amazing temple in Bangkok and my personal favourite and i strongly suggest that you visit this place early in the morning.You cant climb up as it is undergoing renovations but will be open in 4-6 months.Must Visit.

Stunning. This was my 3rd time in Bangkok but the first time I had managed to get to Wat Arun. I loved it. Its a bit of a climb up to the top but the view is amazing. Easy to get to by riverboat. Just ensure that you are respectfully dressed - as with most religious sights in Bangkok.

Go at nighy. I went at night as part of a night bike with grasshopper adventures. Unfortunate that I caught it during restoration, but beautiful all the same. What stood out, for me, was the monks leading the chanting. So peaceful and a wonderful vibe. Sadly I can't recall what time they do this, but it's every night. My guess is sundown for at least an hour. Perhaps ask around?
best in bangkok. From all the temples in Bangkok this one impress a lot, clean , silent and beautiful. a must visit when in bangkok.

Breathtaking. The temple is really worth seeing and if you don;t have a fear of heights, you can climb up the temple which is not for a fainthearted. It is not that hard to climb though but it would be an adventure.
Beautiful temple. Especially during the night, you can avoid people, and see another peaceful side of the temple. I have enjoyed very much.

Beautiful. The buildings are beautiful and very ornate. Worth the small fee to to go into the main building areas.(50 Bht) There was some restoration but you could still see the magnificence of the building.Reached by local ferry 3Bht from across the river at the main tourist stop.
Beautiful temple. Beautiful temple by the riverside, well worth a visit but be careful if you're going to climb to the top, Don't go if you suffer from Vertigo !.
Worth the visit. If you want to see temples in Bangkok, don't miss the opportunity to see this! Go early in the day when it's not so hot or crowded.

Under reconstruction. . Best left to visit once the renovation work has been completed in 2016. Currently it is a building site with extensive scaffolding and workmen chipping away creating new bits of ceramics to add to the crumbling concrete facade. The most interesting features are the statues dotted around and wall paintings within the temple. Overall it's best seen from a distance as the external 'Kitsch' type detail is of poor quality anyhow. Historically significant and a point of interest but probably not worth the effort having viewed the better temples on the Eastern side of the river. Have lunch on the bank opposite and enjoy the view instead.

Beautiful. A lot of work going on in the temple at the moment, but other than that, this is a very stunning temple with beautiful gardens. A word of warning for the ladies, as per all temples, please go with your shoulders covered and at the very least, a pair of knee length shorts. This temple as all others are places of worship and not just tourist attractions. Please show respect and cover up. If you arrive under dressed, you will probably not be allowed in unless you hire some shawls and or sarongs from the temple.

Under construction (march 2015). When planning to make photo's at sunset, don't bother going there, because it's under construction. Yes, it's a beautiful temple, but when you need the perfect shot, you'll be disapointed at this time.

Worth seeing. It is under construction now, but you can still see the splendor of the temples. Thirty to 45 minutes are all you will need unless you want to dig in to every building. This, the Royal Palace and the Temple of the Reclining Buddha are three worth seeing - maybe many more, but I definitely recommend these three.

Excellent. This is a must see for anyone visiting Thailand. The steps are small so take your time. The Thai take good care of this place. They were in the process of upkeep during my visit. You have a great view of other sites from this temple.

Under maintenance. The site is covered in scaffolding. At this time it is not really worth visiting. On a positive note, due to the maintenance it was not too busy. A shame that restoration work is not of a great standard in Thailand.

Amazing (but under renovation). As most of the Wat's in Bangkok, also Arun is an amazing construct with the most amazing and fantastic buildings even so a renovation ongoing, so some areas are not accessibleWe took the small ferry from Arun to Pho - so we also could see this
Breathtaking, especially at Dusk!. A must-see. If you plan for one thing in Bangkok, this is a must visit. Under renovation at the moment (Feb. 2015) so many areas are not currently accessible.

Lovely temple and more. Temple of the dawn was a nice experience and we enjoyed the small ferry ride to reach it too. Quite near the stairs there is also an area where you could be dressed in a traditional thai outfit with a crown, jewellery and everything (not expensive) and we got so funny pictures after doing so :DThere are many small places to buy some drinks and souvenirs.
Be prepared to climb the stairs. Beautiful temple, but the stairs to the top are very steep and be quite challenging. The climb up is tough, but coming down the stairs you need to be careful.

Steep Steps but worth the climb. I had visited several Temples before in Bangkok, but Wat Arun was different. Interesting, seemed older. Steep steps worth the view at the top. It wasn't just that the steps were steep, but each step seemed to be quite high itself - bendy legs needed. Well worth a visit.

dissapointed. though we have visited many temples throughout Thailand , it was sad to see so many market traders screwing poor tourist anyway they can , unfortunately there scaffon around the main temple and there was only limited access, to me a Buddhist temple should be a quiet sacred place where you are able to observe the richness of the temples in a discreet manner , not being badgered by hawkers and sellers.

Okay stop, but not as impressive as other sights. If you're coming from the Grand Palace/Wat Pho side, take the 3 baht ferry across the river (remember $1 = 30 baht) to Wat Arun. Sadly, the wat was under renovation so a good portion of it was covered in scaffolding. The entrance fee here is 50 baht and again there was no audio guide. Compared to the Palace and Wat Pho, Wat Arun is relatively anti-climatic. That being said, the pagoda at Wat Arun is one of the more picturesque ones and the surrounding gardens make it a very calming visit after the hysteria at the other sites.

Wat Arun. We have being to Bangkok three times and I never missed visiting Wat Arun the spectacular grand attraction of Bangkok . This place is a photographer's delight , and with each part of the day the temple looks different . The river cruise adds to the fun .
in reconstruction. nothing to see there actually. For 50 bth fee you can see only scaffolding. Small market near the temple, lot of cats.

A wonderful Pagoda. The time I visited Wat Arun,It was under renovating too. Anyway it's worth visiting so much. This old temple located at riverside of the main river of Bangkok in the center of the city. Access was easily by shuttle boat across the river. Surrounding by many famous temples and the royal palace,you can visit all of these in a day. The old Pagoda was very amazing and when you climb up there you can see the scenic view of Bangkok in panorama.
very nice design. design is very nice , the view from the top was fantastic , during sunset you can enjoy the view from one of the cafes in front of the temple and enjoy the night lights .

Been There. I did not see the beauty of this temple as it is under construction so we decided not to go in even though the entrance ticket is 50bath as we felt we might not see it. So viewing from outside is enough for us, leave the visit to next time and I would like to come here during evening time to see the dawn scene.

Visit to temple of dawn. It is a good temple to visit just take the river boat at sapan tksin not the tourist one. It stops at all the places you need then go to Wat po and have lunch at the deck which has a great view of the dawn temple if the big boat is not moored in front!!!

Wat Arun was under reconstruction. Because of the reconstruction the way upstairs was closed, so I was a bit disappointed. Athough, maybe also becuse of the reconstruction there weren´t crowds of tourists, so the place was peaceful and I had a lot of time and space for taking pictures.

Take the river shuttle from Grand Palace and see it. Under renovation, but that was actually interesting to watch workers making the ceramice colored tiles and applying and cleaning the white plaster/paint. The completed spires are beautiful, and it is amazing to see how much work is required to complete the reno. Easy 3 baht shuttle across the river (max 2 minute ride) from Wat Pho pier #8

Another beautiful temple complex. It is actually another beautiful temple complex, unfortunately there were souvenir shops area that bothered just a bit :) if i may suggest, the souvenir shops should be moved just a bit out of the temple complex.Got a good bargain for souvenirs though :) the quality is not as cheap as it's price. Good quality with very good price. So happy hahaha...
Not just for dawn. I went in the late afternoon and loved the peacefulness up in the temple. It was a little too early for the sunset, but I imagine it would be beautiful.
It´s under consruction till 2016. I just walked around the temple. It´s nice, but it´s under construction till february 2016. For now not worth the visit.
Beers across the bay. I watched the sun set over the Wat Arun while having drinking cold Singha and eating delicious Thai food. Hard to beat
Work being done so couldnt climb. Work was being done so couldn't climb up the temple, bit out of the way, sure the view would have been good otherwise

Bangkok must see. Dear fellow travelers.Nothing more to say actually. Need to visit, must see in Bangkok. I personally liked this temple the most out of whole trip to Bangkok. Something mystical about the place. The view from the place is amazing. Also recommend Temple of the Emerald Buddha.

Awesome temple, need more stories. This is one of the great temples I have ever visited. Not too big, but it has detailed ornaments. You also can climb to the top and see Chao Praya River. There are a lot of souvenir stalls around the temple. However, I couldnt find the description/stories about this temple (I searched it in google later). So I just went around, take pictures, and enjoy my time
Awesome Wat. We went to this Wat during the day an climbed to the top and walked around. We also took a boat ride up the river at night to see it all lit up. Both excellent experiences.

Wat Arun is not to be missed!. This temple is different from some of the others in Bangkok because you are able to climb to the top and experience the grand detail of the Temple's structure and walls. The detail is exquisite!
Unfortunately.... It's being renovated -in March 2015- and it's not pleasant to see (and to pay the ticket to admire scaffolds!)

Renovations at mo!. This was a really nice temple but there was lots of scaffolding up when we visited as they were renovating the temple and the signs said this will last until February 2016. It would have been nice to see it without the scaffolding. This temple was easy to get to using the river boat service, it drops you at the wrong side of the river but you get another one across for only 3b each. It is free entry to the temple.

Very majestic and spectacular. Near grand palace and wat pho, wat arun is a rather large temple with great views. Getting here by ferry, from Wat Pho, is the easiest and cheapest way to visit this amazing temple. One of the main things to do there is climbing the extremely steep stairs, which can be a big obstacle for some people but the view from the top is spectacular. Although the temple was under maintenance, the views were still worth seeing. Climbing down can be quite difficult but after a few tries, it is easy to go back down.

Under maintenance. It was under maintenance... Good place... However they should update their website saying its down for maintenance.... As otherwise its a let down for tourists like us...you book a cab reach there to realise its under maintenance...
Better from the outside?. Take the ferry across the water from Wat Pho and get your photos in. Dramatic on the skyline, and different stone feeling compared to other temples.

Looks great from across the river after sunset. Great view from the top - though the very steep stairs makes even the adventurous feel dizzy on the way down. Closes at 6 pm. We got there just as they were closing and therefore got in free and got be the last to get upstairs before they closed!
Climb and admire the view. Always a lovely place to visit. We climbed and enjoyed the magnificent view over the river. Wat Arun is one of the most beautiful places to visit. Don't miss it.

Great View of Chao Phraya River.. I enjoyed climbing the stairs at Wat Arun and the view was definitely worth it! I can recommend the coconut ice-cream sold by nearby vendors (it is so addictive). Be sure to cover up your shoulders and legs when visiting.
It was in renovation. It was in renovation so we couldn't see much, but i recommend having a dinner on the river facing the Wat Arun = amazing view :)
Worth seeing . Nice temple, unfortunate that there are renovations at the minute but still nice to see and worth a visit. The short trip across the river adds to the experience.

No filter needed. After going to grand palace, we decided to go to wat arun. Outside the palace, a local overheard our conversation on how are we going to get to wat arun. Then he approached us and told us to ride a tuktuk to the boat going here. We told the driver that we dont want a tour we just want a boat ride but then he brought us to the wat arun tour that costs 800 baht per person. We declined and decided to just use the google map to find our way to wat arun. Just look for tha tien pier. The roundtrip boat ride costs 6 baht per person only and it only takes about 5-10 minutes to cross the river. The long walks finding the pier was all worth it. The view was magnificient. We wanted to wait for the sun to fully set but the guard whistled and instructed everyone to go down because the temple closes at 6pm. Aside from the expensive tour offered around at wat arun you have to be careful of the steep stairs.

Gud but photos did not come quiet clear!!. Good to visit in Night as I visited in Day so don't know of the night but night would be much better to visit as looks gr8 in night. Isn't much in there but a nice place!!!

The Temple of Dawn is a good place to see sun set in Bangkok.. The great stupa of the temple is one of the landmarks in Bangkok where you can see from far away on the river bank. You can climb up to enjoy the panorama view 360• on the stupa. Now the stupa is under renovation until February 2016, anyway you can walk around the stupa and the temple compound, climbing up is not allowed till it is completed.

SPECTACULAR VIEW. Thailand is a land of temples. And it certainly can get boring after a heat rush in bangkok. However, temple of dawn is the one and the only of its kind that offers a breath-taking view and also requires many breath-taking steps. Get off at skytrain, Saphan Taksin. Pay like 15 thb for a boat ride from sathorn pier to Wat Arun. I definitely recommend an evening hour as it offers an amazing sunset view. Don't go too late either cus it closes around 5pm. Many tourists make such a hype about Grand Palace and Emerald Buddha, but Wat Arun, standing tall on the opposite side of the river will wow you with its magnificent ancient architectures and beautiful ornaments decorated all over the temple. It's a must!oo_oo and don't forget to grab some ice-cream before you leave. It's soooooo delicious!
Great temple by the river. Really nice and impressive temple by the river. It's also very nice from a boat, during the day and at night

Bangkok's Main Landmark. Unfortunately being renovated right now, so if you're going now expect to see scaffolding. The main staircase to the top was also closed the day we were there. Still a huge, stunning temple, and large parts of it are open. Magical at night!

Historic and functional. We've been too many temples in Bangkok, Wat Arun is on top of my listThe reason being that the temples are more realistic and not so artificially glamorous, also because there are real monks doing their things inside so it's closer to real religious venue than other tourist focused placesThe architecture of Wat Arun is just breath taking, must go!

Great. Great temple and a bit different from the other buddist temples around Bangkok in architecture, the climb to the top via the steep steps make it more fun and the views of surrounding Bangkok are great. A small part of the temple was being renovated.

Nothing overwhelming. I think we just expected something different. We thought you could walk into the temple as you do into a church or mosque. But the temple you need to climb and it also was under construction so we weren't able to see much. It was nice to see monks (like in Tibet)Be aware that you need to dress appropriately (knee long trousers/skirts/dresses and covered shoulders) to enter the temple! You can rent a cloth for 20 baht at the ticket counter (tickets cost 50 baht).
Great Temple. Just across the river and a 3 bat boat ride each way. Climb up to the top and have an amazing view of the city.
Not impressive up close. The best view of this is from across the river when it's lit up at night. Not as impressive up close. Seen it once, but wouldn't bother going again.Visited February 2013.

Nice temple, however it was under construction during our visit.. We visited this place on 6 March 2014. The structural of Wat Arun is awesome. However during our visit, there are some construction going on to the temple. We couldn't take good picture as the construction spoil the view of it. It is recommended to go when they finish up the construction.
Excellent Architecture.. Its Fabulous Buddhist temple located at Chao Phraya River. Due to maintenance upper section was closed. So we did not climb higher. Its entry cost 50 baht each.
Nice Temple. Visitors must see this. Other than this Golden Buddha, Tigre temple, Safari world, Joyus Tussauds Wax work are interesting places including river rides.
Check renovation dates. Amazing! Go early next year. I will also to see what they have done. You will see themes borrowed by Hollywood films like the Wizard of Oz

Beautiful Temple. It was difficult to visit this temple in the past trips because it is located at West side of river. This time, we decided to take the train and boats to get there. From Siam station, we spent 35B on train, 40B on boat and 4B on ferry.
Scaffolding on half of the temple. Disappointingly the temple was covered in scaffolding so it was a little disappointing, still a good place to visit but pointless taking photos.

Scaffolding . I should imagine this would be a truly amazing site with out all of the scaffolding as at this moment in time it is being cleaned, it only cost 50 baht entry and only 7 baht each way for the river crossing, would still recommend a visit, please be aware there are some steep steeps to climb.

OMG what a view and an exhilarating climb - both up and down!!. This is a must see when visiting Bangkok - it is stunning. The climb to the top is well worth doing but is not for anyone with a fear of heights or a faint heart !!! It is breath taking! The stunning views from the top are amazing and the structure and fine detail of the temple are amazing too.
Closed until feb 2016. We went there after reading so many reviews but only to figure that it's closed for one year for maintenance. Hence there is not much to see coz the main temple is closed.

Beautiful Sight. This temple is one of the most famous and gets lots of visitors. We used a private guide who helped us navigate to catch all that we wanted to see with narrative explaining the significance and history. We were so glad we had this on our itinerary. Yup you go you won't be disappointed

Bangkok Temples and Canals Tour with Bangkok Day Tours. This was our first stop. What a fabulous way to begin our touring of Bangkok. One must see Wat Arun. Photos can't capture the beauty. It is also hard to imagine the colors of early morning at the Temple of Dawn. The detail is amazing.

One of Bangkok's must see sites. Beautiful towering temple on the west bank of the river. Great view of Bangkok from the top. Easy to combine this with a canal (klong)boat tour or just take a cheap ferry from the pier on the east side of the river (near Grand Palace-I think it is called Elephant Pier). Next to Wat Pho (Reclining Buddha temple), it is my favorite.Combining Wat Arun, the Grand Palace and Wat Pho would make nice 4 hour tour.
Spectacular from the river. We viewed Wat Arun from the river, on the ferry with tourists and locals. Great sight, and site by the river. Worth a visit and climb - if you don't mind heights

Beautiful Temple - if you only go to one, go to this one. So much to see in a fairly compact area. If you only have time for one temple, come to this one. Main attraction is the reclining Buddha - absolutely beautiful - crowded though, so not easy to get a great picture. Several other Buddhas and scenic buildings all around. Small admission fee, ticket came with a coupon for a free bottle of water.

Make sure you wear the correct clothing!. Unfortunately we didn't get in, they will not let you in with shorts, sleeveless tops, jeans. You can get trousers free of charge but a very long queue. Look stunning from what we could see

Steep steps, but breathtaking views!. Took the ferry here on a day trip! The work that went into this temple is astonishing. The steps are quite steep, so be careful, but the views of the city are pretty impressive once you make it to the top! Make sure this is on your to-do list while in Bangkok!
Restoration in progress. We went to Wat Arun with no idea that it's in the process of restoration. All we saw were stilts, "no entry" signs everywhere. It was quite disappointing.
Scenic, authentic. Authentic temple site, ancient structures. Friendly cats! Lots of tourists due to religous holiday. Good location.

Under construction. It is 3 baht per person one way to take a ferry from the Grand Palace side of the river to get to Wat Arun. Admission is only 50 bhat per person; however, the temple is undergoing major renovations at the moment. You could barely manage a picture without scaffolding and you can not climb to the top. You can only walk on one side of the four sided temple. Had I know this, we would have saved our 100 bhat as we were really looking forward to climbing the stairs for the view. We got the same experience from the outside of the temple. Would not recommend to visit until after renovations are completed.

Under construction, but it made for some great shots. I have vertigo! My companion did not! So, she climbed all the way up as far as she could go while I walked all around Wat Arun taking photographs. I can actually make a complete copy of Wat Arun in 360º panorama! I took well over 600 shots on manual! Took a lot of the day and all in the sun!The eating is slim here and getting there on a Jetty is a bit hard to figure out! However, all in all, it was an experience I would never pass up. One place, where one gets the Jetty to Wat Arun, to the right of the gate, has good beer as well as food! They were so kind and friendly! This made this visit even more worthwhile as it is the people that make the place and not the place itself!Go. Enjoy!

Amazing and Unique.. Compared to the other temples in Bangkok this is certainly unique, and one of the best "must-sees" in the city. I'd recommend getting there early or late in the day, we went during mid-day and the stairs are very very steep! So it was incredibly hot and a good workout. As I said it is very steep, so be prepared to climb; if you are not wearing 'acceptable' clothes, they have garments available for rent so don't worry. It provides a fantastic scenic view of the city. Try not to go on a weekend if possible, you are ushered around the place way too quickly when its busy - you want to make sure you get a good view and can take it in once up the top.

Stunning. Take the ferry for 3 Baht each way from Tha Thien Pier. Upon your return (hopefully in the early evening. Enjoy a Chang and the view from the ramshackle restaurant at the pier. The details of the central Prang are spectacular. I have attached some pictures from one of my ebooks.Larry Stein authorSoutheast Asia on a Rope: Thailand and LaosSoutheast Asia on a Rope: Cambodia and Myanmar

Reserve a table. I did not visit actuall temple but we look the shapes the temple from restaurant on the otherside of the river .We had a late lunch and enjoyed the views then went to visit near Wat Pho
best temple in Bangkok. Come during sunset. Its one of the best temples in bangkok! a bit off the path as its on the other side of the river yet packed full of history!

Huge renovation is going on. The main reason I only gave this place 3 stars is because of the renovation being done. I had to try finding good spots for good photos because most of the parts of the temple are covered with construction frames. It has potential though and it was quite busy because many Thai people were visiting to pray and to receive blessings there.

Amazing temple , even better up close . Beautiful temple. The garden grounds outside the temple are impeccably maintained. It is much more amazing to see up close. It looks brown and drab from across the river but is gleaming and white when you get closer to it. Do not miss this site. Only a 3 cent ferry ride across the river.

Been back twice !. Easy to get to from the little ferry across the river.Much more pleasant than the huge temples further along.The monks run a nice little side line in trinkets etc.but they are never pushy.You will be able to do the whole place in half a day which, because of the heat, is a good thing !

By the river. This is very much an outdoor temple. Nice photos outside but it does not really have anything nearby. The best part is the river, go by boat taxi/ferry from the city side for great views. Better than getting off the boat if you only have a short time. This place looks beautiful at night from the city side of the river, even better than during the day.

beautiful. I liked this temple most of all. Its different from the others. Really nice and has a great view when you climb it (wear comfortable shoes). It doesnt have gold everywhere like the Grand Palace. Its simple and nice.

Gorgeous. A short boat ride across the river from Wat Pho, Wat Arun provides some great views of the Chao Phraya River and all of its traffic. The main tower(prang) has very steep steps that intimidated me, but my husband and daughter went partway up. The intricate decorations are made of porcelain and must have taken a very long time to create. It is a truly lovely place and different from the other wats.

Don't miss this place. Just 3 bhat for the ferry across.. This place is located just across the river from the Palace, so there is no excuse to miss it. The ferry ride is just 3 bhat each way, so it's not too expensive. There is a charge for tickets, however, no one collected ours and I think you could just walk in without anybody noticing. Although the top of the temple has a great view, especially of the Chao Phraya river, the steps are steep and it seems a little dangerous. Inside the temple you will see beautiful golden statues of Buda
Fascinating. Favorite site in Bangkok. We stopped by for lunch in a restaurant just across the river. I will always cherish that moment overlooking to temple and eating the best pad Thai ever.

Must visit Temple!. Out of all the temples we visited while in Thailand, Wat Arun is one that stands amongst the rest! Although a steep climb and a little busy with tourists, the views are fantastic. The temple is also decorated with beautiful Chinese porcelain which made it stand out for me from the other temples. I also loved the whole little boat trip across the Chao Phraya River although busy and a short ride (only 3Baht). When we visited, they were doing work on a few of the towers so there was some scaffolding up but did it not bother us.

Must see. Very grand and majestic, a little busy with tourists, but a must see. If you take the river boat you can make several stops and see Temple of Dawn and the grand place in a short time period.

4 towers temple. The main tower, 80 m high, very rich covered withpieces of painted or coated porcelain, has two levels terraces ( not easy to reach) with an amaising view over the river Chaopraia and the city of Bangkok

A must visit site. this temple is situated on the opposite bank to the royal palace and is just a short boat trip over the river. The climb to the top is quite steep so not for everyone, but once there the views are fantastic.

Don't climb if you have a fear of heights. Many tourists have climbed up the steps because it looked managable but do not do this if u have a fear of heights. You'll end up having to sit and shift your bum one step downwards at a time . Other tourists might take your picture then and post it online with some ridiculous tag .

Beautiful even in the day. The place is immense and one of the most-visited Buddhist sites in Bangkok. Expect the crowds.We toured the site for a little over an hour. Be prepared to remove your shoes to enter the Temple and to be prevented to enter the Temple if you are inappropriately dressed. Dress modestly (women in long pants or a skirt below the knee, no tank tops or shorts). In other words, be respectful of a sacred place or a place sacred to other people! Minimum length of time to tour: one hour, though it's best to spent a bit more time there as the grounds are immense. If you cannot get there to see it, try to be across the river from Wat Arun at dusk because the sun setting turns it into gold and is a picture worth capturing or seeing.Be prepared for the crowds!

Beautiful temple. It's a pity we only saw it from the other side of Chao Praya River, we did not have time in 3 days to go there as well, you had to cross the river and that meant some time for us, bur=t we admired it from the bar across the Chao Praya and at sunset it is just mesmerizing! great for taking some nice photos and getting lost in BKK athmosphere!

Beautiful temple. We booked a boat tour and Wat Arun was the destination stop. The temple itself is beautiful. The monk at the temple tied a blessed cotton wristband and we paid a small donation to the temple. Finally, we climbed the temple stairs, quite steep but do-able. Amazing views from the top! A must see!

My favorite tourist attraction in Thailand. I am in Thailand once or twice per year and have been to Wat Arun at least once every trip for the past 10 years or so. The fact that tourists are allowed to climb around on it makes it very accessible and I keep going back to experience its splendor. I enjoy the riverside setting and the view from the uppermost level.The way up/down is steep and so climbing up is something of an endeavor. However even if you can't get up it, there's much to admire even at ground level. The carvings and statuary from Buddhist and Hindu mythology and the overall craftsmanship are wonderful to behold up close and personal.

A head for heights. If you have a head for heights then the views from the Temple of Dawn are amazing. Great care needs to be taken and it's crowded.A short ride across the river will bring you to Wat Arun (the best views are from the other side or on the river) the temple is dedicated to the Hindu God ,Aruna.It's 17th century with the spires being built in the 19th century during the reign of King Rama II.The beautiful porcelain tiles glimmer in the sunshine ,though the most striking image is at night.The Temple of Dawn is one of the main attractions in Bangkok and is an important place of worship for Buddists .Go early to avoid the crowds.
Impressive!. This temple is one of a kind where tourists are allowed to go up. Once up, the views are breathtaking! We enjoyed every moment visiting Wat Arun.

Fallen into disrepair and covered in scaffolding.. Before visiting and with Bangkok temple experience, I couldn't understand how anyone could give a holy temple a bad Tripadvisor review... And then we visited Wat Arun. Paid to get in but as soon as we got there we could see it wasn't right. Out of the 5 buildings at the temple, 4 of them were covered head to toe in scaffolding and therefore you couldn't actually get to the interesting bits. The one staircase that was open was VERY steep and was not only used to go up and down but also for Chinese tourists to stop and take pictures on. Unfortunately I didn't feel safe. The temples itself looked good up close with plenty of Buddhas and gods dotted around. The monks roaming around looked happy and you can pay to pray too if you fancy it. Still worth a visit but nothing compared to the other Wats.
Um saw so many got mixed up. Queues size massive don't go if you don't like crowds, queues and heat. There are so many Temples, Wats and places of interest, we should've made better plans for visits.

Impressive up close. This is a building where you want to get up close to enjoy its grandness. You begin with a boat ride to cross the busy Chao Phraya river. The fun begin here. Watch the boat zig zag across busy shipping lane to cross the river. After that, climb the narrow and high stairs to reach Arun peak. It is difficult but well rewarded experience. You get a heck grand view of the Chao Phraya and if you happen to be there by evening, an amazing sunset that illuminate the nearby temple as well. Highly recommended.https://vinshengloh.exposure.co/wat-arun-bangkok
Missed it. i missed the night view of this temple. Really sad for that but ya its a must visit attraction in bangkok. Thums up

The Wat Arun to Bangkok - is like the Eiffeltower to Paris. The Wat Arun is one of these Icons you have to visit or at least have looked at @ sunset.To climb it is rather steep, but do-able.There are some good venues at the other side of the river from where you can have a great view,while sipping on a cold drink, like Arun Residences-The Deck and Sala RattanakosinEnjoy this beautiful landmark

Currently under renovations - a bit disappointing.. While this temple looks entirely spectacular in photography, it's currently under renovation which means multiple towers are covered up with unattractive scaffolds. Drift by on the water taxi but don't make a special trip (especially to watch the sunrise at 0630).

Pretty.... After an entire day of Wats, this was our last temple and it was worth it. We had to take the short boat ride to cross the river. The climb to the top was fun and the view were amazing as the sun was setting. We were able to get blessed by a buddha with a small donation and it was very memorable. Again, make sure to wear appropriate attire, bathroom facilities were available for a small fee and enjoy this site.

Half the fun is in getting here!. What fun to take a passenger ferry and then arrive a couple minutes later at Wat Arun. We did not take the steps up to the top, but that would be an option. So, stroll around and enjoy the view.

Beautiful views. The best way to reach the temple is the foot passenger ferry which leaves from a little pier next to the Grand Palace. Apart from the main temple building the area has some nice court yards with gardens and chinese statuary. Wat Arun offers exceptional views across the river and into the temple compound when you climb up to the viewing platform. The stairs are rather narrow and steep and whilst not difficult to climb, some people felt scared going down though, so it's worth thinking about the descent!

Climb the steep steps for an ace view of the city. We took the river boat across to Wat Arun, its only 3 baht each and takes about 2 minutes.
