Wat Arun is another amazing temple in Bangkok but this one has the added bonus of being able to climb high up to the top and see across to the city of Bangkok. The skyscrapers mixing with the golden temples and stupas. The steps are mega steep and a bit scary when you descend but the views are worth it! There is currently renovation work going on but it did not take away from a brilliant couple of hours.

Nice to look at, but that`s enough. After visiting Wat Phra Kaeo and Wat Pho I must say I was rather dissapointed by this temple. When drifting by on a boat, it looks really nice, but up close, there`s not much about it. At the moment (I stayed there in the beginning of February) the smaller Pagodas are all beeing renovated, which is definitely a good thing as practically all the ornaments have started to mould away - but not so nice to look at. In the middle of the Wat stands the biggest Pagoda, which you can climb if you`re fit and not afraid of height. It`s nice up there to look at Wat Po and the River, but for me this sight definitely wasn`t worth the climb. The steps are murderously steep at some points - I`m 28 and quite fit, but getting down that thing wasn`t really easy. So defininitely no sight for kids or older people! If you have to skip one of the three "must do"-Wats in Bangkok, it`s definitely Wat Arun!

Get your camera ready!. It is a jewel by the river! The stairs look daunting and they are, but well worth the climb, the view is magnificent and you get to be in a beautiful structure, a future wonder of the world!

Stairs were closed today. Wat Arun is one of my favorite places to visit in Bangkok because of its beautiful and peaceful gardens, and the spectacular view of the city and river after a walk up the stairs. I want to alert everyone that the stairs were closed today. You can still pay 50bht to enter the temple area. The painstaking progress that is being taken to restore the smaller prang is impressive. However, I was disappointed by the carnival-like atmosphere outside of the temple. People dressing up in costumes for pictures seems disrespectful in religious setting.

Amazing. This is one of the best places to go and visit. Its beautiful and has rich history attached to it. If you go by evenings, it will look even more beautiful. Don't forget to drink coconut water out there.
Crowded!. Very crowded, but also beautiful temple. You can go up the stairs, but it`s kind of dangerous. Totally worth trying.

different then Wat Po, but in a good way.. I've visited Wat Arun straight after the Wat Po.Wat Arun is not one of the big temple propertys with lots of small temples and statues.It is not that good looking attraction with all the detailed design and gold etc.But it is at least the same good experience.The stairs to get "on top" of the viewing plattform are a challenge but quiet fun as well.It is a bit dangerous if you are not that tall and not that sporty.But you will get a breathtaking view over the sourrounding area. The temple is just beside the river located. On my next visit here in a couple of weeks I'm gonna visit this sight at night time.I guess that will be worth more for taking nice photos.As i said it is not that beautiful then the other temples but you can see the history of this in every stone it build!I would say better then the Wat Po. It is not that big and not that exhausting to watch that many on details.

Good view from the top. You can take a shuttle boat to reach here from Wat Pho. Word of caution: The steps here are really steep.. You won't notice it on your way up, but it's really scary coming down!
very good. This requires you to catch a ferry across the river. Very steep climbs up steps are involved so if you have a fear of heights stay on the ground but we'll worth the visit.

Fantastic Views. We needed to take a ferry over to Wat Arun, it only cost 15 Baht. There was some construction going on. The steps up to the top were quite steep, but well worth the effort. The view of the city was great. We stayed up on top for quite a long time because it was so interesting to observe the city. The first few steps coming down were hard because the steps are far apart. Well worth the visit!

Beautiful, but frightening.. As somebody slightly scared of heights, I should've known what I was getting myself into. Climbing up the steep steps was hard, but climbing down them even more daunting. But nevertheless, the view from the top of the temple and the architecture was breathtaking. A true reflection of this amazing city.

Wished we visited it another time. The restoration works around the place kind of hampers the fun but still I would say it was a different experience. We reached the place through the ferry and the whole ride itself was fun and then the view is amazing as well. The steps are pretty tricky with being narrow and small. Plus the climb is half the effort, its descending which takes the life out. Wished we had visited it a different time.

Stunning view at night, rich in history, not much english. Wat Arun is just opposite the river from Wat Pho, which is located on the Bangkok side. War Arun is one of Bangkok's oldest temples, having been built before the Rattanakosin Era (The era of Thailand's Rama Kings). The temple and the surrounding area itself has undergone reconstruction quite a few times since it had been built, and was once the royal temple to the former King of Thailand. The temple draws influences from both Hinduism and Buddhism, while the surrounding area is slightly influenced by China. The Chinese statues present were said to have been used to balance boats that were coming in from China to trade, as the Chao Phraya river was once an extremely important trade route in Thailand's history. The temple itself is beautiful and was built upon the idea of Buddhism cosmology, a difficult concept to understand, but simply shows a hierarchy in life/death amongst different beings. It also depicts the buddhism/hindu belief in reincarnation. The downside to Wat Arun is that there is very little English, let alone signs to help guide you through the rich history of the place. There are absolutely no guides and as a visiting Thai, I would have had a lot of trouble if I had not previously done my research. I would expect foreigners to be able to appreciate the architecture of the temple but possibly not learn much of its history and significance at the site itself. What Arun has recently been very famous as a viewpoint/destination of sightseeing, but from across the river. At night, there are many restaurants (such as "The Deck") and hotels across the river on the Bangkok side which offer you amazing view of a beautifully lit up temple at night, the only one I've seen of its kind. To get To Wat Arun, it would be wise to take the cheap ferry close to Wat Pho, across the river form the Bangkok side. Taking a taxi across the river and trying to enter may take long and lead to other problems as well as it not being easy to enter from the road. All in all, Wat Arun is significant of life in the early Rattanakosin Era, being on the river, and is also the reason for King Taksin to move the capital from ancient Ayuthaya to Thonburi after war with the Burmese.

A Beautiful Building. We saw this building at night (2006) and during the day February 2015. It is definitely more beautiful at night. During the day, we saw it during our river tour. Next time, we will have to go up the stairs and see it up close.

Because of current renovation, give it a pass if you have limited time.. The entire temple is shrouded in scaffolding, so you can't really appreciate the porcelain clad exterior for which it is famous. For the present, I suggest you spend more time across the river at Wat Pho and appreciate Wat Arun at night when it still looks lovely from the river.
Ehh. This temple though huge and magnificent is currently surrounded by scaffolding. Not really oportunistic for views and photo ops. Still should visit nonetheless.

Beautiful. You can get small boat for just 3 baht and cross the river and walk a little or take boat for 15 baht and it bring you just in front of the temple. They have some renovation but this will not make this temple less beautiful and special.Stairs are little scary but nothing special. Definitely go upstairs because view is stunning.Entrance fee is 50 baht at this moment.
Magnificent view at night. We only got to see it on the river cruise and didn't go in person, but that actually provided a better photo opportunity.

Most beautiful and gorgeous art. Try to go opposite side to the temple in the evening or at night and check out bar / restaurant there ... It is very stunning looking back and see Arun Pagoda with the light on and yet its reflection over the river...
Good temple. Good temple...just OK for onetime visit, went with family...temple outside work is in construction modfication phase so couldn't see everything.

Under construction but still a great site to visit. Although renovations are underway to refresh the outside spire structures that involves erecting scaffolding around them, this is still one of Bangkok's most picturesque and identifiable temples. The main chapel that contains a large Buddha image is stunning. We then climbed the 82 meter high Khmer-stile spire (steps are very steep, so be careful) that is well worth the effort. Excellent place to take pictures and enjoy the scenery of the city. Recommend walking the neighborhood either before or after since it contains a lot of great places to visit and sites to see. Given the fact three of the four smaller outer spires have been renovated, its only time until the main one that you can climb will be closed down for renovations. I would expect this will happen within the next year.

interesting ascent. Its an interesting temple with a super steep climb up. My first Thai temple so I've got no frame of reference however I really enjoyed it and found it very peaceful. Take the water taxi over from the central pier which you can reach by the mono-rail/sky-trek

Under remodeling!. No one told us it was being remodeled until we got there and saw that we couldn't enter the temple or climb it at all. All you can do it walk around the grounds (which are very pretty and have other small temples), but I was disappointed because I wanted to see the view from up there.

Gorgeous temple with a great view. Wat Arun is charming from the get go - right from getting there by ferry to climbing its steep, steep almost vertical stairs to get a great view of Old Bangkok. Around sunset, you can get a beautiful view of the city and a good look at the Grand Palace. There was a fair bit of renovation and maintenance going on when we visited, but that didn't mess with the atmosphere or experience.

Thrilling but treacherous. We visited The Grand Palace and then took a boat across the river to Wat Arun. Although it didn't drop us off right at the temple we enjoyed walking through some of the residential neighbourhoods to get there. We were very surprised that you are able to walk right up to the temple with no entrance fee or guard at the gate. The design of the temple is very intricate but be warned the stairs are very steep once you get to the top! There are hand rails but once you are at the top it's so steep you have to climb back down backwards. Well worth the visit but if you have a fear of heights you might just observe from below.

Temple of Dawn. Nice temple to visit, easy to get to by boot, take care when you climb up and down the very steep and small steps, going up is more easy then going down, when I visit the site was under restoration, but still worth a visit.

Under construction!. We were very disappointed with this visit! So much of it was surrounded by scaffolding we could not get 1 picture without it getting in the way.The best part was getting the riverboat ferry across the river to see it. Until it is finished I would be content just to view it from afar!As a little aside look out for the large cockroaches in the toilets! My screams were a source of amusement for many waiting outside!
Great site to visit. Quite an experience even that the site was under restoration. Steep stairs, crowded, but woth to visit. A great mankind achievement.
Under refurbishment . Great spot to visit across the river from the bigger and more crowded grand. Just an fyi that it's in refurbishment right now. But still worth the visit.

Beautiful temple; steep stair climb. This is a great little temple with tons of detail. Unfortunately, portions were covered with scaffolding for repairs when we went. Be warned that if you wish to climb up the stairs are steep and will strain your legs.

under wraps--wait a year or two. They charge foreigners entry but not locals. Didn't like that. Ok, and then so much of the temple is under scaffolding. Better to enjoy the view of Wat Arun from across the river.

Currently having exterior Restoration. The temple is very unique looking but is currently undergoing painstaking exterior restorations so only the grounds around it are open and you can't go on or in the temple. A lot of scaffolding about and has more of a construction site feel than anything else. I think the admission has been reduced because of this but was a bit disappointing.

A must. Going over the river with the small ferry boat makes it even more interesting and gives already a good view on Wat Arun. The decoration with all the porcelaine parts is very special. Fit persons have to climb up the steep stairs to get the great view on the surroundings.

Stunning. War Arun is across the river from the Grand Palace. It consists of a Central Monument and is surrounded by Minor Prangs (towers) all of which are beautifully decorated with mosaic tiles and are really colourful and have statues and carvings which are very ornate. The Wat is currently under renovation but this doesn't detract from how stunning it isYou can climb steep steps up the Prangs to get a really good view of Bangkok's riverside and roof of Grand Palace. The steps are really steep so you need pretty good mobility to get up and down them but well worth it for the view.The Wat is also surrounded by nice gardens and statues of Chinese guards. The Wat is lit up at nice which is best seen from across the river.

Temple of the Dawn to be viewed anytime :-). The temple is opposite the Grand Palace and round the corner a little bit from Wat Pho. Don't take a Tuk Tuk from either, but walk through to the river where there is a local ferry that goes back and to over the river for around 3Thb each way per person. There is a lovely little eating place hanging over the river there too. When you get off the ferry it's to your left, but you shouldn't miss it !! There are a lot of Thai Navy personnel around as the naval College is to the right. It's cheap to go in - about 50Thb and you can clamber as high as you dare up the temple. It's not easy and not for the faint hearted ! More on the way down than up. Great views over to the Grand Palace once at the top - and my 71 year old Mum made it to the top whilst my Dad sat at the bottom. The detail in the walls is amazing and no doubt tells a story. I love the guards too. This is on of the Temple's i never tire of at all and i think i've been to it on every journey. (I pretty much go 2 x a year).

Fantastic Wat. A very beautiful wat with great views of the Chao Phraya as you climb up higher. Thousands of porcelain pieces embedded into the towers sparkle in the sun and the photo opportunities are endless. Take the river boat to Tha Thien pier (N8) then straight on to the cross-river ferry (3 baht). Watch out for the art installations on the ferry! The river boat costs 15 baht, payable on the boat. The all day boat price is 150 baht so it's probably worth buying individual tickets for each trip. The view as you travel back along the river, as dusk is falling and the lights appear on the river boats, is amazing.

Be aware of the steps if you want to go up!. The remarkable Wat Arun looks even more beautiful at night when it is illuminated. The towers or prangs, how they are called, (main and 4 smaller) are decorated with Chinese porcelain and coloured glass. Along the base of the main tower there are statues of Chinese soldiers and animals. There we were told that the central tower represents Mount Meru, the home of the Gods, and the 4 smaller towers are the 4 winds. On each of the smaller ones there is a statue of Pai, the God of winds, on his horse. At the base of the main tower, between each two small towers, there are images of Buddha showing the stages of his life - birth, meditation, preaching and enlightenment. In the ordination hall there is a golden image of Buddha and interesting murals.The stairs to the next levels are very steep and if the climbing up is difficult, the going down is really scary. After the exhausting climbing you can relax in the gardens surrounding the temple and you can see some other smaller structures. On the way out of the complex you will have to pass through a small market with souvenir stalls which is not the cheapest you can find in Bangkok!We went to Wat Arun after visiting Wat Pho on the other bank of Chao Phraya River. Then we walked some 300 meters to Tha Tien Pier and took the cross-river boat to Wat Arun (the boat is only 3 baht per person!).The fee is 50 baht and it is open daily from 8 AM till 5:30 PM.

Beautiful view from the top. A beautiful temple, I did not award the last star as it is currently being reconstructed. But you can still access the temple and climb up (Feb 2015). It is a great to view the river and other temples on the opposite bank from the top!
Beautiful view. Be there in the evening before the sunset. Very steep staircase, ladies are advised to wear pants.Nearby is the Wat Pho, don't miss it out.

Look at them with Thai traditional point of view. Look at them with Thai traditional point of view It may be called "oriental charm" Don't put everything in western eye and standard. It will looses all the folkways.

Unusual ceramic decorations. Much of this Wat is under scaffolding for renovations at this time, but it is worth the visit to see the design, which uses broken ceramic pieces (used as ballast in ships coming from China). Steep steps lead up several levels for those who do not mind the climb. The dress code is enforced: no shorts, bare shoulders, sleeveless tops. (Clothing is available for those who arrive underdressed.) Take a few minutes to watch the painstaking renovation technique.
Very interesting. The temple was very beautiful indeed. Definitely should visit if you are in Bangkok. The night view is even better for photos.
Loved it. Not too busy and very interesting. Was there with a guide (Jamming Thailand), who explained every detail.

Worth a visit!. We enjoyed our visit- steps were very manageable- the railings helped for sure going up to the top level. I would suggest a walking pole if you are uncomfortable with deep stairs, especially going down. Great views from the top level. Although some parts were under repair, this did not take away from the main temple. Nice breeze on some sides as well- helped in the heat. I would suggest a morning visit if you want to climb the stairs to avoid the afternoon heat. Take your own toilet tissue for the washrooms.
Beautiful at sunset or sunrise. Must see when in Bangkok. CLimb the temple and take great picture of the surroundings and river area.
Different temple, interesting. It has very steep stairs and nice architecture. Definetely worth a visit if you are in Bangkok even if you're not that interested in temples in general.

Lovely but under restoration at the moment. When you go to Wat Arun, be aware that the little market in front of it is one of the most expensive in Bangkok. Also you need to wear long pants and shirts!!! They do not have anything to give you to cover yourself up, like the do in the Grand Palace.

Go!. Although I didn't climb the narrow steps, I walked all around and gazed in awe at the detail, the artistry, the colors, the brave souls climbing. Was told to see it at sunset from Bar Amorosa. Could not, but maybe you can!

Temple. Very interesting place. The structural aspects of the temple are different and unique. If you're afraid of heights don't climb to the top as the steps are very steep and the spacing between the steps is larger than other places. I would go again.

Steep Steps. This temple's stairs are steep & the steps are higher than normal but I felt that was the fun part about it. Some people were a bit afraid to come down but just hold onto the railing & you'll be fine. Some things were cheaper to buy from the vendors here instead of on the mainland.

Be prepared to walk very very steep stairs. There are the steepest stairs that you will climb :) There is great view from the top. Easily accessible by boat - that is the best transport, boat and walking :) No tuk tuk's drivers that overcharge and lie in your face telling you that something is closed and will open later, but now you can go there and there and it's free. It's all rubbish.
Well worth the visit.... Very historical temple in the heart of Bangkok... Can access by river which is an enjoyable excursion as well....

good place to take photos; otherwise, just OK.. maybe EXPECTATIONS too high for WAT ARUN. after all, it was #1 trip advisors places to VISIT in BANGKOK. took lots of PHOTOS. stairs dangerous. the first flight steep to 2nd level, but ok due to width of stairs. the 2nd flight WOW, even steeper and stairs narrow. had to put my foot sideways on each step and hold railing with both hands. if you over 60, don't go. find hotel bar or restaurant across the river at sundown and see the temple lit up at night. ***please note*** renovation being done to temple. so you'll get some scaffolding in some photos.
Fun to walk up and down the steep stairs. We took the ferry from the other side and walked up the steep stairs to the second level. Givrs a nice view and it is even nicer to walk down those stairs.

Beautiful view but you need good legs to climb up.. Mooring platform is a bit shaky to desembark from long tail boats, the temple is beatiful but it was in a good part covered for maintenance works. It did not impress me too much when i compare it to many others in Thailand.

Go some time before sunset. Wat Arun is a relatively small temple, but definitely a must see. The view of the river from the top of the temple is beautiful and a good spot for pictures.As other people have commented, the stairs are pretty steep, so you must be careful when going up and down. TIP: Use the boat to cross the canal. The boat is just 3 baht one-way and takes about one minute. The pier is in front of Wat Pho (where the Reclining Buddha is) near a very small street food that leads to the boat.
Will have to cross Chao Phraya. Enjoyed crossing the river most! Nothing much to see once inside, but it's a good introduction to the many temples of Bangkok.

Looking nice from far. For me it is not "must enter" attraction. Actually it looks better wen you are a bit far. It does not worth paying the entrance fee. If short of time can skip it and view it from the boat or from the other bank of the river before heading to Wat Pho.

Waited a long time and worth the wait. I had waited a fair amount of time before I got to actually get to this most revered of the Bangkok temples.The tile work and statues are marvellous and I would go again to get more photos for my long term memories of this temple.

Breathtaking at sunset!. A breathtaking temple, especially viewed at sunset from the Sala Boutique Hotel opposite. Sit at the rooftop bar of the hotel sipping a Thai cocktail whilst viewing this amazing temple. A must see while in Bangkok!

One of the most interesting religious sites in Bangkok. This statue of a Buddha image laying on its side is intended to represent: peacefulness, tranquil positive thoughts and happiness in a general sense. Even if your religion is not Buddhism this statue cannot but help you to actually feel 'relaxed' IF and I say again IF, you are willing and interested to do so! I am a European and have often visited this shrine for the aforementioned reasons - Please give it a try
Pagoda with Hindus Influence. Pagoda with ceramic covering as influence from Chinese architecture. But the pagoda form itself is from Hindu style.

Best temple in Bangkok. This is a great temple for the whole family. The ferry across the river costs just 3 baht and is a fun way to start your adventure. The Wat is beautifully maintained and has lots of opportunities for taking great photos. You can climb to the top and have great views of the river and the city. And when you have exhausted and exhilarated yourselves with the climb, buy food, drinks and souvenirs at the bottom. This is one place that I have never been hassled to buy things.

This temple is a MUST SEE. The temple of dawn is one of the most beautiful landmarks on the river - I am not if the restoration work is completed.. It is BEATIFUL by day and spectacular by night if you go on a boat.

Beautiful Wat. One of the more stunning wats in Bangkok, and very different to many of the others, this place is a breath of fresh air. Actually going across the river to see it only costs 3 baht on the boat each way, and 50 baht entrance fee so it's quite cheap. However it's was very busy, and he steps up to the top are a bit of a climbing lesson - very steep! Instead of going to the temple and risking the steps I would recommend seeing this temple from across the river in darkness. Specifically there is a tiny thai restaurant just above the boat dock which has great views and good food!

panoramic view. Worth a visit, it's one of Bangkok landmark. You can climb up the pagoda but not recommended for elderly or knees problem. Stairs are steep and between steps are very tall without handrails. But you will see panoramic view of Chaopraya river.

Beautiful but difficult to climb. This was definitely a gorgous place, and the major selling point was climbing up and checking out the amazing view- but the stairs to climb were incredibly steep. We went in the afternoon when the crowds were relatively light but the heat was intense so the climb up was even more exhausting. There were several older people unable to make the climb or the way back down, so unless you are stable on your feet you may want to stay on the ground.
awesome river view at sunset. awesome river view at sunsetif u did not clime to top of this temple, u don't know this opinion. must be top of the highest place for best view here.

Pick your times to visit. I saw the temple at night as I heard it was impressive light up, and it is. Though this means you can't enter or climb to the top for the view. You can still get right up close at night and it makes for some really good photos with all the lights on.

Must See . This place is a must See in Bangkok. This Temple is located on other side on River bank of Royal Palace. You can get there by ferry. After you climb very steep steps you get to see astonishing view of Bangkok.
One of the better temples to visit. It is not as crowded as the Grand Palace and you should try to climb the temple for its great view over Bangkok (not for those afraid of heights!)

Climb your way up to an awesome view.. This temple is a must see if you are in Bangkok. Its beautiful from a distance, up close, and from the top where you can see the river and the city from above. Climbing the steep stairs is quite a thrill both on the way up and on the way down so just hold on tight to the bannister and take your time. The effort is worth the experience and the view.
Beautiful surroundings. A very interesting temple but the stairs are quite steep. If ŷou can make it to the top the architecture and views are lovely

It's a place you must visit at least once. You are encouraged not to wear short shorts or clothes that are too revealing. If you are planning to climb the temple, please hold on to the railings as the steps are quite steep.

Good view from the temple. We came down to Wat Arun by cross river ferry from Wat Pho temple. There is an entrance ticket of 50 Baht. We need to climb the steep steps in this temple to reach on top.The views of bangkok / Chao phraya river is really great from the top. We just spent 20 mins on this attraction, which we feel was more than enough. You can enjoy the temple view from the boat in the evening, when it is fully lit and looks amazing.PS: Climbing steps should be avoided by acrophobic people. As once you reach the top and start looking down you will get the dizziness.

Beautiful Temple, Peaceful Grounds. Wat Arun sits on the river bank in a lovely location. It is so beautiful here. Vendors do not pester you to buy. They are there and if you want to look at their wares it is fine, they will sell you whatever they have but they don't get "in your face".... I found this to be the most peaceful temple in Bangkok.

Steep stairs!. We came here after the Grand Palace and Wat Pho on the other side of the river. It was quite late in the afternoon so not too busy, which was great as the steps were so steep that a crowd would have made me nervous descending them! Fear of heights aside, it is a beautiful temple and watching the sun set from the upper level was wonderful.

Great temple & great views. We got the boat to cross the river, which was very cheap and provided some good views.The temple looks astonishing and was well worth a look around and the couple of minutes climbing the steps.Once at the top the views out of the city were quite impressive. We boat back was nice too as the sunset provided for more pictures.

Less tourists. I came down to Wat Arun by boat (15 tbh from Saphan Taksin + 3 tbh to cross by ferry). The river trip is not amazing but it's certaily more interesting and less stressing than coming by taxi. I found this temples here to be smaller and less impressive in size but much more local and interesting than the other famous sights. I saw monks, people praying and meditating and plus you got to have less tourists to "compete" with while walking around. Entrance fee to part of the place is 50 tbh but there is a lot of temples you get in for free in the same area. It's worth to take a look.

Worth a visit.. The views of Bangkok were really good and the temple itself is certainly worth seeing for the architecture and decoration that has gone into it. Unfortunately, when we were there, there was a lot of construction happening around it which took away the sparkle and delight slightly. But, it is still worth it. One word of warning, do your stretches before you climb those steps, seriously! Because by golly, they are so steep that they don't half make your legs ache!

Go there late in the afternoon.. We arrived there in late afternoon via land after taking a long walk opposite the royal palace in a popular borough. You will thus enjoy the part of the monastery that is living its ordinary life with plenty of locals snd monks will be happy to show you some of the best parts of Wat Arun.

Don't want to go back. This temple is good place to visit but I don't want to go back - going up to the temple was easy but going back I felt dizzy. There's a guy who really felt dizzy and his friends was holding him as they go down. But the view up there was so amazing!
Stunning Architecture. If there is only one pic you need in your instagram account , this will be the place !!! Try visiting there in the evening and have your dinner across the temple
Impressive temple. What a great legacy - we where deeply impressed about Wat Arun. The staircases will stay in our memory forever!

The most beautiful temple in Bangkok. I have to say Wat Arun is the most beautiful temple in Bangkok with it unique structure and architectural compares to other temple in Bangkok. The climbing can be quite challenging for senior citizens or someone with knees problem, but I am sure most of the ruins like Angkor Wat is having very steep and high stairs. The best time to visit the temple is late afternoon when it is not so hot, take a boat cross to opposite side of the river to have a beautiful sunset view of Wat Arun.
Fantastic and beautiful temple. This is a great temple to see. You see it from the river and it is impressive. It is equally impressive inside. Another must see in Bangkok.
Wat Arun. Nice temple with a good view. Don't take the tourist boat but the river taxi which the local population use. It is easy, cheap and the people very helpfull.

Its a long way down. We took a river taxi then a ferry to get here. You are able to climb up one of the buildings, but I wouldn't recommend it if you don't like heights - the steps are very steep and seem even worse coming down, If you do climb, the view is worth it.

Truly amazing. Well worth climbing to the top
My eight yr old daughter did it so not too tough.
Please remember to dress appropriately, as it is a Buddhist temple.
Love the boat ride in, and not too full of tourists
Very high and very steep!. Beautiful temple, very steep steps going right to the top though! Just a shame that a lot of the smaller temples were being worked on, will be beautiful when it's done!
Too hot. It was around 1 or 2 pm when I went and it was way too hot. This is coming from a woman born in the Caribbean.

It's great, just go see it. Definitely need to check this out when visiting Bangkok. Suggest starting your day here and after taking a river boat across to the other side to check out the other big temples and Buddhas in the area.

Temple undergoing repairs. Unfortunately, lots of scaffolding around the temple ruined photos. We did not enter the temple as we thought the fee (about $15 US) was excessive and we were not in the mood for climbing a steep stairway. But worth a cross-river ferry visit.
A larger site than we realised. There is unfortunately quite a lot of restoration going on at the moment, but it is still very beautiful and these is quite a lot to see.

Awe Inspiring Buddhist Temple. This was the first temple we visited on our visit to southeast Asia and it established a standard for all religious sites to follow. The temple architecture and carvings are magnificent and novel for a westerner. Bring someone knowledgable in Buddhism so that you can appreciate the symbolism and meaning of all around you.

Watch those steep steps. Arrive by ferry boat, dress to visit a sacred place Shoulders and knees covered (or hire it in the grounds)It is interesting to look at, and fascinating to watch the restoration work - see the before and after.If you plan to climb it, the steps are very very steep with intermittent hand rails.Coming down was much harder than going up. Nice clean western toilets by the souvenir stalls at the back.Worth going to

Check out Arun rooftop bar across Wat Arun. Arun residences roof top bar was a great sunset chillout. it is about 4 blocks down the road after getting off the ferry at the pier, turn right. The restaurant on the ground floor was also packed and reservations is mandatory as we couldn't get a table.

Beautiful building. It's definitely a stunning temple. I was there in the evening and stayed until the night time. You must ride on the river cruise in the evening so that you are able to enjoy the view.

Great attraction. Not for people with mobility issues due to the steep steps up the temple. At 50 baht it was well worth the money and the views from the top are excellent. It's across the river from the grand palace and wat po. A 5 minute crossing that costs 3 baht.

Magnificient temple, with a lot to see. Easily one of the best landmarks in Bangkok, consist of many towers, which are beautifuly decorated. Walking up the tower does not require too much effort. The temple is best viewed across the river at Wat Pho, which can be reached by ferry.
Stunning. we saw the TEMPLE OF DAWN by river cruise.Our tour company had arranged a dinner cruise on the river, and the views of the temple were fantastic.It is a must see.
Beautiful!. You have to take a ferry across to Wat Arun but it's worth the little extra journey. A must see.... just make sure you are dressed modestly (long trousers and shoulders covered).
Must see. They gave us a jacket to cover our shoulders so that we could see everything. We used a guide which was well worth the money. Beutiful

Excellent Architecture!. I didn't see the temple at dusk but the intricate carvings are excellent. It is being refiurbished at present and therefore there is a lot of scaffolding and workers. The temple itself is very steep to climb. The first level is about 40% up and the next step is about 70%. Interestingly this is not something you can go into. The surrounding is beautifully landscaped and in the background you can see the river taxis and ferries ply their trade.Worth a visit but I think the crowds ruins the purpose of a temple on reliefs grounds.

Iconic image of Bangkok. Beautiful temple on the river in Bangkok. Presently under renovations but still worth your time. A lot of stairs but nice views from up there. Beautiful view from the river ferries as well.

Must visit temple in Bangkok. Very beautiful temple. It is currently under renovation (as of Jan 2015) so you may not be able to see everything in its full glory. Still, definitely a must visit site when you are in Bangkok

Incredible Detail. Went came across the River on the ferry which is only 3Baht, and takes you to the Reclining Buddha.The Temple of Dawn has incredible detail, we had not covered our Shoulders and knees therefore decided not to go in and climb up but even if you do not want to climb it's worth the visit. We saw it from a distance at Night, and it looks amazing lit up.Please click if helpful, Thanks.

Amazing detail. Really nice temple the amount of work that goes into this is just amazing. Lots of scaffolding around as they are renovating some of the pillars you still can see the detail even though this is happening. Definitely must see. We didn't go up the steps for fear of having to come back down they are not for the faint hearted.

No typical temple. Great views, high stairs (fun and little dangerous). Interesting and different from the other temples. Great for visiting with older children, for young those stairs can be dangerous. On january 2015 there were ongoing construction works so in some time temple will look like new.

very nice but too crowded...renovating !. besides in construction, renovation....full of tourists , quite chaotic, very steep and people climbing up with little babies...unbelievablei will come back later this year when hopefully it is not as crowded as a bazaarnice temple itself, just fantastic
A must place to visit if you in Bangkok. This is a must place to visit if you ever come to Bangkok. Transportation is through their long boats ie sampan. I think is only 50cents to cross over.

Beautiful architecture. It was a perfect afternoon when we went to see Wat Arun and climbed the top. If you're scared of heights do consider thinking twice before going up there, the stairs were pretty steep and uneven.going down for me was a challenge.The beauty of Wat Arun can be appreciated near and far.There were a lot of carvings/little statues/ figures that got my attention, look deep and you'll see how unique and beautiful it is.I might have to say that Im a bit disappointed that some of the pillars were "under reconstruction" it took the mysterious feel away.

Pretty. Take the ferry from Wat Pho over to Wat Arun. It costs 3 baht per person so you'll need small change. Ferry takes 5 minutes. Once you get to wat arun take a walk around along the river - it's pretty. Buy ticket (50 baht pp i think) and start climbing. Steps are massive and super steep, really feels like a hike up. Once at the top views are nice. Lovely temple. Make sure to visit at sunset.

Thailand 2015. Interesting. A lot of repair work going on especially on the main tower which still had public access but limited to certain areas. Stairs to access the higher levels of the tower are very steep and higher than normal step spacing proving to be very challenging if you have any physical or health issues

Under Renewal..... After seeing Wat Pho and the Imperial Palace, you should cross the river and see this massive temple. Wat Arun offers lots of things to see and to experience. The most interesting might be the fact that you can climb to the top of the temple and enjoy the views of the river and the rest of Bangkok.During this day, the temple is under massive reconstruction so its difficult to truly appreciate the entire place but still, if you are within the area, you should take the ferry boat and make the visit. The entrance fee is not that much and the complex has lots to offer. The best time to visit would be around sunset buts its gonna be crowded so, if you do go at that time, take a lot of patience with you.

Enjoyed but I didn't climb up!!. Was too scared to climb up but it was nice to walk around. We took the 3 baht bus across the river. Rediculously cheap! You need to cover up a bit to go to this temple, but maybe you'll do the Grand Palace same day anyway.

A Must See in Bangkok. Wat Arun (The Temple of Dawn) is a must see while in Bangkok. The whole temple is done in small ceramic tiles. It was dedicated to the 2nd reign of the Chakkri Dynasty. It is definitely on of the most elegant temples in Thailand. It is currently undergoing some touch ups of missing tiles,but it is amazing watch the artisans at work. Beware the steps here are narrow and very steep, but the view is worth the climb.

Easily accessible on public transport. We travelled by the public ferry to pier 8 & then took the boat across to the other side of the river. This boat was only 3THB per person each way, so great value. Wat Arun is very ornate & while we were visiting, there was some renovation work taking place next to the main building which meant that scaffolding was present.I'd read previous reviews advising on the steepness of the steps leading up Wat Arun, I wasn't prepared for the reality. I was, however, determined to go as far up as I could manage. The first set are not only steep but are also narrow in depth. As well as this, there are no handrails: I therefore just looked down & took one step at a time & it wasn't long before I was on the next level. If you want to go up further, the steps seemed the same as before in steepness & depth, however not very wide, which meant that people could be going up & coming down at the same time in a fairly tight space. These steps had a handrail either side. I decided to take a deep breath & go up to the next level. This I did, again taking one step at a time. I'm glad I did so for the views, but decided that I wouldn't go any further as I now had to get down! Again one step at a time with my head down. When it came to the last set of steps without a handrail, I found it helped to walk down at the sides rather than the middle, giving some reassurance should I need to hold on to something solid!As well as the main attraction, there are also other areas to explore as well as places to purchase food. There are rest rooms, however it would be advisable to take your own tissues!

Beautiful view. But nothing else. You don't have a clue why did the creators of the temple did this or that. Nothing. You just climb scary steep stairs and ... Pretty much that is it. You see the river and the city and everything fills you with joy. You get down and move on. As i said, not much to do. You can kill half an hour, not more.

very nice. never got around to it 3 years ago.. but was lovely shame they are doing loads of work on it and its covered with scaffold , beautiful place, climbing to 3rd terrance wow, felt sick when i looked down where i was going to have to come down.. was highmassive place, glad i went
Great Place !. This place is really great. Even you can find many new constuction on January but overall this place is great and you can study about Budha's temple.

A must see after visiting the Grand Palace. Wat Arun is amazing and was easily one of my favourites in Bangkok, this is definitely a sight that you should not overlook. A beautiful, unexpected Wat with a harrowing climb to the middle section. Can be done in an hour if short on time.

Must see! And climb if you dare.... Yes, this is one of the musts in BKK. If you are brave enough, climb it as the feeling on the top as well as going down is unforgettable. Easy to reach, plenty of tourists, but definitely something you don't want to miss while in BKK!

Energetic climb!. Was taken here by our tour guide and glad we did. Took a boat river crossing and to reach Wat Arun. If you are relatively fit then the steps is ok, although quite steep on the way down. Worth visiting whilst on the city tour.

Typical thai architecture. first time visitors should visit the temple. large temple compound and relax and see the architecture. i had already seen this on my last trip so this was a second time for me.

Awesome place. A very good place in Bangkok to visit which is near the river shore. We can reach there by using the ferry service which runs across the river. The main beauty is that the view of the river and other places from the top. And the scariest part is to climb the steep stairs. Wowww

In renovation. A short 3 baht boat ride from Wat Pho makes it a worthwhile visit, although the temple is in (much need) renovation and the scaffolds and works remove some of the majesty of the place.
The stairs are as steep as people say, and the view from the top is alright.

Must see ... especially at sunset. This temple is a must see in Bangkok. The temple is nice, good view from the top ... My advice is to be there at sunset ( around 6 - 6.30 p.m. ) on the other side of the river for a stunning view and great pictures.

Don't miss this. Climb the stairs! Easier than they look...take the canal boat across and then watch the sunset at one of several rooftop bars directy across- worth the $ ( for bangkok) cocktail price!

Wonderfull. Take the 3 bhat boat from Wat Pho and here we are.
So monumental. Looks great and way to the top and especially down may be a little hard for people in ages but it is worth it. Just take relax at different levels.
Nice view to the Bangkok from the top and nice temple territory.
Need to visit absolutely.
Steep but fantastic. Loved every single minute of this: it's a must do. I hired out a boat that took me all over the canals and this was a stopover- best by far. Go see it.

Visit to Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun). Beautiful Wat Arun, as you cross the river on the ferry you get this iconic view of the temple. The wonderful thing is that you can explore and climb up the temple getting a much better view of the intricate decoration and structure of Wat Arun and the surrounding site. (If you don't like heights or steep steps you may not want to attempt the climb - it is steep, handrails are limited, we had no issues with this at all it was a wonderful day out.)

Must visit in BKK. This is must see attraction. take a regular River "ferry" and visit this temple from riverside.If you can go early then this is the best time best to do this or enjoy the night lights. Climb to the top.

Easy to get to by cross-river ferry at N8 (Tha Tien) and really stunning up close.. From across the river, it's merely very impressive, but up close, it is stunning with it's intricate glass, ceramic, and mirror designs. And more prosaically, the souvenir shop on the far side has very good deals and especially nice merchandise, should you be looking for presents for others back home.

Very Impressive!. I was pretty overwhelmed when I walked in to Wat Arun and saw the surrounding structures. The design and architecture was simply stunning against a backdrop of a clear blue sky. It was a photographer's paradise. I walked around in awe and could easily have spent more time here.

Once up to the temple it was wonderful. We came on a very busy afternoon (Sunday, January 1) so I suspect my feeling would have been much better had we gotten here earlier and on a quieter day.That said, the temple is wonderful.The colors, the detail and the history make this a wonderful temple. The location, right on the river, adds to the charm.I have visited many larger temples in Thailand and enjoyed them all but this one had additional charm because I love a water setting.To be hear at dawn or sundown would likely be a better experience.

one of the older tample in the world. Wat Arun Ratchawararam Ratchawaramahawihan or Wat Arun is a Buddhist temple in Bangkok Yai district of Bangkok, Thailand, on the Thonburi west bank of the Chao Phraya River.

Interesting. Wat Arun is among the best known of Thailand's landmarks and the first light of the morning reflects off the surface of the temple with pearly iridescence.Although the temple had existed since at least the seventeenth century, its distinctive prang were built in the early nineteenth century during the reign of King Rama II.

A must see.. A beautiful temple, a must see if you go to Bangkok. Cruising on the river to get to the temple is a new experience.The fish in the river is massive. The fish near the river are not caught for religious reasons, it was nice feeding the fish too.Well worth a visit.
stunning. A visual delight for the senses, amazing to think these temples have been constructed by manual laborers so many centuries ago.

cool palace. enjoyed the palace and got a workout walking up its steep steps. mainly just the one building though, not much else to see there. took a ferry across the river to it for under 10baht (sorry forget actual price... 3 maybe?)

Amazing temple!. I loved this temple. It's currently under construction, but that actually made my visit cooler! It was neat to see the difference in the restored portions and those still undergoing work. Beautiful.
Best temple in Bangkok. Awesome temple, so quiet and so serene. Stunning. Great break from the mentalness of the rest of Bangkok!!

Great place !. The temple was awesome. You can see Bangkok from the temple. But the stairs was scary. It was too high for me to climb. Just have a great time there for a while. And little shopping just around the temple.

Amazing.. I had the chance to see it at the sunset, and it was even more wonderful. Even the way to get there is amazing: only by boat, and you can enjoy an amazing view of the temple and of the skyline.

no long skirt . very beautiful tower and amaing
please don't we A long skirt
when you climb second level of tower, it's really dangerous

Best temple for me. This famous temple is right along the river and is accessed by a very short river crossing costing 3bht. The Temple is under restoration so resembles a building site in places. The tiles are parts of porcelain from China and you can climb up it to a view point. The stairs are quite steep so be prepared for a climb. There is a nice market adjacent to the Temple with local goods. It closes at 17.30 but is lit up at night and quite stunning.

Beautiful architecture. Visited this temple on my last morning in Bangkok. The entrance fee was 50 baht per person. Shame that I did not stumble upon a tour guide like I did at Wat Pho. Basically, we were just wondering around the temple but it would've been nice to get to learn more about it i.e. the architecture, the history, etc. Nonetheless, I found the temple's architecture to be absolutely mesmerising. We climbed the temple steps which were quite steep but it was well worth the sweat. Additionally, men and women alike are able to dress up in Thai traditional wear which I rented for 100 baht and take photos. The only annoying thing was the sales people at the stalls who were very pushy for sales.

Probably worth the fee to go inside. We were hurrying so only saw this one from outside the gates. It is a little strange to see the souviner stands all around the place but people gotta feed their families

Easy Temple Visit. This famous temple is right along the river and easily visited by long-tail boat or as a part of a tour. The Temple is under restoration with one corner completed. The tiles are parts of porcelain from China and the statues quite entertaining. The stairs are quite steep so be prepared for a climb. There is a nice market adjacent to the Temple with local goods. If you take a night cruise on the river, the Temple will be lit up.

View point and ancient temple. This place is one of the best for me in Bangkok. Enter ticket is cheap. It's opend every day till 5:30 pm. There is amazing territory. There is no gold on this temple, and it's very beautiful. Only statues and pieces of porcelain ceramics were used for temple decoration.And you also could walk after visiting to watt Kayalamitr on foot and see not very turistic places. We seen New Arun Amarin road and walking there and used Pak Khlong Talat ferry for come back to other side of Chao Phraya river.

Have to go!. Wat Arun has become a favorite of mine. It is one of the older temples in Thailand but has a beautiful structure. The climb up the stairs is quite extreme as the stairs are steep but I would highly recommend this temple. It's beautiful, majestic and gives a great view of Bangkok.

Very nice.. The steps are steep, but the view is nice. This is a nice spot to check out at a decent price. If you get lost searching you can get a taxi ride since those are cheap too. That was my way of admitting that I got lost finding this at first. Pro-tip: Cross the river directly with the large boat that only costs about 2-3 baht. Cheap and doesn't take too long.

Gotta Climb. The Best part about Wat Arun is the decoration. Old pottery from sunken ships in the river was used to give the chedi/stuppa its tiled appearance and just makes it very unique and special. The other great things is climbing up to the top section and getting the views of the city and the Grand Palace complex. Be careful going down at the steps are narrow and tall,. I recommend walking down them backwards to keep your balance...
Must see!. Quiet and peaceful temple! And you may go up to the second top floor of the temple! Very scary stairs to walk up and more scary to walk down! Nice experience!
Restoration in progress. was beautiful at night but during the day the restoration scaffoling took charm away. decided not to go into the wat. riverside view was good enough

Definitely worth the climb. Wat Arun is by far one of the breathtaking temples in BKK. Yes, the steps up to the top is really steep but it is definitely worth the climb. You can get a view of the river from the view up there.

Different than the others. Wat Arun is on the other side of the river from downtown Bangkok. The ferry takes about 2 minutes and costs about 10 cents. You get a good view from the top.What makes this Wat unique is that it us entirely covered in pieces of dishes,tiles, and other porcelain pieces. You can climb up to the top, which is also unusual.Definitely worth the trip.

Best Wat in Bangkok!. You will worth for a stop at the What Arun.it is a WOW experience to climb up this temple.Not only for the fabulous view of the city but also for the carvings and decoration that this place offer.Must go!

Worth a Visit. If you choose train to reach this place, get down at Saphan taksin. You can catch a boat taxi which charges you 40 bath to take to Wat Arun. When you reach there cross over the river on another boat which will cost you 3 bath. Both boat rides is an amazing expereince and gives a good view of the Choa phraya river. The temple itslef is beautiful. Do climb the steps. There is a dress code, do google it before going. entry fee is 100 bath

Wonderful. If you go by boat this place gets very little time to visit, since they give only 20-30 minutes. The place is awesome, and needs more than a hour at least to do it justice. Also be ready to climb steep stairs.The carving is spectacular.The view after climbing is breathtaking,

be careful on steep steps. It IS a "wow" experience to climb up this temple. Be careful, the steps are indeed steep and narrow so you have to watch your steps and also the people at your side as well. You climb up and fabulous view is waiting for you. Not only the view of the city but also carvings and decoration of the temple are so elaborate and impressive. Too bad that some part are under construction and covered by blue sheet when we visited in Jan. 2015.After Wat Pho, we go across the river ( 3 TBH) and came here. The view of What Arun from the boat is another fine view.

Visit it by dawn. A wonderful site to understand about Buddhism and i was lucky enough to have a very friendly welcome of Thai friend who showed me where is the best place to photograph the temple. You should visit it for sure!
Wat Arun. Much smaller than Wat Pho and the Grand Palace but worth the 50bt fee. The views from the upper deck are fantastic however the climb back down is not for the faint hearted.

Worth the effort to climb up the tower!. Wat Arun is considered to be the most photographed temple in Bangkok and it lived up to its expectation. It is also featured on 10Baht coin. The main attraction is the high tower decorated beautifully decorated with tiny pieces of colored glass. It's worth the effort and the 50Baht entrance fee to climb the tower. Make sure you wear flat and comfortable footwear as the flights of steps are very steep (no worry, there are railings). View up there of Bangkok and the river is spectacular.To get there: - Take Chao Chraya Express Boat from Central Pier near Saphan Taksin BTS station, alight at N8 Tha Tieh Pier. -Take shuttle boat (3 Baht/pax) to across the river. Note the opening houes: 8:30am-5:30pm.

Iconic Place. Temple of Dawn is a Buddhist-temple and is among the best known of Thailand's landmarks a beautiful and iconic place. People says that first morning sunshine is on the top of the temple though I couldn't experience the same. But is a must visit place for temple and history lovers. After the temple visit, we had some light local street food/snacks in lunch which were good and hygienic.

Well Worth a Visit. This attraction can be easily combined with a trip to the Grand Palace.Tour the Grand Palace first and then head for pier number eight which is where you catch the ferry across the river to The Temple of Dawn, otherwise known as Wata Ran........cost of the ferry just 3 baht.Wata Run is a very interesting sight as there is in fact more to see than the actual site itself........in other words, walk away from the river to see typical Thai houses etc...Be prepared for the incredibly steep steps which are quite without risk if you take your time and whereas thie sight is not as impressive as the Grand Palace it is worth a visit and time should be taken to visit it.When accompanying the Grand Palace it does make a good day out

closing time a shame. wat arun is a beautiful temple and the fact that restoration work was being done to it this time took nothing away from the whole experience.. I still find it fun watching how worried people get trying to get down of the structure as the stairs are extremely old and steep. however the most beautiful view from the temple is in my opinion watching the sun go down .. however even though sunset is was at 18:15 they made everyone get out by 18:00 so as everyone is stood watching and has been getting there place to take some great photo's they are all then asked to leave... bit of a shame for the sake of 15 minutes.

" What a magnificent site ". This temple is marvellous to look at, and can be seen from a distance. The structure and craftsmanship is amazing, and you can climb halfway up the building. We combined this trip with a visit to the Reclining Buddah ( Wat Pho). It's s 5 minute boat ride on the opposite side of the river.
beautiful at night. go inside during the day to climb up the temple to see the city view. walk around the outside temple gates at night to see the temple lit up.

Fabulous!. Amazing architecture and decorations on the temple buildings! Scaffolding on some buildings doesn't detract from the overall beauty. A word of warning: stairs to viewing platform are quite steep, but there's a handrail. See this place -- you won't be disappointed!

Wat Arun. After visiting the Wat Pho I visited Wat Arun, which lies across the river from Wat Pho. You can reach the other side Tha Thien Pier by the public water ferries for 3-5 Baht. The stairs of the Wat Arun are long and narrow, but a fun challenge and the view from the top is definitely worth to climb up.nr. 1 tip I can give you, please be respectful towards the buddha statues, buddhists and monks and don’t wear much revealing clothes(ladies).

Beautiful Temple. The temple was a gem.Whoever visits MUST try to climb up the temple - just for the challenge and the beautiful view from both levels.Be careful to dress appropriately, as you may be denied entry if you are not.
Wow. Beautiful temple sight A must for temple loversOne of the icons around the world I've been here many times
excellent view from boat. very peaceful...spectacular view if u go via boat...dont take the road or u will really miss the spectacular view of the temple

wat arun ......under the sun. you have to go to wat arun, better not in the hottest hours (like me!),
the ticket is cheap (5o bath) in comparison to other monuments in Bkk and the experience is great.
Be brave and go to the top!
it is nice to have a walk all around the temple

thrilling. The water taxi over was fun. The fare was cheep. Bathroom was clean - Ladies, bring your own tp or buy it at left restroom entrance. The steps are steep & get steeper the futher you go up. Ladies! Wear proper shoes & clothes. It's worth the climb. Fear of height people may want to pass. Going down isn't the same as going up. For me, it was much harder going down. There's also another temple under construction a hop & a skip away that's worth a go. It's FREE. A monk blessed me for a small donation.

Best Attraction in Bangkok.. If you are only going to visit one temple while in Bangkok (which I HIGHLY recommend visiting as many as you can), then this is it. This is the granddaddy of them all. Absolutely astounding. Not for people with a fear of heights tho, and the elderly may have some issues climbing some of the steps as they are very steep. Beautifully manicured grounds with lots to see other than the main building. Don't miss this.

Spectacular Wat. This is such a beautiful wat which is currently being renovated. It is an amazing structure with a remarkable history and set in a beautiful location with easy access from the river Chao Phraya.

Okay but the stairs are scary. The temple looks different from other temples within the area but climbing the stairs could be challenging. Do climb with extra caution as the second sets of stairs leading up could be too narrow and small for your foot
Historic. Beautiful grounds with very impressive 260 foot spire. This silhouette is often recognized as a symbol of Thailand. There is also an interesting temple, very colourful.
During day or Night. Climbed to the top level non Monks can go! Right next to River and Boat travel. Probably most well known spot in all of Thailand for tourists!

Beautiful Temple. Wat Arun is a beautiful temple. It's a short and cheap ferry ride away from Wat Pho and the Grand Palace, so it's easy to see all three in one day. Unlike the sites on the other side of the river, you can climb the main structure of Wat Arun. The stairs are quite steep, but the view from the top is well worth the trip up! Although a portion of this wat is being reconstructed, there are several other buildings in the temple area that are worth checking out too. A great Bangkok landmark!

Take the ferry from the Grand Palace area dock.. Traveling by river in Bangkok is a superb way to get around. We made an early start to visit the Grand Palace and then took the baht ferry across the river to visit Wat Arun. Even though it was during the holidays, it was not overly crowded. The climb up the temple is steep,but not overly difficult thanks to a handrail.
Great!. Mind bending! a must see! climb it for a great view of the river and city.Spend a least 2 hours. In total restauration now.
Worth visiting. Crazy high steps, gorgeous view at the top. Worth visiting, plus you get to take the boat, and Wat Pho is just across the river.

Gotta climb it!. OMG, it's steep, really really steep. We took the Chaopraya Express to Pier 8 (Tha Tien) 15 bahts. We then took another boat across (only 3 bahts) from the same Pier. Wat Arun feels like it's on an island by itself (even though it's not) since you see green gardens and no car noises for once! Entrance to the temple is only 50 bahts per person.I always thought Wat Arun was made with some kind of prehistoric stone (sorry for the lack of knowledge) but it's actually white, decorated with blue and green and many other color porcelain. it's currently in renovation and we saw a restaurated part already which was stunningly white. As for the climb, this thing is steep. OMG especially the 2nd part is something to come down. Our only advice is to grab the handway well and don't look down. Look instead at the inner corner of each stair. We have been in Bangkok since 5 days now and this "attraction" was our favorite. The climbing, the beautiful setting and the quiet surroundings were such a treat. Do try it, you will always remember.
Beautiful, but too steep stairs. The temple is beautiful and colorful with multiple tiles. The stairs to climb are too steep and I didn't feel safe to go up. Good to see but not to climb.

Best temple in bangkok. You will worth for a stop at this temple. Not so crowded when i went to this place. You can rent for the thai traditional costume and take photo with the temple. If you're scared of height you will not climb to the top of the temple. The view on top of the temple are amazing with the river.
A must see. Wow,wow,wow!! One of my favorite places I visited. The detail is pretty amazing. Do not miss climbing to the top.

Very steep climb. We took the ferry across the river to reach here which cost a total of 6 bahts about 10p, we climbed to the top of the temple, the steps are very steep but worth the climb for the view, the building is amazing, well worth a visit
Worth a stop. Beatiful tower bot be climed. Enjoy the view. Very steep steps and nothing for people who are afraid of heights. Visit the temple behind.

my favourite temple in Bangkok. Of course there is a lot of Gold, but this is a very colorful temple with decorations out of broken china. Climb up to the top for great views if you do not suffer from vertigo.I have been there regularly in the last few years, every time we met school kids who go there - I guess as a homework assignment - to interview foreigners, make small films and take pictures. Lots of fun and giggling

Majestic & imposing. Right now its going through extensive renovation, after a couple of years it will dazzle. One can see the hindu, Chinese &buddhist amalgam of architecture. Climb up to get a aerial view of bankok .The ceramic on the temple walls have come from China . Wat arun will always be a humongous landmark of thailand.

Beautiful riverside temple. Besides interesting history of the temple, the river-side setting is probably what makes this temple stand out among hundreds of other temples in Bangkok. Despite being touristy it still retains a lot of charm.If you don't want to be a victim of Thai double pricing scheme, you can enjoy the temple from one of the restaurants across the river.

nice way to the temple!!. We took the 3 bhat ferry ride to the Wot and it was really crowded. We decided to have lunch in one of the stalls that lead to the ferry. it was a 5 minute ride to the temple and then there is a very steep climb up and down to the temple. This is not for the faint of the hearted..
lovely views. A must do when in Bangkok. Catch a boat for 3 baht to cross the river. some lovely views at the top of the temple

Excellent Temple. Wat Arun is located on the Chao Phraya River opposite Grand Palace. The. Best way to see the temple is to take a river ferry (fare 3 Baht) from Tha Tien after visiting the Grand Palace.Wat Arun is a beautiful temple covered in pieces of ornate porcelain, with two levels accessed by very steep stairs. The access to the second level seems like you are climbing practically vertical. Once there the views over the Chao Phraya River are splendid with good vies of the Grand Palace complex. Once you've enjoyed the views, you then have the daunting task of descending down the stairs. Not for the faint hearted!!!
Splendid architecture and art. Great views though you have to be very fit to climb! Come early to avoid overcrowding. There is much more to see near the temple too.

Daylight experience. Wat Arun is currently under extensive reconstruction but it is clear how amazing the temple is. The ceramics that create the designs came from many ship holds where pottery from China was broken in shipment. Beautiful grounds and a lovely river ride to get there!
Great historical value. Easy to get to, Trip spoiled by constant intervention of people trying to scan you, take your picture and then demand money etc

I love this place. its Great to visited this templeright on the chao phraya river..u just paid 3bath to go thereand pay 50bath for entry to templewell its just scary to climb their stair..loloverall I love to visited this temple

Our favourite temple. i love this temple as it is more unique than many of the others. it is not gold and glitzy it is covered in small decorative tiles. it is interesting to visit for 20 minutes to walk around and up the stairs. It is great that it is on the river and looks fabulous at sunset from the other side of the river. Check out Arun Residence.
Good climb!. Admission is half the price we paid at Wat Pho, yet I find Wat Arun much better and impressive than Wat Pho. The step climb was refreshingly mind-boggling!

Krung Thep Maha Nakhon. You can see this temple everywhere in Thailand, is over any coin, but visit it, simply amazing, buy at the ferry stop on the east side of the temple, not at the temple, where everything is double price...

Beautiful!. Right on the Chao Phraya river, the Wat Arun is a several-stories tall temple with stars and balconies around the exterior. The admission is reasonably priced, and the views from the top are good. On the grounds, you can find some gift shops. Don't be shy about haggling with the merchants, but if you took the ferry over from the east side, you will find that the gift shops on the opposite bank have the same trinkets for about half of the price. The Wat Arun is a stunning view at night when it is lit up, so be sure to look for it then.

Magnificent!. The 1st time I saw this we were recommended by a cafe owner to go to a rooftop bar that looks across the river onto Wat Arun, and WOW! The sunset and different colours cast across the temple, what a beautiful sight!
Must visit. One of the most renowned and glamorous temple/wat in Bangkok. Amazing in its architecture and towering at the bank of Chao Phrya river, this is the jewel of Bangkok.
Very pretty temple. By the river and very pretty. You can climb up and get a view across the river to the city. Amazing porcelain work on the temple

Rating based on finished renovation project. This is a beautiful Wat and interesting complex, but is in the midst of renovation so not a must see now unless you have lots of time in Bangkok. When finished, it will be a must. Easy access by water taxi, and that gives you a sense of the great siting of the place.

It's the most beautiful temple in Bangkok. We took the public boat, for Bhat3, only :), to cross the river to see this temple. IT was under renovation at the time, so some areas are not good for photograpy. But it is still the best temple for me. When I visited in the 90s it was similiar to Fez, were you see Thai men with snakes, vendors around the temple, but now, they made it into a more solemn, sacred place. So souvenir shops are outside the temple. Walking distance is a flower market, and i bought a bunch of orchids.. for Bhats60. When I got to the airport, the same flowers were sold for Bhats850.

Breathtakkng. Was so happy I got a chance to go and see wat arun. Unfortunately some of the buildings/monuments were under restoration or renovation but it was still well worth the boat ride over! (Boat ride is 3 baht each way and entrance to wat arun is only 40 baht!!)

Scary stairs!. Going to this temple was quite an adventure! The stairs are so steep. It was quite hard to go up but was terrifying going down from it. Nevertheless, the view from the top was good. The space to walk around in was quite narrow and you have to walk or stop sideways to let other people go through. Will go back again.

Great to Visit or Gaze At. I've been here a couple of times, but mostly I just enjoy seeing it from the river. The ferry passes it as you go from the Central Peer toward the Grand Palace. There are also restaurants on the other side of the river that have a great view of it. It's a cool temple because it has an Angkor look, which is quite distinct in Bangkok.
Wat arun. Well worth the visit and climbed to the top. This gives you a good view of the river and the surrounding areas. The climb down was very steep but the hand rails helped.

Need strong legs to get to the top!. Has to be visited preferably by long tail boat so you can savour the riverside life.
Well worth the visit also a cheaper way to visit is by the public water taxis which are both cheap and fun

Must see. It is a must see, as all the other places in Bangkok. If we are going to Thailand and Bangkok this is one of the things we are seraching for. From all the temples this on must be seen. Be aware of the times they are praying.

Beautiful and prominent structure. This temple and it's surrounding buildings and gardens are beautiful and the location on the riverside makes it more appealing as the majority of visitors reach the temple by making the short journey across the river (3 baht each way) - this is part of the fun. When we were visiting it was evident that a restoration was taking place and when finished it will be even more breathtaking that it is now. One word of warning - the steps are very steep on the pagoda so it is not for the feint hearted. I would definitley visit and with Wat Pho close by the two temples on either side of the river could easily be visited and enjoyed in one day.

Anciently Astounding. They do not call this the temple of dawn for no reasons. Located, besides the great Chao Phraya River, this remarkable temple is a must see for all foreign tourist. Travel to this place by boat or taxi. Come especially during sunset for those who prefer taking photos. You will definitely not regret as it is beautiful

Prettiest at sunset sitting across the river. I'm sure that the temple itself is great, but what was great for us to do was sit across the river for dinner and watch the sun go down. They light the temple up at night and it was the prettiest temple we've seen done that way. We loved it.

under renovation. Temple under renovation. Directions to structure not proper. Also, the idol of Lord Buddha not in the main premises. Dont know why the charge for climbing the stairs of the temple which are very dangerous.

Climb it if you dare. ...at your risk, these stairs are steep and large but reward with fantastic views of the river and surrounds. Admire the mind-bending detail, sculptures and tableau first hand and up-close.

Khmer architecture in the middle of Thai!. The Temple of Dwan. Deeply inspired by the Khmer architecture, the temple is a beautiful monument. Closed by 6 for the entry of visits to the top floors and then is all lighten up .One of the picture perfect monuments in Bangkok will highly recommend visiting here.

Architectural wonder. Temple of dawn is a great place to be if you love old architecture. The construction is really complicated but beautifully crafted. This truly deserves to be a top place to visit in Bangkok. Temple is under renovation which was a slight turn down.
Must see Bangkok attraction. Amazing temple next to the river. Great views from the top. A must see for anybody experiencing Bangkok for the first time.

Wow. you are left wondering how on earth they managed to construct this glorious Temple considering the time that this was built. under going some reconstruction at the moment so not all of it is accessible but the bamboo scaffolding around most of it makes you wonder what Health and safety in the UK would make of it all. A short boat ride of 3 baht from the leaning Buddha across the river. Combine these two trips for a fascinating insight into Thai culture and beliefs.
A must see in Bangkok. One of the important temples. you have to see it.It is possible to go by boat. From there you can see interesting views of the city.
Nothing in particular.. Buddhist temples in Myanmar and Khmer temples in Cambodia are so much better! Too crowded, scaffoldings around. not impressed.

Watch your step . So today I visited Wat Arun. If this temple was In the UK it would have been roped of for safety reasons many moons ago. The steps you have to climb are basically vertical, one slip and you and who ever is below you is toast. But that in my eyes is what makes it great. There isn't an awful lot else there but it's worth a visit for the climb alone. The view is pretty awesome also. Be sure to go to the bars the other side of the river to see the sun setting being the temple also. Really good photo opportunity.

Flying visit, worth it. Had a flying visit here as we were on our way past on the river and it seemed silly not to get off. We were glad we did, but we didn't spend much time her, there's not that much to do, so 4 of us had a quick look round and stayed on the floor while 1 of our party climbed up the temple. By the time he made the climb down he was shaking, and he's not scared of heights. So if you do go I would only climb the temple if you have a head for heights.

What Arun!. We visited Wat Arun on our last day of our 5 week South East Asian trip. Wat Arun is an amazing complex of temples next to the river that disects Bangkok's river. On our visit, about a third of the complex was under construction. Despite this, the other two thirds were amazing. Wat Arun is a major tourist attraction in Bangkok and was very busy. The main temple is relatively high and a wonderful view of Banhkok can be enjoy by those who climb it; however it should be noted that the stairs to the top are very steep and not for the faint hearted.Getting to Wat Arun was our biggest issue. We caught a ferry from the Centre Pier to Pier 8. To catch this ferry you wait until one arrives and buy a ticket (40 baht) on board. You do not need to get a longtail boat to get to Wat Arun. Next to Pier 8 is another ferry which takes you to the side of the river which Wat Arun is on (very cheaper, only 3 baht). It also cost 50 baht to get into the complex.

Temple of Dawn at night. We were on a dinner cruise on Chao Phraya river and the buildings along the river were all light up like back home in the US during Christmas time. These includes a few other temples and the palace as well. So all the outline and some with the whole buildings came alive at night and it is a spectacular view to watch while eating my dinner.
wat arun. More than we expected !! The temple is on the side of the river and we reached it by a cross - river ferry . It is a fantastic construction and it looks also wonderful from a distance
