Full of detail. Certainly this place is a favorite of the city. Everything is full of charming details. Make sure you spend at least 1.5-2 hours to visit everything since its a very complete complex where you can meditate, pray, think, relax or just taking pictures.At the top of the temple, the view of the river is eye opening.For ladies, make sure you cover your arms since this is a Buddhist temple.

Restoration work in January 2015. When I visited over half of the place was covered in scaffolding and construction material as they were doing restorations. But it was still a nice visit and if you go up the stairs to the top you'll get a nice view of the area, skyline and Chao Phraya river. The stairs are a bit scary as they are very steep so hold on to the railing.
Had a great time here. Tons to see really great to spend some time taking it all in. Be prepared to spend a bit of time looking around.
Day Visit. Amazing architecture. You would need a guide. By yourself the information displayed is surprisingly inadequate.

Steep climb!. TO GO:You can visit this place by taxi/tuk tuk or any other form of land transport.If you are coming by BTS, you need to stop at BTS Sanphan Takhsin, then take Exit 2 to the Central Pier. You will see a ticket booth selling tourist boat/express boat ticket. One way is TBH40/pax. Queue and wait for the call, the operators there will tell you when the boat arrives, just hold you ticket to let them see the colour type as there are day tours there as well.On the boat, a tour guide will explain to you briefly about the buildings at both sides of the river banks. To go to Wat Arun or Wat Pho, drop off at Pier 8 - Tha Tian Pier. You can choose to either visit Wat Pho first or go straight to Wat Arun via the cross river ferry. You need to pay another TBH3/pax per way to cross the opposite side.AT WAT ARUN:Foreigners are charged TBH50/pax. The locals call it the Number One Temple. You are allowed to climb up the stairs to reach the top (almost) of temple. There are two levels, one at the middle, another at almost the top. On top, you will be able to get a 360' view of the Chao Praya river and the surrounding area. Take your time to take some photos and be careful when climbing down the narrow and steep stairs. Do pay attention on the UP and DOWN sign and some people just ignored and caused congestion. BEST TIME:Go before evening for a good sunny view and stay until the lights are on for a nightshot.P.S. the temple is undergoing restoration at the moment (jan 2015) unfortunately but it is still opened to public. Metal racks for restoration are seen here and there, which is bad for photo. But the experience remains.

Short visit. It only cost 3 Bhat to cross the river by ferry and we stayed about an hour, the grounds are nice and the temple looks good made with all the bits of porcelain, every time we visit it seems to have lots of scaffolding up but mus'nt grumble considering its age, I love the guards outside.

Nice architecture, right next to the river. Liked: The ferry ride to reach the place, excellent drawings on the walls of one of the temple interiorsDid not like: Money to be paid to climb the top of the wat to view the city

Gorgeous temple. Currently the temple is under renovation. So, it's hard to appreciate its beauty beyond the scaffolding. The bits of broken pottery adorning the temple are pretty. Also, ladies, if you're wearing shorts, you'll be required to rent a long skirt to cover your legs. Unfortunately, this skirt becomes a trip hazard as you ascend the steep stairs.The views from the top are gorgeous. If you have time, try to view the temple in the evening. Simply breathtaking.

Wow!. More than I expected! Take a close look at the designs, all made from broken pieces of porcelain. Also, climb to the top- although it is steep there is such a beautiful view! Going down isn't as bad as it looks either. This is one temple not to be missed.

Absolutely amazing at night. we took the 3 baht river boat across the river. It was quite late in the afternoon and we visited the temple. Amazing views of the river and of the city. Once it got dark, the lights on the temple was simply exquisite.

Magical Spires. The evening sun was low, by the time we entered the complex. But, the sheer spiraling structure and the golden sunset made the day! The steps were steep, however rewarding to watch the river and the Bangkok city bustling below me

So disappointing. We had visited this temple twenty years ago and had been so impressed. It has been long neglected, is now dirty and has weeds growing n. Currently, it is being cleaned so there is scaffolding everywhere and some stairs are closed. More regular maintenance required so it is not allowed to get into such a neglected state.

Definitely lived up to expectations. The entrance to Wat Arun is tucked inside a narrow street, so when you take a taxi make sure you ask them to drive into this street-- we didn't realise and had to walk the distance. The temple itself is definitely worth a visit, the sculpturing and detailing is amazing. The steps ARE very steep but the handrails help (especially on the way down)! The view on top is definitely worth the climb. There is construction work going on at the moment so some parts are closed and there is some scaffolding on the surrounding temples but it doesn't distract from its beauty.One thing I also recommend is to see Wat Arun on a cruise along the Chao Phraya river as it gives you a very picturesque view of the whole temple.
pretty. Saw the temple from the river at night. RECOMMENDED! Read up on the history of this temple so you know what you are looking at.

peace lies above. The temple is located on the riverbank and has a pristine feel to it. It takes about 20 mins from the shangilla hotel via ferry. It is very tall, so beware of the ascent and more so of the descent. But once at the top you shall enjoy the 360 degree view.
Buddha fun. We visited 3 temples all were very cool. Make sure you take of your shoes and bring water with you. Lots of stairs and walking.

Take your time and come early. If you are in Bangkok and miss this one, shame on you.Do it yourself, no need for a guid.Take some time for the temple next to it.The stairs up are steep! Yes, as in very steep.There may be long queus for the (inexpensive) ferry acroos the river, come early.Long trousers for men needed.Did I say that if you miss this one in Bangkok shame on you?Went there twice.

Majestic and stunning views across the river. One of the most famous landmarks in Bangkok. Found it to be much more interesting than other temples.The ascent to the top of the temple was indeed an experience which was really steep. Spectacular views across the river Chao Phraya.
So much to see. We spent a here and hired a local guide to take us through the temple. It was well worth the time we spent there

Fantastic Building. On opposite side of river to all the other major temples. A real part of Bangkok's rich history and best visited with a knowledgeable guide. It's a long climb to the top if you want to do it!

Another must see!. This is another must see! You can climb to the top of this temple - but the stairs are quite steep. you must cover yourself while in the temple area so be sure to bring a tshirt and a sarong...
Beautiful, but don't forget the sunblock. Wat Arun is a beautiful stop. However, if you're going on a warm day, remember the sunblock. I about roasted out there!

Stunning!. My favorite amongst all the temples we visited. There's nothing more in here, it's just all the about the elegant and beautiful Wat Arun. My girlfriend and I climbed its narrow stairs up and witnessed the most fascinating sunset ever in Bangkok. The details and the structure of this temple was really sublime. Definitely worth a visit. Wat Arun is just across the Tha Thien Pier of Chao Phraya River. There's a special boat crossing the river to get you here. Boat fare costs 3 baht each. It is best visited during afternoon hours, for its stunningly beautiful sunset. Make sure to visit it before it closes at 18:00. For its best appearance, take the boat back to the opposite side of the pier and wait until night time as they reveal the most stunning Wat Arun!

Great View!. The Temple of Dawn is incredibly well preserved and if you climb to the top, there are great views of the other centrally located temples. This is an easy water taxi ride from the Grand Palace and Wat Pho.

Temple. Beware of Taxis that do not start the meter..it is not just one company it's all of them it is illegal for them not to...once u figure out the taxi situation be aware that the river taxi is cheap don't let them over charge you..then enjoy. .but figure 2 x the travel time for traffic

Spectacular sunset and views over Bangkok. An absolute must in Bangkok. Try to get there at about 5pm (in winter) just before the sun sets. Watch the sun setting over the river and Bangkok. Very special.

The Climb itself Mirrors the Struggles of the Human Condition. So amazing in architecture and history, and so easy to get to located right on the Chao Phraya River. Express boat goes there for just 20baht, that’s about .63 cents to you and me. It should be a first stop for any first timers to the city. The views after the climb are miraculous. The climb itself is supposed to mirror the struggles of the human condition, of life, so yes they are staggeringly steep and difficult but worth every step. I arrived around 5pm not knowing if they would still be open. According to the sign on their property they are actually open until 6 so I had just enough time to see everything. A quick praise to TA, I would have never known that Wat Arun would have traditional Thai costumes that you can rent, on the cheap. It was only after browsing all the pretty photos I came across a few with the costumes and thought this is something I would LOVE to do. As a helpful hint, like everything in Thailand, the costume rental is negotiable so feel free to haggle a little, especially at the end of the day.As I am not a fan of one price for Thai, another price for everyone else. I will mention that it is free if you are Thai, everyone else must purchase a ticket for 50baht. For lack of better words I will just say it; this pricing scale is racist and I find any business in Thailand or anywhere else who decides to charge people extra based on the color of their skin is personally offensive. That said, the small ticket price does not take much away from the beautiful experience.

Beautiful Temple- shame about the pickpocket signs. The temples are without doubt breathtaking and worth visiting Bangkok for that reason alone.remember to wear respectful clothing I.e. Skirt to the knee and shoulders covered, long trousers fro men.avoid the toilets anywhere in Bangkok,other than hotels and modern restaurants like at Asiatique on the river.

Not a lot there.... We took a taxi from our hotel to Wat Arun to try and avoid one of the ferry journeys as my partner doesn't like water. There was a lot of traffic to get here and it took some time. The distant views of the temple are great, once there however, there is a limited amount to see and our trip there was longer than the visit. The views are good from the temple but the steps are so steep and the site quite busy in parts that you need to have quite a good head for heights, it's probably not a good idea for anyone with small kids or a disability.We took the ferry back across the river which is only 3 baht and much easier (provided you don't mind being on the water!).

Climbing down not as bad as it looks.. One of the must see sights in Bangkok. It really is a great view once you climb the steep staircase, and whilst it looks pretty scary, is not actually that bad coming back down. I wouldn't recommend the climb for the elderly or people with mobility difficulties. However, the temple grounds are very beautiful and have easy access.
Beautiful. Really beautiful place. Climb up the temple, it's scary but great. It's only THB 3 to take the ferry across and 50 to get in. Dress codes apply.
Great Wat. Being repaired but that didn't detract from the amazing place. Very steep steps, great views of the river. Interesting porcelain on the surface. Good grounds and a nice cafe
Definitely must visit. Perfect view from the top. Climbing on top, can easily take your breath away :) Wear longer sleeves in order to avoid paying extra for lending one.

Worthwhile investigating. If you take a river boat ride be sure to stop here. They're being refurbished (by hand) at the moment, which is interesting in itself. Takes about an hour to have a good look.

Unforgettable landmark on Bangkok's River. This is one of the must-visit places when you are in Bangkok. Wat Arun is situated on the west bank of the Chao Phraya river. You need to ride an express boat to travel across the river towards the pier which is available at very frequent intervals. It is open daily for public from 8.30am-5.30opm.This is a must-visit place in Bangkok. Don't forget to bring hat / umbrella as the heat is quite unbearable during the day. There are few stalls selling refreshments nearby if you forget to bring some water.Highly recommended!The main tower/stupa stands really tall and is encrusted with colourful porcelain. You need to be in good health to climb up the steep stairs all the way to the top. However, the view from the top is breathtaking.
Lovely but crowded. Wat Arun is a lovely temple with beautiful views but it was crawling with people at sunset...still worth the visit if you're in the neighbourhood!
worth the visit. Incredible! if you visit the royal palace then you must take the ferry (3baht / way) and cross the river to go to Arunt Wat.
A must. Unfortunately at present it is undergoing restoration at the moment but doesn't really affect your enjoyment and the good part is that you can climb up

Night visit. We sat Wat Arun at night with a bike tour and it was beautiful. Read up on the history of how and why the Wat was built and you'll appreciate all the more. Although the temple section is closed when visited at night, there is virtually no one there and its awesome!

Climb It. While this is a small temple compared to others across the river the tile work that went into it is a must see...go in the morning for better light for photos and definitely climb up for amazing views of the city!
Climbing. Need to climb steep steps to get the best out of it. Not for the faint of heart. Nice view, but you mostly do it for the experience of getting to the top.
Gorgeous. Loved it but didn't like the stairs so I didn't go up. I did get some great pictures from the ground though.

Interesting complex. Being in the other side of the river is interesting enough, although like most of the historical sites in Bangkok, this place was so touristy even at noon when people were expected to be eating their lunch or taking a rest from the heat of the sun. Still worth your while though as Bangkok would not be complete without visiting Wat Arun.

Worth the trip!. Although this temple is out of the way from the Grand Palace, it's a must see. The steep stairway up to the top base is an experience in of itself, and the main temple is quite impressive (especially thinking about how difficult it would've been to build!).

Beautiful Temple. It looks beautiful even from afar. When we visited, a part of it is under construction but nevertheless, it was a beautiful sight to see. You get to climb up the temple and get a panoramic view of surrounding areas. Stairs are quite steep so it's not for people who are afraid of heights. Usual dress codes to temples apply (no sleeveless / see-through tops, no shorts, no mini skirts, no tights / leggings, no sandals). Entrance fee was B50.
Best temple in Thailand. Dont miss it, we watched the artisans cleaning up the smaller temples & it was a sight to behold. Its utter madness on the ferries to get there though & 6Bht there & back.

Fascinating. It's a very interesting and wonderful site. It does get hot there, so they're now giving free bottled water. Put on your sun cream. It's a definite site to visit if you're going to Bangkok.
Nice Temple. Need to take boat ride in order to go this place but i think it is rather good experience as you climb up the temple. It is really high and steep.

Hire a tour guide.. When experiencing Wat Arun you should definitely spring a few bhat for a tour guide as you will get so much more from your visit, learning about the different styles of temples and why, the different building materials, as well as the on going restoration (each one is redone about every forty years, completely replacing the tiny glass tiles). Yes the steps are steep, but even if you don't scale the temple it is so worth going.

Impressive. Entrance fee is 50baht if I'm nt wrong.Ladies should dress up properly.at least shoulder must be covered and no shorts.better dun wear long skirt or dress,otherwise u will regret when u climb up the stairs. =pThe stairs r scary!!so steeeppp!!!!!esp when u gg down.but the view is really nice.Worth visit!!
Don't miss. First contact for my family with boudhism temple. Very impressive. Help of a local guide improved our discovery.

Fabulous views of the rising sun!!!!. The Temple of the Dawn - or Wat Arun - towers 260 ft (79 m) above the Chao Phraya river. With fabulous views of the rising and setting sun and of the city's main attractions, the temple is one of Bangkok's most visited sights after the Grand Palace.Named by Bangkok's founder King Thaksin to signify the rise of the new kingdom (after Ayutthaya was destroyed), the Temple of the Dawn was originally much shorter until its expansion during King Rama III's rule (1824 - 1851). Local people donated the ceramic pieces that make up the temple's unique exterior decoration. It is possible to climb the temple for views across the river to the Grand Palace and beyond but its narrow steps are not for the faint hearted or if you have a problem with heights.Lots of stray dogs around,but do be careful,not to feed them,or cuddle I was told by my guide. Comfortable shoes and a hat is a must!

Great experience - Not good for people who don't like heights!. After seeing that you were able to climb up the steps of this temple, I made sure that I would make myself do it. The first set of steps are more reasonable to climb up, however, if you are afraid of heights I suggest you stop here.I decided to push myself and climb up except I wasn't climbing up them, I was crawling. The steps are so steep that I didn't even feel safe crawling up them. I was absolutely petrified. After getting to the top, I wasn't bothered looking at the view as I was more concerned about finding a way to come down. The only safety barrier in place for the steps is a hand rail and that is it. Going down was even worse, if you make one wrong step or slip, you would have a serious accident so if you do decide to climb up further, I suggest that you take care and take your time. After saying that, I would totally recommend it though. Even though I was petrified, afterwards, I was so glad I did it and I knew that I would have regretted it if I didn't.

A nice temple with exquisite architecture and old world charm. Located strategically on the Chao Praya river bank and approachable by ferry. The grand building looks awesome in the setting sun and gives you a perspective of the religious beleifs of Thais which is so close to India.

Worth visiting, stunning location. Stunning location, with 'very' steep stairs to get to the top of Wat Arun. Worth it though, since you get birds-eye view of bangkok over the river. Nice gardens around the temple. Worth visiting at sunset, amazing views.

Simple Majestic!. This is one temple that I would say one must not miss if you are planning to visit the temples in Bangkok. The steps to climb up are pretty narrow, and might scare you at once. But its definitely worth going for the amazing view and so witness the grand scale of the temple. The best time to visit the temple is just before the sunset. By doing this you can climb up the temple to two floors as well see the temple in the evening when it is lit. To capture this, the best option I think is to sit across the Chao Phraya river in one of the riverside restaurants, Amorosa being one of them where I went.This place expects tourists to be dressed appropriately. So its better to carry a sarong to cover your knees else, they rent out sarongs to cover urself at a minimal price of 20 Baht

Awesome and different. A must-see when in Bangkok. If you're bored of seeing the same-looking temples, definitely check out this place. A very neat structure, much more unique than typical temples, just be careful on the stairs.
A must see for all those traveling to Bangkok. It is a good place which connects you to the roots of the Thai people which is revolving around Buddhism.

Scary stairs . Loved this monument, some of it was under renovation when I went in Jan 15 but was amazing to see the before and after work. The stairs are mighty steep so you've got to be careful but other than that it's great. Paid 50 Bart entrance fee

Breath taking, but tough with young kids. Magnificent, we went down just in time for sunset, and went to the gardens near by: very impressive.When you climb up you think it's a bit tough. But the hard part is really getting down, especially if you are with young kids. Two of ours (6yrs, 4yrs) thought it was a cool adventure, but I know my heart missed a few heart beats in the process..Also, though the view up there is breath taking, the kids can hardly see anything due to the wall. So if you are with young kids, consider taking turns with your partner, so the kids don't necessarily go all the way up.
Different.. A less glittering but equally impressive structure. Definitely worth a visit before giving in to temple fatigue. Fun ride across the river too.
Nice view. Beautiful site.. There is a nice view up the "pyramid". Steep climbing to the top is worth! You have a nice view of the city and the river!

An amazing monument !. Asthoniscing monument! Ceramic are unique ! Climb on top to See a spectacular view of Bangkok. Architetture, colors and originality give to The structure a touch of magnificent beauty !

Train your leg and don't look down when coming down. Spectacular view when you are on top, be really very careful when you climb down..the stair is like 45 degree , second day you will most likely enjoy muscle ache on your leg, walk around clockwise and you can the view nice Bangkok near Chao Phraya River, and the busy boat travel on the river, really feel peaceful on top with wind blowing.

Bangkok360 tour. My group went on the Bangkok 360 tour, which allowed us to see more than the usual highlights in the Thai capital. Wanna not only told us about what we were seeing, but about their social and everyday background. Highly recommended.

Impressive temple. This place is beyond amazing. The amount of detail that goes into this is still beyond me. We visited over 7 temples this day and this was by far the best one we saw all day. Upon arrival there are many signs stating that visitors need to be careful of false tours and pickpoketers. We bought tickets to climb the exterior walls for 20baht each. The stairs are very steep but the views are well worth it. There is a dress code that is enforced. Females should cover their shoulders. Sandles and heels are definatly not reccomended to climb the exterior. It was very crowded but that was expected. You can see this temple from across the river while it stands out from the others. This tempo is currently under heavy renovation with 2 of the sides being completely closed off but still able to grab some amazing pictures and see the views.

Beautiful place, with a hike!. The stairs looked very steep and challenging and they definitely were a challenge for some people I witnessed there. I didn't think they were too bad, just a little intimidating. Definitely worth the view at the top overlooking the city and the river. You can walk 360 around it. Wish I had seen it during the night tho, how beautiful is it!?

My favourite Wat in Bangkok!. Wat Arun was the most impressive temple from all the temples in Bangkok for me. You could feel the history there. Don't miss this place, when visiting Bangkok. The stairs are pretty steep and they might be a bit scary when looking from the top. But don't worry, even the older people made it with no problems. It's not so difficult to climb them. To get there from the other side of the river (Wat Pho/Grand Palace), you can take very cheap ferry that goes back and forth in short intervals. The ferry stop is very close to Wat Pho. Again, totally recommend!

Different from the typical bangkok temple. Its a beautiful place to visit. You have to take the ferry that crosses the river to get there. Its 3 baht for one way. Its a quick ride. There is an entrance fee to climb up (i forget how much) The steps are quite steep and going down can be quite scary. The views at the top are wayyy worth it though.
Must see in Bangkok. It is just beautiful! Climbing to the top is great experience in provides wonderfull views. Colorful and charming.

Unmissable. One of the highlights of Bangkok and SHOULD be on everyones itinery. As you approach from the other side of the river it gets increasingly impressive. Worth the climb for the magnificent views.

Nicest attraction in BKK. Wat Arun is in my opinion the nicest temple to visti in Bangkok, not as crowded as the other ones because you have to cross the river and to get on top you have to climb a few very steep stairs, which a lot of people can't manage.The views you get from the top are the best you will get.

Better to visit during evenings. i went with the river boat to visit Wat Pho and took the ferry for 3 baht to Wat arun. It was worth spending the time and was pretty impressive . Better to visit during evenings with nice lights.

Awesome view in the evening. I still cant forget the view I had in the evening with the lights around. During the day it does not look that good. But when you look at it in the evening the view with the lights is awesome. If you are going for it then plan in the evening.

Temple from Dawn to Sunset. Wat Arun is known as Temple of Dawn, but wow, sit yourself and enjoy its view from across the river at sunset time then you would agree it is also a temple of sunset, it is just beautiful. The temple is one of the kind, small but unique, with all the antique potteries cladded on the temple architecture, and in such as shape, climbing it is an experience one must not to miss. But I would recommend one more time - after finish the visit, get yourself across the river, find a cafe and enjoy its view till sunset!

Wat Arun. Loved it..if you have females with you ensure they wear skirts if not saris can be hired for 120baht and you get 100 back on retrieval...also ensure the females cover their upper half as well ie a sensible t-shirt or you may be refused as its policed. If you have a head for heights your gonna need it as if you want to scale the top of the temple you have to negotiate some pretty steep stairs,same on the way down. Places to grab some food and a drink so all in all I enjoyed it and so did my partner.

Great views!. Really incredible site but steep steps. Take the very cheap ferry across the river from Wat Pho and Palace area. Go late in the day for late afternoon sun and views of the river. This is a unique wat made from mostly broken pottery. I loved it!
Prepare for vertigo!. This is an impressive temple that allows you to climb the exterior walls like the pyramids! A great way to start your temple explorations.
See it across the river. Several bars across the river offer the best view, particularly at night time with lights on. Take the Orange boat and you won't miss it.

Gorgeous, especially if you have a head for heights!. This is an absolute "Must" if visiting Bangkok. the views over the river are great and well worth the effort if you are capable of the climb. (tip:- back down, like a ladder, rather than forward facing).After the tower walk to the river and feed the fish with some bread.

climbing challenge. The temple is situated crossing a river , better go there in the afternoon and at least you will get a nice view with sun going down ... It was a good experience but please don t go there in flip flops! take sport shoes you will really need them!
beautiful temple. You can climb this magnificent Bangkok landmark, for our kids it was a little adventure on its own, with these steep steps

nice. nice temple
Too steep steps
too crowded generally
right across grand palace campus; must visit.
be aware of grand palace fraud by tuk tuk or taxi

Depends. If you are going to Angkor Wat, then forget this temple unless you just can't get enough of temples.
But it is worth visiting if you aren't going to Siem Reap. It's probably the only real example of a Khmer style temple in Bangkok and quite impressive. Be careful on the stairs. They are quite steep in places!

Walk there from the nearest station. I was recently visited Wat Arun , but I had pleanty of time to get there so I decided to walk there from the nearest Bts station Wongwian Yai . I was using an offline map on my phone , so it was impossible to get lost . If you choose to approach Wat Arun this way it will give you a great insight of how Thai people live in Bangkok. You will be surprised how much cleaner this area from the touristy areas and belive me nobody will give you a damn about you ! No hussle of tuk-tuk drivers or any of that. If you choose to follow me , it will need roughly 2 hours to walk to Wat Arun . Get off the main roads and discover the Venice like canals.
Wat Arun. One of the 5 most inspiring temples in Bangkok.It`s size is seen from afar in Bangkok deffinitely worth visiting even though there is a more inspiring temple across the river.
Mid day visit. Loved climbing to the top, but its not for the fain heart, Take the ferry to it The ground around it was very basic but did not reduce the experience

Uttery Beautiful !. Must visiting place on Chao Praya river bank. Breath taking Mosec Chedi delivered from China to decorated this famous temple. Do not miss out walking up to the top of Chedi to see the fantastic view across the area. Very steep step ,not suitable if you are wearing a high heel ,todler or elderly !

Don't be afraid of the steep stairs/steps. Wat Arun is located across the river from Wat Po. The river ferry is only 3Baht & a very short ride. The ferries look different and are more open than the river express boats.The entrance fee is 50Baht pp and there are signs that you must adhere to the dress code as the Grand Palace, but we noticed that no one was enforcing it & there are no clothing rentals (as provided by the GP).Be aware that the steps of the temple are very steep and uneven at some places. Make sure you have good shoes & are sure footed (heels, flip-flops, sandals not recommended). Ascending is easier than descending. It just looks scarier coming down, but just hold on to the banister and descend backwards (feet/legs first).Views up top are amazing esp around sunset.

Number 1 of all the Bangkok temples we visited. A lot of the areas are being fixed when we were there but it still was a great place to visit. So as somebody else had said - short walk from Wat Po via the market and then to the pier to cross the river via ferry for 3 THB; get in for 50 THB if you wanna climb up to the main tower where you can enjoy the views of the river and sorrounding area. We went during the day and we passed by the temple during the river cruise at night when you can see the temple lit up beautifully.

very nice during sunset. lightup is very nice especially from the other side of the river. there were several restaurants and bars overlooking the sunset. at the back is the wat po. this is also nice.

Great View, Great Visit. Climbed to the top of Wat Arun during a very warm Bangkok morning in early 2015. Provided great views of the nearby busy river and the rest of the Bangkok skyline.Be warned though - the steps are very steep on both levels and you do need to be relatively fit to get up (and down!) from both levels. It's also good to see the local authorities are also refurbishing the brickwork/paintwork of the temple itself - it's age is showing.

beautiful and well maintained. It is one of the must visit destinations while in Bangkok. Getting here can be tricky especially by the ferry but there are many other travelers who can help you. The temple is really well maintained and one should go to the top of the temple to get to see some amazing views of Bangkok.

Awesome!. We saw it from a restuarant across the river and the kids were like "whoa, you can climb that one?!?!?"
So right there, it's awesome.

A must see in Bangkok. We visited both Wat Po, the Palace and the Temple of Dawn in an afternoon and they made for a great whistle stop tour of the Bangkok temples and monuments. Great views from the top as well!
Arguably the most beautiful temple in Bangkok. I recommend going in the late evening to avoid tourist crowds. Went here on a night bicycle tour. Great lighting of the main temple.
Nice to see. its nice to see different culture. it has a huge buddha with beautiful shrine. separate place for meditation. please dont wear shorts and go as you wont be allowed to enter in.
Stunning. This is worth a trip - it is not for the feint hearted as some climbing up (and down of course) some very steep steps but great views from the top and an impressive sight to enjoy
Breath taking. only go when it's not right on the last day of the year or the first day of the year as all locals flock there.

Must See Destination. After going to the Grand Palace with my boyfriend and paying a hefty fee of 500 baht to enter, we were considering skipping Wat Arun. I am so glad we didn't! It was easy to get to. With only 3 baht you can take a 2 minute ferry across the river to reach Wat Arun. We saw a short line past a market and decided it was probably the line for the ferry and we were right. Climbing the steep stairs to get to the top of the temple was an adventure. If you're scared of heights you may not feel too comfortable but its worth getting to the top! The architecture was amazing and I enjoyed the scenes from above. Do not skip this temple! Also I found that it was easier to climb down when I took my flip flops off and went bar foot. I do not recommend for parents to climb up with small children as this slows other people down and is not safe.

You will meet your step goal!. Very different than several of the other temples. Many steep stairs! Follow the directions regarding what sides to go up and down. Not for those afraid of heights. The views are worth all tiers you should climb.

Landmark of Bangkok. Wat Arun is always landmark of Bangkok. You will see lots of promotion brochures and lots of film. The temple is very beautiful especially when you see from the river side. There are quite numbers of cruising and restaurant on the opposite side that you can find with the Wat's view. I might recommend the restaurant which is opposite to Wat Po named the deck which have very nice scenery of Wat Arun especially at night.
Beautiful Temple. So pretty, we went there twice. Worth the steep (yet short) climb to the top to see the incredible Bangkok and river views.

Steep climb but good views. you have to climb up of course, otherwise what's the point in going, A short hop on a boat over from the Grand Palace - takes 2 mins. The steps to climb are up extremely steep so take care and wear sensible shoes. Good views at the top. Impressive building, although one of the four towers was covered in scaffolding when we were there.

Steep stairs but beautiful detail to the temple. This temple was very nice but was undergoing a fair amount of renovations to it when we visited. What is interesting that every bit of detail to the temple is actually hand painted- we know this as we saw them doing it! The stairs are very steep so do be careful but you get some lovely pictures whilst at the top. There are stunning gardens around this temple. If you weren't already aware- do wear trousers and something that covers your shoulders. We forgot this but it wasn't a problem as there are vendors close by that will sell these items at a reasonable price. On the sunday that we were visiting there was actually a parade and it was fascinating to see all of the Monks dressed so differently. We didn't know about this so it was rather a surprise and delight!

Grand Temple. Located across the Wat Pho & Grand Palace complex. Take a boat to cross Chao Phraya river with THB 3 (yes, three thailand baht) ticket fee.Entrance fee is THB 50.This temple is Grand and beautiful. Try to reach the top terrace to get Chao Phraya & city of Bangkok beautiful view. The stairs are steep though, be very careful.A must visit.

Worth the climb. The ascent of Wat Arun is daunting- and definitely not something for those with vertigo- but it does give the tiniest sense of a journey: the steps are tall from the first level, and get taller with every level. By the third level you are really climbing hand over hand. Even the decision to come back down means staring down that first step. The view is fine and the elephants at the top are great.

Awesome. This place is so cool. The steps are steep but really fun to ascend and descend. l felt an energy here but maybe that's just me. Expect hordes of tourists and sometimes a long ferry ride across the not so wide river. It can be busy. It costs 50 baht to walk around the temple and it's well worth it. Looks amazing when lit up at night. This should be be experienced when in Bangkok.
unique experience. its worth visiting this place. crossing chaopraya, climbing on its steep stairs are extremely unique! A worth visit!
Amazing. Amazing structure unfortunately undergoing a lot of restoration when we visited, still well worth going although the steps up and down are not for the faint hearted.

A different perspective in the scenery if temples in Bagkok. A visit to Bangkok will lead you surely to at least 4 temples - and you should enjoy each and everyone of them through their own perspective. Wat Arun don't have an impressive statue of Budah, or the richness associated with gold. It is a different style (Khmer), and the main material used in that temple is porcelain - broken pieces of China that were taken from the ships in the Thailand's commercial route. The interesting to do is to find out how those people transformed what was supposed to be garbage, in a decoration material. In Wat Arun, you can climb 3 distinct levels of stairs. If you do so, you can not only admire the city from the high, but see details of the temple that you cannot perceive from the ground. It is totally worthy. Note that each level of the stairs will have higher and smaller steps. So, just like our path to reaches the Nirvana, each phase will be harder...Be wise. If you're afraid of high, don't' climb. If you're a woman in a long skirt (this is possible, because you're visiting a temple in Thailand and that kind of modesty is required, be cautious in your way down. If climbing the three levels seam too much for you, try two of them... It will still be worthy.

Impressive serenity. Wat Arun is an impressive sight to behold. At the time of my visit, part of the temple was under restoration and the rest to follow in the coming months. The architecture and details on the temple walls are amazingly intricate. Climbing up the stairs until the highest level can be a challenge to those who have weak knees. And the climb down the stairs can be a challenge if one is not careful and afraid of heights. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit and I managed to see the temple complex both during the day and at night with it's lightings.Well worth the visit and the climb up to the highest level. It's good just to sit on the grounds, take in the sights and feel the serenity of this impressive temple.
Must visit!. If you're in Bangkok, this place is a must. It is breath-taking. You get to climb up the spire for really nice views. :-)

Thai culture experience. This is one of the most popular tourist places to go to...so expect this to be really crowded. I suggest going here early in the morning to avoid the big crowds in the afternoon.

Magnificent!. In contrast to Wat Phra Kaew and Wat Pho, Wat Arun is something I would say definitely visit!. The easiest way is by crossing the Chao Phraya river from the pier near Wat Pho. It will cost 3 baht per person one way. There is no fee to roam about around the temple grounds but you will have to pay 50 baht per person to get near the pagoda, but this is definitely worth the money. Thereon, you will get to see closely the ceramic tile pieces that have been used to decorate the pagoda. Climbing the steep steps to the top will give you a breathtaking view of the two sides of the Chao Phraya. Since we had time, we crossed the ferry back and spent some time in the park adjacent to the pier. Since it was Christmas time the park was also lit up with lights and was a definite photo stop. We stayed there till dusk and the lights on Wat Arun was truly impressive. A definite must visit.

Must go!. Amazing!!!!! So cool! breathtakingI liked the night life better than the day light, but seriously it is amazing! The temples are so beautiful and when you have a closer look at the details of the construction it is really detailed!

A long climb up and down. Wat Arun is situated across the river from the Wat Pho and Grand Palace complexes. The Temple itself is tall, and visitors may climb the steep staircase up to near the top of the main spire, where the view of the river and the temples on the opposite banks are the main reward. Going down the spire, though, can be harrowing.Tip: Do the Reclining Buddha and the Grand Palace first before crossing the river to visit the Temple of Dawn.

Nice climb, great view. The premises of the temple are not that impressive. The steep climb was interesting, the temple from outside looks very intricate - great architecture. The best was the view - overlooking the river with floating boats and other side of it with reclining Buddha temple and Grand Palace.
Very impressive. Very impressive temple. I visited Wat Arun with a local friend who explained me a lot and was better than any commercial guide could be,

Worth visiting. Unfortunately I didn't get to see this temple lit up at night which I would have liked. We took the local's ferry over which was an experience in itself as it's literally just a square piece of wood with materials underneath to make it float. The boat was packed out when we were on it and people had to spread out to ensure that it didn't tip to one side! In no way would you want to fall into the river either! No matter, it cost us next to nothing and like previously mentioned, added to the experience. Wat Arun was located a 15 minute walk or so from there. It is a very beautiful temple made up of layers of porcelain. Although it hasn't been confirmed, it is estimated to be between 67m - 87m tall and from the top you can get some stunning views of Bangkok. Taking the stairs back down again is scary as they're very steep but the view is totally worth it. This temple was one of my favourites in Bangkok and I 100% recommend a visit.

Very Steeeep!. I liked the whole ferry ride and getting to the temple but it is very steep and not good for people with a fear of heights, I only climbed halfway up. If you dont want to climb up you can still walk around the grounds.
such a nice temple !. i really liked the temple, the form, the view (very nice view of bangkok!), and the color of the temple ! you can directly take a boat from the temple with the golden buddha!
Temple. Great temple, one of the "must see" category. Interesting details and great view although a large part is inaccessible from restoration. Mesmerizing to hear and watch the monks chant.

Unfortunate. While we were crossing the river from Pier N8 we were quite excited. But once we got there, a bit of disappointment came over us. We thought the entrance fee was a bit much as the temple is undergoing some renovations/restoration. Also, just watching other tourists struggle to climb up/go down the steps really put us off in even wanting to climb those set of stairs. We opted to just enjoy the view and the architectural aspects of the structure from outside the gates. Great view during sunset though so that was a plus.

Awesome place. Climb the steps though. Really nice vibe here. Great photo opportunities. It's too easy to miss the other stuff in the grounds so make sure you have a good wander around once you've climbed up and downtown the steps

Wow that stairs. A fabulous place to visit with lots of history. The stairs are very steep and you need to be pretty brave to climb to the top. Going up is one thing, but going down is scary. A recommended place to visit. Look at the detail !

Magnificent Temple. I visited during sunset and the view was magnificent. I took a ferry crossing from a terminal near grand palace. Max 3 min ride accross the Chao Phraya river. Center tower/stupa/pagoda in Wat Arun is beautifully decorated with colourful porcelain or ceramics and seashells. There are 4 smaller towers on its perimeter. Some of the figures looks like from Chinese mythology or Gods. If i am not wrong the Emerald Buddha was once enshrined here before being relocated inside Grand Palace. Great photography moments during sunrise (as this temple is named Temple of Dawn) or sunset. Entrance fee is Baht 50 for foreigners.

Beautiful; Steep Steps. Take the 3 baht ferry from Wat Pho over to Wat Arun. It is very beautiful and not as packed as grand palace and Wat Pho. We climbed up towards the top and had a phenomenal view. The steps are incredibly steep though. I have never had issues with heights, but I was anxious about taking a tumble down the stairs (more like a ladder). I am not sure how young children, parents holding babies, or elderly tourists could possibly climb down the stairs safely- just a warning.

Very unique structure. It was under restoration so some areas were blocked to the public, but we were still able to go up the stairs to the top. It's an impressive temple and the views of the city from the top are worth the steep steps.If you happen to go before the restoration is over, be careful where you lean on. I grabbed a section of the handlebars while going downstairs that was recently painted and still not dry, so I ended up with gray paint on the palm of my hand.
Must See. This is a great find and a must see. The only issue would be have a translator with you. Little English is spoken and there are many questions to be asked.

Worth a visit. This was a beautiful temple with lovely statues and amazing views. You have to take a ferry across the river to get there but it's only a few mins a a couple of baht. It's one of the most famous places in Bangkok and well worth a visit.

What an experience. We took the water taxi over for about $0.50, what a place! Amazing how much detail is put into making a place like this. We walked up to the top and enjoyed the views looking down over the waterway. Worth a visit. Be prepared for steep stairs. I hike all the time back home, but these stairs were steep. Cover up your shoulders and knees for this temple. They have rental clothes at the temple entrance if you need. There's also some nice little shops near the exit.

Small temple under renovation. Some parts of the temple were under renovation when we visited it. A small temple crowded with visitors. The shuttle boas trip form Tha Tien on the opposite side of the river is quite a good experience. The steep steps up the tower can challenge your leg muscles on the way up and down.

Across the river. To reach this , you need to go on a ferry costing just 3Baht and you'll be welcomed to the sight of this temple. Its a massive steep climb to the top which has a great panoramic view of the city and the river. Though not advisable for everyone , as climbing down sometimes is very treacherous and quite dangerous

Bangkok's most famous temple. Wat Arun is Bangkok's most visited and must snap landmark. Located on the Thonburi west bank of the Menam Chao Phraya, it's the first sparkle most tourists will see first thing in the morning, ornate and well-respected place of worship by the Buddhists visitors.
take the ferry to this unusual temple. I took the ferry over, which added greatly to the atmosphere. Sweet cats roaming about. Worth a visit.
Best temple in Bangkok. By far the best temple we saw in Bangkok. Less tourists than the other temples. Very impressive tile work. See this one!

Must see . During my sight seeing days in Bangkok I visited the reclining Buddha and was not disappointed. A must see for any sightseer wanting to gain an insight into Thai history. Please remember to cover up, you must cover your shoulders and wear clothing longer than your knees.

a splendid place. one place when you can feel Thailand and their spirit.
impressive , and special when you get a guide is more valuable.

SUPERBLY FUN (((:. Despite the renovations that were going one at one of the stupas/prangs/not sure what?, we were able to enjoy the rest of the temple in its glory and it was definitely fun climbing the steep steps of the main prang (tower)! Entirely worth the 50b entrance fee.

Feels so adventure . The actual temple is very ancient and feels so historical then when you wanna go upstairs from high stairs which is too difficult and fun then you can see city and river from top , very unique experience in temples .

See it...but be prepared for killer stairs. Whenever I take others to Thailand with me, this is one of those "must see" stops, if only to see the handcrafted touches on the structure itself. Be warned...the stairs to go up the Temple are WICKED...almost straight up (better wear comfy walking shoes with a GOOD sole).

Amazing spot, very unusual. I liked this temple quite a bit. It has a different feel than the others we visited - more rustic? The ferry ride over is easy and cheap. Eat before you go as we could not find any place worth eating around there.

Nice experiences.. It is a tourist location. Easily accessible by taxi. The weather is very hot over there especially during the afternoon. However the place is quite spacious. However when I visit, the temple are still having some renovation. Coconuts drink are available at 50baht. Try visit there and you will know.

Too many repairs. The site was undergoing a major restoration when we visited, so much of the temple was obscured by scaffolding and tarpaulins. Still, what was visible was spectacular and the view from the top is excellent

Confused and slightly dissapointed. This much praised temple turned out as a slight dissapointment. Perhaps because we were not familiar with the buddhist habits. Crowded, noisy etc. But a new experience anyway. The river boat and ferry beat the temple grounds.

Very different. Coming from a country of temples...Wat Arun still caught our eye....it was less crowded and had an air of old times which appealed to us....the view from the top is great too..the climb has a taste of adventure to it.

Awesome place, different from others. Wat Arun is probably one of the symbols of Bangkok. Its architecture is completely different from the majority of temples. It's especially famous for the night time lighting, however it's totally worth visiting during the day. To get there you have to take a 3 Baht ferry from the pier next to Wat Poh. It takes just a couple minutes. The territori of the complex has several buildings, as usual, but the heart of it is the temple itself. It's not the kind of temple you enter, it's a kind of temple you climb!There are several staircases (on the sides of the temple leading to the middle level. And they are already tough ones. Stairs are high and kind of narrow, so you need to be very careful and it's a workout in itself. The middle level opens a nice view. Besides, the decoration of the temple is very interesting. The exterior is decorated with small colored mosaic-like pieces which compose an ornament. You can see women on the territory of the temple shaping and painting them. When you are on a middle level you have two options - down or further up. The top level opens a great view. BUT! The stairs become narrower AND higher. You can hold on the rail wrapped around with rope, still the exercise is a bit scary. Especially when getting down, the stair cases are put at a very acute angle and are nearly vertical, so think of getting down before going up. The temple is not as crowded as Emerald Buddha or War Poh and very unique. I loved it.

Quite a climb. We took a boat trip and the Temple of Dawn was one of the places we stopped. It is a vertical climb to the top but well worth it as the views are amazing. Coming down was interesting as we had been for a Thai massage earlier in the day and our legs really ached. Not somewhere to visit if you are afraid of heights.

Glad we visited. Have been to Bangkok many times, but never quite got round to visiting Wat Arun. This time we made the effort and found it was worth it. We enjoyed climbing up and getting the views and found it q good antidote the Grqnd Palace, which seemed somehow less spiritual than Wat Arun.

Stunning. One of the oldest Buddhist temples of Bangkok , dedicated to the Hindu God 'Arun' (Son) . It is Located on the west bank of the Chao Phraya Rive it is one of the most stunning temples located in Bangkok . It looks stunning at sunset, particularly when lit up at night. The quietest time to visit, however, is early morning, before the crowds.

Boat ride + climbing the temples. Wat Arun is easily accessible by taking a public express boat (not the overcharged tourist boats) which makes for an enjoyable experience in itself. We took the BTS to Saphan Taksin and then a boat from Sathorn Pier up the river. Visiting Wat Arun for a small fee gains access to the grounds around the temple and to climb the temple itself. Climbing the "stairs of doom" is frightening, but exciting, and the view of Bangkok / Chao Phraya river is (probably) worth the risk. But I warn you that these stairs are extremely steep and narrow in depth, so be careful!
nothing other then stairs. its good to see it from a distance, as there is nothing here except very very high stairs. and its quite a high that you have to go up to see the entire old bangkok.

Top 3 Temples to visit in Bangkok. We take our visitors to this temple when in Bangkok. One of our favorites. The artwork of the temple is beautiful. It is less crowded. After you visit Wat Pho the reclining Buddha walk to the near by Fish Market to the Pier and take the boat over for 3 baht. A fun experience. You can climb up the Temple but it is very steep so watch your step. Once your to the top you have amazing views of the Chao Phraya River and the city. Worth your time to visit.

Amazing sight after dark. We did not have time to visit Wat Arun, so instead we took in the grand sight while eating dinner across the river. The temple is lit up as you can see in the photos and it is just beautiful! Relax and watch the river cruises go by... From small boats to grand yachts. The night we planned this, there was actually some kind of festival happening at the Wat, so we could hear music and chanting while we ate. Don't miss!
Temple of Dawn. The view from the river side is great during the sunset time. This temple is a very old temple since long time ago. You can reach there via boat service. 3baht per pax

Take Yourself. It amazes me that there's a company out there that charges to take visitors here. Just get into a cab and tell the taxi to take you here. It shouldn't be more than 100 THB. Once you arrive, just pay the entry fee and start taking pictures.

Small place but worth a visit. A very beautiful place. The stairs were really steep, but it wasn't that bad since there were only a few steps. You can't really go up to the top, it was just the second top floor if I remember correctly.

Amongst the Most Famous Temples in Bangkok. On this trip we were taken to a restaurant directly on the opposite side of the river with Wat Arun in front of us with shining spotlights showing off the mounted porcelain chards and metal objects covering its surface. What a treat. It brought back memories of when I first visited Bangkok in 1989. Pure decadence for the wholly indulgent.

Magnificent . Very accesible place to visit near the Reclining Budhha temple. The ferry boat cost 3 baht one way and just a quick ride going to the temple. By the way make sure (for ladies) when u visit the temple, if wearing shorts bring extra sarong or u'l be ending up renting one (100 baht deposit and 20 baht for rent but the 100 baht will be refunded back when u return the sarong) or just better yet wear jeans or a skirt or dress below the knee. Remember u'l be climbing steep stairs as well. There is a entrance fee 500 baht then a u can take ur time exploring the place. Its true in the reviews here that the view is spectacular so no regrets. Went there 1st week of December and they were restoring the temple, repainting it so there were nets which was an unlikely site especially when taking photos. But I was able to get my way around it. Hopefully it would be done soon. A must see to visit!

Must Visit During Bangkok Visit. A Beautiful Temple and a must Visit Site when you are in Bangkok. You Should take a Ferry from the other Side and visit this temple around the Sunset Time. The Ferry from Lebua/Sheraton Takes about 30 Minutes to Wat Arun, and its an enjoyable Ferry Ride.The Temple Climb is Quite steep, once you Climb its a beautiful View from the Top. And For Photographers its a Delight. You Should spend about an hour or two at Wat Arun.

Amazing. Wat Arun is amazing. The restoration work may make it more interesting, as you can see the difference between the old section and the new ones.If you come from the airport, plan on a full two hours of traveling time, one way.There are lots of little streetside restaurants behind the monestery.

One of the must-see attraction in Bangkok. Go here during the day & night. I prefer enjoying the view at night with the temple beautifully lit up. You have some great options of thai food across this temple & you may want to check them out too

Great view from above. Climbing the steep steps is highly suggested for the great views. Temple is pretty with intricate details. The garden around the temple is beautiful to sit and listen to the birds chirp. Only a few Bahts to enter the temple. Easily to.cross over from Wat Pho's side through a water taxi (and super cheap at only 3 Baht per person).

Stunning, Spectacular. Visit the temple in the morning around 9am in December via ferry. The advantages of visiting the site in the morning is less people (easy to move around), cold breeze and stunning view. Even though the stairs were steep, there is a rail you can hold on to, so don't be scared. The view up from the top was spectacular. Before the left, we stopped by the souvenir shops near the temple entrance and the prices were compareable with other places in Bangkok.
Very High!!. Took a Boat to Opposite, Quite High Building, Hard to Climb. Nice Scenery Though! Ticket was expensive, Place is under construction too!
one of the must see temples. great temple, good perspective as you are onother side of river. fascinating history (as they all do)

Great views, fun ferry ride over.. The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars is that they are currently restoring it and there's scaffolding everywhere, diminishing the aesthetic of this really cool mosaic-tiled wat. The climb up is a little scary but not too hard (it's nerve wracking going down), but the view from up there is totally worth it. It was also a blast meeting travelers from all over as you trade cameras for shots so you can a) avoid selfies and b) actually interact with people. The ferry ride to get there across the river is cheap, fast, and fun as well. And to top it off, the bathrooms on site were impeccably clean which is always a bonus. :)

A must for a Bangkok visit. This was worth the extra track across the river for 3THB. The climb up the narrow stairs was pretty scary especially when coming down them but worth it for the views. We left just as the sun was setting and the place looked amazing. A must see if you go to Bangkok and shouldn't take more then 1/2hr of you time.

The iconic landmark in Bangkok!. Very iconic temple with cool architecture. It is currently under some heavy renovation, 2 of the 4 side towers and the whole backside of the temple is surrounded by scaffolding, kind of a bummer but it shouldn't stop you from visiting if you are in bangkok. The stairs are steep but once you get to the top, you'll have a great view of the chao phraya river and the bangkok skyline in the distance. Take the sky train to BTS Saphan Taksin station at the edge of the river. Walk to the central pier where you can catch the ferries. Most tourists will buy the tickets to the tourist boat. 40 thb one way or 150 thb for an all day ticket. If you are savvy you can catch the local shuttle boats with the orange or yellow flag, one way should be 13 or 18 thb. Take any ferry to stop N8 Ta Tian. You can check out Wat Pho on the same side of the river, it houses the giant reclining buddha, another must visit, 100 thb entrance fee. To get to Wat Arun from N8, take the cross river ferry for 3 thb. Entrance to Wat Arun is 50 thb and closes at 6:00 pm. On the way back you can stop at N5 Rachawongse to visit chinatown (Yaorawat).

Beautiful. It is a beautiful temple, the decorations are complicated and delicate. You can climb on the high steps until almost the half of the height. It is under restoration now, you can see craftsperson are working on them, during which is a good way to know how the decorations are done for the temple.

Great place! MUST go!... and climb a little!!!. Amazing temple... outstanding architecture and view from the steps. One of the best attractions in Bangkok that includes a ferry ride. Don´t miss it! Go with tennis shoes, not flip flops :)

Nice temple by the river. Worth a visit. Steep steps to overcome climbing up the tower. Ladies to wear long pants for convenient. Dress code required for ladies, hot pants or shorts will required cover up as a respect to the religious ground.

Temple under major renovation during our visit. The truth is that after a day of visiting temples and surrounded by annoying people who were more interested in taking pictures than enjoying the sights, it was difficult to appreciate wat arun having left it for our last stop on this very hot day.The temple was also undergoing renovation so unable to see it in its full gloryWhat did help is that you could climb up the temple so made for a more adventurous visit than the nearby others in Bangkok

Precarious climb!. Took this in today before the flower market, I admit I hummed and hawed about whether or not to do it, as the entrance fee is 50baht, but I eventually did. It's worth it! The climb is precarious and scary going up, hellish and terrifying going bsck down, so keep your wits about you when you do it. The views are pretty good, but there is a lot of restoration work going on right now, and at the time of day I went (13.00 ish) it was pretty packed. Also, be aware that there is a clothing restriction for female identified people, they will give you a sarong if you don't measure up.

Spectacular- a must see. This is not an elaborate temple, like many of the ones in Bangkok. It is not covered in gold or sparkles. But it is probably the most stunning temple we have seen in Thailand. The view from the ground is great, and if you climb all the stairs to the top you get a beautiful view of Bangkok in all directions. It is well worth the 3 baht to get across the river and the 50 baht entrance fee. Just make sure you get to the right pier that shuttles you across the river, or else a private boat will try to get you to pay 200-800 baht for the 2 minute trip.
Steep climb. Another temple worth visiting in Bangkok. Steep steps take you to a nice view. The river views are nice.
Really lovely. The architecture is really amazing. Climbing the steps of the main temple could be a challenge but it's fun. At night, with all the lighting, the Wat looks even more attractive.

Nice Temple. Was in Bangkok for a praying and shopping trip with my wife and went to this temple for pray. a very very nice temple to visit. there are 2 booth to rent amulets too and you also can get blessing from the arjan in the temple.

A colourful must see. It’s really interesting to take a closer look at the colourful decorations of the temple – you can climb up to a small terrace (the staircase is VERY steep and it’s actually easily to get up than to get down). The view from the terrace to the river and the grand palace is well as the city is worth the climbing efforts!

Not another Budha, beware of leg pain. After having visited some other Wats earlier the day Wat Arun was the last one and proved that for Wats it's not the same as for churches: seen one, seen all.It's a great temple to visit to have a nice view over the city. It's basically a tower where you have to climb up so prepare of leg pain the next day.Having seen it once I will go there a second time on my next visit in BKK

Wat Arun -- The Nr. 1 Landmark of Bangkok. Wat Arun is beautiful to visit as well as to have a look at @ sunset or in the night-time.Is again one of these places you must have seen. Take the Bus boat on the river and pass by per boat or visit Arun Residences around 18:00 hours and just have a drink and enjoy the life at the river.

Light show after sunset. Stick around after sunset with a camera, as they light up Wat Arun with colourful lighting. Some of it was undergoing renovations, but that wasn't a problem, and I'm glad they're trying to maintain it.
Favorite temple in Bangkok!. Hop on a boat to go and visit the most beautiful temple in Bangkok! Wat Arun has a great view to offer and is very unique. Definitely my favorite in the City of Angels!
Vat Arun. It's a lovely piece of architecture situated on the banks of the river. 360 degree view of the city from the upper terrace. Must visit, particularly early in the morning.
great view. 50 THB to enter, worth climbing the stairs for the view. Opened until 6:00PM. Located near Wat Pho, took a ferryboat (3 THB each way by boat) to Wat Arun

Scale the heights. We visited this Wat last on our trip, but were attracted to its tall beauty from across the river. I strongly recommend that you go, but only if you can climb - this one has many very steep stairs but affords a lovely view. Also, since they are repairing the main towers, you can get a close view of workmen painstakingly restoring the unique, ceremic faces and flowers. I understand also that this is a must at sundown, so I will make a point of going back at that time.
Amazing!. We took a boat trip and stopped off at the Temple of Dawn. It is quite a climb to the top but you get amazing views and it is definitely worth it. Quite scary coming back down though!

Not our favorite - hard to get to. Luckily we had a boat ride before hand and went through the canals and saw all the houses = then we had a great lunch and visited this temple. It was steep and some people chose not to go up or down. It was vey spiritual. I would not put this in my top temples -- even though the view was great.
very nice. a great place to visit on a river trip. The steps are quite steep, but you rearded at the top. A good time had by all.

Must visit by sunset!. It is very beautiful to visit when sunset. You can walk up the stairs outside the temple to have a better look over the city and the river side. But the stairs are very steep and windy, so please be careful. Dress code applied so be prepared for that too. Transportation is quite easy too. Go to the Pier at Saphan Taksin BTS station, buy 1-day ferry pass (THB150), then you can go to all sightseeing spots introduced in the booklet of 1-day ferry pass, including Grand Palace, Wat Pho - Reclyning Buddha statue, Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun).

Arrive by boat, if you can. To get to Wat Arun, we took the Chao Phraya Tourist boat from Sathorn pier which is a short walk from the Saphan Taksin station of the BTS Skytrain. The tourist boat costs 40 baht for a single ride, or you can pay 150 baht for a day ticket. Stop 8 of the trip boat lets you off on the opposite side of the river from the temple - the view is great - I took several photos from the water. Once on shore, look for the ferry to take you across which costs 3 baht. The temple grounds are fascinating and worth the visit. If you don't mind heights, you can climb up the temple and see the view. I find it hard to climb steps, so I didn't go up, but still enjoyed the visit. Well worth seeing!
Something what i can say.. I like it because it is attractive. What i dislike is you have to cross the river before you reach the wat arun temple. But all over is still good.
Worth it!. Only 3 baht to cross the river then 50 baht to enter it was totally worth it! It has a old charm and the experience of walking up to the top is thrilling also!

Worth the visit if you're in the area. Pretty good view from the top. We went in the middle of the day and it is nice enough. We saw this after the grand palace so I guess it's not as impressive in comparison. Worth it if you are travelling up the river anyway.

Enjoyed my climbing. After lunch got there by river. Extra payment for entrance - 50 Baht per person. Rented a pashmina as knees should be covered. Hat was on my head. Climbing was challenging as the ladders are extremely narrow and steep. Great overview was on Bangkok and river. Walls of Wat Arun in some places were covered around with a blue fabric to protect from writings on them: but on that material it was possible to leave your sign or doodle what actually I had done. Unfortunately the rain started and we had to leave such amazing place.Downstairs there were lots of kiosks with souvenirs and possibility to put on a Royal Dress and decorate yourself as Queen. Got Royal impressions about the visit.

Enjoyable visit. We visited Wat Arun as we had ventured into the city to see Wat Pho. Wat Arun is a short boat ride across the river and if in the area is well worth a visit. This is a small complex unlike Wat Pho where you can spend time looking around the various buildings and temples. In contrast Wat Arun is just the temple and surrounding grounds. You can climb to the top if fit - I only managed to the first tier - suggest you do not wear a long skirt and flip flops! The top tier of steps are extremely steep.

Great city views. Beutiful temple Steep climb up , two different levels Great views Spectacular temple architecture Ladies need to hire a should scare and a sari if in shorts Deposit money is refunded on return of clothing

High rise temple - Wat Arun. Have to climb good amount of steps to reach to the top of Wat Arun. However the view from the top is good and rewarding. Can click nice panoramic pics. Also at the base of the temple you can click photos with traditional costumes (really good ones)

Enjoy the peace after excitement. Just as the name suggest, it is a wonderful place to visit before sunset. After you climbed up all those crazily steep and narrow stone stairs onto the half top of the wat, while legs still a bit trembling, suddenly got astonished by the sunset overview of the river bank. Under all the shade of golden sunshine, the bustling river bank actually appears to be quite peaceful. However, calm down before you step off each stair as they seem to be more steep when going down.Wat Arun is just beside a pier, so most tourists get here by boat. Be cautious of the swindler who lobby you to take a "much cheaper" boat tour from some private piers. He/She pretends to give you a very friendly local advice. Actually, the boat tour from public piers costs about 500THB, but they will charge you 2000+THB.

It's a Must. Wat Arun is among my 5 top favorite Bangkok's sights. It's nice to reach it from the other bank of the river, by boat. They keep on renovating and replacing the old painted porcelain, with new ones. I could stay and look at their work for a long time. You can stroll the nice gardens surrounding the "stupa". If you are in good shape, you can climb up the stairs to the top. After visiting the temple, it's possible to take a boat ride along the river.

Magnificent Supta!. Best time to go is sunset. We werent able to catch it being lit. Compared to Wat Prakaew, you can relax somehow while enjoying the view of people coming in and out crossing Chao Praya. It has an entrace fee for tourists while free for locals.

Bangkok masterpiece. The most important Buddhist temple in Bangkok. It is on the shore of the river and it has a great look at night from the other side. You can visit the complex by night to enjoy the privacy and the serenity. Still you should pay a visit in the morning to visit the temple and why not, if you are capable you can enjoy an outside climb and enjoy the view from the top but you have to be careful since the upper part gets very steep.
Must see, beautiful temple. I loved that the whole temple is decorated with broken pieces of china. Beautiful and creative. Great view when you can hike up to the upper sections.
Go for sunset!. Great little climb, cost 50baht (£1) bargain! Took the ferry over which cost 3baht, some places charging 1300baht for an hour tour, just use the ferry to cross for 3p :)

Must see BKK. This is a Bangkok must see, not to be missed, and easy to get to via the river. Many different architectures and styles to buildings are present. Beautiful! If your a photographer plan for extra time!

The jewel of Thailand. One of the main attractions in Bangkok and I have to say you cannot miss it or not visit it! I would recommend do it in the morning when you are fresh as there are quite a few steps to go all the way up! Also the steps are very narrow so people with fear of height might feel themselves uncomfortable, however the view from the top platform totally worth it!

A must see!. Visited this temple a couple of times. Love taking the boat to get there. Try to climb it if you can. It's also nice to have dinner opposite the temple at night when it's all enlighten. Definitely worth visiting.
View. Travelers would like view when climbing up and noodle soup at the ferry departure on the other side of the river.

Great from a Distance.. The Temple of Dawn is a significant landmark for all visitor to Bangkok. I believe it was known from the explanation of the local guide in the morning floating market tour. The site is very impressive during the morning hour. However aside from the majestic post the temple has over the Chaophya River, the temple ground is relatively simple. The Temple of Dawn or Wat arun, the same meaning in Thai, is part of the grand sightseeing of Bangkok.
So incredibly beautiful!!. Wat Arun is one of the most stunning buildings I've ever seen! Be sure you go see it because it's one of the most recognized sacred buildings in the world.

Beautiful.. This temple is beautiful. The pagoda is a enormous and you can actually climb it to the top and take photos. The stairs are quite steep but I watched a little toddler climb it. There are rails to help you get up. I went on a weekday and it seemed quite busy but I assume weekends would be worse. I still have room to take photos with one or two people in the way so it wasn't too bad.I also have to mention their friendly kitten mascot who roamed around chasing leaves and cuddling with tourists. He was adorable!!!Cost:50B for foreigners. Sarongs available for hire 20B for women with short shorts.

Amazing temple. We arrived via the river so we had a very nice view of the temple. The temple is amazing because of its intricate design. For those who want to climb to the highest point, it is important that you have strong legs. The view from the top is very nice. There is a temple where any one can enter as long as one is decent. So wear clothes with sleeves and long pants.

A must visit place. This temple is located opp chao praya river. You have to take a boat which cost THB 3 to cross the river. There will be lots of people waiting to lure you to the long tail boat which cost THB 100, do not take it. Nothing much to see in this temple except the tall tower and you have to climb the steep stairs up. However, it gives a beautiful view of the city. The designs on it are so beautifully crafted and intricate. Entrance fees cost THB 50. Nevertheless, it is still a beautiful temple. Maybe you can see the sun rise there. Be extra careful when climbing up and down the steep stairs.

Take a Camera!. One my 2nd day we went for a visit around Bangkok to all of the temples, it was amazing and the Wat Arun does not disappoint!!The magnitude of this statue has to be seen to be believed.

Top of the Mark. This is one of the most intense sights around Bangkok. If you enjoy the Temple scene in Thailand this HAS to be seen. It's quite intricate and very elaborate. It's only 50฿ To get in! It's pretty easy to access most of it. Unless you want to climb up in it. It's out of my league! You can come across by boat from the flower market, I saw bicycle tours, cabs, walkers from the bridge. There are many sights around here. Dig in!

Breathtaking Temple. The Wat Arun, perhaps the most photographed sight in Bangkok, is magnificent. Its' architecture is beautiful and its location along the Chao Phraya River add to its beauty. It is worth taking the time to see and located in close proximity to the Grand Palace and the Reclining Buddha.
Magnificient. Majestic architecture. You need to have energy to climb up the steep steps but you won't regret when you see the beautiful view from the top.

must visit. really beautiful and breathtaking view of the Chao Phraya from the top of the Stupa.The grounds of the temple is beautiful as well. Remember to cover up as you won't be allowed to enter the temple if you are dressed in shorts or sleeveless.take the 5 minute boat ride across the river. It's more fun! Try some of the food around the temple as well. However, they are more pricey because it's a top tourist spot.

gorgeous. i like where it's located but didn't get the chance to see the sunset here. Hike up to the top of the temple to see the view of the Chao Phraya. Be careful with the stairs that are steep and uneven

Heart stopping climb. Amazingly detailed architecture and art. To really appreciate it, you have to climb up the most ridiculously steep steps. Talk about a heart stopping, vertigo inspiring experience....especially when you start to come down! Views of the city and river from the top were breathtaking.Yes the temple is being renovated, and yes there is lots of scaffolding, but then great art work always needs maintenance. Would still highly recommend a visit.Get there by taking a tourist boat 40 baht, then a river taxi 3 baht.

Beautiful temple. Stunning detail work and decorations around the temple, great view from the top tier. Take the 3 baht ferry across the river after visiting Wat Pho or the Grand Palace and get some snacks from the food carts at the ferry crossing to keep your blood sugar up!
one of my favorite places. one of my favorite places, up those stairs was like going to heaven, art is impossible to explain !!
