Worth a jaunt up the river. Accessible by boat or road. Great structure something different in temples after being templed out across Asia.

must visit!. beautiful architecture, represents the thai culture. after visit, you can shop around the area where you get pick up by speed boat to wat arun. the atmosphere are like traditional market, the price shocked me, very very cheap. cheaper than any shop in the entire shopping place in Bangkok as far as i know (I've been to asiatique, MBK, platinum mall) if you wanna shop things like traditional-Thai-souvenirs for your friends in school, college, or office in large amounts, go here and bargain.

stunning structure by the river. unfortunately, we were prohibited to climb up the temple...but it was still worth our visit to look closely at its colorfully decorated spires..do not miss the lighting of the temple at night time~~~

Great to fill in some time. Had some time to kill with wife and 3 children. Lovely and interesting temple. Getting there from Koh San Rd half the fun. Caught the orange flag boat from pier 13. Tickets bought at pier 3 x 15 baht, kids not full price, get off at pier 8. Next bait to cross river 3 baht each, eachway. In return to pier 13 buy tickets once on boat. Overall good trip and good photos.

Beautiful at night. I and my friends didn't have a chance to go during the day, but took a boat ride in the evening and you know what it's absolute Beautiful!!!. We felt very bad that we couldn't make it during the open hour.

Some tips. - Cross the river at the Jetty in front of the Wat Pho - 3 Baht/1 -way/person- entrance is 100 Baht - great fun climbing the steep stairs and the view is really nice / but you can just watch the temple from outside if you're short on money- no need to buy water - there's a fountain with drinking water so fill up your own bottle (in this little pavilion next to river, in front of the temple gate)- currently, some parts are being repaired and in scaffolds - but great to watch the patient workers plastering all those little pieces back together- there are clean toilets inside the little market (it's free - but nice to leave some coins)- have a cappuccino or artisanal ice-cream (39 Baht) at the coffee shop, right next to the jetty (on the left) before heading back to the other side
Many Sections Closed for Renovation. Always great to see up close to half of the surrounding towers are under renovation. I do love the views it offers of the River and the city skyline.
Take time to get the insperation of this palce. I liked everthing. But please dressed with long trouses, because it is not only a tourist place. respect the culture
Crowded. Temples can be a bit over rated...very crowded ...had trouble finding info on it's history and significance....."
Temple Review. Its not that nice but if you are there i would suggest you visit it. I have seen many other ones so maybe thats the reason.

So tall, good views, good price.. Little bit more out of the way than the other temples but I think it's the best one and one of the cheapest too.Tall with very steep steps (careful not to fall!) to the top but this makes it a bit of an adventure and the views from the top are good. The temple is covered in bits of pottery or china and it's very beautiful to look at. Remember to dress respectfully/conservatively.

Nice place to visit at night too!. It's a nice place to visit at night! Only drawback would be that you can't enter the temple itself. You may look around the compound, enjoy the beautifully lit temple roof and structures.

Loved it!!!. It is really amazing, this was the last temple we visited on our trip to Bangkok and we all enjoyed every minute there. When you see the high, long stairs up do not be afraid, just climb!!! You won't regret when you get to the top and admire the beautiful view.

One of the most impressive temples in Bangkok. Don't miss a trip to Wat Arun and surrounding areas. Although on the other side of the Chao Praya River, there are many ferries leaving every half hour. The intricate detail on the temple's facade is gorgeous, but the trek up the stairs into the temple is not for the faint of heart (very steep steps).
Best for a temple with a difference. This temple was different to alot of the others. It provided great views from the top, the stairs are incredibly steep however. It is worth the trip.

Scary. No doubt that this temple is one of the best, must see temple in Bangkok. But if you are afraid of heights might want to consider giving this a skip. The temple is very steep, my stomach was quest all the way up, and even worse coming down. But definitely worth it. Also the boat to cross the river is only 3 baht. Careful u don't get scammed. Almost happen to us. A local tried to sell a boat trip for 1500 baht. So careful!

Nice view, steep climb. My visit to Wat Arun was hampered by rain, but still worthwhile. Remants from royal ceremony the previous day (flower displays, etc.) very popular for colorful pictures. The temple itself is uniquely ornate, decorated with what looks like second-hand porcelain china. Was able to climb up to midway point on the main tower before rains came back. Great view of the river, Palace, and cityscape.
Beautiful stupas and temples. Beautiful stupas and temples, eventhough we could not visit some parts due to renovations. As with all temples and museums in Thailand: bring your own toilet paper/

If you're scared of heights DO NOT CLIMB TO THE TOP!. Wat Arun is a beautiful temple and is a great site to see, however, in order to climb to the top of the temple for a great view of Bangkok you have to climb some incredibly steep stairs! I am not usually someone who is particularly worried about heights, but coming down such steep steps was not an experience I would want to repeat any time soon! Still an excellent trip though!
Great place to visit. A must see for all first timers in bangkok. Worth the 50 baht entrance fee. The view at the top is pretty great. Visit this when you go see thr grand palace and wat pho

Just amazing. It is on the west bank of the Chao Praya river and is directly opposite Wat Pho. The design is very different to the other temples you can visit in Bangkok. Given beauty of the architecture and the fine craftsmanship it is not surprising that Wat Arun is considered by many as one of the most beautiful temples in Thailand. The spire (prang) on the bank of Chao Phraya River is one of Bangkok's world-famous landmarks and is over 70 metres high. You can climb the central prang if you wish, the steps are very steep but there is a railing to balance yourself. Awe inspiring.

Nothing special, scary for small children and people who fear steep stairs!. There isn't really a lot to see at this temple. I think it looks best from a distance so if you pass by it, that can be enough. Me and my girlfriend have climbed it and the stairs are incredibly steep. You can almost call it plain dangerous! Visit the temple if you're really interested, but for me it wasn't worth the entry fee.

Great view. What's cool about this temple is that you can climb up it to get a great view across the river and Bangkok. Apart from that, there is not a lot more to see and do, which is also kind of nice after having spent considerable time exploring the Grand Palace complex and Wat Pho.

An Amazing Structure. After your visit to Wat Prah Keo and the Grand Palace, take the river taxi directly across the river (3 baht) to Wat Arun. The structure is about 70 meters high and if you are brave enough, you can ascend the stairs to very near the top. The stairs are very steep and going down is much more difficult, and scary, than going up. This is yet another Wat that is not to be missed.
Worth your 30 mnts. It's by the way when you visit grand palace, asiatique, etc. go there in late afternoon to avoid strong sun

Not so crowded. Combine a trip across the Chao Phraya in one of the ferries near the Grand Palace and Wat Po to this interesting temple. Much less crowded that anything on the other side of the river. Magnificent views from the top.
place of worship. I liked everything about this place.It is abit crowded but you have to accept as it is a tourist attraction

Vertigo. I was amazed at the steep staircases! Could not go up to the top due to acute vertigo but the view of the Bangkok skyline was lovely. The ferry from one side to the other was on 3 Baht per trip!

Beautiful temple surrounded by touts. Loved the temple, absolutely magnificent, especially evening or morning times when the sun hits it a certain angles
Hated the hard core touts, totally ignore them seems the best option
Amazing temple on river. Of course, another incredible must-see in Bangkok. You can climb up this one if you like, or just look at it from the ground. You can also see it well from the river boat.

Prepare to climb. Frequent cross river boats take you to wat arun from wat pho .Its just across the river.You can actually climb the entire height of the temple.However stairs are very steep but the view is fantastic.Travel early morning or late evening to avoid the harsh Bangkok heat while climbing.Entry fee is quite less,i think 100TBT and included a free watter bottle

Lovely Place. Fantastic site to visit whilst in Bangkok, a short and cheap boat ride from the Grand Palace. Worth climbing to the top (not for the faint hearted!) The only thing that lets the place down is the amount of touts trying to sell cheap tat and canal rides. If you get a chance, visit The Deck for evening meals to view Wat Arun lit up beautifully.
Beautiful dawn temple. Beautiful and unique architecture next to the river. Cambodian style Buddhist temple. A must see at sunset.

Been there more than twice and still like it!. Wat Arun has always been one of the most stunning temple in Thailand for me. To go there we need to cross the Chao Praya River by the small ferry which is one of the most local things to do in Bangkok. The entrance fee is not expensive, and the Stupa/Temple/Pagoda is definitely worth a climb!
Good one. A must see temple. It may look daunting,but the climb up the very steep steps to the gallery...the view over the river is worth it.Dont try in rain

Gem across the river. Separated from the main tourist area by a river sits this beautiful Wat Arun. We went before lunch in October. The place was half empty, which was nice to explore without the push of other people. Tip: Come at a later or earlier time. The heat at noon and our hunger shortened our stay.
Awesome. Really enjoyed this temple. No two temples are alike. The steps get steeper each level you climb. Definitely worth it. Great views when you get to the final level.

Magnificent.. The journey across the river to reach the temple itself was splendid, and the Temple of Dawn was magnificent as the light reflected around the glasses. When you climb atop the Temple, the view of the surroundings will be stunning and memorable.
Great views and pics. Just a little hot as your waiting for the sun to go down but from the bar across. Just amazing views . Took lots of great photos while we drank expensive beer.

Wat Arun is a must see!. Wat Arun is worth checking out in the daytime because you get to see all of the intricacies of the art work within the construction of the temple. I thought the steps were easy to go up and down on. There were two small children climbing the steps with ease too. The kids were no more than four years old. It's a interesting visit for the entire family. By the way, it's very humid at Wat Arun and at Wat Pho.

Wonderful Temple. This is temple is different than others because you walk up the outside of it rather than walk inside it, the steps are vary step and could be dangerous. It's a very interesting place to visit for a couple of hours. Well worth a visit.
Must See. The temple is truly magnificent. Well worth a trip across the river. And if you are game, climb up to the top and capture a splendid view of the river and nearby surroundings.

Better to visit in Evening. Wat Arun is great historial place and the evening is perfect time cause during the day you'll sweat because of the heat and humit.The view of the Chao Phraya river is beautiful in the evening time.

Beautiful place. Our friend has recommended this place, It was really nice and worth for visiting. The location is on bank of Chaophraya River. If you go up on the big pagoda, and then you will see the view of the River King clearly. It's worth for visiting.

Statue behind 10Baht Coin. Flip and have a look on the 10Baht coin, the building is Wat Arun. Wat Arun located opposite Grand Palace, Wat Pho & Sanam Luang. Wat Arun is hundreds years old and can be traced back during Ayutthaya Kingdom.Go to Pier 8 (Tha Tien) and get the ferry crossing Chao Phraya River to the Wat Arun. The ferry is different from the Chao Phraya boat. It cost 3Baht crossing the river by boat. Either sunset or sunrise, Wat Arun has the different views. For photographers, choose your preferred time slot for the best shot.You need to pay for the entrance fees which cost u 50Baht.

Love this Temple. This is a huge temple, with some interesting history, and the guide said this was also figured in one of Thailand's most colourful festivals, the Royal Kathin. Sadly this will occur on Octorber. 50 Baht for this isn't a waste of money.

Nice temple to visit in Bkk. it's a nice placeto visit while in Bangkok. You have to go on a boat ride to get to the temple area. before you get to this temple, you can feed the fish in the river with breadloaf available on boat. Wat Arun is an old Buddhist temple, you have to dress politely when in here.You can climb upstairs to get a nice cityview from the top of the temple.Beware the steep and narrow steps when climbing up or down the temple, surely you dont want to trip down from that height..afterwards you can buy some souvenirs from the stalls area right adjacent to the temple building. the price is quite cheap, especially if you are willing to bargain to get the best offer possible.
Stunning Temple. We saw the Temple of Dawn by night. It was all lit up and was soo beautiful to see. On my next visit I would like to go by day as well, but night time I believe is better
Holiday. Nice place it was raining when we were there but still managed to get around. Access via river boat.

Best visited at night. Too crowded during the day - completely breathtaking by night (as ironic as that may be). The river cruise and the night cycle tour provide a great way to check out Wat Arun away from the crowds.

Subliem Pice of Art at the river bank of the Chao Praya river. Dont't get it wrong, from far it is already beautiful but when you get closer it is even more. The green colour that dominates the temple can not been seen from the river or from the road. It has so many beautiful things to look at from the ceramich tiles to the creation of flowers in ceramic and the giants all over the place. You can climb 2 levels to have a nice view from the river and the city of Bangkok. The Royal Palace is not so far a way so the veiw is subliem. Worth the trip! Admission fee for Internationals as in most of the temples in Bangkok.
Steep Dawn. Beautiful temple but the climb up is very steep and the climb down is even worse so not for the faint of heart or the weak-kneeded.
fantastic. Everybody who visits bangkok must see place wonderful architecture and culture amazing view from the temple
Great place must visit. Bring comfy shoes, and climb th stairs the view is amazing.I heard the sunset and sunrise is gorgeous from here.We visited during the day and it was very hot.

Amazing. Any of the many temples are amazing in and around Bangkok. I would highly recommend going. There are many tours that are set up in hotels to get you there are take the Sky Train, and walk a bit but take in local culture as well.
Must see. Ancient building of Tkhmer culture- who never been to Cambodia must see this. A lot of details , nice place to take photos.

Great Temple. It was awesome! If you are scared of hights, Like me, it can be hard to climb the temple. But the view on top is nice and worth it! Also the lightning at the evening is really cool! You can take pictures from the other side of the river!

Perfect holiday place !. Temple is impressive, beautiful gardens,walking distance from city ,sunny day Thailand holiday life is wonderful .we had knowledgeable guide Mr Juank thank you so much .once is not enough I will back on next yrs.

Quite the experience!. Our tour guide took us to the Temple of Dawn, I must say that this temple is very beautiful especially when viewing from far away. Me and the hubs went up and down the steep stairs, different experiences for these directions. Going up was alright, just a bit tiring but going down was another story. The stairs are steep and if you're afraid of heights this one is not for you. I don't think you won't miss much if you didn't go up the Temple, the views were pretty but not worth the hassle of going down. Better to see from a far.
temple day. The is another superb Temple to visit, but if you are not good with steep steps just admire it from outside don't pay the entrance fee.
great. great place to go but watch out from the fake guides they will tell you its closed due to construction work and don't forget the fairy cost you only 3 BHT

Only need an hour here but worth the trip. when we went it rained so the view was a little grey but still worth the visit. The steps to the second tier are very steep and some may find it hard coming down but you need not climb them. Lovely view over the river and down town. Try and visit near night fall as the site looks impressive when lit at night.

Steep stairs. Took the taxi boats from Shangri-La pier and clearly got robbed a bit since we paid 700 bhat! the Wat Arun looks impressive when you get to the food of it. We climbed up the stairs and although you can't get all the way to the top, it was still worth paying the entrance which was 50 Bhat for each person. Be very careful when climbing the stairs, they are extremely steep.

Steep Climb with a nice view of the city. Wat Arun is part of the three big temples you can see while in Bangkok. If you're running short of time, you can probably miss coming to this temple as the main thing to do here is climb the step to the middle level of the temple. The entry is only 50THB (cheapest of the big three) and the 3THB river crossing boat makes it easy to access. However, if you do get a chance, take a photo of this temple from afar during sunset!
Wat arun. Lovely temple with beautiful ceramic inlays. Great views of Bangkok from the top. Tip- get a long tail boat to take you, it will drop you for 30 mins before taking you to other sights.

Simply stunning.. This is easily the most impressive temple I have seen in my albeit somewhat limited experience within Thailand. It is set within beautiful, peaceful gardens with smaller buildings decked with ornate and garish yet beautiful decoration in the Thai tradition. It was fantastic fun scaling the ever steeper staircases almost to the top, where 360 degree panorama of Bangkok old and new awaits the gaze.Definitely worth a detour from the Grand Palace but don't get conned by the boat boys charging 900, 1200, 1800 baht for an hour's tour on the canal/river. You can get them down to about 500 for this.

Wat a set of steps. Easy to get to by boat small landing fee of 30bhat. Tickets to get in are only 50baht. Takes about forty minutes to go round. Great set of steps. To get to the toppish part the steps are almost vertical. Great views of bangkok from the top as well. Definitely worth spending some time here... Just remember, you'll need to cover up if you're a lady. If you forget though... There's shawls available to rent. Quote of the trip from my wife... Buddhists seem to have a love of peace and dangerous steps!
Great views. Can be a little tiring climbing the stairs but the views are well worth it. Amazing architecture and well worth the visit!
Worth the visit. The steps are quite steep but nice temple to visit to get view of the Bangkok city. One should either go in the early morning or late evening before the sunset.

Great views and awesome climb up and down. We spent the first part of the day at the Grand Palace and walked from there to the reclining Buddha and then onto Pier 9. We took a 3 Bhat ferry ride across the river to the Wat Arun. we enjoyed the steep steps climb up and down
excellent heritage. very well maintained beautiful structure ,people around are polite andwell behaved. they are not after your money
Pretty lame spot. So small, not much to do there, a bit hard to get to. Very hard to figure out which boat to take as people didn't speak much English and weren't very helpful.

Worth the Climb. A must see temple, look for all the broken china adorning the temple. It may look daunting,but the climb up the very steep ( I mean VERY steep) steps to the gallery...the view over the river is worth it.
wonderful. its one of the most impressive temples in bangkok. also bangkoks town landmark. great chinese ceramics. a must see direct on the bench of the chao praya river.

Challenging. Climbing to the top stairs was one of the most challenging task for me, since I am once afraid of height. However, I enjoyed the reward, as the view on the top is very beautiful, especially the view across the river.Also found some interesting history story between Thai and China, thanks to my Thai companion and kind people at the temple

See it at night!. This is a lovely temple. But it you want to experience it's best appearance, go to 'The Deck' across the river and enjoy the view. It's beautifully lit and looks wonderful from across he shimmering river. Enjoy.

My Favourite Wat (Temple) in Bangkok. There are many Wats in Bangkok buit this is a personal favourite of mine. It was my first ever wat visited in Thailand on my first trip so holds a special place for me.The first time I went I walked across one of the bridges and to the temple on foot, getting lost and spending two hours of traipsing very non-tourist roads to find it (this was fun).However the ferry peer near the Grand Palace will take you across to Wat Arun for the current sum of 3 baht (about 5p in GBP) and you get to see a bit of the river as well.Wat Arun rises above the river. It's a serene little slice of paradise in my opinion, you can climb the steps up to the first and second levels and look over the river (be careful level 2 is steep and feels worse on the way down!)Also while you will currently pay 500 baht (£10/$14) for a visit to the Grand Palace, Wat Arun is a steal at 50 baht (£1/$1.5).So go spend your £1.10 on a ferry ride there and back, and a wander in one of Bangkok's prettiest Wats.
Beautiful.. We got a ferry across the river. 3 baht each and only took a few minutes. You can climb up the steps to the most amazing view. It's steep!! A bit of a leg wobbler but totally worth it!!

Great Temple. Liked the way you have to climb up the stairs to reach the temple. Good view when you get to the top.
Al-tough, we did not visit at the dawn time, which I believe it is specialty.

Walk to the top even If you're scared of heights. This temple is amazing. The porcelain decorations are one of a kind. Everyone should visit this when in Bangkok and climb to the top, even if you're scared of heights. The view of bangkok is one of a kind.

One of the greatest temples we have seen. Bangkok is filled with wonderful temples, many in easy proximity. This one, easily reached by ferry for 3 baht (9 US cents) seems a bit magical on the approach. Linger away from tourists to pick up the essence of the place. Go early to avoid the crowds. And climb anything you can.
Beautiful and Grand. Coolest way to get there is through the Chao Phraya River with speed boat. Very beautiful surroundings and Grand structure
stunning!. The most scenic, breathtaking sunsets go down over wat arun. Catch it from the other side of the river.

Make sure you wear the right clothes. We didn't plan to go here but just on the spur of the moment decided. Because of this we weren't dressed appropriately to enter a temple. We wen't stressed because every other temple they had offered clothing to cover those who had shoulders or legs showing. We got there and had to pay 50B to enter the temple, then 20B + 100B deposit for wrap around skirt thing, then another 20B + 100B deposit for a handkerchief to cover our shoulders. The stairs are VERY steep, and because of the rain they were quite slippery. There is no signs or any type of information about the temple so do your research before you go to understand it. Was very beautiful.
My favourite sight in Bangkok. Out of all of temples in Bangkok, Wat Arun is easily my favourite. It is simply stunning.The stairs up are steep but it is worth the effort! Good views from the top.

a great place to visit when in the centre of bangkok. best place to see wat arun is across the river in an old cafe which has an upstairs seating area which affords a great view to have a bite to eat and a few cold beers while watching the sun set and the lights come on to shine wat arun into the sky

Bangkok Landmark. It is one of the most beautiful temple in Bangkok which must not be missed by anyone, it looks even more better during evening when the lights at the temple turned on and spotlights cast on the temple, the color of the temple just look vibrant and brilliant along with the color tone of sunset sky which is good for photography session.

Thailand's most iconic temple!. Wat Arun is one of the most photographed structures in Thailand, with great photos obtained at night when the temple is bathed in brilliant artificial lighting; early morning, when the sun reflects off the thousands of pieces of porcelein studding the temple; and at dusk, when it is silhouetted against the setting sun. The impressive central prang (Khmer-style tower) rises about 70 meters above the banks of the Chao Praya River, and is particularly impressive when viewed from a boat on the river. But, also be sure to visit the temple site itself and climb up as far as possible for greater appreciation of the artistic beauty of the temple and the views from above. A must visit for anyone traveling to Thailand!

Enjoy the climb. A visit to Wat Arun is definitely worth crossing the river for!We'd been to Bangkok before and did not bother to do so, so on this visit, we made it a must!We climbed to the top and enjoyed the views, beware, the stairs are very steep! But it is worth it if you are fit enough to make the climb!The surrounds of Wat Arun do not provide to much to look at, but I think the climb of the Wat is the main event!Make the crossing if you have time, I believe the best view of Wat Arun is at night from a cross the river, I'll have to do that next time!

Old style thai pagoda. wat arun is an old thai style pagoda next to the river. Go early in the morning around 9am when it is open, at noon as it gets extremely hot and humid. In the evening, they light the temple when it looks really pretty from outside even though the temple closes at 6pm. At the end of your day take boat to "ta tien" boat station, where you get a beautiful view of the temple. The steps to the top are steep, those who are scared of heights can climb 1st and 2nd set of stairs but not the 3rd.

Absolutely stunning - must see!!. What an absolutely awe-inspiring temple this is - I honestly cannot recommend it enough. Climbing up to the top is not for the faint-hearted - it's very steep - but the views are more than worth it. We chartered a boat to take us here and on to Wat Pho just across the other side of the river which seemed to be the best way to see both. We felt like we could look at the temple all day and still not be done, so give yourself at least an hour to make the most of being in such a beautiful place.
Amazing. We only had three days in Bangkok so were squeezing things in and I'm glad we saw this. It's an absolute Incredible and beautiful temple. An absolute must see.
Beautiful temple. You need to climb narrow and high stairs in order to enjoy the temple. It is worth doing so. It is next to the river so the best way to get there is by a boat
Beautiful. Amazing temple with exquisite detail in it design. Lots of stairs was fun to climb and see the views of the river!
Fabulous. Our guide gave a comprehensive tour and conversation about this temple and the religion. It was great. So enjoyed and recommend.

Nice view of the river and city. Very nice place to visit. Near the river, the entrance is only 50baht (1,20€). There are a lot of reclained stairs but you should go the the highest point because the river view.

Beautiful temple. To to to this temple we have to accross the river about 5 minutes. The temple is beautiful and artistic. We can use traditional thai clothes too. Around the temple there are a lot of merchant which sell souvenir items such as T-shirt, and other thai handycraft with affordable price.

1 thing down from my bucket list. wat arun has been on my bucket list ever since i first saw it in imagesso when i first saw it, it was not up to mark (may be i expected too much from it). but, that was because i saw it from the back as i entered from the back gate wat arun is as magnificent as one can think. its structure its architecture everything was beautifuli'll love to see it once again now from the other end of river at night

Beautiful temple. This is a must see! Spend some time observing all small details and the view from the top. There are some high steps going up though, but seriously nothing to worry about, they are not that many. You can easily get there getting the boat in the pier to pier 8 and then getting another boat for 3THB for crossing the river. You`ll see it right away.

A wonder along the beautiful river. This is one of the most beautiful and unique temples in the world. Ensure that you visit both in the daylight see its glittering golden image under the sun, and also the night scene with its lights lit up (which is wonderous to see on the river boat).Make sure that you climb up the temple, which is a great experience itself.

Beautiful views of the river. Very nice place to see Chao Phraya river from above. Very steep stairs. Quite recommended at sunset.Tip: you can get there for 3 Baht (about 0,10 USD) by a ferry boat for locals.
Amazing Place. Amazing and Magical Place. A should when traveling to Cambodia.Be sure to go for the Sunrise, definitely worth the 5 am wakeup time.

A challenge for people afraid of height. Such a wonderful experience. I am a person who is so afraid taking a challenge especially if its about heights. But I did the challenge since I am with my hubby. It take me a long time to go down because of the steep stairs. Be careful of every step because the steps are tiny. Some manage to take the stairs like as if they are walking but for me it took long to do it. But at least I tried. If I am asked to go to the temple top again. its a no-no once is enough. lol

Must see. Plain and simple, if you haven't seen this while in Bangkok. You're missing out, beautiful temple. Right across the royal palace. If you're approaced by people saying it's closed DON'T believe them, they'll try to scam you.
MUST SEE. it resembles the indian culture , must see in bangkok day tour, it will take the time of 1 hour, it will show the old culture in thailand

Must visit!. I came to the Temple of Dawn on my first day in Bangkok and I must say what a way to begin! I came by boat from the central pier and then took the shuttle boat across the river. The architecture of the building is amazing and the way temple blends in with all the smaller shrines allows you to take some great photos, both of the site and also the rest of the city that can be seen from the tower. You can climb up 2 levels of the tower, the first set of stairs are steep but manageable. The second set of stairs however are almost vertical! But it is worth it when you get to the top.The only thing that ruined it was the scaffolding and building works on some some sections, so the atmosphere of the place ruined a bit by this and can be an eye sore.

my favorite!. This temple is so unique and beautiful! The climb to the top rewards you with amazing views and a nice breeze. The grounds are removed from the hustle and bustle of the city, making it a truly peaceful spot.

as always, prepare yourself properly to fully enjoy. To be honest, I'm not quite sure why this is no. 2 of Bangkok's attractions but it has to be on your list. The location on the Chao Praya is the first plus and for the photographer, there are classic views both from across the river (if you have a long enough lens) and even from the bucking long-tail boat we were on !! Closer to the solid, highly decorated edifice is covered with beautiful porcelain and offer further chances for fine photos. You can climb it if so inclined (it was raining and I'm getting old). But do prepare yourself: we had a guide but even a study of Wikipedia will help you understand it for what it is, not just what it looks like. we personally saw echoes of the Kajurao temples in India. The Chinese guardian figures at ground level are genuine, our guide assured us.

Great views. An iconic temple on the less visited side of the river. Easy to get to on the Ferries and worth an hour or 2 wandering around before you continue up the river to the Palace or Reclining Buddha.
Worth the Visit. I visited this iconic temple and i was lost for words. I recommend couples to visit this site after the boat ride around the river.

Sightseeing. I was impressed by the artwork that went into this temple. It's also a great place to get above the other buildings to take some wonderful pictures. They allow you to climb the first three levels on steps that appear to go straight up. My only suggestion would be if you are afraid of heights, don't climb the third level. :)
A Spectacular Temple. Easily accessed by Sky Train and a short boat ride. One of the "don't miss" spots in BKK. Highly recommended
good. good for morning tour we go here with family we enjoy a lot we will back we got special price for tickets
Wat Arun. The most atmospheric of Bangkok's temples, particularly at dawn or dusk. If you have a head for heights, make sure you climb to the upper level for some impressive views.
Beautiful temple. The history is interesting but remember that you can only visit the grounds. The temple is best visited with a guide who can tell you all about its history.
historic. easy to reach from hotels, well worth a visit from the river boats, you have got to put it on your itinerary
Wat Arun. Another amazing Thai temple. Loved the view of the city after climbing ALL the steps :) Wish we'd had a bit more time, but the day was getting late and we all were wearing out!

Good view. Had to pay to enter and not that much to see. Atmosphere is interrupted somewhat by the ongoing building work and sleeping that builders. Very steep steps but nice view once you're up there. Could do worse for am attraction but don't go out your way.

Great to explore. Clumb to the top, only temple in this area that you can climb on top of. Recommend to go in the early morning hours as it gets really hot in the afternoon, specially when the sun is beaming down on your back while climbing to the top

Climb not for the faint hearted. Accessed via the ferry that crosses the river directly opposite every 10/15mins, small admission fee. The temple is smaller than it looks from the river, very impressive architecture. You are able to climb the steps but as previous reviewers have mentioned the steps are steep and narrow not for the faint hearted especially when coming back down! Worth visiting but not as impressive up close as some of the other sights in Bangkok.
What a work of art. Huge temple by the river with fantastic artwork but the climb up to the top is almost vertical! Well worth a visit especially arriving via long tail boat.

My favorite Bangkok temple. On the Chao Phrya river opposite to Wat Phra Gaew and Wat Pho, it's a very beautiful Buddhist temple which you can climb for some spectacular views of Bangkok. It's not great if there are lots of other tourists so try and go early or late in the day

Experienced the narrow steps. Wat Arun is among the best known of Thailand's landmarks. Travel by boat along Chao Phraya River, this Buddhist Temple can easily be seen on the river bank. Entrance ticket is 50baht/person. It is under renovation at the time we went there. Seems like every visitors wanted to experience the very steep and narrow steps from the ground lead to a balcony high on the central tower, which is encrusted with colourful porcelain.

Well worth a visit. Wat Arun is one river stop from the Grand Palace. It is beautiful with so much intricate work and detail in its structure. There is an extremely steep climb involved in getting to the second level and one I thought would be impossible for me to attempt, but I managed to overcome my fears and so glad I did. Took some wonderful photos and really enjoyed the experience.

Very Steep Steps, Wonderful View!!!. Of all Bangkok temples I have visited, I consider this to be the most memorable. We were not aware, and prepared, that we had to climb up (and then go down) steep steps. Scary at first but worth it because of the wonderful view of the Chao Phraya river, other temples and the city. Also because it will allow you to have a closer look at the finer details of the Wat Arun.If you have time, go to the back and find more temples where monks are praying.Fee is only 50 Baht. Ladies should be decently attired (bring shawl to cover shorts). Drinks/food are available for sale within the grounds.Easy to reach by ferry for only 3 Baht from Wat Pho to cross Chao Phraya. I suggest that you take the same route (by ferry) back to Wat Pho to get public transportation (buses, taxi, tuktuk). Bus to/from our hotel was just 8 Baht. We tried to take the back route and got lost...I plan to go back this October and visit in the evening since they said that the lights are nice.The Wat Arun is included in a 2N/3D Do-It-Yourself (D-I-Y) itinerary for US$29 which I prepared for friends who are interested to visit Bangkok. Check out details in: http://dhappyretiree.blogspot.com/2014/09/2n3d-bangkok-d-i-y-itinerary-best.html#more to see itinerary, cost, transportation directions and other tips.

Beautiful Temple.... After deciding against paying to see the Grand Palace, I made the short ferry across the river to Wat Arun. On the river taxi up to the area it is the one building that draws your eye and you left looking at it in awe. It's different to all the other Temples I've seen and the detail of the figures and the temple itself is magnificent. Definitely worth a visit!

Beautiful building, nice view and exciting climb. It can be arrived by taking a boat across the river (only 3 baths). The tower is pretty beautiful. There is pretty nice view from the second stage. It is a big challenge to climb very steep steps and go down, but it worths. High recommend to go there in the morning or late afternoon.
best temple. One of the best temples of Bangkok original in shape and inspiring tall and steep with so much of carvings

Amazing Temple. wooo so amazing temple like jewy i do love so much . i visit there with my sister and friends my visit so amazing i do love so much
next holiday wil go again
many thane

Nice views - worth the climb. Worth arriving by boat and climbing up and walking all the way around to get many nice views over the city centre and see the river traffic going up and down. Amazingly detailed craftsmanship of the many many figures all over the Wat.
great experience. This temple is really unusual for me and with beautiful view once on the top. Just a bit complicate to climb very steep steps and also to go down, especially if its hot.
Amazing!. Amazing temple shows the civilization of Thai culture and religion. Really relax by riverside snack and ice cream.

well worth the visit. Beautiful temple surrounded by delightful trees & gardens. Such a peaceful place within such a busy city. Such a gorgeous riverside location but climbing the stairs is not for the fainthearted or with bad knees. I wouldnt recommend going in the middle of the day or mid afternoon as its extremely hot & when we visited it wasnt even summer. Definately take the public boat up the river to this Wat.
Beautiful by night. visited at night on a bike tour - looks beautiful illuminated. It was cooler and quiet in the evening.

Lovely Temple but not the best in Bangkok.. Just had to visit thIs Temple, as it shared my name! We visited late afternoon. It's not as beautiful as the more well known temples in Bangkok, but it was lovely. The climb to the top was enjoyable and the views of Bangkok and the Chao Phraya river wonderful. We wrote our names on the orange fabric that was wrapped around the Temple top along with numerous other tourists. This is a great place to take photographs of the views and of the details on the Temple.The climb down was as fun as the climb up, but as nearly all the reviews state, it is not suitable for everyone. You must take care as the steps are very steep.Glad we visited. There does seem to be some restoration work taking place here, and if it restores the Temple to its original state, I am sure it will be stunning.

Interesting. Taking the short ferry ride was interesting. The temple is not big and very much like a miniature of the Angkor Wat. The most interesting part is not climbing up, but seeing the temple has used a lot of broken china to decorate
Better than Wat Pho. Loved the boat ride across the river from Wat Pho. A sunset visit from across the river (Wat Pho side) would give a photogs great shot of this temple

Very nice place to visit!. It's a beutiful architecture. The steeped steps on the way to the top is a challenge. When you get there to the top, you get to see the river delta, and the city buildinga all over. :)
Enchanting. A wonderful exposure to beautiful architecture and history. But be careful the steps aren't for the fainthearted!

Good view from the top. Took the boat across the river for a small fee, you get a good view of the temple from the other side and while on the boat. The grounds were quite nice to walk around and it had the usual stalls selling souvenirs and drinks. We paid the 50 baht each to go to the top which was well worth it for the view of the river, grand palace and city skyline. The steps to the final level are quite steep, but you still get a good view from the lower levels if you can't make it all the way to the top.

Steep steps. A temple that stands out from the rather same-y selection in Bangkok. Definitely worth seeing. Take the 3THB boat across from the other side of the river. Entry was 50THB and renting a covering clothing item was 20THB with 100THB deposit. Very steep steps would be an issue for children or the elderly.

Famous Temple in Bangkok. I took a boat trip on Chao phrya river to get to the temple Look very grand from the exterior. the grounds around the temple are will groom and clean. Admission fee of 50baht to go into the pagoda while the surrounding grounds are free.

gorgeous, enjoy the steps up for the view.. great at early morning or sunset. take the river cruise away at sunset for some amazing pictures. Peaceful and serene as most along the water at the right time. Can be crowded, could be empty its really hit or miss. Lovely site either way.
worth a visit. Great views from the top but better if you go late afternoon 4-6ish to see the sunrise. Deffo worth a visit!

A must go in Bangkok. This is a beautiful and peaceful temple. The architect of the temple is stunning. You can change into traditional Thai costume for photoshoot at a fee. Do spend 3baht to take the ferry across the river to another temple across after the visit.

Interesting place to visit. The stairs are steep almost vertical climb at the top but really a good experience. Challenging if have height phobia or for the elderly and really young. Go on the river ride with multi drop offs pass. We started at 11am and ended just after dark, stopping at a few stops. The sunset is beautiful to watch. However the ferry got really clamped when it was close to last few rides.

beautiful for short visit. temple is very beautiful but there is nothing much to see. Its like another god Buddha temple. But if you have free time like 2 hours you can visit temple and click some beautiful pics :)
Beautiful. Architecture is beautiful. In front of it you can rent some 'costumes' to have photos taken. Going up the steep stairs was a bit scary but at the same time exciting.
an Amazing culture. This is a must .It gives you a close look at the local culture. Its very easy to get there . Just don't forget to dress properly.
brilliant!. bangkoks must do and its only 3baht to get the ferry over to save money on getting a taxi around to it. a scary climb and decent but best views of bangkok

good view from the tops. climb the tops of this temple, see a tremendous view from up there.
beware of pickpockets. lots of people will come here especially in tourist holiday's month.
will be packed with lots lots of people
High!. It is a beautiful temple and can be easily accessed by boat. Unfortunately I was able just to walk around because to go all the way up is a mission for someone who is scared of heights!
beautiful. Ladies, Make sure you wear long pants or long skirts to get into the temples. Also not singles allowed, they provide you with some scarves or sarong like skirts for a small fee
Wat Arun. A most distinguishable part of Bangkok, situated by the Chao Phraya River, overlooking Chonburi district..
Beautiful! . Definitely worth a visit. It's just across the river from Tha Thien pier near Grand Palace, easy half day tour.

Pictures don't do it justice. This piece of architecture is impressive by day or night (especially by night from the river). We took a guide here and it is just out of this world. The details are never ending, the intricacies are impeccable. We climbed to the highest you could go and the view of the river is very nice. When you take a river cruise at night, it is lighted up and it looks beautiful, highlight of the cruise. Pictures don't do this place justice, a must see in person.

Amazing. I combined this temple with Wat Pho and I was not disappointed by either attraction. To do this just get the ferry for 3 baht (1.5P!) from tha tien pier. Allow 1 and 1/2 hours for a leisurely visit. From the top of the main temple there is fantastic panaromic views of the other temples and bangkok. The temples themselves are also fantastic both in colour, detail and splendour basked in warm sunshine. The steps to cli,b the temple are very steep even for a fit enough young man so take care with these.
Great. History is deep here, get a guide. There is a lot to learn about the conflict between the countries and the hopes and fears of the people.

Beautiful by night. Very easy to get to with the many river boats!
Beautiful to see, but unfortunately closed by night...
A must see!

Stunning. Stunning architecture and fine craftmanship. We arrived early afternoon and climbed those steep stairs which took some doing the but view above is well worth it. Afterwards we took the water boat across to the opposite side and had dinner at Eat Sight Story with wonderful views of Wat Arun opposite. At night, the Temple lights up and is really lovely. Suggest you book if you want a table as the ones close to the water edge get booked up early.

Quiet, older temple with a great view. This temple is across the river and part of the fun is getting there via the local ferry which is extremely cheap (like 3 or 5 baht, I can't remember) that runs constantly. The temple itself is quite old, one of the oldest, and covered in old broken pieces of china and tile which make it beautiful but also difficult to maintain. The area is quiet and you can climb the outside on very steep stairs to get a lovely view of the river and Bangkok. It is a nice change of pace and a good place to go for a view of the city but if you are afraid of heights or wanting to see the gold and glitz of the Grand Palace you will be disappointed. But for a change of pace, lovely old temple, trip across the river, and good view then this is the place. Our guide recommended the duck soup sold there but my daughter got sick a few days later, I only had the broth and noodles and was ok but would pass on the street vendors!

An instant favorite. Loved the place, the views, and the extra push to cross the river to visit it. You will be told in the way that is closed or that there is a ceremony or that it's 1 hour walking. Just find the right pear in the same steer that Wat Pho and pay 3 B to get there. It is open.

Amazing but helps to be fit. Wonderful photo opportunities, so much to see, lots of steps if you decide to climb up the temple, there were two viewing levels, if you decide to go to the higher level the steps are very steep and some people had problems coming down.

Climb to the top for great views. This is across the river from the many of the other sights, but it is worth the trip out here. We took the ferry and it was an easy and enjoyable experience. Not a huge sight, so you can see it relatively quickly if you are in a rush. Climb to the top for great views over the city.Note: take time to look closely at the roof-top decoration on your climb up and down. The flowers and other decorations are made from china plates that were dumped in the harbor as ballast hundreds of years ago.

Short Trip to Wat Arun. We initially were planning a trip to the Grand Palace, but as it closed earlier ,we decided to take a trip to Wat Arun "temple of Dawn" . The temple is quickly accessible via personal speedy boat trip or a Ferry ride that takes a bit longer . We decided to take the fast boat from the Silom pier ,close to the Shangrila hotel . The return was via the ferry and took about 40 min . The temple area is quite exquisite in design and the top of the temple requires you to climb steep steps, but once you are at the top you are compensated by beautiful views if the river , the city and the Grand Palace and other popular temples . The temple grounds offers some nice manicured lawns and great photo opportunities .

Nice temple.. To get to Wat Arun, we took a tuktuk to the harbour and took a water taxi that cost us 3 bahts (very cheap!) each way. First one of the taxis took us to a little harbour area and they tried to overcharge us saying it would cost 1000 baht to get to the other side and they would also give us an hours tour around the river. Beware of these people, theres loads of them located along the harbour. Make you way to the water taxis (you will find lots of locals there). When we got to Wat Arun, we paid a small fee (50 baht) to get inside the attraction. The views were nice. You can climb the stairs to get to the top but we didn't bother as it looked really difficult. The stairs are very steep at the top and even grown men had to sit down to come back down the stairs.All in all, the visit to Wat Arun was ok but we enjoyed the Grand Palace more.

Romance Your Soul.. What a beautiful place to uplift and romance your soul! It gives you a great exercise for legs, while soaking in the beauty of Thai culture, splendor of the temple architecture and a view of Bangkok skyline and Chao Praya river.I love coming to this temple by ferry every time I'm in Bangkok, to recharge and wander around temple grounds to discover numerous quiet nooks and crannies to get calm and clear.
Go!!. Serene temple, awe-inspiring whatever your faith. Clearly the Thais know how to revere their ancestors and to pray.....

a nice day out. you take the tourist ferry and then another ferry across to the temple. it sounds like a journey and a half but it is not and it is so cheap... this is more laid back than the Palace but well worth a visit

Fabulous. This is an amazing piece of Thia culture and history all rolled in to one. Visit in the morning when it's not as hot. Plan to make a day of it as traffic in bangkok is 24/7. A must see fir everyone and they do entice the dress code

Lifetime Memories. Loved my visit to Wat Arun. I'd read so much about it and obsessed over photos for years. I'm happy to say it was what I'd dreamed of and more! Such an amazing preservation of history and architecture...I was overwhelmed with the details of the temple and the view once I made it to the top. I honestly will always remember my trip to Thailand and this was one of the many highlights!

Good but below expectations. Based on the rave reviews on trip advisor, I had really high expectations of the temple. However compared to the other temples (Wat Pho and the Emerald Buddha) the temple just seems very poorly maintained. It is still worth a one time visit. The sculptures on the pagoda are interesting and chinese inspired, but disappointing compared to the architecture at the other places.Climbing the stairs up is definitely worth it, however the stairs are steep and quite scary.

Classic Bangkok tour site. Lots of reviewers described the Temple, so I thought I would clue you in on a simple, but almost mandatory half day of touring in Bangkok. This arrangement maximizes your time use and keeps your travel flow simple and quick between these various sites. Remember that Central Bangkok traffic can be some of the worst anywhere in the world.Wat Pho, 8:00 a.m. opens early About 100 baht now.Wat Arun, 9:30 About 50 baht will double next yearFerry boat or long tail boat ride, 10:30 - 11:30 Ferry 3 baht long tail boat about 1200 bahtGrand Palace 11:30 a.m. - 1:00 p.m. (opens 9:30 a.m) about 500 bahtLate lunch - lots of snacks if you get hungry earlier.
Awesome. Must visit, so much to see and learn. I liked it and I had a chance to take a lot of pictures. If I have chance I would visit again
Good to be there. In the evening times. When the sunset comes up it is great to watch the temple. When the lights go in it is especially amazing

Nice for a quick stop. This temple is pretty cool for a quick stop (ans it's usually included in most of the boat tours you can do around the city)the main attraction here is the temple itself which you can climb up and take in the awesome views. Careful though as the steps are quite steep and coming down can be a bit daangerous.I heard that if you get there early you can see the first light of the day reflect off the temple and its supposed to be quite cool to see

Aesthetically beautiful. The exterior of the temple is actually made up of Chinese-inspired crockery and it's actually aesthetically beautiful when facing the temple facade front. The stairs leading up can be a tad challenging to climb, but definitely a must-do!

The icon of Bangkok. For me the most spectacular landmark in Bangkok and totally worth to cross the river and climb up the steep stairs. The temple itself is as spectacular as the view from it, with the Chao Phraya river right in front of you and the skyline of Bangkok and the palace in the background.From the distance it is impressive with its Khmer style shape. Only from the close-by you can see that the whole bulding is covered in colorful tiles.Take your time, bring water and get ready to climb the steepest steps that you will probably ever climb.

Hard to reach, but very peaceful. its a little hard to reach.
best to take the riverboat taxi.
you will be rewarded with the chance to walk around a nice temple.
Feed the (massive) fish, or set free some eels/snails/turtles into the river.

Beautiful view, stunning architecture. Located just accross the river from Wat Pho (were the reclining Buddha is located) Wat Arun is worth the visit. I would go here first and then to Wat Pho.Wat Arun offers a beautiful view of the River, the gardens around are pristine and the climb to the top is fun (and VERY steep). A place for an enjoyable stroll.

Beautiful and all.. This is the last stop of our private trip arranged by Indochina Odyssey Tours and we enjoy it a lot.Very beautiful and elegant temple. It was raining when we visit there, but it is still very attractive.According to the legend, one ship carring a lot of procelain sank into the river and the king used the pieces to decorate this temple. What a lovely idea.

Beautiful sunset experience!. My Bangkok recommended a place to watch the sunset in front Wat Arun...incredible experience! The place is located right in front the temple in the opposite side of the river, we loved the spot - it was a great experience all around! I'll recommend to all friends and travelers!
Great for historic admire and high view. Nice coffee under tree shade after hot day. River view is good, nice temple setup with great Buddhism history.

A landmark. Wat Arun is definitely one of the mu st-see temples in Bangkok because of the Khmer style architecture that stands out along the Chao Phraya. It only costs 3 baht to cross from the Grand Palace and makes for a good side trip.
Holiday. Great wonderful absolutely brilliant. I had a lovely time there and can't tell too many times how friendly people are

Up and Out - Beautiful Views. Wat Arun has a simply stunning piece of architecture - all the way up to the top. The structure itself is beautiful and it is wonderful to see up close how they used the smashed up pottery to create the multiple patterns. Definitely try to make it to the first raised level if only to see out and around the Wat. It is a beautiful view of the surroundings.Be warned that there are three levels (ground plus two going up the structure) and the stairs to the first raised level are steep - and the stairs to the top level are ridiculously steep. You will want to think not about whether you can make it up - but whether you will be able to make it down.

Pretty amazing!. This should be one place you need to visit while you're in Bangkok. Cheap at 50 bt. Be sure to wear or bring appropriate clothing. Steep to climb to the top of the temple, but an excellent view! Beautiful to walk around!
Incredible. magic place with beautiful colored tiles. My favorite temple all over Thailand. easy acces from the river boats and ferry
Fasinating view along the river. To climb up the pagoda was a good experience but it's a bit hot and sweating. This is a magnificent art of Bangkok

Wat Arun temple tour. Well as I said with the culture between Christian and Buddism it is quite obvious the differences, we enter the church shoes and all, in Thailand Buddism no shoes and cover your shoulders and legs

Wat Arun. What a Temple! Full of little pieces of broken china.. like mosaic. It glistens in the early morning sun. If you are very fit you can walk up to different levels. Be prepared., it is VERY steep, but well worth it for the view. It is a must to view.

This temple reminds me of La Sagrada Familia in Barcelona!. This temple itself is beautiful. The work and craftsmanship is so meticulous. There are VERY steep stairs. You have to hold onto the rail to climb up and down. It was made for giants. It's also easy to get to from Wat Pho. Take a ferry across for 3 baht!
Nice and Beutiful. It is a Perfect ! So Beutiful in Bangkok.Have a good trip and good time in Thailand. The Temple Closed Chaophaya River and Grand Palace.
Night view. We went for a dinner cruise in the night and the temple was brilliantly lit. It was amazing to see the lighting at night and from the river.
Beautiful!. A very nice temple, we were able to take beautiful photos and "climb" the steep steps to the top. Loved all the inlaid mosaics and it was generally much less busy than the grand palace.

Detailed and Picture-worthy!. We had a day pass for the river and paid an additional 5 baht or so (pocket change) to access the temple via ferry. We did not climb the stairs to the temple, but we enjoyed its surrounding area by sitting in the grass and relaxing with a view. The structure is ornate and detailed with much beauty and skill. This was a nice change from other temples like those inside the Grand Palace.

Beautiful landscape. Lovely landscape with difference building to see. The steps are very steep but highly worth the effort! It is a small site compared to the bigger temples but this is a must see, not just from the river boat rides.The views of the river and city are great and you find you can just sit and stare in relative peace.

Wonderful - sunrise sunset view. A must visit for anyone visiting Bangkok.Temple is wonderful, architecture is amazing, very scenic and absolutely brilliant. Travel Points to note1. If travelling with kids - there are people outside the temple with traditional Thai dress. They charge around 200THB for letting the kids wear the costume and take photographs, Its worth it2. The temple is on the other bank of Chao Paya river - Grand palace & Reclining Buddha are on one side (the side were people normally get dropped)3. There are ferry's taking people to Wat Arun from the pier close to Reclining Buddha and it would cost just 5 THB for the ride. One should not fall prey to the so called guides who try to cheat people by saying we will take you to Wat Arun ferry cost is 200THB etc4. Normally one should visit Grand Palace in the morning, followed by Reclining Buddha and then take the ferry to Wat Arun5. If one is going by oneself (as in taxi's etc) then note that after 5 PM getting taxi's is a problem and most of the guys then start charging flat rates. To avoid this suggestion is come back to the pier near Reclining Buddha and take a boat to Sapan Taksin (BTS station) - the boat is every 30 mts and will charge 40THB per person. From BTS station one can access any place in Bangkok. This way one can avoid being fleased by the Taxi guys6. The steps that take one upstairs of Wat Arun are very steep and can cause vertigo while getting down. But its still worth it as the view from upstairs is simply superb7. Visiting Wat Arun for sunset is must as the view is extremely beautiful - the sunset is normally around 6.45PM in summer and 6.20PM durng winter.8. If not sunset then sunrise is the other option Wat Arun looks beautiful on both occassions9. There are river cruises that operate on Chao paya in the evenings - one can take them to get a view of the lighting around Wat Arun in the nights (which is worth)Overall Wat Arun is a must go in Bangkok.

Don't attempt if your scared of heights. Great temple but view from the bottom if you are scared of heights, but it was great to see all the bits of porcelain and imagining the time that went into building this..

Good touristy area. I visited there a few times as I was taking my friends around. I think it's great from pictures but once you visit, it's AWESOME. I'd say, it's rather touristy than a true hidden cultural exploration. But I enjoyed a lot. Thanks
Wonderful. A wonderful heritage of Bangkok alongside the river easy to reach by ferry and skytrain. Defiantly worth a visit besides other attractions along the river
prettiest place. geometrically divine, but look closely - every design is made from broken pottery... left from the goods transported from China.

Simply breathtaking!. My wife and I visited Wat Arun around January of this year; we weren't disappointed. The culture, artistry, practices, and beliefs associated with this historic site must be witnessed before one dies. All fee's were included in our tour and our tour guides did a great job of giving us a history lesson of this famous temple. Overall, this was a beautiful experience and I would recommend this to anyone who appreciates different beliefs and cultures.

Take a look early in the day and right at sunset!. Unfortunately, by the time we got here it was already closed but seeing the exterior of the temple with all the beautiful details was very impressive! We arrived around 6ish and stayed until the sun set and saw the temple light up at night and it was very beautiful!So time it right so you get to see it during daytime and nighttime!
A Beautiful Symbol of Buddhism. Yes I cant get enough of the Temples and this one is spectacular to visit and to experience a great euphoria of ages past and present.

Nice, for a short visit only though.. Temple is quite high and therefore looks pretty impressive. Climbing it is the biggest challenge given the temperature and the very very steep stairs. We estimates the second set to be about 70 degrees, close to a complete 90 degrees perpendicular angle.There is not a lot to do except for climbing it (and visiting the tourist shops around it if you're in for it).Note that once you're on site and your shorts are too short, you're asked to rent a long skirt for 20 baht (with a 100 baht deposit).
nice views. Very steep climb, so be carefull decending. but amazing views of the city and river. entrance fee is 50 baht.

Steep stairs rewarded by a nice view. Wat Arun is facing the Temple of the Reclining Buddha on the other bank of the Chao Phraya river. Also, next to the latter temple, you will find the Grand Palace.Wat Arun is quite impressive. You will want to be in condition, and go when it's not too hot. Also take a bottle of water with you. The stairs up to the highest level attainable are steep at first, steeper at second and steepest last. But it's worth the short climb. You will be rewarded by the view of the Chao Phraya river and Bangkok.

Great sunset experience in Bangkok city!. My wife and I visited the Wat Arun Temple in July...WoW! We were lucky to find a traveler who recommended us to visit a place / bar in front of the Wat Arun to watch the sunset, one of the most amazing experiences we had in the city of Bangkok. We highly recommend to all travels on Trip Advisor, you will love!

Amazing site of Chao Phraya River from the top. This temple is right on the bank of Chao Phraya River and have a beautiful architecture. The steep staircase is not for faint hearted to climb and descend, but the view on top is really something to WOW for!!

Better viewed from afar. Don't go at noon. It can be really hot. I suggest wearing sunblock and don't forget your umbrella. I think Wat Arun is best viewed from afar. It's easier to take a full photo of it across the river than when you're at the grounds already. Travelers can go up until the second to third level. The city can be viewed from above but I suggest that if you have fear of heights, do not go up anymore. The stairs are very steep (really!). It might be easy to go up but it will be a challenge going down.

Most beautiful temple in Bangkok. The best way to see this temple is at night from across the river. Look for a hotel named Bann Arun, right on the opposite side of the river, and go to their rooftop bar. The view of the Wat is amazing

A lucky accident. Even though we were intending on going to the forensic museum we accidentally got on the wrong ferry and headed off the Wat Arun, at 3bht a ticket to take the boat we weren't exactly disappointed and this temple was nothing short of breath taking from a distance, there is a 15bht entrance fee and like any other temple in Thailand you will need to cover up (or you can rent clothes at the door) Passing the huge guardians holding up the temples base you begin the climb to the top. You are quickly met with a set of very very steep stairs which could be a hassle with small children, but do not let this dishearten you as the view at the top is well worth it. I would definitely recommend visiting the temple of dawn as it is unlike any other temple in Bangkok.

Beauty..... We get a Waav feeling when we visited this temple. evening 6pm it will be closed, so better go before that. We gave 3 bahts to cross the river to visit the Wat Arun. Wat po and wat arun are either side of the river. We took photographs of the Buddhist monks. There are many cats in the compound of the temple. We had a decent time in this temple. MUST VISIT, spend 45 minutes..! You can also buy souvenirs near around.

My best temple!. Out of my 3week Thailand backpacking trip this was my favorite temple. It is not the typical type of temple you expect to find. It's size and structure are incredible. This is a must visit! If you skip this out you will be missing out. Remember to dress in correct way to visit a temple. However in order to get across to Wat Arun you have to take travel across the river, we got taken to a private boat owner who wanted to charge us THB1000! and four streets down the local ferry boat cost us around THB20 one way. So be careful!
disappointed. during day time there are very bit different with the picture i saw from online, therefore i feel disappointed. At night the view is jus average for me.

Worth a short visit. Across the river from the Grand Palace. There are steep steps to climb up if you want to check out the view but is worth it. Does not take long but I have a a bit of fear of heights at times especially if the there is a steep incline and short steps. I was easily able to hold the rails and walk down backwards and was fine. It was not too busy.Nice view of Bangkok. Do a quick walk around the temple and get a feel of the architecture. Would rather advise make it a shorter visit and spend more time at the Grand Palace. There are a lot of impressive temples in Thailand and if you spend too long at them, guaranteed you will be 'templed out' and will not want to make an effort to see all of them.

Dawn at Sunset. I visited in the early evening, just the light was softening. Then able to take wonderful photos. This is a photographer's paradise and the temple is photogenic. The decoration is largely made of broken porcelain. Although I saw so many temples in Bangkok, each one was unique and worth the visit. But, make sure you do see Wat Arun which is based more on the Cambodian style.
Gorgeous. Must see if you're there. Absolutely beautiful views from the top. Some of the stairs are a challenge but totally worth it!
best temple in Bangkpok. really like the high river view after going up a few flight of stairs. well laid out and organized. People working there were really nice and considerate

the best!. Wat Arun, the temple of dawn, was definitely my favorite!
It was great to see the river from above! Climb it (dont look down!) and be careful when you're coming down.

Amazing sunset experience!. We got lucky with the sunset the day we visited.
We loved the experience, we were sat at the bar in front of Wat Arun, it was amazing!
I will highly recommend to all travelers!

Beautiful but intense climb. Definitely a must see spot. Beautiful view from the top and even around the base. You need to ride the ferry to cross the river in order to get to the site. The ferry is 3 baht. I'm very fit/strong but climbing up Wat Arun was very challenging as each step-up is dangerously steep. Do it if you can, it's worth the experience!

Glittering Tiles. We took the cross-river ferry @ THB3 per person per way to reach Wat Arun, because this temple is situated on the otherside of the Chao Phraya river. You have to spend enough time at this temple to make time to admire all the small detail which decorate this whole temple. Thousands of small glittering tile and mirror pieces were used to beautify this temple. If you are fit enough and not having knee or hip problems, spend time and effort to climb all the stairs right up to the top. Just be careful because these steps are quite steep and narrow, but the view from the top was every step worthwhile. Many photo opportunities, so don't rush.

beautiful views at night from across the river. very unique and it has some very cool lighting in the evenings while you dine across the river on the Bangkok side... during the day it is a steep climb up the temple...

okay for one time visit. Not at all recommended for aged people or people with knee issues as one has to climb several steep stairs to reach the top. The best part is that you have to cross the river.You have to pay 03thb for crossing the river to reach wat arun. Also, make sure your knees and shoulder are covered.. else you have to hire clothes to get inside the temple... same goes for the visiting grand palace and reclining buddha as well.worth one visit ... but nothing much to see and explore.
This was sweet, what can I say. Definitely a "wow" moment when you pull up to Wat Arun. The great view from the top is just a bonus. What are you waiting for, go check it out.
Best temple in Bangkok. Go just before sunset and stay til its dark, then take a taxi across river and dine w the view in the background. It has an old character other temples don't

a must see. to see how thai people love their religion is always worth seeing. when you go to wat arun you not only see the real thai people but you also see an amazing temple in all its glory. to get to the temple only use the boat taxi as it is cheap and exciting.

Bangkok Treasure. It is regrettable that the climb up the stairs puts a lot of people off.. This was one of the very first tourist attractions I visited when coming to Thailand and still remains a favourite. It i good to read a little bit of the history of old Siam before coming - they share the same background of these wonderful (but relatively new temples compared to other wonderful places like Sukhothai or Ayuttaya - but in ore recent times.

a float in the air. i don't know how others felt but as i mustered my courage and climbed the stairs, and looked down, i felt marvelous. i have height phobia so i was cautious but walked to every corner of the temple and looked down at people. took pictures of the surrounding stupas that are being restored. Climbing down was difficult than climbing up. before climbing, when i was just looking at the top, it felt like the temple is floating in the air. one small thing, in an information corner displaying a flex chart of drawings of the temple, everything was in Thai language so visitors unknown to Thai language cannot understand anything. a lot of tourists come here, so maybe this information chart could have the information on the temple in English.

Spectacular, must visit place. This temple is located at the bank of Cho Phraya river. The temple is dedicated to Hindu god Indra, the main deity can be seen only when you reach the top of the temple. The temple is huge and the steps are very steep. Please note it would be difficult to climb up, climbing down was scary. If travelling with kids or elderly, please avoid climbing up. Temple looks spectacular and scenic from every angle. Best view will be at sun rise and sun set.Overall, this is a must visit scenic and spectacular temple

Dont miss it. This temple is really nice to see. It might take a while to get there by cab, but its worth the trip. It wasnt so crowded like the other temples we visited, so we enjoyed it even more. Always bring something to cover your legs (ladies), guys pls wear long pants.

Not to be missed. The temple is very beautiful. It's a steep climb to the top but there are a few levels where you can walk around and take a break from all of the stairs. It's a trickier climb down. The view of the river is lovely. There's not much else around this area. Make sure you have a ride back.

Climb up for view!. Located on the bank of Chao Phraya river, Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn takes you back in the history with it's glorious architecture. It is easily accessible via boat. The temple got some really steeeeep steps. Go for it for some really amazing views and adrenaline rush. - Ticket costs THB 50- No particular dress code unlike other temples- Dont forget camera for amazing city views

Gorgeous!. Probably one of my favorite places in Bangkok. The intricate detail is amazing! Steps are super steep and for some you need to step sideways, which can be challenging! There are rails for part of it. I opted not to climb the steps, but it was still worth the visit.

Steep steps. Not a difficult location to get to if coming by the river boat, the highlight of the location is obviously climbing the steep steps but there are a few other temple buildings within the area that can be explored together as well.Entry fee (50 baht) is only charged for the main temple, while the rest are free of charge. There is a dress code in place so do remember to dress appropriately.

A steep climb with a view. Kids were allowed free, and our 50THB was definitely well spent. Zteep and tall steps indeed, but no-one is in a hurry, so just take whatever time you need. Getting there by ferry was a bit of an expedition, finding out which ferry goes where, and even more so where the pier is! Where we boarded (north of Grand Palace), the pier was hidden behind the houses and restaurants, and not very well indicated. The food at the ferry station was pretty good, actually :)

Amazing. I really liked this temple, the views of it from the river and from the temple itself are lovely. I would however make sure that you are careful whilst climbing up the steps as they are very very steep.

Another crowded but unbeatable place to see. It's overcrowded of course but it's an incredible place, very easy to reach from Wat PO. Just take the boat that cross the river. (3 bath)
So you can see Wat PO and Wat ARUN one after the other.
What a climb!. Another must in bangkok! My wife is Indian and she tells me Wat Arun in Hindi mean Temple of the Sun. Beautiful!

Obligatory visit!. This is a really amazing visit. From one side to othero of the river, yoy have to catch a boat , that´s is really cheap, arround 4 TAI BAHT and then the Temple is really near, with gardens.The ticket for the entrance si really cheap, arround 100 BAHT. The best of this temple is that you can climb the parts of the temple, so not all the peopole can do this, requires to be in a good form.There are so many lazy cats that are adorable!

Steep steps!. Really stands out as the best temple in Bangkok, the view from the top is incredible and definitely worth the climb. The steps are steep but there's a handrail with excellent grip, and plenty of sympathetic tourists around.

Now this is a Temple!. 2nd visit - last visit July 2013. My favourite temple. Absolutely mesmerising and an must see if in Bangkok. We travelled around a lot and used the water taxis most of the time as it is an arterial route to pretty much everywhere. Wat Arun immediately caught my eye - seen from the river is the best view. It is awesome by day and night. We visited but the stairs to the top were too much for me in the humid heat so I just wandered around it. It gives off a very tranquil vibe. Quite a few there but not packed. We took water taxis to restaurants at night and the view from the river as you pass it all lit up is probably one of the most spectacular views in Bangkok. Very highly recommended.
A must do. Loved the boat trip to this temple. The steps are a little scary but we'll worth the effort for the fabulous views. The drop-offs and pick-ups by boat are a bit confusing.

another high point. Wat Arun lies across the river from the Grand Palace. It is easily accessible by ferry at a nominal cost. Its tallest structures are visible from a distance, but the details in the mosaic that covers the temple are worth a closeup. Climbing the tallest tower is an adventure, and the views from the top are impressive.
Mesmerizing. One of the most beautiful wats. We almost didn't visit as it was our last day of a 14 day Thai holiday and we had seen plenty of wats. We are so glad we did. It was by far our favorite.
Touristic. Lot of tricksters in the area that try to take you to the boat trip all around which appreas very poor
