Beautiful temple. This temple is on the other side of the river from the grand palace.You can take a ferry to get there and its easy. The temple is just breathtaking at night when the lights are on. Its a sight to behold and the reflections on the river are simply amazing. The climb up the stairs is quite tedious and would be very very difficult for elders but the main attraction is the outside and not the inside of the dome.

Nice place with spectacular views. This is called the Temple of Dawn but most guides and guide books suggest going during dusk/twilight or even later when the whole place is lit up. Whenever you go, the place offers spectacular views of the river and the Bangkok skyline. Of course, the higher you climb, the better the views. Be advised that the stairs are quite steep and if you have dodgy back/knees or if you have vertigo/altophobia, then don't attempt it.The main central tower is surrounded by 4 smaller towers. The body of the towers are decorated with porcelain and sea shells. The central tower is topped with a seven-pronged trident. The base of the tower is decorated with various figures of ancient Chinese soldiers and animals. Over the second terrace are four statues of the Hindu god Indra riding on his elephant Airavat (called Erawan in Thai). The presiding Buddha image is said to have been moulded by the king RAma II. The ashes of King Rama II are interred in the base of the image.Though it is Buddhist temple, the name comes from the Hindu Sun God's name Arun. There is a fee of 50 baht(July 2014) to climb the tower, there is no fee for entering the complex. To reach the temple, you need to cross the river on a ferry; ferry charges as of July 2014 was just 3 baht. The journey takes around 5 mins.

Beautiful Thai temple. I've been here twice in 2014 and I really liked this temple, around which you can find some stalls where you can grab some food and drinks. Just pay attention and get the right ferry from the right pier, because some foreigners nearly got scammed for 1500 baht until we told them the ferry normally costs around 40 baht.Definitely a must-see attraction

Day or Night - Beautiful. The short boat ride across the river is part of the experience in visiting Wat Arun. The temple detail is incredible. I would recommend visiting in the late afternoon and then taking the boat back across the river to watch the sunset as the temple lights bring an entirely new dimension to this wondrous structure.

Climb up to the Dawn!. My wife and I both climbed to the top of Wat Arun clinging to the rope handrail as we negotiated the high, steep steps. The view from the top was worth it but I'm not sure we would have made the climb had we realized that there was no entrance or chamber into the Temple.
Great place. It can get a bit busy on the thai holidays with people going there to pray. But it is a lovely place we took some lovely photos I would go back again if we went back to Bangkok

Well worth the trip. This temple is a little harder to get to and includes a trip over the river but it is very cheap and the temple is there when you get off the boat so no walking on the other side. Once over there make the trip up the temple if you're able... the steps up are steep and even me and my boyfriend who are healthy and in our early 20s were tired after climbing in the heat but it's worth it for the views and pictures. It's completely different to any other temple I've seen in Thailand and definitely worth the extra effort taken to see it!

A really nice Wat which you should visit. Wat Arun is on the other side of the Chao Phraya River. The scenery is really nice.You can climb to the top of the Wat and you will have a wonderful view across the river to Bangkok.It's really good to take pictures, especially shortly before sunset.Enjoy and have fun! :)

Wanted to go to the top but climb was too steep. I just loved the temple, the architecture, the colors, the beauty and everything but couldn't reach top because the stairs were to steep and weather was really hot. We took a tuk tuk from grand palace to go to the river bank from where we wanted to take a ferry to reach wat arun but the tuk tuk driver dropped us to a port where his friend offered us a boat ride for 1500 baht and then we have to walk for good 10-15 minutes to reach the ferry port. In bangkok you have to really beware of scams of tuk tuk drivers. Taxis on meter arranged by hotel or Malls are much better and cheaper than tuk tuks.

Worth a visit. Worth a visit.The temple here are amazing.anyone of them.The Temple of Dawn monastery is one of the most recognizable landmarks in Bangkok. Its history, architecture, festival, preservation project and gallery.

Must-go temple, sketchy travel method. Wat Arun is a beautiful landmark worth seeing. Although you cannot go inside the main building, the steep steps to climb to the top of this temple are scary and fun at the same time. There's a small costume shop where for 100 Baht/person you can where the garments and take pictures. My wife and I regret not taking the opportunity while we had the chance. The pier you need to find to get here is rather sketchy. You have to go through an alleyway then wait at a rather unpleasant looking dock. The fare however, only costs 3 Baht/person.
picture worthy at night. i was able to see this while on cruise during afternoon and evening. i must say it is more dramatic in the evening while having dinner cruise on chao phraya river. :)
Nice temple. Wat Arun is worth visiting. And you must also try to climb to the top. Great views over the city. Combine with a Chao Phraya river tour on a long tailed boat. Recommended.

The climb up is worth it!. Just do it, climb as far as you can and enjoy the view. Easy access via the Choa Praya river. Thai monk singing all the time. Go crazy and pose next to a guard (looks like a devil with bad teeth)

Best to be visit during Sun set hours. one of the must-go places in Bangkok. lies along the Chao Praya River. same time u may also pay a visit to the Wat Pho. the Reclining buddha directly opposite the Wat Arun Temple

Unique Wat across the river. A short boat trip across the river from a jetty not far from grand palace, takes you to this beautiful Wat made entirely out of porcelain. Climb the stairs to the highest section for a pretty good view over Bangkok. Not for the faint hearted as the steps are very steep, and proper sandals or shoes are recommended.
Amazing. Fantastic sight to see. The climb to the upper level was challenging but so much worth the effort. The view over the surrounding area was great.
AMAZING WAT WITH INCREDIBLE VIEWS!. Worth arriving early and climbing to the top! Children loved it too! Amazing to look at from the river and approach by boat.

It's the atmosphere and the view from the top that is iconic!. Wonderfull experience. Great views from the top.This temple has a special atmosphere. Probably because of it's location.Beware to make a picture using the 'statue' at the base of the temple. It has a small sign that says it costs you to many bahts to use it.

A steep climb!. As other reviewers have said you can just take good photos of Wat Arun from the river but we thought it was worth the 50baht to visit. From a distance you miss the tremendous detail in the decoration. The climb up the steps is steep but worth it. (Take a bottle of water with you!) Coming down is harder! we didn't find much else of interest in the compound. You can catch a boat from the pier by Wat Pho for a few baht.

Amazing. Amazing achitecture. So beautiful. We stayed in Shangri-la so it was easy for us to cross over the river by boat. We went there early so we could take time to enjoy this magnificent temple. Highly recommencée.

nice experience for the kids, good view for the city. nice experience for the kids, good view for the city
climbing the stairs is not easy, but it helps to remember this site

Charming and Peaceful. This temple is my favorite wat in Bangkok. It is really peaceful and the setting is very nice. I like the fact that there was a soft breeze when we visited, for the wind chimes played and the sound was just so relaxing. Best view are on the top, where we can see the stretch of the Chao Phraya river and the Bangkok skyline on the opposite banks. Climbing up is okay, but the climb back down proves to be a challenge, as the stairs are really steep. And it gets even steep as you go higher up.It's not very crowded so you can enjoy your time there. Must visit.

great view from the ground. We visited Wat Poh and Wat Arun via private boat. When we arrived at Wat Arun there were heavy dark clouds and about to rain hard so we just decided to appreciate it from the ground.We wished we were able to experience the steep steps.
Approach by the river... This Wat is a Bangkok landmark.Take a boat form the opposite pier and admire this impressive Wat.Don't forget to walk around the whole complex.

Most interesting place to go. Wat Arun is not particularly on the tourist map as it is on the other side of the river. However, the grandeur of this temple is amazing. Also, you can get to scale the high arches and get to see a lovely view of Bangkok and Thonburi

Magnificant views. Temple is amazing made out of broken porcelain bowls and plates. come excellent views over looking the main river. It was a hot day and very humid, some travelers may need to choose a more suitable time to visit

Beautiful setting, beautiful temple. I liked the setting of this temple on the bank of Chao Phraya river and its intricate details. For the best view you can climb to the top, but the stairs are incredibly steep so going back down is not an easy task at all. I also liked the fact that there weren't a lot of tourists around, so it was very quiet.We went to Wat Arun after visiting Wat Pho and we took the boat to the other side. It's incredibly cheap (12 baht) and fast. Tip: If you want to take beautiful photos, you should go at sunset.

Fantastic and fabulous!!. The first sight of the Wat (Temple will be so thrilling and the beautiful art work on the temple on so large scale will definitely make you spell bound. It is just besides the Bangkok River. Early morning visit is advisable when the temple is open for tourists at 8.00am. After the temple visit, you can take a boat to reach to other side of the river for as cheap as 3 bhats. After reaching other side you can Wat Pho and Grand Palace. Since both of these are within walk-able distance from the river.Must see place if you are going to Bangkok for the first time.

Climb to the top. This is an exciting wat to visit. The steps get increasingly steep and is not for the faint of heart. The first 2 levels nearly everyone can make but the upper level is like walking straight up. Enjoy the view.

Wat Arun. Take the ferry across the River Bangkok, if you're staying at the Shangri La. You will be transported back centuries. It's hard to believe that this Temple could have been built centuries ago without modern machinery. The height and the ornaments, little animals and gorgeous flowers cut out of stone. It's a world wonder and I enjoyed it more than Angor Wat as it is more personal to view. It's is quite spectacular and because of the humid weather, one can see and enjoy the Temple of Dawn in one hour, especially for people who can't bear the heat and sun. However, it is a MUST SEE !!
View is fabulous!!. We lingered for a long time for the view and the architecture and took lots of photos! Go and see the sunset from here. Beautiful.
across the river. we made our way to the river. there we took a boat with local people and went across to the temple. Visited the temple and took the boat back across.

Definately a must!. Do go in the mornings as the direction of the sun will allow you to take beautiful photos (not against the sun). Also be aware that as per Thai customs, you must not wear shorts and you will be taking you shoes off in some areas.

Enormous and tiring, but beautiful. Its huge and very intricately carved. Climbing up the steep steps is very challanging and particularly in the heat, but thats what u go there for! I was sad that didnt allow us into the shrine- I dont even know where it was ! but the architecture is beautiful standing right on the banks and looks very pretty with all those lights in the dark

One of the must-sees on the Bangkok temple circuit.. Take the ferry over for only 15 Baht; they ply to and for fairly regularly, as its worth the trip. I particularly liked the decorations on the Wat, the blue china plates made into flowers and the embellished temple guardians that decorate the central pillar. I did not climb up as its very steep, but many others did. Refreshing fresh coconut is an excellent reward for those who need cooling down afterwards.

My favourite temple in Bangkok. Lovely temple fantastic views over Bangkok and river! My favourite in The city. Beautiful mosaic tiles on the temple however the stairs are very steep to the second viewing platform.

Great views...be careful with the boats. A must see in Bangkok! you get a great view if BKK and it wasn't overly busy either. The steps are very steep but the view is worth it! However when trying to cross the river our tuk tuk driver took us to the 'main ferry port' which ended up being a side street. Here we were sold an 1hr tour of the canals in a long boat via the smaller floating market (which is only on at weekends just so you know - it was a tuesday) then dropped off at Wat Arun. Sounds great - the cost = 900bhat eachThe 'tour' ended up being 20 mins and the floating market was one woman in a boat (probably the captains nan) then we had a 20 bhat charge to get off the boat at wat arun. So when you visit make sure you go to the main port because the ferry is about 3 bhat!This was the only time we were conned in BKK and it was down to our own inexperience!
Temple of the Dawn. Stunning view of the river and the city from the top, definitely worth the climb. the grounds are also beautiful. very cheap to get to from across the river

amazing from the other side of the river. amazing from the other side of the river. especially at sunset it is so ... Thai. i think it doesn't worth a visit, but just photos from the other side of the river

Great temple that doesn't take up too much time!. We only visited 2 temples in Bangkok- the Wat Pho and the Wat Arun. But this is definitely better of the two if you're not a big temple junkie. Sure the Reclining Buddha at Wat Pho is awesome and all that - but it's just too big of an area! Wat Arun was perfect because it was extremely pretty, offered gorgeous views of the river from atop the spire, and is a fun challenge getting up those stairs. It's a relatively small temple to cover, leaving you plenty of time to do other things. Get an iced coffee on your way out back to the pier. Strong as hell but so yummy! You won't miss the aroma :)

A steep climb towards heaven. We visited in the afternoon so we did not see the sun rise behind the temple. Very different design (at least for me) and a nice view over the river from the 2nd level where it is possible to walk around 360 degrees and get all different angels of Bangkok by the river. A very special experience and for those inclined, it is a place where it is easy to get connected to whatever you believe in.

boot trip at chao praya river. the view and the boat trip, the temple looks even better from the oppite site of the river. Nice experience to get up the stairs of the temple and have a good view over the river.
Lovely Architectutre. This is one of the best Wat I have visited with so much peace & Architectutre. One gets to visit with oneself.

Iconic. Its in every Bangkok itinerary probably and worth it as well because for one the view around the place is amazing. You could take the ferry to the place while exploring the surroundings to the place. Be prepared for a whole level of drastic climbing because the temple has one of the steepest stairs and that too so many of them but then you can’t complain when the final view is so rewarding. The temple can be a little crowded and probably making arrangements to visit it early or towards late evening and catching it along with sunrise or sunset will perhaps make your trip a double fold fun.
Work of Art. Amazing place. We were able to climb up to the top and enjoyed the scenery. One of the must visits in Bangkok!

Wow!. This is a beautiful sight! At first, I was not sure if, I wanted to climb the temple. There was a woman that was at least 90 years old and she was climbing the temple. It is very steep climbing up and feels worst climbing down, but it was worth it. I wish, I had time to do the dinner cruise at night in order to see all the magical colors I read about. Next time!
This temple looked different from others. By boat this temple looks different from other temple, very different. I saw like 3 white pole, but the middle is the biggest.
Amazing temple - great views. Just take the ferry across. Small temple but looks amazing. Steep climb up for beautiful views of the river and the city. Must do. Beautiful at Sunset.

Scared of the steps but lovely.. This is the one temple I had planned to visit and it was lovely but less breathtaking than others and my fear of heights kicked in at the top of the temple because the steps were so steep and narrow.

Not for People who has a fear of Heights!. We went here last 1st of Aug, there doing some renovations at the area but still you can walk up to the highest area tourist is allowed. To get here just take a shuttle boat across the river at Tha Tien terminal, very near Wat Pho Temple (Reclining Buddha). So best done after Wat Pho.3 baht/person only. The steps get steeper as you get higher. There are some hand railings to hold to. A must do if for first timers in Bangkok. There's a orange banner where you can write anything you want. The view from the top was relaxing. Overall be prepare to have lots of energy because this attraction is tiring.Dont forget your fluids!

Wat Arun. Make sure to take plenty of water as tis is mostly in open sun. Well worth the climb up to the top. Fascinating history and amazingly scenic location on the banks of the river - stay till sunset to see the temple lit up brightly.

Incredible. Both day and night scene are very different... I prefer the night .... especially taking the Night Dinner Cruise along the Chao Phraya River. The scenes at night are breath-taking.. Highly recommend doing both day and night visits.

The temple of sunrise/sunset. We visited this temple both in 2013 and now, 2014. It is quite fascinating - the idea is to try and see it early in the day as the sun rises and also later as it sets. The colours and natural light effects are really wonderful.You can access it by river transport of course, taking the river express at the Taksin river station. It costs about 15 baht. You need to take a smaller boat which costs next to nothing to take you across to the Wat Arun site.If you're not afraid of heights, then you shouldn't miss climbing the steps to the top of the temple. You can see the skyline of Bangkok from up there and it is quite beautiful.Must warn you though that the stairs are quite steep - I saw people go up them with little children and held my breath until I saw them get safely down again.There are snacks and beverages on sale. You can rent local clothes and costumes and take pictures with these.

Steeeeeeeep. Not a very big temple as compared to wat pho opposite the river. However, one must climb to the top of the pagoda (not really top though, need to pay 50baht) and take a breathtaking view of Bangkok city from the opposite site. And please be careful for those whom are not good or always climb. The staircase is very steep. Going up is okay, the main problem happens when one tries to get down.

Absolutely stunning!!. The Temple of Dawn is a must see. You need to travel to it by boat which crosses the river. This only costs 3 baht which is incredibly cheap (pennies). The journey is very short. The pier number where this is located is right by Wat Po- the reclining Buddha temple. The entrance is slightly hidden by a small market but it is no. 8 on the pier. The views from the top of the Temple of Dawn are magnificent but be careful climbing up as the steps are incredibly steep. For the ladies make sure you wear trousers as the climb down is very steep and could be quite revealing as some of the other tourists discovered. The steps are enormous and looking down is pretty scary. Also ensure that your shoulders are covered as this is a mark of respect and very important when visiting the Temples. An excellent visit. Seeing it at night is incredible too as it is lit up!

Temple of Dawn. Beautiful at day. I bet it looks even better at night. Would have loved to see it all lighted up. The stairs are a bit steep and short (for people with big sized feet, it can be quite a challenge). But the view at the top is amazing. You can even write a short message or your signature at the yellow cloth provided, it was wrapped around the structure, so make sure you have a pen. The structure itself is an amazing work of art.

Truly spectacular. I suppose I have to use the same old phrases - "Amazing", "Beautiful", "memorable", etc. but they're all true. If you're a history buff, like me, you will love it. If you're a photographer, bring your wide angle lens, and take plenty of panoramic shots. Being scared of heights, I was too chicken to climb all the way up, and I regret it - don't make the same mistake. Bring sunscreen, water and a hat - and don't bring too much stuff with you cause it will only get in the way. One thing I didn't like was all the tourists crowding the place - they all probably think the same thing. If you want to avoid them get there early. Oh, one more point, the river boats don't take you directly there, but to the opposite bank (close to Wat Pho) - you have to catch a ferry to Wat Arun, which is right there and costs - wait for it - an entire 3 Baht! that's about 0.069 EUR; 0.093 USD; 0.10 AUD. Don't miss it.

Prettyy. Such a nice change from many of the other temples in Bangkok. Very old looking but so detailed and well preserved. The stairs are super steep through...be careful! Beautiful by the river and the views are great!

Unique temple and water taxi ride a great experience. Especially if you go closer to sunset, the colors are ideal for photography and it provides a great view of the city. Climbing the steep steps is part of the fun and the architecture is very impressive. I've been twice and just think it's a very neat experience.
Worth Climbing. nice temple to vist specially at sunset.View from top of temple is good.Lot of repair work going on.Better take cross water ferry to reach there rather than taxi or bus.

Felt I was checking out Bangkok from a Chopper.. The best of all 3 Pagodas we visited in Bangkok.
Climbed up and voila!!!This is the place where you can use your panoramic features of high end cameras.I will recommend my fellow travelers to spend at least an hour here.

Small Temple. It is not recommended to visit if you have been to any temples in Thailand, Especially to those ppl who visited Indonesia Buddhist temples in Jogjakarta or Angkor wat. It is ok to come if you have not visited any temple in Thailand. Wat Arun is a small temple (to me), and nothing much to see.

Nice view from river front. The Climb was too much , one has to cross the river to reach the place, very solemn & nice area , we took the Chaopraya express & got down at Wat Pho terminal from where you need to take a boat across , they charge 3 bahts

Great view on the top of temple. This is most worth wat to visit in Bangkok. To whom like thrills, pls climb up the narrow steps to the top. From here we will have nice view of city. Remember bring an umbrella along if you are afraid of sunburn. On 5B coin (thai), have wat Arun on it, so pls compare it!
Beautiful. one can access the temple after taking the ferry crossing which takes 3 bhat. The climb on top of the temple gives a view of bangkok which is worth it !!!

A must-do for every first-time visitor to Bangkok. A visit to Wat Arun is a must-do for every first-time visitor to Bangkok. I would recommend visiting early in the morning - though you can't get in at dawn - before the busloads of tourists arrive. It feels calm early in the day and it's lovely to climb the temple in the early morning when the air feels clear and you can get a beautiful view of Bangkok. You can then catch a ferry over to the Golden Buddha.I also heard that you can get into Wat Arun for free after dusk - I am not sure if this is true or not. If so, the night-lights of Bangkok would be beautiful.
Climb the Wat Arun and see the river view!. It's guite scary to climb the Watarun. but once you are on top of Wat arun, you can see the wonderful river view of Bangkok. Value for see!

Worth a look. Wat Aran is an interesting place to see but I wouldn't say it is a must-see. The steps are very steep so be careful when you are climbing them. The view is ok from the top but it is too busy to have a good look round. You get a fairly good view of the river but not amazing. There is a cheap boat (3 baht) across the river so it's easy to get to.

Classic. I always take my guests here. Dont walk up if you are scared of heights! It is well captured by viewing this historic landmark from afar. Take the ferry over for 3 bhat on the day you do wat Po.

Amazing close up. We took a long boat up to the Temple of Dawn which was great, although from a far it doesn't look amazing but when you get close and you see the level of detail they have put into every little thing it's amazing. The steps up to the are steep but worth it to see the view of Bangkok and the Grand Palace.
View across the river at night. Did not get to go visit in-person, but was admiring it at night while having dinner across the river - it was beautifully lit!

Wow - must see. This is a must see. If you can get a guide who will explain everything there and also arrange your river crossing. Beautiful place. Steps up are very steep - its actually harder to come down than go up. Need approx 45 mins to an hour to explore. Stalls selling food and drink around so you will be able to get that much needed water. Be sure to buy some bread and feed the fish - they are huge.Remember this is a temple so be sure to cover shoulders and legs.

Worth a visit. There are many temples all over Bangkok. But this one is very visible any time traveling on the river. I thought it was interesting and worth a visit. But be warned. The steps to go up the side of the temple are very narrow and steep. So this could be frightening to some people.

Must See!. This is designed by a Cambodian architect that's why you would think this temple looks the the ones in Cambodia. Whether you go day or night, You will see it's beauty! Very steep steps! Be careful!

Temple of the highest order. We thought after many many trips to Asia that we would be all tempted out. Wrong, this whole area is truly a wonder and worth the effort. As advisors have already said to see it at night is terrific, but the day spectacular is even better.

What a view!. This is a beautiful temple during the day & night. Climbing the steep stairs to the upper level gave you a splendid view of the river & city. The gardens were peaceful, well looked after & and the statues were amazing. This is a MUST VISIT location when in Bangkok.

A lovely temple. Climb up to the top carefully. Its a breathtaking view. Nice little gardens outside where one can stroll. Its just across the river from Wat Pho , the reclining Buddha as well as the Kind Palace.

Must see if you are in Bangkok . "So calm and beautiful" You will never forget the very special place. This location is nearby the Chao Phraya River and look great in the dawn. You may visit here before 9.00 am and go to the opposite side by ferry to see the Grand Palace for the next.

Breathtaking. We saw Wat Arun during a night-time dinner cruise on the Loy Nava. During the night, the lighting arrangement is spectacular.The following day we headed across town to see Wat Arun in daylight. It was even more impressive. The steps up the temple get progressively steeper (a challenge for children and adults alike, but quite achievable). The statues and carvings are beautiful, and you can feel the tranquility of the temple even with hundreds of tourists around.Beware the vendors around the temple, they will try and charge you triple. A bottle of water is 10 baht, they will ask for 20-30. Just offer 10, or walk away.
A site not to miss. This doesn't take a long time to do but must be seen! Can walk up the stairs and see the city across the river.
Went at night. We went in the evening and so the temple was closed. However, we could still walk around the grounds and it was beautiful all lit up. There were also some monks walking round.
A must see in Bangkok. We visited this temple in the evening on a bicycle tour with Grasshopper tours. No tourist crowds and very impressing all lit up

Pearly Iridescence!!!. .. Wat Arun is probably one of the most photographed temples in the world for its sublime and glorious beauty beyond words. The delicate prang was decolated with seashells and tiny bits of porcelains from China. Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) is located on the grounds of the royal palace in King Taksin's reign (just like Wat Phra Kaew on the grounds of the Grand Palace). The two infamous Demons (Yak Wat Jang), one green and one white, are guarding at the entranceway to the Ubosot (an ordination hall). I also like to visit this temple at night when there are just a few people around. And for THE best viewing spot (Wat Arun at dusk), try Vivi cafe on the Bangkok's side - their iced latte is my favorite drink there. And enjoy the incredible sight of this amazing landmark of Thailand!!

An exceptional temple in Bangkok west bank. When sailing Bagkok main river, at the level of pier nine (east bank), you are attracted to a particular temple, different from the others scattered around the city of Bangkok. You cross the river and you discover an exceptional temple. You go up the stair case and you observe the details, they are simply beautiful. Besides, you have a great view. If you visit Bangkok, do not miss Wat Arun!

Amazing temple!. I went there in June and part of it was under construction, however, you can be able to visit most of it. Remember to wear long pants and long dresses (over your knees), otherwise, you have to rent a skirt for female and a long pant for male to enter into this temple. It have 2 levels and I freaked out while go up stair to the 2nd level, the higher it is, the scarier it is. Its not for height fearers like me. Anyway, Wat Arun still worth your time.
Amazing. The temple is amazing and there's not many around the world like it. Its centrally located and it's definitely worth a visit.

Nice view. Although it is touristy and a bit crowded, Wat Arun provides a very nice view of Bangkok in the distance and a river view in the forefront. It's a nice temple that is easy to access by river boat and can be a quick stop. Under an hour at this temple is plenty of time to enter, look around, climb to the top level and enjoy the view. Plus, it's right by many other tourist attractions - if you're going to the Grand Palace or in that area you should definitely pop across the river to Wat Arun.

Amazing golden spire and views. The Wats in the temple district of Bangkok are amazing. Catch the ferry across to Wat Arun. It has steep stairs and maybe don't climb it if you are afraid of heights, but it is well worth it otherwise.

Climb the stairs for a wonderful view. Definitely worth a visit if only to climb about half way up the central prang of this temple...climb itself is fun...very steep steps...best to come back down backwards. Great views of the river and some of the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Don't forget to see the rest of the wat (Ordination Hall, etc.) which you can reach through a separate entrance manned by two very large Yakshas.

Wat Arun. nice temple but talking the stair is a bit scary when coming down.
but when u reach the top is have nice view around the temple.
most important 50 baht for entry.

A great first looking into Thailand's history. The first temple that we visited in Thailand.
We climbed the steps to the top and watched some of the restoration process taking place.
Going to the top isn't recommended if you don't like heights or very steep stairs!
amazing views. Very good steep stairs but if your not afriad to go up them its 360 views of bangkok, beautiful golden budda's around the temple def worth a visit!
Worth it but i don't like heights. The architecture is amazing and worth the trip, the views are stunning but steep steps and i don't do heights. Despite this was a very enjoyable trip

Worth Visiting. The temple is situated on the river and the boat ride to get there is fun if you combine it with the river tour by long tail boat. It makes for some excellent photos and memories as well. If you want to tour the city and get a feel for the temples, this one is worth the visit.

Loved climbing this amazing ballast-ceramic temple!. Even though there were plenty of tourists present, I still truly enjoyed visiting Wat Arun. The climb up to the second level isn't for those frightened of heights (since you practically have to pull yourself up the last set of stairs), but the view is beautiful! Take your time to fully appreciate the great detailing in these spires made of porcelain/ceramic pieces and seashells salvaged from ballast dumped from Chinese ships. Explore the grounds a little too since there are some other interesting sights (incl. golden Buddha statues and towering guard statues).Ladies- save yourself some money in sweaty, used sarong rentals and just buy one of those cheap sarongs everyone's selling the first day you get to Bangkok so you can toss it in your backpack/purse every day. Nearly all temples require you to cover your knees (and many your shoulders/decolletage), and it's too frigging hot for long pants.

Great afternoon trip. You start out with a boat ride across the river from many hotels or the sky train stop. Then you travel the river to the Temple. If you are a photographer you are in for a real treat bring your camera and all your equipment. Try and have lunch at a place along the river.

Worth a visit!. Even though the Temple is ranked #2 of attractions to see in Bangkok, there was no pushy sellers or heaps of tourists at the site. We arrived by long-tail boat, and spent a good 20 minutes at the temple. There was plenty of space, and we were able to take photos without there being a ton of people everywhere we turned. The Temple of Dawn is an impressive structure, and definitely worth a visit. It is however important to keep in mind that the final steps up to the top of the temple were EXTREMELY steep, and not to be climbed by small children or unfit people.

worth crossing the river for. This was the first temple we visited in Bangkok, and it was one of our favorites. All the tile detailing was beautiful, and the grounds had a lot of paths to explore. The stairs to the top were quite narrow and steep, but the views of the river and city were amazing!
mice temple. Tourist can have many possibility to visit some temple in BKK but I suggest .. dont miss Wat Arun temple , I am sure you will agree with my suggestion.

Great boat ride, Nice photo place and awesome feeling up there.. I haven't been here for a while, we had some night photos last year and the year before.This time, i went up to the middle tier of the temple. It was an Asaha Bucha day, the day before Khao Phansa, Buddha Lent day. So it was so many temple visitors as well as tourists.It's really a great boat ride and we took a boat from Saphan Taksin to Wat Arun pier. Had to take two boats trip to get there.. The cost was 15 baht for regular river boat and 3 baht for ferry across the river. It was fantastic. We could capture quite alot of photos there and we were allowed to go up there until the middle tier.. It was a bliss and I was enjoying quite alot this time. There were a bit of renovation process going on and you have to be careful of the structures and built because they are quite vulnerable. So, please preserve and be careful of the stairs when you go up. The stairs are small and a bit slippery as well. However, it was not so steep and high compared to the Angkor Wat, so it's really for everyone and it was fun to see a bit from the top to the riverside.. Sunset photos are not that great, but I thought Sunrise photos would have been awesome.A must visit place when you are in the Bangkok City Center.. I would say.

beautiful view. this is a beautiful place to visit , i have been several times . the recommend visiting during the week , it can get very busy on the weekend ends with thai ppl enjoying it as well it is a beautiful temple with a great view and some steep steps to get to the top . the is a good noodle place on the grounds to out to the right of the river end exit
awesome. stay at the bar crossing the river, it does not have good food but you can take a beer and appreciatte the sunset , the wat would look like a real palace!

Wonderful Temple in Bangkok. I loved this temple. We took a Tuk to the ferry and took the ferry across the water. This temple was beautiful with intricate carving and I loved climbing to the top for the view. Be aware that the stairs are very narrow and VERY steep. Everything is outside. It is inexpensive to enter (50 baht). You can see everything in a half hour. Make sure to bring a camera. In the surrounding area is lots of vendors with snacks, waters, and souvenirs but none really hounded you. Overall a must see in Bangkok. If you don't want to enter just hop on the ferry and at least see it from the water.

Easy, Beautiful and Quick Stop. Absolutely stunning and scenic stop on the river. There's a little coffee kiosk with a nice area to sit and enjoy the view, and a nice cup of iced tea or coffee. Great stop for photos, and a free attraction.

Great place, careful with the boats!. First I will warn you about getting here, find the main ferry in between the grand palace and wat po this costs only 3bhat. We were struggling to find this so a helpful tuktuk man took us to a different peir where we were sold a river boat trip including floating market for 900bhat, this would have been ok except the boat went for half an hour and the market was one woman in a boat! Oh well we all get ripped off in bangkok!The temple itself is definitely worth the visit! Only 50bhat entry and the climb up the steep steps gives great views over the river and bangkok. I would recommend going before it gets to hot as we were boiling and fed up by the time we left!

Be inspired. To get there we took sky rail to S6, 37 baht then ferry to stop 8, 40 baht. Ladies where long pants or skirt and cover your shoulders or you will have to hire clothing at entrance. 50 baht entrance fee. Take your camera and were comfortable shoes for the steep steps you will climb to get amazing views.

wow! Stairs. Got there yes. BUT when I saw all them stair to climb, steep steep that was a no no for me. It look like a struggle watching the people struggle up, I guess half of them must have given up and never reach the top for sure. And if you dont like heights like me just stand back and admire.

Best at Sunset. History and cultural enthusiasts heaven! Word of advice, get transport direct as it's a little out of the way from everything else. We decided to do our usual transport to general location and then walk rest of way. As with any Buddhist site please be culturally respectful and aware and cover up . This means both males and females,.

Beautiful. I had a chance to visit the temple both day and night time. During the day I visited by public boat which it's incredible cheap. If you chose to go with join tour, it's expensive. In a day time I claimbed up to the top and found out that each step was steep and shot, so I was wondering about how tall Thai people were. During the night it's more impressive, because there're lighting and it's totally beautiful. Would recommend!!!
Steep steps. Great place to start your day. The steeps steps give you a workout and the view of the city is great from the top. Make your way to the Royal Palace by boat from here.

Beautiful Temple. First of all, please visit Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) before visiting Emerald Temple (Wat Phra Kaew) simply because some of you might be disappointed If you visiting Wat Phra Kaew first and than compare the two which are two totally different style and period of temple. Wat Arun is one of a kind temple!!! It is colorful( in closed up), old and simple nothing much but broken pieces of porcelain china from 19th century pieced together with beautiful design decorated. Wat Phra Kaew on the other hand Is more fancy, ornate with gloden accentS every where you looked. The whole Complex is stunning. Perhaps Wat Arun much better appreciated from the far distance or the other side of Chao Phraya River especially at dawn. It is gorgeous with all the lighting for its picture taking.Be aware of steep stairs to climb up to the top, but it well worth it. It is a beautiful view at the top. It is also very small temple and it won't take you long to finish up. It took me approximately 1.5 hours.If you take BTS, you will have to get off at Saphan Taksin and Take a orange taxi boat for 15 BTH( be aware that there are two taxi boat that take you to Wat Arun, one is more expensive than the other. The white flag taxi boat will cost 40 BTH, it's like a boat with tour guide that just tell you the history along Chao Phraya River). After first boat you have to take another taxi boat to cross the Chao Phraya River for 3 BTH. The fee is for Wat Arun is 50 BTH.Wat Arun should be to do list in BKK for sure.
wat arun. lovely old temple with great views from the top. well worth 4he climb to the top. nice and very cheap boat ride across from the river. a quick taxi ride from khao san rd

Nice View. Its a nice place to visit ut don't bank on being here too long.The best way to get there is by boat, There is a 3 baht ferry that moves between Wat Arun and a jetty 100m from the temple of the reclining buddah.
Wonderful and often overlooked. We were dropped off by boat here and explored this ancient temple for about 30 minutes. It is wonderful in itself and offers great views of Bangkok across the river.

Must visit while in Bangkok!. This temple is very nice to visit. There is not that many details on the decoration of the temple, compared to some others in Thailand, but it is impressive by its height and by its look. The temple is quite high and the stairs to climb over the top are very steep. It gives you a nice view around. You need to wear clothes to cover the knees and the shoulders, like in most Buddha temples. If you don’t have anything to comply with the dress coat, you can rent some for extra money. There is some entrance fees, but as far as I remember it was cheap. This temple should definitively be on your things to see in Bangkok.

Visit at least once. It's a place you must visit at least once if you have time, especially if you are a Buddhist. You are encouraged not to wear short shorts or clothes that are too revealing. If you are planning to climb the temple, please hold on to the railings as the steps are quite steep. There is a 50 baht entrance fees but think of it as donation to keep the temple ground clean.It is located just across the river from Grand Palace and Wat Pho. There is a ferry you can take to cross the river - it costs 3 baht/person.

exciting experience and seen art of build. it is a must go when u visiting bangkok. although if u wanna climb up to the top of temple u have to go tru very steps. it was fun although my heart jumping fast. weather is hot. i brought umbrella n bottle of water. it costed 100 bakts n i felt it worth.

If you can climb, do not miss this one! If not, see it anyway!. Take a ferry from Tha Tien next to Wat Pho across for 3 baht. I also purchased the fish feed for 10 baht while getting off the ferry but I wasn't able to find the fish :) Did they mean the fish in the river? The entry fee is a measly 50 baht. If the sun is shining hard, be prepared: drink water, take shade breaks, whatever you need to do. There are rest areas in the corners where you can sit, drink, eat and smoke. There is also what looks like a nice cafe out front.This is a beautiful temple with plenty to see. The highlight is the cimb for the view. There are two levels to climb, the stairs are steep and the steps to the second one are even more narrow than for the first. Do not even think about it if you have any physical issues that make climbing difficult or you're afraid of heights. I shot straight up holding my GoPro, not looking down, left or right. But when it was time to go down, I can't pretend that I was totally cool about it. It helped seeing two cute Japanese girls really struggling to collect the courage to head back down so I just went down very slowly and carefully, sideways, one step at a time, like a 44 year old grandpa. No shame in being safe!This is probably my second favorite temple here (after Wat Suthat) and it's one of the two views in Bangkok worth the trouble: the other and easier one to conquer is Wat Saket (Golden Mountain).

Scary Climb, amazing detail work. Loved this temple. Seemed so much more interesting than a lot of the more ornate ones, had stories and symbolism with the creatures on each level. the stairs are reaaaally steep and dangerous, but people tend to be cautious. You can buy ice cream nearby to cool down- and if you want a picture of yourself in elegant thai garb in front of the temple, that is available for purchase as well
amazing. Well worth the great views after the climb but be prepared for your leg muscles to kill for 2-3 days after the extreme climb!

Amazing,Must do In Bangkok. I was looking forward to my visit here and wow it didn't disappoint,yes the stairs are pretty steep but the view is just amazing. we did this on the same day we visited grand palace,wat pho and wat saket,had a great day and this Wat was a massive part of the whole day. Must Do.

Too hot and too steep for me. Although this Wat is breathtaking I found the heat of the day to be rather oppressive. The temple has very steep steps, some without handrails and I only went up to the first level before I gave up. The view was incredible of the river and surrounds. I thought the landing fee (as we came by boat/ferry) was a bit cheeky.

Not to be missed. One of the Temples you must see - visit early to miss the crowds and the hot sunshine if you wish to climb to the top!Great place to visit and the boat ride over is entertaining and hardly worth them taking the 2p of whatever it cost to cross the river!
Great View. Enjoyed our second visit to Wat Arun. Art work is amazing on this Wat. Walked to the top and enjoyed the beautiful view of the riverside and the city of BangKok. Great photos here.
A Must. Brave the height of Wat Arun and see the city from a high view point. This opens early so you can go here before crossing back over the river to the Wat Po.

A worthy stop. Take the ferry up the river and stop opposite Wat Arun, you will have to take a second boat (cheap!) from the opposite bank. This is significant landmark and a piece of history and the entrance fee is modest.to say the least. If you choose to climb it, take extra care with kids on the rather treacherous steps.

Need more time. This is a beautiful place! So singular in my trip! But I think that you should spend more than 1,5 hours here (its hard when you have a thai guide trying to do everything shorter than should be). The statues of golden Buddhas aligned are a beautiful composition to your pictures.

Must see in Bangkok. Steep Stairs but cool place to see - it was very interesting that the decorations on the temple are all broken porcelain dishes that were broken on the way to Thailand - Very fun place fun to climb the steps and see Bangkok! Careful of the cutouts on the river side if you stick your head nside to take a photo it will cost you 1200 Baht! Yikes!

My favorite spot in city. Considering the fact that i am living in Bangkok for 2.5 years, Wat Arun is still one of my favorite spots and i wouldn't mind to spend my day off going to Chao Praya River and climbing Wat Arun.It is beautiful sightseeing with great view and challenging steps up!Usually, i take my guests to Wat Arun and Wat Pho and skip the Grand Palace (entrance is 500 thb!).
A place of meditation. Bangkok is full of temples. My advice is to see couple of them and do other things. Bring a lot of water with you and try to go early in the morning

Charge you for being a foreigner. The fact that I'm a foreigner does not mean I should be charged to enter whilst locals are let in for free. It seems "religious monuments" are nothing more than a money making machine for the religious authority that runs them.And for god sake, why are people climbing this monument when you have a sign at the ticket booth saying "treat it with respect".
Vertigo inducing steps!. Steep steps to a fantastic view. Wonderful decorative temple. Getting there by river boat and the 3 BHT ferry from the pier on the opposite side of the river.
beautiful. An absolutely beautiful building and well worth a visit, very steep stairs though, my son told me the views were great though!

One of the better places to see on the river. This is one of my favorite spots on the river as far as the religious monuments and such go. The temple is very busy and popular during ceremonial times like on Songkran. Climbing the very steep steps can be a bit vertiginous, but just hold the handrail and live a little. The view from the top tiers is worth it. Just watch your step, and you'll be just fine!
Must go!!!. This perspective to Bangkok adds flavour to ones visit. Nice views on offer, next to the riverside which made it beautiful during the evenings.

Stand alone masterpiece. Sited on the banks of the Chao Prya River, Wat Arun has dazzled visitors for decades. Go at dawn to see the reflection of a rising sun on the millions of ceramic tiles. Or, take the ferry in the late afternoon to see the sun setting on it while enjoying a brew from one of the waterside bars and eateries on the other side of the river.

Riverside gem!. My favorite temple in bangkok! The style is different from all the other temples. Wat Arun is great to visit, but if you just want the view, best at sunset from across the river at The Deck, Arun Residence!

Beautiful. Excellent superb Funbut the HEAT was killingThe Street Side vendors Charge double the priceThey also know we know the price still wanna charge more.. That is badThe taxi operators CHARGE 3 Times the amount. Do not want to Run taxis on meters

My favorite temple in Bangkok. We took a free bicycle (there are several places where you can get those, free from 10am till 6pm) from under bridges Phra Pok Klao and Memorial. It is possible to leave bikes at the entrance. Tickets coast 50 bath if you are dressed properly (no shorts and open hands, like in the Grand Palace). But climbing to the top is existing and a bitt scary! The is a way to get inside for free like in every temple, but it is not that pracy. The view from the top is great, the temple it self one and only.

An absolute must see!. Along with the Grand Palace this is a must see when staying in Bangkok, it is very cheap to enter so no excuse for missing it. Easily accessible by boat for 3 baht and it is just a stunning structure. Be prepared for a leg work out as the stairs are incredibly steep. There wasn't much information about Wat Arun available but it is so interesting to look at all the carvings it didn't really bother us. Thoroughly recommended!

Iconic temple. Visit to Wat Arun is a minimum destination point for any visitor to Bangkok. It is opposite to Grand palace and is accessible by paying 3 baht ticket by crossing chao phraya river.We reached to BTS taksin station and from the station itself, we took tourist boat ferry ticket @ 150 baht for a full day trip for Grand palace, wat arun , royal barge museum etc. The boat ticket is valid throughout the day.Wat Arun means Sun temple, Temple of Dawn. This is a temple of historical , religious architectural and cultural importance. Going to higher elevation is little adventurous and may be difficult for age old peoples. This is a must see place even for a day visitor to Bangkok. Grand palace, Wat pho and wat Arun can be clubbed together for a 2 days visit.The place is well maintained, well preserved and tourist-friendly. Every corner of the place is picture perfect. Great view from top of the Stupa. Tender coconut are available at reasonable price.. No service from tour agencies are required for visiting this temple. A must for every visitor to the country. I think ticket cost is 50 baht. Everybody should wear full sleeve pants. No shorts, no topless......

Outstanding historical site!. I caught a metre taxi from my hotel to Wat Arun first, just 3 bath for a boat and 50 bath for entrance fee.I would like to give a recommendation for this place. I was really really nice, better you should climb the stair to the top of this temple.
Its ok. Perhaps bit overrated in the guide books. I took a riverboat and got off at the root of the temple and think it is better appreciated from a distance and during sunset time.

Good work out for the thighs :). Impressive temple with great views of Bangkok from the top when you conquer the very steep stairs. Liked: cheap entryDisliked: not much information available in English about the history of the temple

Beautiful architecture!. A must see in Bangkok!- stunning and beautiful, intricate carvings - lovely view from top- a little adventure climbing those steep stairs :)- you can see it from the boat ride but worth paying 50 BHT entrance - ladies need to cover legs can rent sarong for 20 BHT + depositNOTE: be aware of people trying to sell you boat rides for 300 BHT or more! Take the local or tourist boat (from Grand Palace then across river in total should not be more than 15-20 BHT for the 2 boats) and even from train station to the dock should be about 30-40 BHT. Do not over pay SO many people tried convincing us the cost was more. You can even get a full day boat ride hop on hop off for 150 BHT. Go directly to person at booth selling tickets to ferry (not tour companies at dock)BTW, I liked the reclining Buddha (Wat Po) even more, check it out too!Enjoy and don't get ripped off :)
Amazing . Great place! This is a must visit temple whilst in Bangkok... It's a bit of a climb to the top but well worth it and a good adventure...
Gorgeous Khmer style temple!. Impressing by being modest and less decorated comparing to other Thai temples. Beautiful and spiritual.

Must place in Bangkok. This is one of the traditinal icon in Bangkok. Along the Chaoplaya river you will easily find the unique shape. You may visit together with the "sleeping Bhudda temple", as there is a local connection boat from that side.Once entered, please try to "climb" the steep stairs. You may find it interesting, and make your visit momorable.

A lot of stairs. We visited this temple without a guide, and used the water taxi to visit the main attractions on the free tourist map. The Temple was lovely, but the stairs are very steep and not for anyone afraid of heights if you want to venture up. It is narrow, steep, and the height can make you a bit woozy. That said, the view of the river is incredible if you climb to the top, and it was an easy, quick stop on a day of walking around Bangkok.

Peaceful beautiful temples. All was interesting had no dislikes Bangkok as many temples
Thailand as many culture but mainly buddist we visit Bangkok
A least once a year and always visit different temples.

boat trips are a rip off!!. the boat trip to get there was a rip off!!
however the temple itself is amazing, we didn't go in, however i do highlight and recommend a visit here

1 in 9 of Royal temples in Bangkok. A very beautiful temple, with pretty high stairs to high level of Stupa to see sceneric of Chaopraya river bank, this is not recommended for people who fear or scare of height. But as other royal temples in Thailand that you have to dress in polite casual dress with cover shoulder and your knees.
Oh god another temple. Came here on a bored tour (killing time before a night flight). Another pile of meaningless stones. Yawn...

okok... went there in the afternoon and there was nth much to see except climbing up the super steep stairs. climbing up is quite exciting as the stairs are really steep and you get to see the really nice view at the top. tips: beware of pickpockets and gals pls wear jeans or long pants.

Uniquely Thai design. The Temple of Dawn is one of its kind. You canot find a design like this one anywhere else. Situatred by the Chao Praya River, Temple of Dawn is worth a visit. Do be prepared to climb up some steep steps to reach the top of the pagoda. Don't attempt to climb up if you are afraid of hieghts.
Great at night. Great to look at when it's dark from the other side of the river. It's pretty. In daylight not so much. It's nice to see, but when you saw one temple, you saw all of them.

National icon. Very beautiful temple, and something just a little different from all the normal temples you see whilst travelling SE Asia. There's nowhere to go inside but some steep stairs to climb and nice views of the Bangkok skyline. Wear clothes that cover shoulders and below the knee otherwise you pay 20 Baht for a shawl on top of the 50 Baht entry.

Its Ok. Nothing really exciting about Wat Arun. The only fun or interesting part is climbing the really high and steep steps. The steps are so tall and steep that there is no way for you to climb up or down without holding on to the rail. If you are not a fan of heights DO NOT go up these stairs!

Awesome. Well worth the visit. The climb up the temple was steep but well worth it. Easy to get to off the local ferry. Tip for tourist you must have shoulders covered and be wearing clothes below the knee. If you dont you will be asked to wear a sarong to cover up. This is the same in all temples.No negatives about this place its beautiful.

Worth the visit, and the climb. I took a boat taxi to Wat Arun. I take the orange flag taxi which costs only 15 baht from the Central Pier (Saphon Taksin BTS) and then take the cross river ferry for only another 3 baht to Wat Arun. I arrived at 10 a.m. and the crowds were scarce. However, when I left at 11:45 there were a lot of people there so I recommend going early. This temple is an incredibly beautiful mosaic of china plates in various colors and patterns. It is truly an incredible work of art. I climbed to the very top and took in the view of the river and city. However, if you are not up to taking the final set of steps (which are as steep as most ladders) then simply climb to the lower deck where the view is also quite good. If you climb the final set of steps you will be rewarded with a beautiful view, however you MUST climb back down as that is the only exit. After climbing the steps, be sure to take time to explore the grounds and side buildings. There are many magnificent golden Buddhas inside these buildings. You can reward yourself for making the climb with fresh coconut juice served in the shell and sold on site.

Must visit place in Bangkok. One of the most picturesque temples in Bangkok along with Wat Ben. Great views during sunrise and sunset. Enjoy a canal ride at the end of which they let you visit the Wat Arun or enjoy a dinner cruise on the Chao Phraya where you would get great views of the temple. Wonderful architecture and rich in history!! Must visit place in Bangkok...

Worth going :). That was one of the three temples I chose to visit on my trip. Definitely worth going to. They are quite strict on skirt lengths tho ! You are allowed to climb quite high up but coming down is bit scary. Stares are very narrow and under a sharp angle ...

An interesting temple with nice river views. Although you need to cross the river to get here and the walk down the temple stairs is rather precarious because they are so steep, this temple has amazing detail to it and is worth the visit

Not for the faint hearted. This was a stop off on a river trip and the first look at that flight of stairs is daunting. However, it can be done provided you do not try to rush it whatever your age. The temple itself is a very historical monument for Buddhism and totally different to the majoritory of other temples as it is one of the oldest. This is one temple that should definitely be on your visit list. There are various stalls and eateries in the grounds to wander round after your climb,but they are the usual mish-mash aimed at the tourist

Loved it - be aware of the "helpful locals". Firstly on the walk there you'll get overly friendly locals trying to help you as something is closed on which they flag down a tuk tuk for you to go somewhere else. It gets tedious. Then the pest "tuk tuk" drivers who try other tricks. It gets tedious and which is why you always get in a taxi that uses the meter. Everything else has been said before. The boat is about £0.05p each way and the wat is fantastic. Just make sure you know your confident getting down - it's a lot scarier looking down the stairs than going up and it's very steep

Quaint Temple. It was a nice visit, but best to just take photos at night. It's definitely an iconic and historical temple for followers of Buddhism. It is a major part of Thai history as one of the oldest temples. Ascending the narrow and steep steps was kind of thrilling! Really, just taking the ferry across the river was the most fun part!

Best of the lot. Temple of Dawn is definitely one of the best temples around Bangkok. While other temples are necessarily golden with red hut-like roofs, Wat Arun is entirely different & very beautiful. I even made sure that I visit the place at Dawn, but not a lot of scope if you're looking for a good sunrise picture.

Excellent. The place is amazing. No words. Just be carefull of the men dressed in police uniform and informing you that the place will be opened only in 2 hours and you can visit handcraft shop by the time :)

Worth a visit. Much much quieter than the Grand Palace.. The Wat Arun is located on the opposite side of the river to the Grand Palace and is easily accessible by ferry for THB3 per person from ferry stop #8 (1km walk from the main entrance of the Grand Palace). Yes, the Wat Arun is nowhere near as pretty as the temples within the Grand Palace, however, this site is far more peaceful, with far less crowds. Entry costs THB50 per person, and oddly enough, only women must cover their shoulders – men are allowed to walk around in thongs (flip flops), shorts and singlets.This temple is not pram / stroller friendly, but you can walk around the base of the temple, but don’t even bother trying to attempt to carry the pram up to the second or third levels.The Wat Arun is worth going to especially if you’re already out at the Grand Palace. We were in and out within 30 minutes.

Worth the climb. The climb is pretty steep to get to the temple. For us it was a little tiring because of our kids but when you get to the top to get the awesome view it was an amazing experience. This temple is a must visit if you are in Bangkok.

One of my favorite Temples in Bangkok. Event though I'm living in Bangkok, I always make sure to visit this beautiful place every once in a while during different times of the day. During the day, the Temple provides this place of peace and harmony. Anyone interested in ceramics, then this is the temple to visit. In the evenings, I can't stop looking at its beauty shimmering in many different lights and shades...
Nice view and nice place to massage:). Nice place a lot of sculptures in all temple and the best old school massage because is born many hundred years. Enjoy

Lovely view, both from and of!. Wat Arun is stunning by night, viewed from the river as it is lit up marvellously.The temple itself is nice without taking the breath away (until you attempt to mount the steps, which are somewhat steeper than they look!) From higher up, you're also treated to a grand panorama of the city. While not quite the same calibre as the Golden Mount, definitely worth the ferry trip across the river.

Amazing Structure. On the banks of the Chao Phraya River this amazing structure is more beautiful the closer you get. Towering many metres with 4 smaller but still amazing towers around it it is completely covered in fragments of Chinese porcelain . Very tall steps prevented these 2 septuagenarians climbing up, but some younger folk attempted the climb, with wonderful views from the top. A very worth while experience.

Awe inspiring. It was so amazing, and massive, definitely go in the evening or early morning because it is incredibly hot! Also make sure you have cash to pay for the boat over and the entrance fee. But it is worth it. The climb is pretty intense, but the view from the top is amazing.

Interesting. Visited this place on May 20, 2014 as part of my family's Thailand Holiday on May 19 to 26, 2014. you need to cross the river by boat to get to this place. The place is less majestic compared to the other temples we visited in Bangkok. The highlight of this place is the climb up one of the temple tower with stairs that was really really steep. I thought the stairs we used to climb up the great wall in china was already steep, but the stairs on this tower was even steeper! one should really take great care when going up/down this stairs. over all though, it was a great experience having done it!

Beautiful. A first saw this Wat whilst on a river dining cruise. Decided I must visit it. Glad I did. It's a very old Wat, very pretty close up, even went to the top from the outside. An experience it's very steep but worth the climb. I will visit again next time I'm in Bangkok

Truly amazing. It is beautiful beyond description. I went with two of my sons and the steps are too steep for them.After climbing up to the top, every sweats worth while.You got to climb up to the top!!

Fun and a must do. One of my favourites in bangkok i enjoyed everything starting from the small boat ride across the river to reach the temple, climbing the steep stairs was fun you will definitely enjoy that unique temple

worth a look. Tuff going on a hot day but well worth the trouble. The climb to the top is not for the faint hearted as the steps are steep and it is quite high. Also sometimes you can't wear shorts but the day we were there they seemed to be quite relaxed. We went as part of a canal tour which went for about 3 hours or so.

Very Hot Very Steep you need to be a wee bit fit. With a 70 meter high spire its impressive decorated in lots of little bits of glass and porcelainwe went in the day time as we were on a private trip for 2 on a long tail boat so we stopped and paid our 50 Baht and had a good walk around (we have since been told that it is even nicer in the evening) Ladies make sure you have your shoulders covered lots of little shops ice cream and lots of Cold Water available. Its know as the Temple of Dawn it has a really good walk up to the top which apparently is amazing once you get to the top, I sat at the bottom while my lovely husband went up to investigate, I couldn't do it as it was to hot to steep. but it really is amazing

Temple visits.. Absolutely fabulous. Fantastic day out. Lots to see and climb!!! Oh boy was there lots to climb. Beautiful temples with VERY steep exterior stairs. All family members say the views on EVERY temple were worth the climb. Majestic all round. Most of these sites in themselves, we were told, free, but we took a package and the free ones were also included in them.

Fantastic views. Well worth a visit. The climb to the top is very steep but well worth the effort, the views along the river are amazing.The whole temple is covered in the most incredible mosaic tile work.A must to see

Very Exquisite. I went there during my bkk trip. It was magnificent. Although it was rather run down for some of the craftworks, but for a whole temple to be crafted with gemstones and etc it's really magnificent. Go climb the stairs if you have the chance to! :D
Beautiful. A stunningly beautiful temple. It may be daunting for some, but you must climb the steep steps to the top for the fantastic views of the Chao Praya River.
great place. amazing art and friezes. stunningly beautiful place and there are quiet areas to contemplate the wall paintings which are mesmerising.

My favourite.. Located on the Chao Phraya River this structure is called Wat Arun or temple of dawn, is very beautiful with intricate work. There are golden leaves on the borders. Of the roof of the structure. Looks lovely. We went there by boat and spent about an hour.

beautiful architecture. despite as a temple, Wat Arun architecture is enormously "wow". the staircase is very narrow, worth going up. btw, it has a up and down way. please follow. otherwise, massive jam in the staircase.

A Unique Temple You Can Climb!. From a distance this temple looks like ruins but it's not!! When you get up close you can see it is small tiles designed to look like flowers and it is gorgeous! There is a small fee to enter the temple grounds ~50-100 baht (can't remember exactly) and you can climb all the way to the top. It is very steep and if you are afraid of heights don't look down but the views are great! You don't have to take your shoes off to climb to the top! You can take the water taxi, ~3baht (each way) from across the river, it's quick and easy and it leaves relatively frequent.
Nice stopover during a boat ride. It is worth going to the temple and climb the stairs to the top (although a bit harrowing). Have a close up look at how the designs are made - totally interesting.
Lovely views along the Chao Phraya!. The steep steep steep climb was fun! Great photos from up the temple and from the long tail boatride as well.

Go after dark for a breathtaking experience. We went around 8 pm and not only had the place practically to ourselves, but also got to see the temple grounds in spectacular lighting.The view of the Old City (Bangkok) is also pretty awesome at night.
NB!! You can't go into the actual Wat in the evening, but you can roam throughout the grounds.

1st place too visit. there is no dislike in my Thailand tour.....but just careful of those con man around
ChiangMai, Krabi and Hua Hin are my next place to go
Cheer !!!

Wat Arn is best enjoyed from afar!. The golden light from Wat Arn is magic from across the river at night, But, take the few baht ferry across in daylight and you find it’s pretty bare with no gold. It can be fun to climb the towers but the dress code is stricter than the National Palace, requiring long pants, or long skirt and long sleeves. Long is longer than knee length. Other than the towers there is very little else to see. Wat Arn is best enjoyed from afar!

architectural beauty. In addition to its architectural beauty and mythology that explains the temple itself, it is important to climb the steep and narrow stairs and enjoy the view of the Chao Phra river and the opposite bank. After a visit to Wat Pho and / or Grand Palace
Gorgeous temple. Beautiful, great views. Remember to cover your shoulders or you can hire a scarf for B120. Be prepared for a extremely steep climb up the stairs though!

become fearless and enjoy the view. Wat Arun is not far from the reclining buddha or emperors palace as shown on the map, its a mere 3 baht ferry ride which takes 3-4 minutes. The ferry stations are worth it because of some really cool shops. also the station at Wat Arun has a nice little family run ice cream cafe for a snack. Wat Arun itself is a rather quick visit, but worth, the entrance is 50 baht and the excitement kicks in once you climb the first set of stairs, the second staircase is quite steep and not for the very faint hearted. I'm scared of heights but I made the short climb to get my kicks and I surely did. the view on top is pretty amazing and over all its fun. go for IT!

A monument of Bangkok. Ok, I'm not someone who loves to go and visit temples for the architecture. I do visit them more for local reasons. However Wat Arun is an exception and holds great historical value in Bangkok. Located on the Thonburi side of the river it's easily accessed by boat from the royal Palace, Wat Pho and Wat Phra kaew, so you could do all the landmark temples of the old Phra Nakhon at once.
Excellent. I liked the marble effect and view from the top .Good aerial view to take pictures ,nothing to complain

Very impressive temple. Across the river from the major side of Bangkok be aware of tuk-tuk drivers that try to take you across the river with privet boats for 1000 baht's… you can easily take the public ferry for 5 baht's. The temple is quite amazing. Don’t miss the climb to the top although it seems a tiring climb.

Great View. Caught the ferry across to Wat Arun after visiting the Grand Palace. Great view of the city and surronding suburbs. If you are scared of heights, this may not be for you. Stairs are very steep but admission (50-100) worth every Baht.

Go early .... as it was so hot by the time we got there. This was a simple journey from our hotel but we got waylaid by some large bloke when we got off the sky train claiming to work for the railway. So if you find yourself looking at the map in the street you've gone the wrong way, just turn around & go back up the stairs where you come from, the boats are right there. Otherwise railway man will approach you & put you in the tuk tuk. My husband does insist on stopping & listening to everyone! OK so we got to see another temple .... & all for 20 Baht, but then the young boy dropped us off at the tourist boat rather than the cheap local boat. We only realized when they wanted 3000 Baht each! Eventually we got on 2 boats to the temple, one cost 15p each, the other 3p each I must admit I was exhausted by the time I got there & needed a rest & drink. Sadly we didn't get to climb the steps, but the temple was amazing & we really enjoyed it.
amazing temple. when i searched in the internet,i didnt think i would be impressed too much but its incredible,beautiful, very nice.i couldnt leave that temple for hours... soo different

Gorgeous temple at sunset. This is the most gorgeous temple in Bangkok. However, I never got close to it. Our hotel had recommended to go see the temple from across the river from a rooftop restaurant called Sala Rattanakosin. And it was an unbelievable view! There were very few people on the rooftop and we watched a magical sunset with this temple as the centerpiece.I would have liked to climb this temple, but we were short on time and didn't get a chance to. However, it was probably more beautiful from where we did see it. Yes, try to climb it if you have time, but be sure to see it from across the river as well.

watch out for the journey back down!. I found Wat Arun to be a little dissapointing. There was a lot of construction work in the temple complex; very little information to help visitors understand the significance of the temple.The highlight is being able to walk up to the first and second levels. If you are uncomfortable with heights then be careful - the downward journey is hair raising.

Charming as always. the 12 angles Khmer DHAVARAVADI stupas decorative with Chinese porcelain establshed for deciated to King's Rama2 death; The Landmark of Bangkok tourism travel Logo. Steep climb to top but worth the BKK river Panorama view; Charming at nighttime when golden color shade from spotlght bathe on!!
Beware of the Steep steps. Great view of the river and city from the top but beware its a steep climb up and a little unnerving going down.

Very cool . Definitely take the 3 baht ferry ride over. Super cheap. You can take a long tailed boat ride but that was about 1000baht to go around. The temple has a ton of steep steps. But the views of the city are great! Make sure to bring temple approved clothes (for girls- pants and shoulders covered). It's helpful to buy elephant pants and put them over your shorts when you get there :)

nice attraction. It is beautiful.The entrance fee is 50 thb You have to cross the chao phraya river from Pier 8 exactly opposite Wat Pho entrance.The ferry charge one way is 3 thb. It is worth seeing but do be careful as the steps to the top are very small.It is a lot safer if you step down sideways holding on to the rails.My video link.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tCL6EWUOjRE
Stunning. We went at night as part of a cycling tour. It was amazing and enchanting. Must visit! Heard the monks chanting as well which was really special.

Not for the Faint of Heart. Climbing this temple was a wonderful experience! The stairs are quite steep which is lots of fun, but not for those who have a fear of heights. The view from the top is very nice and the temple itself is very pretty. It is also very conveniently located close to both the Grand Palace and the Reclining Buddah. Ensure you wear temple appropriate clothing, especially if you are a female.
Great view. Go in the very early morning, by boat, you'll have some walking and steps,but the views are worth it. When you're done, go across the river and spend a few hours in Chiana town
Exceptional Temple. A great one to visit after you have been to the Grand Palace, architecturally beautiful and very reminiscent of the style you see at Angkor Wat

Climb Wat Arun and you ll not be disappointed!. It is one of the nicest temples in Bangkok and always a spectacular landmark ( especially at night with the effective lights) you see it from the boat when crossing Chao Phraya. Take the ferry to visit it ,as it's very affordable,and enjoy the view from the top once you have climbed the very steep stairs .....but be careful when you come down especially if your foot is number 45 ....

Wat Arun on the Chao Phraya River Bangkok. I visited Wat Arun (Temple of the Dawn) when I went on a boat trip along the Chao Phraya river. The temple is situated on the west (Thonburi) bank of the river opposite the Tha Thien Pier. This design of this temple makes it one of the most stunning temples in Bangkok, with its beautifully crafted and decorated spires standing majestically over the river. You can climb up the steps on the outside of the temple if you want to but the steps are very steep. From the top you have views over the winding river, the Grand Palace and the Wat Pho which is opposite. At the base of the central temple tower there are sculptures of Chinese soldiers and animals. As well as this being a tourist attraction, the temple is used by local Buddhists as a place of worship.Entry to the temple was 100 baht. If you got a river boat to the temple you have to pay a small fee at the landing pier so that they allow the boat to briefly moor to allow you to get off. The boats then wait for you in the river and pull back up to the pier when the driver sees you are ready to leave. The temple is open from 8.30am to 5.30pm and you should allow yourself approximately one hour to go around the temple. Make sure that you cover yourself appropriately, particularly shoulders.
