There are scarfs/sarongs that can be supplied for a small fee and a deposit is needed which is returned to you when you return the garment. Drinks and souvenirs can be bought on site.
Worth the Climbing Experience. The Temple itself is much prettier from a distance, but the climb up the steep stairs is an experience itself.

Nice scenery. Climb up the Wat and you can enjoy some nice scenery of the Chao Phraya River. The stairs are a little steep, makes climbing up tiring and coming down difficult. Recommended to get down sideway.

Beautiful View from the top. This was a beautiful experience, but make sure to wear hiking shoes!!! We took a ferry to get to the Temple, it was a very inexpensive trip. I cannot remember exactly how much, but we did not break the bank by any means. When you get to the temple, you climb some very steep stairs to get to the top. It is always extremely hot in Thailand, so it couldn't hurt to have some water with you as well. Despite the heat, the view from the top of the temple is worth it all. It is very peaceful. I do not recommend the climb for young children! It would be very dangerous for them. There is rope and it is not an impossible climb, but I certainly would not want my children to try. There is no elevator to get to the top, so if you have any sort of mobility problems, this is not the trip for you. I would plan to spend 45 minutes to an hour here, between walking from the ferry to climbing, to walking around.

Magnificent. As with most temples in Thailand, you won't be disappointed. This temple is gorgeous. We visited during the day (although the photos at night look beautiful) and climbed up some very steep (and scary) steps for a superb view of Bangkok. Most people seem to get the ferry across to it, but we got a tuk tuk fairly cheap also for people not wanting to get a ferry! Definitely worth a visit!

Amazing intricate detail on this Wat. Easy access to Wat Arun via ferry across the river from the Tha Tien wharf, near Grand Palace. You need to get up close to appreciate all the intricate detail. It's a steep climb up to higher levels on the outside of the temple. Peaceful setting on the river, way less crowded than the Grand Palace

Beautiful!. It was really hard to find this temple on foot, phew! but nevetheless the temple itself is pretty amazing, one huge stupa with very steep creepy stair, and large temple complex, i enjoy exploring the city!

great &attraction number 1 in bangkok. when i was planning to visit bangkok i decide to visit Temple of Dawn. i read about it alot but the real too pretty.nice building & good old design.worth a visit & also close to the river.i enjoyed by The steps aren't for the fainthearted however as they are very high, steep and quite narrow.The view for the top however is definitely worth it as you can see.in my opinion attraction number 1 in bangkok

Unbelievable place. I don't regret visiting this awesome place, my teenage sons were not interested in coming but I managed to get them on the ferry and to Wat Arun, once there they were more keen than I was, taking pics to show their mates at school. Great view once on top, after climbing many narrow steps but feels way worse on the way down. Do be careful on the way down. If your a lady and have a short skirt on they'll make you hire a wrap around for THB 120 to which you'll get THB 100 upon returning the garment.

Renovations hamper getting into some areas. Not as impressed on this visit but mainly due to the fact that the temple is being renovated and therefore areas are out of bounds for safety reasons. Obviously the renovations are commendable and our timing to visit was just off kilter.
Great. Wot Pho and this are well worth a visit, very close to each other.Allow all day to see both and then you will be templed out!

Beautiful. We had a boat ride that took us to Wat Arun and so we didn't have much time to look around however as with most of the temples in Thailand we weren't disappointed! The steps aren't for the fainthearted however as they are very high, steep and quite narrow! The view for the top however is definitely worth it as you can see for miles in every direction across Bangkok.
Beautiful site. The climb up the temple it awesome. One need to experience to understand it. The stairs are safe yet very steep and one gains height really fast while climbing. It is very clean.

Nice temple to visit. I loved the architecture which is similar to Khmer and (even can draw parallels with Mexican Aztec style.).Go there by boat. If you are anywhere in Bangkok, you can go to nearest BTS (blue line)/sky train subway station. Having a subway map handy from your hotel is good idea. Once you reach Saphan Taksin station (on green line), you are to look out for ferry terminal (subways has directions).At ferry terminal- don't fall prey to agents who would sell you expensive tickets. Go for 15 bhat ferry boat counter. Other charges vary from there to a bhat 100. Some tout tried to sell me aferry to floating mkt- 3000 baht..he came down to 1000 baht..that just put me off..By the standard ferry, one reaches the river side that is opposite to this grand temple. There is another boat (some 3 baht) that takes you across the river.I realised that best way to go to musuems, palaces is by this metro to ferry rides rather than catching tuktuks from train stations etc. I even ventured in their buses..but no english is used so we should know how to spell some words like Hualampong (main station) etc if we want to be adventurous enough.

Amazing view, wonderful experience. I love the fact that you're allowed to climb up the steep steps up the temple and be able to have such a close encounter with this beautiful temple. The view from above is amazinggg and standing up there on this majestic building is pretty liberating. The people below literally look like ants. And the steps, wow, they are steeper than they actually look but I had a really fun time getting up and down the steps!:)Also, the temple at sunset is great for taking pictures. Really scenic.Such a beautiful temple, I love it!
Wonderful photo opportunity. Great opportunity to take photos of it while on a ferry. So pretty all lit up at night. Would go back there again just to look at it and take it all in.

My favorite temple in Bangkok. I saw a number of Temples in Bangkok and this one really stands out. It's location is beautiful facing the river. You can climb up most of the way for some amazing views. The stairs are pretty steep at the top so be warned. This is amazing by night or day. The details on the temple are amazing. This is also one of the older temples.
Astonishing architecture. Its an ancient temple near river adjacent to it. Grand palace is visisble from its top.It has steep stairs to climb up to reach to top. Nice architectural monument.
Superb, especially when enlightened at night. Superb, especially when enlightened at night. It is one of the main temples of Bangkok, facing Wat Po on the other bang of Chao Phraya river

Beautiful. Stunning temple. We got a canal tour which ended here and it was a fantastic. Lots to do here and as it's one of the more popular temples it's got a lot of tourists and tourist attractions. But that's not a bad thing as we got to dress up as Thai dancers which I would recommend! It's not the cheapest but the pictures you get are worth it, and it's fun. Stunning temple!

Spectacular. Wonderful site in Bangkok across the River. When I was younger , I climbed the precarious steps up the Temple and got away with a few aching joints. For my recent visit , I stayed on ground level. If you want to do a climb , the you need to be fit , so please take care.You can still get excellent Photographs from ground level.A must-do if in Bangkok.

Wat Arun. Amazing landmark and so wonderful that you can still climb to the top. It was part of our bicycle tour and they saved this gem for the last. Beware of photo opps with cut-out faces. There is a charge of 40 baht, with the sign hidden very low.
great Thailand historical ancient symbol. great and amazing !!!.......better come in the morning.....historical Bangkok ancient ! great Thailand historical ancient symbol

nice visit. it's very easy accessible via the river, so if you are around the pier8 it's worth to cross the river and visit wat arun; also the admission fee is 10 times cheaper than to grand palace; and be ready for some serious climbing...

Wonderful place. It's a very nice experience to go across Chapaya River by boat and view this temple. To climb up certain places the steps are steep. But could take a good view going around.It's by Anoja.

Nice view on a great build. First off there is a fee of 50 Baht for foregners to enter the temple area.This is a very nice temple, you can climb up some very steep steps, gave me vertigo and i don't have much of a fear for heights, so beware if you do. But once you get to the top it's a really nice view, even tho there were ongoing maintanance on parts of the temple it was still worth wile to go and see, amazing details.

The view is worth the climb :) . To get to the too of the temple you have to climb some pretty steep stairs, but when you get to the top you will forget all about the climb as the view is awesome. I also really like the colors and the statues - definitely a must :)

meet the treasure. yes, this is the sacrifice place for Budhism, but you can learn the culture how they pray or do activity, and you can climb to the highest temple if you want to and write your name or pray in a white banner

Worth a visit. A quiet and peaceful place, set apart from the old city. The ferry ride, although it takes less than 2 mins, is a good experience, at least for the efficiency with which it functions. The temple itself has a park-like area, statues, and beautiful art. And if you are so inclined, be blessed by the priests.

Beautiful temple. I enjoyed my visit here also because I got to go on the Chao Phraya river and see the city from the water. It is located right on the river, opposite from Wat Pho and is easy to get to from the ferry terminal, though it did require a change of ferry from the up river one to the cross river one. It's very cheap though, 3 baht for the cross river ferry and 15 baht for the upriver one. The temple itself has immaculate grounds, lots of cats, and the main pagoda can be seen from miles around. It was undergoing renovation work when we visited so some of the temple areas were off limits however the main pagoda was accessible. You have to climb about 80 or so steps to get to the top level and the stairs themselves are something to see, very steep. The view however is worth the effort to climb, you can see a good section of the river and city looking towards Wat Pho and the Palace. Beautiful craftmanship as always with Thai temples. Worth a trip to see

The temple you can climb. Unlike the other temples we visited in Bangkok, you can climb this one. Wat Arun has some VERY steep steps that lead you to a beautiful view of the surrounding area. The attraction costs only a tiny bit.Tip for tourists: This site, and all historical sites around Bangkok, are better visited with a good tour guide. Our entire Bangkok experience was better off for it (see my review of BKK tours for more info). Also, you should wear pants and cover your shoulders for all temples in Thailand. The locals consider it disrespectful if you dress more casual than that (though they are too polite to tell you so).

Stairs With a View. This little temple is full of lovely surprises. First are the surrounding lovely, lovely grounds that you're not aware of when you see it from afar. It glitters with the decorative mosaic work on the outside. There's a beautiful buddha inside. I love the tradition of taking your shoes off before entering the temple itself. And, the stairs! Very steep so these are not for the faint of heart. But do it! The views are worth it and the hustle and bustle of Bangkok recedes into the background as you watch the river traffic and feel a cool breeze. Stunning.

Watch Those Steps. A good place to stop and look at one of the major temples in Bangkok. Worth putting aside an hour for the visit but watch those steps. They are almost vertical so unless you are fit you will be forced to stay at ground level. 50 baht per adult and worth the money.

Cannot miss it. If you go to Bangkok, it is mandatory to visit Wat arun. Very nice and interesting temple to visit, you can learn a lot about the culture and asian way of life by visiting amazing places like this. The boat that takes you there is a journey apart. Take your camera!

Mind Blowing. Majestic!- this place was absolutely fantastic and beautiful- such a presence and majesty about it! It is something that has to be experienced and words on a travel website cannot explain the feelings of seeing something like this!
Climbing Wat Arun. Interesting place to visit. I recommend visitors to climb the temple stairs but it's not for the faint of heart. :)
Must visit temple!. If you are a photographer, you need to visit this temple, its Thailand heritage, beautiful…iconic…fantastic.

Worth The Visit. Hi,
This is a great site to see in Bangkok. We were able to get there by water taxi which was an experience in itself. The temple is beautiful, very ornate with plenty of placed to grab beautiful pics. Add this to your list!

Super Hot Summer - Steep Stairway Climb to Top of Wat Arun Bangkok. Worth a short visit to this Temple of Dawn. We took a short ferry from Tha Tien Pier to cross to the temple. Each person 30 Thai Baht one-way journey. Ride across took about 2 minutes. Best time to visit is 6am - 10am when you will not be scorched by the burning sun. Be warned: This is not the usual climb for tourists. Though the building structure is not high but the design of the step is VERY STEEP and not really for faint-hearted. Going up was still ok but coming down needs a little bit of patience and step-by-step movement. Saw some people struggling to make their way down .... No way is this place suitable for children below 4 years old. Entrance per person is 50 Thai Baht. Go during weekdays to avoid the crowds.Once at the top, a very nice sweeping view of the Chao Phraya River and Grand Palace (opposite) comes alive.Building structure has wear and tear and can see that the relevant authorities are in the process of some refurbishment and maintaining repair works.

The most beautiful place in Thailand. Nobody can believe it's real. Extremely beautiful temple with decorations. Some parts of tiles are broken and lost, everybody should take care of it. Stairs are so steep, so need to be careful.

A must see!. This is a real nice temple on the Thonburi West Bank of Chao Phraya River. This is not a place to bring children if your intent is to climb the central tower. It is quite a steep climb. If you have good balance and don't have high anxiety, I would recommend to climb the tower. Once up on the top you will have a great view of Bangkok and the hectic river. The temple as such is very nicely decorated and it is amazing to see the level of detail that went into building this temple. Simply breathtaking and that goes for the climb up and down the tower and the temple as such!

dont go home without it. maybe Bangkok's most beautiful feature, Wat Arun. located by the main river that runs through town. There was an entrance fee, i forget how much but not a lot. either way - well worth it, you'll never see something like this in any westernized country. oriental exotic !

Amazing!. All I can say is this place is amazing! The architecture was grand and awe inspiring. . The only downfall was the incredibly steep steps to the top which made it scary to walk down but the view made up for it.

worth a short stop by. We were tricked by a local guide to take a private boat tour. However, I have to say it was a nice experience. We were in Bangkok in the beginning of this April, it was quite hot and a lot of tourists spread along the river side. Taking this boat tour gave us a chance to keep distance with crowded and the breeze kept us cool! The boat stopped at Temple of Dawn, so we took 45 mins to explore the detail of this temple and get some background story of it. It totally worth it, you have to get close enough to the temple to understand why it called piece of art!

Wonderful. Until we went to close of the temple, did not realize how beautiful it is! Very detail decoration on the outside. Also you can climb into it to have a view of the river. A must go while having the river cruise.
Amazing Temple in Bangkok. Better you go here not in the middle of the day, the temperature is super hot. 4-5 am is the best timing to see this old temple.
Serene tour. The steps up the temple were very steep but the view is superb. the temple architecture is stunning. The trip to this temple is a good break from the shopping spree

Truly a Bangkok " Must See". Right on the river across from the Grand Palace, it is very easy to see when visiting the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. All you have to do is take the very cheap, frequent, short river ferry across. The Wat Arun is stunning, and steep though the stairs are, one must make the climb part way up for the amazing views of Bangkok and the river & temples. This is truly a Do not miss when visiting Bangkok
Well worth a visit. I got to the top lever and views are great; The only thing I was quite scared to get back; Be careful not to let small kids get upstairs;

Well. We took a 3 baht ferry from Wat Pho to Wat Arun. It was beautiful. I found it is easier to climb up and the journey down was rather scary.The area surrounding was rather commercialized, there were some Thai dancers life size cardboard near the entrance, we took some pictures with it and suddenly an old lady came out of nowhere and asked for 40 baht. Apparently to take pictures with it cost you 40 baht (the writings were so small we didn't see).

disappointing. It is a disappointing experience to visit this temple after visiting grand palace and Wat pho. The ferry from the pier opposite to Wat Pho to here is however convenient. However getting a taxi from here is difficult and we had to walk a long way though local streets and lanes in scorching sun to find the main road and catch a taxi back to our apartment. Overall, it is nice to see from the river and outside the temple, but you are not missing a lot if you don't have time to cover this.
A must see. Brilliant and worth the visit how some can review this as average I just wonder what they would call great it would have to be a nine wonder.

Amazing temple dont miss this place!. This temple is just mind blowing and you can see the photos attached. Just climb up the stairs to the top and view some stunning views from there!. do not miss this at any cost and is just across the river from wat pho. wat arun was even more beautiful than wat pho and we really enjoyed being here...some photos attached.
A sight to behold. The biggest gold Buddha in lying position. You never seen so much gold in one statue. Just amazing. Take plenty of water because it is hot.

Fantastic temple. We spent an hour here after going around Wat Pho. We walked to the Tha Thien pier (N8) and paid 3 baht to get a ferry to cross the river.Entrance fee is 50 baht and you get great views once you climb the extremely steep steps to the top. Well worth doing - this temple is iconic!!

A must for anyone in Bangkok. If your travelling to Bangkok on business or for pleasure, don't miss the opportunity to come to the Temple of Dawn. try to come in the day and photograph it and a must to come at night to do the same. I assure you will not be disappointed.
Best thing to see in Bangkok. One of the best sunsets in my life, get a place in Sala Rattanakosin and don't miss the sunset over this majestic temple!

Iconic. Iconic, specially when seen at night. But I was there in the middle of the day with temperatures well above 40 degrees Celsius. Then climbing those steep staircases to get to the top for a view over the river and the old city is a massive undertaking. But even without that it is certainly worth a visit. A great display of Khmer inspired architecture and craftmanship. Look for all the symbolic creatures...

Not easy to reach. The temple was exciting, like the other great culture destination. But it was not easy to reach the destination consider lack of navigation. You can reach the place by regular boat which costs only THB15. But so many 'trap' that send you to private port with private long boat which costs you about THB100.

Scary Steps. I saw it at night from the outside and went in at daytime. The steps are crooked and quite big. I was a bit scared to go up. I recommend that if you have fear of heights don't go up, but do go to see it from the outside. Once you are up the view is amazing and you can see the skyline. I went to this temple by car and it was a good experience. Also I would recommend wear comfortable clothing and shoes to visit this temple
Nice temple. Nice temple with great views. Just take the boat near the Grand Palace, it only costs 3 bht and takes 2 minutes.

Wonderful spectacle. This is the iconic temple you will see from the river. You'll have to most likely get a river boat over which is pretty cheap - although very full at rush hour. The entrance fee is reasonable (about $5 as I can remember) and you will be able to climb the temple to get a great view of the city from over the river.

Perfect During Sunset. The mosaic tiles + the sunset . . really a wow! This place shows the beauty of Thailand and really an essential during your trip to Bangkok.For travelers: It would be better if you'll take the cab going towards here. Just dont forget to tell the driver to use the METER. Avoid getting through here by a boat or youll regret it. We've seen a lot of tourist and mostly caucasians that are lured to take the boat for more sight seeing. You will see nothing and absolutely a big waste of money.. They ask for 650 baht for some and upto 1000 bahts or more for some instance, wherein fact, the place is really close to the boat station. If you do this so, aside from the boat fee, you need to pay another entrance before you n get into the compound and another fee before you can go climb in wat arun temple. Also, there where lifesize dancing figures wherein there is a face hole so you can take pictures. You also need to pay for this after some one has taken the pictures. The attendant will not inform you at the spot that you need to pay, but they will point on the ground that there is 40 baht marked on it. Again, extreme care to enjoy the surroundings.
Awesome. As a tourist... I was so impressed with the Temple. Magnificent. Easily a full day to see it all. I took the boatride over, that was fun too!

My favorite temple in Bangkok!. This was my favorite temple of all the ones I visited. Unfortunately, we visited at midday in 97 degree heat and so the lighting wasn't as favorable as what I've seen in other pictures online. But I did get to see it again from the river at night and it was pretty spectacular. The main thing for me was that I climbed to the top (or as high as one can climb). I just had to go up and see the view and it was worth the climb! Considering that I'm 61 years old, I was wearing a skirt, and I'm not in great shape, I was pretty proud of myself! The climb is very steep and pretty nerve wracking, but if you go slow and don't look up or down, it can be done. Our guide was not very good and she didn't point out all the amazing parts of the temple and other structures. I didn't really notice all the beautiful tiles and statues (since I was so focused on not dying on the stairs - LOL) until I looked at my pictures later. I wish I'd spent more time there really looking at everything. My advice is to take the time to walk around and truly look at the details of this amazing place.

Essential for any trip to Bangkok. Beautiful temple - fun to climb - recommend going early in the morning or early evening to avoid the heat of the day as you are exposed on the temple with no shade later in the day - combine with Wat Pho and the Grand Palace complex
Beautiful. It's a beautiful building. The mosaic tiles capture the sunrise beautifully. It's nice at any time of day but best at sunrise
Awesome!. it is a very special place, and magical too! I takes one back in time to sense the history of Wat Arun. The place is a reflection of the beauty of Thailand and it's people!

Must go. it's easy to get to Temple of Dawn or Wat Arun from Grand palace3 Baht for ferry boat wat = templearun = dawn, morning, rising sun free for local cause Thai pay tax and 50 Baht for tourist here not a big temple but you can climb to top of pagoda(stairs quite steep) to see nice view of Chao Phraya river

One of the Special Ones. Look, your obviously not going to look at every wat in Thailand... is literally impossible and will also send you well crazy.. but if you were to choose 5... this would be # 1at all times of day this Wat is incredible... but as is the case with these magnificent Temples... Dawn and Dusk offer the best viewing times with regards to Beauty.. and Photo Opportunities.Other reviews are spot on with heading there yourself or heading on a tour... both are cheap options ..

Don't miss it. Made a last minute dash from the Palace across the river to visit here before it closed and even though it was my third visit it is still amazing! That and I seem to keep forgetting how scary it is getting back down. Amazing sunsets here if you hit the right time :)

One of my Bangkok favourites. Wat Arun is amazing and was easily one of my favourites in Bangkok, this is definitely a sight that you should not overlook. Great views of Bangkok from the temple, beautiful grounds, and amazingly intricate temple details. Loved the bits and pieces of china cups and saucers on the facade of the temple.

Remarkable. The decors on the pagoda are tiles and boned china imported from China and individually laid. Apart from the pagoda, the main temple housed King Rama II relics while many Thai royalties were cremated on the temple ground.
Bangkok must see. Try to climb the stairs to see view. Breathtaking view to the palace and wat pho from the top of the temple.

Either independently or as a tour, Wat Arun is worth a visit. Take the regular commuter ferry, and then the cross river ferry, rather than some of the more expensive tourist boats. Its a difference of 15 Baht, versus 300/500/1000 Baht.
Great setting. I was almost templed out by the time we got to this one, but it is very different from other we visited, get there early in the morning to beat the crowds!
Must see. If you are in Bangkok , a must place to visit this awesome monument , specially at dawn . As you climb stairs ........ Awesome feeling .

Worth the trip across the river!. A beautiful, unexpected Wat with a harrowing climb to the middle section. Not for the faint of heart but worth the climb!
It was easy enough to get here using the river taxi- smaller dedicated boats run back and forth regularly to the far bank. Can be done in an hour if short on time.

Interesting Place. A must see after visiting the Grand Palace and Wat Pho on the other side of the river. There's a 3 minutes ferry ride to and from the river banks which cost only 3 thb one trip. I've made it to the highest deck of the temple. Climbing up was pretty easy but getting down later on wasn't. The stairs up are literally a 85 to 90 degrees incline which is close to a total verticle climb up/down. And my legs are shaking all the way down. The second deck (highest) aren't really suitable for elderly or people with acrophobia but the first deck is fine for everyone.Entrance fee is 50 baht if things havent changed. You'll get a nice panoramic view of bangkok city at the top (second deck) which is beautiful.

A must see. Glad to have seen it, as its on the other side of the river and a little less mayhem. It closes at 5,30 so thankfully we were 5 minutes late or we would probably have started to climb it like everyone else!

Beautiful Thai architecture. The temple of Dawn is one of most beautiful ancient thai architecture around. Whenever you visit thai temples, ladies have got to wear at least a shoulder covered top, and knee length pants or skirt. Otherwise, you can also rent the covers.

beautiful. The temple is really beautiful and it gives you a great view of the city. Remember to bring clothes with sleeves and cover your legs so that you don't have to pay for a sarong. You can take a boat that costs 3baht and then walk or take a tuktuk. That way is much cheaper than those excursions they sell.
Beautiful. Beautiful temple. I went at sunset, which gives a gorgeous light over the gardens. Absolutely worth a visit (unless you've already overdosed on Thai temples).

Delicacy. Done dinner cruise, boat cruising, drink at the hotel across from Wat Arun, and sightseeing. Different purpose each visit, and got to see the tempting side of Wat Arun. Probably ill do the dine out next time at Sala again to overlook this masterpiece

Splendor in the City. The Temple of Dawn or Wat Arun is an amazing tourist attraction in the city. You need to take a boat ride to cross the other side of the river to get there. The boat trip is inexpensive and run frequently. I visited Wat Arun only on my third trip to Bangkok and I am glad it did not give it a miss this time. Climb the steep stairs to the top and enjoy a good view of the river and Bangkok City. Excellent photo opportunity from the top.

Visited at noon.... Wouldn't say it's a must-see but it was beautiful on its own right. I don't recommend visiting at high noon as the lighting is (naturally) terrible. Take the temple's name as a hint.
Entrance ticket comes with a guide to teach you something about the temple.

Beautiful. Amazing temple, steep climb but well worth it...a must see!
Little boat across the river from Wat Pho for 4 baht!

you always remember your first stupa.. wonderful ancient architecture in the heart of a cosmopolitan city. a cultural phenomenon too.
A must go for all who visit bangkok.
Lovely site. Definitely worth a visit if you can. Lovely, beautiful temple and lush gardens. It's nice to get the boats and ferries around there too. Great photograph opportunity here!

Definitely worth your time. On my first every visit to BKK, i was sure i wanted to visit the main temples, and Wat Arun was on the list. And i am glad i went here, in fact i enjoyed it more that the Emerald Buddha and Wat Poh (the reclining Buddha), it probably had to with the time of the visit. Went here early in the morning (we were one of the first ones to buy the ticket). It opens at 8am. So avoided the bigger crowds that start coming in later in the day. Actually it is very good idea to get here early, as there is some climbing to do, and the heat later on in the day will make it more difficult. Even at 8, the sun was pretty strong! The views from the top of the river Chao Phraya were amazing. It makes it worth the climb. The main spire looks beautiful contrasted with a clear sky. And it surely is a beauty, worthy of its recognition as a landmark (you see it imprinted on the coins). There are some shops on the entrance on the river side, we bargained to buy a few small items, which i think was a good deal!
Worth a visit.. Another example of the quality Thai's place in their temples. Remember, to enter any of the temples you must remove footwear.

A must go for first-timers in Bkk. A quite touristy place but must go for first timers in Bangkok. Try going after it is dark. The light-out is really beautiful but visitors are not allowed to climb up the place.
Nice view. Go during the sunset! Its very beautiful. The vies is absolutely amazing, but its dificult to climb the steps. Be careful.

Wat Arun Temple. This Wat - Temple is one of the most famous and well known temples in the whole of Thailand. I frequently visit this beautiful place and is only a short boat WAT PO, where the sleeping Budda and emerald Budda is kept. It's situated further down river on the Thon Buri side of bangkok. There is other places you can visit near to this temple and it has a nice Thai culture market in the Siriraj, and aray of Thai food stalls a lot cheaper than the inner city of Bangkok.It's only a 10 minute taxi ride from Kho san Road. Come and see for yourself. The best time to visit here is around early morning and at sunset, where you will get some beautiful sunset photo's of this Temple. sunset time around 17:00 to 18:00 pm if you what to enter inside the temple, then it will cost you 50 baht and the outter area is free.
Iconic. Must visit place when in Thailand. Take a boattrip on the Chao Praya express around sunset. It is amazing.

Most unique temple in Bangkok. After a long, hot day dealing with thousands of other tourists at The Grande Palace, Wat Arun was the perfect attraction to visit. The temple is by far the most unique and beautiful temple that we visited in Thailand. It boasted some of the most incredible views of the river and the skyline once you make the daring climb to the top. Getting to the temple is cheap and easy. It is just a quick (and slightly sketchy) boat ride across the Chao Phraya River. There are also some amazing restaurants and bars in the area that have amazing views of the temple lights at night.For the price and convenience, Wat Arun is a must see for any traveler. You will see a different and unique side to Bangkok, while spending as little as 50 baht.

Climb It to The Top. Laid on the side of Chao Praya river, this temple scenery is beautiful. You can access into the top of the temple by using stairs. The stairs are not easy to be climbed, but the view from the top is amazing! You should come when it's dawn, and watch the sunset from the top.

great eats. remarkable structureinteresting river crossingfantastic little street food alley before entering the temple - there was some rather delectable and intriguing stuff, pancakes, soft-drinks, ice-creams each was unique.... and reasonably priced.the climb was steep and scary, fun for my sonview of the river from the top and the palacelilting chants

Fascinating. An amazing building - fantastic workmanship. The steep climb to the top is worth the effort for the view across the river . We were disappointed not to have sufficient time to visit the interior of the building.
nice place. Be careful about tuk tuk drivers trying to cheat you. They will often try to tell you the temple is closed just to take you places at your expense.
Wow!. Very steep to climb but amazing view from the top. Wear respectable clothing or else you have to hire but only 100 baht deposit. The ablutions facilities is not that great!

Must See - Super Steep. This is a must see Temple, purely for climbing the stairs. The stairs are so steep that it is very freaky to climb up it and back down. The stairway is also so thin that you cannot have that many people there on the stairway at once. Absolutely amazing to see. We went during the day. I'd recommend going during the day and night.We also took a taxi over, rather than a boat. A few boats tried to scam us for 600 Baht, so we took a 70 Baht taxi or so!

What a run!!. I love this place and i visit it every time i come to Bangkok. It's really beautiful in the sunset while grabing a drink on the other side of Chao Prayha. The stairs can be a bit tough if you older or are scared of heights.

Great but not that great. So this was an exciting place to begin with as temples are a huge part of the Thailand culture. Getting here was quite a task too as you have to switch trains and then at the end take a ferry. But getting there was fun as you travel. Once there, I thought I'll be able to traverse the long stairs upto the too. Turns out there are just 2 floors. And then the access was restricted or there aren't more stairs to go. I mean this place is subjective. But still it is definitely worth a visit.

Beautiful. We really enjoyed our visit to Wat Arun. We went on a Sunday morning. It was quiet and peaceful. Local worshippers were making offers to the monks. We climbed up the temple and enjoyed the view over the river. Worth a visit, take about 1-1.5 hours to take this in.

Beautiful day or night. Wat Arun is really one of the "must-see" attractions along the Chao Praya River. If you're going to schedule a visit to the Grand Palace (and you should!) then you should also try to pay a visit to Wat Arun.
Beautiful at Night. Fewer tourists and cooler nights. Can't climb it but looks beautiful. Bring a good camera and/or tripod.

Great view from the top!. Visited Wat Arun whilst on a tour of the Thonburi Klongs (canal boat ride) before heading to the Grand Palace. We were some of the first visitors on the day which was probably ideal really as it isn't the biggest place and I'd imagine it can get quite crowded later on in the day. The amount of visitors will have a bearing on whether you decide to climb to the top of the temple (very steep steps), which I would highly recommend for the fantastic view over the river towards the Grand Palace. We spent about an hour here which was about the right amount of time. We will probably visit the temple again at some point in the future when we return with relatives.

Worth to visit!. Famous landmark in BKK. This one is not for the faint of heart and have fear of heights. The temple stairways are steep. It's really worth to visit and reach the top of the temple. You'll love the view of the Chao Praya river and city of BKK especially during the afternoon sunset.

วัดอรุณราชวรารามฯ. The full name of the temple is Wat Arunratchawararam Ratchaworamahawihan. Named after Aruna. The temple is so named because the first light of the morning reflects off the surface of the temple.

great views. climbing to the top of this place is great a little steep tho breath taking view of the river real can you feel Bangkok come alive. I took a ferry late at night also and saw this temple the place looked magnificent it was lighten up bang out a few shot.
The view. Awesome temple. Was my favorite. had a little panic attack climbing the second set of stairs. It's a thrill and would totally do it again, plus the view from the top was amazing!
Wonderful Temple across from the Grand Palace. Easy to get to, and very reasonable entry fee. Right across the river from the Palace. Very tall, so you gotta climb.

Worth seeing!!. Absolutely one of the highlights in Bangkok! But be carefull, very steep and high stairs. In case you are afreight of heights it might be less nice. Take the time to look also at the rest of the area. Relax at the riverbank and enjoy the view to the busy Chao Praya. Best to arrive by boat! Take BTS line Silom, station Saphan (Taksin Pier). At the water you will find the pier of the public boats that will bring you to the Temple.

Bangkok - Wat Arun - Superb temple and great views if you climb to the top.. This is a wonderful temple standing virtually on the banks of the river, and a must visit in Bangkok with its climb to the top level. This is not an easy climb but even if you make the first level than it is well worth it. The upper top level is a bit of a challenge particularly when you come to descend as the steps are extremely steep but if you can make it then the views around and up and down the river are brilliant. Relatively cheap to get in we got here late in the afternoon and it was pleasantly not too busy, although waiting to climb up and down was a bit of a task as people either bottled it going up or nervously put off matters to get back down. You just had to be kind and crack on or you could be there all day. The mosaic form of covering is superb and the temple itself a wonder of the city. Spend an hour or so just wandering around its base and if you do climb up then you'll remember it for a long time.

Well worth a visit. Took a long tail boat ride and had a rather quick look round as it was raining. Would have liked more time. Very serene and steeped in history and culture. If you only do a couple of Temple tours - make this one of them.

Unique Bangkok Wat. A must see in Bangkok, although climbing up (& especially down) are not for those with a fear of heights. Superb location on the riverside. Short distance & ferry crossing from other major attractions.

Detailed architecture temple. I amazed with the details of the temple. Beautiful temple. If you dare and have a good heart, you can try to climb the temple. Did I climb it? of course Not... Just saw it only make my knees limp.This temple is look more beautiful at night, because of many lights on the temple.Note. the cheaper T-shirt for souvenir is here.

Wat Arun - Excellently situated on the banks of the Chao Phraya River. Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) is located on the western bank of the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok and is one of the most popular attractions in the city. This large Buddhist temple that is enjoyable to visit and can be beautifully seen from the other side of the river. At Wat Arun (50 baht per person) was built between 1809 to 1851 during the reigns of King Rama II and King Rama III. Here you will find five separate Khmer style prang (towers), with the large centre prang towering 70 metres into the sky. You can partially climb the central prang by climbing rather steep steps found along its sides. The towers are decorated with encrusted porcelain and stucco figures that add colour to the temple when viewed from a distance. While attractive from up close, we actually prefer viewing Wat Arun from across the Chao Phraya River. Having the river in front of the temple adds to the view and makes for better pictures. In the evening and at night views continue to impress as the temple grounds are lit by flood lights. At Wat Arun, you will find souvenir stands as well as boat piers where you can feed catfish that reside in this part of the river. This is considered a lucky activity. Fish food can be purchased (10 baht) for a bucket of pellets or bag of bread. For those eager to visit additional temples on this side of the Chao Phraya River, you might want to make time to see Wat Kalayanamitr (large seated Buddha) and/or Wat Rakang as well. Combined these three temples make a nice way to spend 1/2 day on the western side of the river. Overall, Wat Arun is a very nice temple in Bangkok. It makes for excellent views and pictures from across the Chao Phraya and is worth visiting for those who want to see it from up close. Hint: For meals and drinks with excellent views of Wat Arun, try Bitter Deck or ESS Deck restaurants and the Eagle Nest or Sala Rattanakosin Rooftop bars, found near Wat Po on the eastern side of Chao Phraya River. We enjoyed each of these venues and have reviews for them here on TA if helpful. Hint: Ferry crossing from the Tha Tien Pier to Wat Arun is 3 baht per person and takes 3-4 minutes only. This is the cheapest and most convenient means for crossing the river to visit Wat Arun.
Very good temple. It was one of the only different temple , which folllows the combodian style of architechture. Steep steps very inviting , i could not climb the last stretch but my son did.

Mind the stairs!!!. If you have a problem with heights - do not climb up all the stairs, as coming back down they are very steep and quite scary looking down them, be careful! Remember to cover up if wearing a vest top or shorts. Loved this temple :)

A site for sore eyes. Well worth the few baht ferry ride for the breeze alone !! A short trip across enables you to enjoy the river for 5 minutes, then after a short easy walk up the pier, its the most wonderful sight for sore eyes as you take in the incredible mosaic work covering every piece of available wall space. If you have the energy and the mobility take a climb to the top of the temple, though not for the faint hearted, the views all round are beautiful. We went in the late afternoon when most of the crowds had moved on, so for a few hours, we were able to walk around and enjoy the tranquillity and beauty of such an amazing place. A little respite in such a busy city.A definite must see whilst in Bangkok.
The temples are amazing. Whilst in Bangkok we visited all the major temples. Wat Arun is definitely a must see. Make sure you go early to beat the crowds.
Awesome Architecture. A must visit place in Bangkok. Transfer to Wat Arun is by boat and the entrance fee is only 50 bath.

night time beauty. unfortunately was only able to visit at night so didnt get to go inside or climb it but it's a very beautiful temple to see, all lit up and very serene at night beside the river. not to be missed

This place should be on your "to do" list. Combine the trip with a early visit to the King Palace and take a ferry on the river to this Wat (temple). Also yo can take a trip by the river, use a fast boat, or take the ferry bus, which is cheap and stop in the wat when comming back from the river.
Amazing architecture. River views and grand, old sculpture- worth a visit but cover up as a temple. you might need to hire clothes if in shorts. Very steep steps .....

I went at dawn ... it was closed. This was on my list of places to visit, but when I arrived at dawn to find that it doesn't open until 8 AM, I was a but disappointed. I'll bet it looks great at dusk (and might be opened).

Don't miss this one. This is unique in its decoration and a beautiful temple well worth seeing. Decorated with seashells and pieces of Chinese porcelain all over, you are able to climb it for some lovely views, but at night it is one of the major landmarks of Bangkok itself, when it is lit up to provide a beautiful sight and backdrop along the river.

interesting. very interesting place to visit although a bit difficult if you have problems with heights: difficult to climb to the top and even more difficult to go down - the stairs are really abrupt and steep!
Marvelous. ONe of the nicest experiences in Bangkok, fully recomended, I recommend you study your tour in advance as there's no much indications around when you visit
A beautiful temple you must visit. Nice temple & friendly monk! The exterior & interior view is amazing. We skipped climbing the steep stairs due to limited time.

Very interesting temple. Due to the heat (we were travelling with a 9 year old), we did not climb the steep stairs or go in. It looked interesting and fabulous from the outside and the food vendors there were good too.

Beautiful temple, great views. This temple is beautiful. Be prepared for a steep climb up to the top. I walked sideways like you do in snow shoes when ascending and descending and did not experience any difficulties. The view from the top is amazing. The little market outside that was run by the neighboring school was one of the best and offered some unique items like the flavored waters and fresh summer rolls (watch the spicy sauce - no joke spicy and I like it hot!).

Free food!. When we went there the monks gave us free Thai food. It was delicious. It made me smile. They were so nice. Thai food is so awesome. The rest of it was way touristy, but I loved the free food.

Nice Temple with a view. The temple is situated west bank of the river and to reach it from the palace you have to take a bus boat to cross the river.
The temple itself looks beautiful from the river. When climbing the stairs up the temple there is a nice view.
Uniquely beautiful. This temple has it's own feel and look, well worth the visit and the small donation asked of you at the gate.

Must visit !!! Not to be missed.. This beautiful temple is an excellent place to visit in the evening. It look beautiful at dawn when lit up. One gets an excellent view of the temple from Rajni Pier, if one is interested in taking night shots of the temple. Do not miss the steep climb to the temple top, its scary but definitely worth the climb.

Interesting place. Wat Arun or Temple of the Dawn is situated at the west of Chao Phraya river bank in Thonburi area. The temple is surrounded by small towers or Phra Prang. You can climb the very steep stairs to enjoy the view from the top. (Assumption height is more than 100 meter).The temple is photogenic, although the best spot to photograph this beautiful temple is from the river, unless if you are using wide angle.If you are fancy to take your picture taken in Thai dress, there is Thai traditional dress for hire.The temple is open from 8.30 to 5.30 with entrance fee of 200 THB.

beautiful from the other side of the river. from the other side of the river it looks amazing. once u there .... nothing special to see. stones. hot. after 5 minutes we left the place and took the taxi boat

Amazing. Wat Arun can be seen from a long distance, but getting there takes some knowledge.Just take the boat from anywhere along the river. This should only cost you 15 baht. Do not buy the ticket before getting on the boat. Buying it before you get on the boat costs you about 80% more than on the boat itself. This boat should cost you about 15 Baht. Get off the boat at the dock closest to Wat Arun (on the opposite side of the river) then take the ferry to the other side for around 4 Baht, then it's a 2 minute walk. around Wat Aruns gates there are also multiple food stalls that sell great food and fresh coconut(water). There is a sign post saying "Tickets" in front of the gates of Wat Arun, but the entrance is free of charge. At the ticket desk they charge you 50 Baht for a guide which is not present.It is not recommended for people that are afraid of heights. The structure itself isn't that high, but the stairs up are extremely steep.

Must to go place. Must to go if you visit Bangkok to get some understanding of culture. It is a central famous buddhist temple situated on the banks of the Chao Phraya River. The temple is so-called because supposedly the first light of morning shines off the temple and gives off a renowned glare.
worth a visit. Stopped by during our canal boat ride. Worth a stop. Even more enjoyable close up. Only can walk up halfway.

Location Location Location. What a lovely location for a temple, on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River. This temple complex has several structures decorated with pieces of colored tile, with little or no gold gilt. But the effect of the tiered structure and the exponentially curving profile, reaching for the heavens, is quite pleasing. It is enjoyable to climb up two steep staircase/ladders to reach different tiers and feast your eyes on the views at each level. This would certainly be a lovely place from which to watch a sunrise. The ferry shuttle across the river from the east side costs only 3 baht, about 10 cents U.S. The entry to the temple area costs 20 baht. Vendors were selling drink, snacks and tourist trinkets at the site.

Better than Wat Pho. Wat Arun (or the Temple of Dawn) is another Buddhist temple situated on the banks of the Chao Phraya River. The temple is so-called because supposedly the first light of morning shines off the temple and gives off a renowned glare. As such, watching this event at dawn is a popular pastime. Wat Arun has a famous central prang, which is built in Khmer style, and it is possible to ascend the very steep stairs to the top, to get some good views over the river. This central prang is surrounded by four smaller prangs. At Wat Arun, you can be expected to be charged 50Baht for admission.

Beautiful and exciting but not for anyone afraid of heights!. Before you can get to Wat Arun, you'll need to cross the river on a boat. This ride costs 3 baht. The temple grounds are quite neat and have a souvenir market nearby. Like many other temples, it's a requirement to cover your shoulders and knees. When I arrived I was inappropriately dressed with shorts above my knees. I had to hire a sarong for 100 baht but I get 80 baht back when I return it. The highlight of visiting Wat Arun is the excitement of climbing the stairs. It is so steep it is almost like climbing a ladder. The stairway is narrow and there are hand railings on both sides. It is definitely not for the faint hearted. The first set is not too bad but it gets progressively steeper in the next 2 sets. Between each storey of steps is a level where you are able to walk around the temple and see the city. The views are lovely. Going up the stairs was a challenge in itself but going down is the scary part. There isn't actually that much danger because you have the railings to hold onto and everyone moves down quite slowly but I think it's more a psychological fear that makes it scary. Definitely something I would recommend people to do in Bangkok. Since it is also very near the Flower markets and Chinatown we made good use of being around that area of the city for the day.

Amazing. This temple is gorgeous. The steps are very steep but are sooo worth it once you reach the top. The views over Bangkok are amazing. If you are im Bangkok and can afford the 50b entrance I would defo go :)
great view worth the hike. great view and beautiful architecture. it is well worth the climb up the many stairs. don't forget your camera

Beautiful. Didn't like the heat and humidity this time of the year. The temple is beautiful and you can get a great view of the Grand palace from the top of the temple. Take the boat over, neat experience.

Amazing place. I loved Wat Arun. Just the crazy walk to the top is the greatest moment you can have in Bangkok. I think this is a must in every traveller's checklist. The views and photo opportunities are endless.

Steps, steps, steps. Every step is worth the effort, this is an amazing place and the view from the top is just so worthwhile From here you can actually see how big the grand palace is. I loved the mosaic detail on the building as well as the gardens

Come!. Came here with my local family who live in Bangkok and it was an amazing day. A beautiful temple with lovely grounds in a central area of town by the river, great spot for photos. It was really hot and humid that day, but up at the top of the steps on the temple, it was the best breeze...Highly highly recommended! Take the ferry over!!

Lovely view. One of their most magnificent temples, it is a must-see for all visitors.One may visit the shrine and the magnificent Buddha statues as well as the lovely surroundings, or climb up the steep flight of steps to the top for more mystical sights.Its pearl / porcelain elegance brings out the intricate works of the architectural designs of this temple. So this place is the perfect location for tranquil worship, rest and feast for the eyes, a religious-lesson for all the curious minded.It was also here that my friends and I donned ourselves in traditional Thai costumes for photo-taking. It was a very interesting experience.For more detailed information and photos, do viist:http://thearcticstar.blogspot.sg/2014/01/tackling-thailand-bangkok.html
beautiful temple. I love this temple,It's very beautiful and fantastic.this the most important and beautiful temple in Thailand.

Part Temple, Part Adventure Park. Wat Arun is a Buddhist temple dedicated to a Hindu god. Yet another of the many incongruities in Thailand, which undoubtedly lead to the creation of the term "Land of Smiles." Like many temples it looks better from a distance. The temple known for it's pearly iridescence, caused by porcelain inlays up close looks like someone dropped their best china and glued the broken pieces to the sides of the temple. The Wat Arun once housed the Emerald Buddha and was within the palace grounds. Both have now moved across the river leaving the poor Wat Arun in the low rent district. But the climb up the perilous staircase to the next more perilous staircase to the final staircase of death which can only be climbed by grasping the railing with both hands an pulling yourself up adds a redeeming nature for the thrill seeker. Once atop the temple one enjoys the breathtaking view while meditating in fine Buddhist style, "How the hell am I going to get down from here."While the guards are not as strict as at the palace, woman probably should not wear short skirts, as the climb up the stairs would expose everything. This is a fun place to double dear your friends and loved ones to experience new heights.Note: The view of Wat Arun seems to be the selling point for all the boat ride shills. If you really need a boat ride, go for it. But Wat Arun can be visited by few baht ferry ride and a quick tuk tuk trip.

Must see of Bangkok. Perfect view to the old city, amazing architecture of dawn and exciting be-reliefs. One of the wonderful pieces of thai's history.
There is a small cozy restaurant near with a view to the river and old city where perfect fish is served.

One not to miss. Amazing place, but very busy like most of Bangkok. The climb up the steep stairs is great fun, but beware of the idiots going the wrong way. You need flat shoes, once you get up there the view is spectacular over the river and old Bangkok.The temple is beautiful, not quite as intricate or flashy as the Grand palace. It would be better to visit very early or late when less busy.

Wat Arun - Look at but pass by.. There is no doubt that Wat Arun, the Temple of the Dawn, makes a dramatic statement on the banks of the Chao Praya River.Though it is known as Wat Arun - it is actually best photographed in the sunset light from the perspective of the River.Please check with the concierge of your hotel to see if you can ENTER the Wat - because it has "Restoration construction" in progress.If you land you can (if it is open) climb up the steps to the top. To do this you must be VERY fit and have a good supply of water. It is a LONG way up. At the top you can't just hang around and photograph the surrounding beauty. Polite but firm temple assistants will move you on and down. There are many higher rise hotels in the area - take a trip to one and take an ice cold lime juice in the Roof garden and enjoy the equally spectacular view in comfort.You CAN rent a place in a long tailed boat for 500 baht and sail past Wat Arun with plenty of time for nice photos. Or you can take the public Ferry for 11 baht.NOT photographing or looking at Wat Arun is a bit like visiting Rome and not going to see the Colosseum.

Stunning. We actually did not take steps into Wat Arun but took the river cruise from Shangri-La hotel along the Chaopraya River. We passed Wat Arun and I must say the view is breathtaking, especially at night with the lights on. A sight to remember!
Superb!. The temple is definitely worth the visit. You have to buy a ticket to get to the ferry that brings you to the Temple. The temples has very steep steps but the view from the top is very nice.
Unique Experience at Wat Arun. Bangkok has so many temples but Wat Arun stands out in its unique stupa and the fresco work. A must see!

Nice Temple in Bangkok. Wat Arun is located by the Chao Praya River with a great view and artistic architecture. We have to cross the river using their river transportation (similar like boat) with only THB 3 per person.

Great views of the old city. Great views of the old city and the Chao Phraya River. Interesting way up to the stairs! As in many other temples, if you're a woman, bring a shawl or shirt to cover your shoulders and, if wearing a skirt or shorts, bring at least a knee length skirt to cover up; if you're a man, consider long pants. They also rent those if you don't carry them with you.,

Must see, even if you don't go there.. Going there was good, but hard to take in the site itself while being there (forest through the trees). Better view is to see it one of the few restaraunts on the observation decks right across the river. Reserve during the evening when it goes from evening to night.

A Must See. This temple is absolutely fascinating, easy to explore, and full of wonderfully artistic temple art. It is fun to climb the steep stairs to the top level and see the surrounds and the temple itself from that perspective. Don't miss it!
Great temple. Great peacefully temple, great view and quite a climb. Beautiful piece of art. Amazing view over the river
A must visit temple in Bangkok. Excellent view from the top. Temple is a nicely crafted stone structure. You will get a birds eye, well a little below that view of Bangkok.
Great. A must see!!!! 1st time in Bankok and wanted to see as much as I could in 3 days. Definitely glad I saw this temple.
superb scene. pay 3 baht to get here from across pier. Remember to bring sun block, the sun will burn you if not. a lot of indonesia here, they can speak bahasa.

a Must!. Beautiful temple, it's amazing the amount of work done in it.
Stairs very small but worth the effort, you get to see a beautiful
view of the city.

Beautiful Wat Arun. The temple is very beautiful cause its ceramic decoration, especially at night with the light on it. if you want to climb the stairs to the top of the temple, visitors should pay entrance fee for 50 bath. The stairs are very narrow, so be careful when climb up and go down the stairs. Around Wat Arun there are many shop selling shirts and souvenirs with good quality. Souvenirs and t-shirt quality is better here than pratunam or chatuchak market. Here you also can find shop that rent traditional clothes for 100 bath.
A beautiful temple. Thailand is the god place of temple . All the temple covered by gold , so elegant and fancy . Bow down my head and respect for all of wonder history of this temple.

A great sight!. To get to Wat Arun you must cross the Chao Phraya River, and any excuse to be on a boat is a good one for me! Once you get to the Wat you can climb up a few levels, and get great views of the river and of parts of the city. Furthermore, the Wat itself is beautiful, and by climbing and seeing it really close up you can notice so much more than just viewing it from the water!
Amazing!. We went there in the afternoon and again dined across at a restaurant with a full view of the temple. A must see!

little gem until u stand beside it. This incredible complex from the river looks quite boring but when u land at the pier and enter the site you are instantly transfered into a world of splendour the gardens and lawns immaculate lush with greeneryand and then you see tthe temple up close and your first thought is completely reversed, the temple is huge in size and splendour you should only climb the temple if you have head for nights as surprisingly is quite tall and very small stairs to the top levels bare foot is better. The views across and of the city are breath taking the detail of the temple is mind boggling
Awesome. Everything and all the lovely people I met on this particular visit, steps a bit of a challenge but once your up its well worth it.
Beautiful and challenging. It's a beautful Temple, but climbing really steep stairs was even more memorable ;) give it a try and you won't regret as the view over the river is really great!

Best View from restaurant near Wat Pho. Take the Chao Phaya River Tourist Boat and stop at Tha Tien Pier. Wat Pho is within walking distance. Recommend to take lunch at Coconut Palm Restaurant near Wat Pho (local Thai food). You can find the location of this restaurant in Tripadvisor. We know the boss and she served us their signature dishes - noodle, pat thai & etc. Very delicious! Then take a short walk to any restaurant nearby. Go up to the higher floor and take a photo of Wat Arun. Recommend during sunset and enjoy the great view!

Nice!. If go to bangkok, dont forget to visit this temple. You can have very nice view from the top of the temple. But before that, u need to climb the steep stairs and I did it! Make sure you wear proper clothes so that u dont have to wear their sarong!

Wonderful experience. I personally loved my visit to Wat Arun. The grounds are particularly well kept and the atmosphere in this temple is a delight especially coming from the bustling streets of Bangkok. My family were a little weary of walking to the top of the temple so I went up alone and it was truly a beautiful experience. Steps are very steep just be careful :)
Amazing climb with great views. You must check out this temple if you visit Bangkok. There is a fun boat ride involved and a steep climb up to the temple but it is worth it for the views!
Its OK. You have to take a ferry across the river to get to this one. It's more impressively viewed at night when it lit up from the other side (without crossing over the river).

Amazing.. Its hard to describe what makes visiting historical places so great, but visiting Wat Arun was something i will remember for a long time. Its beauty, its details... Well, my best advice for you reading this is just go see for yourself!
Amazing!!!. We had a great time at this beautiful site make sure you have tennis shoes to climb up the stairs! My legs are still sore but well worth it!

Wonderful trip. You would have to take a very interesting boat ride for around 600 to 700 bhat to get here. You can also ask to be dropped off on you next destination's dock afterwards. You will pay 50 bhat to get in the temple, and climb a very steep set of stairs to get to the top. But the view is amazing. The best view is during the dawn. The temple is beautiful with all the colorful mosaics and statues.
Worth the climb. We did a boat trip and visited this temple. The climb to the top was very very steep but well worth it. A must if your heading to Bangkok

So different close up. The most famous of Bangkok's temples, highly visible on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River. Close up it is entirely not what you would expect. It is one massive mosaic of smashed bits of porcelain. If you like art its nice to just lose yourself seeing the crazy mix of designs on the broken crockery. The signs around the place are pretty funny too, I particularly liked "Do Not Dangle any Doll".

Beautiful. One of the main attractions in Bangkok.Worth the visit. I visited during a cloudy day. For what I´ve seen in the pictures, it´s probably much nicer at night. The stairways to the top is extremely steep, with very narrow steps - be careful! Everything is on your own responsability!Visiting at night is probably more beautiful, but the transportation is not so easy at night - you need to take the ferry, and it´s not so organized, hard to get the directions, since there´s nothing in english and no staff in many stations.
A temple you shouldn't miss. There are so many temples all around Bangkok, you sometimes don't want to do all. This is really the one to choose. It is beautiful and it is nice to climb up to the top.

It's worth climbing the very steep and narrow stairs. A good friend recommended visiting this temple. And it was so worth it. Take a boat ride t get there, an experience in itself (make sure you get on one of the big boats as the small/narrow ones go so terribly fast you can not take any pictures). At the top of the temple - it's really worth climbing these rather scary narrow steps - one has a good view over the water and the nearby Wat Phra Kaeo temple. These two temples and Wat Pho (reclining Buddha) can easily be visited in one day, if one has the stamina to beat the heat (drink lots of water). But back to Wat Arun: The outside of the temple is made of pottery of all kinds of colour and designs. Really interesting up close and makes for good photo shots.

Must-see temple in Bangkok. A temple by Chao Pra Ya river, this is a very good attraction if you're looking for a temple with awesome tower. You might have to beat your fear of height though if you want make the best out of this place. You can take a boat across to the other side the river to reach other temples easily too. I always take my friends from a abroad to this temple if they request to see one....100% positive feedback so far!

Favourite temple of Bangkok. Get close up, as the temple is finished with thousands of shards of broken chinese pottery. Travel there by riverboat. Later, if it is not too busy, find the Amorosa Bar on the other side of the river, for the perfect sunset panaroma of the temple and river.

Wat Arun. Great temple and if you climb to the top its got great views down the river. Easy to do this as a combo with the Golden Palace and reclining Buddha which is very close on the opposite side of the river.

Perfectly visible along the river side.. The most unusual temple in construction. Actually quite recent, but built in an ancient style. Very beautiful early morning or at night. The ferry fare is actually 3 baht, but the con-men in longtail boats will ask you for 1500 baht for a tour. 50 baht entry, drinks and snacks available, manageable size, allow an hour. If you are shaky on your feet and/or affected by heat and heights then do not climb it!

Peaceful and Beautiful. We saw at least a dozen temples on our visit to Thailand, but this one stood out as having the most peaceful atmosphere. The hectic, Disneyland-like ambiance of some of the major temples is missing here. Even the tourists seemed calmer and more respectful. The view from the other side of the river is the best, and taking one of the public boats to cross the river to the temple is highly recommended. The climb to the top is quite steep and should only be undertaken by those in good physical condition.
Must see. Distance okay.. Didn't climb to top, but saw from across river at dusk and then again while our on the river. Stunning!
is okay. Has a more "real" feel to it than the other famous temples and is next to the river. But a bit small.
Dazzles at dawn or dusk. This is a wonderful place but the best time to see it in all it's beauty is at dusk if possible. Glorious site
Fun, but steep climb with young kids. Was a nice cultural experience, but the climb to the top is not very secure, so hang on to your young ones closely going up and down!

Original Wat, but no need to pay to visit. I liked this Wat, i thought it was very different (no gold, more porcelain) than the other main ones (Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaew). And in my opinion no need to pay to climb as this Buddhist temple can be observed and appreciated from the nearby fence.I found bizarre that my girlfriend was able to go around all the way to where a buddha statue stands (which is where the monks pray) without being asked to add clothing, yet she had to pay 20bats to put a dress when going to the tower where no monk were seen…?

OK but pales in comparison to the Grand Palace. The central tower is nice to see but other than that, we were surprised to know that this is referred to as the symbol of Thailand. I think it probably looks better either in different lighting or from across the river. Glad we stopped but not a place to spend too much time at.
Impressive place!. Went here on a private boat tour. Didn't understand alot of it, but was impressed with the architecture and it made for great pictures!

A Must see!. For the traveler who first time come to Bangkok, this place is a must visit place! Put it in your itinerary; "Take a picture in front of the Temple" or "Take a picture of Bangkok at the top of Temple of Dawn, when the sun goes down!" Its beautiful!
recommended!. you might have to pay some fee to get through entrance but it is definitely worth it. this is a nice place for you and friend release stress.

Very nice temple. Its a great place to visit while in bangkok. nice temple with friendly people and easy to get to. This temple charges a small fee at entrance (atleast i got charged 50 or 100 baht) but it was definetly worth it and you can get some great pictures over the river.

great views of BKK and river. a 3baht ferry ride over from wat pho gets you to Wat Arun. Worth a visit to see the work that went into building it and wont take up to much time to visit. if you have a head for heights climb the steps to the top of the spire for breathtaking views over the river. Dress appropriately, no bare knees or shoulders.
Wat Arun Bangkok!. Wat Arun Bangkok is another Must do thing in Bangkok if you have never been here! Get there early and enjoy the sunrise!

Get ready for a climb. Great temple to visit if you are up for climbing up the very steep stairs to enjoy the view. Note if you arrive by private boat, they will charge you a landing fee in addition to admission to the temple. You are not charged the landing fee if you arrive by public boat.

Beautiful place that you wont want to miss it!. It is a beautiful place to visit. Nice place to take many picture. Be careful because when we are making our way up is getting more steep. So please take care of each other and enjoy the view overthere. when you reach the top is a very nice view! "take a deep breathe" Is really worth climbing up. I would bring my friends along next time.

Views of the temple and the Chao Praya river make the steep stairs worthwhile. We arrived in the humid heat of April, and read that the temple exudes an iridescent glow in the first morning light. With an abundance of sea-shells and other adornments on its surface, it's easy to see why this would be the case. There is a dress code in effect -- they seem fine to tolerate tasteful shorts, but if you have short dresses they will rent you a sarong (their concern about the steep stairs and how short dresses would work there is understandable). Also worth walking around the temple grounds -- we saw a Buddhist monk in a nearby building meditating and interacting with the public, and there are some beautiful gardens as well. The view of the Chao Praya river from the top of Wat Arun is stunning.

Temple of Dawn or " Heaven". We took the boat over a quick 10-15 minute ride, but you could also take the hop on/off and get off there as well. It is a stunning site, with many places and areas to explore! Beware and be prepared to pay the 30 baht pp when you get off the boat and then to get into the Temple another 100 baht pp, not what they tell you prior to arrival. You can take all the pictures you wish. You have a VERY steep climb to the top, you will need both hands and one person at a time climbing up one side and you climb down the other side. This is NOT for someone who is scared of heights! It is a beautiful site up from the top, but you do need to be a little bit fit to make it and the last set of stairs you need to step sideways and the steps are about the height of 2 steps each. Take water as you will definitely need it at the top! The mosaics and statues are so intricate and beautiful you will really enjoy them. You can see the navy base from the top of the temple as well. Make sure to walk around and see the gardens to the side of the Temple, they are worth seeing and taking pictures of. They have awesome statues of warriors on each side and the garden itself is really pretty. Enjoy and take your time.
spectacular temple. Very beautiful but steep climb to the top. There is a easy boat connection to cross the river and go to Wat Po

Steep stairs, but worth the trip. Wat Arun is right on the river (beautiful when it's lit up at night), but really is worth a trip. We enjoyed taking pictures with the guardians and slowly making our way up each level as we appreciated some of the intricacies of the art along the way. The stairs are fairly steep and you have to go single file. There's not much surrounding this temple, so it can be a fairly quick visit.

Wow! Don't Miss this temple!. I absolutely loved, loved visiting this temple. The temple of dawn has incredible views at night by boat and make sure you get there before 6 pm because that's when it closes and you wouldn't want to miss it! Gorgeous architecture, beautiful history and amazing structure...a must see!

Good for a quick visit. What's cool about this temple (Wat) is that you can climb up it to get a great view across the river and Bangkok. Apart from that, there is not a lot more to see and do, which is also kind of nice after having spent considerable time exploring the Grand Palace complex and Wat Pho. Wat Arun is best appreciated from the other side of the river, at sunset

Adventure in altitude. Very nice place to visit, you will pay a fee to get a boat that leades you to Wat Arun, the lovely Dawn Temple. You will see it iluminated at the riverside, but to get and climb it, is another adventure. High and sharp steps will ask you for some litlle corage. But the view upstairs is very nice, Bring a pen yo leave your messages on the top! Very excting!

Beautiful ancient temple on the banks of the Chao Phrya river. Wat Arun has its own charm and is completely different to all the other temples. Where the others are immaculately preserved, you can see with this one the real history in its structures. The Wat its self looks to be hundreds of years old and construction of the temple sites is still occurring to ensure the temple is maintained.Like the other Wats/temples there are still many tales and stores inscribed into the walls and structures of every spire which are quite beautiful, and some are quite old that they are falling apart but in a kind of ancient beauty.You can also climb the very steep (and i mean steep) steps up to the halfway mark on the main spire of Wat Arun where you get a brilliant view over the city and the Chao Phraya river. Its definitely well work the short climb up. But if you are afraid of heights it may not be for you. But i must admit i really enjoyed it.There are also many gardens and other temples and building around the Wat Arun complex that make it an interesting visit, and it is also very cheap for entry as well which is a bonus.Id definitely recommend visiting this Wat if you visit Bangkok. This is really good to do with the big three if you wish to get a taste of Bangkok's temples:Wat Arun,Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaew (emerald buddha)Wat Pho (reclining buddha)

Wat Arun - Temple of Dawn. A good location for photographers also. Very nice view and beautiful,after a high climbing :). Just visit Dawn if you want some really good pictures. Also ensure you wear decent clothes since it's a temple.

Temple of Dawn, before sunset. After a visit to the Grand Palace and the Wat Pho, you can visit this Buddhist temple in Bangkok Yai district . It is on the Thonburi west bank of the Chao Phraya River, 3 minutes walk from Wat Pho to the pier where you can take the 3 baht boat cross. The temple derives its name from the Hindu god Aruna, often personified as the radiations of the rising sun. I would highly recommend to visit the place just before sunset and see the magical temple when its light up.Ferry/ boat is available again at 3 baht to cross back.
Nice visit!. The temple is beautiful... Although we got a it scared of "climbing" the steps to go up :) But it is worth to visit!

Beautiful and Peaceful.. A good location for photographers also. Very clean and beautiful. Arrive at dawn if you want some really good pictures. Also ensure you wear decent clothes since it's a temple.

Overpriced. Temples look awesome, we only had 20minutes there as we were on a river/canal tour. Would of liked to have seen more. A lot of markets there pays to look around before parting with money, they like US dollars but will gladly take baht, don't forget to barter.D
Nice place. Wat Arun is a very nice place. "Must visit" place on Bangkoks map places to sea! Go to Wat Arun by long boat, cross the river
Beautiful Temple. This is certainly on the "do not miss" for Bangkok. Beautiful temple with 50 baht entry fee and it has beautiful views. It's just across the river and so worth the visit.
