awesome - just climbing up and down is a spiritual journey. Steep up and steep down... if you have problems with height - it will be a test of strength and spirituality.. just lovely... and stunning view across town and up the river......... well worth catching the 3 baht cross river ferry

Visible from other bank of the river. I admit for not visiting this temple. However I want to add a tip for finding a recommended point at the other bank of the river to gain a good view over this temple. The location is near the Tha Tien river boats station. We visited the Pak Khlong Talat = flowers night market. Then it is recommended to continue towards north, in parallel ti the river, visit the fruits and vegetables market and then continue a few hundred meters. Just before the river bank boats station, turn left into a short alley. At the right end of the alley, climb the steps up to a bar restaurant. From the steps and from the upper level you'll see a magnificant view of the Wat Arun. I did it at night but this point, of course, is valid for a point of view, day time as well. The view is nice due to the height position of this point, I found it by chance.

Worth the trip across the river from Wat Pho!. Beautiful temple with 50 baht entry fee and hardly any tourists! Climb up to get great views over the city and river. Well worth the 3 baht ferry across from the royal palace and Wat Pho!

Gorgeous views from the top!. It's definitely worth climbing up the short, but steep flights of stairs to the top of this temple to enjoy the gorgeous architectural detail along the way and, once you reach the top, to look out over the skyline of Bangkok. I went about an hour before closing, which was perfect because the heat of the day had passed, the crowds had thinned and the sun began directly behind the temple, making for some gorgeous pictures. Ladies should wear pants/skirts that are at least knee-length. Although you can rent a sarong to wrap around your waist, if you forget.
Great views!. Very beautiful, amazing structure. The view from above is amazing, but please be careful when climbing the stairs (and descending).

Can't be missed. If you are in Bangkok this is certainly on the top of your list. Depending on where you are staying, you may need to take the tourist boat up river to get there. Be sure to have 6 baht in change per person. Once you disembark, you will need to hop on another little boat to cross the river. The charge is 3 baht per person per trip. The temple is amazing and the climb to the top is a bit treacherous so be careful. Try not to purchase bottled water in the vicinity as you will pay four times what you would pay elsewhere.

Don't miss this one. Because it is on the other side of the river, one might be tempted to overlook Wat Arun. That would be a big mistake. The Wat itself is colourful, but even more impressive are the heights one can climb and the views those climbs provide of Bangkok and especially the Grand Palace. As its name suggests, going in the morning provides excellent lighting not only for the temple itself but for the rest of the city.
Most beautiful in Bangkok. The place is one of the oldest in the city.Take the chance to climb the stairs to reach the top.It's really difficult but stunning!

Great View From the Temple. Wat Arun is a very detailed temple that offers great views over the river and the Bangkok skyline. You can reach it by using the river boat transport system. Go to Pier 8 then cross the river for 3 baht. There are directions at pier 8 as to how to cross. It is only 50 baht to enter. Girls wearing short shorts/skirts can also rent long saris if needed. The temple itself is fabulous. There is so much detail with all the different animals and figures carved into it. The stairs to go up to the top are steep and nerve-racking, but once at the top you will have great fun taking photos of other tourists as they try to negotiate the stairs. Oh... and the view of the city isn't too bad either.
Beautiful temple. Really worth a visit. A really beautiful temple. Looks even more special when lit up at night. Lots of small steps up to the top but worth the climb.

Magnificient temple- must climb stair to top. The architecture is Sumatran style with center of universe in middle spire and four poles in corner spires- the uniform cosmic belief shared by hinduism and buddism is manifested, close snaps show fantastic angels and demons made of porcelain coloured pieces, breathtaking view of krung thep (bangkok- city of angels) and chao phraya river from top, must climb the steep stairs to top- railing is attached

Lovely ornate complex with a challenge. be sure to check out the decorative details in the architecture.If you decide to make "the climb" you just might feel yourmuscles the next day. :-). Coming down is quite steep, sojust relax and take your time. Glad I did it. At 75yo, I stilllike the challenges out there in our world. This was a minorone, but Aleve came in handy the next day as I recall.

A must visit. Great place to go in Bangkok, one should travel early morning or late, the place closes at 6pm. Great view from top, of a picture perfect surrounding. Best to take a taxi to the place and come back in another. There is an option to take boat, but can be very warm.there are two placard (metallic) of apsaras kept at the side- beware before you start clicking photographs by putting your face in- there is a charge of 40Baht - a lady may come up from nowhere demanding the money.

Wat Arun > Wat Prakaew. Great value! We originally wanted to go to the Grand Palace but they wanted 500 bhat for the entrance fee and was super crowded with Chinese tourists. Wat Arun was only 50 bhat, way less crowded, great view of Bangkok at the top, and even cooler looking. The steps to the top are definitely steep. Tuk tuk drivers wanted to rip us off but we ended up just walking here from Khaosan Rd- This is totally possible by the way! If you go to river crossing #8, they only charge 3 bhat to ferry across the river.
Wow. A great photo at every turn. If you have height issue DON'T go to the top of the temple and certainly not in flip flops. 18 steps of sheer OMG can I get a helicopter to get me down.
Loved it!. Wat Arun was a beautiful temple with interesting statues. The stair climb was steep and exhilarating! Great views from the top

Very old and. If you do not have the intention to visit at night, it is best to go early in the morning before visiting the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Go by boat (PUBLIC BOAT from PUBLIC STOPS, 15 bath or 40 bath, the express, pay attention). At the stop 8 you cross the river by 3 baht (USD 9 cents) each way. DON`T TALK TO PEOPLE AROUND, EVERYONE THERE HAS A SCAM TO GET YOUR MONEY.

Leaves you breathless. I mean this both figuratively and literally. Wat Arun (The Temple of Dawn) is one of the most awe-inspiring buildings I had ever seen. Unfortunately I did not get up early enough to see the morning sunlight illuminate the china mosaique patterns. Instead I arrived after lunch and immediately understood why Wat Arun is one of the most famous landmarks in Bangkok. It is completely stunning and has an interesting history if you're into that. The colourful porcelain used to decorate the temple had previously been used as ballast by boats coming to Bangkok from China.Whilst breathtakingly beautiful, be warned that the climb to the top of this temple may also leave you a little short of breath. It's quite steep with high steps and can be a little daunting for some. The views are lovely though so I would recommend chancing the climb. Maybe just take your time on the way down.

Just beautiful. Wat Arun is definitely a must-see tample when wisiting Bangkok. It's unique structure is only matched by it's beauty. When visiting, take the stairs to get an overview of the beautiful area. You'll get a unique view of Bangkok as a city with the contrasts of old on the modern city skyline. Don't be discouraged by people who say it's difficult to walk up the stairs because of the height. It isn't. I'm afraid of heights and still had no problem doing it. A good tip is that you do it backwards when coming down.The ticket were only 50 Baht ($1,5)/person. When it comes to clothing, be respectful. No tanktops or short skirts. For men it is acceptable to wear shorts, but they have to go below the knee. Women have the oppurtunity to rent sarongs for 20 Baht ($0,7). So you don't need to walk around in jeans or long pants the whole day just because you want to visit the temple.Getting there is really simple. Take the BTS to Saphan Taksin, from there you can purchase tickets to the Cho Praya River Boat for 50 Baht ($1,5) /person. The boat ride takes about 15-20 minutes and stops on the opposite side of Wat Arun. Take the oppurtunity to vist Wat Pho (temple of the reclining Buddha) and Wat Phra Kaew (temple of the emerald Buddha). They're only a two minute walk away. Once you've visited these two temples go back to the pier and ask to go to Wat Arun. The tickets are 3 Baht ($0,1)/person and the boat ride takes two minutes. When you want to go back home just do the same trip, but in reverse.
a great place. a great part of it is tourist business - but there are still many quit corners to discover. Will go again.

Amazing. The temple and surrounding buildings are absolutely stunning, worth climbing up a couple levels, but the steps are steep and on the first steps there is no hand rail. We were only there for one night and tried to cram in as much as possible by using the river ferries, definitely worth going too.

Beautiful place & great view. The Wat Arun temple was a good experience. The area around is very beautiful and you can easily spend some more time just to relax around the temple. The Wat Arun shuttle boat only cost 3 Bath and makes it easy to visit Wat Pho right after.
Wat Arun on a wet day. The intricacy of the construction was amazing. The admission fee was extremely cheap. Alternative clothing was available for hire if you are inappropriately dressed.
Good experience. Take a 3 baht boat ride across the river to Wat Arun. The steps to the top are pretty steep and intimidating, but worth the climb

Beautiful. I conquered my fear of heights and climbed those steps! They are some climb but well worth it. This temple is amazing, and well worth it. The steps are pretty precarious and take some large steps to get up. I recommend the descent going sideways or backwards as they are narrow and large steps in between.

Stunning-not to be missed. Amazing structures,do the climb for the view and to appreciate the scale of the buildings.
Take the ferry to get there,go early before the crowds and the heat of the day.
great statue. it has giant statue of reclining Buddha. but kinda hot for the weather. and the place rather smelly. the toilet not very clean though.

A must visit.. There should be no second thoughts about visiting this Buddhist temple. Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) is open to public everyday from 8.30 am to 5.30 pm it is an architectural marvel, the best part being the climb to the top of the main chamber. I would recommend taking the ferry to reach the temple.
What a climb !. We picked the time the heavens open to climb this gorgeous temple.....so definitely a bit scary. The view was fabulous from the top...well worth a visit!
Well worth a visit. An exciting climb for a great view. Take the ferry across the river from attained if possible, it costs around 6p sterling!

It might be better at night. the temple is close at 5:30pm and obviously its lights is gonna be turned on only at night so we visited in the morning and it was just okay, it was worth the visit and the temple is not gold in color just so you know. its gold at night because of the lights
Wat arun. A nice place to visit. The stair walking up is a bit scary, but once reach to the top, the view is really nice.

My favorite temple in Bangkok. This temple is so different from others in Bangkok ! This is a quiet place with gardens and temples, close to Chao Phraya River. I recommand to climb at the biggest tower, and the view on Bangkok is outstanding with temples, rivers, buildings... Boats to cross river cost 3bahts, temple entry is 50bahts.

Temple of the dust .... Unlike the Grand Palace and Reclining Buddha, which sparkle, the Temple of the Dawn is in need of of some serious TLC. I am sure cleaning it up is an extensive job and an expensive one, but it is looking very faded.Still worth a visit though, as you climb up the steep sides for great views across the river. You’ll need a head for heights and a steady foot, so don’t forget these.

Beautiful!. My favourite Wat and would definitely return once again to view Wat Arun in the evening time for even further spectacular photograph opportunities.We comfortably saw the Grand Palace, Wat Pho temple of the reclining Buddha and Wat Arun in one day.We also found a great small local restaurant called The Coconut Palm, which was a great place to have a rest and try out local food.
Average. Moderately cool, took way too long to get to. Better to go to a rooftop bar if you want the view. Better to go to other temples for the temple... it's a temple, they're all similar.
A different temple. This temple is unique in that the main element does not have a sanctuary. The temple is a pyramid, and you can climb to almost the top.Beautiful when lit at night.

Extraordinary place. We arrived by river boat at the temple, and wow what a fantastic place. The buildings are a work of art sporting lots of intricate sculptures and amazing detail. If you have a head for heights you can climb the three staircases to the top tier of the temple, where you will be rewarded with a fantastic view of the area. These get steeper the higher you get, representing the fact it is hard to get to heaven I believe.Tip, women must cover their arms and legs so buy a shawl or wrap before you go in, although these are available to rent at the entrance to the temple.

Unique and beautiful temple. We got there by boat along the Chao Phraya River. There was a small fee to enter the temple, but it was worth it. The temple looks pretty impressive, with beautiful decorations and tiles. We got to climb up the steep steps for a few levels where we can see beautiful views of the city from all angles. Too bad I was there in the afternoon, a sunset view would have been lovely. Definitely worth the visit if you go to Bangkok.
Must see / do!. 50 baht well spent for a great temple. You can visit plenty of temples in Bangkok and Thailand, but htis is one you must see and climb to get beautiful view of the river and city.

Might as well go if you're in the area.. It's hardly worth coming to Bangkok for this but if you're around the area taking in all the temples and the palace it's pretty nice to go up and take a look.The view from the top is nice and it's fun to climb the steep steps .

beautifull temple. This temple is amazing, how it is build and the suroundings, so lovely to walk aroundthe Wat Arun and the other temples and the garden. Unfortunatly we were not able toclimb the steps, but so lucky to live just across the river. Wat Arun is beautifull in the evening too. Wat Arun is a must and cost only 100 baht.

A must see while in Bangkok. A must visit site while in Bangkok! Climb up the the temple stairs, you will get some cool photos of Bangkok skyline. Entrance fee 50 Baht . Boat to/from the temple of Dawn just 3 Baht.
Picturesque Temple. We visited as part of a long tail boat trip and found it Interesting for a short visit and for the very fit an opportunity to climb the steep steps up the temple.

Loved it. I simply loved it. We got there by boat and climbed up the steps and had an amazing view. The area around Wat Arun with all its temples, gardens, and beautiful extras was stunning. I always wanted to see Wat Arun and was very satisfied. I dont remeber the price, but it was cheap.
Must see visit. The temple itself is impressive, but make sure you walk round all the other buildings in the compound - there are lovely wall paintings and ceramics to see.

Great art work in the bank of the river. It was really a good visit to this great art. Though we went at noon (it becomes more beautiful in the evening after lighting) we liked this place. We climbed till top and had a great view of the chao phraya river. renovation work is going on, so you will not find the true beauty of this great temple now.

Lovely Temple. This temple is covered in pieces of porcelain, it is beautiful. You can walk up the steep steps to the half way mark and get lovely views of the river, Wat Pho and the Grand Palace. We caught a boat across the river to get to Wat Arun at a cost of 3 baht. Spent approx. an hour here. there is a temple you can visit behind Wat Arun with rows of gold buddhas etc and there is also a small café where you can get a drink at the base of the temple. Well worth a visit.

Steps, steps, steps. Just across the river from the Grand Palace and reached easily by ferry.The temple looks really impressive from the river as you can't see all the scaffolding currently in place for the renovations.That said the scaffolding is to only 1 side of the temple and really doesn't ruin the visit.Climb the stairs to the top for a great views over the river and across the rooftops of the Grand Palace.The steps are steep which isn't too bad on the way up, but does make coming down a little treacherous.Be sure to make it round the back of the Wat to see the monks quarters and to ring the gong for something a bit different.We went slightly out of season so no crush of other tourists but would imagine it gets quite busy later in the year.All in all a nice way to spend some time (no more than an hour) and no dress code here.It's also rather nice seeing the monks themselves climbing the steps to see the view.

A temple with a view. Wat Arun is a Bangkok temple which gets your heart racing in a different way to most. Unlike most of the more popular temples it is situated on the west bank of the Chao Phraya river, The easiest way to get there is to take the ferry from Ferry landing N8 (Tha Tien) which costs 3 Baht each way. From the ferry landing it is a short walk to the temple and associated buildings including the tower (prang). The tower for a lot of people is the main attraction but the temple and surroundings should be explored. The tower is very steep and to get to the highest viewing level requires climbing two steep flights of steps. However, it is worth the effort as the views across the river are fantastic. On the way back to the ferry you can buy food to feed the catfish, the river is full of them!

Great.. We went here the day after the palace and tbh this wins in my book. It is not so mobbed for a start and it is just much more majestic in its own understated way. Great views and nice sense of achievement when you make it to the top and down without killing yourself on the steps! Def a good stop in bangkok!

Nice place, lovely view!. I went this place in the hot afternoon. But it was worth to see n climb up. Location was great with both river view and city view. But it will be much better view from sunset to midnight( which i did miss).

Very beautiful place. I love Wat Arun - The Temple of Dawn.
One of my favorite and the beautiful places in Bangkok.
Highly recommended to visit even if it is the first visit and if you also had been there.

Wonderful experience. I visited this place on from outside in the evening. It looks beautiful when lights fall over it. Looks quite majestic in evening as per my experience when i had a look at it from outside. I missed to go inside just because of rainy evening.

Wat Arun. Great to visit but even better is getting back across the river to have a drink at sunset to watch it set behind the temple. Try Sala, a new funky restaurant, or the old favourite Ambrosas. But, get there early. If you wait until just before sunset you won't get the prime front row seats. The rooftop bar at Ambrosas only opens at 5 (due to drinking regulations). We got up there just after 5 and secured a great seat and just drank cocktails until the sunset at 6.15pm. There are a couple of great restaurants along here that can be a bit tricky to find. it also pays to book, particularly if you want a window or river view
Beautiful. So pretty! Easy to get to from ko San road by tuk tuk or walk. Be careful of the tuk tuks they try and over charge you or take you to jewellers or tailors
360 View of Bangkok. Very nice attraction. And a pleasant walk from the riverfront. The view from the top was very nice. My guess is that sunsets would be quite nice if you can time it right.

Beautiful. Yes another temple but beautiful. There are not as strict about attire here as the Grande Palace. Be careful of the climb up the side of the main temple. Not too bad going up but a little unnerving coming down with short treads on the stairs and fairly steep. Not as much to see as the Grande Palace but enjoyable.
wonderful day out. a stunning place to visit, full of charm and warmth. very big temple and you need a few hours to enjoy everything it offers

Bangkok must see landmark. This place is amazing, the architecture, the attention to detail and the history. There is currently some renovation work but that is minimal and wont really impose on your experience. Beware if you climb the stairs to the higher levels. They are very steep and a bit scary to climb back down.

Wat Arun worth the few Bhat and time to see. The setting on the river, the boat ride to the Wat, and the placement opposite Wat Pho makes it a great intro to Thai temples. Friendly, helpful staff, and a great view of Bangkok after climbing the steep stairs to the top!

Beautiful Temple. Wat Arun is set by the Chao Phraya river with great views from the top. Beware however, as it is very high and very steep. Not for the elderly or for those scared of heights Vertigo? it is almost vertical.

Spectacular view from the top.. This was our second trip to bangkok. we were unable to visit war arun last time. It is a short ferry ride from the royal palace so i would recommend combing it with a trip to the royal palace. Takes about an hour or so to visit. The temple makes for some gorgeous pics from the water/ferry and up close as well. There are steep stairs (3 flights in total) to make it to the top. The view is really something. On one side you see modern bangkok, sky scrapers and all and the other side the royal palace with the chao praya river snaking through.Be warned the stairs are steep. they were not a difficult climb but my husband and I are young and quite fit so we did not feel it. wear shoes which do not slip and hold on to the railing and you should be fine. Around the temple (at the base) there are shops which sell "ayutthaya costumes". headgear and wrap around dresses which you can wear for a few quick pics dressed as an apsara or a thai nobleman. Renting these were not cheap unfortunately . you can bargain it down a little bit. and you can also ask for some mix and match versions. After hearing the prices we did the headgear alone and took some pics. This is if you want to do the regular "i went to bangkok touristy stuff"All in all this was one of the best architectural spots to visit in bangkok. We saw war arun from a distance later that night ,lit up . I cannot comment on those dinner cruises but i heard it is quite beautiful. i would certainly recommend seeing it during the day for the view from up top.the ferry across the river from the royal palace is about 4 baht. carry change

Great Temple. Its nice and breezy on the second level, it feels good to get out of some of the bangkok heat. anyway, temples big but you cant go inside. The steps are really steep and there are usually no kids on top so you can really enjoy it

Aesthetically beautiful and historic. This temple is the Angkor Wat of Bangkok. Smaller in scale, it has a similar design. We recommend slip on shoes for visiting most of the Bangkok temples, but Wat Arun requires sturdy lace-up shoes if you plan to climb it. It is very steep. Pay close attention to the details: broken porcelain, elephants and warriors. The boat ride from the Wat Pho side costs 3 Thai Bhat. The entry fee to Wat Arun is 50 Thai Bhat. There is a small market outside, but the prices aren't as good as in other locations. There is a small business that sells smoothies and light snacks.

Good exercise. Beautiful Buddhist temple. Really steep stairs; recommend for those who are are capable of strenuous physical activity (and have good knees...) But the view is very rewarding. It's fun to take the boat there too, even if the river is a bit disgusting. This brightens up the experience. Tip--women need to cover their shoulders and upper legs. They'll charge you to use one of their coverups. Save yourself a few baht by bringing a scarf along. Wear capris/pants/longer skirt or dress too. It's best to dress a little more conservatively in Thailand anyways (short shorts are not the wisest).

Worth the Climb!. Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) was the last of the temples that we visited. It is said that this is one of the most striking riverside landmarks of Thailand. For me, this isn't the ordinary because there was this chance to climb uphill. And you could see the view from the top. Although the steps were steep and narrow, it was still an adventure going up. We just stayed in the middle level and didn't dare go higher. Climbing is easier but going down makes you dizzy. But it was all worth it. Although they say the most spectacular view of the glittering monument can be seen best at sunset (we didn't have time to wait for sunset) it was still a sight either from afar or even very near. Temple is sooo tall and made of colorful porcelain. Great architecture like the other temples.We took the 3Baht ferry ride to cross the other side of the river.

Should visit. I have to add to the title that I preferred the view of it from the river than being at it close up. It was a nice experience but there are many sights like this in Bangkok which we preferred. Being in Bangkok you should still go there.
Good view from the top. One hell of a climb for a senior citizen but one hell of a vie from the top. Easily accessible from the other side of the river using the 3 baht ferry.

It was worth the trip. Our only visit to a temple so an experience. It probably has a lot more significance for Buddhists but nevertheless worth a visit. An easy exchange, a few yards away, from the express river boat to the ferry across. The cheapest ferry crossing ever (ok the Staten Island Ferry is free).
wat arun. We did not manage to visit this time but passed on our trip on the riverWecwill make a stop there on our next visit

nice wat!. Had a great time climbing up and down the scary stairs of this beautiful wat. Add a ferry ride to get there and great food and trinkets on the other side of the river, and you have a very nice outing!

Amazing view. Wat Arun temple towers high above the river, providing a great view of the city from the top. Beware however that to complete the climb, you have to be pretty brave with not even the slightest fear of heights. The steep steps make it a little frightening once you reach the top and realise you have to make it all the way back down again, taking extra care not to get caught up in your harem pants, topple over and fall head first down a vertical descent.To view my full travel guide of Bangkok including photos, please visit my blog post here: http://lorileysesh.blogspot.co.uk/2014/03/thailand-part-1-bangkok.html

Steeeeep. Placed across the river from the Wat Po ( Temple of The Reclining Buddha). Admission 50BTH. Climbing it is an advanture, if you have acrophobia- don't do it. Best pictures from the dostance, ie from the boat, especially at night, as it is beautifully iluminated ( like all Bangkok attractions), but it is closed and can' t be climbed after dark.

definitely worth it. Personally like exploring a few major sites in each city i go to. Just to see and know about their local culture and religion. Have to climb up the steep stairs to get a view from the top.Dislike: Nothing to dislike about this temple.
Wat Arun. If you are Buddhist or not, This temple is simply stunning. A must see ! Worth every penny. The stairs are quite steep and not for the unfitt.

The beautiful Wat Arun. Visited in the daytime crossing the river by boat and climbed the very steep stairs to the top and back down. Somehow felt scarier on the way back down...not for the faint hearted and felt a huge sense of achievement making it back down in one piece! If you are a woman definitely recommend not wearing a sarong whilst climbing up or back down for safety reasons.Must be the best Wat around for its beauty, the impressive views and atmosphere.50 baht entry fee unless you live locally.My favourite Wat and would definitely return once again to view Wat Arun in the evening time for even further spectacular photograph opportunities.We comfortably saw the Grand Palace, Wat Pho temple of the reclining Buddha and Wat Arun in one day.We also found a great small local restaurant called The Coconut Palm, which was a great place to have a rest and try out local food.

Pretty!. Wat Arun was my first real destination of the day. I took a ferry from the Tha Tien Pier for 3 baht to get there. I paid the 50 baht entrance but no one collected my ticket (maybe I looked Thai?).I climbed up to the second level of the Temple. The detail and art is astonishing but at least two of the stupas around the main stupa was under renovation. I didn't have the courage to climb up to the 3rd level because it was so steep but I felt like I already had a good view from the 2nd level. Might be a better view at night when the city is lit up.
Steep Stair, and beautiful scene. Becareful while climb because of steep stair. But once you arrive at top, the view is so beautiful. You can see Grand Palace and Chao Phraya River.

Favourite place! . Vertigo to the max with this place! Stairs are very steep to the top but the view is worth it! 3TBH on the ferry each way and the whole temple is amazing. Great experience and even better photos. I recommend waiting on the opposite bank for the eventing sunset and night time photos when it comes to life. Truly magical.

Thrilling climb up & down.. Really went to do the steps & see the view across the river. Wow, steps were incredibly steep. For us scared of heights, it is a nerve rattler. Go slow. And don't ever look down when on steps especially while going down. 50 baht. Ticket booth between river and temple. Directly across river from Grand Palace. From pier at end of road dividing Grand Palace & Wat Pho (Reclining Buddha), take ferry to Wat Run. Follow the crowd. It costs 3 baht each way. 3 baht, folks, 3. This is the ferry you want. Easy.
beautiful view from above. for 50 baht its a good experience :-) you can see bangkok from above. that is if you are not afraid of heights as the steps are scary. worth to visit.

Three headed elephant in Wat Arun.. I'm not sure if anyone have noticed the three headed elephant at the peak of the temple. Got the best shot when I finally finished climbing this Wat Arun, from there you'll see the busy city of Bangkok. Entrance fee is 50THB. Inside, there's a lot to see, vendors who offers a custome for you to experience how to dress like a traditional Thai and for 200THB you'll get an instant souvenir a picture of you with traditional dress... nver forget to use your power to bargain.
Step back in time. Breathtaking and nerve wracking at the same time when climbing up the steep staircases. A must visit.

beautiful view. A must ...located in the old city during the day you can access to the place and during the night it has an amazing view, specially for a romantic dinner by the river...the view is great! :)

Incredible detail!. Wow, the amount of detail that has gone into the creation of Wat Arun really does make this worth a visit. Definitely recommend going up to the top, and although the steps are steep, take it slowly and carefully and you will be fine. I am not great with heights, plus I am clumsy, so this did have the potential for disaster, but I was really glad we did it.We did not do the tour but instead just walked around so we may have missed out on some of the detail here.If you can fit both Wat Arun and the Grand Palace in to your trip, then definitely do both, but if you only have time for one, IMHO I would recommend the GP as it is simply breathtaking.

Beautifully ornate temple on the Chao Phraya River. This beautiful temple is quite colorful, and the setting along the river is breathtaking. Know that to get the best views, you are required to climb many stairs that become progressively steep the higher you go. There are no handrails, so it is best to stay close to the sides. The step heights are uneven. Good shoes are a must. The views from the top make the climb worth it. Going down is harder than climbing up!

impressive. This Temple is just Impressive ,the incrediable detail ,and work ,we didn't climb the stairs to look off the middle as they are extreme ,very steep and small ,there was some restoration going on but i would that would be on going to maintian the temple ,take the river shuttles cheapest way

Wat a Place. Very interesting tour, made all the better by our guide. Part of a day tour, arranged through Absolute Bangkok. Not great for less mobile as part of the attraction is climbing the steepest steps you're likely to see!!!
Majestic!. It was great to be able to climb up. The stairs were very steep and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who suffers from vertigo or has bad knees, but otherwise well worth the climb.

Wat beauty. When the ferry turned on the Chao Phraya river and I caught the first glimpse of Wat Arun, I must admit I was a bit underwhelmed. I had imagined it to be taller and somehow more majestic. But when I saw it up close, I realised what an incredible piece of art it is. The entire temple from the base to the tip of the spire is covered in colourful little pieces of ceramic. They are arranged in beautiful patterns with rows of monkeys and demons in between. The level of detail and sheer hard work that must have gone into it are astounding, and make it all the more wonderful. Do make the effort to climb the steep steps (they're not as scary as they first seem) to truly appreciate its beauty. Personally, I found the complexity and aesthetics to be more charming than the other temples that seem to go with gigantic gold statues of Buddha - something that strikes me to be the antithesis of the Enlightened One's teachings. That said, even Wat Pho and the Palace deserve a visit, but if you're short on time, I'd certainly recommend Wat Arun over them. On the opposite side of the river (where the pier is located), there is a small restaurant right on the river with a stunning view of the temple at sunset, and good, cheap food too.

Oh ... those steps are a challenge for the faint-hearted!. This is a fabulous temple; well worth seeing with a great view from the top of the steps both around the city! The final set of steps are very steep and need care coming down them if you are a little afraid of heights as my wife was! She made it one piece however and was delighted to have made the climb!

Good but not the best visit in Bangkok. If you start from the more popular side of the river (where all of the main tourist boats stop) you will need to catch a boat across the river in order to get to the tower, the cost of this boat is not covered by the ‘all inclusive’ boat ticket that many tourist purchase. The tower is impressive, high and that’s about it. You will probably not spend more than half an hour here as once you have climbed the 2 levels to admire the view (the steps are very steep) and walked around the base you will have seen all there is to see, yet its still very much worth a visit. When we visited some of the monument was covered in scaffolding which does spoil the odd photo.

In a hot day it is better to skip this. This temple is interesting by the fact that you can climb it up. But ... it is very steep, so ... this is nothing for people who are affraid of hights. The entrance was only 50 bath, but ... if you have seen the Emerald Buddha or the Reclining Buddha temples then this is not worth while. Also ... if you visit in a really hot day, it is not a pleasant experience.

beautiful temple. Wat Arun is a beautiful, clean and very popular temple on the bank of the Chao Phraya River. You can access from land or the river. Arriving by river boat is a great way to see this amazing temple.
wow, the steps are very steep. Good view over the river, once you've climbed the incredibly steep steps. An iconic Bangkok buildingCosts just 50bt, to climb the steps

Best temple in Bangkok. If you only go visit one temple, make it Wat Arun. Take a Chao Phraya express boat from Saphan Taksin BTS to Tha Tien and then take a cross river ferry to Wat Arun. Cheap transport, pretty ride on the river. No need to pay admission here, unless you want to climb the temple steps. Plenty of good photo opps outside the gate, walk around the grounds and enjoy.

Beautiful temple, day and night - do the climb. Such an ornate temple, from far away at night when it glows yellow, and in the day up close when you see all the tiles and artwork that adorn the walls.You can climb up the side of the temple, very steep stairs but great view. Lots of photo opportunities. Outside is a little 'market' but very much tourist trap. Don't take the photo's where you put your face in the cut outs that look like traditional clothed people. If you look carefully it says 40thb on each one. As soon as you take the photo a little lady will pop out of nowhere demanding money.For 3 THB you can catch a ferry directly across the river to Tha Tien pier No. 8 where you can join the normal boats up the Chao PhrayaThe temple will loan you a sarong if you're dressed inappropriately, the best time to go is earlier in the day or later in the afternoon when it's not so hot to climb. If you're going to use the bathroom there, remember to take your ticket with you as you will exit outside the temple and may not be able to come in without paying again

Best view at night from opposite bank of the river. We visited Wat Arun on a earlier trip to Bangkok. This time we chose a Restaurant with a view to Wat Arun for dinner. Absolutely stunnin at night, since it is fully enlighted..

Interesting. Bangkok is full of Wat's, this one of the most interesting. Climb to the top for some great views. Use the local river taxis, much cheaper than the river cruise boats, orange line costs 15 baht per trip and runs full length of Bangkok.

Top Wat. Have to agree with fellow posters- having visited all the main Wats in BKK this one is our favourite.Visited in morning with Sam from Tong Tours and it's unhurried, very scenic views and steeped in history .

Amazing. Well worth the visit. Climb the temple for fantastic views of the city. Easy to access by two river taxis, check the timetable. You need to dress conservatively but it is an amazing feat of engineering.
Nice and quiet place. Walk around and enjoy the atmosphere. Easily reachable with the Prao Chaya ferry boat. Mind the steps.

Endless details!. By the river... you cannot imagine this scenery unless you are actually there. From didtance you cannot see the details, but many buddha images line up to provide the many bases of this high temple. Elephants and colorful tiles also account for the unique design of this temple. Stairs are steep so only go up if you really have the guts (and air!) There is no "going inside it", you will only be able to go round it at the highest level. Howveer the magnificent viwe of the river and constructions compensate for it.

Be prepared to climb :). This is directly opposite Wat Pho (Reclining Buddha) which you can reach from the opposite bank on a boat that runs continuously for 3 baht. Apart from the silly tourist "put your head through this to make a face" things as you come in this is an amazing temple. You don't actually go inside it, instead you climb stairs up it. The stairs are very steep so if you're inform it's best to enjoy it from a ground level. From the top (actually the middle) you get great views of all of Bangkok and the river. It's 50 baht entry. Worth a visit! :)

Amazing porcelain temple. This was the first temple I visited in Bangkok. I enjoyed the breathtaking view when approaching it on the ferry. The main stupa is tall and of beautiful proportions. There is dress code for entering the temple (knees and shoulders should be closed); you can rent a sarong for a small fee on the spot. The stupa is fantastically decorated with sculptures, carving and ornaments made of broken porcelain items (I could identify plates in several cases). The legend is that the broken porcelain pieces were brought to Bangkok on Chinese ships as ballast. You can climb up the steep high stairs to the top of the stupa - you must be sure of you physical condition as it's quite an ordeal in the moist heat of Bangkok afternoon. The ascend gives you a chance to have a close look at the ornamentation and all the details as well as a great view from the viewing platforms located at several levels. The temple looks beautiful at night being masterfully lighted.

Beautiful Chinese Buddhist Temple. This is a very old temple right off the Chao Phraya River. It has been around since the 17 century but the spirals were added in the 19 century. This is a unique temple that you climb up and around. The steps are steep and going down can be a little scary at times. The temple is highly decorated with Chinese porcelain. The temple offers amazing views of Bangkok and at night it is lighted beautifully. It was under repair on the backside so it really didn't distract from the beauty. This use to be the home of my favorite Emerald Buddha. Just a very different temple that you can leave your shoes on which you will need for climbing. Booth with snacks and tourist items are for sell on the grounds.
Definitively a must. Definitively worth a visit, as well as all the other temples. A different experience for an European.

Crazy. I liked visiting this temple. Less people, and the river crossing was an adventure. Just the the BTS/Skytrain to the river and a river boat will escort you. Afterwards, we paid 3baht to cross Chao Praya River to visit the Grand Palace. Oh yeah, the steps are really really steep...so if you are easily scared of heights, you won't make it to the top! Unfortunately my bro-in law was one of those people. Otherwise if you make it, you earn a great view! Also the price to get it was reasonable, I think it was 50-60baht for tourists.
Beautifull. climbing up the stupa was steep and lovely,has to be as early as possible in the morning,otherwisw too hot!
Worth the time...especially at night. Is absolutely stunning at night. Worth effort and time to see. Was much larger than we expected. The temple of temples.
impressive, steep climb. Our first Buddha visit, so we were very impressed with its hugeness. Lots of visitors. Need to remove shoes.

Very different from most Thai temples. I have been to Bangkok a ton of times but never went here until recently. I figured it would be nothing special since I had been to numerous temples in Thailand. It was quite nice though and very different from most. Seems like they use bits of porcelain pottery as the decoration for the temple which gives it a very cool look. Definitely worth a stop if you are in the area. Ladies, wear long pants or a long skirt and a shirt with sleeves or you will have to pay a fee to rent a wrap to cover yourself.
Impressive temple. Been to temple of Dawn in march 2014, and climbed up the steep steps, to catch a good view of bangkok. Noted some parts of the temple were under renovation and covered.

Unique Temple. This temple is unique and very popular. We can go to the top of the temple (but not the highest).What I :Like : The temple is unique and its cheap to enter the temple (50 baht) and there is a market that sold cheap goods (clothes etc)Dislike : We must across The Chaopraya river. We need to pay 6 baht. The temple is not big as grand palace
A must in Bangkok. There are places in Bangkok which all tourists have to visit. One of them is Wat Arun. After reaching the summit you can enjoy the spectacular views. A real must in Bangkok.
beware of the steps!!. better visit at night its more impressive because of the lights..or take a dinner cruise by the river.
the most impressive wat in bangkok. you can climp the top and you have a marvelous view from there. no so golden like other wats but in fact more beautiful!

A must see. You don't realise just how big this place is until you are there. Lots of beautiful buildings and statues. The climb up to the top of the temple is very steep but the view is nice when you get up there. The only let down was the horrible lady working at the booth to get in and also the fact that if you aren't dressed appropriately then you have to pay to hire clothing. I had to pay twice as I had to hire a bottom and a top. I understand why you are required to dress appropriately but the reclining Buddha just across the road offers clothing for free if you aren't dressed appropriately so I don't see why this place isn't free also

Stunning!. It is stunning! A MUST stop on your visit to Bangkok. I think it was my second favourite of whole trip to Thailand. Not only is it breathtaking visualy, but it also has an interesting history. It costs 50Baht to get in, but it sure worth it! Climbing to the top is not for weak hearts! Steps are getting very steep and narrow by the end. However, the view is incredible!To get there take a boat from near the Grand Palace for 30Baht!

Not just your average temple!. Not to be missed! This temple is quite different then the others nearby. The sound of the bells on the towers and the chance to climb up some very steep steps to a wonderful view.Easy to access after visiting the Wat Pho or Grand Palace. For 3 bahts the ferry will take you across the river.

Amazing. I didn't realise how big this buddha was until I saw it for myself. It was amazing to actually see, and the whole atmosphere felt unique. Even though it was very crowded, I loved this. And there was also lots of other little things to see around this building with the reclining buddha. It was only 100TB to get in, and I enjoyed this more than the grand palace. I would recommend this to anyone visiting bangkok to get the true feel of the thai's way of living, it was really great to have a better understanding of the buddha.
Steep climb, but great view. It's a steep climb up the temple, but at the top, you get a great view of the river. A nice bonus - there weren't as many people there, likely because of the climb.

Simply Breathtaking. This was one of our favorite attractions in Bangkok. Make sure you are in decent shape and wear the appropriate shoes as it is a climb to make it to the top. Once you get there, it is a great view.The temple itself is beautiful and amazing. The great pictures others have shared does it no justice as compared to seeing it in person. Also, make sure you see it at night! it is even more amazing lit up!
Stille og roligt område. A small oasis with stunning temple and look over the city. Be sure to see all the temples and have a drink in the cozy cafe.

Amazing. Wat Arun was the first temple I saw in Thailand. I was amazed by the beauty and details of the temple. It is definitely a must see in Bangkok in order to make an idea about what Thailand is and represents.

Unique wat. I have been to many wats in Bangkok and they all start looking the same after a while. But this wat was different from all of them. The view was breath taking, but the steps are steep so do not bring small children.

Beautiful temple but be aware of stairs. The beautiful temple and grounds were lovely however I just want to warn people that the climb up/down the stairs wrecked my thighs for several days. I've run several marathons and it felt the same which hampered our next few days. Maybe I took them too quickly or too fast. Not sure however I was in PAIN for days.

Wat Arun - pretty impressive complex. We enjoyed a trip across the river from the Wat Pho pier (3 baht) to this impressive complex. A steep climb up the central structure affords excellent views of the Royal Palace opposite.
Climb aboard!. When you see the close-up view and detail of how these structures were made you will be amazed!Climb the steep (very steep) steps up 2 levels for a great view over the river.

A beautiful sight. This temple is certainly worth the 6 Baht to cross the river and back, and the 50 Baht entrance fee. After exiting the Grand Palace you can walk around 10-15 minutes down the road to find the pier for the river crossing.The temple is very different from anything in the Grand Palace, and provides some amazing photograph opportunities. At first glance the climb appears very steep and daunting but it isn't at all and you enjoy the view of the river when you reach the top.Make sure you don't miss this attraction!

Amazing!. This is the most spectacular landmark i visited in Bangkok. I took Chao Praya Tourist boat at Central pier, then stop at Tha Tien Pier (stop no 8). From the pier, take small boat ride to Wat Arun, fare is 3 bath one-way.
Don't miss the climb and please wear appropriate clothes when you wish to enter the temple.
An Artist delight. A great place to see paintings and works of Thai culture. but be wary of the dress code to enter the place, no shorts or exposed shoulders, that's it enjoy a visual treat.

Worth the trip. This was the last temple we saw during our day trip so we were a little tired when we arrived. With that being said, I was still glad we took the time to visit. The climb up the temple was steep and the way back down was even more fear inducing, but enjoyable.

Symbolic. This very famous temple has a 260 ft spire and is often recognized as the symbol of Thailand. It is located across the river from the Grand Palace Palace and is an integral part of any historical tour of Bangkok.

beautiful view don't be afraid of the stairs. Enjoy the afternoon in this temple, find strength to go up and enjoy the beautiful view, it's worth the stairs climbing :) take the long tail boats to discover another side of bangkok and don't forget to leave some donation for the monks they really do a great job there.

out of the world.... the temples in bangkok r stunning,grand and awe-inspiring.if u miss them here,u will regret for whole life.i have never seen temples like these anywhere in my life.if u r able to c this in early morning hours the beauty becomes even more.but u can enjoy the outer beauty in the night lights also.every place n section is just wow,wow.....n believe me u will spend more time here than originally thought.many.many pics to b taken.
Awesome colors. ..... specially if you go around the sunset, so you'll have time to visit it and later have a drink from one of the rooftop bars around it watching the sunset behind it.

Unique and Beautiful. The temple is not done in the usual thai style and that is what makes this temple unique and a must in every Bangkok itinerary. The main highlight around the place for me were the prangs itself, the central being above two levels which can be reached by the stairs and then you will find four other smaller prangs in the corners which is striking and beautiful. There is no need to remove your shoes at this particular temple which was a relief for me being visited the place with a swollen feat after all those walking and explorations. The temple has some of the best porcelain decorations I have ever seen

My favourite of the BKK temples. There's just so much to do and see in BKK, so many temples and historic sites. As far as temples go, this was my favourite.It's not all gold-plated and gaudy like the others; rather she's showing her age, and I loved that. You can see hundreds and hundreds of years of age in her fading, chipped mosaics. You can also see the real human aspects of its creation. Plus, the killer views of BKK from the very steep climb up the side.Absolutely worth taking a ride down river to see. Magnificent.

Worth a visit!. Wat Arun is located across the river from the Grand Palace and other attractions. For a short and super cheap boat ride, you get a nice view of Bangkok and slightly less crowds. The wat itself is different from the others in Bangkok, less gold glitz, more ceramic, so it is a nice change. The steps are steep but worth a climb for the view from the top! There are also some nice leafy green places to wander in the area around the wat.

Beautiful place. The best thing about wat arun is that it is not the same as any other temple. It's old and more 'real' than the freshly painted grand palace.
Make sure you have a guide to share some information which makes it more interesting.!

Nice..... Wat Arun is nice... but just that. Eventhoug I think it's worth to cross the River to get a view from Bagkok City.So much details to see, so much porcelain styles...At sunset, we waited for it to be lighten but it never happen... did not know if they have special schedule to do so, so my advice is to do a little reserch if you want to see it fully lighten or buy a postcard instead!

Don't miss..... Definitely one of the most beautiful temples in Bangkok.Approach by the river and the experience is even better.The steps are steep and high so be careful.Don't just visit the main sight but take a walk around the complexe.
The view!!!!. Climbing up the stairs was scary but thrilling, and the views were gorgeous. Convenient to get to by water ferry (quite cheap as well) which was fun.
Riverside temple. Got a ferry from pier 8 and walked around Very busy but a lovely setting for an hour after Wat Pho and used the tourist boat
Beautiful Temple. Boat ride is really fast across, and only 3 baht. Even as I am sea sick it was fine. Temple is beautiful, they also have a market inside with great merchandise for cheap.
Beautiful and quiet. Amazing place, the view from and to Chao Phraya river its beautiful. Exotic and wonderful, perfect for take pictures

Best Temple. This was the best temple we visited. It looks almost eerie, the way it rises up right on the river. The steps are so vertical, you feel like you could easily fall backward. But the climb is worth the view.

A Temple With a View. We went to this temple in the daytime when it was over 90 degrees and boy was it hot! We took a ferry boat to the stop opposite of the temple and then took a ferry that crossed the river. We climbed the very steep steps of the temple and at the top landing, you get a very good view of both ends of the river as well as the areas around the temple. There was also a wide cloth ribbon draped on the wall where people were writting messages with a marker. You must be careful climbing up the steep steps but even more careful going down! They were also giving out free containers of water outside of the temple by the river. We gave a donation for their thoughtfulness. A nice temple with a good view.

Amazing views. The stairs are steep and the steps are deep but if you can take your time the views across the river and city are superb. The temple is a little bit different in the decor. The prangs are amazing with all the porcelain demons etc. Very different to Wat Pho (Reclining Buddha) and The Grand Palace complex. Not as touristy either. Great views along the river. We took the Chao Phraya River Ferry to opposite the temple (they don't stop at the temple but opposite it) and then you pay for a smaller boat to get you across the river to the temple.
Slightly less touristy..... A little less well-kept, yet still beautiful. We stopped in one temple and were blessed by a monk while there with holy water and given wrist bands for good luck.

An amazing temple. This temple is quite stunning, right on the banks of the Chao Praya river. You can get a boat on the river to a stop opposite the wat and then get a ferry across the river to the temple itself. The queue system was pretty confusing , however, to get on the river boats. The temple has many very steep steps to climb if you want to get a view over the city and across to the Royal Palace. Don't go up if you are at all frail and take it very slowly! However, it is really worth it if you can make it and the views of the city are stunning.
Love the river view from this side. Went to the temple in the evening and cilm to the top it was nice the river view from the top, and also the temple so amazing.
Prepare To Climb Steep Stairways. Go there by ferry for the visual effect uncluttered by other buildings. The climbs are worthwhile for the views over the river and around the city.
GREAT VIEW. Find courage to walk the very steep and narrow steps of Wat Arun that will lead you to the central balcony. TIP: Bring a pen :)
Climb those stairs!. Get up on those stairs and witness pure gorgeous art, myth, fantasy and a monument to Thai culture - a must-see!
Excellent Dawn View. Excellent Dawn View with access to the river. Spend at least couple of hours. You will enjoy the scenic views from the top of the temple.
Intricate details. It was amazing seeing the detailed work on this structure. Worth the climb up the two sets of steps even if the top set is very steep, just hang on tight.
My opinion. I echo what most everyone else says. Was very nice the steps climbing up are very steep a fall would be very painful. The view is very good.

Fascinating. A must see. Amazing, truly exotic architecture. If you are located at the other site of the river (where the Royal Palace is), a good way to cross the river is on a ferry-boat. Takes just 10 minutes, including waiting for the boat) and costs about 10 cents. All taxi drivers know were the boat crossing is (right across the Temple).

Fascinating. A must see. Amazing, truly exotic architecture. If you are located at the other site of the river (where the Royal Palace is), a good way to cross the river is on a ferry-boat. Takes just 10 minutes, including waiting for the boat) and costs about 10 cents. All taxi drivers know were the boat crossing is (right across the Temple).
Great Place to visit. Very beautiful at night and great photos to be had from the river. A small market is there and the products are good and not too expensive.

Make sure you wear long pants.... A word of warning, very steep steps, and those below you can see EVERYTHING. It is not safe to look up when climbing your way to top. Even so I highly recommend catching the ferry (3baht each way) over the river and seeing up close the intricate mosiacs and city views.
Very steep steps. Easily reached from the other side of the river by ferry (3 baht). High levels can be reached by some very steep steps, rather like climbing a ladder. Best in the morning.

Fascinating. Part of the fun of visiting this temple is taking a trip on a longtail in the canals! The temple itself is beautiful. I had seen this temple many times in photos, but to see it in reality was wonderful - the way the temple was constructed, with mortar and porcelain: just amazing!

A must visit temple. This is for me the best temple in BKK. If you are traveling alone take the river crossing from Tha Tian peer (3 THB for one crossing). You must pay 50 THB to enter the temple complex. Take care while climbing the steep stairs to the highest floor. But ones up you will enjoy great views of Chao Praya river, grand palace and other important sights.
Recycling. The building is covered by Chineese pottery an ceramics that are several hundreds years. The building is overwhelming and very nice
Magnificent Temple. Brilliant views, fantastic ancient architecture. Beware though of very steep steps if you want to enjoy the views.

Beautiful. We did not stop at this place but while taking dinner cruise it went pass the temple of dawn. It is so so beautiful at night. If only we had another day in Bangkok we would have definitely visited.FOr those who has time..this is a place to go

Unique landmark. Wat Arun has been recently restored (in Thai 'art' means 'dawn'). It is definitely a unique landmark in Bangkok for many reasons. First, because of its symbolic architecture: a huge chedi (or stupa) flanked by 4 towers. The building reflects the symbols of the upper circle (the Sky) and the square delimited by the 4 towers (the Earth). The entire construction has been plastered with bits of chinaware so that it may glimmer in the morning light at certain times of the year. Hence its name, of course. Then, it holds a strategic position on the Thonburi side across the Chao Phraya River directly facing the East on one side and the West on the other. Consequently, it is worth seeing it at different moments of the day: morning, sunset and even at night. It is best to be on the Old City bank to see it then. Sunsets are really a magic time for this Wat.The stairs that lead up to the upper platform of the chedi are really steep (probably 75%) and are classified as one of the world records for stairs! As the temple is on the Thonburi side of the river, you must take a special ferryboat (only 3B) to cross the river. But it is quite frequent and quick to sail across. It costs 50B to get into Wat Arun.
Good as Gold!. And lots of it. Beautiful temple and very crowded tourist attraction. Early in the day there are less people, so more serene and peaceful.
amazing. wonderful and amazing Wat Arun in bangkok Thailand

Beautiful temple. We enjoyed our visit to this temple, as it's very different to the Cambodian temples we had spent the previous week visiting. It's well maintained and has a great view from the top. Definitely worth a visit.

Must visit in Bangkok :). Certainly must visit place in Bangkok. The journey to temple is so refreshing for our group as we take the morning around 9 am trip. Totally love the temples view from the top. :)
Ancient Glory!. So worth the ferry across the river. A magnificent edifice, climbable but very steep! No bad points, lots of good ones!

A must see when you visit Bangkok. A must see when you visit Bangkok! There are many of the main touristy sites within Bangkok but the Temple of Dawn is simply amazing. Try to book a boat trip at night and you'll cruise along the river and you'll see this amazing site. Enjoy

mesmerising temple, beautiful details. This was a beautiful temple, it is very unique with great details all over the walls, steps and surroundings. The steps are very steep and the view from the top is great of the river, surrounding buildings and the palace across the river. A beautiful spot.

If you are visiting Wat Pho after that, then take the river cruise after you visit Wat Arun. Although the steps are steep, but the view you get from the top is totally worth the climb. Take a river cruise after visiting the Wat. There's a kiosk behind the Wat that offers the river cruise service and ask them to stop you at the opposite side of the river. This is because Wat Pho is just at the opposite side of the river.

An absolute must if you are in Bangkok. The Bangkok temples are breathtaking and as a structure, none more so than Wat Arun, while it doesn't have the spiritual feel of Wat Po, the place itself is incredible, if you're not scared of heights then the view from the top level is stunning, even if you don't fancy the climb the detail and workmanship of the place will take your breath away.

Get there by boat and definitely go. Best day attraction in bangkok without a shadow of a doubt. Just beautiful and the atmosphere is like you imagine thailand, a far cry from the rest of bangkok. Stairs are so steep they ate frightening so if your elderly you may want to give this a miss. The photo opportunities were amazing. Loved the fact whilst there were stalls you were bugged by the sellers at all. The monks were lovely to see and the place just screamed tranquil despite it being busy. I have heard bad reviews on how to get there. Best thing we did was a long boat. Takes you right to it and then across to the palace straight after. U can catch a long boat cruise which is private just you and you partner for extremely cheap around £25 and it takes you up the river, through old city, through a small floating market, to this temple, let's you off and waits fir you for 30 minutes, which is plenty of time. Then takes you to the grand palace. Wish someone had told us of this boat trip before we came. Due to this we were able to see all the sights we thought would take a full day in a morning. Have robust this form of transport to get to the temple. The rest is just no where near as good. O and if there is more than two of you don't worry the boats have lots of seating, it's just they are hired out for solely your party for no extra charge. Would fit I would guess around 10-12 people max. But the temple best place to go!

A beauty right next to the river. You're probably go to Wat Arun after you've finished up with Wat Pho, they are conveniently close to each other and crossing the river over to Wat Arun is both fun and super cheap to the price of 3 bath. Crossing the river you'll also get a little taste of the hectic traffic on the river.After seeing all the glittery stuff over at Wat Pho and having had your breath taken away by the massive reclining Buddha, Wat Arun may seem a little bit more "sane" then it's neighbor across the river. First af all, bring your good climbing shoes and some extra water, because you'll need it. Climbing the central prang (khmer tower) can be a challenge with its steep steps. But once up it is so totally worth it and maybe you'll get that super panorama shot of the lively river.

Beautiful temple. I was surprised how un-crowded this temple was compared to others in Bangkok. I visited mid afternoon and the boat was full on both crossings of the river (3 baht each way). There are fairly large grounds to walk around in away from the other tourists. It is a shame that there is currently scaffold around parts of the temple. However it was still possible to get shots without scaffolding and it was still climb-able. The climb should probably not be attempted by many people... it has the potential to be very dangerous. I would have loved more information about Wat Arun as it is a fascinating place.

Wat Arun. set spectacularly on the river bank, off the ferry and straight in. Second to the Royal Palace as the most wonderful cultural experience of our Thailand visit. Add it to your 'must-do' list.Its not so big as to take up the whole day, steep stairs to climb if you so wish, the views are worth it!
Beautiful Building. We just saw this building from the river and it was beautiful and amazing!This building is more beautiful at night.

Thailand, "Borobudur" Temple. As a Indonesian, the Wat Arun remind me to Borobudur temple in Indonesia. Tourists usually go upstair to see Chao Phraya River from above and takes pictures of it. a beautiful temple with a small market sell souvenirs.
Nice Temple. Go there early in the morning, a lot of tourists and others, you need to cover your legs, the water cost 50 and outside just 10

Highly recommended!. Definitely worth the visit. To really maximise the impact, check it out during the afternoon and then head across the river to one of the many rooftop bars dotted on the opposite bank to grab a drink and watch sunset on the temple complex.

Wat Arun. This was my husbands favorite temple visit. Climbing up to the top was not the easiest as the steeps were pretty steep and uneven, but it was well worth the effort. Great view of the city and river from up there. We hopped on a shuttle boat that went only between Wat Pho and Wat Arun for only 3 baht each! Don't miss this one

Amazing climb to the top of Wat Arun. We climbed the steep steps of the amazing Wat Arun. It was so fun and the view is great. At the entrance of the temple are vendors dressing ladies up in beautiful Thailand clothes and accessories. It was good fun.

Amazing!. Our favourite thing to see in Bangkok. Amazing to visit and great to see from the river as well, both by day and by night. The stairs to the top were a bit steep and demanding but with a bit of caution they're fine. Great view from the top as well!

Beautiful Wat in Bangkok. Wat Arun Ratchawararam Ratchawaramahawihan or Wat Arun ( "Temple of Dawn") is a Buddhist temple (wat) in Bangkok, on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River. The temple is best reached by the ferry that crosses the river from the Grand Palace dock and takes about 5 minutes. The cost to cross is 5 TB (or about 16 cents USD) When you get off the ferry, go up the ramp and the temple is to your immediate left.For the foreigners, the temple charges an entrance fee of 50 baht (about $1.50 USD). It is definitely worth some time for you to visit the wat, though currently sections of it are being renovated. Women are required to wear pants,skirts or dresses that cover their knees and tops that cover the shoulders – no low necklines allowed. A pashmina or shawl that covers the essential areas is allowed. Gentlemen must wear shorts that reach the knees, and shirts that cover the shoulders. There are staff on each side of the entrance, and anyone who is not appropriately dressed are directed to a booth where they can rent acceptable attire. However, think about it. . .do you want to wear something that hundreds of others have worn without the benefit of laundering? Best advice is to dress appropriately and avoid the hassle.  The temple derives its name from the Hindu god Aruna often considered the personification of the radiations of the rising sun. Although the temple had existed since at least the seventeenth century, its distinctive prang (spires) were built in the early nineteenth century during the reign of King Rama II (1809-1824). The main feature of Wat Arun is its central 250 foot tall prang (Khmer-style tower) which is encrusted with colorful porcelain. The corners are surrounded by four smaller satellite prang. The prang are decorated by seashells and bits of porcelain which had previously been used as ballast by boats coming to Bangkok from China. The presiding Buddha image, cast in the reign of Rama II is said to have been molded by the king himself. The ashes of King Rama II are interred in the base of the image. The towers are supported by rows of demons and monkeys. Very steep and narrow steps lead to a balcony high on the central tower. The climb to the second terrace is steep but doable by most people. The climb to the top terrace is much steeper, with narrow steps and even with the rail is difficult. Coming down is more perilous than going up. So be honest with yourself about your ability, and don't be afraid to turn around and come back down part way up if you are beginning to feel unsteady. HNext to the prang is the Ordination Hall with a Niramitr Buddha image supposedly designed by King Rama II. The front entrance of the Ordination Hall has a roof with a central spire, decorated in colored ceramic and stuccowork sheated in colored china. Like all other wat in Thailand, if you wish to go in for a closer view of the Buddha you will have to remove your shoes.The best way to view the wat is from the boats that ply the river, and from the opposite bank. The place to be at sundown is the Amorosa Bar, part of Arun Residence, which hosts a restaurant (The Deck) and the Amorosa Bar. The place is fairly difficult to find as it is down an alley off the main road, and it is very poorly signed. Note that because so many people only come to take pictures and not buy any food or drinks, all of the tables along the river will have “reserved” signs on them to prevent you from sitting at them unless you indicate you are going to eat/drink and then the maître d will seat you. They will allow you to go up the spiral stairs at the entrance of the restaurant to the bar above and take pictures for free. However, the reasonably priced food is quite good so you may as well relax and enjoy the beautiful view.

The steps are steep, but you've just got to climb them. The first time I climbed the second set of steps a few years ago my legs turned to jelly. They are steep, fine going up, but frightening to come down. However it is worth the climb, it isn't really very high, just the achievement and the view of the area.The complex is very small compared with the Grand Palace but it is the arriving by boat that adds a lot of the excitement to the visit.

Stunning. Amazing!!!! We went there just on time before it closes. We were able to see it both during the day and at night. After that we could saw it everytime from the taxiboat and trust me the night view from the other side of the river is stunning
Must Visit!. My favorite temple of the many I saw around Thailand, Laos and Cambodia. Beautiful design and great views.

Wat Arun. The best view of this temple is right across the river as you come from grand palace. We took the public boat to cross the river which was damn cheap and take 5 mins to get across the bank. the temple has few steps which are really steep but it is well worth going to the top. You get a good skyline view of the city with the grand palace across and the busy river with all the motorboat traffic below. Dont miss this if you are in the city.

Temple of Dawn can be also called as Temple of Dusk!. You have to take a ferry from one of the piers on the Wat Pho side to cross the river. It costs 3 BHTs per person. This temple has a 3 triered central tower and the steps become narrower as you climb up. The tower is tall and you can get a bird's eyeview of Bangkok once you reach the highest level. Though there are safety rails provided, it can be scary initially while climbing up or down. Nice stone carvings and statues make this temple a must on the itinerary.

Stunning place and climb. This was the highlight of all the temples. If you can find the grand palace keep walking to pier 7, the public ferry and it will only cost you $3 to cross the river and then $50 to enter temple. The climb is worth it as the view is stunning. Only takes about and hour including river crossing and definitely worth doing. Skip Grand Palace.

Peaceful but lots of steps!!. You go across the river on a little boat 5 bht? from the Wat Pho golden Budda to this temple area...lovely gardens masses once again to see and a brilliant view point but its up lots of STEEP steps, all safe but I admit I was a little 'scared' at the height and steepness...but if that doesn't worry you then you MUST climb them for the views...even without going up the temple lots to see and once again beautiful

i love it!. I din spend much time in bangkok actually because of the demonstration tension. But i did visit Wat Arun and I found this temple beautiful. i love the details. Unfortunately the steps to go to the top is quite dangerous.
Amazing temple a must see. Travel here on the river boat , use the tourist boats cheap and fast. Amazing photo opportunities. A must see

Beautiful place to visit. Parts of it are being restored, but there is still lots to see and the view from both sides of the river is great. Sunset is a must and the night view is also great. Watch the steps to the top, they are VERY steep. Take a water taxi across the river for 3 THB one way. Cheap food is available on both sides as well.
Top notch. If you think you have seen Thai temples think again, the whole design is different and the climb up the central tower is not for the faint hearted and not suitable for young kids

Great Place. Been there in January while on a honeymoon.Great place & beautifully located temple.Must see for every one going to Bangkok.Do go for a floating market tour which starts close by to the temple for a more authentic experience.

Nice place to visit. We took the boat ride that went to all most of the attractions along the river. Its a long day but there is plenty to see.One of the stops was this temple. Ladies.....wear something covering your legs or you will need to rent a wrap. If you are caught with bare legs you will be command to leave as my wife was.....(they just tell you to go...no explanation. Even if you try to put it on while they are fussing at you they still tell you to leave. It not explained as to where you need to cover your legs as there are areas that you dont need to so cover them all the time to avoid the hassle. As you approach a the temple there is a board you can stick your head in and look like a Thai dancer.....it cost 45 baht to take your picture......which I did not realize till after the picture was taken.....the sign is at the feet of the board which you dont see till its too late. Seems like we messed up with most of this temple adventure....but it was fun anyway.

A must see!. We visited a number of Temples in Bangkok including the grand palace the standing Buddha and the reclining Buddha, and this was by far the most spectacular!! Thoroughly enjoyed our visit!
stunning. it was very busy here, but worth a visit. The amount of temples in the complex is overwhelming, and the climb up the main temple is strenuous but definitely worth it!

Breathtaking experience. We went there during the Bangkok shutdown and it's perfectly safe along the river. Climbing to the top is not that hard. It is going down that is more challenging. Also the view from the top is amazing

A beautiful temple visit in the evening at sunset!. The best is to visit the evening when the sun sets, around 17 to 17.30! Attention closes at 18.00-ticket costs 50 baht for entrance and ticket for crossing the river Chao Praya on the west bank, is one of the temple, cost 3 baht for a road (6 Bath total return)Be careful, the station is near the Chao Praya Express pier, left it!The temple is very beautiful, if you have altitude sickness can soar above the top for a great view, but with care, it's narrow and slippery and difficult downhill!If you look carefully, are still seen in some parts of the temple, the temple pottery shards glued hundreds of years ago (in the meantime been replaced, but there are still traces of history)And here you can rent a long tail boat for a trip on the canals of the Chao Praya, where people still live as hundred years ago an experience worth living!
My opinion.. I liked the hotel but its location is not very good. I am of the opinion that hotel should have room service for lunch, dinner and snacks as and when guests require.

Nice temple. Its a nice temple, a view from the top, however short beng called outstanding perhaps. The only disturbing thing is that the river boat ferries charge an exorbitant amount to reach the temple which is not more than a 10 mins from the other bank. the river ferries need to be better regulated.

amazing place. been here 4 times and i always see something new! amazing wat on the river and a steep climb to the 2nd level for great views. explore all the grounds as there many interesting areas to see.

Too bad we were late. Too bad we arrived past 7pm, we just checked the vicinity and took photos. Can't find any food stalls here around that time. I was too hungry to enjoy the scenery. But saw the temple from the boat at around 3pm.

A highlight!. Looking back visiting Wat Arun at dawn, just before the sunset, climbing the (yes, they are steep at the top!) stairs, enjoying the view and the sound of a vibrating river below (and the heart beating ;)) might well be among top three souvenirs we brough home from Bangkok!
