Stunning.. Beautiful temple, stunning design. Climbers are rewarded with amazing views after an extremely steep climb on mini- steps.
Cheap boat across 3bhts!. Fascinating ceramic work..great views across to Grand Palace?Lovely gardens. Interestin style of Buddha,

Worth seeing as well.... It is a very popular attraction. Just like the others, I was not personally overwhelmed or disappointed. I would plan an hour and check this box too. There's only so much gold paint I can see in a day...

Scarey climb but so worth the view!. Being 54, I have to be a little cautious about climbing. This effort was worth it but not for everyone. Climbing down was the gut wrencher. We were there late afternoon and the view was spectacular across the Chao Praya river toward the Grand Palace and Wat Pho area. There were some novice monks decorating for Loy Krathong (lantern festival) and we were able to take some beautiful pictures of them with the Wat nearby.

Just over the river from the reclining Buddha. After visiting the reclining Buddha, you can walk down to the river in a few minutes and see this temple on the other side of the water. There is a boat to take you across at very little expense, it is quite an impressive structure and worth a look for 1/2 hour. You can get a good view of it from the front without paying a fee to enter.Please hit 'YES' if you found this helpful

Stunning temple best viewed from across the river!. Once you are templed out, one WAT is much like another. Seeing sunset FROM the temple is nowhere near as the temple actually being in the foreground as the sun sets behind it, from across the river. There's a couple of rooftop bars right on the waterfront opposite. They're a little tricky to find through the indoor market but climb to the top and wait. You'll be rewarded with the views of a lifetime! Not to mention a cold beer in hand!
Magical. The khmer-style tower (prang) is decorated with colourful porcelaines, which is something you won't see from the distance. As always, dress in a appropriate manner: it's a temple

Beautiful Place. Take the ferry to get to Wat Arun from Tha Tien Pier also called the Wat-Pho pier. It leaves frequently and costs 3 Baht one way.Take the steep climb up the main stupa for a wonderful view of the temple and the river. An early morning visit will give you the perfect sunrise while during sunset you would want to be on the opposite side of the river watching lights fade from one of the nice rooftop restaurants.
A must see. It is simply beautiful and it is easy to see after you have visited the Grand Palace and the reclining Buddha.

Go up the stairs if you're buying tickets!. My mountain climber friend and I immediately went up the stairs after getting here. Good view of the city at the top (not high enough for adventurous visitors but not low enough for the less adventurous). Entrance fee is 50 baht – small but wise to pay only if you're climbing to the top of the temple. No visitors after around 5:30 p.m., but it's easy to take good pictures from the pier or the nearby cafes. Excellent second stop if you're coming from the Temple of the Reclining Buddha (Wat Pho).
amazing. a wonderful place to visit. stunning scenery. the climb up to the sanctuary is strenuous but well worth the effort. it was amazing to see dawn at 5.00am.
Magical and one of the must-see Wats. The Temple of Dawn is a great first Wat. Go before the Grand Palace visit. Good excuse to cross the river. Its a magical and beautiful place.

Very pretty. The temple(s) were really pretty as were the surrounding grounds! Ok we didn't take the steep climb because we were just beat from walking around all day, but we did rent the Thai clothing and had a blast with it!

Impressive. Nice to look at but one helluva flight of stairs. Didn't spend a lot of time visiting this place as I was unable to climb the stairs. It would be a great view from the top. At the waterfront there is a place where you can dress up and have your photo taken for a minimal fee

Great place. You can really see the talent and hard working of south asian people from the giant architecture. However, it's a little bit hard for me to climb the tower. It looks very danger. No dress
Another gem along the river. Take the steep climb up the main stupa for a wonderful view of the temple and the river. The monks in the temple rely on donations and sold items to support the temple.
Spectacular. Truly the highlight of Bangkok, amazing architecture and well run. The crowds may always be here but go early 0800 and you'll miss the worst
Beautiful. This was my favorite temple of Thailand and since I was there on a school trip, I saw a lot of temples.

Impressive. This is definitely worth a visit and I would recommend travelling by river to get there. You need to wear something that covers your shoulders and legs or you have to borrow a sarong to cover yourself up. Some of the steps are incredibly steep - pretty much vertical in places!!

Beautiful Wat Arun, Fun Ferry Trip to Get There. To start with, you take the ferry to get to Wat Arun from Tha Tien Pier (#7). It leaves every ten minutes or so and costs 3 Baht one way. The trip over's kind of fun and gives you a good view of what you are about to explore.The 5 prangs of War Arun are porcelain - pretty in and of themselves, but you have the ability to do some climbing here, and it's well worth it to climb up and take in the views.One of my favorites among the many temples we visited during a couple of weeks in Thailand.

Incredible. I saw many temples while I was in Bangkok but this was my favourite, Wat Arun looks incredible and is surrounded by beautiful scenery, climbing the stairs to Wat Arun is so much fun and when you reach the top your rewarded with amazing views, getting back down was fun for me, but because the stairs looked so steep, a couple of people were a bit scared to climb back down, but its the only way back down so you have to be brave. theres handles at the sides of the stairs so its safe and you have something to hold on to when your climbing up and down the stairs.
Amazing place!. Loved all of it, breathtakingly beautiful, should imagine however that it can be pretty overpowering in the summer heat.
Watch out for a Steep Stairs. Beautiful place at sunset. We enjoyed taking the ferry across the river. Climbing to the top is not for the faint of heart as the stairs are STEEP.

Truly A Top Attraction. No, I never made it here at dawn, when the sunlight is known to make the temple extra special, but I have been at other times of the day and found it to be a spectacular temple. Take the boat ride to it on the express taxi and add to the enjoyment of what is a top Bangkok attraction.
Good to travel on boat, worth the breath-taking view. The stairs are kinda risky but climbing up is a great experience. Best template in BKK in my honest opinion

Lovely place to visit when in Bangkok. We were also lucky to visit Wat Arun at night when it was all magically lit up and the were no other tourists through doing the bangkok at night bike ride with grasshopper adventures. We returned the next day to see it in the daytime and so we could actually climb it and enjoy the views from the top.... Not for the faint hearted!! The steps are very very steep, but even if you do not take on the challenge, Wat Arun is still worth a visit as the grounds are lovely and set right on the Chao Phraya river.Our tip would be to combine with a trip to Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Visit the Grand Palace early before the heat and crowds, then walk round the Palace walls to Wat Pho, after Wat Pho cross the road at the exit and follow signs to Tha Tien Pier where it's a quick ferry across the river right to Wat Aruns entrance.
A great sight.. Looks wonderful from the outside, statuesque and towering over the river. Very peaceful inside, worth visiting when in the area for the other attractions.
Jan. visit. Beautiful structure. The stairs are crowded and steep so be careful. Due to some resoration work we could not walk all the way around the structure.
Temple of dawn. Loved the quietness inside the temple. Climbing steep steps was a challenge but we enjoyed the views from the top.

Our favourite of the temples. Views were great, the detailed design was amazing and appreciated. The walk up was definitely worth the views and the walk down was not as scary as it looked (just face the temple on the decline).

Better at sunset time.... In you are in Bangkok, this place should be on your "to do" list.Combine the trip with a early visit to the King Palace and take a ferry on the river to this Wat (temple).Also yo can take a trip by the river, use a fast boat, or take the ferry bus, which is cheap and stop in the wat when comming back from the river..this temple dont has must to see but at sunset, if you climd to the top you get a nice view.

Nice place - steep stairs to climb. Nice temple, cheap ticket. It is a must see attraction due to it's different construction and the steep stairs. There is a very nice view in the top but most elders will pass because it is hard to climb.You can have a good look on it in 1 or 2 hours.

wat arun- well, more like "wat aclimb"(what a climb). beautiful history displayed in each piece, worth the time, stairs are steep, and fun to climb- not ideal for small children, beautiful vie of the river, and surrounding areas.

A Mystical place!. Try and come here at the earliest possible! Its called the temple of Dawn for a reason...as it is best viewed with the slanting rays of the rising sun! The sun rays bring out all the details! Also you will be missing most of the crowds! best to come from the central pier where you either purchase a 1 day pass for 150 Baht on the tourist boat & ferry boats or else you pay 15 baht for a one way tkt. You still need to cross to the other side of the river paying 3 baht!

One of the better temple in Bangkok. Wat Arun is a small but old temple. It is made of very steep stairs. The steep climb is unforgettable. Once up there you can see how steep a climb you have come from and a good lookout at the Chao Phraya river too.

Worth visiting. This is a beautiful Wat (temple complex).Entrance-50 Baht in December 2013. Here the central temple rises in a spire. Its style seemed different from the few other Wats I have seen which are more open courtyards surrounded by buildings with long sloping roofs, their edges embellished with nagas (the mythical snake). This reminds me a bit of the Hindu temples in Tamilnadu, India. The steps are very steep. As an asthmatic senior person,it was not easy to climb and more difficult to come down. Only the young and athletic attempted the 2nd and 3rd flight of steep stairs. The Ganesha statue in the complex ground was also unexpected in this Buddhist temple.Catch a ferry from the Pier No. 8-Tha Tien Pier, near Wat Po to Wat Arun. Cost us 3 Baht each.You can watch the temple and the boats on the river from the opposite side while having a meal at Restaurant Deck or another restaurant with similar name Ess Deck.

Amazing place. Do not miss this Place. Even though you normally aren't interested in culture/religion/museum or stuff like that, you will enjoy this place. Beautiful buildings, lots of extremely steep steps and tons of people, but still a must see. After those cruel steps view is amazing when you get to the top. Make sure to have water and camera!

Best seen from the river and spectacular at night!. The wat is lit up at night, so a boat ride on the river highlights its impressive shapes and silhouettes. You can take a cross river ferry from the opposite pier if you want to visit on site -- the highlight here seems to be climbing up a long series of steep exterior steps.

Great temple with steep climb. The temple is the image on many tourist brochure. You can access it easily by ferry and if you are at the grand palace walk around the corner to the reclining Buddha and then to the river where you can catch a ferry across. If you don't like heights the climb can be scary as it is Really steep, but once at the top level you get good views. Entry is cheap. The excellent rating is also the experience of getting to the temple by ferry from down river. There is not much at the temple other that the souvenir shops at the bottom but I spent time up the top enjoying the cool river breeze and watching the fear on tourist as they tried to descend the stairs.

Must see when Bangkok. This temple is just across the river from the Grand Palace and one of the top 3 sights one must visit whitest in Bangkok. While you are there climb to the top and you have amazing views. The steps are very high and very small so hold on. It is a very steep climb. To see the whole complex I guess you need one hour. Just fantastic.

Nice & Great Temple one in Thailand. If you want to know the cultural of Thailand, Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn is one of the temple in Thailand that you've never miss to see and take a look during you stay in Bangkok, however the view in morning, afternoon and evening are different as the time that you visited. But for nighttime is the beautiful one when the lights are spoting to the Dawn is very beautiful
Must see!. Huge and impressive with many details and artwork. Take a boat to get there and away. try to go before sunset.
Must see. Awesome, unbelievable, don't miss. Should be number 1! Must climb to the top, it's not as bad as it looks. I did it with my backpack full of stuff easily. :)
big gold buddha lying down. cant say more than the title really it is what it is, good for half an hour, one of the must sees on the tourist map inexpensive.

Must do stop in Bangkok. I think this is one of the 3 must-see sights in Bangkok (in addition to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho). This is a great place to take photos in the beautiful dawn or dusk light. The temple has tons of intricate carvings, and some of the steepest, scariest stair cases I've ever seen the public allowed to climb. If you're scared of heights, you'll just have to observe from below. Great views of Bangkok from the top. Pleasant place to wander around. The only downside is that there are literally tons of tourists everywhere. Maybe try to come early when it's less crowded.To get there, take the Chao Phraya river taxi to the Grand Palace stop. Get off there and then pay 3 baht to take a ferry across the river. The lines look terrible, but move quickly.

Do not miss. This place is amazing. If you have a couple of days in Bangkok do not miss the temple. It is accessible in many ways and it just looks fantastic. Just like the other temples and the palace, this place is impressive.

A landmark!. A must see in Bangkok. Great view of the city and impressive view from the harbor. The entrance fee is very cheap (50 Baht) and the boat to cross the river is also very cheap (something around 3 Baht). It may be a bit steep, but the view is worthwhile.

Wat Arun. This temple housed the Emerald Buddha before it was moved to Wat Phra Kaeo. From far, you cannot see the beauty of the carvings. Take the ferry from Pier 8 (Wat Pho) to Wat Arun - it costs 3 Bahts. The temple next to Wat Arun is also gorgeous with golden Buddhas lining the walk all aorund the courtyard.

Iconic. Passing by the Wat Arun on the river taxi on
y gives a glimpse of the calm and splendor of the place ... by all means make the effort to explore the grounds.
Beautiful. Well worth a visit, so beautiful! We went with our tour guide Mook from 'Tour with Tong'. We could not have appreciated this beautiful place without her knowledge.
Great temple!. If it were in Europe, probably we wouldn't have been allowed to climb it :) A great view, and a lot of adrenaline while going up the stairs :)

Don't bother to take the ferry boat!. They just take you crossing to the other side, not even take you 3 minutes, and I had to queue about 10min, and the hassle to board into the boat, it's just not worth it. You'd rather just go inside the Wat Arun complex. You won't see so much from the ferry boat..

love it!!. this place that I never came before and just perfect to drop in. take a Chao Praya boat and stop at Pier NO 8 only for THB15, than take a boat to cross the river only for THB3. or you can drop at pier No 10 and walking distance to Wat Arun about 1 hour because theres so many attraction on the way to Wat Arun.

Don't miss wat Arun if you are coming to Bangkok. Don't miss the absolutely beautiful view from the top of the temple, the climb up those really steep staircase is worth it. The way the porcelain bits reflect sun rays is quite magical.

Stunning. Really enjoyed the climb to the top. We stopped for only 15 minutes with a boat tour, I wish we had another 15 minutes (not more) the climb to the top was a great interactive little trek, a little scary, but I felt proud after I made it down.

One of my Bucket list. A must visit. The grounds are beautiful. I went up to the second level. Was a bit nervous to attempt the third level. If you are not afraid off heights go for it. Coming down was scary. I turned my back and did not look down. From the first level down there is no railing for support. The steps are steep and narrow.
great temple!. although lots of visitors, it is amazing!! You must go there!! if possible, go earlier to avoid crowed...

Worth the climb... A great view from the top!. We visited here in December. It's a beautiful climbing temple. There are lots of decorations encrusting the temple which make it great for photos. The climb was steep to the top but my girls aged 13 & 11 made it up just fine. The top provides a great view of. The river and city.

Scary to Climb!. Visited here when going to the grand palace. Took a pass on one of the tourist boats that travel up and down the river all day. There is a spot for war arun, but it stops on the other side of the river so you have to pay 10 baht to get in a boat that will ferry you across to the shores of war arun. there is an entrance fee which is reasonable but not sure why it is required (they give you a bottle of water which is nice). You can climb up the wat which is cool in theory, but the steps are VERY VERY steep. going up don't look back. i got anxiety once i reached the top about going down because it literally looked vertical and got scared. not for the faint of heart. i went down the stairs backwards and held on to the rail for all my life. others were tackling the stairs frontwards which i thought was very scary. View from the top is impressive. worth the climb but so scary!

Beautiful, fantastic view from top!. A really beautiful temple you can climb up. From the top great view of river, Grand Palace and the city. We went by river taxi and arrived in the afternoon. Women must have arms and legs covered to knee. If you come unprepared you can rent shawls to drape over you. This was the nicest temple I saw in Bangkok, very different from Wat Pho (golden laying down buddha) which was beautiful to.
Absolutly stunning views.. But watch your step and don't look down. There is some renovation going on at the wat but it doesn't get too much in the way of the beauty of this temple.

A definite must-see!. A must see temple in Bangkok. Climb the very steep stairs if you dare for beautiful views of Bangkok and the river. Scared of heights? View from the ground then! Walk around the temple grounds for other sights to see.

Very beautiful and unique temple. Nice temple with very steep stairs and awesome view when you climb there. Entrance fee is 50 bath and no shorts allowed (so cover your legs or rent a scarf there). With very low fee (6 bath I think) you can easily get there from other side of the river. It is also possible to rent Thai clothes from ladies standing next to the coast (when you get out of boat from other side of river you will see them) and make some nice pictures with the temple, price is 100 bath.
Amazing. top 5 thing to do in bangkok, take a boat ride, it a new experience. worth and amazing place to visit.

More than amazing. Words and photos can't do this place justice. It's outstanding. Tranquillity and jaw-dropping architecture go hand in hand at this temple complex on the west side of the river. The views that greet you after climbing some very steep steps are well worth the effort.

Nice temple. Visited this temple at around sunset. to get to the temple, one would have to cross the river via a ferry that costs 3 baht per pax. The entrance to the temple is located facing the river. The temple itself is rather small, but provides very good views of the river and the surrounding. One can climb up to the temple (strongly recommended) . The highest part that is accessible to visitors is on the 3rd level, where one can see all of the temple grounds. The climb to this level is via a set of steep stairs, for those who are scared of heights should consider scaling the temple.

Easily accessed by the river taxi system.. A great place to visit and to get a bit of exercise climbing the stairs. Beautifully decorated with ceramics, a great glimpse into the Thai culture and history. Well worth seeing when lit up at night.
jetlag. Always a nice place to visit,nothing to dislike.And very pretty.Im taking my son and his wife here this year,and cant wait to visit again

Blessed by a monk and whimsical sculptures. i liked the chance to make an offering and be blessed by the resident monk. I didn't like the steep climb up the steps to the top of the temple - but my husband went to the top. Mosaics and sculptures are delightful and there is good shopping around the wat.

For the view and climbing experience. It was such a wonderful place to visit. It took only a few bahts to sail across the river. The temple is just beside the it. Climbing up the main pagoda was very exciting experience since the stairs are quite steep. But when I was finally on top, I was amazed by the view. From that standpoint, one can see a lot of the city, even attractions far beyond. Be careful when you climb down wearing flip flops. I would suggest girls to not wear short dresses, otherwise when you climb down, you offer another view to tourists,which I did embarrassingly. You do the math.
Great display on stone. Beautiful temple. But don't go there by boat. Go to the other temples first by road and then access this temple.

brilliant views. To reach the temple take the cross river ferry costing just 3bahts (about 6p). There are gardens surrounding the temple but many people pay 50 bahts to climb the monument itself. Not for the faint hearted, the steps are very steep, especially towards the top, however, the views from the top are fabulous .. well worth the climb

Must go place if you're into architecture. Stunning architecture! It gets you wondering how did they build this temple from scratch. Simply amazing. The stairs are very steep though… For visitors who might be afraid to come down after climbing up, try going down the stairs backwards. It helps me to overcome my fear.
Awesome view of Bangkok. Interested in photography? Gotta climb all the way up to get awesome shots pf Bangkok at dawn...5 mins walk and 3 mins ferry from Wat Pho..

Quick, but awe inspiring. My brother and I were traveling around Bangkok on our own before we flew out from the city, and we wanted to see the temple based on other reviews. The visit was perfect. It wasn't incredibly crowded (especially when compared to the hoards of people we found at the royal palace) and we didn't have a tour guide with us, but we were still able to appreciate the great view from the top and the intricate design of the frescos.For lunch afterwards, while there were a few stalls for street vendors on the west side of the river, I recommend taking the ferry over to the east side and going through the outdoor market there with some shops selling pad thai, noodle soup, fruits, and a few more traditional foods.

Stunning view from top level. Absolutetely superb temple. If you only have time to visit one whilst in Bangkok, this must be it.The upper parts are not suitable for the disabled, as there are very steep stairs to be climbed. The highest level can be accessed by climbing an almost vertical set of steps, but when you reach the platform...WOW what a view over Bangkok. Well worth the effort, but go slowly when you descend.Lots to do and see around the base of Wat Arun, including dressing up in Thai dancer clothes,souvenir shops & of course the national pastime...eatingA Must visit on your list.

a little overrated?. Do not get me wrong, Wat Arun is amazing at night, from far, but we visited during the afternoon, and yes it has a great view - but it is a very steep climb up - which my parents did not manage to climb - and maybe we went on a foggy day, but you couldn't see the whole panorama clearly. It can be easly acessed from the pier close to Wat Pho, it is the next stop across.
Awesome. Incredibly steep stairs, magical experience. Check out the details of the figures. Take the boat across one way. Lights up at night

Must Visit in Bangkok. Amazing temple with great architecture. Ideally, you need atleast 3 to 4 hours to see the whole of it. Take the ferry which is very nice and there is another temple on the opposite side of the river as well. Entrance was 100 Baht but was totally worth it.

A must.. This place is right across the river from the Emerald Palace. We literally walked towards the water until we found a pier. It was empty, but to the left was a pier that had a bunch of people. We walked that way (Through little alleys). The cost to the temple is like 3 baht or something really cheap like that. It was almost annoying cuz we had to break a bill and then you had all these coins. Not a big deal. The temple itself had a fee to enter. It was like 50 Baht. There is a climb to the higher levels of the temple. It looks worse than it really is. I'm a bigger guy. And I had no trouble going up and down. I was a bit out of breath but it was no big deal. The view from the the top is incredible. You can see the emerald palace across the river. It's pretty nice.

great to see... great climb or walk up.... very steep.. great views... and a must see in Bangkok. Just a short hop across the river and a good location to then take a trip around the klongs from here..

beautiful well worth a visit, iconic of Bangkok. We visited here, you will need to cover your shoulders and wear a longish skirt. the temple is beautiful and the climb up to the top is rather difficult but worth it when you see the views of Bangkok. truly a wonderful once in a lifetime experience. If you aren't covered you can hire a sarong for about 50bhat :)

Good value for money. We took the ferry from beside Wat Pho across the river which cost 3 baht either way for 6 baht there at back, tickets in are 50 baht which is good def worth it if you got a few hours to spare, stairs to the top are frickin steep though so if your scared of heights good luck

Beautiful temple with extremely steep steps. Wat Arun is a beautiful temple on the riverbanks and is best approached by boat. The views as you approach the temple are gorgeous as you get to marvel at the sheer size of it. The entrance ticket was 50 baht.Other than admire exterior beauty of the temple, be sure to climb the temple steps for amazing views of Thailand including that of the Grand Palace grounds. Do note that the steps are extremely step and do not always have railings to assist the climb.
Good Trip. Good boat ride and good view of the surroundings, recommend you to take slow boat rather than the fast one.

Beautiful view. Took the public riverboat to get the the temple. Very steep stairs, so don't wear flip flops and don't wear a skirt!! Easy to climb up, a bit scary coming down. Just hold the railing and go at your own comfortable speed.Gorgeous views from the top.

Nice. This temple is best seen from the opposite side of the river during sun dawn or sun set. Although it's pretty easy and cheap (3B) to go across the river I guess the best call is still just enjoying the scenario from the distance.
Exotic!. Nice architecture and nice scenary from the top. Definitely worth the visit. Low price too.
Well worth a few hours. Temple is quite huge! The climb to the top may scare some, but is worth it for the views of Bangkok over the river.
Definitely a must-visit!. One of the best temple in Bangkok. Be careful with the stairs - one of the steepest stairs I've tried in my life.
Beautiful. A veru nice wat by the river. It is fun to go up. The view is no extraordinary, but nice indeed. I recommend to go there by the river if you can.

Must see "Wat Arun". Seeing Bangkok from Wat Arun provides another better view of this city. Temple is quite huge; and one needs to climb many stairs to reach top. From the top, the entire view of Bangkok is amazing.
Breathtaking. Wat Arun is my favorite temple in Bangkok. The view from the top is astounding, and the beauty of its architecture is jaw-dropping. Definitely don't miss seeing this temple!

Beautiful. The boat ride from one side of the river to the temple is just great , the temple is clean and gives a scenic beauty of the Bangkok city , with the river breaking across the city into two parts

Great place to visit for great views. Great place to visit & it forces you to the other side of the river & you can climb it for great views over Bangkok, alas the stairs are pretty treacherous but do-able

Fascinating. A feast for the eyes and visually impressive but there are very steep steps to the top. Good views if you can make it. We loved the fact that ships' ballast, the intricate ceramic decoration, was an early form of recycling material in a beautiful and useful way.

Nice temple. This temple must be included in a day visit to temples in Bankok, the best way to get there is by boat, as a previuos review says one option is the Chao Phraya tourist boat however this a bit touristy and cost 45tbh optionally the public boat costs 1/3 of this, worth a try.The steps to climb the temple are really steep and the views from the top are not that great so unless you really feel like getting up do it otherwise save energy for other temples.

Must See Temple. There are many temples in Bangkok, but none with more history than this temple. It is an important part of Thai history, so it is worth visiting, even if you only view it from across the river.
One of the must sees. You'll likely travel to the wat by riverboat. It's a must see for Bangkok. Take the time to climb the steep stairways for a great view.

Best way to get to Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn). The easiest (and cheapest) way to get to Wat Arun is by boat, the boat will take about 15-20 minutes, this will save you time and money and will almost avoid any traffic jam.1. Take BTS train and get off at Saphan Taksin station2. Walk (about 1 min) to Central pier (or Sathorn pier) and take Chao Phraya Tourist Boat to No.8 Tha Tien pier 3. Get off at No.8 Tha Tien pier and take the Wat Arun tourist boat to the opposite side of the river where the temple is located (the fare is 3 Baht).P/S: climbing to the top level of the pagoda is most highly recommended if you want to enjoy the beautiful river scenes of Bangkok.PP/S: not sure how many have noticed that Wat Arun is actually the reverse design of Thai 10 Baht coins

Nice view. I have to admit, the place look prettier in the picture. We never stayed till dark to see Wat Arun across the river. We waited for the sunset across the river but the view was okay. Still it is worth seeing.After seeing wat pho, We took a boat to cross the river to see Wat Arun. They are very close to each other. The place looked not so tall from a distance but actually it is tall (?m) and pretty steep. If you have a fear of height or have conditions to climb very steep stairs, this is not the place for you. Coming down is even more difficult and scary than going up. But when you get up the 1st level you start seeing the spectacular view. It is even better higher up.We have been to almost the same temple in Ayathuyya but it was not as steep climb though.After came down from the top, you can rent local dress for photo with small fee.
Beautiful Temple. This has to be on your to do list a beautiful temple. Best seen at sunrise or sunset and watch the colour change. Careful of the stairs take your time.

your "must see" in Bangkok. Wat Arun is a symbol of Bangkok and entire Thailand, you cannot avoid it. I think the best time to vivit it is the afternoon when the sun is more gentle. Take a boat ferry across the river from Tha Tian pier ( close to Wat Pho temple). It cost only 3 baths. Unfortunately in the area of Wat Arun there are not any place to eat, so plan a lunch somewhere else

Dont miss it!. Visit Wat Arun during evening hours ( but go there before 5pm, it closes at 5pm). Its a beautiful place, view from top is just amazing. You can see the river, lights.. boats.. best place to take some of those photos which you want to keep forever. Its lit post 6/7pm, looks just beautiful from across the river as well. Dont climb the stairs if you are scared of heights (its steep).. but dont miss it if you are in Bangkok..

RECOMMENDABLE VISIT. Bangkok is not defined for being a city with many things to see, but this is one of them. Out of the hubbub of the monster city, is a "quite" place to visit (as quiet as it can be) and contrast with the high skycrapers and the up and down traffic of the city
Beautiful. This temple is astounding. Be warned though, the steps up are very steep and not for the faint hearted - but even from the bottom it's worth visiting.

Incredible art piece. Since the name is temple of dawn, I guess it's better to visit it at dawn. But it's definitely must-visit place in Bangkok! The way they crafted all the stones and build it as temple, it's so awesome! But be careful with steep stair. It's not gonna be easy to climb those stairs to go in the top, if you have short leg like me.
Absolutely worth seeing. The nicest temple in BKK. You should visit it at sunset or evening when it's quiet and the colors are magnificent

I would say just don't miss it. A Cap and a bottle of water is what you need to go around this wonderfully built temple.By far my favourite part of the trip, following a journey down the river on a long boat we arrived at Wat Arun. Like nothing i've ever seen before and every tiny detail of the building are stunning. After climbing the quite steep and precarious steps the views over the Grand Palace and across to Wat Po were amazing!
good views of river. right next to river climb steep steep stairs to get view of river and bangkok nice gardens topiary. get river ferry

A great view that is worth the trip. Wat Arun (Temple of Dawn) sits across the Chao Phraya River and is easily accessible by the blue Tourist Boat (150 THB unlimited all-day travel) plus 3 THB to take the ferry across the Chao Phraya.Unlike the rest of Bangkok, Wat Arun is well manicured and great attention is paid to keep the place looking clean. Surrounding the temple are gardens with trees, statues, and strategically placed stepping-stones. There was really only one peddler trying to get some of our tourist bahts, but he was pre-occupied with his most recent victims who were dressing up in Buddhist clothes and taking pictures by the temple. The entrance to Wat Arun was 50THB each and, like all temples, one’s knees and shoulders had to be covered. We read about the climb and the steepness of the temple, but really didn’t think much of it. However, this is something that is not to be ignored!Warning: If you are afraid of heights or have trouble get up and down stairs, you will not be able to make it up the temple steps! They are almost straight up and, at times, you are actually climbing opposed to walking. Regardless, it is worth the view.At the top, there is a nice breeze, which is sometimes lacking in Bangkok, and there are millions of pictures to be had. Also, there is a tarp at the top and we weren’t sure if they were fixing something behind it or if they put it there for people to write on. The tarp was filled with signatures and we excitedly added ours to the list. This is definitely worth the trip and don’t let the ferry to cross the river intimidate you, it’s cheap and quick. Some people walk around confused about the ferry, just pay the 3 THB per way and jump on, you’ll be glad you did.

Best temple in Bangkok. This temple is perfect located in the riverside of Chao Phraya. Climbing this temple is a must if only you do not have any paranoid of height. The stairs were quite scared but once you are in the top, you will enjoy Bangkok.

A must see!. By far my favourite part of the trip, following a journey down the river on a long boat we arrived at Wat Arun. Like nothing i've ever seen before and every tiny detail of the building are stunning. After climbing the quite steep and precarious steps the views over the Grand Palace and across to Wat Po were amazing! Well worth a visit!
amazing temple. great temple and cheap to go see, its a must, other temples are across the street too, if your around the khao san road area its a you can walk there in 15mins

Climb It. I wanted to climb to the topmost but the steps were getting smaller and I was afraid to slip while holding on to my DSLR! But it is really breathtaking from afar, from the ground looking up, and even while standing at the second level looking down at the Chao Praya.
scary stairs. Climbing the temple's stairs is may be not for kids, some people panic, especially when they need to come down!

Temple of the Dawn - maybe worth visiting early?. Wat Arun (Temple of the Dawn) is on the other side of the river from most of Bangkok centre. You can get a ferry to it from Sapphan Taksin boat pier (by the MRT station of the same name) or you can visit it as part of a longer boat trip around Bangkok from the same pier. It's worth climbing at least part way up the central spire because this gives you good views across the river and enables you to look close-up at the seashells and bits of porcelain that decorate it. But, it gets pretty crowded and the steps are very steep in places without much in the way of handrail/places to hold on, so if you get a bit freaked out by heights and crowds perhaps go early morning (it opens at 8am).

Dont miss while in Bangkok. Wat Arun is located on the west side of the Chao Phraya river.It was the home to the Emerald Buddha before it was moved to Wat Phra Kaew (located inside the Grand Palace complex). There is a small entrance fee for foreigners to the temple complex (50 Baht I think). The main attraction is the central tower, which has been encrusted with porcelain and seashells.There are steep narrow steps up the tower, giving a view across the Chao Phraya river, not as steep as the steps for those who have been to Angkor Wat. There was some remodelling of the gardens in July, probably completed by now. If you enjoy temples, Wat Arun should be one you visit while in Bangkok, along with Wat Po, Wat Phra Kaew and Wat Saket.

Best experience. This was one of the best experiences in Thailand. If you have a free day, don't even think about it. The temple is in the best place in Bangkok (by the river) You should visit this temple in the morning so you can enjoy the view of the river and the beauty of the temple. You should do at night a cruise so you can see them temple with lights.

Wat Arun. Wat Arun is a great stop in combination with the royal palace and the reclining buddha. Easily accessible by taking a really cheap boat across the river to get to Wat Arun. Steps are extremely steep, but worth the climb to see the view from the top. Don't wear a skirt and try and wear running shoes.

Very interesting. This was one of the most interesting and beautiful Wats we have seen in Thailand. The views from the top are stunning! The steps are quite steep to climb but really worth it. Definitely worth a visit.

Wat Arun. We have the all day tourist pass (150 baht). From central pier (ferry accessible tru BTS Taksin exit), take the n8 exit. From there, you will avail the Wat arun ferry crossover which costs 3.50 Baht. Upon crossover, Wat arun is right at the exit of the ferry. The ticket costs 50 baht.Currently, parts of Wat arun are under construction. But it is still a beautiful temple with intricate designs.
Highly recommended. Very inspiring and the detail for the tike work is amazing. Beautiful at night when lighted with a golden glow. We were fortunate to have a view of it from our falconry.
Great. arrived by boat as do many. Not energetic enough to climb all. The steps but nonetheless got a wonderful feel for the temple even at Lowe levels.

worth the trip across the river. I've been to a bunch of the major historical sites in the area but there is something about this place that made it my favorite. There is something cool about taking a ferry dedicated to getting you here. Watching the temple get closer as you cross is like something out of an Indiana Jones movie. This is a much smaller attraction than the Grand Palace or the Reclining Buddah but being able to climb up the very steep stairs of the temple and take pictures made the experience that much more special. When you visit the larger attractions, you will appreciate how calm this experience will be in comparison. The surrounding grounds are beautiful and impeccably maintained and well worth exploring.

Beautiful art from waste. The temple wall is impregnated with broken cups and other ceramics that gives it a different look.we enjoyed wearing the rental traditional Bangkok costumes that provided us with memorable photoes
Fascinating temple. Besides kings palace and other cultural spots in Bkk definitly a place to visit. combined with a nice boat trip on Chao praya river a good sightseeing trip.

Must see. We went at daytime, but people told me it was lovely to be there at night seeing it light up. So, go after dark.You can climb the stairs, but it is very steep, no handrails and long steps. I'm a short person, so my husband had to hold my hand so i would'nt have to sit and climb down. Not a good idea to bring small children, especially if they are afraid of heights.Easy to get there by longtailboat by chap praya, but be aware; they want you to pay the admission fee as well (not the boat driver, but a ticketer on shore), 30 thb.50thb to go inside. Food and drinks for sale outside.
Great Wat to visit. You get to climb to the top which is very steep and high (wear proper shoes ladies) but you get rewarded with an amazing view for your efforts

Be careful of local guys tried to rip you off from taking a photograph. This is actually one of my favorite temples in Bangkok. It's a pity that our recent trip was spoiled by a local demanding for us to pay him after we took photos with the board statues dressing in Thai's costume. The tricky part was that he was not around the statue when we were taking pictures and the sign for the charge was hidden very small at the bottom of the statues. Only after we took pictures then he came towards us asking us to pay B80. This is outrageous and a rip off. We paid but would advise you to be careful of this scam when you visit this temple.

Pretty temple to visit. We visited here during khlong boat tour and liked the place. A pretty traditional temple right next to Wat Arun. Nice to walk around for 20 minutes and look at the amazing architecture.

Interesting spot, steep climb. Very cool temple, worth seeing up close. Be careful of starting the climb, however, if you don't want to commit! I didn't realize quite how steep it was until I got swept up in the crowds climbing up. I spent my whole time at the top dreading the climb down. To be fair, I do hate heights, but I also got stuck at the top of the temple for a time because someone thought it would be a good idea to bring a small child up. He froze halfway down the top level and stranded us up there for around 20 minutes. The view is nice, if you are comfortable with heights and capable of a bit of exercise, it is worth it.

A must see, but not to my liking. The Wat Arun is one of the most famous Thai attractions as it well should be. Its exterior is made out of porcelain used as ballast by boats travelling to Thailand. Its steep stairs lead you to a small plateau which has a great view. Even though I can understand why it is so revered I have to say it is not to my liking.

a must see, a must go. this lovely temple can be reached by the water taxi/ferry.many people but ample space to move around and to climb up the temple.fantastic view although the weather was very hot in june.

A must visit in Bangkok for tourists. Wat Arun is far away from the main shopping and hotels area ie - Sukhumvit and around, so it takes more than an hour to reach there. But this place is a must visit due to its calmness and beauty. I suggest you to go there around noon(Post 11 to 11:30) when most of the morning traffic soothes, otherewise go early to beat the daily traffic.

A unique temple made of ceramics. A fun journey to the temple. You must cross the river with a rented boat.. Be careful when you rent the Thai costume before the entrance to the temple. Vendors in the frontline offer you higher rate. Go to another vendor located a bit inside (still in the same frontyard of the temple). 50% cheaper rate.
Peaceful. This is a much smaller wat and less grand than others. However, this wat is worth visiting as it is small and less crowded and quite peaceful.
Xmas in Bangkok. A great view after a steep climb and if you buy the bread watch out for the frenzy when feeding the fish.

Good view. Must see, experience to take ferry across. Can be done fairly quickly, although nice coffee shop and gardens at the bottom to relax and take it all in. Great view of the city on top BUT be warned of the steep decline after!!!! Like seriosly, think about it when climbing up. Otherwise lovely! :)

Lovely Temple of the Dawn. We stayed directly across the klong (canal) from Wat Arun for a week last year. We saw the temple at every time of day in every kind of light. It is gorgeous. We also travelled across the klong on a boat to visit Wat Arun for roughly four hours. The temple is elegant with good visitor facilities (including a bookstore and gift store), bathrooms, and a chance to scramble all over the magnificent structure, whose façade incorporates significant amounts of shattered Chinese ceramics and mirror glass that arrived in Bangkok as ballast on trading ships. The shape of the structures is extremely lovely. The temple location on the klong adds drama, as ever changing river traffic can provide a lot of entertainment. I would suggest taking one of the standard local ferry boats to the temple, then riding around the klongs on the ferryboats afterwards.

Is it worth crossing the river to see Wat Arun. Only if you have the time. It is quite small and what you see from the other side of the river is all there is. When I first went to Bangkok 20 years ago, you could go anywhere on the Wat and climb it. Now there are restrictions.

a must!. The main feature of this temple is its central prang (a Khmer-style tower) which is encrusted with colourful porcelain. The construction of the tall prang and four smaller ones was started by King Rama II during 1809-1824 and completed by King Rama III (1824–1851). The towers are supported by rows of demons and monkeys. Very steep and narrow steps lead to a balcony high on the central tower. One need to be rather well fit to go up and down those steps.

Night Visit. We arrived just seconds after the guards had shut the gate to the interior section (the main site closes at 6PM). Even so, my wife and I immensely enjoyed seeing this place. Wat Arun is lit at night, so you can still get a good look even if the main area is shut. Additionally, the surrounding grounds are very park-like, and you can walk among many beautifully manicured topiaries. In all, a trip there is not only a must-do in Bangkok, but also makes for a pleasant break from the traffic of the city. Speaking of traffic: if you want to take public transit, buses 19 and 57 have stops nearby and cost 8 baht one way per person. That's a good value, especially if you agree with me that bus travel in Bangkok is a combination of cultural experience and spectator sport.

Nice temple. I liked this temple better than some other simply because you are allowed to climb. The stairs are STEEP and not for the faint of heart but the view is quite nice and the opportunity to witness the detail and imagine the HOURS and HOURS that went into building these wonders is what i appreciated the most. The grounds are also quite lovely, though some of this temple is currently under construction. Enjoy!

So steep - wear stretchy trousers!!. Luckily we'd been warned about how steep the steps are if you're going to climb to the top (which you should as the views are great) so we wore stretchy trousers. However, I followed a lady up who tore a big whole in hers exposing her to everybody below...Lovely temple, doesn't take long to visit and the views from the top are definitely worth the steep, sweaty climb!
WOW. We loved this trip - you just can't explain how magical the temples are in Thailand - this one topped the lot for us

My favourite Bangkok attraction. I loved Wat Arun, I thought it was more interesting and picturesque than the Grand Palace. You can take a short ferry trip across the river to get there or charter a long tail. Either way, don't miss this. Kids will love walking up the super steep stairs to amazing views. Careful! Some of it lacks handrails. The broken ceramic pottery and seashells embedded in the walls makes for some great photos up close. The views at night from the river are great too if you're doing an evening cruise on the Chao Phraya.

Must See place. The climb up the temple to look around was worth it, you can see up and down the river. The artwork on the outside of temple was incredible. Recommend spending about 90 minutes here, then about three hours across the river at the Royal Palace. May want to start at the Palace, then move to Wat Arun as this stay open until about 5pm.

Second time always difficult to climb. It was my second time in this beautiful temple. Very nice to see but not easy to climb for the old people...take your time. The view is beautiful when your arrive to the last floor.

Seen from a river cruise at night - stunning, up close during the day - spectacular.. Must do with a day guide to explain each temple and ticket buying. Worth the reasonable cost for guides and private drivers. If on the river cruise, I guarantee the pictures will be hanging on your office wall.
Worth seeing at night from the river. Heard it wasn't worth going inside, so we just took photos from a boat trip. If you are not local to it there are other things to do.
Amazing building. This is the most amazing building I have ever seen. I wonder how did they built it, how hard it was.

Of course you got to visit this when in BKK. I disliked that part I had to take a ferry from the terminal to another pier to take another ferry to cross the river to reach the temple. But when I got there, it was all worth the effort. The temple is unlike any I had ever since, and I had seen quite a few. Amazing decoration, and the history behind.

Amazing experience. The sight of Wat Arun from the other side of the river was very captivating, was not sure what it would be like while on the ferry ride to the temple, a great and unusual way to reach the place. Once there the whole place with its steep vertical height struck me. Great architecture of the Pagoda temple style. The detailing on the walls is intricate and amazing, climb up the steps to the first level and start seeing the great view of the surrounding, the steps are steep, the next level is just amazing, the steepest steps I have ever climbed, you are suddenly transported to height from where the river front , the city skyline , the grand palace complex is all visible, a great view with the old and the new architecture superimposed on each other. The all around view is breath taking, you will run out of your camera batteries and memory, so much to capture in still and video. The climb down from the top is also a very daring experience. This experience Will stay in my memory for a very long time. Strongly recommended if not afraid of climbing heights, but should definitely give it a try.

be ready for climbing the steep stairs. Be ready by morning time, while the air was chilled, and not so many travellers arrived. Bring along the camera to record the fantastic steps ahead. Afterwards, you can see the Chao Praya and its surrounding in a majestic view above. Ticket 100THB. Don't bring small children. I left my youngest daughter with my husband chilling in nearby shop.
A whole wat more!. Saw this wat in the night and in the day. What a cool place at night. Few people around and beautiful lights. During the day, packed with so many people. Definitely a must see.

A to do for Bangkok. Several scams for visiting this temple. Avoid trusting tuktuk drivers bringing you to obscure piers for cruises going through the canals, making you visit temple which is not Wat Arun and dropping you on a pier where you are threatened if not paying an arrival fee. Go either for the public boat (yellow or orange flags) asking you a few THB or go for a reliable tour organisator.

Beatifull temple and view. Wat Arun can easily be reached by a ferry from the other side of the river. The stupa is amazing to see. It's possible to climb on the stupa and then it's possible to see more near the statues and the building
Incredible sights. Iconic sight not to be missed. View from the top was good but looking at the monument itself was actually better.

Ancient. My boyfriend dragged me to Wat Arun and we got caught up in the rain. The stairs were very narrow and steep and it's high up. If you have acrophobia like me then you will have a hard time especially when going down, however. Once you get up there you'll get a lovely view of the city and the river making the climb worth it. Be careful on going down though. :D

Bangkok Sights. One of e not to be missed temples in Bangkok. Short boat trip from Thaksin Bridge on a long tail who will wait for you for the return trip. This teamed is also beautifully lit at night making a spectacular sight from the eastern side of the river.

awesome views after the climb. the temple is steeped in history and has a fantastic viewing platform beware the climb to the viewing platform as it is steep that having been said the climb is not for the fainthearted the view from there is truy magnificent

Wat Arun Review. Great temple also known as the temple of Dawn. Very nice temple and very nice view from the top. To reach the top you have to climb three flights of stairs of increasing steepness. From top you can see the river in front and the citlscape engulfed in distant fog. Very nice. Must visit! Small buddha temple infront to pray.

Good food,great view and beautiful view of Wat Arun. Perfect for a romantic dinner. Excellent food and very friendly staff. The food was delicious and the view of Wat Arun gives it an extra special feeling. A must try in Bangkok.

Of all the buddhas/temples, make time for this one!. There seem to be more buddhas in every direction than you can imagine in Bangkok. However, this temple is really worth a visit and definitely in the top 3 (along with the Emerald Buddha in the Grand Palace and the 5 ton Golden Buddha). Be sure to climb the "very steep" stairs to the top and you will be rewarded with great views of the river and the city.The best (and most fun) way to get there is to take a riverboat ferry from the Saphan Taksin BTS Skytrain station.You can do a basic transport only ferry for 15THB or the tourist ferry (with English commentary) for 40 THB. When you alight @ pier 8, you will be on the wrong side of the river... So you need to take the transfer boat, which is even smaller, for 3 THB. It sounds cumbersome but it is not! The views and the atmosphere are very pleasant along the way!

Amazing Temple. Beautiful temple with so much detail it can be overwhelming. You cannot visit Bangkok without seeing this gem along the Chao Praya River. You can climb the STEEP steps for a breathtaking view of the river and city but don't look down! It is very reasonable priced and worth it. Check out the area around the temple for more lovely architecture.

Must-go. Beautiful structure that you definitely have to visit! Lots of opportunities for photograph here.The entry ticket is just 50 baht (equivalent to $1.50 USD) and the boat ride from Tha Thien pier is just 3 baht.

A Must Do. A must if you are visiting Bangkok and have time; as with all tourist attractions particularly ones with religious significance get there before the crowds and the heat of the day as the climb to the top is exciting to say the least.

Climb to the top. There are so many temples in Bangkok, but this one of the handful you really should see. Climb the steps to the top for the experience and the view. The steps are steep! I wasn't sure how I was going to get back down, but thousands have done it so I did as well. It was worth the effort.

Best views of Chao Phraya River in Bangkok. Wat Arun, also known as the Temple of Dawn in Bangkok is one of the best temples to visit in the capital because it is the only one which has an outside stairway that you can climb up giving a great view of Bangkok including the Grand Palace and the river. Because the temple is covered in a mosaic of tiles and old porcelaine plates it sparkles in the early morning sunshine. From a distance it looks like a Thai version of the Eiffel Tower and it is the most noticable landmark beside the river. You can get to it easily by express boat heading south from Phra Pinklao Bridge (the nearest jetty to Kaosan Road), which is in Phra Sumen Road. You can get off the express boat on the opposite side of the river and then pay a few baht for a boat across to the Wat Arun Jetty. It costs about 20 baht to go in but is well worth it for the views of the various chedis and other temple buildings.There are several Buddha images inside one of the temple buildings near the entrance and there are nice tropical plants outside.

GREAT ENERGY HERE. Even if you feel you're all "templed-out", this is a great place to visit. The temple here smacks less of commercialism and more of the 'right' energy. If you want, you can get a blessing for wealth from a monk - for which you can give a donation. Then take a leisurely stroll around tghe gardens, nice and quiet. Take the ferry (3 baht each way).

Boat ride. Visited this temple of dawn by boat, we hired a boat to take us to the temples and the Grand Palace. Was a great experience. Please don't haggle with the poor young girl who asks for a landing fee. It's 50c to a $2 per person. Remember she is doing her job! Sorry had to get that in as could not help feel for her when other tourists where haggling with 50c!! As for the temple worth a visit take the time to,walk around and you can even climb up. Beautiful.

Well worth seeing. Even if we were tired by the end of the day after seeing many other temples it was really worth taking the water taxi across the river to see Wat Arun. To get the best view you have to climb the stairs, well worth the effort.

Do NOT miss this!. This place was amazing. It is a little heart-pounding to go all the way to the top (and to make your very slow way back down!), but it was one of my favorites! Word of advice: if you're like me and not in great shape--the massive steps (and there are so many) will make your legs hurt like CRAZY the next two days--so bring ibuprophen and try to plan your next two days after Wat Arun with less trekking! :)
Reasonable Temple. The temples in Bangkok are all in the same style and appearance although the differ in size.Entrance limited.

Truly amazing. The whole temple is a spectacular sight from across the river with it towering well above and giving and elegant showcase especially in the night with all those light works. I made it to the temple next day after having been captivated by the night beauty and my guide had already warned me about the steep climb, so I was prepared for that with comfortable shoes and in my best possible modest attire keeping with the religious nature of the place. The climb is a bit hard one but is totally rewarding. As you climb the whole steps and reach the top you will get the perfect view of the whole place around the temple of dawn beautifully spread.

The other view. The best place is of course any restaurant or hotel on the other side from the river, hotel Arun, where you can enjoy the great view, morning and evening, and have also a great view on all the ships passing by.

A must visit place in Bangkok. One of the biggest temple in bkk. Beautiful view especially at sunset. Next to Chao Phraya river, another attraction if you want to go with a boat. Kindly consider not to wear shorts if you want to go visit this place.

Must see!. Make sure you cross the river on the ferry - cost is 3 baht each way. This temple is so different because you actually get to climb up to the middle portion of the temple. Please be aware that these steps are extremely high and this is not for any who is scared of heights or has knee problems. These steps are extremely steep and go straight up. Must be able to use both hands to assist in your going up/down process. First set of steps are not as steep as the second but once you get to the second level, it is ALL worth it!! Enjoy the view!

Bangkok Must See. One of the must see spots in Bangkok with excellent views from the top. Well worth the climb! The temple sits adjacent to the river and is a definite photo stop once the sun goes down!

Wat Arun Couples Visit. We visited Wat Arun during the day. It was nice, but I am a bit afraid of heights and the steps are really steep to get up and down from. It was beautiful, but enjoyed some of the other Wats more. Nothing to really see inside.

Excellent. We visited this in Dec this year. Get the river taxi to pier 8 and then cross the river using the shuttle taxi which cost 6 baht. You will need to cover up for this visit, sarongs are available for hire at the entrance. The steps to the top are not for the faint hearted, I chickened out and my boyfriend went up who said it was very much worth the ascent.

Worth to see. A place really worth to see in Bangkok. We took the the BTS from Siam station to Saphan Taskin station. Then down to the station there is water boat station where water boat is available in every 30 minute. We went upto Pier Tha Thien (N8), then crossed the river by another boat.The boat riding was an good experience. The temple has 50B entry fee for foreigners. It has amazing sculpture with good architecture so you wont be disappointed.

Don't miss Wat Arun. If you have just enough time in Bangkok to visit one of the sights there, do Wat Arun. Stunning architecture and location. It is supposedly the best place for stunning sunsets. However we were there on a cloudy day and didn't get to see the sunset. The views of the city and the Chao Phraya from the top are excellent. A word of caution - the stairs are steeep but there are no sign boards warning you about this! Though you may not realize it when you climb up the stairs, getting down can be daunting... The climb is definitely not recommended for little children or adults who are scared of heights or have vertigo. I bravely took my 4 year old girl up to the 2nd level. Going up wasn't a problem as she climbed on her own but coming down didn't look safe at all - I had to carry down her in my arms.
Did this on our last day in Bangkok. Visiting Wat Arun is only worthwhile if you climb to the top. The view from the top is what makes it a must see.

Quite Amazing to See and Touch. Easy to get to and very easy to walk around and the views are spectacular! You can take the Sky Train to Taksin Exit and then take the Tourist River boat to Stop # N8, then for 3 baat, you take the shuttle over to the other side of the river and then you can spend as much time as you like exploring this very majestic Temple and grounds!

incredible temple!. One of the best temples around bangkok!You look at it from the other side of the river and looks majestic but then you get there and it's really wonderful.Make sure you climb all the stip stairs to get on top and enjoy bangkok from there.

True Thailand experience. Great place, we climbed up those gnarly stares, a memorable experience. If you happen to be visiting the near by attractions like Royal Palace, which was a disappointing, but a separate review, this is a must stop by.
Lovely Temple. Its a lovely temple and the climb up the stairs is exhilarating. Its definitely a must see in Bangkok. Do take a thin shrug along to cover your shoulders.

Wat Arun Bangkok. We have been there and it was very nice views from the top. Also the temple is very nice. If you are in Bangkok you have to go there ... But you have to know that you will have to go on stairs .. It is just oposite the river...
Absolutely beautiful!. Right by the river side! Beautiful building with intricate designs...! Amazing! One of teh highlights of Bangkok and it's many wats! :D
Beautiful. We went at towards the end of the day and it was very quiet. IT also allowed us to take a taxi across the river and have a great dinner at sunset overlooking Wat Arun. We loved it!

Unique in it's own right. I didn't knew we could ascend the temple! It was rather exciting, there was no guide to tell me what to do so i just followed the crowd. It was almost like hiking, the steps were narrow and tall and once i reached the top, i could get a good view of the Chao Phraya river and the settlements on the opposite side. The highest level was about the height of a 4-5 story building, altophobics beware. The ordination hall had a lot of Buddha statues as opposed to the murals found in Wat Phra Kaeo. Though many parts of the temple were still under maintenance when i went, I did enjoyed my visit.
A Great place if you don't mind a treacherous climb. Liked the setting - especially amazing to take the public transport boat past at night.Disliked he climb to the top - felt (and was) treacherous.

Unique experience. We wanted to get there by cab but most of them did not willing to do so. Finally we found the boat terminal to cross the river to reach the other side of Bangkok. We got there with a small boat and only cost less than a quarter buck! Wat Arun is pretty, got a nice hike to get to highest point. You can see Bangkok clearly. Definitely worth to visit.

Breathtaking view and great night viewing. Wat Arun is a great temple to visit as you can climb the steps to the top and look at the amazing view of Bangkok and the river. The stairs are fairly steep, but plenty of rails to help. We climbed Wat Arun at dusk so was able to view the sunset whilst at the top. At night, Wat Arun is lit up brightly with changing coloured lights. From there, you can take a very cheap boat (less than 10 baht) to the other side from which you can visit nearby markets and attractions including the Grand Palace and other amazing temples.

Steep but worth it. Beautiful temple which was well worth the visit but the stairs are quite steep and not suitable for people with mobility problems. I would recommend making it a first stop in the morning because as we were leaving it was starting to get busy and I can imagine that negotiating the stairs would be much more stressful with a queue of people behind you. Oh and also I would recommend wearing trousers, I had a maxi length skirt and it did not protect my modesty on the way down !
Wonderful. That was a great journey to climb there,view is fantastic; also there are restaurants across the river and the wat arun view is fantastic there,ı recommend to have a dinner there..

Nice wat. Renovation was going on when we was there end of nov 2013
but still worth it,just walk around relax and enjoy it

Beautiful Temple - glows in night. I have seen it from outside during the night and it was spectacular.
first two day was so tiring that i wasnt able to visit inside the temple. I also came to know that it was under construction / renovation and a few part were closed.
I will visit it again next time i visit bangkok.
dont get con. many taxi drivers there trying to sell you a tour... just go in buy your own ticket. Don't buy anything frm the street. Those tours are over priced

Simply amazing. The most beautiful temple in Bangkok without a doubt. Structure was amazing & it is a must see sight especially in night time from the river. Locating the place is very easy if you have done the homework before start the tour. It's steep climb to the tower is an unforgettable experience & you would be rewarded with a great panoramic view.
Not for the faint of heart. Climbing the 2nd level was like climbing a ladder. I did it but my gf couldnt. Scary but a cool experience.

Beautiful temple. This temple is really impressive and well worth a visit! The steps are steep and a little bit scary if you're not good with heights (especially on the way down), but the views at the top across the river of Bangkok make it all worthwhile.

amazing!. Of all the temples in BKK, this is the one that I enjoyed the most. The intricate details of each temple amazed me. It's not as big the grand palace so you will not get tired of going around each temple. You can actually take your time and just get lost! :)

Great views from the top across the river. It's a steep climb up and can be scary coming down but the views from the top across the river and the Grand Palace are second to none.Use the public ferries to Tha Tin boat pier, from there you can get a 3 baht ferry across to the Wat. Beware of scammers and "tourist boats" that will charge you an order of magnitude more, stick with public transport, it's excellent and efficient.

Great view. We went over to it by boat and then climbed up the side to nearly the top . Would not happen here as health and safety would stop you very steep and narrow steps not for the faint hearted or unfit. Great view at top .

My Favorite Temple in Bangkok. Before my trip to Bangkok I received mixed reviews about going here. Most people said "only go here if you find yourself with extra time." I ended up having some extra time and went here and loved it! This was by far my favorite temple in Bangkok. I went to Wat Pho and the Grand Palace and didn't really care for either of them. Wat Arun is really cheap - 3 baht boat ride and a 50 baht entrance fee. Also, it's really fun because you can climb the steep steps to the top and get a cool view of Bangkok. This is a definite must if you are in Bangkok and are interested in seeing some temples!!
Great view, worth the climb. Steep climb to get to the top but well worth the view of the city and river. Must see temple in Bangkok! Beautiful temple and unique from all others.

Seen on the River trip. Recommended to visit but you need a head for heights if you are going to climb the very steep, narrow steps up to the higher vantage points. The view is worth it, but not at the expense of vertigo!

my favorite in bangkok. I really enjoyed time at Wat Arum. Climbed up to the top to see nice view over the river, spent some time with monks inside the temple. The feeling was very relaxed and it felt like a received a new energy for all day. A must in Bangkok
The best of the temples that I saw. The intricate designs were fantastic, although the steps up the side are incredibly steep so don't go up if you don't like heights! It's definitely worth a visit.
Lovely. Nice temple. Lots of steps to climb. I was staying near Hua Lamphong, so ignored the tuk tuks and caught one of the local buses back to the hotel for 8 baht.

Eiffel Tower of Asia!. Wat Arun is called the Temple of Dawn simply because this temple is beautiful during the dawn!To get here, you must take a short ferry ride from the station across the Grand palace. The ride costs 3Baht (one way).When you get here, there is a minimal entrance fee to get to the temple. You can climb the temple and you'll see magnificent view of the Chao Phraya River and the heart of the city.The best place to view Wat Arun is by the river during the night. To me, it's like Asia's very own Eiffel tower!

Must see while in Bangkok. I went to visit Wat Arun with friends and we took a Ferry to Wat Arun from the BTS Saphan Taksin station for B150 each. The riverboats on the Chao Phraya are almost a must see while in Bangkok. The grounds are very impressive overall and awe inspiring from the central prang to the Ordination Hall itself. The best part of Wat Arun is being able to climb the stairs halfway to the top of the central prang and see the views of Bangkok and also Wat Po and the Grand Palace across the river.It would be wise to use insect repellent beforehand because the mosquitoes here and near the River carry machetes I think and possibly Malaria.

Really Interesting!. This isn't as grandiose or overwhelming as the Grand Place or the Wat Pho, but it's much more intimate and "user friendly" (not withstanding the steps). We only climbed half-way up which was fine. Several friends of mine said that this was their favorite place in Bangkok, I can easily understand now. Not to be missed!!

Beautiful temple by the river..... We decided to visit this Thai temple as it was mentioned as one of the attractions in Bangkok.The interesting thing is, besides the temple the actual journey itself was quite an experience. We stayed at Anantara Riverside during our trip to Bangkok. Our hotel provides a complimentary boat taxi to one of the main piers along the Chao Phrya River. Therefore to get to Wat Arun we took a boat taxi to one of the main piers and then onto another taxi to the pier on the opposite side of Wat Arun. We then took one final boat ride to get across the river to Wat Arun. The boat taxi is reasonably priced and one can even buy a day pass for any trips up and down the river.On arrival at Wat Arun there is the main pyramid like structure with a few smaller temples around. If you are up for the climb (walk up the steps) you can pay a fee to get into the main structure area. Otherwise you can admire the structure from ground level and see the smaller temples in the area. At the ground level there are some food stalls where you can have fruits and fresh coconut water (truly a thirst quencher on a hot day). There are other stalls on the side which are selling souvenirs including clothes for quite a good price (feel free to bargain)Overall a nice trip to see one of Bangkok attractions including the journey along the Chao Phrya should not be missed.

Similar style to Angkor Wat. Another must see in Bangkok. 30 Baht to get in and make sure you climb to the upper level although you may have to come down the steps backwards as they are very steep. Best visited early in the morning or late afternoon. Wonderful.

Really Interesting Temple By The River. We viewed this as half of a two-part temple visit with Wat Phone on the opposite side of the river. It is a truly impressive temple, with fantastic handiwork having gone into its construction.I'd agree with many people's comments about the fantastic views, and also with their words of warning regarding the steps. They really are very steep and not for the faint of heart. They are the closest thing to a ladder that steps could possibly be.Whilst sunset is no doubt lovely from the temple itself, we hopped over the river and had dinner at a restaurant called Sala, right on the waterfront and directly opposite Wat A run. The sunset views from there were astonishing - and we were able to enjoy them over a glass of wine. Beautiful.
Good city views. This is a great place to go just before sunset to watch the city light up. Just be careful of the steps.

Amazing Experience. Words fail me about this wonderful location. One minute you are standing next to another visitor and the next there is a priest standing there.This is a MUST VISIT location, just for the sheer experience of the tranquil, calmness which is a couple of minutes walk from the river.There is some really ornate stonework on both the statues and the temple buildings both inside and outdoors.

Not for those with fear of heights. This temple is absolutely beautiful and so different from the other temples. The use of ceramics is wonderful, and the very steep climb to the top always pumped my adrenaline. And so is climbing down the stairs. But the view of Chao Praya river from the top is the best.

Best temple in Bangkok. By far the best temple in Bangkok. Granted, I haven't seen them all, but out of the big and famous, I liked this one the best. The entrance fee is just 50 baht (compared to the astronomic 500 baht at the Grand Palace), it's not overrun by tourists, and the souvenir shops are not located on the grounds of the temple, but in a building close by. This results in a temple you can walk around and look at and take pictures of in peace, without being trampled on by guided tours and harassed by aggressive sellers. Plus, the temple itself is awe-inspiring, at over 80 meters tall. It is possible to walk almost all the way to the top, which gives you a beautiful view of the Bangkok skyline, but be careful, as the steps up there are extremely steep (and a little slippery!)And don't listen to the tuk-tuk drivers telling you you HAVE to take a river cruise because it's the only way to get there! There is a boat crossing the river at Wat Po for only 3 baht one way!
Beautiful temple!. A beautiful temple with beautiful surroundings! We hired a longtail boat and private guide - it was great! Would love to see it at dawn.

Wonderful old temple in Thailand. I think Temple of Dawn is the most attractive place in Bangkok. I was impressive by the magnificeness of this temple. It had many grand statues and a wonderful view from the top. But it is very crowded with many tourists. Anw, that is my wonderful experience. Highly recommend to anyone when visiting in Bangkok and remmember that your dress must be appropriate with solemn place.

Nice Temple but do not pay too much to get there.. We got done a bit on this one, but also learnt from it. The driver took us to the pier to catch a long boat ride up the river and to see the fish and a small floating market and then onto Wat Arun. Not the temple was certainly nice enough, but the fish, well I've seen and caught plenty of catfish in my day, so nothing exciting for me, though the kids did like that. The floating market consisted of 3 boats in the canal that came to you trying to sell you drinks and even for the driver. The long boat ride didn't need to be so long but you know when in Bangkok. However the biggest catch was the price 2000BHT was way too expensive - look to pay about half of that if you going on a private trip. That's the biggest thing.

A gem of a place to visit. Well worth the short ferry journey. It is like stepping into the country - so calm. People suddenly appear very laid back, and wander about, enjoying life from the other side of the river. A highlight on our visist to Bangkok - would encourage anyone to go
must see. like thailand alot because of great food, friendly people, and different but interesting culture to see and experience.

Worth the climb. We saved Wat Arun for last on our day of Wats and it was definitely our favorite place. The view from the top is breathtaking and it's a little less touristy than the Wat Pho and the Grand Palace. If you're on the older side, ascending and descending the stairs might be a challenge.
