Must see. Wat Arun was the first stop on our Bangkok temple trek. After a 15 ride down the river, we reached the Arun complex and spent about an hour touring site. Arun itself is covered in statues, porticoes and thousands of intricate colored tiles but, don't leave without touring the surrounding temples and structures as well!

Beautiful old temple and great views. This thing is awesome. It is old, historic, and it has great views of the river and Bangkok from atop of it. Like most places in Bangkok, it is very crowded with tourists, but it is a fine attraction and worth checking out. Make sure you take the right ferry to get there (only costs 3 baht), versus the longtail boats which try to rip you off for 1,000 baht!!

A Spectacular Place!. Located on the edge of the Chao Phraya River Wat Arun has the most perfect setting. The beautiful decoration and steep steps lead you to spectacular views up and down the river. Highly recommended to anyone visiting Bangkok!To get there take the Chao Phraya Express Boats to pier N8, Tha Tien, then take the cross river ferry to the other side of the river, 3 baht each way. The small restaurant at the pier is a great little place to relax while waiting for the river boats.

Steep climb but worth it. This was my favourite place that I visited in Thailand. Absolutely stunning and a fantastic view from the top. Make sure you dress appropriately though there are clothes on sale in the grounds if you forget. Be careful on the steps and don't forget your camera.
Nice ancient temple. This is an older temple and has many places you can explore, including one tower you can climb up - it is steep so be careful going up and down the stairs.

Better view at Night. This place is a bit tricky to get to because the local tourist boat doesn't really stop there. We chartered a boat to do the canal cruise and got there without any hassle. However, the boat ride was quite bumpy given all the speed boats and heavy traffic on the river during the day. The Wat is the least colorful amongst those by the river but it was done at a period and modelled after the cambodian architecture. At night with the bright lights around, the temple looks much more glamorous in photo and real life. It is worth visiting if you are a first timer in this city. If you are not visiting during the months from Nov to early Feb, go late afternoon, the heat is much more bearable.

Must see. If you like khmer architecture, you have to visit this temple.The climb is worth it, you have a nice view on Bangkok, and the temple itself is in really good shape, and has a lot of carved details.

Must see!. Great attraction! Quite amazing temple and its also quite high. If you are a first timer in Bangkok you have to make sure that you visit this attraction. Been here twice already, but I never got tired of looking at it.

Gorgeous tower, a must visit. There isn't much else to say about this place other than you should make sure you see it on land and from the canal to get the full effect (during the day and at night, too). You can go on a tour, but you don't need to, just walking around on your own is a rewarding experience. Look up close to see the strange and interesting details of the temple (it's a unique design I haven't seen replicated since). Like many places in Bangkok, the earlier you get there the less crowded it will be. I would suggest approaching it by boat and then making landfall to do a wander.

Not for people who suffer from vertigo. A neat temple with good 360 degree views and an interesting ascent and descent. The steps are so steep that most people are clinging onto the hand rails for dear life - including me.

Beware. Very nice.Rented a Thai traditional costume with full set of accessories for 100 baht for photo taking.But BEWARE!While walking around I saw those cut-out (where people put their face in the cut-out to take photo)Thai figures, and decided to take a photo with it. After taking photo with my own camera, I was told I need to pay 40baht?!?!?The guy who asked me to pay up, used his foot to press down some grass and there revealed the "price tag"!!!I felt so cheated! The cut-off Thai figure was not nice at all but just took it for fun. In fact, another couple who were waiting to pose with the "coloured wooden planks" walked off after realizing such stuffs required a fee!

Wow that's steep!. We got here via the Tourist boat & then the boat that goes across the river, which was easy enough. Very nice looking temple. If its your first time to Bangkok you have to include this in your itinerary. Make sure you bring a pen or texta, as there is a piece of material that wraps around the temple of the top level to write your names on.

Beautiful Surroundings. Fun temple to visit taking a cheap boat across the Chao Phraya river. Absolutely stunning and intricate design on the temple structure. Quite a few steep steps up to the top which provide a stunning view when you make it. Beautiful at any time of day but well known for being absolutely amazing during sun rise. Definite must see for a visit to Bangkok.

Could have stayed all day. So much to see, both in the structures and on the grounds. We were with a tour boat and felt rushed. I would have liked at least 2 hours to wander about. It would be a lovely place to stay all day!

Amazing structure. This Wat is a much smaller compound than the others, but impressive in its enormous height. The steps are also some of the steepest I have ever seen. The entire structure is also brightly colored ceramic tile, with Garudas (birds) serving as part of the support structure. This is an amazing Wat and well worth a two hour visit. Take the ferry from Wat Pho. It takes ten minutes and costs 3 Bhat. Add this one to the list!

Stunning!. What a view. Would recommend this to anyone going here. Is a bit of a trek, but holy heck the views are perfect. REALLY high! Getting there if you are traveling from the Grand Palace, defiantly do not take the main fairy. You can pay up to 3000 baht. There is a small fairy to the left of the Grand Palace right next to the Jade Buda where you will only pay 3 baht to get across!!!

Worth the effort. Didn't have this on our itinerary at first, but a friend recommended just before we left. Was certainly worth the effort. Took the very cheap and short boat ride across the river after seeing Wat Phra Kaeo and Wat Pho. View from the top was breathtaking, and there was a nice breeze blowing up there to cool off. Steps to get up are steep.
Beautiful place. Great views of the river and city, a beautifully rendered temple on the far bank of the river, the boat journey to was was worth the visit too.

Stunning. Great place to view surrounding area and fantastic workmanship. Tiny tiles of glass and ceramics are really amazing.
Don't climb if you have vertigo or sore knees are steps are high and very steep but it is a great climb and if I don't climb a Mayan Temple, I've done this one.
Loved its beauty and work.

Worth a climb. Popped over from visiting Wat Pho and glad we did. Nice place and you are able to climb it if you wish. Quite step and caused the wife a bit of discomfort when she came to go down as no hand rail

big climb. The stairs are pretty dangerous and I was a bit nervous climbing them but the view is worth it from the top of the pagoda. Use the handrails! Not all of the halls are open, unlike at Wat Pho, but still there are a few other halls to see while you are there.

Crazy mosaic tiling. Actually its been a couple years since I was there, just that back then i wasn't really into the big reviews. On top of that amazing detail its a rather discombobulating climb up and even more so coming down. If you get vertigo don't attempt! As the naming suggest its best at dawn though dusk is also great.

Looks better at night on a dinner cruise. Looks really good at dusk or dawn but it is not very delicate when you are very close. Better take a long distance shot, at night time with light. However it is located very close to town and easy to get there. Just walk to the river and catch the public boat for 15 bath and you will be there.
Good climb. It's a nice climb up and if you happen to be in Bangkok then you should have done it for sure! It is indeed a must do for bangkok but again it's not the 8th wonder of the world

Beautiful view from the top. Just a short ferry ride across the Chao Phraya River Wat Arun is a beautifully contract temple of sculptures and mosaic. The steps to the top are alarmingly steep so be careful and hold on to the guardrails! The temple is most definitely worth a visit at any time of the day or night.
Great climb. You get to climb the main tower, but it's a bit steep. We went during the day so didn't see the famed sunset.

On the first place. Really amazing temple, worth to see. You can approach from the river, price of the boat is 3 THB, trip takes 3-5 minutes. A lot of arduous stairs, but when you arrive to the top you will see a beautiful panorama.
No elevator nor wheelchair access.

Nice View.... Nice view from the top of the temple, go during night time will be better.
Nearby this temple got other famous attractions, such as Grand Palace and Wat Pho, you may go to those temples in one day together with your family and friends.
Worth seeing.. Definitely worth having a wander about. Not too much to do but you can climb the temple and the area around the temple is nice to hang around.

Leave fear of heights at the door. This temple is absolutely stunning, both far away and up close. For a rather inexpensive fee (boat + temple), it's definitely worth a trip if you're already going to see Wat Pho. You can climb up about halfway to see what amounts to a pretty great view, but keep in mind that the steps are narrow and steep, and the only thing to hold on to is a rail wound in rope. We ended up descending sideways so that we could grasp onto said handrail with both hands and see each step, and also because people are going up and down at the same time. Be careful, and enjoy!

A perfect view of the city. Pleasant view up there, make sure to be properly dressed ( no tank tops or shorts). The stairs are quite steep but I wore my flip flop and I had no problem at all going up. The temple itself is simply amazing by all the little details and you'll a good view of the city. If I remember well it's only 50 bahts to get in.
Great climb up and view. Great temple and a superb view.When it is wet one has to make sure to hold on to something while climbing up or down.I enjoyed this temple more than others.

lovely temple. Easy to visit by boat. take a ferry from tha tien pier, cost 5 thb pp. entrance fee 30 thb. beautifull temple complex with great mosaics on the central prang and other towers. the prang can be climbed but the steps are very steep. great view from the top

Best wat in bangkok. This wat was the most interesting with great sculpture and reliefs that could be viewed. The best way to get there is orange express boat to wat po and then take local ferry across. The grounds have Thai, Indian and Chinese influences which make this wat a must see.

Be careful of the stairs. The stairs can be steep. Be careful. Don't forget to bring pen or marker to write your name on top of the Wat. Best part of visiting Wat Arun is that our group get to dressed the traditional Thailand dress (100 baht) at the lower part and we take photo like crazy with Wat Arun as the background.

Lovely Temple. We visited with a guide who made sure we also saw the hall of the Buddha statues that was lovely as well. The Temple itself is really steep to climb. The best part is really seeing the artwork on the Temple itself rather than the climb to see the view.

A Must In Bangkok. . .. Went to this temple twice, once with my wife and second with my brother and sister. Second time was a disaster only due to rain :))If you're planning to go to Wat Po (Temple Of Reclining BUddha) and also Grand Palace then this temple is within a sequence, just catch a BTS to Saphan Taksin and continue your travel by water taxi to Chinatown then cross the Chao Phraya river will only cost you about 5-10 Baht itsef (for crossing only). You can climb the stupa and the beauty plus its history will only take your breath away. They offer for a photo shoot in traditional Thai dress (will have to pay for this).One of my favourite spot in BangkokCheers. . .

Take time to visit. Fairly easy to get to from the river ferries, for us a river crossing costing 3 Bhatts (6 pence). Short walk from the ferry point to the monument, small entry charge then you can if you wish climb part way up. Be very aware that the steps up are very steep and the last section is nearer to climbing a ladder so if you do go have sensible footwear. Great visit, great views

Average site. I hired a private guide who was very knowledgeable and helpful. We too a boat across to Temple of Dawn from Grand Palace. At the jetty, my guide gave me some fish food which I threw into the Chao Phaya and the fish were huge! Her history lesson about the temple was also enlightening including her explanation about the cross-river rivalry between temples.I personally find the temple with its steep climbs a disappointment. Visit this temple if you have the time. I usually read Lonely Planet and do all these by myself but with time constraint, I hired a guide and it was enriching. Another reason I hired a guide was because of demonstrations in Bangkok (at time of writing, it was getting worse!). She brought me to Democracy Monument - the epicenter of the demonstrators - and the atmosphere was carnival-like. I was lucky too that the weather was fine.

So detailed!. This temple does not look like much from afar, but when you get close you can see how detailed it really is! Each part has thousands of pieces of Italian tiles and pottery pieces. Very, very detailed and you can appreciate the time and effort that went into building it. Definitely worth looking at up close. There are very, very steep stairs which you can climb to the top of the temple. Going down is harder than going up. You still get good views of the temple from the bottom, but if you are up for it, the views of Bangkok from the top are wonderful! We went around sunset and it was beautiful.

Nice way to end the evening. located at the banks of a river, the best way to visit this temple is to take a ferry across the river (3bhat). 6- 6:30 would be good time to reach the temple. The temple is a Buddhist temple and requires an entry fee. Be careful to cover the shoulders (spaghetti straps/ sleeveless ) and shorts for women are disallowed. One can get wrap arounds on payment if one ends up dressed up so.The climb up to the temple is wonderful. The stairs are steep but the view from the top is wonderful.

Intricate stone work with great stairs to climb. The beautiful intricate stone work was beautiful both from far and from close. Climbing the stairs gave a great view of the river and other sites of Bangkok.

Must see. We went on a private tour by longboat and really enjoyed the experience to have a knowledgeable guide to ourselves as we'll as having as much time to spend as we liked at this truly magnificent temple
In the Top5 for your first day in Bangkok. I like it especially for the view on the river and the Grand Palace.Great spot and Time-lapse shots!

Beautiful..Beautiful. It is such a beautiful temple. Just can't be missed when you visit Bangkok. I would say this is my favorite temple of all the temples I visited in Bangkok. The climb is a little steep but it is worth visiting.

Unique, fun, less crowded than other sights. We visited in the middle of the day. Such an amazing structure! They let you climb up the very steep steps, which lead to an awesome view. There were not many people when we went, making it much more enjoyable than the grand palace and emerald buddha (both were crazy when we were there)Only 3 baht to cross the river, and the dress code is not as strict.It is a simple thing to do in bangkok, but one of our favorites!

Stunning. We stopped here during a river trip and sadly only had 30 mins here which was not nearly enough time to explore this stunning Temple. An extraordinary prang clad in discarded broken bits of ceramics. The climb is not to be attempted if you suffer from vertigo ! The surrounding area is beautifully laid out. Again with all the major attractions in Bangkok getting there early is essential.
Great view. At the end of our Thonburi canal tour in a long tail boat, we visited this temple.I'd been there many years ago but still enjoyed going again. It's a great climb and view of the river .

Incredible!. You have to take the water taxi to this site, but you should skip any canal rides. This was a very unique complex and were lucky to visit at a non-busy time (close to lunch time). It seemed like we had the site to ourselves. This is a must see.

Pretty Impressive. Make sure to include Wat Arun on your schedule as it is different from most temples. When you get close you'll see that it is adorned with thousands of porcelain fragments. Really lovely!!

Great fresh thai food. I have to admit we stumbled across this place when watching the sun set and to be honest I think next year i will make the journey just for the food.........
Great restaurant to chill, drink and eat!!!!

Amazing construction. This temple is unique, situated on the river and turn out to be outstanding in the night. You can access the temple by boat or ferry, which costs 5 baht. Climbing up to the steep stair of the pagoda is painful but the view for the top is very beautiful. Don't forget to take some photos with this amazing architecture.Highlighted for tourist in BKK

Lack of signage. An interesting place to wander around for ~10 mins, and you get to climb up some very steep steps, but with no signage it's impossible to know what you're looking at. For 50 Bt, I'd expected more detail inside the gate.

Must-see in Bangkok. This is and amazing piece of art and culture.It's one of the three or four temples every Bangkok visitor should really see and not just pass by on the boat...Anyway, too many visitors to Thailand underestimate what Bangkok has to offer by respects of art/ ancient architecture and cultureAll is made of finest Majolika ceramics. Amazing piece of art!It's accessible both from the river and from the (narrow) streets of Thonburi. Although there's nothing really interesting inside, the huge stupas and all details are amazing to see.Don't be afraid of dogs straining around. They're more afraid of people walking by than the other way around. (they're not treated really well there)Very close to there, you also find the Royal Barges Museum and the largest canal that leads into an amazing world of days gone by long ago, by entering the extense canal system of Thonburi, amidst coconut trees, with old wooden houses and quiet plantations in the middle of this bustling city.

one of the most beautiful and peaceful temple. the temple and the whole area around it is sooooo beautiful and peaceful. less crowded then the other touristic attractions. the art work is amazing. we tried to climb up but only managed the first floor which was already high and hard, and coming down is an experience....but the view from up there is great. and then the whole other little temples around and the area is so nice that we could have spend half a day there easily.Really on the must see places in Bangkok

Go on top if you're not afraid of hights!. Unusual temple, quite unique. When you're on top you have an amazing view. Try to throw a coin on Buddha's urne at the entrance for good luck. Girls have to borrow something to cover their legs and shoulders to enter in.

Don't dismiss from far away. The closer you get, the more you appreciate the Wat Arun. The entire structure is covered in porcelain with dragons, gods, etc. made on it. 3 baht ride from the boat station across the river. Nice to couple this with a long tail boat ride to the canals.

Incredible Temple Both Day & Night. To me, this is the temple to see at night. From many different angles, it's height is what makes it so inspiring. During the day, it's incredible, too. But BKK often is overcast with somewhat "grey" skies, but at night is when you want to capture the beauty. See it from the river if you can. Another "must see" temple in BKK.

Very special building. Located on the water (on the Chaopraya river), it is best reached by boat from any of the piers ont he Bangkok side of the river. The climb is very steep. Watch your steps coming down (can be dangerous). Very good view of bangkok

Worth the Climb Up. One of the places not to miss is Wat Arun both during the day for its views and at sunset looking beautiful when the sun goes down. Getting to it is so easy using the river boats. It is worth paying the entrance fee and making the steep climb up the steps

One of the better temples to visit when in Bangkok. Wat Arun is a must see and should be included on any sightseeing tour. Best way to avoid crowds is to come early when it opens or late just before it closes. The reclining Buddha is the longest one in Thailand and is the highlight of that temple but managing a photo without people is a challenge! On the temple grounds, you also have a Thai Massage School.

Beautiful!. Since I am an architecture student, this temple was on my must visit places and in fact, I was not disappointed. We went to the temple during the morning and we were really amazed. we visited all parts of it and went up the stairs to admire the wonderful view.

Favorite Temple in Bangkok. This hands down is my favorite temple since it has not been fully restored. If is just awe inspiring to see the old surrounded by skyscrapers. The climb up is brutal but, is worth it if you can make it.

Awesome Temple. This is an awesome piece of structure that tells the history of Thailand very well. From the Chinese ceremics used to build this temple that tells the story of how close we were, trading with China.

Wonderful. My review title summarizes everything. When we see Wat Arun in postcards of Bangkok or Thailand, then that is what we get in real. The only thing is we need to be a bit careful when you climb the stairs, because as you go higher the stairs go steeper. Once you've reached the top, then all the efforts, maybe fear or even pain will be diminished. Fresh air and city view of Bangkok including the Grand Palace and Chao Phraya river will be unblocked. Very good. Also take care when you are about to descend, it is the same steep stairs that you are taking.
A nice morning visit. We did this temple on an a morning visit and had a nice little wander around this it was good because you were not hassled by sellers or anything.

climb up to the top, eatpad thai at ta tian pier for the view of Wat arun.. try to climb up to the top to make the most of it and see chaopraya river view. it is more beautiful when at evening. then try catch a boat at the temple pier to the opposite pier(ta tian pier) and grab something to eat as you would have a cheap lunch with a view of wat arun. if you are around the evening time then walk to the park which is next to Ta tian pier (the one you walk out and see wat pho and grand palace). yes. i love the sunset at the park.
Amazing!. You shouldn't miss the chance to go up there and appreciate the panoramic view over the cultural district of Bangkok!

My favorite Thai Temple. Wat Arun is a must see landmark. It is a very old Buddhist temple. Be prepared to climb up a very steep stairway and enjoy a beautiful view of the Chao Phraya River and the Palace. Do not be fooled, you can see this temple when you go to the Royal Palace just take a five baht boat to cross the river.

Breathtaking. Amazing value for money to see what is one of the most amazing Temples we have seen. Breathtaking looking at the temple from over the water (especially when sun goes down behind it). As someone scared of heights I didnt think I could do the stairs but managed it and was worth it for the views at the top - just take time coming down as they are steep! Take time to visit the full area as we noticed many people just doing the stairs then leaving but there is the active temple too where Monks meditate and beautiful gardens to visit too.A must see for me in Bangkok,
beautiful temples. visited this temple, close to the hotel, many visitors come to this temple. arctichure very good lots of gold work in the temples of bangkok..

Amazing. If you ever want to know how a great kingdom feels like, visit this Wat. It has something special. Don' t be afraid of the steep steps, just do it. It pretty easy and worth it because the view is excellent
Angkorian type of architecture. This temple is very pretty at sunset as well, it is all lit up at night and looks amazing over the water where it is located.

Nice view from the top. There are probably more impressive temples in Bangkok but Wat Arun offers a nice view and an opportunity to take pictures of Bangkok and busy river if you are willing to climb pretty stepp stairs to its top terrace.The best way how to get there is to take private boat or public ferry from boat station near to Grand Palace.if you decide to hire a private long-tail boat be prepared to negotiate hard ... these guys know how to strip tourists of their cash and the first offer is usually unreasonably. But there is always an opportunity to hammer it down and save couple hundred bahts,.

The best place I visited in Bangkok. Wat Arun and The Grand Palace are on each side of Chao Phraya River. After visiting The crowdy Great Grand palace, we decided to cross the river to visit Temple of Dawn that costed us just 3 Baht. The ticket was also very inexpensive. I an one of my friends from China decided to climb through Wat Arun without taking too much time. Although when we came down we were having serious leg cramps. The view from the top of Wat Arun is just awesome. Chao Phraya river with lots of ferries and skyline of Bangkok will just make your day.

A Wonderful Temple.... And a must see! The climb up the Wat was well worth it, but be careful if you aren't very nimble as the steps can be very steep. Beautiful pottery covers the surface, and the accompanying view is very cool. This Pagoda should be on any itinerary for Bangkok.

a Beautiful Pagoda. A "must" on the list of things to do in Bangkok.Breathtaking and scary while climbing the steep stairs of the pagoda. Open view and fresh air awaiting at top of the building. Amazing structure!

Beautiful. Its well worth experiencing this temple when in Bangkok. Simply beautiful inlays of porcelain and stone, meticulously detailed and not terribly crowded with tourists like some of the other temples. Also, take good shoes (and, as with all Thailand temples, wear long pants as a sign of respect for their customs). The very steep temple steps are worth climbing for the view, but take it slow and cautious and use the hand rails... did I mention they're steep? And not very deep, much like one would encounter when visiting a Mayan temple. Our tour was arranged as part of a 3-day tour with Absolute Bangkok.

Climb it and enjoy!. While they still let us, climb as high as you can and enjoy the views down the river and across to the Palace. The craftsmanship and detail are amazing, and like all things in Thailand, make you step back and pause. If you can, go early so it is not as crowded and similar to sites in Angkor Wat, the steps are steep so take your time and be careful.

A very sacred place. Wat Arun is just near the wat pho(reclining Buddha) you have to take the boat from the pier for 3 bath and you are there.its a quite good place and can be done while doing the temple tour.

Amazing view and unique building. Be sure that you wear good shoes so you can freely explore this place. Climbing up the stair is a must because of a great overview from the top. Not so crowded like some others Wat,visitors could see, touch every details of sophisticated sculpt and decoration.
See it at dawn if you can. At Ta Tian pier you can get a ferry crossing to this temple. Try out banana fritters while checking out this old beauty of a pagoda.

Well worth seeing. Took the hop-on hop-off taxi boat over to see Wat Arun which was extremely cheap (think around the equivalent of 5 euros or less if I can remember). Very steep climb if anyone wants to climb up to the top.

Great view!. After visiting the Grand Palace and Wat Pho, we took the ferry to cross the river for 3 baht. The Wat is decorated with art designs that's made out of porcelain and sea shells, very beautiful details.The staircase is very steep, be extra careful and make sure to hold on to the rails.Once you make it to the top, you get a great view of the Chao Phraya River.It was a very hot afternoon when we visited, got sun burned from walking around the top of the Wat just for a short period of time, don't forget to apply your sunblock!

Breathtaking, and just a bit scary. This towering Wat is so immense and ornate it makes me wonder how it could have been constructed. The entire façade has been covered with ceramic tile and Buddha statues. On the scary side, it has the steepest stairs of any pyramid I have ever climbed, and they go quite high. Hold the handrails, watch your footing and don't look down. Once up, the view of the city and river are worth the effort. The central spire is so high it literally seems to vanish into space. I was awestruck by this temple. There doesn't appear to be a door that lets you inside, if there actually is an inside. No worries; you will be just as impressed. A "must" on the list of things to do in Bangkok. Oh, you can get to it by taking the river taxi from Wat Pho for 3 bhat. Don't let someone scam you into some complicated scam of "you can't get there from here", and I will arrange a longtail boat for a thousand bhat. Be smart, but add this one to your list!
Beautiful at sunset. Go into w afternoon see it before it's dark and then get a boat across the river have a beer or some food and see it lite up at night very beautiful

Wonderful view, fun climbing up the stairs. Steep stairs, but had fun climbing up with my husband. Had to go down sideways and holding the hand rail. Great view of the Chao Praya river. We also did the pictures of us wearing traditional Thai costume for 100 baht each - very cheap and great pictures!!!

A must to see. I have been to many wats in Bangkok and they all start looking the same after a while . But this place was different from all of them . The view was breath taking , but the steps are so do not bring small children . There is a 50 bhat fee per person . Should to see when coming to bangkok .

Beside the river.. Nice Wat , very steep staircase, watch you steps. Nice breeze. Also careful with the tuk tuk drivers , they will cheat you money by recomending long boat trip , but actually it just cost 3 baht to take ferry to other side of the river. So chosoe wisely.

Spectacular and a bit quieter than Grand Palace. This is one of the most beautiful Wats in Bangkok and well worth the visit. It is quite easy to get to from the Grand Palace. You can just walk to the river and get a boat across which is quite handy. From what we saw it was quieter than the Grand Palace. You get a great view of the river and the skyscrapers from it. It's an uninterrupted view of the entire city.

Beautiful - be aware the steps are scarily steep!. The temple of Dawn is something I am intending to go back and visit in the evening when it is lit up, as so far I have only seen it during the day (and it was spectacular). It is not as large as some temples, and not as lavishly decorated (as it is decorated mainly with broken ceramics), however unlike other temples you get to climb it. I use the word climb with good reason, the steps are scarily steep. The first set of steps are normal steep steps and are of no concern, the second set of steps are very steep, but one might let a carefully supervised child climb them, the final third set of steps I'm not sure I'd let a young child climb. Especially seeing as they are far more scary on the way down than on the way up. A few people climbed up the third set of stairs and then realised they had a petrifying climb down ahead of them.It's quite easy to get to the temple, you can take a boat from the central pier north to Tha Tien boat stop (N8). This drops you on the wrong side of the river unfortunately, but on the pier next to the one where you are dropped there is a boat that takes you across the river for only 3 bhat (6 pence)For 50 bhat it's incredibly fun, just come prepare for a mini adventure

Worth the boat trip and extra THB50 entrance. So glad we went around 4pm that we were able to go up the steep steps and it was totally worth it. I just can't imagine doing it when it's all sunny and hot so later PM is perfect, just before sunset. And when you're there, just go all the way up. If you need to take some minutes being extra careful with your steps then do it. Just finish all the way and fully enjoy the view as well as appreciate the temple.

Stunning!. We stayed in Bangkok for 3 nights. The climb of the stairs to the Prang was better than what we expected. The architecture of the temples is stunning and probably best view at sunset. We went to the temple using the river transportation which was great. Would recommend visit if you hv not done it previously.

A Must See. Unique wat. I have been to many wats in Bangkok and they all start looking the same after a while. But this wat was different from all of them. The view was breath taking, but the steps are steep so do not bring small children. There is a 50bhat fee per person.

An awesome temple in the middle of a huge city! Very old, very cool!. One probably needs to spend less than an hour here, but a must is to climb up to the top if you are able, as you can see much of the city from the top, a very nice view. The temple is old and located in one section of this huge city.Definitely a place you do not want to miss.Once finished, walk out to the river, and go to the end where you can buy tickets for the ferry across to the other side, where you can then visit the enormous and very famous relaxing Budda! Both need-to-see sites!
Stunning!!. We visited Wat Arun last week. The temple is stunning, especially when seen from the river. The detail on the outside is amazing. It is indeed one of Bangkok's finest jewels!!

MAGNIFICENCE!. never have enough of this, really! There have been a number of visits we made to Wat arun. By boat, car, foot, day time, at dawn, even at night for their annual Wat Arun festival.So proud to be Thai, so proud of what we have. Hope we all take care of all these places well for our children.

My favourite temple in BKK. Not for the less able. I love this temple. It is so unique compared to every other Wat in Bangkok. It can be a bit hairy to climb up and down, with steep steps and sharp stone, and a distinct lack of health & safety. Still, the views and sense of achievement from the top are well worth the climb!

Beautiful. Steps are a popular addition to the temple, so disabled and old beware. Females be sure to bring appropriate clothing, cover your flesh etc.
Aside of this? A true marvel. Amazing to see and hear about the history of the temple. Well worth a visit.

absolutely amazing. Bring something to cover your shoulders and no shorts (capris OK). They have sarongs for a refundable deposit. Wear sensible clothing and shoes. The artistic and historical significance is very interesting. The style and art is beautiful. There are several levels with stairs. 1st level easy, 2nd more difficult, and the 3rd are like climbing a ladder and at the same angle. The view is amazing. There is some reconstruction going on on the backside. It is a good morning visit as it is not as hot. We also retuned in the vening to look at it with the lights on/ Inexpensive 3-4 Bhat river ferry, cross just south of the ferry stop for the Palace and Wat Pho. We used the commuter river ferries everywhere for 15 Bhat each way. They are the best transportation mode.

Magnificent and elegant in a simple way!. Do not leave Bangkok without visiting Wat Arun! I am suffering from heights but even I could not resist to climb up. It felt like 300 steps. With every giant step you basically move your whole leg and after a day you feel all your individual muscle groups of your leg (Better than going to gym) It is annoying to see that all temples are free to locals but you need to pay a small amount of 50 Baht which almost to nothing. Once you reach the top you see the old houses, adjoining beautiful buildings and you imagine how royal priest have felt ages ago. I loved this temple because it is decorated with broken ceramic plates! All kinds of design patterns and colours are together! In an magnificent way soooo simple. Of course the hardest part was coming down as there is no handrail or anything to hold on to unless you have a partner! (Tip: You can always take the orange flagged local boats rather than touristic ones. Not only cheaper as it is more fun too. You feel like a local when you squeeze on board!)
Nice Day Out. It is a very nice old temple. However watch your clothing as flesh-hugging is not aloud for ladies. Old people should also avoid it as Stairs are very steep.

Evening trip will be better. We went there in the morning. Was suppose to take bus there but due to recent protest, our tour bus cannot go and we took the ferry instead. It was an experience, although crossing the river is only 10 minutes.Also, you need to pay to climb the pagoda. Majestic temple. Unfortunately our tour give us only 30 minutes to explore. Need more time. Looking at picture online, I would think that night visits will be better as the view is fantastic with lights. Read somewhere that there is dinner cruise that allows you to view the temple, maybe will try that the next time in Bangkok

Unique Ancient Temple. Having visited both the "Temple of the Reclining Buddha" and the "Temple of the Dawn," I have to say I was much more impressed with Wat Arun. There is something about it that practically screams authentic. Instead of taking your shoes off and shuffling through crowds of people in tightly enclosed buildings like at Wat Pho, here you are outside, touching and feeling the ancient architecture, climbing (steep) stairs to the top, and getting an amazing view of the river and Bangkok in general. If you can only visit one temple in Bangkok I would make it this one.

Unique, imposing and spectacular monument of breathtaking beauty.. Wat Arun is an imposing Buddhist temple on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok. It consists of a main pyramid-like central tower surrounded by four smaller ones. There are outside stairs on the main central tower leading to an open balcony-like corridor running along the perimeter of the structure. From there one can take another set of stairs that are quite steep and with taller-that-average steps, leading to a second open balcony higher up the tower.Wat Arun (basically the central tower) is a huge (at least 67 m tall), impressive structure. Also impressive are the surfaces of its walls, which are embellished with all sorts of figures, shapes and statues. These consist of myriads of colourful porcelain beads that are embedded in the walls.The visitor is strongly advised to walk up the stairs and visit both balconies, as this will bring him very close to the artwork on the walls and so get the opportunity to study the whole thing from a close distance and admire the fine detail work and the painstaking effort that has gone into its creation. Another reason for climbing up the stairs to the second balcony is the view of the surrounding area from up there; it is magnificent, exquisite and panoramic! And a word of caution: going upstairs, especially to the second balcony, requires a firm, athletic body!Wat Arun impresses by its sheer size and unique, breathtaking beauty. It is equally attractive at night when it is illuminated by spot lights, making for a rare, marvellous spectacle.In my opinion, Wat Arun is the star of the Bangkok sights. It is not to be missed.

Amazing. Wow, this temple was great the art, the architecture just amazing. Most of the tourists seemed to be rushing straight up to the top to see the view, meaning the spiritual houses were particularly empty. Go chill with a monk once in a while.

Have a head for heights.....and water.. After visiting Wat Po we managed to find our way to the pier crossing (very simple, only three streets away) and happened on the 3 baht ferry crossing to Wat Arun.Crossing Choa Phraya is a little adventure in itself and you can see close up the various boats doing the longer boat trips.Once you dock, for 10 Bht you can feed the enormous fish (and pigeons) that live near the dock. It is a short walk to the temple and for a small fee you can climb, and I mean CLIMB, this lovely structure.A reasonably steep ascent to the first level gives you lovely views across and down the river, but brave it and take on the almost verticla second level. Stunning views and a real sense of adventure and another example of an easy to do attraction, without relying on organised trips.

Interesting site, nice view. We stayed only 2 days in Bangkok, we had choosen to make a boat trip and at the end, the driver droped us for 15 min at the temple. The climb of the stair is not that easy but short. It can be eventually challenging for those that are scared of heights, But still the stunning view of the city and the canal from the top worth the climb! The architecure of the temple itself is quite different of most of the temple we had seen in Thailand. In two days we didn't have much time to see all the "recommended" sightseeing and visiting this temple was a really good choice.

Great detail work. At first I told myself seeing it from across the river was enough (mainly because locals were pointing me in the direction of a 700 baht boat) but when I discouvers it actually cost 6 baht both ways for the boat I went. I am so glad because the detail is amazing! I love the re-used ceramic feel. One of my favourite sites and a great view from atop

Stunning View. If I say that this Sun Temple changes its hue by tick of the clock, I will not be wrong. It is one of my favorites and I have spent hours taking its pictures. Every time I go to Bangkok, I make it a point to either visit the temple during daytime and in case I miss that I take a dinner cruise to view it in all its grandeur by the night. The sight is not to be missed!

Great views and quirky architecture. Great views from the steep but short climb up and well worth the 50 Baht entry fee to get up close to this amazing and iconic structure. Take a marker pen to write on the gold material put there for that purpose. From the river boats get off at pier 8 and get a separate ferry across the river for 3 Baht.

Very pretty at night. We planned our visit to Wat Arun at sunset. We took one of the many boats available to the pier across from the temple. There was a little park adjacent to the pier that we were able to sit and wait for the temple to be lit up. It really is very pretty at night. In the daytime, it's a little dull to look at, however, we didn't get close to walk up the stairs. Worth seeing!
I was moved. I feel the history and dignity of the Kingdom of Thailand, and I feel nostalgic for something, but a heart is cleansed when I put the body in the solemn space.

A tricky climb. Worth a visit but plan for only an hour or two.Very interesting watching the monks.Climb up temple very steep and dodgy.Amazing buildings,very attractive and tranquil.Went during the day,but I'm sure it looks spectacular lit up at night.
Impressive. From the hotel I used to take a ferry to downtown and I got accustomed to this marvellous temple, better seen early in the morning when the sun is horizontal. The Temple really shines.

StunninG. We were on dinner cruise in Bangkok and the ship passed this temple. It looks stunning with the lights. Next day we had time so we went to this temple. Wow! no words can describe its beauty! Also the view from the top was just amazing! It looks stunning with the lights.

different experience. you could cross the chao praya river after the grand palace visit for few Baht only (forget how much) to get here. Just to make sure dont wear skirt if you want to get to the high level of the temple and make sure you are not acrophobia as you may face challenge to climb step to step and next visitor behind you could see anything inside your skirt if you happen wear skirt or you will be confused how to step down since the steps were almost vertical.but being in the area already a nice experience. if you cant catch the visit hour, enjoying the view from distance in the evening is great also.

Beautifully Ornate - MUST SEE!!. One of the most beautiful structures I have ever seen. We did not get to see it lit up at night, but we climbed up it during the day, and it was simply amazing. Beware that the steps are at about a 60 degree angle (no kidding) if you want to climb to the highest level that they allow you to climb to, but it is worth it if you aren't afraid of heights. Like every holy place in Thailand women must cover their shoulders. I would recommend bringing something of your own to use as a cover, as my spouse was always annoyed with how uncomfortable their fabrics were.A MUST SEE!!!
Incredible. The dedication of the people of Thailand brings Wat to life and the purposefulness of Buddha in their lives unfolds here.

Great place. Been here twice. Never get bored. But if you are afraid of height, just don't climb the temple.
If you visit at weekend, there are so many food sellers around the wat. You can rent thailand traditional clothes too! But if you visit at weekday, there is only one food seller around here!

Stunning. Everyone should see this as the sun comes up on a clear and fresh morning [you can get them in Bangkok if you are lucky!!!]........matched only by sunrise over the Masai Mara! Could make you change your religious persuasion!

Fantastic temple near the river. With the soaring arch from afar, I think Wat Arun simply shone so beautifully, be is day or night. Miss out the evening view but will be returning in the near future for it!The temple is currently renovating but one can still climb up the temple for a fantastic panorama view of the magnificent Chao Phraya river and Bangkok city. There is a feeding spot for catfish, so just buy the bread for them because they really look starve.Not to be miss in Bangkok!
Beautiful Day or night!!. such beautiful temple by the Chao Phraya river. Climb to the hightest level to have a nice view of the river and surrounding areas.

Beautiful Temple. The temple & its structure is just beautiful. Its one of the must visit location in Bangkok. I would recommend people to buy souvenirs at the small shops near this temple for a good bargain price. :)

Again. It was our second visit to Wat Arun. 12 years after our first visit it seems enchanting even more. We have noticed big progress with restoration and better up-keep. It is a "must-see" for any visitor to Bangkok.

Beautiful Temple; good climb. I specifically wanted to see Wat Arun on my recent visit to Bangkok. It is a beautiful temple complex with a great central attraction. The climb was tough but short; the steps are quite big and steep so take your time and its fine. Once at each level the views are wonderful and worthy of taking a few minutes to stand and look about. Hold off on the photos for a few minutes and just appreciate the view.My only complaint on the Temple is that getting to it from the Grand Palace/Wat Pho side of the river can involve running a small gauntlet of scam artists and peddlers. Ignore all offers of better tours or of floating market tours and aim for the public ferry which costs 3 baht and will take you straight over.

Challenging Temple. Wat Arun or known as The Temple of Dawn was famous for its vertical stairs and beautiful temple ornaments. Wat Arun was easily reached by ferry. I had to take ferry from Tha Thien pier to Wat Arun pier for only THB 3 per person. Tha Thien pier was located inside a local market near Wat Pho. The scariest experience in Wat Arun was when I was climbing the ancient steps. Actually, I am a little bit afraid of heights. So, both climbing to the top of Wat Arun and climbing down the vertical steps were challenging. When you're on top of Wat Arun, you could see a beautiful scenery. This place will be very hot at noon. However, if you're going to see this temple at night, there was beautiful light illuminate the temple. It was wonderful.
Beautiful setting - quite impressive. This temple is stunning and should not be missed. You can't help but be impressed and enjoy the accomplishment in creating this venue.

Visit at Sunset. We went over the river, having skipped this particular temple on previous visits to the city, in the late afternoon since we were at a loss for something to fill the rest of the day. We really enjoyed it and had the place pretty much to ourselves for the most part. We then sat on the grass by the river and watched the sunset behind before getting the boat back. Really awesome to see, just watch it on the stairs as they are steep!

Mind Refreshing. I liked the whole journey to Wat Arun. From central pier to tha tien pier by orange flag express boat and then the shuttle boat took me to the Temple of Dawn. The wind from the river and the quietness of the area was very much refreshing. One can sit in front of the temple as long as he wants taking a coffee or juice in his hand. I saw some monks around us. When I went to take picture of big Buddha into a big room (I dont know what it is called) the Head-Monk called me and told me to sit. He then uttered some mantra and tied a white band on my wrist saying "Good Luck". If you want to go up of the monument then you have to pay 50 bath, otherwise no charge to roam around. There is also some shops in the compound.

Beautiful views of sunset, airy. Beautiful temple, very ornate, but different from the other ornate designs. If you can muster the steep climb on steep steps before sunset, you will be rewarded with a lovely view and breeze way up.

Must see. The temple of dawn is definitely a must see when you go to Thailand it shares so much of the culture and history and there is so much on the grounds to see. It was definitely worth seeing and going.

Disappointed. We wanted to see Wat Arun in its shimmering glory at sunset/night but the glowing lights are exaggerated when comparing to online pictures. It honestly looked like a haunted temple. I'm sure if you actually go inside, it will be a different experience.

Incredible sunset in religious site. The temple is located on the west side of the river, so after a short ride in the boat from the pier located close to the wat pho, we reached it. The temple is surrounded by gardens, statues and small Chinese like buildings. After paying an entrance fee, you get access to the main building in which a group of stupas surround a higher central stupa. On each side there are steep steps to get to the higher levels where there is a beautiful view of the city and if the time is right, you can enjoy a great sunset from the top level! The carvings are impressive in their detail and represent a blending of Hindu and Buddhist religions. At night, the illumination of the temple make a great picture. The wat Arun is one of the most famous places in Thailand, so don't miss it!

Well worth the climb to see the views. We visited the Temple of the Dawn as part of a private guided tour. We think this was the most interesting temple we visited as we had a smaall insight into the lives of the monks and also climbed the very steep stairs (take care) on the monument to take in views of Bangkok including the river. We travelled to the temple by Longboat after a canal tour and back to bangkok city by public ferry which was a great experience.

not a temple person. We only went here because it's only right across wat pho. it's different from the other wats as this isn't embellished in too much gold. the sunset is amazing, however when we went here, they didn't turn on the lights in the evening so we missed to see it "sparkle" like the other travellers have.

Astounding Khmer style wat. This is wat is very famous for being in the of the coins. It looks great from afar and has amazing detail up close. There was an even going on and a bit of construction so a lot of areas were inaccessible. The climb is a bit daunting so don't bring small children, pregnant women or people with disabilities up the wat.

Boat trip across the river and a hike up the Wat. Taking the ferry to arrive at Wat Arun is a trip in itself. The entrance fee to the Wat is reasonable and the grounds beyond the temple itself are attractive and peaceful. The trek up the steep steps are not for everyone (there is little to no handicap access in Asia) and groups stopping to photo their friends on the steep incline and descent can create human traffic jams and potential disaster so be careful! On the other end of the ferry line there is a little cafe/beer hall with low ceiling; be careful of both the low ceiling and the hustling bartenders.

Wat Arun temple. A must see temple. Other than having to pay an entrance fee but its worth it - fantastic!!
A whole roll of stalls selling varieties of souvenirs and you will enjoy this little shopping as it's shaddy and cooling. The stall owners are all so welcoming. I really like this place - thumbsUp!!

A good way to start your visit to Bangkok. The day we arrived in Bangkok we decided to go to some places that we're not included in our tour. So we went to Wat Arun by boat (you don't need to get the tourist special boat that is more expensive than the regular boat and is as good as the the other one) It was a great. Making time for Wat Arun and climbing the ancient steps for the magnificent view of the city is a must do in Bangkok. Don't miss it !!!

Must do also :). Taking a boat across the river from Wat Pho is only 3THB and you can enjoy the views on Wat Arun on the way. It is really impressive to see it and seeing the tourists conquering the steep steps - fun :) Some really have problems going down again, but trust me, it is really worth it for the views alone. You do not need a lot of time and probably is best to reserve this temple for the late afternoon to enjoy the setting sun (at leafs in the winter time).

If you like to climb a temple.... If you like to climb, you will like Wat Arun a lot. It's a very high and steep temple as well as being the oldest one in the city. The garden is also refreshing with lots of animal statues and mini-lotus pools. The transportation is very easy from Grand Palace with a 1 minute boat trip.

I thought Wat Arun was absolutely amazing. The detail of the carvings on the temple columns was breathtaking. I enjoyed climbing the steps to get a good view, but was very disappointed in the steepness of the second rung of steps.

Be careful if you want to take pics. The temple was good, we must reach the temple with a boat. Need effort to climb to the top and write on your wishes.But be careful if you want to take pictures with the statue outside the temple area, they will charge you money just for taking pics with it.
Def. Worth Seeing. You can climb it too!. Its on the temple circuit (Wat Pho, Grand Palace, etc) Just a short 10 min walk from Wat Pho.Climb the 70 degree incline steps! The views are great!
Great temple. Very fine arts of temple in Thailand. As suggested by Mirth Sathorn Hotel, We visited and were happy to check this out.Please note: wear full cloths, they don't like shorts in temple.

A Bangkok Landmark. Well worth a visit as it usually requires a ferry trip across the Chao Praya. The stupa can be climbed and results in a glorious view down the river. Otherwise, view from the opposite side especially at night.

Fantastic Place. Easy to combine with a visit to Wat Pho. Wat Arun looks fantastic at night from the river, if you can time your trip to be returning along the river by ferry after the lights have come on it's spectacular.

Worth a visit. Take the steep walk up and the views are just amazingly fantastic from up there. Be warned while
walking down, it is quite scary :)

Not worth visiting in the night... A big temple with lots of marble works on it. Worth visiting inside considering the art work.
Temple of dawn doesn't look good as in the photos as they have changed the lights little ago. The lights are switched on at 6.30 pm. It is not worth visiting at night. Wasted lot of time waiting for the lights.

Excitingly steep. Place was quiet and beautiful. You have to climb up the temple through its really steep stairs. Quite scary specially when you're up top looking down. Not for the faint of heart.We went by around 4 in the afternoon. Took a 3baht ferry from near Wat Pho (reclining Buddha). It will take you 5mins or less to cross the river. Once you're there, there is a 50baht entrance fee. There is a really nice view of bangkok from the top.We stayed there for a while since we were waiting for the lights to come up. Its around 6:30pm when it does. Well the thing is we thought and expected that that the lights outline the structure, well, it doesnt. Its just a spot light from the bottom. It was more beautiful looking from a far than near from where we were. Since it will create a detailed picture with the shadows when you're far.But it was a great experience and I would definitely would want to climb it again.

BREATHTAKING. This is our first itinerary when we go to Chao Phraya, although we have to transfer a small boat to bring us to Wat Arun...When my partner start to climb the 1st stair I just followed him because it's easy for me then climb to another, the view is nice but when he climb the 3rd stair...He just called me to follow then I did...the last stair is easy to climb...the view was WOW simply AMAZING the perfect view of Chao Phraya river is BREATHTAKING....but when were going down Oh boy it took me like 30 mins before going down...the stairs Oh my...when I reach my partner my legs was shaking LOL...But honestly its all worth the try...A MUST IN BANGKOKREMEMBER: NO ELEVATOR GOING UP :P

Aruna, Indian god of dawn. Wat Arun gets its name from the Indian god of dawn, Aruna. It is very large and stands on the banks of the Mae Nam Chao Phraya river. At 82 m it is covered in mosaic made of broken prcelain.

Great Views. The Temple is currently undergoing a 3 year restoration, but it only just started so we only saw one building that was covered with scaffolding, the rest of the place is open and beautiful. Climbing to the top level is a challenge....I have to wonder what they before they installed iron handrails and rope guides to haul yourself up and down those steep steps....it is a lot of fun to do so don't be put off by the steepness.

Beautiful temple. This beautiful temple has some really steep steps that are definitely a problem for elderly people. However, you don't really need to climb the steps to appreciate the beauty of this temple. The best camera-worthy views are from across the river.

Spectacular temple!. The most beautyfull building - both when you are right beside the buildings and when you look at it from the river or from across the river. Different from many of the other temples.

Must visit. Plan well so you can visit the Grand Palace, Reclining Buddha, and Wat Arun on the same day since they are all in the same area.Wat Arun requires you to take 2 ferry rides (<30 THB per person total) if you go from the dock closest to the Grand Palace (no direct boat from this dock unless you are willing to spend a lot more for a local to ferry you directly). One boat to go to the next dock on the same side of river. The second boat to cross the river.Worth the visit.Amazing how they built this temple.If physically able and scare of height, must climb up its steep stairs to see from the top level.Has a nominal entrance fee. Worth it.

Stunning experience. We have visited lots of wats but the Temple of Dawn is simply stunning. If you wish to climb to the higher levels you will need to be fit and careful as the steps are both steep and of different heights but it affords excellent views of the river.The wat is adorned with pieces of broken glazed pottery creating a beautiful effect from such a simple technique. Because it is so popular it does not have the calm spiritual feeling of some wats but it should be on everyones itinery. Easily reached via a river taxi.

Beautiful temple!. I went to this temple with a group tour. Took a boat to get to and from there. The boat ride was very bumpy because the current that day is rather strong I think. The temple itself is very pretty. I didn't climb upstairs because it's pretty high and I'm afraid of height but looking from below it is already beautiful! There are many stalls outside and near the toilet for you to get some souvenirs too.

Steep Steps! 急な階段. Highly recommended! お勧めです！You should go and wear tennis shoes lol You can climb up the tower but obviously the tower is steep! The step is vey narrow and small in width. I gave up half way because it was raining and I wore sandals... it was very slippery. I also gave up taking a picture in Thai style dress costume. There were few photo booths at around the tower, I don't remember how much it was but it was not expensive. Definitely I will come visit again!階段が急で狭いので、スニーカーなど履いて行くといいでしょう。私が行った時は雨が降っていたうえに、サンダルを履いていたので、とても滑って危ないので途中まで登ってあきらめました。塔の周りで、タイの衣装を着て記念写真を取りませんか～？って声をかけてくるお姉さん達がいたので、ぜひとも写真を撮りたかったけど、これもあきらめました。いくらだったか覚えていないけど、安かったです。今度こそは、上まで登って、記念撮影もしたいと思っています。

AMAZING.. Not only do you get a beautiful view ground up, but you also get the chance to climb some incredibly steep steps up to the top for another enchanting sight. The temple is beautiful, very intricate, definitely recommend it!

Cool style of praying and I did it.. Being a Buddhist myself, this may have been a different sect of Buddhism and a different way to pray. I've tried the golden leaf and stuck it onto the Buddha Statue here. I did not climb up Wat Arun, but even with the view from down below, it's so fun!!!

Afraid of heights?. This was not one of the main attractions on our list of things to do but once we saw it from our ferry on our way to the Grand Palace we knew we had to stop in. This temple is available for visitors to climb. The view from up top is amazing and allows you to see up and down the river. The 2 sets of stairs to get to the top are STEEP and may not be a great idea for those afraid of heights. There are no other ways to get to the top or get back down other than the steps. As many of the attractions (temples, palaces) in town, they will not allow you to enter the grounds in a short skirt, shorts, or tights (or pants they deem too tight, I was wearing tights under my shorts but they wouldn't even allow that) I highly recommend you take a long sarong with you everywhere you go if you don't want to wear shorts during your trip.The fee to enter was cheap and I highly recommend checking it out.

Stunning. From afar this temple is beautiful but only once you get up close can you truly appreciated the magnificence of this structure. The temple is decorated with thousands of small broken pieces of pottery imported from China. It’s truly stunning. We were at the temple in the early morning and found that it was not very busy. There are a lot of steep stairs to climb on the side of the temple so if you plan on climbing to the top I would suggest going early before it gets too hot.

Really impresive!. This temple is a must! The views from the top of the pagoda are gorgeous. The stairs are really steep so you should be carefull. Not recommended for elderlies. The best pictures are taken from the other side of the river. At night it's beatiful.The rest of the temple is not great at all... In fact, there are no signs, no maps (at least I didn't see them), so we walked around in the alleys. We found some Buddha images, but weren't well maintainedBear in mind that if you're a woman you can't enter the temple wearing a skirt or without covering your shoulders and also, no flip flops.
Temple with a difference. This was my favourite temple quite different to rest and didn't seem as busy much more peaceful easy to get to using sky train and boat

Not bad... but then again not great.... I thought this place would be an excellent place to stop by, I have seen it from the river at night and it always looked nice... On arriving it was clear that it was not much more than a tourist trap. Free entry for Thais and 50 baht for foreigners (typical of thailand, i know, but still Irritating especially as i Live and work here)....
Breathtaking!. this temple is awesome. So many details and you can even climb up to the top! Carefull, its quite steep! But the view from up there is just breathtaking! What an experience!

One of Bangkok's Must See Temples. Built in the early history of Bangkok (200+ years ago), Wat Arun is a must see temple in Bangkok located on the east bank of the Chao Phraya river.Make your way by vehicle or ferry to the Tha Tien pier and from there take the cross-river ferry to Wat Arun (3 THB). The cross-river ferries leave every 10 minutes or so. Entrance price for Wat Arun for foreigners cost 50 THB.Both the view arriving at Arun and close up is quite appealing and the view from higher up on the temple is good as well. The steps leading to the higher levels get progressively steeper so factor this in if you have an issue with heights. Coming down is even worse than going up.

Worth to visit. Interesting site but I expected more. They dont let you inside. Do not plan to be there more then 30 min. Have to climb up to second level if you are not afraid of height. The stairs are very steep and going down the stairs is scarier then going up.

Nice temple. Is a very nice temple and beautiful temple. Entrance fee are reasonable too. If u want to climb up the stair make sure u are not afraid of high. Going up was easy but when going down was not that easier specially for some gals. The view from the up level was good but unfortunately when i going up it start to rain force me have to come down. U need to take taxi or tuk tuk to going over there because location was not very easier to locate by foot. For me i will recommended go to Wat Arun 1st then Wat Po then The Grand Palace because latter we can going back by boat if u stay near silom.

A good view of BKK. Wondeful place to visit and has a lovely view of the BKK skyline.. do remember to climb up the S T E P S to the top.. if you didn't do that, it ain't worth it (a little scary though)

Post Card Temple of Dawn. The Internet pictures of Wat Arun make it look like a fabulous night view but we did not find that to be the actual experience. After visiting the site we waited along with a number of other tourists to see the lights come on and I would suggest to you that it was not worth it. If you want that post card picture you need to buy a post card or be prepared to photoshop the actual results.The site is otherwise nice and if you do not mind climbing it is worth a look.I would add that Bangkok was okay but does not compare to other options like Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai and Beijing or even Singapore. I would save Bangkok until I had seen each of these others. Conversely, if you will do Bangkok an any of the others go to Bangkok first and save the best for last.

Our Kids love this place. After seeing the Grand Palace, where it was choc-a-block full or people, and the entrance fee for tourist was quite high.... we crossed the river to this lovely temple. There were much less people, much quieter and we all found it very unique.The walk/climb up the steps of the temple was fun for all. The last section was quite steep. Coming down was a little terrifying for the young and old. The first step was hair raising... looking down at the steps below!Lovely temple!

Not as expected. I went there in the afternoon and it's true that it doesn't look so stunning at noon. Nearby the entrance there's a booth to lend traditional Thai clothing and we can take picture with the temple as the background. It was pretty fun; the clothing and accessories were beautiful. Because it is said that this temple is best seen when it's dark, I was looking forward to see it on the dinner cruise at night. But when the time comes, the temple was only lit on three spots by white colored lamps I can even barely see the shape of the temple. It wasn't covered with shimmering golden lights the way I saw in the other travelers' pictures before. Are the golden lights turned on only at dawn or maybe that was just not my lucky day? I don't know.
A must see attraction. Its not as complicate as it at the first may seem to cross the river. Nice views from the city, but the main tower deserves to be better conserved.
Must go. Nice place to visit. But be careful coz the stairs is very steep, not advisable for those who afraid height......

Just go there, it's amazing. Wat Arun in one word : breathtaking.Looked small from afar but it's actually gigantic. Take the Chao Phraya Express boat to Tha Tien pier (15 THB) and from there take the ferry to Wat Arun (3 THB). I believe there's one every 10 minutes. Tickets cost only 50 THB.Get there early in the morning when there's less tourists.
Beautiful. Gotta see it during sunset and at night (it closes at 6pm but it is beautiful from outside when the lights are on)
unique,gorgeous. not many travellers know of this great temple .it is a must visit especially during sunrise or sunset.climb the steep steps to the top to see the fantastic view
One fantastic temple. Once one has swathed oneself in Nylon and taken the arduous climb to the top it's a fabulous view! We loved this beautiful temple, full marks!

beautiful temple and fun climb. There we went by boat trip, it's worth the visit. Took a lot pics from the boat and in the temple. It's different kind of architect compare to Chinese one. I felt kind of mystery but beautiful. Especially we arrived there almost in the evening. I was scared climbed up the steep stairs at first but it's safe and fun eventually. Afterwards I got sweat from head to toes. The view was good. Some people found it is similar architect with Cambodia one which was even larger and stunning. I haven't went to Cambodia yet ,found this one good enough.

Simply Beautiful. I loved the architecture of this place. It was so beautiful. Once you clime the stairs, you have a beautiful panaramic view of Bangkok city. Also, the temple itself has beautiful details that allows you to feel the history behind it. The temple has restriction on the type of clothing you should wear. Ensure you wear pans and a t-shirt that does not show your sholders. On the other hand, you could rent the covers from the ticket desk for about $1 or $2, so if it super hot outside I suggest you do that.

Awesome View. Views over river were fantastic, not for the faint hearted as very steep climb up very narrow steps. Getting down is much harder than going up, and best way to get down is backwards and hold on to ropes. Otherwise well worth it.
Good!. I visited this place coz, its place known to tourist very well. Many people many car surrounded this temple. But when u go up its top u will like the view.

Beautiful place, but beware....... it's really a beautiful large temple.. but beware of the scammer, best advice is to research a best way to get there or better to find a guided tour by the river. do not happily hop on to any tuk tuk or taxi and tell them you want to go to wat arun. they would just bring you to those scamming boat operators so that they could get a commission out for bringing you there. as have learnt my lesson for not doing a research before getting there. so there i was alighted from the cab, we were told that they will be touring the area for 1 hr. The asking price for each person was a scamming amt of 1000bhat, we eventually settle it 600bhat for each person for a boat since they were the only operator at that area fyi, we are the only guest as well. and of course the tour on the boat only lasted 30min instead of what we have agreed 1 hr. unable to communicate totally with the boatman. we alighted at wat arun temple.

What a climb!!!!. WAt Arun was beautiful. I am a bit afraid of heights and it was scary to clibm the steeeeep stairs and don;t ask me about how i climbed down the stairs! it was actually difficult to start climbing down but once you start, it was nothing. very easy. views are excelent.

Beautiful from the river.. Although it is a beautiful and highly respected temple, after seeing the palace and the reclining buddha, this was somewhat less than I expected. A four hour river tour on the river would be time better spent visiting Bangkok. IMHO. If you have ample time, then include it in on the day with the Reclining Buddha since it is so close. It is just across the river and ferries are just 10 to 20 minutes apart. The cost is very cheap

A must visit temple in Bangkok. Take the orange flag ferry to cross the river at Chao Phraya.
My child enjoys the ride and also the climbing up the flight of steps at the temple. I like the scenery up there.

Peaceful and interesting. Wat Arun has it's own unique style with pottery making up the bulk of the decorations next to various statues. You can walk up it which is quite a steep climb. I must admit I felt a little woozy at the top and needed a hand rail at times. Great views of the city and river as well.

If you go here before some of the other temples you'll appreciate it more. Wat Arun was under renovation and it needed it. What I enjoyed about it was being able to climb up for a view - the stairs are incredibly steep - so don't try it if you're afraid of heights. Since this was the first temple that I saw, I loved the ceramic decorations and dancing people made out of ceramic pieces. There were some wonderful sculptures as well. However, if you visit the Grand Palace first, the decorations here will likely be disappointing.
Great experience. I very much enjoyed this site. There are many temples to visit and statues to contemplate. I was glad I made time to wander around the grounds.

One of the most beautiful temples in Bangkok. We took a private boat to the temple and were limited on time. What a beautiful site. We where sorry that we hadn't allotted more time to explore this gorgeous temple with colorful activities abound. Some of the activities included women dressed in traditional Thai attire. Don't make the same mistake...give yourself a few hours to explore.
The detail is amazing. It was interesting to see up close, though be warned the steps are very steep, though not unclimbable We made the trek up and down in a misty rain with 5 & 6 year olds.
Very peaceful temple. A lovely place to sit and relax. This temple is very well maintained and a nice place to sit and watch the world go by.
Just simple. All temples are same and really simple. They have not any historical backround. They even use plates for decoraripn on temple. I dont find any amazing side of this temple.

A must-see in Bangkok. Wat Arun is one of the must-sees of Bangkok. We found it very interesting and impressive. Covered with beautiful sculptures, it really stimulates your imagination. It requires a little bit of climbing (people with acrophobia should be careful, especially when going down), but the views from the top and the overall experience are definitely worth the effort.
Lovely View across the River. New restaurants have joined "The Deck" in offeriing a lovely view of this unique white Wat bathed lights.
Must go!. Very nice temple with great craftsmanship. Going there by boat and there is shop set-up within the area for drink, souvenir, photo taking etc.
Well worth a visit. Be prepared for a steep climb if you want to reach the top. Going up not too bad coming down much more difficult. Aim to spend 1 to 2 hours visiting this amazing place.

Great!. The only one destination from chao phraya river, quiet good! Not bad for stop over, better u buy ticket for boat on the boat, damn so cheap compare bought at the ticketing, 10 times so expensive, its only worth it for one day pass only! Regret it! Can use for do shopping at chatunchak, better!

My favorite. I just love this Temple. It is beautiful and so majestic. A must see when in Bangkok. All the organized tour brochures I received did not include it, so I requested a special visit to be part of my sight seeing day
Awesome. Awesome trip there a lot of understanding other culture.. seems like I want ti live in Thailand a a good experience and a lot of fun..

Thai Temple. Many things to see, but just get ready for the heat. There is plenty of walking to do in the temple and you get a feel for the traditional Thai culture away from the busy life of the city. There are many rules in the temple so just make sure you do some preparation. Also, the heat can be unbearable sometimes so just prepare cold water and wear cool clothes.
Beautiful view of Bangkok. Its so beautiful view of Bangkok from this temple specially in evening it look so good. You can climb up to temple highest point it simply too cool view.
Best from the river. A lovely view from the river especially in the early morning, you can catch the ferry across the river after visiting wat pho
A must see. That's a nice place to see specially at sunset for the view but you have to climb some stiff staircases. You feel like centuries ago.

"Wat Arun". If you are in Silom/Bangrak area of Bangkok take the ferry from Saphan Taksin Pier,"yellow or blue ferry".............Get off at "Tha Tien Pier N8,once there you will find ferry to cross over river to Rue Wat Arun Pier,cost about 3 baht.There are some nice gardens to stroll in before or after you enter the temple and there is a small fee to enter temple for tourists but is free for Thai people,also a free bottle of water is provided inside on receipt of ticket.As with all temples in Thailand there is a sense of history and peace,but expect lots of people because after all it is a tourist attraction..If you are energetic there are stone stairs to part way up the temple and you will see very nice view of surrounding area,but please be aware the steps are steep,and feel even steeper on the way down,so be warned !!!The central tower of temple is is decorated with thousands of seashells and porcelain which when viewed at sunrise or sunset twinkle and shine in the sunlight......All in all it worth the visit even if it just to say you have been there
I have climb it.. Guess, is somewhere which one should visit. The climb up the view was tough but worth it. U get to see a very nice view.

Wat Arun- great place to visit. Take the water taxi to get to Wat Arun, the water taxi is available. However, you have the option to have the 1-Day pass or just one-way.For 1-Day pass, you may want to consider if you would have time to visit other place, as you would need to spent more time at the temple.SCAM ALERT: there is this stall selling food - phad thai, coconut water. His stall was the only one around the area of Wat Po (nearby the restroom)He told us that the Wat Arun (Wat Arun is just opposite Wat Po) had closed (it was abot 4 pm when we decided to have a rest after visiting Wat Po) & suggested to go to the LUCKY BUDDHA etc....& silly us, we went to the temple.
