Upon reaching the temple, there was very less people there & suddenly, out of nowhere, there is a guy, who was very-very friendly , explaining the history of the temple.In the end he recommended us to go to a shop selling local goods & we went there only to find out that it was a gem stones shop. Nowhere to see any local goods!Wat Arun is a good location to appreciate the beauty of temple. Wear appropriate clothing & you must climb till the top to have a view of the whole place.Bring a marker pen, to pen down your memory on a cloth at the peak of the temple!

Stunning Temple with great city views. Wat Arun is a two minute 3 baht trip on the cross river ferry at Tha Tien Pier, ferries are very regular and you can easily combine this with a trip to Wat Pho for the reclining Buddha. Do note that the steps are very steep and not very wide so do take your time especially if it's raining like it was when I went. Night time trip is also well recommended but the city views during the day are equally as good.

Wat Arun. One of the more famous temples situated on the banks of the chao prahya river. you can climb up the steep steps of the templ but needs 50 baht entrance fee. and ladies must have their shoulders and legs covered(means pants and t-shirt, no singlets)
A must at night. The best time to see the Temple of Dawn is at night from the river. It is illuminated and is quite spectacular if viewed from oneof the dinner cruises.

My absolute favorite in bangkok. Wat Arun is a beautiful temple, not like any other. Made of old Chinese porcelain broken pieces from the old Chinese trading vessels. You can get there by BTS to Taksim Bridge, and from there by one of the public boats to opposite the temple. Cross the river by the shuttle. It is a time well spent, and not like any other place.

Stunningly Beautiful. The intricate workmanship of Wat Arun is mesmerizing. I visited it on foot during the day, and saw it at night (breathtaking) during a long boat tour. Its spiritual nature draws one into its majesty.

Not for the faint of heart!. Such a beautiful temple! It makes you wonder how on earth were they able to construct a monument / place of worship like that at that time in history. Steps are really steep. and you only have (sturdy) ropes as the handrail. But do be careful!

one of most i like to visit. visitor need to cross the river and cheap to pay. beautiful view to see from the top of Wat Arun, the stairs have high angle and need extra carefully to go up. Will visit this place again if one day go to Bangkok

Best at Sun Set and Rise. We visited the temple and also viewed it from the river. The temple is best viewed in the evening. the beautiful architecture and the design is impressive. we felt great peace and calm at the place. the flight of stairs was exciting yet treachrous. Lots of things to see and do.

A must see when in Bangkok. I included in a private river tour and have been there multiple times. I must see day or night and restaurants view also from across the river. Can also be viewed on a dinner cruise one of the most stunning temples in Bangkok and at night very striking. I believe the most inspiring Wat with a spire over 70 meters high, and a Bangkok landmark. Beautifully decorated with tiny pieces of colored glass and Chinese porcelain placed delicately into delicate intricate patterns. The climb and photos you must take as is a world experience in viewing. Wat Arun is almost directly opposite Wat Pho, so it is very easy to get to. From Sapphan Taksin boat pier you can take a river boat that stops at pier 8. From here a small shuttle boat takes you from one side of the river to the other for only 3 baht. Entry to the temple is 100 baht. The temple is open daily from 08:30 to 17:30

Wat Arun. I have visited The Temple of Dawn 3 times and always love the time I spend there. There is a peaceful ambience there even when there are lots of people visiting. The views are spectacular and the entry fee is worth every Baht. Getting there is easy, by public ferry, tourist ferry, taxi or tuk tuk but women must dress with respect. We had a tour guide with us which was helpful in the history of the area and we also were able to wander through the beautiful temples and garden areas adjoining Wat Arun.

Quick trip to Wat Arun. Impressive structure , but is being renovate at the moment. Very steep steps wouldn't be acceptable to safety conscious European laws.Still worth a visit a quick ferry trip across from Wat Pho costs 3 BHT.

Fascinating. What an awesome temple. Really beautiful. Great spot for photos. Be advised, if you want to climb up the temple, the steps are steep....very steep! This should not detract you from visiting this temple. Take the boat across the river back to town, but be advised, there is a "landing fee" at the other side of the river (another BKK scam).

Landmark of Bangkok on the Chaopraya River Bank. Wat Arun. Wat means "Temple", Arun means "Dawn".The best time to visit in the morning and around 4.00 p.m., it is so hot in the afternoon.After 6.00 p.m. you can sit in a park on the other side of the river bank to see sunset.Opening hours: Daily, 8.30 am. to 5.30 pm.ฺฺBoat: Tha Tian PierAdmission: 50 BahtDress code: Properly, otherwise 20 Baht for renting clothes to cover you up properly.

Beautiful and scary. It is a fascinating structure. Very old and highly decorated. You can climb up a few levels, and this is the scary bit especially if, like me, you have no head for heights. The steps are very steep with narrow treads and high risers. It's a long way down when you stand on the top level looking at your descent The views once you get up there are great and the sense of relief once you get down is palpable. It's a really cheap cost for what is an amazing structure. Careful for the touts again. This should be a 3baht ferry across from Wat Pho, anything else is a con.

Another gem. This is well worth a visit. A bit more touristy than the grand palace and nowhere near as spectacular it is still very different and you can actually wander round the grounds and see the temple without having to pay to go in if you just want a quick look and some photos.

nice panoramic view. Very interesting site, crowded like all Wats. Beautiful ceramic tiles and a nice panoramic view over the City. Make sure you are not scared of heights before you climb up the steep staires to the top. You will have to use them again to get down ... Not suited for little kids.
One of the better temples to stop and visit. One of the better temples to stop and visit. We arrived in a long boat that we hired from the pier and took a tour along the canals.
Outstanding Temple. This is a must when in Bangkok. Take a boat from the other side of the river for good photo opportunity.
temple of the river. I enjoy sitting in the afternoon having a manggo and sticky rice for a break, watching the dawn at the Wat Arun. There are a lot of gulmae on the river which make dirty.

Breathtaking and fun. Wat Arun is just amazing. When in Bangkok my wife and I stay in a condo just a few miles down the river and we can see Wat Arun from our balcony. Although we have been there many times we make a point to still go on occasion. The magnificence of the place and the intricacy of the sculpting cannot be overstated. One fun way to travel there is by taking the Chao Phraya Express boat to the dock directly across the river. Then you hop on a ferry across the river to dock right at the Wat. The cost for both of the river rides is very inexpensive; less than a couple dollars total for both, and they are ways Bangkok locals use to get to work and home. So you get a real Thai experience, not like the tourist boats that ply the river. I don't know if the tourist boats stop here or not. I also must tell you that neither the river express or the ferry have handicap access so be cautious of that if needed. Oftentimes when we step off the ferry there are people there holding pythons, etc that offer you a chance to take a picture. Be warned that they expect payment for taking your picture with the snake or, for the ladies, in a traditional Thai dress. This is Thailand; just go with it and have fun. It's only a few bucks, too. We took my parents here several years ago and my mother still has the picture of her in the Thai dress in her living room to this day. It's a great conversation piece. In short, Wat Arun is amazing and anyone with a couple days in Bangkok would be remiss not to see it at least once.

Very beautiful scenic... Every temple in bangkok has its own uniqueness..wat arun is unique in the way to reach the place and also the height..you can reach this temple easily with boat just for 3 baht per trip per person..when I went there it's raining so the weather is not too hot but I suggest not to climb to the second level if it's in rain..elderly can reach the first level of this temple..it has metal border for elderly to climb safely..I don't recommend to shop around this area because it's far more expensive than other places..
Impressive. Even though it was raining, the visit to the temple is an experience! Do not miss. I enjoyed it more than the Temple of Reclining Budha!

did it! climbed the temple. Wat Arun has stairs that allows visitor to climb. it wasn't lots of steps but the steps are VERY tall and it was scary to climb up, even scarier to climb down. mini challenge, felt accomplished to have conquer my fear

One of the highlight of out Bangkok trip. This is a must-do. Very beautiful temple. There was very few people when I went there. It's extremely steep so get ready to climb some scary stairs. From there you can take a boat (3 baht) to cross the Chao Phraya and reach the Wat Pho or the Grand Palace.

Really cool view from its top. Wat Arun maybe is not one of the most visited temples in Bangkok, but it should be. It has a distinctive style than most of the other teamples around. besides that, from its top it's possible to have a panoramic view of old Bangkok including the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. During the night it's full of light making it even more beautiful.

A temple with a little workout. To fully enjoy Wat Arun, you need to climb the steep stairs. No rush, just enjoy every step and climb all the way to the top (really it's just 2 floors).Entrance fee is THB50/person. Small temple, you get a view of the temple and as you climb up, you get a little view of the river and surrounding. Probably spent less than 30minutes here. Must comply with dress code. I had open toe sandals, but wore long pants and tee-shirt. Definitely no shorts! They have scarfs for rent.We took a cab from Wat Pho for roughly THB70. Some people took the boat from the pier near Wat Pho for much cheaper. BUT it was so confusing as to which boat to take and how much to pay, i felt much easier to take a cab. Always remember to ask them to run meter!

I already "award" it as a must-go destination before I depart to bangkok!. I will consider this as the MAIN LANDMARK of Bangkok or even for the whole Thailand! It is simply magnificent and significant! Even there are hundred of "Wat" in Bangkok, however for me I still find it very different from any other "wat" in Bangkok. Obviously It is among one of the oldest Wat, and that's why it is unique! Too bad that the sun was so fierce on me that day and I was not able to make it to the top of Wat Arun. When there is another chance in future, I will go Wat Arun at night time! Besides to stay away from the cruel sun, I eagerly wish that I can be given a chance to admire the beauty and mystery of great Wat Arun at night with lights on!!^.^* To respect the local religion, long pants or sarung please especially for ladies. :p

Well worth a visit!. This temple is very steep, therefore I'd recommend suitable clothing, i.e. not tight trousers. It is very steep, so be warned. The views are fantastic when you get up there however! (Coming down is quite scary!!!)

Nice View. Arrived by boat and first impression was it's small. It is a beautiful piece of architecture and the tiles are stunning. Climbing first lot of stairs is fine but beware the second lot of stairs they are very narrow and steep and don't look down until you get to top landing. It is worth the climb as the view is stunning and regret not going in late afternoon for sunset but probably would not have climbed the steep part of the stairs. Excellent photos taken but when I looked down the stairs I freaked out and took me a couple of minutes to get courage to get down. Definitely worth a visit.
AWESOME. Wow, no words can describe the view from the top. Only went up 1/2 way, but stunning views. At night time, it looks stunning with the lights.

made it halfway up. This wat is very beautiful, but if you have a fear of heights you may not make it up all the narrow, steep steps. I didn't butit was still worth the trip. There is also another wat adjacent to the property, but free to enter, which is also very beautiful. When I went in there was a Buddhist monk giving blessings. You can take a great picture of Wat Arun from the river ferry.
Well worth a Visit. Been here many times and always try to visit when in Bangkok. If you are going to climb up the 'stupa' where good shoes and be warned it's very steep. Particularly coming down.

nice place. The temple derives its name from the Hindu god Aruna,[1] often personified as the radiations of the rising sun. Wat Arun is among the best known of Thailand's landmarks and the first light of the morning reflects off the surface of the temple with pearly iridescence.[2] Although the temple had existed since at least the seventeenth century, its distinctive prang (spires) were built in the early nineteenth century during the reign of King Rama II.

Beautiful and panoramic view of Bangkok. Temple of Dawn was a great experience. We got there and the cost was fairly inexpensive. We took plenty of pictures from the ground, but I wanted to get higher. So I climbed up to the second level, which was quite a journey. The stairs are very steep, which is because climbing to the heavens is supposed to be a carefully measured task, so the monks need to do it slowly. I thought this was quite interesting. Definitely would recommend visiting and climbing up! Just be careful going down.

One of a kid. Beautiful sunset by the river! Looking over by the river when the sun is going down is absolutle superd and romantic..You can takea cab to wat poh and cross the small street and jumb into a bar nearby wgich id just across from the street. And see this fabolous view.

Beatiful Design, Not Much Else. The temple itself is very impressive in that it is a different style of architecture and is massive. You can also climb to about 2/3rds to the top via stairs, however be warned that the second level of stairs are extremely steep, virtually like a ladder. This is not for the faint of heart. Other than that, there are not many other attractions here. You also have to take a boat to get there, albeit the ride is less than 5 minutes and is very cheap (3 Baht I think).

Beautiful!. Take a taxi boat of any east coast pier to Wat Arun, which on the west shore of the Chao Phraya river. More details on boats: http://www.chaophrayaexpressboat.com/en/tourist/Beautiful, old, temple with very steep stairs (the climb is not suitable for the young and old). You will probably see monks walking around.You can buy snacks and use toilets near the temple.

Terrible experience. We wanted to visit wat arun temple and maeklong floating market. Took a tuk tuk which lead us to nowhere by an irresponsible driver.Took another tuktuk to some main entrance of the river which requires us to take boat to the 2 places.Extorted 1500bht each for my mate which includes a ride along the river including w only the 2 places.Boat driver dropped us off at the temple and said will wait us for 30min. Paid entrance fee to the place at 15bht, another entrance fee to the temple itself for 50bht.Nth much inside, came out and the boat was gone. Nobody to help us and we had to ask for directions to take a tuk tuk to leave the place.This clearly means the temple and anywhere else they claim boats are the only transport are FAKE.Felt totally ripped off and not worth the price at all even tho the temple is pretty.Terrible experience.Encourage tourists to take bts to the various piers for any boat rides.Btw, went on a tuesday 1st oct 2013, the water is terribly dirty as I believe there are floods.Water is in muddy colour with rooted trees floating along.Boats were of such low quality that I am more worried for my safety instead of enjoying the view.

Beautiful temple. A beautiful temple right next to the river. You could watch the busy river and the whole city on top of the temple. The only thing is that they charge 20 Baht for renting a long skirt while it is free at Wat Pho.

My favourite temple in Bangkok. Wat Arun took my breath away a little bit because of the steep climbing but mostly because of the magnificent view and peace I felt standing on the highest open plateau of the temple. The temple itself is magnificent, too. So many details to observe and admire. It is mostly adorned with pieces of glass and broken porcelain that Chinese boats used as ballast on their trips home after delivering their wares. I am glad I refused pushy tourist guides on the other side of the river (just accross Wat Arun is the Grand Palace) and took regular river ferry from the Pier located between the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. It was less than 5 minute ride.

Beautiful mosaic temple. Beautiful tall temple made out of glass and porcelain. Steep stairs made me nervous so i went only half way. A must see. The scenery is so gorgeous. Right on the river.The photos came out awesome.
A Stunning Temple!. The religious and historical significance of this site was awesome!The location was fantastic. There was nothing not to like.

Very Nice Place to visit. Very Nice place to visit.You can take the Chao Praya Boat for tourist (150 Baht per day, and you can hop on and hop off as many times as you want). I would recommend to do this so, during the night you can take a nice photo from the river.Entrance Fee is 50 Baht.The stairways are really difficult but you must try it....the issue is when you are going back...Actually if you are planning to go, please do it know because they are going to repair some parts of the temple during the next 3 years. So maybe, the pictures will not look so nice.

Central Stupas are closed. Visitors should be aware that the central monuments of Wat Arun have now closed for a three-year period of restoration. You can still walk around the perimeter of the inner compound and visit the outer buildings/grounds, but not climb the main stupa for the view. A 4m model is apparently planned to substitute, but I haven't seen it materialize yet.
One of the nice place to see. Wat arun was located at the river side and you can see the nice view of the River once you manage to climb up the steep staircase.

temple's excellent. This is a huge temple, that is a great sight to behold. which features a soaring 70-meter-high spire decorated with tiny pieces of colored glass and Chinese porcelain. I loved the history of the temple and the amazing decorations made from tile mosaic. The stairway to the top viewing level is not for the faint hearted but I managed to conquer my fear of heights and get up there to see a wonderful view

Great place - Must visit. Visited on 21st Sept. It is a good old stone structure, very impressive.There is a fee of around 200 Bht to visit Open only upto 5.30 pm in the evening, but the lighting starts from 6.30 pm and it is more impressive wih the lights on. Actually you can public boat on Chao Phraya river, get down at Pier Tha Tien, go to sleeping Buddha, walk to the palace and then come back, then pay 3Baht to cross the river and go to Wat Arun. There are around 70-80 steep steps to go upto mid way from where you can get a good view of Bangkok. It takes around 20 minutes to go up. For us Indians this climb was normal though I saw some westerners struggling. You can sit on the grass around and spend time.

Climbed Steepest stairs in my life..... the staircase are very very steep... I hav no prob climbing my way up .... when I wanted to come down.... I was having a height scare .... Ladies.... Pls make sure u wear your long pants n cover shoes... Pls avoid wearing long skirt,short skirt, short pants .... As u might step on ur own skirt while u climbing up o down.... U may wear sleeves tops... But pls be sure u bring along your scarf to cover your modesty to show respect.... If u forgot to bring 1 ,there's a shawl or scarf stall for rentals purpose too... Definitely recommend to go during sunset o sunrise... As the suns colors the temple n chao praya river with its goldens.....

Dahil sa' yo.... We saw this temple last time we went on a cruise. So amazing! We enjoyed much dinning during our cruise while hearing serenade and at the same time seeing lighted interesting historical temples...and mind you...you' ll never know this would be the first time you' ll be singing in public hahaha... The singer/ entertainer handed me the microphone and we sang " Dahil sa' yo..." What an experience! We will come back...

wonderful place. just across the chao phraya river on the other bank is the Wat Arun temple. The pagoda is excellently built and looks great both from far and near. the temple sculptures are quite fascinating. Only drawback is the extremely steep stairs leading to the top pier. Its quite adventures to go up these stairs, but while coming down its better to come down by facing the stairs rather than away from it, since it gives a better sense of control. Views from the top are quite impressive.
Great experience. We climbed up the main temple which was extremely steep so if you scared of heights do not go. It was worth it though.

Majestic!!. Giantttt .. Amazing.. you take a boat to get it.. and once you arrive your adventure will start.. you should have a brave heart so you can get to the top of this temple.it is huge with small stairs but an amazing experience. Must GO!There is also a place where you can wear the traditional Thai costumes and take photos.

Iconic and interesting. I loved the history of the temple and the amazing decorations made from tile mosaic. The stairway to the top viewing level is not for the faint hearted but I managed to conquer my fear of heights and get up there to see a wonderful view (tip for people who are scared of heights like me - come back down the stairs facing inwards). My Intrepid guide gave me some wonderful information about the history if the place. Really fascinating. Well worth a look!

UH-MAZING. I went here by a boat. Of course. Though when I saw the map (freely given by the hotel I was in a.k.a. Best Western Klassique Sukhumvit), Wat Arun can be reached overland. But it'll surely be longer.So, uh, as I said in the title. It's UH-MAZING. I mean, it's clearly beautiful. One great spot for taking pictures :)But be careful. I was here when it kinda rained so, it's slippery. And because I went here by boat, there's a time limit. If I'm not wrong, it's 45 minutes. So you gotta be fast.Ohoh, and the stairs are kinda high and narrow so, just be careful.

Great place. Worthwhile to visit!. We went there in a rainy day. It is not easy to get there, first you should arrive to the river (near the great palace) and take a ferry to the other side. The sights in the temple are great, but you should climb stairs that are really difficult and even they can be dangerous.But once you get there the views of Bangkok are nice even in a foggy and rainy day.

Don't miss out on this beautiful temple!!. A must visit especially if you are I the vicinity of the Royal Palace. To get to Wat Arun, walk 5 minutes to the pier and then take a 3 baht (yes that's three) ferry - each way - to Wat Arun to enjoy what I think is one of the best temples I have seen. I would suggest going there later in the evening - around 4pm and staying until the lights comes on at about 6:30 pm. This allows you to not be in the heat and burn up as you climb the very steep steps to the top of the temple. The crowd also seems to taper off by this time and so the photo opportunities get better, especially with the temple lit up. Another perk is that you also get to watch the Buddhist service that starts around 6p in the temple behind.

Don't fall off the mountain..... We visited the Temple of Dawn, Wat Arun, as part of a Canal Tour. There are other ways to get to this place, for example you can catch a water taxi. Our guide told is that this was the spot where the new capital of the old Siam was founded in the 18th Century by the King Taksin. He arrived there at dawn so he honoured the god of dawn, by building a Temple and calling it Wat Aruna, after him. The temple itself is very interesting. It is characterised by steeper steps than usually found in temples. As well as this it is quite a small site. The reliefs are intricately embellished with ceramic mosaics which creates a sense of fantasy about the place. There are monks who live on the site and who can be seen sitting and meditating under trees or just putting out the garbage. In keeping with the rest of tourist destinations, there are small souvenier stalls and opportunities where you can either put on a dancer's head dress and have you photo taken, or put your face in a cut out image of a dancer and have you photo taken. The money raised goes to help with the upkeep of the temple. There are also the river cat fish that come to be fed. They grow to an enormous size mainly because they are unpleasant to eat, so they just live in the river, entertain the tourists and earn their keep by generating income by eating the bread they buy from vendors for this purpose. This is a lovely place to visit. If you are on a spiritual journey and want to take the trouble, you can come here at Dawn, or even Sunset for that matter and meditate upon the state of the planet or the position of the sun in the sky. Otherwise it is quite a pleasant stop on a longer canal tour. It is important to get it that Bangkok is essentially a river city and doing a canal tour reveals the truth of this. Good for photos, take your camera. Bit risky for small children, older children will have your heart in your mouth because of the steepness of the stairs and because of the shallow depth of the steps. Real falling off the mountain territory.

Nice to see. This is worth seeing but dont need to allocate much time to it, once you have seen it and maybe taken some photos that it - can walk to top if you want but we didnt see the point and its not that high so cant imagine the view is anything special
Beautiful temple!. We took the small ferry to the other side to visit this temple. What a great place! Just be careful climbing to the stop as the stairs are very steep. Great place for photos!

my favorite. Easy access by water taxi or water bus. This temple is different from the traditional Thai temples. it looks more as a stupa. Entrance fee is very cheap. For this you can climb the main attractions (it is rather high and steep!). Not to miss if in Bangkok.

Best place ever to watch sunset!. Wat Arun is the best place ever to watch the beautiful sunset in the world! You should visit it around 4-5pm and then climb to its top to see the sunset from the other side of the river on the background. It is really adventurous and fantastic to climb up and down. Be careful of the slinny and high stairs! You should dress in a pleasingly tidy manner, bring some drinks and a camera – the most important thing to cacth marvellous moments of the day!
View from the old temple. If you wanna see a rustic view of the city from an old ancient lookout go to these temple. It's so amazing and carefully patterned with a bit of a hike.

superb. Simly stunning. read up before you go as you will appreciate the temple more. went in morning and evening, just so beautiful under lights. temple being closed next week for three years for renos etc, you will still be able to see from the outside.

SUPERB!. I saw a group of monks on the boat when crossed the river. Unfortunately we were not allowed to sit or stand near them esp. for women. Amazed by its culture also the Wat itself! Nice view from the top of the temple, a bit sunny but it's worth it. Be careful with the steps because it's very steep.

One of the best sights in Bangkok. While you have to cross the river to visit, make sure you take plenty of photos of Wat Arun from the boat or the other margin too. Outstanding site, climb if you have the energy under the troical heat.

an amazing palace but a bit of a leg burner on the stairs. The sheer size and construction of this temple is amazing from the river, let alone up close. Easy to get to by ferry.Be aware there are steps to climb this and they are not regulation steps we are used to in Australia. The steps are a lot taller and steeper (bit like climbing a ladder) and not for those who have fear of heights or leg injuries.If you are a little adventurous the climb to the highest level is worth it just for the view.

Conquered Wat Arun. From a far, I thought that it would be easy to climb the temple. But when I arrived at the temple, it was challenging! So when you are able to climb up to the temple and safely go down. Then you have conquered Wat Arun!
stunning. It really takes your breath away when you see the sun peeking over the top of the temple. Definitely not something that should be missed.

Watch your step. In a city full of Wats, this one stands apart. The stone steps are narrow, but if you hold on to the railing, you can ascend about one-third to the top. From there, you'll be rewarded with an up-close encounter with the Wat carvings as well as a panoramic view of the river and much of the city. Contrary to my expectations, getting down wasn't all that terrifying either.

Great view at night. It is great to climb the steps during the day for sure. Make sure you take something to cover your legs and shoulders. They rent to you here if you don't and take a deposit. BUT, take a look at it at night as well. It is lovely. And maybe you will time it just right with the monks chanting and a rain shower . .. magical!!!
Breathtaking day or night. Must see if you'er in Bangkok even for a day. Such a majestic site and so well maintained. Best place ever for photography.
Great views of city. Take your courage in both hands and climb the steep steps to the top level - the view of the city skyline across the river is worth it.

Exhilarating climb. By far the steepest set of stairs (verging on ladder) I had ever climbed. Upon reaching the top, we were rewarded with magnificent views of the city, but the real thrill was in the descent! If you have a fear of heights, prepare to confront it, or you'll be stranded atop this soaring temple for quite some time. We finally chose a backwards, one-foot-at-a-time retreat, gripping railings for dear life. Ok, it wasn't quite that bad, but it sure felt great to feel both feet on solid ground again. Worth the trip across the river for the close-up view of the intricately carved architecture, the view from the top, and the rush of adrenaline scaling the structure. Definitely our favorite wat in Bangkok.

Perfect Spot to Watch the Sunset. Wat Arun is one of the best places to watch the sunset (along the chao phraya river and the bangkok flyer for me). It's amazing to see the colors of the temple get more vibrant as the sun sets in the backdrop. You can easily reach it by crossing the river from Wat Pho by ferry which should not cost you more than a few baht. It's the perfect place to end a temple hopping day.

Beautiful Temple (Must Visit). via http://www.sagarsonker.com/travel/thailand/#placesOn my website, you will find links, photos, and up-to-date information as and how I remember it.This is a must visit if you're going to Bangkok for the first time. It was beautiful and worth it. It costs 50 Baht to enter the temple, and it's open from 8 AM to 6 PM daily.Climbing the stairs was dangerous, but an amazing experience. The view from top is amazing. Be careful while climbing down though.GETTING THERE: I thought it's difficult to get there, but it was pretty easy. Catch the BTS Skytrain (Silom Line) going towards Bang Wa (that's the name you'll see on the boards on the railway station). Get down at Saphan Taksin. Check out the exit towards the boat ferries (known as Sathorn boat ferry station at the Chao Phraya Tourist Boating Services), and take a ticket (costed me 40 Baht) to Wat Arun (which is the Station # 8) of the boat. There are proper boards, and announcements made in the ferries, so don't worry. Once you reach the Station # 8, which is actually known as Tha Tien. It's the opposite side of the temple. Then take a ferry to Wat Arun to cross the river (costed me 3 Baht), and there you are. Click on this ticket's photo on my website to open a higher resolution.Although it's a temple and I went there in shorts, I was not stopped by anybody, but it's always good to go there in decent dresses. It's very hot there, so wear accordingly.

Climb The Stairs If You Dare. Wat Arun is pretty in person than in the photos. I had no idea that you were able to climb up two set of steps (which get smaller the higher your go) to see a fantastic view of the Grand Palace and the Bangkok riverfront. My only problems was climbing back down...It is not for the faint of hearts but it was well worth it!

Climb the stairs....up close is unique!. Temple of the Dawn is decorated with porcelains from broken plates that travel the canals....truly unique and amazingly beautiful. Unless up close you would not see this feature. The temple complex is a nice place to relax and savor the river action.

Great views with an element of danger!. If this temple was in Europe, it would have a man in a high vis jacket with a clipboard and traffic cones telling you (with a nasally voice) that you can't go up there.Well this is Bangkok. And in Bangkok there's no bloke called Keith telling you what you can and can't do. Which is good when it comes to Wat Arun. The steep and potentially treacherous steps you have to climb are well worth it to get a view across the city. The detail and craftsmanship of the Temple are a sight to behold and I would recommend this brief little respite from the chaos of Bangkok to anybody who is visiting this mental city.

Vertical steps!. Do at the same time as Wat Pho and Grand Palace, use the river to get around, it's much quicker and cheaper! Wat Arun offers a great view of Bangkok, but take care on the steps up, they really are about a 1:2Just a shame there isn't more information in English about it. But still more than worth the trip.

Wat Arun the Temple of Dawn. Walk from Wat pho and take the boat from Tha Tien cross the river to Wat Arun the Temple of Dawn. From here you can climb up Phra Phrang the main building of this temple (very high slope) and see the view of Chao Phraya river, Grand Palace and Wat Pho.In the evening around 5.30 PM you can see the beautiful sun set from other side of the river with Wat Arun on the background.

Lovely!. My girlfriend and i saw Wat Arun on our trip through Bangkok In February. It was a hot day but we had a lot of fun. Climbing up the stairs definitely worth it if you're up for such Activity. Great views from the top I love the clink long all the bells around the courtyard.... So peaceful and lovely In this busy city. What definitely recommend to go see the temple of dawn if you have a half day for it. If you do it in the afternoon make sure to have drinks on the opposite side of the Chao Phraya River And take lots of sunset pictures of the temple. Amazing!

Boring Buddha, but breaking architecture. To start, sorry if I hurt some traditional views about Buddha followers.If you are visiting more than 2 cities in Thailand, you'll be soo saturated by Golden colored Buddha temples that, you'll deny going to any more of it!But this is good to visit for the architecture which stands out and this is gud place for some antiquie building photo shoot!

Steep stairs but great view. Got the cross ferry boat from the pier close to wat pho and the grand palace costing 6 baht each way. I thought the climb to half way up the temple was a scary experience until I had to go back down again! The views were lovely but it took me a while to pluck up the courage to get back down the steep stairs and I wasn't the only one. Also very tricky to do this gracefully in a long skirt without flashing people at the bottom of the stairs. I don't recommend the climb to anyone who has a fear of heights, but I definitely recommend doing to see this lovely temple.

a good climb. Loved the climb up to the top of the temple. It is a big of challenge, but I made it. The stairs are really really steep. Only those brave enough can climb to the top. A nice change from the spiritual temple experience.

You really need a good guide!!!. Don't go to the Wat Arun as well as any other Temples and palaces in Bangkok without the guide who:1. Studied the history of the subject2. Well spoken 3. Doesn't want you to jump to nearest jewelry shop to earn %4. Thai person proud to do his job.Otherwise you might miss the whole greatness of the Temple.

Beautiful old shrine. Very dramatic. We saw this as a stop off on a river boat ride, and it provide a good contrast to the style and temples elsewhere. Whilst it was bustling, it didn't have the throngs we found at the Royal Palace.
go up and look around for the details. climbing up the narrow stairs, the experience and the view. Try to do it towards the end of the day for great sunset photos.
Great views over Bangkok - worth climbing up to the top. A great, peaceful location to view Bangkok, and to take some time out from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Beautiful. After getting a cross river ferry for 10thb we arrived at Wat Arun. It's breathtaking, so big and yet so ornate. I walked around the grounds as my fiance climbed up to the top to take in the incredible views across the Chao Praya river and Bangkok. He did say that it wasn't an easy climb, very steep, very small steps that were more like a ladder in parts, but the view was worth it!

A golden lit temple. the only nice thing you'll see lit up at night in Bangkok really, though not open to go inside its lovely to admire at night, I had just arrived that morning and was hating Bangkok but this really changed my mind, this golden jewel showed me that amidst the dirt a ge can be hidden, you just need to seek it out

Wat Arun is Awesome!. 2MovingTheChi’s first wat visit was Wat Arun on the banks of the Chao Phraya river in Bangkok. Standing majestically over the water, this temple is a stunning vision of art and architecture. Two giant demons guard the entrance gate. Wat Arun is one of Bangkok’s most noted landmarks, its most revered temple, and the image that appears on the 10-baht coin of the Thai currency.It is called the Temple of Dawn. It was covered with colorful mosaics of porcelain, and embellished with sea shells, elephants, monkeys and mythical figures, as were the four smaller towers (prang or spires) surrounding it. The grounds were quite extensive, with multiple structures. The chanting of monks could be heard in one of the temples, while a craftsman was busy at work at the steps of another temple.The central prang offers excellent views of the old city of Bangkok, if you are up to ascending a steep climb. Climbing these steep, narrow stairs symbolizes the challenge Buddhists face reaching nirvana. Although you are only allowed to climb to the second of four levels, the steps were still enough of a challenge. Descending the steps can even be more unnerving than climbing them.If you’re in Bangkok, you have to visit Wat Arun.2MovingTheChi.com have been traveling since April. First in the U.S. and currently in Thailand. For additional photos and information on Wat Arun, visit 2MovingTheChi.com.

Go early!. I almost didn't do this temple, as I was on a really quick trip to Bangkok. But I decided I should check it out, and I'm so glad I did. I was there around 9 am, and got the temple almost to myself. It is so impressive, and very different from the other wats I saw in Bangkok. I did the climb (be careful, the steps are crazy steep) and got to see some great views from the river. As with everywhere else in Bangkok, the staff were very friendly, and took a lot of pride in their temple. It was a pleasure to visit.

Amazing!!. Is one of the most beautiful places in Bangkok!!! the mosaic in all the temple are a expression of art and religious symbol!!! You have to go to this place and is near to the Grand Palace and Big Buda Palace!!!

ALMOST A TEMPLE OF YAWNS. I visited on a Monday- avoiding the weekends. Still, the place was crowded. Not conducive for picture taking with other people hogging the scene ... you end up having unwanted strangers in your photos.The Temple of Dawn looks more impressive from the river as the boat comes in. Feeding the catfishes at the landing pier was more exciting than sighting or visiting the Temple.It has, for me, one redeeming grace. Outside the Temple are photo-stations where you can costume yourself in a traditional Thai outfit and have you mug shots done. No need to pay the entrance fee to get into the Temple of Dawn.Near these photo-taking stations is a black statue of an individual flanked by elephants. There is absolutely no signage to throw light on who or what is represented.I thought it was Peter Pan! But then, maybe it was Droopy. Who knows?The visit is often a hurried one. Your duration to drink in the sights depends on when your boat leaves. Buy your entrance ticket, explore the Temple ... then find yourself rushing to meet the deadline for the boat's departure.
Impressionable. The mosaic art work is fantastic and the meticulous way in which they place each piece of mosaic with so much love and patience

An amazing Temple tower that is a must see in Bangkok.. At only 3 baht to cross the river by ferry why would you not go over to see and climb this huge structure. The intricate detail of the whole thing is amazing. Righ down to the laced hand rail on the stairs. The view from the viewing level is fantastic. Yes the steps are steep but not that bad, go down backwards if you are not keen to look down frontwards as you decend.

Awesome Wat. This was probably my favorite wat I saw in Bangkok. It was fun to take the short boat ride over that was way cheap (3 baht), and it is very easy to find on the other side. At first I walked all around the outside of the wat that you didn't have to pay to go in and looked at the outside temples and statues which were themselves cool, but the obelisk in the center is the main attraction, of course, and it doesn't disappoint. You can climb all the way up to very near the top, although I wouldn't recommend this for anyone who is weak, either physically or constitutionally, as the stairs are steep and tiny and it's a long way down. But if you can make it to the top, you are in for a treat. You can see the whole river and all of Bangkok behind it. I took some choice photos of me and Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaeo, which you can see clearly from the top. The tower looks really cool as well, it has ornate designs all along it. It was an amazing trip up and well worth it.

Amazing architecture.... The place is accessible but we went there around noon time so it was so really hot and I got easily tired. One can enter for a minimal fee. And while the temple itself is really awesome, the steps are so steep so I did not manage to go up as I am quite acrophobic. One can really feel the solemnity of the place and I couldn't helped looking up everytime to immerse myself to its beauty. Worth a visit.

Magnificent place. Very famous temple to visit. Interesting as it is accessible by boat through the chao phraya river. Be sure to climb the stairs to the top as the view of the river is awesome from there.

Beautiful and historical. beautiful place when there in the day time. they had peddles there who sells things. you need to bargain with them as usual since it's a tourist attraction area therefore prices are hiked up.Would want to visit it at night if i could the next time.i visited in Aug 2012 ( the below dates didnt allow to to select Aug 2012)

I'm certainly going to re-visit this place. My visit was on a day that saw constant drizzling, hence I was unable to really make the most of it. The structure of this temple is awe inspiring, very clear from the proportions even in pictures. But when I saw it in real, it was fairly staggering. There are a lot of details on the walls including sculptures in various positions. For photography enthusiasts, there are many photo opportunities around here, specially over different times of the day as well as night, when the temple is illuminated. The steps are really steep and it was not helpful with the wet weather. I arrived by a boat which later also dropped me off on the other side near the Wat Pho. I intend to visit this fantastic temple again, hopefully sooner than later.

Good up close as well as from afar. I didn't get to see the temple all lit up at night which i was disappointed about, but during the day I would personally recommend taking the river taxi across to see it up close, From the river during the day it looks rather grey and bland compared to some of Bangkok's shinier temples, but if you pay 50baht to go in and see it up close you can see all the intricate details and colours. You can climb up 3 levels, but from the second level up the steps are very steep. You can get a good view of the river even from the first level, and can walk the circumference of the the temple.

I hope you like heights!. We liked this temple, it was different to any other we had been to (architecture) if you dont like heights then i advise not to climb the steep temple, there alot harder to climb down then up. it was 50bht each entry which wasnt too bad, appropriate clothing had to be warn like most temples in Thailand, all in all a great few hours spent here.

Old Bangkok feeling. love the site as well as the old Bangkok feeling, one of the only real sites to go in Bangkok with great old area around it.Hate the fact that tourists need to pay and that they made it like a small market and its annoying sometimes to go around there.

Spiritual. This site really evoked emotions in me, watched the sun setting over Chao Phraya and Bangkok from the top of the temple and for a second felt a connection with the history of this magnificent place. Keep in mind that climbing those stairs is easier than going down - especially if you have any fear of heights (I was almost panicking).

My favourite in bangkok. This is an amazing site and very cheap. It is spectacular from the river and close up. I went in the middle of a huge rain storm and got trapped under cover for 30 mins while thunder rated and lightening flashed and this location was even more astonishing in the rain. To get there you need to cross the river from the reclining buddha.

Great temple for views of Bangkok. Unlike most temples in Bangkok you can climb all over this one. The steps are very steep and it's hard work climbing them in the heat (it's even worse getting down!) but the views over the city and the river are well worth the effort.

just one statue. we've come here by boat across the Chao Praya river from Tha Tian Pier (we went to Wat Pho before).. it costs only 3 baht/person but you have to wait for the boat to arrived and get full.. this Wat is smaller than Wat Pho and Grand Palace.. it only has one building (statue) inside but we can climb it.. the stairs was so small and high that we feel like hiking.. if you're afraid of height, you better don't come upstairs..

Captivating Sight and View. Looking at it from the other side of the River you will be captivated by its simple Grandeur,especially at Dawn and in the Evening.Climbing up the Temple provides a great view of the activities and buildings along the RIVER.

Great climb, great view. Though my wife was ready to kill me when we got to the steep top, this temple is worth a visit and climb. It feels very unique and you get a great view of the city from the top. It is easy to cross the river to get there via water taxi.

you can't missed!. The best temple in Bangkok. The own location is simply perfect because you can see the Wat Arun from far to soar from the river.
Each weather conditions make Wat Arun unique, because a light and colour change a lot. The visit is adviced.

Well Worth It. So different to most of the other temples, it is well worth the effort to get across the river and climb up onto it. You get great views, and it is nice to really feel engaged with a temple, and not just have to walk around looking at stuff with your shoes off.

A most do while in Bangkok.. It's is cheap, beautiful and it has a great view from te top. Even if you can't climb the stairs, it is worth the visit there. You can take te boat to and from wat po for only 3 bath.

Interesting Temple. Bankok is blessed with Excelent sight seeing historical places o interest and this is certainly a must see. Please add it to your itinery, when we visited there were services going on which added to the spectacle.

scary!!. we thought we wouldn't go to Wat Arun but then decided we have come all this way so why not! and we are glad we did as it was quite fun and scary! My boys really loved going up the very very steep steps! My husband took us up one by one as it can be dangerous with young children..but definitely worth a visit.

Good Wat to start with. Good temple to start with but it is not the best. It is nice to take the ferry across and to see the Wat from the riverside. The steps up the Wat are incredibly steep and not for people who are scared of heights - also not ideal in flip flops. Once you've reached the top, there is a good view of the tops of the monasteries and the river. Wat Arun is a good introduction to temples and takes less than an hour to get around but if you are really short of time you should give it a miss. Entry is 50B.

Leaves you Breathless. Just close by the Reclining Buddha Temple, is the Temple of Dawn which can be reached through local boat. An excellent place with breathtaking views, if possible try and visit during night as well to catch the stunning night view. Carry enough water with you if you are visiting during day time and take along a good guide with you who can explain you the history.
One of the great icons of Bangkok. Suggest going early before the sun is directly overhead as there's lots of walking to do. A "must see" for anyone visiting Bangkok.

Great Wat to see. Go see this temple after seeing Wat Pho. You walk down the street and can catch a ferry across the river. The ferry is 3 baht per person. The wat itself is great. You can walk up the very steep stairs to the top and it's a fantastic view! Not as many tourists during the day. Entrance fee is 50 baht.

A must see early in the morning. Wat Arun is one of the great historical sights in Bangkok that is revered by the Thai people. It is a beautiful sight to be hold in the morning.A cautionary note... Scammers love to charge western tourists to enter, which in fact it should technically be free. To avoid the charges go around the temple side entrance early in the morning. You'll get in for free!
Night temple. One of the beautiful places ive visited in bangkok, you have to climb the steep stairways to see the panoramic view of Bangkok and uou can see also the Grand Palace of the King..
Magnificent. This is so amazing attraction, I'm just speechless.Very beautiful garden over there, and cocoa water is sold for 50 baht. You can get there by Chao Praya Express boat for 15 baht.

Beautiful Temple. Loved the temple more at night- so pretty. But also loved that we could clime halfway up during the day. Very steep and quite a thrilling visit- not really for young kids. Drink lots of water because you get quite hydrated quickly with all those steps. A must see I reckon.

Must see Historical site. Wat Arun is an imposing sight while coming up the river. My children had a wonderful time climbing up the steep stairs. The attractions were the architecture as such and the photographic opportunities standing on top.
Go in the morning (of course). Rent a private boat and include this temple in your tour,start early morning, the temple is more Beautiful then

One of the must visits in Bangkok. The ferry ride to reach the temple premise was awesome. The temple premise is maintained very clean and tidy. If one climbs the stairs to the top of the main temple, he/she will have a spectacular view of the Bangkok city arond the temple. From the top one can see the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, the monasteries around the temple and the beautiful river. Everyone who visits Bangkok should atleast visit this temple once.

Climb up for a closer look. You have to buy a ticket to explore this site for 50 Baht. This Royal Temple is dedicated to the 2nd reign of the Chakkri Dynasty. It is covered from top to bottom with a mosaic of items. This is not easy to climb but worth the effort. The breeze makes the numerous bells chime. At night this Wat is spectacularly lit.

Superb views and amazingly intricate. This is a must visit place if you are in Bangkok. It was a super hot day, so take your water and sun hat. The climb to the top can be a bit steep, but if you can, do go up, it is absolutely amazing.

Lovely to visit if this is your first time to Bangkok. Wat Arun, along with the Temple of the Reclining Buddha and the Grand Palace are must sees if this is your first time in Bangkok.
I recommend going early in the morning to fully appreciate it and to avoid the tourist crowds later in the day.
awesome temple. temple unique with Gold Buddah! and lovely views of China Town. it is interesting to have a tour guide to understand the Thai temple and different Buddah's history.
Amazed. Cheap ticket, only 50 baht when February 2012. But it's really hot there. Try to reavh each stairs of the statues. Creepy, but made me curious.

Peace and Solace in the mid of Bangkok. Wat Arun is a beautiful Buddhist temple and a must-visit for all tourists who come to Bangkok. Take a ride on the long tail boat, explore the concrete heights of Bangkok city and get surprised by the amazing architecture of Wat Arun.

truly great. a must see temple when visiting Bangkok.it is truly great, with magnificent views of Bangkok, only short cross river ferry from side on which other temples are located like Wat Pho or Wat Phra Keaw
must visit in Bangkok. it is a ancient,beautiful temple,you can take good pictures here. and can visit the grand Palace,Temple of the reclining Buddha at the same time. the river is full of story :)

Great sunset. Wat Arun, the most iconic temple of Bangkok almost opposite to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho.its full name 'Wat Arun Ratchawararam Ratchawaramahawihan' is rather hard to remember so it is often called 'Temple of Dawn.The stairs to reach a balcony on the main tower are quite steep, usually easier to climb up than to walk down, but the view from up there is really worth it. Despite its name, the Temple of Dawn looks amazing at sunset.

Jaw-dropping beauty!. Wat Arun, locally known as Wat Chaeng, is situated on the west (Thonburi) bank of the Chao Phraya River. It is believed that after fighting his way out of Ayutthaya, which was besigned by a Burmese army at the time, King Taksin arrived at this temple just as dawn was breaking. He later had the temple renovated and renamed it Wat Chaeng, the Temple of the Dawn.During his reign (Thonburi Period), Wat Chaeng was the chief temple, and it once enshrined the Emerald Buddha and another important Buddha image, the Phra Bang, both of which had been removed from Vientiane.For more Top 10 Things to Do in Thailand visit http://loopin.com/article/79

Beautiful temple. The temple is a work of art - because it consists of about one million small chinese porcelain particles, and thus gives a unique mosaic view. Especially recommended to visit the temple at sunrise or sunset .
Wat a treat!!!. Nothing can prepare you for how stunning this place is. DO NOT forget your camera. The culture and history is just magnificent. A must visit place when in Bangkok!!

Good workout. The steps to the top get progrssively steeper, the higher you climb. I have a knee problem and was contemplating on whether to go all the way up, when a group of 70+ years old tourists did just that. That decided it for me. Having said that climbing up is easier than getting down. It was a warm morning, so don't forget to carry a cap. It wasn't too crowded, with people leisurely taking in the monument. Definitely worth a visit
Nothing great.. Nothing great only good if you are looking to see a sunset from the top of the temple stairs. No buddha temple only somesmall statues at the bottom.
Very hot but beautiful and worth it!. Really enjoyed visiting the temple with a Thai friend who could tell me more about the temple. Just amazing to see!

Wat Arun. We have family trip going to Wat Arun. This temple is very good to visit and this temple is very unique.We have climbed Wat Arun, you can view the Chao Phraya River from Wat Arun.Value for visiting this Wat.
Amazing from within & outside. This was the best temple I visited in Bangkok. Its view dusing sunset from across the river is also breath-taking.
Nice piece of detailed architecture. Very nice building. Unfortunately very crowded all the time. The best way to visit is by boat as early as possible.

Wat Arun (Temple of the Dawn) Bangkok. One of the most beautiful temples I have ever seen, and certainly the most beautiful in Bangkok. The detail in the mosaics which make up the outer shells of the Chedis is astonishing.To get there, take the Chaopraya river ferry to the Tha Tien pier (Number 8) and hop off. Walk a few yards to the little cross-river ferry, pay your 2 or 3 baht and cross to the temple.There's a small admission fee (about 30 baht, if I recall) but the temple is FAR superior to the rip-off What Phra Keow on the opposite bank, which is now some 400+ baht for foreigners (but free to Thais).Take your camera. Best seen at dusk, despite the name!

Lovely!. This temple is on the West side of the Chao Phraya river, diagonally opposite the Grand Palace, and easily identified by it huge spire. One can climb to the top of the spire, from where there is a stunning view of the river and the grand palace and temples across. The climb up is very steep and tricky, but it is worth it. The climb down is jut as tricky! However, it is a beautiful temple to visit in Bangkok for an hour or two.
Awesome. Loved it but it's not for the faint of heart....the steps are extremely steep and narrow .....very detailed......built in the 17th century
Really nice and few people. Nice, clean and with few people visiting it.Take you time to enjoy the structure and architecture. Climbing the stairs could be more challenging that it looks.
Great views. Short river boat ride across the river. Think the entry fee was 50 baht. Great views of the river & the city from different levels. A very nice side sojourn.
Its a nice temple to visit. Do surely visit it, i have never seen such a beautiful temple before. The lighting in the evening is mind blowing.

MOST SEE IN BANGKOK. This is an attraction in Bangkok you have to visit. visiting the temple takes about 45 minutes and its very necessary to go up the stairs and see the beautiful view of the river and city of Bangkok.The stairs seems very hard to climb but do not be lazy!I think its very good to see the temple day and night but we took a LONG TAIL boat to see the river and the temples so we did it at day, but i think its good to see the Wat Arun at night too because of lighting.You can feed the fishes in river across the temple.(children will love it!)

Don't...look...down!. What an exciting place to scale. The steps are STEEEP! Don't go right to the top if you're a bit squeamish about heights. 50B entry per person well worth it! Definitely recommend taking the ferry from further north down river, especially at night when lit up to see the Wat looming over the Chao Phraya river.
A lovely temple. WOW! A beautiful temple across the river. Lots of monks and people were really friendly and helpful.

Stunning. We saw the temple of Dawn on various river boats, day and night. It is lot up at night and looks amazing.We then visited as part of a tour and after a tough climb, stairs are massive, the view is great. Not too busy as it is down the list after Grand Palace and maybe the stairs but people off. Be careful coming down.
Climb the stairs if you can. The main stupa has a very steep staircase to the upper levels. It's worth a climb to get a nice panoramic view of Bangkok.

Wonderous. First trip to Bangkok and one of the first things you notice on a river taxi is Wat Arun. Standing on the right bank of the Chao Phraya it is an impressive sight. The mistake most people make when arriving by express boat is to miss the correct landing. Alight from the river taxi at Tha Tian and pay your 3 baht to take another boat across to the temple. I can not explain in words how amazing this temple is ( all the temples actually) the work that as been ongoing for centuries is amazing. The setting on the river is superb, the people friendly. I was called over by a monk and blessed by him. I am an atheist and at first refused, but he still called me over. He blessed me and enhance my aura by sticking a piece of gold leaf to my forehead, then attaching a friendship bracelet to my wrist. This simple act made me feel quite uplifted so if a monk does call you over take the opportunity. I will not try to explain the architecture or views here as I can not do it justice. Just don't miss it!

Words Won't Do It Justice. I've seen quite a few temples in my travels to Thailand. In terms of look, Wat Arun was my personal favorite. It has such a powerful presence, standing tall while resting near the Chao Praya River. The view from the top of the temple was magical, countless photo ops to be had. Climbing down the stairs from the top of the temple can be a little challenging, especially if you are afraid of heights.

Worth the climb to the top. Nice view from the top of the temple. Stairs are steep and it is required to decent facing the stairs. Took a long tail boat from here around the canals where the local people live. Very interesting.

One of the best in bangkok. Went after lunch for a hour or so and really enjoyed it, great views by the river lots to see and do!
Would highly recommend to everyone.

Amazing Temple especially on sunsets. This is a must visit attraction if you visit Bangkok.A beautifully made Temple, a lot of details and ornaments and the color of it is amazing.A lot of crowd visit this famous temple everyday , but the best time to visit the temple is in the afternoon , when the sun is about to set.This made the Temple called 'Temple of the Dawn'.We suggest that you ride a ferry boat from the Saphan Taksin Pier ,which is accessible from the BTS.Cheap and pleasant ride , and you witness the beauty of the temple along your journey on the river.Advisable not to go here by Taxi or Tuk Tuk , its more expensive and will took a lot of your time, because it will stop on places you dont want, like fake gems shop, crappy tailors etc.And in fact, Bangkok is a congested city , traffic jams are all over.Wear your sport sneaker or your hiking boots.Be careful with the steep steps if you intend to climb the Wat Arun.Weather in Thailand, cannot be predicted these days , from sunny can become a stormy rain , so think about bringing umbrellas,hats or foldable thin raincoat.Bring adequate supply of water , because Bangkok sometimes amazingly hot !
Exhilarating.... Loved the climb up to the top pedestrian level. The views are quite spectacular for a flat city. Stop at each level to get a good perspective.
Amazing Temple. Amazing temple at riverside chao praya. Big and high, the second step of stairs are so steep. Nice river view from upside.

Went twice, once early in the am, and once in the afternoon.. This is a great temple to visit. There is a lot of detail in the temple, and while the climb up the stairs is ridiculously steep, it is worth the view if you are able to easily get up the steps!The first time I went to Wat Arun was super early to beat the crowd, I got there at 7 am, and nobody else was around; however, the sun wasn't up... This is something to be wary of if going during monsoon season. The temple was much prettier during the afternoon when the sun was out. So my recommendation is to try to see this temple when the sun is out & shining.Also, DO NOT TAKE A TUK TUK OR TAXI straight to this temple... It takes way too long. Instead have them drop you off at Wat Pho (reclining buddha), from wat pho there is a ferry near the market on the river where you can buy 2-3 baht to take a ferry across to Wat Arun, and then back again. This is much cheaper than taking a tuk tuk or taxi which might just drive you around longer than you need to get more $ anyways.My General Tips to Surviving Bangkok:-Taxi meter > tuk tuk! Tuk tuks generally try to give you a cheaper rate, but will drag you around to different places in Old town such as tourist agencies & suit shops, because they get free gas if you stay there long enough or buy something from the place. I only paid 40 baht for a 2.5 hour ride to a few sites, but also was brought to 3 places I didn’t want to go to, and was really annoyed. So while it is cheaper, it can also be a hassle if you are limited on time.-Always tell the taxi driver to turn on the meter.-Don’t shake hands with the people trying to sell you something, or the guys who say “Hey Brother” or are trying to get your attention. They know how Westerners operate, and are trying to have western behaviors to lure you in so they can pitch their sale to you.-Best way to avoid them is to say no, look straight ahead. Don’t waste your time or theirs.-When buying stuff, haggle haggle haggle, especially on Khao San road. You should never pay full price for anything they are selling in the markets.-Carry your wallet in your front pocket, or better yet get a money belt, or one that goes under your shirt and around your neck.-Do not argue or get in a very heated discussion with the tuk tuk drivers or taxi meters. While many are friendly there have been incidences or tourists being harmed & killed for not paying things as little as 50 baht. Sometimes it is just better to be “ripped off” and pay the guy what he wants, than to argue over it.-The earlier you get to the temples, the more quiet and cooler it will be.-Don’t open your mouth when on the river, that water is pretty gross, and a few drops landing in your mouth could make you sick.-Street food, restaurant food, drinks, silverware, cups, straws… They will most likely be contaminated at one point or another, and it isn’t because they don’t clean the items, but because many of the Thai people do not regularly wash their hands after using the bathroom, even in restaurants.-Bring antibiotics, buy them when you get there, and make sure you get your vaccines & shots you need to before coming.-Learn some Thai words before coming, like “I do not want” or “I will not go”

Stunning complex. An absolute must for a visit to Bangkok, design and visual impact are amazing, try to climb up the three levels to the top viewing balcony, views over bangkok are stunning even if a bit hairy getting up the very steep steps.
Interesting to see. I would read about it well before I go, our tour guide was absolutely useless and didn't give us enough history.

Brilliant!. This was one of my favourite attractions in Bangkok. It looks amazing from the river and it it worth paying to climb the structure. The steps do get very steep which is very nerve racking but you don't have to go all the way up if you don't want to. The detail on the structure itself was incredible. The ferry to get to the temple is very cheap (3 Baht each way). Worth a visit!

well worth a visit. Situated on the river more or less opposite the Palace, it has great views for the top, if you are brave enough to climb the very steep steps. the Khmer tower decoration and architecture is a great contrast to the Palace.

STEEP stairs to get a great view of Bangkok. Beautiful grounds, lots of buddhas to see. The stairs up the main temple are quite steep, not for those who are averse to heights. But there were sturdy handrails to help. The view from the platform was breathtaking. Definitely worth the 50baht entrance fee and the views of Bangkok.
Nice experience. This was a very nice experience. Just look out for the taxi's wanting to make a stop somewhere on the way to your destination.

Stunning construction. The best way to visit Wat Arun is to take the ferry across the river and it is a short walk from there. It is best to climb the steps but take care as it is steep, although there is handrail. Make sure you have camera or better still a video camera as the view is terrific. The river traffic is amazing and a wonder there are not boat accidents.

A must see. A must see experience well worth the trip and completes the Bangkok experience. There's not really any help for disabled people which really restricts access to the main sight but there are assistants around everywhere that seem more than willing to help. We were given free bottled water and fruit as it was a very hot day but free water is always available. We were warned to respect the religion by cornering shoulders and knees which we did but the locals were not to strict with this as my husband was welcomed in to the temple with his shorts. Altogether very worth seeing
A must to visit in Bangkok. Walk up the steep steps to the tower is good exercise. The area around the temple provides good scene for photo taking.

An air of calm in the madness of Bangkok. We arrived by boat and were charged 30tbh just for disembarking. Our boat driver only gave us 30mins but that is really all the time we needed. Entry was 50thb per person and women need have there legs covered. You can borrow clothing at the entrance for a small fee.The temple itself is small compared to other sights but very impressive. There are very steep stairs where you can climb to two levels with views over the river of the grand palace. An air of calm in the madness of Bangkok.
Awe-some!. Wat Arun is incredible - a must visit in Bangkok! The climb up & down the Wat is WOW! Haven't got much to say about it...except that go and see it for yourself!

Beautiful building!!!. It is an amazing building. When you get there and see it from a distance it is beautiful to look at, but when you get near and see it is covered with little pieces of porcelain, you get the idea that you are looking into something unique. Please climb up the stairs, even though they are kind of steep, to see the city from a different point.

classical and beautiful. had a chance to enjoy the beautiful scenery of this temple late afternoon with my dear friend. people already takes their seat along the river bank. great spot to view the sunset. the river is also clean and the air is not that humid. a great architecture not to be missed. one day, will climb this temple and enjoyed close experience.

Well worth seeing. I would say this is a must do for any first time visitor to Bangkok. Thai history is fantastic! The traffic was horrendous getting there but once we were there it was lovely. Not sure I'd take my kids there however as they are probably too young to appreciate it and it's not visually spectacular but very pretty. Teenagers would enjoy it I'm sure.

Good One. Compared to the grand palace, I think this one is better to visit, the ladder was really steep, but it is some unique temple, not just a mere stone, at least you got some new things to discover by seeing this, and sees bangkok from a higher point.It was unfortunate that I can't visit it at evening, people said it is beautiful at night
Beautiful broken porcelain Temple. Loved getting there by boat from just across the river! Did not walk up to the top but I'll bet the view were wonderful!
Climb the steps. The is right on the river across from the Grand Palace. Climb the steps for an amazing view, but be very careful coming down!

Overated. It is one of the oldest temple, but there is nothing really impressive apart from the nice pack where you can rest a little bit. There are more impressive temples like Wat Po where most Thai movies are filmed when it comes to temples.

Grand Buddhist temple....must see. Located on the banks of Chao Phraya river, this grand construction is one of the best Buddhist temples in the world. The entirely built of stone facade and steep steps leading to 4 platforms give it the iconic sight which this temple is famous for. The view of the river and the grand palace from the higher platforms are good. Definitely must see in Bangkok.

Pieces of porcelain,tight buns and superb river views. If the god -of- dawn is what you named your daughter,then this striking Bangkok landmark will strike a resonance with you. Its main prang is 79 m with acircumference of the base at 234m You will love the ornamentations created with broken pieces of porcelain. The style of this monument is Khmer architecture and its unique ,symbolizing Hindu-Buddhist cosmology. Climb the steep steps on the central prang and as you start to experience the tightening of calfs and knees,you may appreciate that this grade is as difficult as reaching higher levels of existence. You can climb halfway when restoration work allows. The degree of difficulty is high. Take your time and keep breathing. The four minor prangs are decorated with niches, inside of which are statues of Nayu,the god of wind ,on horseback. An interesting aside as you admire the colorful porcelain used to decorate the prangs was donated by local people. River views are best appreciated from the elevated levels of the prangs as well as from the river cruises and ferries on the River Chau Phraya.
worth the visit. becareful of tuk tuk which offer really cheap price , they will offer to take you to other sight seeing place before sending you to your destination
beautiful..nice. worth seeing, more personality and things to see...but after a while all temples look relatively the same
Beautiful temple. Beautiful temple, make sure to wear good shoes that are easy to slip on and off. Also stairs are quite steep!!

Awesome experience !. Must do once in bangkok. With amazing architecture you'll be amazed. Most interesting will be the stairs, very steep. So be carefull ! Also easy to access via crossing boat (3bath) one way if you are from grand palace. From the top of the temple u can take picture of grand palace.

A climbing experience. You should make this a part of a canal tour by boat and you can visit it by stoping by. You need to be ready to climb up a very steep stair to the top of the temple. This will give you a nice view across the old town.
Beautiful temple. It was our first temple and it's structure was just so eyecatching. Ladies make sure your shoulders and uper legs are covered or you won't get in!

nice experience. Just at walking distance from Wat Pho, the place is really beautiful. The surprise package was a 2 min boat trip across the river to the temple. The best time is to visit after sunset. A MUST GO.
Amazing views. Climb to the top for great views, especially at sunset. Like most religious be prepared to treat the Temple with respect and not just as a tourist attraction.

This is the Wat you must visit. The experience of getting here by the 5 minute public boat was something new. The Wat Arun itself is a beautiful temple and the steep climb is worth it! Even if you ditch the palace and other Wat's in Bangkok, this is the must see Wat. Once you get to the Tha Thien Pier it takes 3 Bhat by the ferry and 50 Bhat to enter. Many taxi drivers may not take you to the pier instead will take you to private piers which are very far away from the main place.Happened to us. So take a bus or just say Grand Palace. The Pier is next to it.

A lovely contrast to the Grand Palace. After visiting the Grand Palace, I didn't want to visit any more temples - but after doing a tour of the canals we decided to be dropped off at Wat Arun. Really pleased we did this - a beautiful temple and lovely and calm. Well worth a visit.

Saw from an distance - Looked nice. Wat Arun (วัดอรุณ), also known as the Temple of Dawn, is an iconic temple at the west bank of the Chao Phraya River. I took ferry from Pier (N9) Wat Pho after exiting Grand Palace. Direction : After exiting Grand Palace, turn left and then again turn left from the corner. After walking for some time from your 2nd left, ask for pier to Wat Arun, you will be sent to pier N9. At pier you need to take ticket at the counter (Baht 3, each way) Ferries take off about every 10 to 15 minutes and operate daily from 06:00 till about 22:00. Walking around the temple gardens and looking at it from a distance is free, but if you want to enter the temple compound and climb the steep stairs, it costs 50 baht. The temple grounds are opened from 07:30 till 17:30. Thousands of foreign tourists visit the temple everyday, many of them by canal tour early in the morning.As we were tired, we just saw the temple from outside and did not buy the ticket.
cool place. no public shelters and drinking water available , but yes a nice place to see and enjoy spiritual calmness.....a must visit alongwith wat pho

Amazing view from the top. An amazing temple covered with broken Chinese porcelain and seashells. The climb to the top was steep and looked to go on for ever but the view was worth it you can see a long way up and down the river. Can be busy at times it seems to be better earlier in the day.

A bit different. Loved this, was a contrast to the Grand Palace and the climb to the second level was well worth it. Just be prepared that the second lot of stairs are steep and uneven and whilst hard going up, are more difficult coming down. Abandon dignity and come down backwards if you don't like heights

Amazing place. It was an amazing and beUtifulnplace to visit,,,,one of the best places i had visited, its culture and history is really awesome. Aside from the preserved culture and history, the place in itself and the people are worth to see. The temples are well maintained and cery cleAn... Well organized tours, and it is one place that the government tourism takes care of the visitors, they are all very accomodating and helpful,,,and kind. Siem reap is a very clean city And very safe to move around,,,,i love this place soooo much,,that i wish to go back with my husband and take time to enjoy the place, its culture, and its foods....and to top it All,,,its not an expensive place to go....

watch at night but visit by day. Wat Arun - was built in XVIII century, as new kingdom was create (dawn of a new kingdom), more or less as BKK was established. Good to climb and see hole BKK - but be carefull - the higer You climb, the more dangerous it is :) You have to conquer yourself
Amazing architecture. Beautiful architecture! You can also rent a female Thai costume to have your picture taken by your friends. 100Baht.

Crowded. We arrived at about 11am and were swamped by the crowds. There were tour busses lining the streets and thoudands of tourists. be sure to cover up - no shorts or sleeveless tops - even for the men! Bit pricey too - 500 bhat. But absolutely beautiful.
