Visit to Wat Arun. We have been there with the family during the bangkok citytour. Great view, but not really a lot to see. Worth going there.
Beautiful, not to be missed. Despite loads and loads of visitors, the inspiring serenity of the area is not lost. Go there around sunset if you can - very atmospheric.

By the river. It´s a nice and a very diferent Buddhist temple. It´s a place for meditation, but there are so many people that is hard to believe . The decoration of the temple is made of porcelain ( china ) , dishes, saucers and so on. You get there by a boat taxi. It´s Worth seeing.

Ancient Treasure. One of Bangkok's most treasured temple.
Magnificient architectural design and unique finishes entailed to this ancient temple.
Unbelievable breath taking scenary when you climb up the stairs to the top, Great view
of the river. Best time to visit is in the morning.
Great views!. You have to travel over to the "West" side of the river to see this, but it has great views from the top level. But watch out for the super steep steps! :)

Steep to climb, pretty to watch. The area has a park where you can while away time as you rest after a long day of walking, with views of the temple of the dawn, the river, the pigeons, and all walks of people. I didn't dare climb, I didn't have a strength to go on.

Spectacular. we took a boat for the view of this majestic structure. also can be reached by road, but we preferred the ride by boat. it was enjoyed a lot by the kids. as they were tired we didn't go inside but gazed with amaze...leaving it for the next tour to bangkok.

This is my favorite. I simply love this temple - could be visiting it every day while in Bangkok. It is majestic how it stands even without too much glamour and glitter. The bone china decorations make it very special. It is extremely photogenic. No more words needed:)
A great view. You can climb this temple, it is very steep but worth it for the views of the river. We went late in the day after seeing the Grand Palace. It is worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Take the tourist ferry paying 150 TB for any of their ferries for the day to 10pm. Get on and off and one again as many times as you want. To get to the Watt take the cross ferry at a cost of 3BT. In great condition, you can climb up and really see how it was constructed and great views of the river from there.The area is really well kept.

Increadible!. Wat Arun is known as the Sunset Temple and really makes justice to it. Take a nice trip from Bangkok accross Chao Praya River from mid-afternoon onwards, have a walk around and wait for the sun to go down - and wait for it to take your breath away
gold and history. I loved the richness in history of the place . The architecture is amazing. I liked going to the grand palace, wat arun, wat pho .

Amongst the best temples in Bangkok. From amongst all the important temples in Bangkok, this was probably the smallest, but certainly the best. It was the least crowded, but the most interesting one as well. The temple's architecture was different from that of the others in that it allows you to climb up different levels through steep steps that are on all four sides of the main temple structure. The steps leading to the highest level are very steep so be prepared to climb up only if you are confident of getting down (which might be a bit more difficult). The views of the city on the other side of the river from the top was pretty nice. There isn't much more to do/see in this temple other than the climb, but it was an interesting change from the other temples.
Architecture at the best !. Wow , what a temple. amazing . we learnt a lot about ancient history , Buddha and many things. will be in memory for long time.

Beautiful views. Worth the visit. Try to go early, it gets really hot and the steep steps are scary enough without being light headed. Ladies, wear a skirt, long pants or sarong, otherwise you won't be allowed in. The views from the top are AMAZING.

Wat Arun means temple of rising Sun. Wat Arun is a unique architecture of an ancient sun temple. It has steep stairs which could be challenging for elderly and handicapped persons. It is on the bank of Chao Praya river and provides a beautiful view while navigating through the river in a boat or a cruise.

Easy to get to, take a climb up (don't look down). Easy to access via the river boats. A facinating climb up to the top, it is rather steep so if you don't like heights you should keep you eyes up and don't look down.Otherwise, a worthwhile visit and a nice view (also can get to a nice breeze on a very hot Bangkok day)

Wat Arun. It is a very steep climb, really challenging but you can hold on to the railings on both sides of the stairway up to the top. Bring along a marker or some stationery and write a few words about your trip when you get to the top as there is a banner hung on top. Will really be meaningful if you head back for a second visit and reminisce about your previous trip to Wat Arun :)

Spectacular. With only a few days in Bangkok and so many temples to see we chose Wat Arun. It is staggering in its beauty. At only 50 baht to enter it's a no brainer. If you suffer vertigo be careful about going down the steps from the top.....it is incredibly steep.It's a 3 baht trip by ferry from the wharf closest to the Reclining Buddha. My suggestion would be to go very early, see the Reclining Buddha first, walk to the wharf, catch the ferry then spend an hour or two here.

Very steep !. If you are the person who is afraid of heights.Be aware that Wat Arun is very steep!The view from the top was very nice, it has many step to get to the stop and very, very steep.But worth you a visit.Personally, it has not the appeal as the same of the others"Wat", but once you there in Bangkok with a tour guide, its ok to visit.We took a boat to get to the Wat Arun from the Grand Palace to Wat Arun. The traffic is horrible, so, don't go by car.

The world's greatest. Temple of dawn amazed us very much. How did they built this 200 years ago. Lots of work and lots of craftmen to built up this temple. The way to get up this temple is high and very steep yes it looks dangerous if you are not careful.

Its BEAUTIFUL. This Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) is beautiful. We took a boat ride to get to the temple. Its a temple complex with 1 big temple at the center. The detailing of the temple is beautiful.Try to climb the center temple, be careful its very steep, not for one who afraid of height, as the last set of stairs angled at 70-80 degree, but the view from up there is really nice.Definitely will come back again to see the temple at sunset time and night time.

Exhilarating climb to the top. Beautiful temple. It was an exhilarating climb to the top, and a great view of the river side. Stairs are very small and steep. You must be careful, because you may die from falling.

Nice. It was our first temple. Nice and quick visit. In front of the palace, across the river. Well located if you are grouping visits. When you visit Thailand, you will see a lot of temples, i will recommend this one.

If you are in Bangkok this is a must see. Very impressive and it's also interesting to better understand the Thai culture. There is quite a lot to see so you need at least 3 hours. The ticket is 100 Bath and includes a small bottle of water.

Beautiful Temple. In the land of many temples this is one of my favorite. Located on the river, this ancient temple is Just Stunning! The views over looking the Royal Palace are excellent not to mention the exquisite architecure. This is a must on anyone's list visiting BKK.
Great for pictures and to hang around. Great for pictures and to hang around. Usually monks are present and there is restaurant by the river.

Amazing view of Bangkok, not as crowded as Grand Palace. This was a very worthy stop. It's a 50 baht admission fee per person and is much less overrun by tourists than the Grand Palace. Climb the very dauntingly steep steps for an amazing view of Bangkok. Lots of fun!
Not a must see. an older temple with a stronger Buddhist connection that is still being used but perhaps if you are short of time not one to go to.

Dawn means Sunset!. The reddish color of sky will attract you to see this temple from the other side of the river.
Be carefull, It Looks dark in Rainy seasons. So if sky is clea, its really lik Dawn Temple.
Its just 5Km from "MIRTH SATHORN HOTEL _ BANGKOK"

Pretty place!. Loved all the porcelain flowers, loved the river trip I took to get there. I didn't climb as both my mum and I have bad joints, but many other tourists did and they enjoyed it a lot.
Tips: Bring your own long pants or long skirts if you do not want to rent.

Beautiful temple. a beautiful temple and a greast way to get there is with the river boats. Perfect for a nice day out. There is not much shade at the Wat Arun, so take your suntan lotion or an umbrella
Nice climb to the top... The climb up the steep stair was something i was looking forward to after seeing the photos of the temple and it did not disappoint me. Good view from the top :)

Great - must see. I liked the share size and specially how it decorated with porcelain and shells - see for you self. We arrived with boat and just that trip was magnificent - to sail across the busy river was a experience in its self.

A must see temple. Located on the Chao Praya river bank, the temple is easily reached via boat (3 mins from Tatien wharf located at the back of the Grand Palace) or by taxi, both are cheap forms of transport. However, be careful not to be cheated by taxi drivers. Be sure, the taxi is run by legitimate operator with meter. Entry to the temple is free for local, small entry fees are applied for overseas tourists. Dressed appropriately. No shorts - no thongs - no sleeveless tops. Display good manners and respect during your visit there. The temple was built to mark the beginning of the current Chakri dynasty. It is decorated with Chinese mosaic which looks absolutely stunning at sunset and sunrise, best viewed from the opposite side of the river bank where you board the boat. Visitors are allowed to climb to the top of the temple, but be warned, it is steep.
very challenging WAT to climb up. what i liked was that i had to take a ferry to cross the Chao Phraya River that reminded me my hometown in West Borneo.

Less Crowded, Very Pretty. Located across the river and accessible by ferry, this temple owned me. I climbed it, and fell down the 14 stairs at the top... It is a very pretty temple, not as big as the grand palace, but pretty and if you like/appreciate temples it is a must see.. Just watch the steps, they are skinny.. :)
Very nice place. This is a good place to visit if you like to visit temples in Bangkok. But the view from upstairs is not so great as one think.
AWESOME. An amazing must see in Bangkok you can get the train to central pier (day pass $130 bart) then a day pass($150bart) for the boat down the river and get on and off wherever you like

My Very Favorite Attraction in Bangkok. I thought Wat Arun was absolutely amazing. The detail of the carvings on the temple columns was breathtaking. I enjoyed climbing the steps to get a good view, but was very disappointed in the steepness of the second rung of steps. Decided not to climb all the way because of the seemingly impossible small steps to navigate. Many people climbed the highest steps, so if you don't have a fear of heights, I would think it would be well worth the adventure.

Nice view at night. i visit it at night while doing the Chao Phraya river cruise but could not enter inside the temple since it closes at 6pm but it looks beautiful from outside under all projected lights it looks as a glimmering star&you still can walk around it's garden it feels really calm & beautiful...
Beautiful and breezy. Go either for sunrise or sunset. It has wonderful views of the city (although be prepared to climb some steep stairs).
Must visit.. Not so over packed as Wat Pho, love the architecture, so many details and so many good spot for a photo shoot. entry fee about 50 bath.

CLIMB IT!. crowds were bad and took away from some of the beauty of the temple itself. You have to see this if you visit Bangkok. There is a steep climb which may make some nervous but would recommend doing it if you're not afraid of heights
special architecture like others. We had been there, but a part from it typical architecture, nothing special because it looked like others in the area. THere are lots of monks there to do charity
Amazing structure. A beautiful temple which allows visitors to climb upward on the outside. Be careful, the stairs are steep and there are no handrails, but worth the climb!
Impressive. Well worth the visit. I didn't do the climb as there were too many people but I enjoyed the site and the gardens.
Nice temple. It was the last of the "major" temples we went to in Bangkok Traimit, Phra Kaeo and Pho being the others. After those three Arun wasn't all that fancy, nice history though.

In the top five temples. We went in the morning. Good thing. Becomes very , very crowded as the day progresses. Make sure to not where a dress or skirt, you need to climb straight up to appreciate this temple. Worth the visit!

Beautiful,and a little challenging. The steps are steep and vertiginous. The view at sunset may not be it's intended moment, but is beautiful just the same. Lots of nooks, crannies and angles for taking pictures of the intricate carvings, statues and spires.

One of the better temples. It was interesting, a "must-do" since it's unique to Bangkok, Thailand, and one of the better temples there. But, not necessarily the most "exciting" thing to do (at least for me).

Beautifull temple. I was there in the rainy season so there was no point in going at dawn because it was cloudy. However the temple was still beautiful and was not filled with too many people. The stairs are steep and being someone who is afraid of heights, I only made it halfway to the top of the temple because the higher you go the steeper the stairs get. I do not recommend the temple if you are someone who has trouble with balance, walking, or a fear of heights. The view from the temple of the chao praya river is stunning. You can catch a boat from the temple and go to other sites like the grand palace for just a few baht.
NICE PLACE. Big place that have to be visited. May be the one you have tosee when landing on before try another historic place that make you understand the depth of traditions
Worth the visit!. Interesting experience and better go in the early morning to avoid the crowds. Great view over the river!

Definitely a great experience here. It's a scary, yet extremely fu experience climbing the Wat Arun temple. The staircase is the steepest I have ever seen. I'm still young old and could appreciate the cool, old architecture. Besides that, it isn't as pretty as Wat Pho or the Grand Palace, but still worth a visit.
Don't forget to climb to the top. Unique design and architecture. You approach it in a ferry from Pier N8 that costs 3B/person. Don't forget to climb to the top, it's a great view but be careful

Boring and very touristy. This is a rather boring touristy place. The views overlooking the river is pretty nice and I think that is why so many tourists come.I also took a boat tour on the canals on the western side of the river and visited two temples. Those were both living temples and so much more interesting.

Do the steps!. Great views from the top! Take a water taxi across from the Reclining Buda/Grand Palace side of the river for about 10 cents! Lots of photo opportunities at the bottom, but the climb to the top of Wat Arun is a must! Great views of the city and river.
Gat temple. Try to get there at dawn! It is fantastic! Its location is not very easy to get to, but it is worth especialy if you get there at the right time of day!

Amazing structure! Nice view... Great temple, something different than all the other Wat's in Bangkok. Nicely located next to the Chao Praya river. There are more places to overlook Bangkok, but nothing beats the view from an ancient temple. Cheap to cross the river by ferry from the city center, for only 3 baht pp.

Beautiful Wat, Amazing Views. Wat Arun is at the top of this list for a reason: it's amazing. The whole complex will take a few hours to see, but you only need to pay for the big temple. The use of colors and details is unlike anything I've seen before. Climbing the stairs to the top (including the really steep ones!) is well worth it for the panoramic views you get of the river, the wat, and the city. Just be sure to visit on a clear day!
unique Architectural. Love the place it is away from the crowd and the architectural of this temple is so unique. no restaurant in the area only Cafe bring your food.
Lovely..... Visited this place on our tour to the Grand Palace as a package tour and it's a lovely site to see. Recommend visiting this place when in Bangkok.

Fun! great views. It was a bit of a hike up to the view but the result was breath taking! There is a very convenient ferry boat ride you can take from about where the flower market was across the river to the temple. This isn't an all day event. Maybe an hour or so of sight seeing. Maybe more if you are a temple enthusiast. But overall I consider it a must see if in bangkok.
Experience Bangkok. Visit Wat Arun Temple with Chao Phraya River Tour. A good way to experience Bangkok. I have limited time at Wat Arun Temple but being able to walk in this area is mind blowing.
Amazing. Glad we made the effort, it is impressive. Very steep climb to the top but great views. Boat trip there and back a bonus too

Simply Beautiful. My second time to Wat Arun. I'm still amazed at how beautiful it is. Steps at the second level is very steep. However, the view overlooking the Mekong River is simply amazing. It's a very serene place. I went there around 5 in the evening and avoided the heat. Wat Arun is made of pieces of China. It's may not be as grand as Wat Phrakeow but somehow it has it's own charm. A must go place in Bangkok!
What no trousers!. Absolutely stunning temple, but make sure you're wearing trousers. We had to buy a pair (only 100 bahts) from store across the road.
Steep steps but worth it!. A great temple with a view! Hot and steep but worth the climb to see the bustling river below. Also lovely viewed from the river.
OuTSTANDING!. Go, See, Be inspired. If you have been to other temples and pagodas/stupas in SE Asia, this one will blow you away!
Impressive. We were fortunate to have guide "Tran" with us from Great Bangkok Travel Co. to explain history of this temple and its surroundings and significance to Thai people.

The best advanture. We stayed in Koasan road and walk out around the land mark. Wat Arun was on our lest, but I didn't expected it to be such thing.We corssed the river to the other bank and ported in the wrong spot, we walked and enjoyed eating what ever is on our face cuz it was lunch time, and we are lucky to meet all of these ppl who sell Thia pancake and fruits ...etc.However, Wat Arun has its own port, you may go for few Phats on the big ferry and pay attention to those who will miss lead you to buy a rid for higher price. Once you reach there, you may go for an adventure trying to climb on the most difficult stairs I have ever seen but don't worry you always have the option of getting massage.

loved it!. Took a long tail boat to Wat Arun and spent 40mins looking around. It was quite breathtaking and good to get a sense of Thailand and Bangkok other than the shops and street food. I didn't climb all the way but my partner did. The few steps I climbed were tricky, going down even trickier. I wish we had have had more time to dress up for the photos with my daughter.

The place is absolutely a must see while in bangkok. Visit at night if you can as you bypass the crowds. The only drawback at night is that you can't climb up it as it is fenced in. The detail on it is very nice. It was amazingly decorated with broken Chinese porcelain. The detail looks amazing (until you see the chedi at Wat Pol (sp). Again, best to see at night unless you want to climb it.
Nice temple. Lovely looking temple, but very steep steps and I'm afraid I don't like heights, so I only went up to the first level, but husband went right to the top and took some great photos.
Must-see. One of the must-see places in Bangkok.Together with the royal Palace, Wat Pho and the Floating market, Wat Arun gives you a good imprssion about Thai culture and tradition.

Beautiful temple. It is a very very beautiful temple considering there are lots lots of temples in Bangkok. The steps up the temple is very steep and probably not advised for older people. It is indeed a nice and wonderful place to visit if you have the energy to climb up the stairs. Each step is quite high and almost requires you to bend your knees. So you can imagine how high the steps are. We were amazed how they managed to build such a high temple! And also wonder the reason behind the high steps. Try to go all the way up and you will get to see a breath-taking view of the river and city.

Beautiful !!!. This is one of the most beautiful temples that I have visited so far.The peculiarity of this temple are the stairs which take you to the mid section where you can have a good view of the river and dont forget to write your name on the sheet of cloth tied around the temple at the top ;)Make sure to have a look at the temple from the other side of the river.

Beautiful. This temple is a definate must see!! It is simply beautiful.Do not miss the chance to climb up the steps of the temple to contemplate the views from above even though these steps can be a bit tricky to get down as they are very steep and narrow!!
Magic,. This place is everything it's hyped up to be! Before traveling to Bangkok I did a lot of research and Wat Arun was on my must do list!This really is something else. It is stunning!

Fascinating temple. Very interesting temple to visit although, unlike other temples, the highlight of this is the climb up the outside rather than the inside of the temple. Be aware that this a steep set of steps to climb so you should be comfortable doing this to get the best of the visit.

Different. This is a must in Bangkok! I visited the other temples that are pretty much more "golden", but Wat Arun will remind you more of ruins. You can climb the stairs (although the slope is really sharp) and see the other temples and the river from above, it is breath taking!!!
River View isspecial. Saw this lit up in the evening from our river dinner cruise.... lovely. will visit next time we're in Bangkok.

The Temple of Dawn. One word can best describe this location....AMAZING!!The Temple of Dawn ( Wat Arun ) is a must for every visitor to Bangkok.A short ferry ride across the river costing only a few Bhat and you are greeted by a majestic mosaic covered Temple reaching towards the heavens. Climb the narrow steps as far as possible and get a great view across the river and surrounding sites. For the serious and regular visitor to Krung Thep this is almost a place of pilgrimage.

Best sight i ever saw in thailand. In my opinion, wat arun or the temple of dawn is the best sight i ever saw in thailand during my many visits here in thailand. I think the view from the outside when you pass through Chao Phraya river is the most amazing sight of wat arun. Try to see it yourself and you judge by yourself.
Impresive, but check in advance its history. Also walk around and visit the minnor temples surrounding it, you will find a lot of amazing little details. If you are a phot fan even more.

Nice simple but impressive architecture, nice view across the river. The Temple of Dawn sits across the river from the Grand Palace and from the top you get a nice view of the Grand Palace, well worth the almost vertical climb to the top. (There are ropes along the steep stairs to help you to the top.The architecture is quite simple and, compared to the grand palace, understated, but it is still impressive, and perhaps a nice change from all the gold and sparkly bits.Well worth a visit!

Magnificent view. I'm not much for sightseeing, but Wat Arun was definitely spectacular. You can take the boat across the river from Tha Tien pier for 3 baht (one way) & admission to the temple is 50 baht. As mentioned by almost every other reviewer, the views are fantastic, the temple is magnificent.There are 4 stairways up the main pagoda, the first set up is pretty manageable. The 2nd set of stairs get steeper, so it might be daunting for some as it was almost a 180 degree upward (& downward) climb. As with most temples in Bangkok, you need to be respectful and cover legs and shoulders, rental of sarongs at the entrance of the temple can be done. Side note, best if you didn't climb up the pagoda in a skirt/dress, especially if you don't want your undies turning up in some other tourist's holiday photo. As mentioned earlier, the stairs is literally 180 degrees upwards and downwards.

Change my mind about Wat. When I visited the Temple (Wat in Thai) of Dawn, it has changed my mind about perspective and personal feeling about temple. The decoration is date back to decades where chinese porcelain is famous. You could also see statue of Chinese and (I think) Portugese soldiers in the area. The attraction is to go up on stair of stupa (about 60 degree) and enjoy the scene of Chao Praya River (please note I think it is the only temple in Thailand that allows lady to go up on the stupa, this is strongly prohibited elsewhere).

Fun to visit...for about 10 minutes. It's fun to hike the steep stairs and there is a great view of the city from the top, but overall it's not a place to spend 2-3 hours. Worth a short visit but don't expect much.

Well worth a visit. Opposite the Grand Palace on the other side if the chao praya river the temple of the dawn is very different to many Thai temples with the Stupa, which provides great views back over to the Palace, being the focal point of the complex.
don't miss its stunning view from the other side of the river. one of Bangkok's Landmark. one of the most beautiful temple in Thailand. don't miss its stunning view from the other side of the river

The Best Temple and an introduction into the real Bangkok. Cant say too much except this is special , I took my Dad here on his 80th birthday . This is the real Bangkok. The Temple is something special BUT you have to understand the incredible history of Bangkok to appreciate
trip on the river. nice trip on the river and special Temple with wonderful view over Bangkok, special construction with ceramic and special design

One of those things you have to do. Not really too much to it-spent maybe 15 minutes there. You walk around and go up some pretty steep stairs to get some nice views around the Wat. Looks like it could use a nice refurbishment-some of the colors are fading and there are lots of chipped places. It is pretty cheap to get in and just short river boat rive to get to.
A Must Visit. An easy visit by river ferry and one that you will use your camera on. The intricate details on the temple are fascinating.
just beautiful. is more beautiful from the opposite side of the river. Don't really need to visit the temple inside.

Spectacular temple. A definite must-see when you are in Bangkok. I regretted not climbing the steep stairways up the Temple, as the surrounding landscape surely will look awesome viewing from atop :(
I also missed the opportunity to visit it at night for its spectacular golden glow against the dark sky.

Temple of Dawn and klongs. Great location that you can link in with a longboat tour on Klongs. Magnificent structure in lovely grounds. If you only want to see a limited number of temples, this is a good one to see.

worth visiting. When you get to the top of the temple you'll have some nice views of the city. Climbing up and going down those steep stairs is adventure itself :) There was no admission fee.
Definitely worth visiting while in Bangkok.

Wow. Catch the ferry to varying different parts of Bangkok (there is a dock at the temple)Beautiful place but at all Thai temples that attract tourists be where of scams. Dont give personal details if you choose to fill in surveys (this information could save your life so don't be naive or cocky about it). Pick pocket gangs are rife around the tourist areas so use your street smarts and you will be fine.

Worth a quick trip across the river. This was our last sight stop during a recent trip to Thailand and we were still impressed, even after weeks of wat-ting around. The unique ceramic mosaic is cool to see but I really liked being able to climb up and get an elevated view of the city.I would recommend making the 15 baht trip across the river for this unique wat. Enjoy!

Fun climb. This was a fun little excursion for our family (mom, dad, and 2 kids, 12 and 6) our last morning in Bankgok - we took the river taxi from our hotel to the station across from the imposing Wat Arun, and then took the ferry (3 baht) across the river. The ride was a big part of the fun - our son got to chatting with a Buddhist monk from Tibet. Dad and the two kids climbed to the top, which was a challenge, because the steps are very steep. Wonderful spot for photos, and a must see in Bangkok.

It needs to be seen from the Chaopraya at night. Though we couldn't see it from the inside, it was the highlight of the evening cruise.The amazing lights just makes it a heavenly sight! Definately take the night cruise.

Amazing view of Bangkok. I was at Wat Arun a few hours ago for second time. The first time was in 2011. This Wat is the best in Bangkok for me and has an amazing Bangkok view. If you get on any public boat you should get off the boat at Tha Tien Pier, number 8, then you will cross the river for 3 baht with another boat to arrive in Wat Arun. Don't miss it, you will like it.
Different from the rest. I liked it alot and I would for sure go back anytime I was in bkk and Maybe one day when I do I will sit in the restaurant across the way called the dack

Another must see temple in Bangkok. An interesting sight from the water as well as in the premises. Go later in the day, it's not going to take you a whole hour so don't go at the hottest part of the day. Nice views if you are able to climb the very steep steps. Definitely worth visiting.

Beautiful temple, steep steps!. Lovely temple with views across the river back to the Grand Palace, and over the city. Nice porcelain pieces and ornate mini statues decorate the temple. It was very peaceful and slightly away from the hustle and bustle, but is very close/easy to get to - a very short boat ride (and only 3 baht) across the river from near the Grand Palace. The pier area is quite hidden, but what looks like stalls/street food/shop buildings is the way in. Have a look at a map beforehand and it'll be easy to find - and worth the effort! The steps are very steep - not for the faint hearted, but even just looking at the temple from the grounds is worth the small entry fee.

A good Silent place on river of Chaophraya. If you are a solitude lover, you must visit a few hours to temple of dawn or Arun, Arun is a sanskrit word meaning Sun same as in Thai, gives an Idea of Relation of Indo thailand in Past.The Temple of Dawn monastery is one of the most recognizable landmarks in Bangkok.
Night is different from the Day. Try the cruise down Chao Praya with lights casted on this temple. It feels so different from the day.

Stunning. You can't miss this. It's a marvel. Not just the temple itself but its surroundings. It's only 50 baht per person. Also be aware that women will be required to cover their shoulders and legs before they enter. If this is a problem, you can rent clothes for as little as 20 baht at the entrance (100 baht deposit).
Worth a short boat trip across the river. Nice experience. It was a fun experience. You can climb the steep stairs on the exterior of the temple for a great view of Bangkok.

Worth the climb - beware fear of heights. I tackled the climb of the stairs which are pretty steep and narrow. I am a big guy and made it up there dripping in sweat, but that's Bangkok. Loved the view and have some great photos as a trophy for the climb. The worst part if climbing down. NOT RECOMMENDED IF YOU FEAR HEIGHTS. I do not suffer from fear of heights but that got me nervous.
Visit at Dawn. When the weather is good, go early and enjoy the sunrise at the temple - breathtaking. After that, just sit and enjoy the simple local folks getting around

Wonderful place!. A beautiful place,another must-see/visit place when in Bangkok. Impressive details,wonder how they made this, went during sunset and the view is amazing from the top..stairs are steep so could be a challenge for some who are afraid of heights. It costs 50Baht to enter and it closes at 6pm. Worth a visit!!
Beautiful at day!! Spectacular at night!!!. Temple so intricate and the steps!! Whoa!! You'll get a kick climbing up until the third terrace. View is great.

peaceful and inspiring. certainly a place to visit, especially if through a nice and calm boat trip (trying to avoid the fast driving long tail boats). Opposite the temple, there is a very nice restaurant - The deck/ Arun residence - from which you can sip a glass of wine and enjoy the view of the Wat Arun at the sunset... Not to be missed

Like a stairway to the skies. A visit to Wat Arun was the last stop of our DIY temple tour. The temple is easily accessible via cross-river boat from Tha Tien pier, which is located near Wat Po (Temple of the Reclining Buddha). Boat fare is 3 Baht to and another 3 Baht from the Wat Arun. Entrance to the temple is just 50 Baht, and there is also another booth near the ticket booth where you can rent traditional Thai garb for 200 Baht and get your photo taken wearing it against the fabulous Wat Arun.The temple is just as glorious up close as it is from afar, probably even more so. Traditional chinaware were used as ornament for the temple, and you can even climb the steep stairs for a great view of the area. It can be tricky and scary going up and down these stairs as the steps are very narrow and the drop is very steep.

Amazing mosaic temple. A beautiful mosaic temple which you can climb. The stairs however are very steep and small so it's an adventure. The highest viewing area gives amazing site over the busy river and the Bangkok skyline. It costs 3 baht to cross the rive by ferry from Wat Pho, and 50baht to enter.

Amazing. The initial view from the river is amazing., then when you get closer the detail and beauty are incredible. It is quite a steep climb but the views are well worthwhile. You can see the hectic river traffic, the Royal Palace and the remarkable detail on the towers.

Fantastic place!. Beautiful place! Worth visiting especially during the night :beautifully illuminated and crowd free. We got there with small group, cycling on streets of Bangkok by night. Next day we came back with standard tour. I can tell, I loved night visit better. Must see in Bangkok!

Another temple. The different of this temple from another is the building were cover by ceramics. You can see all small pieces ceramics all over it. If you take the step to the higher level, you can see around the Bangkok City. but becareful when you step down as it's a bit scary. I don't suggest it for old people or who have problem with higher things or heart. Also, you can find cheap Bangkok t-shirt at the market behind the temple. It's cheaper here than other place so far I found. In front of the temple, you can find people rent thai traditional dress for photos with the temple as background. Nice try.
Stairs were a fright.. Very interesting place near the Grand Palace to visit, but if you have short legs, you will have trouble climbing up and down.

View and atmosphere was wonderful. This is an adventure, taking the ferry and then climbing the temple- and its a steep one! It gives you a fantastic view of the river area. The temple has ornate ceramic mosaic - some of which has weathered with age. it has a feeling of being untouched and in its original form. My only disappointment were the number of vendors trying to sell their wares. It seems impossible to go anywhere in Thailand without being accosted by vendors and it seems a pity that this has to take place in a spiritual place. By the way, we were ripped off getting across on the ferry. We were told we were paying for a return but then had to pay again at the other end. But then at a pitiful 3bhat it really didn't matter.

grand and majestic. it was massive. intricate carvings and colorful inlays..it was spectacular and majestic at night! a must see up close. i strongly suggest that you walk up there and wait til sunset and wat arun is lit up by the spotlights.

Wat arun just not good enough !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. Hello trip advisor people Today i see it is Wat Aruns turn for some unnessessary complaining/moaning by more tourists.We have people moaning about various situations ranging from having to pay 50 baht ticket froma ticket seller?? to the temple being tacky run down and crowded? too many tourists and bad location? The main source of complaining is having to pay these huge 50 baht fees to see an outstanding beautiful historical temple of thailand (wat arun) My heart bleeds for these people..how do they afford this huge 50 baht charge for boats, temples? Considering their flight probably cost anything from 30,000 to 50,000 why do theycomplain about paying a very cheap 50 baht to take transport or to enter a buidling or historicalarea?To be able to visit such a wonderful temple is in itself an honour, i think many people all over the world can only dream about visiting any part of thailand let alone the temple of dawn. Whydo so many people complain about something when there is nothing to complain about.Its no wonder that on occassion thai workers in the tourist trade sometimes get fed up with visitors.I think it is an insult to the great thai people when tourists complain and moan about50 baht fees when we all know that they can more than afford it.Stop and think one about what you are seeing, the temple of dawn is not something that was built a few years ago. This wonderous temple dates back to the 17th century and has so muchhistory following through its time.Some tourisst have complained about wat arun being too crowded, well what do they expect from a major tourist attraction in bangkok? Do certain farangs think they will arrive at the temple or any other tourist attraction in bangkok and be the only ones there?Can we not come back down to earth and be happy and honoured to see such historical and beautiful sites rather than search for something to complain about and ridicule?I read where one tourist had reviewed the wat arun as tacky, god only knows where they link tacky with wat arun. These sort of people obviously have no culture understanding education or forward thinking about travel.I think its a great insult to thais if they have to read about the varied rubbish that some tourisstdeem true about some thai sites, cultures, trips etcFor those tourists reading this about to embark on their thai travels around bangkok. take it from me and understand that the temple of dawn (wat arun) is a 100% must see wonderfulexciting cultural experiance which you need to enjoyOh for those who are worried about the HUGE 50 baht fees for certain thai sites boats etc stay at home and buy yourself a POT NOODLE and immerse yourself in its culture.Ok my trip advisor people talk soon spigs

Climb up it! A wonderful memory.. We decided to get our 'Absolute Bangkok' guide to take us to Wat Arun, though I'm sure it would be easy on your own too. There are other little bits to the temple area, not just the main temple. A beautiful gong - you can hit 3 times for luck, and a set of 5 bells you can ring. Beautiful gardens and paths with amazing "Dr. Seuss" trees, trimmed so they're little balls on curly sticks. Wonderful!The Temple of Dawn, Wat Arun, is a massive talk spire, but the lower levels have steep steps up the sides to about half way up. Its fantastic. Wear only sensible grippy shoes, no slaps or slippery sandals. Only go if your knees can take it. Take note of the direction most people are going. It's dangerous to go up when everyone else is coming down. Walk around the 'balcony' at the half way mark,....take your camera, but make sure you hang it round your neck, as you need both hands to ascend. And then up to the top for an astonishing view all the way over the river, and temples. Really interesting and unique.The temple itself is different to others in that it's ceramic...that is it's covered in ceramic plates and dishes for decoration, weird and eccentric...but totally beautiful. We loved it.

Beautiful temple. Take a quick ferry ride across the river from Wat Po and visit this temple. There are pieces of painted porcelain tiles set in the cement and you can climb the steps up two levels to get a great view of the city of Bangkok. The admission was only 50 baht.

Amazing. A must see in Bangkok. The best way to cross (coming from Wat Pho) is the pier beside it, you will come through an alleyway of small shops, not to worry lost of tourists and locals pass through, very safe, pay the old lady 3 Baht/person (to cross one way) and tour for as long as you like, just come back to the same spot you got dropped off and pay 3 Baht to cross back of take the fast long boat to the closest pier near your hotel (the long boat is way more expensive - about 200 - 300 Baht/person depending on how many people are in your group). Also take the river cruise at night and see the Temple at night i looks golden and just nice to view. Ladies please remember to cover your knees and shoulders when entering Buddhist temples. I just wore capris and a plain t-shirt.
Climb this temple for an incredible view of Bangkok. Wat Arun is definitely worth a stop in Bangkok. While the stairs are a bit precarious, the view from the top of the temple is fabulous!
Around Wat Arun. You will find interesting cafes and restaurants around Wat Arun, catered for tourists. Waiters have no problem speaking simple English.

Must Visit. The best place to visit in Thailand. But be very careful as you will have to take a Boat to cross the river. The Boat charges are 500 Bhat from the main Pier which includes 20 minutes at the Wat Arun and 40 Minuets round at the old Bangkok City through Canal however we ended up paying 800 Bhat per person as we did not know that. The main pier is just opposite to Grand Palace. Please do not listen to any taxi guy as they all will misguide you to earn some money. they talk very sweet but tell all lie to take you at different places. They will even say that the particular attraction is closed so you do not need to walk there and they will take you at different place in cheap price. Please do not listen to them.

Cheap and a Great Wat for Kids. Entrance is only 50 Baht for adults, the outer temple is beautiful and free, the inner part, the prangs, are great fun for the kids to climb, they loved it. Getting there by river and the views from this location, are highlights.

Beautiful. Beautiful and interesting temple complex with a fascinating history and wonderfully decorated. Will definitely need a tour guide (recommend private tour guide with Gift) and you should go early in the day to avoid the crowds.

Some fun across the river. After a 3B ferry across the river Wat Arun is fun to explore. You can climb up it which a bit scary but is a treat having a nice breeze and great view. We came back the next day at sunset to see it lit up from the other side of the river which was also nice.

Worth visiting..... Nice huge temple... only thing i hate is charges for Non-thai people.Colorful and worth visiting..... It will check your stamina and courage while going up and getting down the temple stairs... :)
Good. Good Art Work. Beautiful Place easy to reach from Wat Poh ( Reclining Buddha). Take a boat ride in 3 bhat only
Beautiful!. I absolutely loved Wat Arun - and the steep stairs are well worth the climb for the views and peace offered at the top!

A Cultural Treat. I commuted via train from my hotel towards the river pier then took the main boat, then took another small ferry towards the temple. I enjoyed watching all kinds of people from different countries flock on to this temple that looks like an outdoor sculpture for me. There were monks that guards that guard it as well as the surrounding areas. It's a sacred place & all people seems to treat it so.

Absolutely gorgeous!. This was an amazing place. Great views after a climb up "some stairs". Quick little ferry ride across the river. LOTS of tourists though...i think it was 50 baht to enter. No big deal. Cover up for the ladies required.

Nice to look at. Shame we went here when our legs were knackered and we were out of puff.Was beautiful from the outside but couldn't be bothered to go in and climb to the top, but I imagine it would be brilliant! The jetty over to the temples costs only 3 bhat which is good value, and when you cross the river, you are surrounded by lovely gardens and you can get dressed up as a Buddha and get your picture taken which is nice.
Wat Arun review. Easy access to get there from Wat Pho on the ferry - only 3 bhat. Nice views and intricate picturesque temple. Very steep to climb up especially to get to the 2nd level.

Nice view from the top. The temple is not as good as Grand Palace or Wat Pho. The main attraction here I think is the view from the top of the temple. But need to put an effort to get to the top of the temple. We have to climb up the stairs which are very steep and narrow, so it's not recommended for seniors and children. From the top we can see the Chao Praya River, parts of Grand Palace and buildings alongside the river.
So So. you have to pay extra 30 baht at jetty if you arrive by long boat. and only given 20 minutes to see the whole place.

Best temple in Bangkok. Temple is very beautiful from the river. A very steep climb will get you to the top. Watch out for all the scammers that hang around trying to sell stuff. Be especially carful of the wooden cut outs that you can put you head through and take pictures. A the very bottom in small print it says 40 baht and a lady will come out demanding the money. Women need to cover shoulders to access the temple. You can bring something to cover with, purchase something there, or rent something.
temple tour. beautiful temple not overcrowded. go to the morning tour not so hot. we had a. private tour so we had a tour guide to ourselves and learnt a lot

Fantastic. Awesome place to visit ... The mix of the old and the new will be a photographers delight! Beware of climbing up the Wat though as the steps are very, very steep ... but the view is definitely worth it! The climb is not recommended for young children ... Easy to get to but go early as it can be very hot, especially if you are going to climb the steps.

Awesome experience. There was a festival/holiday happening when we visited by water taxi - we hop out and there are dragons racing around and music playing and incense burning. We walked up the steep vertical stairs and really enjoyed the views and experience.

amazing. when you have had 2 hectic days in bangkok is is great to get up to this place. you feel like you are a million miles from bangkoks busy streets. my advice would be to buy a water before you go in and wear loose clothing and perhaps some comfy shoes as there is a fair bit of walking around. this is a must do!

Great views from the top. Beautiful temple, worth the steep climb up the stairs to see the views from the top. Be sure to dress appropriately, no short shorts or sleeveless tops for women. Otherwise, you will have to rent sarongs to cover up with.

Peace in the midst of chaos!. Loved it here. Easily accessible by the Chao Praya Express Boat. It's amazing how quiet it was here in the middle of Bangkok chaos! You're also able to climb areas of the wat, which gave amazing views! Must visit!

A must see when visiting Bangkok. The best way to see the temple is to use the Chao Phraya Tourist Boat which can be accessed from the BTS Skytrain Hau Lamphong station. You can use the boat all day for 150 Baht from 9.30am to 10pm and is a hop on - hop off service with most stops next to the main sights or in the case of Wat Arun, the pier where you can catch a ferry to the other side of the river for 3 Baht. The entrance fee for the temple is 50 Baht. By using this service we were lucky enough to visit the temple during the day where we walked around the grounds and climbed to the top for great views and then saw the temple at night from the river which looked even more spectacular lit up. A must see when visiting Bangkok.
A Feast for the Eyes and Spirit. Easy to get to via water taxi. Be sure and wear your runners to climb the steep steps of the temple.
Must see temple in Bangkok. Go over to the top!! The stairs are very steep but once you reached the top you'll know why this place is a must visit spot in Bangkok

Sparkling gem under the night sky!. I got the chance to view this temple from the board of the dinner cruise.The temple appears fantastic during sunset and especially when the lights are on, the golden glow looks spectacular from distance. It is very much adjacent to the Chaophraya river and is located on the west bank.

A tourist must in Bangkok. Wat Arun is a Buddhist temple (wat) in the Bangkok Yai district of Bangkok, on the Thonburi west bank of the Chao Phraya River. Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn, is named after Aruna, the Indian God of Dawn. Sitting majestically on the Thonburi side of the Chao Phraya River, the legendary Wat Arun is one of the most striking riverside landmarks of Thailand.You can get to the temple taking on the Chao Phraya River Express boats from any other pier, or take a taxi to it. The temple is open to the public daily from 8.30 a.m. to 5.30 p.m. The Admission Fee for this legendary monument is 30 baht for foreigners, while entry is free for Thai citizens.

Good place to visit. This is very close to the temple of the reclining Buddha. One can see both the places in one day. Try and start early in the day and cover both places in the same day. The temples close in the evening so ensure you have enough time on hand. It is about 30mins ride from Ashoke metro station ....

Stairway to Heaven. A must see and the stairs in the central prang are a definitely a must do, not only for the nice view of the city but because it is scarily fun to do it for the steepness of it..
Be ready for aching legs the following day...
Nice to look at. This was right by our hotel and it was nice to look. We walked to the top to see the view but actually were not very impressed. Better to look at than look out from!

beautiful at night. Wat Arun looks beautiful at night - we didnt actually visit the temple itself but seen it when we were on a dinner cruise - which we had enough time to go and visit because we definitely wanted too!

Extraordinary - and steep!. An incredible temple. Amazing porcelain mosaic work. The climb is steep and not for those with a fear of heights or bad knees, but absolutely worth it. Little girls will love trying out Thai princess costumes in the surrounding courtyards. A unique spot.

Amirable great wonder of the world. The entrance is decorated with porcelain flowers and guarded by two large statues of ogres. The temple is surrounded by a gallery in which are lined with statues of golden buddha sitting. Out through the south gate we come to Wat Arun. The prang is really beautiful, with all these colorful porcelain inlays and numerous statues. Top four niches contain statues of the god Indra riding Erawan (three-headed elephant). The four corners, four other smaller prang equally beautifully decorated and colorful house statues of the god of the moon on a white horse.

My favourite. In Bangkok Wat Arun temple complex is my favourite. I caught the 3 baht boat across the river to the immaculate grounds with the Wat towering above. The colour and workmanship of the cladding is amazing.I wasn't brave enough to climb the stairs as I knew that I would freeze with terror when I arrived at the top, however there was plenty to see from ground level.There is a nice little kiosk selling coffee and it was very pleasant to sit in the shade drinking an iced latte and marvel at the incredible sight before me.Please remember to have your upper arms covered and wear something to cover your knees, as I witnessed many people being stopped for being too skimpilydressed.
a new experience. We visit temples a lot. But Wat Arun was a revelation. Must see for all Indian tourists at least. Did some puja there. Similarities to hindu beliefs and pujas is striking.

Lotsa Wats, but this one is worth it. Wat Arun is unusual and draws far fewer visitors than many others. It's covered with bits of pottery and porcelain and is, like the taj mahal, as impressive up close with the finer details as it is from a distance. Climbing up the wat is not for the faint of heart or for acrophobes or for people less fit. Very enjoyable.
Beautiful view. It is worth climbing up this temple, though a bit dangerous. If you can physically make the climb do so, the view is excellent.

Worth the Climb. Visited Wat Arun on my 2nd day in Bangkok and it was an amazing experience. There is a fee but it is so minimal it's barely worth mentioning. Be prepared (if you're a lady) to have your shoulders and knees covered before entering the temple. You can also rent sarongs and scarves at the entrance if you prefer. Climbing to the top is worth it not just for the experience but also the views! Be prepared to take lots of pictures. The view is amazing, and incredible architecture of the temple is worth lots of close-ups. Enjoy!

top view. you should go there in the evening before sunset and waiting to see a nice beautiful sunset here:)and i suggest u take picture with thai giant here because that giant its so famous in thai history.

A spectacular place to visit. A must see. A beautiful and spiritual place. I found a school there which educates poor teenages in the study of nursing. It is called the School for the Development of Humanity. It's located in district 6 within the temple area. Hartonto is the headmaster. A great man, a fantastic mission. Make that school a stop and meet Hartonto.
Special temple very steep steps. Very special temple because of the Cambodian architecture. Climbing is relatively special. Descending even a little dangerous.

Must see. This is a very beautiful temple set against lovely Thai scenery. Get their early in the morning or later in the evening to avoid crowds and heat and if possibly take a night cruise to see it against night lights magical.

Just remarkable. Not to be missed.. Take the 10 cent ferry across the road from Wat Pho and climb the challenging stars for an inspiring view of Bangkok. I had wished for perhaps a better variety of touristy shops at the site, as I would have loved a Wat Arun t-shirt, but that's no slight against the site itself. For a $2 admission you'll come away with the sort of photos which make friends jealous.The ordination room, outside the compound was closed when I visited on a Sunday, but I saw a photo of it online and it's worth a look as well if you have the opportunity.
Beautiful Temple. If you visit Thailand, you must not missed this place. Very Beautiful.You can walk around and take river boat to visit other temple and market
Fabulous temple in Bangkok. Wel worth taking the time to find across the river. Great temple and lots of photo opportunities. Bit too many touts on the way but it's Asia!

Go early in the morning. Went very early. Before 0900. Arrived via long tail. Lovely tour. Not overrun with other tourists. Was able to have a nice look around and take some excellent pics. Like the other Thai tourist spots, this one has a lot of merchant selling tacky stuff and trying to get you to pose for photos, which they want to sell you. Still, glad I went. Memorable tour.

Beautiful temple worth a boatride. We really enjoyed the short boat ride over from the pier near Wat Pho, a walk around, a climb up part of the way- too high for me- and just being on the other side of the river looking back over to where we were spending most of our time. The mosaic decoration is very unusual and beautiful.Not to be missed.

Must see in BKK. This temple is unique compared to the other tourist spots in Bangkok. It's erected high above the ground along the river and will take you back to old Siam as you climb the steep stairs to reach the top. Take the 15 Baht river taxi up and down the Chao Praya to reach this wat and it's counterparts across the river. Admission is 50 Baht, be aware that it's a steep climb but worth it for the view of the city! It was one of my favorite to visit because it was unlike Wat Pho and The Grand Palace.

Beautiful Temple, but the climb not so beautiful!. The Temple is absolutely gorgeous... must visit. But the steps in the temple are ridiculously steep and makes it difficult to climb up or get back down.
You can also see the temple from the boat, there is not much to miss if you don't go into the premises. It's the building you need to see.
Lovely experience. The climb to the top of the pagoda is nice. I got my mala blessed here too and everyone was very nice and friendly :)

land mark of BKK. It's one of the land marks of Bangkok tourism. Need to ride a boat twice if you're staying in the eastern part of Bangkok. Worth a visit if visiting Bangkok for once, sun set might be better for cameras. The scale, structure, history of all temples in Thailand can't beat Myanmar! If you're willing to see the real culture of Buddhism, give a visit to Myanmar!! Myanmar is fantastic for the culture.

Loved the history. We visited Wat Arun (The Temple of Dawn) as part of a canal tour. It was a very impressive sight from the river. Although I didn't climb it (too steep), my partner did and was impressed by the views. You need to be suitably dressed to enter but if not, sarongs and scarves are available for hire at minimal cost (deposit refunded). I was particularly impressed with the history of the formation of the city of Bangkok, which was originally built with its back to the river. But they soon realised that the river could act as a 'moat' to protect the city from the invading enemies and moved across the river to set up the city. It is amazing that the temple wasn't razed by invading forces as in Ayutthaya. Just as well as it is a tourist spot well worth visiting.

best temple in bangkok. from the lying down buddha temple, go through a dry goods market to the dock on a short walk to take the very short ferry ride to get to this temple. Try going to this temple on a less sunny day as it is all outdoor. This temple is consisted of delicate, exotic and beautiful ceramic structures/sculptures. It is quite difficult to climb all the way to the top but the view from the top of the temple is very good.
Wat Arun. Nice temple. Much quieter since its on the other side of the river, so not flooded with the tourist hordes as much.

A "must see" in Bangkok. I think if you plan to visit Bangkok you must plan to visit Temple of Dawn either. It is located along the river so you can reach there by motor boats via the beautiful river which crosses the city. Its amazing architecture is fabulous. If you want to reach its top, you have to climb some long stairways with very sharp decline, so don't forget to wear suitable shoes. From the top you have the whole Bangkok under your feet, so don't forget to bring your camera, you can take so many wonderful photos up there.
nice temple - fun climbing up there. Impressive temple. nice view from the top! was fun climbing up the wat arun. make sure to wear long skirt/pants und sleeves - otherwise they dont let you enter!
A Must See and Climb. This is truly spectacular, and we'll worth a visit and a climb. I personally, prefer it to the Golden Buddha or the refining Buddha.

Very nice. I walk from khaosan road to here. Wat Arun is very nice place and a must visit in Bangkok. Please Becareful your step if you want to step up. and i would not recommend for old people to stepup.

Beautiful and different. Beautiful but too high for an acrophobe like me. Very different architecture and style from the other temples. I thought it was best viewed close up as the decorations are all different and fantastic.
Very high!. The view is just WOW! The stares are a little scary because the seem to be used often before! I can recommend this temple because it is allot diferent than the other temples.
Not to be missed. Quite extraordinary buildings and the level of work and gold leaf in the tiling is to be seen to be believed.

My favourite Wat. A really atmospheric place - and one of the most photogenic.
Excellent photo opportunity - go at night, just before sunset for the best views.
Marvelous Place. It is so high when you climb to top. but there is the most beautiful scene I have ever seen before.....btw, climb down is very scary.....
Great views, fewer crowds. Loved the amount of details and work that went into the temple and the other surrounding buildings. The view from the top is lovely.

What an awesome place. Visited Wat Arun at night. The place is absolutely a must see while in bangkok. Visit at night if you can as you bypass the crowds. The only drawback at night is that you can't climb up it as it is fenced in. The detail on it is very nice. It was amazingly decorated with broken Chinese porcelain. The detail looks amazing (until you see the chedi at Wat Pol (sp). Again, best to see at night unless you want to climb it. Please remember to not make much noise at night as the monks may be meditating.

Great Temple. One of the must see places in Bangkok - get ready to climb a few steep steps (if you can't climb then there is no need to buy a ticket to enter the place as there is nothing else to see).

Well worth the visit!. Anyone who knows anything about Bangkok knows you cannot have a trip without visiting the vast array of shrines and temples on offer. Most are within an hour of Bangkok by train and its the only way to travel there in my opinion. The train ride alone fills you with glee as the sights along the way are both fantastic and an eye opener!
Memorable Wat Arun. It is a beautiful structure worth visiting. It stands on a beautifully lawned garden and the compound is very clean.
Steep Steps to climb. Was good to visit. For elder people, the steps might be too steep to climb. Better to take a boat ride to this place and then to the palace.

amazing. Really amazing architecture and well located so easy to get to. I think we snuck in without buying a ticket so give that a try! If I'm remembering this temple correctly you can climb up it, which is a bit scary but worth the effort!

Beautiful temple - a must see when in Bangkok. One of my most favourite temples in Bangkok - I always bring friends and family who visit me here in Bangkok.
The area is lovely and green and after a steep climb to the top of the temple, you see fantastic views over the river and surrounding areas.
A must see if you are in Bangkok.

A Must Visit in Bangkok. Impressive!. A lovely Wat. It is nice to see the local peoples' piety.
It provides for good photo opportunities. Visit during the morning when it's cooler.

Must visit of the wats !. We started our local Bangkok visit from this using the klong service and were pleasant surprised. The climb to the top most level of the temple is worth it for the excellent views.
Very Cool. The geometric patterns of all the mosaics and sculptures are incredible. Quite a steep climb up to the top. A "must do" for any Bangkok visit.

An excellent set of various Temples in the same grounds. Wat Arun we found to be such a relaxing place to spend a good couple of hours exploring around the compounds. The ticket price we believe is very reasonable and there is so much to see and experience. The very steep steps one of the temples was well worth the climb as the view of the surrounding areas was perfect. Wat Arun always houses a number of cultural museums in its ground and the assortment of the antiquities were quite something to behold.There are plenty of areas for one to sit down and take in the grounds and gardens. Also there is a lovely place in one garden which has a refreshment stand which serves a great Iced Lemon Tea amide other assortments of refreshments and foods. Wat Arun we would thoroughly recommend it when visiting Bangkok.
Outstanding architecture. Absolutely a must if you're in Bangkok - remarkable architecture that has to be seen to be believed.
My third time here. Love this place...it is a great place to take amazing pictures and look great at night. I like to visit every time I am in Bangkok.

Great views and a temple with a difference. Right on the bank of the Chao Phraya river and across from the Grand Palace this Wat is build in a different style from most of the other temples you typically see in Thailand. You can climb 2 flights of fairly steep stairs to get some impressive views of the city.If you are at the grand palace it is just a short walk to the river where you can catch a ferry for 3 baht across the river and back. A great attraction to combine with a visit to the Grand Palace and the very nearby Wat Pho. If you get a chance to see it at sunrise or sunset it Wat Arun makes for some great photos!
Take the ferry to Arun, just 3 Bhat. Wat Arun has many interesting architectural features and a temple and school grounds for Buddhist monks
Loved it!. Loved the structure itself! Beautiful from afar! But so not expect much from this place, it's only a one tall edifice symbolizing great artwork of Thais.
Steep. A more ancient appearing temple. You can climb it to get some good views. Be careful though. The steps are STEEP almost vertical. Not for the feint hearted.

lovely old temple. not crowded with tourists which is nice, very steep steps to climb if you actually want to go up. I just took photos from the ground, too high for me. they provide sarongs if your inappropriately dressed

Our Visit to Wat ARUN in Bangkok. From Wat Pho Temple where Reclining Buddha in Gold, you must visit Wat Arun Temple of Dawn. Coming out of Wat Pho walk for 2 minutes and you will be at pier, catch local Boat by paying 3 baht one way for getting to opposite side, its very quick and convenient. Get out of boat and you are in premises of Wat Arun. It was very beautiful and peaceful. it's in the west side of Bangkok which is more calm and quite which was good after leaving the Grand Palace and Wat Pho, which were extremely busy. Once you get there it's incredibly beautiful! The closer you get, you see more and more details of this beautiful temple. Great place for pictures. you can Climb up the temple. The steps are steep and a little scary but its worth going up as view is beautiful from up. Beautiful ancient architecture ...the Temple stands out on the River. Worth the visit and must see in Bangkok. From Baiyoke Sky Hotel Taxi fare will be around 150 Baht and from Wat Pho you can take Bus No,.47 which will drop you to MBK Mall Area and from there you can take Baiyoke Suttle free service to Hotel.
Amazing place. Amazing by day, you need a head for heights, but go to the pier at night the temple lit up and reflected off the river is awesome

My favourite place in Bangkok! A must see and climb!. Brilliant value for money at just 50 baht - just over £1! Views at the top were incredible and architecture was amazing. Steps are quite steep so beware! I actually preferred it to the grand palace! Would highly recommend!

Dont miss Wat Arun..river boat was easiest way to travel there.. Not just another temple. Really was well worth the visit. As it is permitted, my partner climbed steep stairs right up high and got amazing views and sights..

Fascinating Temple. You can get a good view of this temple without entering the main grounds. However it is worth paying the100 baht to climb up the slightly scary steps for the wonderful view along the river.

Wat Arun, Bangkok, Thailand. There were advices from the websites say that it is best to avoid crowd in the morning and go there in the evening to see the lightings. So, it is depend on individual travel plan. As for us, we decided to visit Wat Arun upon arrival to join the crowd. So, we took the boat to the opposite and started walking. Enjoy the climbing and the scenery surrounding! It is worth to climb. And look down to see how steep the stairs are. The below picture shows how steep the stairs are. It has technique to get down and again, it depends on individual preferences to go down. On the left side of this picture shows the design of the motif found at the wall of this building. It is an unique design.

different. amazing temple. something different- not yellow or red. if you are afraid of hight don't even go there. some steps are really small. but the best place i visited. don't forget to take water if you are palning to visit it.

Details and Colors at Wat Arun. Decided to to visit Wat Arun in my last day in Bangkok. Took Chao Phraya Express boat to Tha Tien Pier, fell in love with some details and colors at Wat Arun. Definitely different with most of temples I've ever seen by far, beautiful, but becareful with all those steps, overall Wat Arun is worth to visit when you visit Bangkok. Feel free to visit Travelagys.blogspot.com for more photos and travel info in Bangkok. Happy to share and travel :)

Interesting temple but unpleasant greedy vibe around it.. The longboat you are travelling pulls up at the pier to deposit you - 30baht to disembark. Then buy a ticket from a very disgruntled ticket seller, then pay to use the toilet (another grim face collecting), and then you walk to the adjoining temple and need more baht for another ticket. We encountered more avaricious people today at Wat Arun than we have met in four previous visits to Thailand. The temple itself impressive but beware steep steps.

Formidable. Beautiful ancient architecture ...the Temple stands out on the River it is huge... Climbing up it makes you realise how high it is ...the view is stunning ...well worth the visit..a must see in Bangkok

Beautiful. Visited in May - go really early in the morning, otherwise it is stinking hot. Take some water with you. Beautiful area to photograph, but steps are a killer, the first set don't have a handrail and are quite steep and the height of the steps is tall. The second set of steps are ridiculous there is a rope handrail which you need to literally haul yourself up and the height of the steps are very very tall. Having said that well worth the effort - magnificent!!!!!
Love it. Beautiful, timeless, and awesome, with great views when you climb the central tower. Love the temple complexes of BKK.

An unexpected adrenaline rush. This is a relatively small Wat and can be toured quickly. We had read about the stairs and the climb but were still surprised by the steep pitch. It is worth the climb but only if you do not have a fear of heights. Even without a phobia it will likely have your heart pumping. It is amazing to think of those who built the temple and why those stairs are so steep! We are from the states where warning signs and guardrails are always there to "keep you safe". Well...nothing like that here. Enjoy and be careful - it is worth the climb.

Favorite temple!. Out of the many temples in Thailand, Wat Arun was definitely my favorite. It was very beautiful and PEACEFUL. it's in the west side of Bangkok which is more calm and quite which was good after leaving the Grand Palace which was extremely busy. It's approximately 50 cents to cross the river and its very quick and convenient. Once you get there it's incredibly beautiful! The closer you get, you see more and more details of this beautiful temple. Great place for pictures. What I found most exciting was that you can actually go up the temple. The steps are extremely steep and a little scary but its worth going up because the view is beautiful.

Wat Arun Review. Lovely temple and nice location.... river side, peaceful environment, looks marvelous in evening lights.good architecture to see. they have a park behind the temple (river side), good to roam around in the evening.Shoulders and Legs need to be covered while entering the Temple premise, so better avoid shorts/skirts or off-shoulder clothing else take scarfs/clothes on rent at the temple.Good place to visit.

Amazing view from the top. The views from the top are really good. However, the steps, particularly the last set, are a challenge. I left my camera bag with my wife and daughter and went up with just the camera. A big mistake! It was tough climbing up with a heavy camera hanging from the neck. I was really worried that it would bump against the wall. However, the effort was worth it. You forget everything once you reach the top. This is also a nice complex by the river and you can spend some time here. I was there late in the afternoon as I wanted a sunset view and wanted to photograph it in the evening. The sunset view wasn’t great as it became a bit cloudy. We crossed the river and there is a park next to the ferry station. You get a good view of the temple from the other side of the river.

Gorgeous Temple!. After being almost completely "templed out", I nearly didn't go to Wat Arun. I am so glad I did though. It is so different to the other temples in Bangkok and the location on the river is magical. I went in the evening right before it closed and was one of about half a dozen people there. It is well worth the trip across the river (3 baht for the ferry) and it is close to the Grand Palace if you want to visit before or after going there.The stairs are very steep, but the view from the top is worth it!

Another Temple. All of the temples in Bangkok are worth a visit, but they do become just like visiting Churches in Europe. This one was very different and worth climbing the stairs for the view over the river. It was 50 Baht to enter, and they don't let you in with skimpy clothing on. I got in with a short sleeve shirt and long shorts on without challenge.Easiest way is to get the BTS Skytrain to Saphan Taksin make your way to the water taxi and get the boat to stop 8, it should cost 15 baht. Beware of the people selling 40 baht express tickets, unless you are in a hurry. The Orange flagged boat is the one you are looking for.
Amazing temple. A must see temple!! Your in for a good workout to the top and bottom! the stairs have no slope so be careful! we'll worth the view!
Beautiful Khmer-style-building. The view from the top Chedi is stunning ! The details on the porcelain sculptures, and the Bot behind with the Buddha Gallery.

I nearly stayed there - not good for height phobics!. Fantastic site. Be aware that if you are not good with heights, the steps are pretty steep and scary - it took me a long time and a lot of coaxing to come down - going up was no problem.
worth a visit. very interesting place to visit as you have to go by a boat or a ferry across the river which in itself is a experience on it's own

Fantastic site to see. the view from the top was amazing, and walking around the grounds was a different experience. we caught a little ferry over to the other side of the river and that was also very good and quick. so many nice places to eat out there and was lovely to just walk around a look through the markets and shops.
Beautiful temple. A great place to take some sunset pictures from the river water taxi / ferry crossing. This golden temple really catches the glow of sunset on most days.

Beautiful. What a beautiful temple! Arriving by boat is so nice. The kids loved to climb all the steep stairs. I was a bit afraid that they would fall down ;-) I think it's not a good idea to come here with very small children. You have an amazing view from the temple.

Precious temple on the riverside. W booked a boat tour including the entrance to Wat Arun.It is a beautiful temple with great opportunities to take pictures. The offer tradiotional robes at the entrance that you can try on and take a picture with. Women should cover their shoulders and legs. The stairs to the top are VERY steep and dangerous, so sneakers instead of flip flops would be good or you just go up and down barefoot.
amazing place. go between 5/6 at dawn it s the best time to go it s just amazing, Also look for the tree that the flowers blossoms by clapping in your hands. An amazing place an amazing experience

Just.. fine.. I don't get to see the temple at dawn so maybe my review wasn't full comprehensive. We took the ferry (THB 1,5 one way) at afternoon, the temples are nice but not extravagant. The stairs are pretty steep, since we get there at low season there wasn't many people so it was fine, but it would be much troubles when it's crowded. Not much to see in the afternoon, to get the best of it, I suggest to follow the name, see the place at dawn.

Beautiful night view. we took the local ferry and crossed to it. It was very quiet when it gets dark. Not sure is becasue it was a sunday? We were alittle afraid, there seems to be no tourist police and the locals were staring at us in a strange way. We hurried took few pictures and took the ferry back.

A must see place in Bangkok. We were very impressed with the temple overall but if your not good with steps, many of which are pretty steep you will find it difficult to climb to the top of some of the temple spires, but even at ground level there is lots to see and many photo opportunities.Wear a hat and sun glasses as a lot of the temple is in the sun and it can get pretty hot walking round.There are places that sell the usual touristy souvenirs much of which we were not interested in.If you have time and your at the temple as its getting dark catch the ferry to the other side of the river and turn left there is a small park right on the rivers edge and you can get some nice pictures of Wat Arun lit up.

beautiful temple. i like this temple, we to climb up, which is very high and and difficult. if you have a phobia, better not climb up and stay on the ground. we have to pay, if i'm not mistaken about 50 or 100 baht. still worth it for the price, but we also have to pay for the boat, but is very cheap

Beautiful location, but annoying workers. I was thrilled to go visit this temple, though it was a bit difficult to get to on the overcrowded ferry.. It was beautiful and I would definitely recommend going- just watch out for unscrupulous workers (one tried to charge us for taking a photo in front of the cut outs near the water, after watching us take the photos without saying a word about payment)

Gorgeous grounds, but too many touts. As with a lot of Thailand, I was disappointed by the nonstop commercialism, materialism and sale of every type of good in every place, including temples. We did get some great photos here, but I would not return.

A must visit. If ever in Bangkok, this is definitely a place where you need to visit to just absorb the significance of these temples. Great architecture. Stock up on liquids as there is little or no shelter. Not recommended if you're afraid of heights. The steps to climb up are rather large steps and going up is easier than coming down.

Beautiful, unique, steep climb!. Lovely temple.
