Ferry to go over cost 3 baht pp (many scams operate including ones to take you on a 'fast boat tour' with an awful 'floating market'- not worth it) each way. A lot of the porcelain that decorates the temple is apparently leftover from chinese sailors that came to Bangkok years ago. The climb to the top is pretty steep, but you can get some nice views.

Good place to visit. We visited during the rain seasons so it was not as crowded as it would have been other days. Good to walk around, and i enjoyed being able to take the stairs up on the top of the temple and look out over the river and city.

Fond memories. Last visited the temple 20 years with my gf (now my wife). This trip was with my wife and extended families. The place was what we remembered and it brought back fond memories.
Hope the place will last for another few hundred years.

Beautiful temple. It is beautiful even in the day, and you would be even thrilled to see the steps up the temple! Probably not advised for older people, but it is indeed a nice and wonderful place to visit if you have the energy to climb up the stairs! Each step requires you to bend your knees to a 90 degrees angle. So you can imagine how high each steps are, isn't it. I was pretty amazed how they managed to build such a high temple, and I wonder the reason behind the high steps.. Beauty is worth a price afterall. Go all the way up and you will get to see a breath-taking view of the river and city.
Amazing, but best to see on the river. We got off and walked around, but to be honest you probably don't need to as you can't go inside. Just take some pictures and enjoy it on the river.
Daunting worth seeing and climbing.. An amazing and interesting Temple not to be missed. The architecture is incredible, how did they build these!

Worth the jump across the river!. Get on the west side of the river, and see this awesome temple. A breath of fresh air away from the crowds and madness on the other side of the river near the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Speaking of which, the Wat Arun offers top notch views of them, if you get to the top of the Wat. Yes, the stairs are as steep as you can get, but suck it up, grab the rails and pull yourself up to the top for the view. Gorgeous detail on the temple and at night, it glows like a gem.
Nice. Impressive temple. Beautyfull view in the evening or at night, fantastic illumination. Just too short working hours, as in many other places in Bangkok....

thrilling was to reach the top. situated next to chao phraya river ,this architectural marvel stands apart from the rest ,nestled between the landscape gardens the huge pagoda stands taller than u see in the pics.The fist stairs r easy to climb but the other stairs u need the courage as its too steep ,the prob is not abt going up but real thrill is while getting down.once up u get a good views of the river n the bangkok city.Near the gardens u get a chance to dress up in typical thai dresses which is worth a try.
Whacky temple. We loved the broken china covering, apparently ballast fro old ships. Well worth the climb for the views. Easy to reach by local river ferry

Best temple in Bangkok. After vising all the popular temples in Bangkok, we had some more time to pass so decided to come here. We found it to be the best temple that we had visited in Bangkok. It's easy to get to from the local port near the markets and only costs a few Baht for a quick boat crossing.From memory, it was 100 Baht entry each which is a reasonable price compared to the overpriced Grand Palace. Nice views from the top of the temple but the stairs aren't for anyone who is afraid of heights or not very good at climbing, they are very steep!

Good view and an unusual serenity at the top. Had to take a break halfway because the steep and narrow steps sure caused some anxiety in me. But I overcame fear and reached the top, and the view of Chao Praya River from there is rewarding. You can see the busy river traffic and yet, do not feel the urgent pace of things.

It is a great experience to climb.. Wat Arun is one of the places you have to visit in Bangkok, in spite that no everybody likes to climb stairs you will also enjoy the view from the ground. The steps are very short and you have to have good balance. I climbed as far as they allow you to; that is part of the adventure. People are very kind, nobody forces you to buy, they just offer what they make in order to survive, that is much better than begging or stealing...... The Temple is beautiful, looks like a big porcelain.

Lovely temple..... The stairs are a killer but worth it when you get up to the second level.... little hint... i found it easier to climb from the second level down backwards... like i was on a ladder, those stairs are steep..... :)))

OMG! The architecture is magnificent!. I love the place! You can climb all the way up and have the greatest view of Chao Phraya river. Bangkok is filled with temples but this one really the biggest representative of all. It's quite well-known so just take a taxi.

Great thing to do in Bangkok, I missed out half unforunately. Wat Arun and the climb of the stairs is a popular thing for tourists to do in Bangkok.I unfortunately missed out half of the climb because I climbed the first main set of stairs to the halfway mark and then chickened out and did not like the steep stairs from halfway leading to the very top. Lucky it was a sunny day with no rain otherwise the climb would be even more challenging. My partner on the other hand, climbed up once when i decided to stay at the halfway mark, and then climbed up again when i was down on ground taking a video of him.Overall, the building was very beautiful, if you cannot climb steep stairs or have leg injury, this is not for you.
Beautiful temple. Nice porcelain covered temple with amazing statues. It is possible to climb to 3/4 of the temple by stairs.

Good for photoshooting. You have to pay to enter and you are prohibited of wearing shorts. Upon climbing up the steep staircase, it was a real challengue. My knees hurts after getting down. On the way to Wat Arun by boat, some kids will forced you to buy his garlands and you have to pay for it which made me mad. It was like daylight robbery. Anyway, the surroundings is scenic and calm in the evening.

....definitely worth a visit when in Bangkok.... We arrived here via shuttle boat from the other side of the river and started our trip by feeding the giant catfish that inhabit the river. The architecture is stunning and there is so much to see and plenty of photo opportunities. Definitely worth the very steep climb to the top for the view of Bangkok and the river.
A must see even if you are templed out. Stunning building, reasonable entry fee and a great view of the city. Challenging climb though if you are a small kid.
nice trip with boat. i love to get that place with boat and i could see many things around and view tamples around. it was long journey by walk so tired and hot ;) but fun laaa.

An excellent place for sunset and views of the city. This was an amazing temple and worth visiting after I made it to the location with out getting ripped off. So first of all you will have to be careful how you get here. I was in the Tuk tuk and asked the driver that I want to visit Wat Arun. He took me to the end of one street by the river and a guy with a boat asked me for 1500 baht and said that it includes a ride in the boat for 30 minutes and then drop off to the temple across the river. I told him that I read on the internet that it takes 5 bahts to go across. He told me that there is no such thing and I can either swim across or forget about it. Even the guy at the Tuk Tuk that I hired for last 4 hours and treated very well told me that he is right and thats the only way to go across. I told them that never mind just drop me off somewhere else and i'll skip this temple. Because I had a feeling they were not telling me the truth. I found out later that the tuk tuk drivers get a kickback from these boat owners for bringing the tourists to them. Ideally I found the pier below the BTS station and paid 5 bhats to go across.

It is fine seeing it from a distance - if you don't have time.. After traveling through SE Asia for over 5 weeks and seeing many temples - I was expecting this one to be amazing. Honestly, in comparison to many others in Laos and Cambodia or Northern Thailand - it was just okay. The amount of tourist definitely affected the experience but more importantly there is just not much to see. It took me longer to cross the river by ferry than it did to climb the steep steps and look out over the city. However, I did enjoy the materials used to make the temple - the porcelain and sea shells were interesting and something I had not seen before. I still would recommend going but it is not a must see if you only have a day in the city.
Nice sightseeing location. Despite the dirty river water the wat arun is quite pretty and you will need to pay to enter the temple. Remember is kinda hot there!
Magical. Magical. The khmer-style tower (prang) is decorated with colourful porcelaines, which is something you won't see from the distance. As always, dress in a appropriate manner: it's a temple

Visit at night. This is my second time there, but the first time at night. The glistening gold and the intricate designs looks more amazing at night than in the day. And in the rain, it was really quite breathtaking.
Worth a Visit. A bit crowded but otherwise fine. Be careful as you approach, lots people trying to distract you, make a buck along the way.

Must see!. This was worth seeing. Temple of Dawn was so amazing and breath taking. Definitely should be at the top of your list!We arranged a private tour with Angie: + 66 8 1 397 6285 Very knowledgeable and friendly. Showed us around for the entire day for $10 USD! I wasn't sure at first, but she was recommended by a friend. I like going to places and having a guide who can speak proper English and really knows her stuff. Much easier than getting head phones or trying to read your travel guilde.

My favorite temple in Bangkok. Bangkok is filled with temples. Our trip was made more special by random strangers who shared their love of their Thai heritage and bits of history about the different places we went. Our helpful tuktuk driver said that among the temples listed in our itinerary, we should try and see the Wat Arun. We weren't disappointed. Its a pretty steep climb to the top, but the facade of this temple was worth the climb. The different porcelain dishes and painted exterior was truly worth seeing.
Beautiful site.. This was one of the best sites in Bangkok for us. Very beautiful and historic and really represents Thailand. Go check it out!

Beautiful. We took one of those rip off private boats on the river and stopped here for about 30 minutes.I have to say I wish we could've stayed longer, because this place was magical. Very unique tower. The towers were pretty tall and if you are older, this might be challenging to get to the top.

Pretty mosaic temple. Peaceful & pretty temple on the banks of the Chayo Praya RiverNote - after visiting the temple, go down to the wharf & hire a long tail boat that will take you around the back canals to view life on the waterways.

Major sight in Bangkok. this huge temple is a major sight and everyone drops by to see it. My advise, go see it first. why? because if you see the grand Palace first this one will look mediocre and that just would not be fair.Do not fall for the "take a canal cruise" scam. The days of the beautiful , quaint canal(klong)cruises are long gone. Instead get the cross rive ferry for 3 baht. save at least 997baht and get at least 250million fewer E.Coli in your mouth from long tail boat spray.

Little gem across the river. It costs 3 baht to cross the river by ferry and 50 baht per person to enter the temple. You can climb the really tall tower in the middle of the temple and get a scenic view across the river and the palace. (Very very steep climb, slippery when wet, hold onto the handrails)Takes less than an hour to visit, so definitely worth it if you are in the area.

A must see. If you are in Bangkok this is a must see. Very impressive and it's also interesting to better understand the Thai culture. There is quite a lot to see so you need at least 3 hours. The ticket is 100 Bath and includes a small bottle of water.

Beautiful Temple. This is a major sight in Bangkok, and is quite easy to get to by a cheap ferry across the river. The stairs are steep, but not too difficult and you get a great view of Bangkok from the top. Would you go to Paris and skip the Eiffel Tower? This is an amazing spot and well worth the trip.

A must see.. NEVER trust the taxi driver from the front of the hotel. A trip across the river is 3Bhat. They will try to get you onto a 1500Bhat "cruise". Take the ferry across wat po. Note: 1155 is the tourist police help line. They are very good.The temple has a bit of steep steps. Not too difficult. Takes 2-3 min to climb.The sunlight on the temple is like a million gems. Missed seeing it at sunrise. Well maybe next time!

One of my favourite places in Bangkok. Bangkok has many beautiful temples, but Wat Arun really stands out for me. One of the special features is that the prangs (towers) are decorated by seashells and bits of porcelain which had previously been used as ballast by boats coming to Bangkok from China. This exceptional surfaces yields beautiful reflections at sunrise or sunset. In addition, the views from Wat Arun over the Chao Phraya river and the royal palace are amazing.

Wat Arun. Like all the temples in Bangkok, this one too was so nicely maintained.. A nice and quick boat ride to cross the river from the Wat Pho side and you are at Wat Arun... the ancient architecture is truly well preserved.

Best views, amazing temples. Awesome experience to climb, although I had thought you could climb to the top - but stairs only go halfway (enough for most people). Amazing views, and just a great feeling to admire all the workmanship that went into building such a massive structure
Wat Arun, the other side of the river. Beautiful temple, and it is worth it to take the stairs - steep! and go up for the marvellous views over the river and the city.

Bring your climbing shoes. It costs 50 bhat to enter. We travelled via the river boat.Make sure you got good footwear as it is a bit of a climb to rech the top and the steps were very narrow.Really great view!

Absolutely stunning temple on the banks of the river. This Temple is really worth a look, especially if you are young and can climb all the way to the top. It is a stunning view of Bangkok. To get to the Temple of Dawn on your own, first make your way on the Skytrain to Siam. From there take the train to Saphan Taksin. Take the stairs down to the walkway to the pier. Do not get confused, just keep walking straight. Someone will help you if you look lost. Take a boat from here for 200 baht to Wat Arun. When you get to the Wat, you will be charged a 10 baht disembarking fee. The entrance fee to the temple grounds proper is 50 baht. Keep your ticket handy in case you want to go to the toilet or get a drink. For those not afraid of heights and who can manage the steep steps you will get one of the best views of Bangkok. For the rest of us you can take in the decorations of the temple. Here you will find porcelain that has been cut and used to make the decorative patterns. It is quite a delight. There are places to get drinks and buy typical kitsch. You might want to try on one of the costumes and pose in front of the temple. The young men and ladies will take your photo for you. On your return back you can catch a river boat to any other destination. To get back to the Central Pier it should not cost you more than 200 baht. If they try to get you to pay more just smile nicely and tell them you only paid 200 baht there. They will not argue with you and if you are lucky you will get your ride back on one of the very fast long tails! It is quite the ride (not for anyone nervous about fast boats though). This temple is also not for the very feeble. It is difficult to get in and out of the boats and you would only be able to see the lower levels of the temple. Also if you are temple hopping in Bangkok, ladies will need their shoulders covered and they will be needing to wear a skirt (and not a short one). Young men need long pants. There are always sarongs to rent while you are inside if you forget. Also easy on and off shoes are essential.

Expected more. There was an admission fee of 50baht per person. Not sure whether kids need to pay but I didn't pay for my daughter who is 6 years old and about 110cm. This attraction require you to be able to climb up stairs which are very steep. There were a total of 3 sections. My parents only managed the first section while I could only do the second section. Only my husband was able to climb to the third section which he says there's nothing much except for the scenary. Probably visit once is enough.
Bangkok Temple. Nice temple in the city. Very steep climbing up so you really had to hold the ropes and carefully climb down the those steep stairs.
Top temple. Beautiful, beautiful temple in lovely grounds right next to the river. You can get dropped off here at the end of a river cruise then hop back over the river for a few baht later.

Excellent piece of Work. Not to say much on this...It is very picturesque from the river itself and as you climb on the top, you would able to see the brilliant view of river and Bangkok with architectural work of Wat Arun itself...Covering a large area, it took us around 1 hr to visit the temple...I visited it in the noon time and I was told that the temple looks much more worth watching during early morning hours, so keep this as your first site to viewThe stairs in the main temple are too steep and not for everybody...its easy to step up but challenging to step down, so take precautions with kids and young children
Worth a look. The temple and surroundings offer something new/different, which is welcome if you've done a tour of a few. Climbing the steps provides a great view as well.
Amazing. Beautiful temple by the river. Maybe the most Beautiful in BKK? Well worth a visit, take the tour along the river and make a stop.

Not for Acrophobic (one who affraid of height). Wat means Temple. Wat Arun is a temple in Bangkok known for its height. I went there with a tour agency. We rode a long boat through a river to the temple. In the middle of the river you will be offered to buy bread to feed the fish in the river. It cost 20 Baht (70 cents USD). When you arrived at the temple you will see many souvenir booths. And you will also find a cardboard cutout of a Thai couple with traditional dress. It has two holes on the face of the thai couple. Nobody sits near the cardboard cutout, and you will be tempted to take photos with it.After you finish taking photos, somebody will suddenly appear and ask for money. It's not free, you know. They will ask you for 40 Baht (USD 1.5). It's small money, no big deal. But the way they trapped you what makes it not fair.After that you will see the Tower of Wat Arun in front of you. It is not that tall but quiet challenging. Because when you climb it with the stairs, as if you climb it with ladder. It is almost 90 degree angle. Piece of cake? Wait until you go down. It is more challenging compare to going up.I saw one tourist has to be accompanied by her friends to go down the stairs. She almost cried. By the time she reached the ground, she has to sit down and catch her breath for almost 20 minutes. it is obvious that she's an acrophobic.

Worth a visit. Climb up to 2nd level ( very steep, hv to hold rail with both hands when coming down, very much like climbing up Angkor Wat).Make me wonder if both sites shared sane designers, builders or what?Worh a visit when u r in Bangkok

One of my favorite places in BKK. I've been to Wat arun at least 10 times over the last 5 years (Living in BKK half the year makes that pretty easy of course...) . The view is so nice, the little steep climb up the stairs is fun,the great atmosphere,... My absolute favorite temple in Thailand. Tip: for a nice or romantic drink in the evening: go to the other side of the river, directly opposite Wat Arun and go to The Deck/Arun Residence. That's a bar on the 3th or 4th floor with an open view to the temple and the river. it's 120 baht for a small Singha beer, but on Khao san Road it's also not getting cheaper and over there you're sitting on a crappy little plastic chair with a view on drunk backpackers and streethawks.

Made me traumatized with stairs. There are not much to see at Wat Arun, as I have read in the net that there is nothing really special from Wat Arun when you see it from near.Not knowing what else to do, finally I decided to walk up the ladders to the top, it's a long trip to Wat Arun from south of Jakarta ;) so it would be a waste if I don't do what I can do there while I'm there...... STUPID stupid decision :D after finishing the 1st part of the stairs, which is quite high already... the second part is much worse, it's way more steeper and the steps are smaller, it's just about a span. To go up I have to hold both the railing left and right to make me more stable, at the top when my friend took my picture from below (smart girl, she doesn't want to go up :P ) I looked down (to face the camera of course), immediately regret came in to my mind and I was in frantic not knowing how to get down as it looked way steeper from up there then below, and getting down must be harder then going up.Finally after being dizzy looking down, I walked around the top of Wat Arun to calm myself too, the view is really great, you can see the Chao Phraya river, it's a pity I left my camera with my friend, so I can't show the view here, and the soft breeze is just great though the sun is still striking it's force. Ok... time to go down. With lips unstoppingly hushing prayers, I tried to go down holding both of the railing on my left and right facing down, besides being steep and only having small steps, the height for each steps is very high, when I stood up on one step I could feel the next upper step is on my behind.Finally when I reached at the bottom all I could say was "Thank you Lord, I arrived safely" while trying to catch my breaths back and tried to stand straight again with those wiggly feet. Seriously... that ‘incident’ made me traumatized with stairs for around 2 weeks.

get ready to climb. Great Wat to visit - very colourful and intricate.you get to climb to the top which is very steep and high (wear proper shoes ladies) but you get rewarded with an amazing view for your efforts

Fun experience . if u want to visit wat arun, i would say it is a must to climb up the very very steep staircase and you will get to enjoy the view of chao phraya river. But the challenging part is how to get down, saw a lot of people.hesitating, standing there strategizing how to get down. And I'm one of them.But overall, I would say it is a real dun experience I had
Simply Stunning. This is a wonderful attraction and a must see. Bangkok has so many fantastic attractions, but this has to top the list.

Wat Arun is worth for visit. Although getting here quite confusing, be careful with the "touris-ish boat" try to stop you from taking the normal boat. normal boat took for a while to reach Saphan Thaksin Central Pier and it's cheaper.

beautifull at sunset and sunrise. a very small site compared to the bigger temples etc but this is a must see. its alot more tranquil than the other sites and the extremely steep steps leading up to the top are worth doing just for the fun of it! its even more fun watching people go down.the veiws of the river and city are great and you find you can just sit and stare in relative peace :)
Worth a Visit. One of the impressive temples in Thailand. Climbed to the top, view spectacular. Worth taking in the history of the site.

The most beauitiful temple in Bangkok. Wat Arun is The most beauitiful temple in Bangkok being on the river overlooking the Royal Palace.Many tourists do not bother to go but is often the most peaceful place in this busy city -especially the Paklace which is always crowded

Beautiful.... If this is your first time to Bangkok, then this is a must. Do take the main boat and pay on the boat, Baht15 per trip. If you pay at the counter its Baht40. Then take the boat for Baht 3.00 to cross over to Wat Arun. Entrance fee: Baht 50Ladies do wear long pants/trousers/jeans or long skirt (not the flair ones). For, as you climb the steep steps, especially when its windy, you need to keep the flair skirts from riding up while you hold the steep handrail.Lots of pictures to take outside the temple. Do bring a shawl if you are wearing sleeveless blouses. Men Tshirt with sleeves & long pants/jeans..

Beautiful and steep steps. Beautiful riverside temple named after Aruna, the Indian God of Dawn. We visited in May 2013, arriving by the private boat, and paid boat fee in addition to 50 baht per person entry fee charged to foreigners. It may be better idea to get there by taking a ferry that crosses the river for 3 baht per person from Wat Phra Kaew, at the corner of the Grand Palace.For a small donation sit with Buddhist priest and he will recite you a prayer and tie knotted prayer bracelet (not sure how to name it). The towers (prang) are decorated with meticulous porcelain mosaics; the central prang architecture symbolizes center of the Buddhist universe, Mount Meru, as I read. While you climbing (careful, very STEEP) steps you are reaching different base which each symbolizes different level of thirty-three heavens. It also gives a nice view of the Chao Phraya river.We were there at around mid-day, and it was very, very, hot. Even with strong sunscreen my face burned, so I suggest wearing a hat at minimum as an additional protection, and have some water as well.

Interesting climb ;). Liked - The journey across the river on the boat. Fruits and petty shopping at the pier. The magnificent structure. Views of the city from the top. Details on the temple building. Climb up the main temple. Dislike - People disregarding the 'no smoking' message in the temple premises. One was allowed to smoke at the resting area, but people took liberty and went beyond the resting area which can be not so pleasant for some.
Beautifule. Great site in bangkok, Closed Chaophraya RiverYou can see by boat at the chaophaya river, On the nIght you can see a spotlight to the pagoda

Ancient and Amazing. We enjoying climbing the steep stairs of the temple - the exercise was better than the view. Very different experience and even kids enjoyed doing it. There are lot of shops near by but they are way over-priced.
Beautiful. Been to Bangkok many times but never had time to walk up the Wat Arun before for the view, definitely worth it
Nice Architecture. Beautiful architecture, nice view.Danger to walk up and down the tower, yet nice view and good feeling up there,
Nice place. It was a nice place but very hote. Have to bring your glasses, umbrella and cap. But if you buy souvenirs there it was cheap. Cheaper than other places. Don't forget to bargain also

Nice old temple in Khmer style. This is a quite large temple complex with a large Pang in the middle. If you master the steep steps you're rewarded with a nice view on he river, the royal palace and Bangkok's skyline. Don't miss right take some time for the mosaics that cover the towers. they are made up from glass, porcelain and some other stones. Interesting!

Heaven in Bangkok. One beautiful and unique ancient Buddhist temple in Bangkok. It is different from other temples visited in Bangkok. The temple is made of ceramics collages. It is best to visit around sundown and the temple is lit up. You can get there by boat and / or ferry depending where you are on Chao Phraya River. Personally, I think is is the most beautiful temple in Bangkok.A must visit!
Amazing!. Just Amazing and nice and peacful. It's great to see at dwan and at sunset. Great from the river boat too.
Just another temple. Its an average temple, nice to see but not so special. Its rather busy most of the time.You can take the boat to it to visit.

Be careful on the STEEP steps!. A quick 3 baht boat ride across the river from Wat Pho was a nice quick visit to Wat Arun. Entrance fee was a cheap 50 baht and the Temple wasn't over crowded which was a nice change of pace for Bangkok! We went as far up the temple as we could and were surprised at the steepness of the stairs leading to the top! The view from the top was nice where we were able to get some good pictures.

Beautiful. Beautiful temple, our guide told us the colorful decoration of seashells and bits of porcelain had previously been used as ballast by boats coming to Bangkok from China. It is amazing and quite stunning from the river as well as on the actual site of the temple, worth the visit.
most see. well this is a most do if you stay in Bangkok. in the evening sit in the bar just beside were you get off the boat across from here. when they turn on the lights it looks fantastic.

A very beautiful temple, especially at night. Wat Arun is probably one of the prettiest temples I went to during my time in Bangkok (I stayed for 3 days). I went at night, which was particularly awesome. The temple takes on a whole new look and since it's right next to the river a pleasant breeze is almost always blowing. If you have an hour to spare at nighttime this is definitely the time to go see Wat Arun!

Check it out. One of the top (i.e., busiest) places to see in BKK. It's a crowded place but the sights are beautiful and it is nice to take your time walking around all of the areas they Wat Arun has. I've only gone in the AM but I heard sunsets there are nice, too.

Don't Trip Up!. Beautiful Wat, easy to get to and quite cheap too.Nice temple grounds and felt more secluded due to its location on the other side of the river from where we stayed.VERY steep steps up and down. when we visited, we were lucky enough to have it start raining too, making it even more difficult to navigate. be very careful!!Definitely worth spending a couple of hours here and make it one of the items on your "Thailand Temple" list.
If you love history, you will love Wat Arun. This place is beautiful, the level of cleanliness is high.I guessed every worshipping place, should maintain their cleanliness like this place.

Fun Temple to Visit and Explore. This temple was a little more fun than some of the others because you get to climb on it. The views of the city are awesome from above. It is a little steep so coming down was a little shaky if you are not well hydrated. We took a water taxi across from the back side of the Grand Palace that cost about 3 baht. I would definitely see it while there.

Worth the trip, unique temple to visit. This temple is unique because you can climb up very steep stairs to near the top (maybe 2/3's up?) and walk around to see a lot of Bangkok. It costs either 50 or 100 baht (I forget, sorry!) which I think is sort of a lot for the short time it takes to see the sights, though is still worth it at least once! It is right on the river. You can go to Wat Po, then hop on the ferry for 6 baht or so and go straight over to Wat Arun in no time =)

Top of the list. This Wat was so beautiful. The steps straight up to the sky were unnerving but it was magnificent. You can see this lit up at night as well from one of the many roof top bars. I loved this Wat and remembered it above all that we saw.
Great view. Great place to visit--only 50THB. You have to climb up the steps for the best views! Be prepared to sweat however as it is really hot this time of the year.
boring. save yourself time and effort, it's a tacky tourist site that is not worth the visit. Watch out for the river trips as well, they are just a ploy to get you to the market

What a run(Wat Arun) is right name for this temple. We decided to go here as it is the top attraction in Bangkok, but what a disappointment. Very run down and the name is appropriate for this place Wat Arun (What a Run) down temple. Buddha's in desperate need of repair/painting. Walls peeling, roof needing repaired, The steps are in poor condition and it all needs repairing. What are the people who run this doing with all that Bhat they make ? Not really worth the visit and the price is either 50 Bhat or 100 Bhat depending on how busy it is. Don't get caught like most of the other tourists who get asked to pay 40 bhat for a single trip. Get the express boat (local Ferry) with the orange flag it only cost 15 Bhat a single trip and its 3 bhat per person for the ferry crossing from pier 8.

Bangkok. Temple Tour and Elephant ride were amazing. Far ride but worth it. City Tour took us to the Train Market-not something you would see in the US. The Golden Buddha, Reclining Buddha and the Grand Palace. Floating market was another sight. It was all wonderful

a refreshing view of the city and the river. Climbing up to the temple is not that easy as it is steep but the view of the city and the river makes all the effort worth it plus the sunset is beautiful from the temples

One of the 3 must visit temples in bangkok. Unique design and architecture. You approach it in a ferry from Pier N8 that costs 3B/person. Don't forget to climb to the top, it's a great view but be careful

Climb to the Top. This is an amazing site. Although it is best appreciated while on the Chao Phraya Express boat, it is worth the time to actually walk around. You have to take a separate ferry to cross the river. Take a chance and take the stairs to the top. It's tough climbing, but the view of the city is worth the effort. Be careful coming down. It's steep!

Stunning!. My only regret with regard to Wat Arun was that I did not get to visit at sunrise. Nevertheless, it remains one of the most stunning and camera-ready places in Bangkok. It rises above the Chao Phrya River and immediately captures your attention. The entrance fee, as I recall, was 50 baht for farang (foreigners), and the visit was well worth it. As others have noted, the steep climb up rewards you with great views of Bangkok. The first step down, though, is dizzying enough to cause one to question his balance! When seen up close, the detail apparent in the construction of the temple is amazing. Highly recommended.

Very huge and fantastic temple. The gold sleeping buddha is amazing and the whole place is very huge. You need to pay a few hundred Baht for entrance fee. Nothing disliked, this is a place worth to visit if you are not visit before.

Peace!. Visited the temple after the Grand Palace-Wat Phra Kaew tour. Took the ferry for just 3 bahts each way. There's an entry fee too (100 bahts i think), and since had paid 500 bahts for the previous temple, decided to skip it though later thought should have entered as the view from the top would had been amazing! But enjoyed the views nevertheless.The Chao Phraya river and the entire area is very peaceful, not crowded like Wat Phra Kaew. There's another temple in the same complex, for which no fee is required and is very beautiful and relaxing and you can spend sometime there. Coudn't visit at dusk though i guess it'll be a totally different experience! Have some mango with sticky rice from the stalls on the opposite side and enjoy the view!

Get your Climb On!. You pay a fewt you go across the river where then walk to the temple. The walk up the temple is a little bit freaky but what a sight! The temple is beautiful too and you can take some great photos here. WAlking down is freaky as it is quite narrow but this is worth the visit and the climb!

Get up and see!. Don't waste your time and go there during the day. The view wil be still nice as temple itself but you miss the really spectacular view of a sunrise over Bangkok. Be there before the sunrise begin take you camera and bring some unforgettable memories home!
Beautiful scenery. The structure of this temple makes it unique. Very steep steps, but worth it after you get to the top. The views are absolutely amazing.

Scariest walk down a Temple. Amazing experience!. Wat Arun is a must on a trip to Thailand. It provides great views of the city, it is scary to go up the VERY steep steps, but worth every minute up there.

Mini Angkor. A beautiful Khmer style temple across the Chao Phraya River. Definitely worth a visit after the palace and Wat Pho. The steps are quite steep so be careful. Of course, cannot be compared to the temples at Angkor but still pretty amazing.

Accross the river. Take the ferry and climb the veeery steep tower!
Nice view on the city and river. Not to be missed! ..............
Amazing design. All around this temple was handwork. The creativity was unbelievable. It must of took years to build this place.

Great wall art and views from the top. If you get the chance to have a visit here, get ready for some steep climbs up and then down. The walls around the temple are all intricately decorated with a variety of colours, features and textures. There are monumnets and buddhas inside a lower building with a lovely garden layout on the river bank. Worth a boat ride up and around Bangkok to get to the temple and arrive from the river.
beautiful temple on the other side of Chao Phraya river. Beautiful temple of Dawn on the other side of the Chao Phraya River. You can go there with local boat from public boat pier nr 8.

Beauty on the banks of Chao Phraya River. The temple is located on the opposite bank of Wat Pho and is the temple dedicated to sun god. A good view of Bangkok city from the top of the temple but the last flight of stairs to the top is very steep. The idols of Indra, the king of gods sitting on airavat, an elephant is clearly visible on the top whereas on the side pillars the idol of sun god is located. Worth visiting .

wat arun. if you in bkk dont miss this one. its an awesome structure 20 floors tall made of stone. best time to go would be early morning and late afternoon coz the place can get v hot in the day. you have some climbing to do here but the effort is worth it coz of the bkk views that you get from the top.if you take a boat with the orange flag which is the public boat from any of the piers on the chaophya river it would take 20 minutes to reach. the road takes longer due to the traffic and you got to cross the river since the temple is on the other side of the river.
Good day out. You can climb the steep steps of the temple for breathtaking views of Bangkok. Very interesting architecture and sculptures. Worth a visit.

Only climb this if you are very fit and not scared of heights!. Gardens were lovely well worth a visit, interesting place with plenty of historic value.Unfortunately you only appreciate that you cannot easily get up the temple once you are on site
Nice. Take a boat from jetty which near the Reclining Buddha for 3 baht per person and u will get to this temple.Beware for the ppl who has weak foot,the steps are steap
Wat Arun. Always pay a visit each time my wife and I are in BKK. Found alternative route - take BTS to Saphan Taksin and take river boat (40 baht) to Wat Arun

The best place. The most peaceful place ever!!!!! I love the place!!! It was so relaxing and it will take your mind off everything. You can take a ferry ride for about 40bhat and no entrance fee.. BTW if you wanted to go inside the temple make sure you bring your Sarong or you can borrow it for 20bhat & 100bhat for the deposit which will be return after your done with the sarong
Stunning views. Go here at sunset and climb..yes it's hot work but the views of this great city are worth it..lots of stalls selling exotic foods are everywhere

Wat Arun - Yet Another Must See. Dramatic spires pierce the sky like missiles as you approach by cross-river ferry from the opposite side of the Chao Phraya River. You're already mesmerized. But the closer you get, the more beautiful Wat Arun, The Temple of Dawn, becomes.You soon realize that the temple's majestic silver gray colour from afar is in fact a rainbow mosaic of thousands of ceramic fragments which cover every surface. An amazing effect!What's even better? You get to climb halfway up the main spire. But be prepared for a "steep grade up ahead!" The final flight of stairs is as steep as an almost vertical ladder!! BE VERY CAREFUL, hold the railing, only take 1 step at a time SLOWLY.Of course, you'll be sweating like a sow in the tropical heat once you get to the top, but the effort is worth it. Your reward is an amazing view across the buzzing Chao Phraya River to the many golden spires of the Grand Palace, the Temple of the Emerald Buddha and the Temple of the Reclining Buddha, all sitting majestically side by side on the opposite river bank.Arrive soon after Wat Arun opens (7am) and you'll be rewarded by cooler temperatures, less crowds (you'll have the main spire almost to yourself) and the sight of many Thais making merit by feeding the many happy, healthy temple cats. A very special place in Bangkok. You'll love it!Easiest way to get there: take Chao Phraya River Express Boat to Tha Tien Pier (N8) which is on the opposite bank directly across from Wat Arun, then take the smaller cross-river ferry to Wat Arun from the same pier. Very easy, safe, cheap.

Impressive. We stayed in a small colonial style hotel directly opposite Wat Arun and had a great view of it lit up at night feim our room.It looked so spectacular. We took the short ferry crossing to the other side of the river which was an experience on its own, for the princely sum of 3 baht each.The temple was a cock stride from where we disembarked and cost 50 baht to get into the grounds.Once in you could take the ridiculously steep steps to the first level of the temple to get a really good view up the Chao phraya river.The temple itself you cannot enter .It is an amazing edifice and on close inspection appears to be made up of mosaic and stuck on bits of pottery.The whole thing was very solidly built but quite intricate and totally symmetrical. Each level appeared to be held up by ferocious looking mythical Thai soldiers or spirits. It is well worth a visit but the steps certainly aren't for the faint hearted.An amazing piece of architecture and worth an hour or two out of your day
nice temple. like another temple in thailand, this is also a must visit temple when you come to Bangkok. it's located near of the palace. you can come to this temple by using a boat

Different wat from all the others. Wat Arun is a different beast. It's coated with parts of pottery, shards of plates and cups, all done in a very decorative style. The temple has incredibly steep stair cases, an event by itself to climb them. Great city views as well from the top.

Not for the faint of heart or those fearing STEEP stairs!. Wat Arun is fantastic, but the steps you have to go up are probably 2-3 inches higher than "normal", are not very deep, and are VERY steep. From the ground level to the 1st level there is no hand rail (only about 10 steps), from the 1st level to the 2nd level there IS a railing, but there are probably 20 or so steps. If you had difficulty with the first steps, then REALLY think before attempting the next level. If you are bothered by "edges", it will be quite the challenge coming back down. I had to grab the railing and literally come backwards down the steps. If you have knee/hip problems - don't even think about the 2nd level. The 1st level will be YOUR challenge for the day! Still - the temple is really beautiful - it's made with pieces of Chinese porcelain on top of the basic form. WELL worth a visit.
Must see site for Bangkok. Very beautiful temple and was probably our favorite Wat we visited in all of Bangkok. The stairs up to the view point are extremely steep, almost like climbing a ladder.
interesting but not a must. nice place to visit during early sunrise or sunset , interesting architecture, takes 1 hours max to see it all...try climbing up - very nice view

Impressive Temple complex. Right across the river from Temple Wat Pho, this temple (Wat Arun) is an imressive sight. Easily viewed from afar it dominates the Skyline in the area. Temple is decorrated with vast numbers of sea shells. Only visible right up close. You can climb the steps to the upper levels for better view of temple itself and sourrounding area. But beware the steps are very steep and you need to take care and get firm footing at each step, a head for heights sure helps.Once you managed the climb and descent successfully. Reward your accomplishment with a cool coconut water drink, straight out of the coconut, from vendor at the base.
great place of old thai history. The wat is great, worth a visit. You can stairs up to the top of the main building and you will see the whole bangkok.

This one has a little for fitness enthusiasts too!. More than the temple (which is a vertical climb up high steps, and up three levels), it is the view from the top and the dresses available for photo ops, to pose in traditional attire (replete with head gear and long curvy brass nails!) in the temple avenue that attract, and of course, the fantastic work out if you do two up-downs of the entire steps! Worth a visit if you come over to the Grand Palace. You can visit Wat Pho (10 min walk from the Palace. Pl see my review for more on that) and then catch a 3 Baht ferry cross the river to Wat Arun (Sorry I erred and called this temple Wat Pho in my Wat Pho review!), from where this place is 100m off. To get back to the city or elsewhere, you have to take the same 3 Baht trip back across and then take an Express Boat to the City (Central Pier) or any of the other ferries to the various places around. Worth the extra 6 Baht spent getting here! And of course, you get to justify the huge dinner afterwards if you do climb up the levels here!
worthseeing temple. worth seeing out of many Buddha temples in city. travel in taxi. avoid evening time to avoid rush. Indians will enjoy more

No change since 1977. My first visit to Wat Arun was at 5 or 6 years old with my parents. I am glad that the temple will remain the same after tremendous modernization in Bangkok. The stair case to climb up is steep and it must be careful to climb. It is about 60 to 70 degree sloopy.The only thing that I shall advise tourists is that do not take photo with the costume boards outside the temple. This costume boards are actually owned by the local. If you take the photo with it, the local will ask you to pay about 40B. I was careless this time to take photo.The moral in this trip to Bangkok is that the local people are more cunning and take advantages of tourists. Always do not think anything is free despite of nothing is mentioned to pay. Especially in a country when you can't argue or talk in local language.

Nice on the night. Like : the location easy to reach with the boat from chao praya  the best scenic is on the evening when the lamp is turn on. Dislike : only stone and not too interested from near , its better see it from far away

Fun Experience Climbing. Definitely a great experience here. It's a scary, yet extremely fu experience climbing the Wat Arun temple. The staircase is the steepest I have ever seen. I am 23 years old and could appreciate the cool, old architecture. Besides that, it isn't as pretty as Wat Pho or the Grand Palace, but still worth a visit.

Not for the weak legs. Far far away and high up in the sky there was a temple called Wat Arun. it was built with a view overlooking the Chao Prya River if you have the heart to climb each stairs, each ot the individual steps are not your conventional steps at your home but higher than usual. A look down from where you are would actually let you know how high you have climbed therefore you have been warned!All I can say is this is a beautiful place to go and if you are not much of a temple fan, try this to make it your only temple to visit.

Awesome craftsmanship, colors and details.. A must see in bangkok. Beware that if you climb up, it's very steep on the way down. Climb down backwards facing into the steps. Cheap 15 baht river taxi and some very small entrance fee.

Scary steps.. It's a must-go since i'm a Buddhist. Besides religious reasons, it also makes for a really good photography spot for all keen landscape photographers out there. Climbing the steps was an unforgettable experience, getting down was a real test of courage. For people who's got a height issue, it's best to give the top a miss.
Not to be missed. Very beautiful temple and garden. We visited early in the afternoon and had a great time. Wonderful photo opportunities all around.

Beautiful. This is the famous photograph at sunset. Go to the opposite side of the rive to the temple just before sunset, and admire the colours. It's a stunning view.The temple itself is incredibly detailed. The decoration alone must have taken many months to complete. And the view from the walkway around the upper level are really lovely.

Climb the temple!. I liked the fact that you could climb up the main temple. We went half way because it was so steep and I didn't have the right shoes. (Wear running shoes so you can do the climb.) The cost is 40 B and I thought that was very good. Everything around the temple was so clean. The shopping space was small and chaotic (and I don't think I have to mention it was HOT!). Not sure if anything can be done about that.
Pretty day or night. Easy to access with a river boat pass. Possibly the most famous temple in Thailand, as it adorns the 5 baht coin. Makes a great photo anytime of day.

Beautiful and central. Great views over Bangkok & the river. Interesting architecture and gardens. Loads to see and certainly worth climbing the tower, although steep steps may put some people off. Afterwards take water taxi back across the river.

Go at night!. This temple was beautifully lit up at night, there is no tourist rush and you can enjoy this temple peacefully. Unfortunately there is no entrance to the temple in the evening, only to be enjoyed from outside.

Great sunset place. Beautiful place close to the river. Enter half an hour before they close. Then you can stay inside the temple with less people. Enjoy to climb up the small steps to the top of the temple. The view is amazing. Take the rivertaxi, its nice and cheap to reach there!

Nice. Seems it is less visited than the other temples due to its location - on the far side of the river.
Provides a nice two hours tour of a beautiful temple with great architecture, amazing details and great view from the top

exellent. Loved this temple, It is a buddhist temple but the temple is traditionally a hindu temple, the name Watt Arun derives its name from the Hindu god Aruna. Great place to pray or meditate, reminds us of the knowledge of our ancestors. very interesting, beautiful at night. a must see site in bangkok, dates back to time of the Ayutthaya Kingdom. about 400 years old, makes it one of the oldest wats in Bangkok.

Beautiful. Wat Arun, which in Thai means the Temple of the Dawn, is one of the must visits in Bangkok. Situated right across the Chao Phraya rivershore on the Tha Tien pier, its architecturally beautiful, and is a great site both from the river as well as up close. I'd read and also seen photos that it looks gorgeous in the night when lit up, but we didnt have time to see that. I definitely recommend a visit, and visiting through a Chao Phraya river cruise.

My favourite Bangkok site. All I will say is get there early (as the name suggests, Dawn is the most fabulous time to visit Wat Arun) and be ready to take lots of pictures. Everywhere you walk, the view is more stunning than the last.

Wonderful Temple & Good Place for Shopping. Wonderful temples to watch, with a good market for shopping in a bulk amount and cheap price. Crowded in high season, and especially really hot in afternoon.

A nice temple but nicer to see in the evening from the river!. Ok temple, some nice sculptures on the min chedi, but nothing extraordinary, not worth the struggle to get therebetter to dine in front of it in the eve or take the eve cruise to see it

Must visit in Bangkok. + Wonderful architecture+ You can climb in one of the biggest Pagoda, it is vertical but steps are built with Hand rails, and you will get a nice view from there.+ Shops nearby where you can have a drink or eat some snacks.- Straight across the Grand palace by river. After visiting Grand palace or Emerald Buddha temple take a boat ride from "Tha Tien Pier" to Wat Arun temple which costs only 6 THB for two-way ride.- Avoid afternoons, it is really hot.

Definitely worth it.. Take the ferry to pier 8, and transfer to the cross river boat 3 bath. Temple is less crowded and you can climb up if you are energetic. Great shots at sunset when the lights come on.

My favorite. This temple is not like the others. Much more ancient, it was truly awe inspiring, almost alien looking. Loved the setting on the river. There are stairs to climb, but beware, they are steep! Make this a must destination. Several other temples and Grand Palace across the river.
historic and interesting. It is an historic place and worth the climb to the top too. Nice market and very clean bathrooms. I would like to see it at dawn sometime.
Worth a look. This temple was part of our canal boat trip and it was good. My husband climbed up with our 4 year old daughter on his back which was a bit hair raising but worth a look.

Amazing experience!. Best to go early as it was extremely hot while climbing the stairs to the top but it was an amazing experience! Crossing the river,changing boats to go down stream to Sathorn pier was great! It is an excellent and cheap experience, the entry to the temple is 50 baht for westerners and free for Thai people and it is an amazing Mayan style temple.

Great view from the top. We visited Wat Arun in the morning before we went to the Grand Palace. There are many temples in Bangkok, and we found that Wat Arun is one of the must visit places when you visit Bangkok. Try to climb to the top to enjoy the view. You can see the Grand Palace from there. The best way to get there is by river boat. After visited Wat Arun, we took ferry to cross the river to visit Grand Palace. It's quite far from the river to the Grand Palace entrance (around 1.5 km), we took Tuktuk to get there.
GO HERE JUST BEFORE SUNSET. You can clime up on it and see far around in Bangkok. A historical site not to miss when in Bangkok!
Stunning. Amazing Thai temple. Climb the crazy steep stairs for some great views of the surrounding area. Take the river cruise at night and see the temple lit up...beautiful.
Beautiful temple. If you want go to wat arun, i suggest you to try sunset in here and wait until nite coz when the light on, the temple become a gold colour and amazing

Beautiful. Before we arrive at wat arun we took a tour around the canals.did some catfish feeding at one of the stops.the canal and river is dirty, yet there are people taking dips or bathing in it.the climb up wat arun is slightly difficult but worthwhilejust take your time to climb up and down as the rest of the people visiting this place has an abundance of patience for fellow travellers.have been up wat arun a few times already but each time up is a different experience.managed to get a good view of bangkok city from the top.it has not changed much from my last trip to bangkok a few years ago.wat arun is different in design compared to the rest of the temples in Bangkok city.i am told this is due to the Khmer influence in its architecture.a serene and wonderful place to visit.

Beautiful place but must cover up. Went on a boat tour up the river, which was ok and got dropped off here (wouldn't really recommend). Absolutely beautiful temple, the detail is outstanding. Spent ages here taking oh so many pretty photos. Definitely climb to the top to see the view the steps aren't as bad as they seem. Women shoulder's and legs must be covered when entering temple which no one mentions until you get there but i just bought a long skirt pretty cheap from a stall there. Definitely a must see and you don't appreciate the work put into something like this until you see it from up close.

Peaceful surroundings. Ideal stop crossing the river if you have just visited the grand palace.We climbed the steep stairs to get a good view of Bangkok. Very nice gardens around it, nice small outside cafe to relax.

Great during the day, better at night. We visited the end of April during the day with a tour guide and was amazed by the beauty of this place! Our only regret would be not to have seen this at night. Make sure you walk up the stairs to get a wonderful view of the city, but be aware, the steps are narrow and steep. It's a bit frightening on the way down. PS - Our guide walked us through the tables afterwards and stopped at a "dessert" stand. Had we not been with a guide, we would of walked right past it. If you go, look for a stand that has foot long bamboo pieces stuffed with rice inside. You pick the one you want (we had the darker colored one) and another man has a hammer and cracks the bamboo open and gives you the dessert inside. Ours was filled with sticky rice, coconut milk, palm sugar and red beans. It was WONDERFUL! My boyfriend and I fought over the one we bought to share. They stuff the bamboo and then roast it over a fire to cook the mixture. We haven't seen it again since :(

Beautiful temple, with beautiful views. At first glance, this temple seems mundane, compared to other temples, but be patient. As you explore the grounds, you will happen upon one beautiful sight after another. I highly recommend that you climb the stairs to see the beautiful views of Bangkok, but be prepared. The stairs are steep and those with a fear of heights may have issue, but it's well worth it. The reward is great and you will have conquered a fear.
Landmark of Bangkok. Didn't enter but admired from the river.Beautiful building,great to appreciate at the dawn hence the name.Also sunset is a good time.

A cultural must see. I go on trips to expand my vocabulary on culture artifacts and activities.And this place do deliver.The soaring towers look great from afar.But as I got nearer and you notice all of those intricate details, I feel totally awed by all the labor and concentration it took to build this temple.It's like watching the complications of a good watch, but at a massive scale.Don't bring kids or teenagers, they won't understand. They'll just complain "hot hot, I wanna go home, I wanna go home, hot hot"
Should see with lights. This is a nice experience to see in the night time. Should see with lights. It is beautiful with lights.. water infront...
Nice outdoor temple. I loved this temple you are free to walk around your own pace so you don't have to stay for hours, stairs are very very steep but lively view once you get up
Climb it!!. This temple is in such a contrast to the Wat Phra Kaew but just as beautiful. Climbing the tower in 100 degree heat is a challenge but well worth it to get the view and the BREEZE!!

Beautiful, Majestic and Spiritual. Wat Arun is a must-see for visitors to Bangkok. Don't just cruise by on a river taxi, but stop for a few minutes and enjoy the beauty and serenity of this wonderful temple. The carvings and tiles are really beautiful and artistic. The physical location of Wat Arun is in perfect balance with the city, the waterway and the other magnificent sites along the Chao Phraya. Even if you are not a Buddhist, it's difficult not to feel and appreciate the spiritual significance of this temple.

view it across the river at sunset. It's better to see the Temple of Dawn at sunset.although i went there in the hot afternoon, and climbed up to the top of the temple, where a stunning view of the river as well as the city center

Magnificent. Spent most of the day here, crossing the river on a traditional barge (trying not to breathe in as the river is just toxic!). Visited the surrounding temples and some funerary Buddha's first, was blessed by an old monk in a chair with a sheave of wheat. Magnificent temples and scenery, the ornate statues were astounding, one in particular that was man height and seemed to be made of solid gold. There was so much detail to see in each and every building, it was just fascinating. My husband then decided we had to climb to the top (which was incredibly steep), and when he ran out of puff he made me keep going up to "get the right picture". Thanks honey. If you like architecture, history, artistic detail, and lots of gold, then this is a great place to immerse yourself in Thai culture

Take the climb and see the spectacular views. This impressive temple complex is worth a visit. Take the ferry over and meander through the complex. As highlight climb up the stupa and enjoy the views of Bangkok and the river. As with all temple complexes in Thailand you can always find a quiet shrine to relax and meditate or just get away from the crowds.

just another temple. Nice structures but most of them just look all the same. Once you've taken a couple of pictures that will be all. Taxi cabs waiting outside will not use taxi meters and instead charge tourists exorbitant amounts.

Superb, even better at night. We went mid afternoon for a nice stroll around, such a beautiful place! It was the first Wat I've seen in my life and I've got to say it's also the best.I would recommend seeing it mid afternoon when the crowds have left, then as the sun begins to set have a beer in the bar on the pier where the boat drops you off opposite, then once the sun has set have a meal on one of the many restaurants on the front (We went to the deck) to see it lit up against the dark sky....Amazing!

Only OK compared to the Grand Palace or Reclining Buddha. It is nice and a thrill climbing up the stairs for the view. It is really steep, and I climb mountains for a hobby. There are good handrails there, so hang on. But while the Grand Palace and the Reclining Buddha exhibits have dozens of things to see, there is only one here. If you have the time to see all three great, but if time is limited this is by far the weakest of the three.

Surreal experience. I have been living in Bangkok for sometime now and had always heard about Wat Arun. I went there right before sunset and had time just enough to drag myself up the stairs right to the top. I was not let down it was really a surreal experience. Climbing down was a challenge though, the stairs are really steep and you need to be careful. The lights illuminate by around 6:30 and then it is a different Wat Arun, the view is better from the other side of the river. I will highly recommend this site in Bangkok.
Interesting. Crossed the river by the local ferry which was about 6 barts for the two of us each way. The building is quite spectacular well worth visiting,
Gorgeous and marvellous. Have to see from upclose. It's a temple made of broken tiny little porcelain pieces. The temple look white from a distance

Beautiful. This was very beautiful. Though located on the opposite side of the river as Wat Pho/Wat Phra Kaew, it is easy to reach and worth the ferry price (less than one USD, I think I remember). You can climb up, which looked as if it might provide some really nice views. We did not go up as it was late in the day and we were exhausted from a full day of visiting the various major Wats in the area.

Great view of Chao Praya river. I went to this temple just before dawn. Seeing the sun slowing unveiling and the glistening tiles on the temple was an amazing experience. It is very steep to climb up the structure so definitely recommend wearing the appropriate foot wear. Great view of Chao Praya from the top. Recommend visiting this together with Wat Po and grand palace since they are both in the area. Definitely allow a good hour each way if you want to travel by boat to and from the closest BTS station.

Transports you to the old Bangkok.. Getting here is very easy, especially if you are visiting the Royal Palace. From the boat pier on the side of the Palace, it is a short and very cheap ferry ride to the other side of the Chao Phraya. Less than 5 minutes (although the wait for the ferry might be longer) and it is less than $1.This place makes it really easy for you to imagine how Bangkok was before all the buildings came up. The view of the river and the city across is a sight to behold. You can climb all the way to the top. But be warned that the last part is quite steep and going down is no easy task. If you plan on doing this, do not wear a skirt or dress and grab on to the handrails!

Incredible views. Wat Arun is very beautiful and offers some stunning views down the Chao Praya. It's not a place that can take all day (like Grand Palace), but it's worth a stop if you can fit it into your day. It's also easily accessible by river taxi, so you can always visit before/after a visit to the Grand Palace.
Fantastic! Don't miss it!. Beautiful temple complex! Climb to the top for a fantastic view. It is a steep climb but so worth the effort!
a beautiful view on the river. A very different type of temple where you just have to be very careful going down the stairs, so steep they are, but it's really worth it.

Ancient temple with steep stairs. You have to cross the beautiful Chao Phraya river to visit this temple, this journey is one of the sceneic as you can see the diversity of the city. The temple compound is very well maintained and has ancient architecture mainly from India and China. There is also a chinese temple in the premises. This is also a must see when in bangkok.
Good place to pray. There are many peoples come this place to pray so i think if you want to get lucky may be this place is good choice

Got to have a head for heights.. Not for the breathless or unfit. Going down is as hard as going up due to the size of the steps. The view from the gallery is worth it though and it should be on everybodys list. The little 'restaurant' next to the ferry boarding point on the Palace side of the river is fabulous and so cheap!

Fantastic Temple worth a visit. A bit of a chew to get to but via skytrain to Saphan Taksin (35baht) ferry across river by ferry 3.50baht then taxi which was about 45 baht you can do it easily. Again not too expensive to gain admission think was 100baht...splendid temple with very steep steps to gain the higher(3rd) tier with splendid views both directions along the river Chao Phraya. Views across to Grand Palace and other local areas as well. Temple like Ankor Wat in Cambodia so fantastic site if that is what you are looking for.

Choose Ferry for dinner. This temple will perfect view on night time.You should book ferry ticket for dinner.They will take you around the Chao pra ya river.It's so so beutiful temple plus wonderful dinner.It's romantic time for the couple!

be careful of the upper levels. great for photographers, be careful in climbing the upper levels though as the steps get really steep. at the highest level, you get to see the view of the Chao Phraya river and the grand palace and wat Pho.to come here, take the transfer ferry at Tha Tien (3Baht) at regular intervals. You can't transfer to the other ferries from the side of Wat Arun though. You have to go back to Tha Tien and move to a different side of the port to ride a different boat.

Great view from the top. The place is just across the river from Wat Pho. The plan was to go there after visiting all the other Wats at the other side of the river via boat ride. However, there was an ongoing Royal parade by the river so we had to take a cab which took us about 30mins where in fact it could have been less than 10mins by boat. It was worth it though. We got to climb to the top of the Wat. It was stiffed so it was scary when going down. We were able to watch the parade from the top so that was a good experience.Tip: Try not to take a cab from that place coz it will take you long to get one due to traffic jam. If there's no choice, ask a tuktuk driver to take you to the closest subway station instead. Keep your tourist map handy.
Amazing. As with all temples, Wat Arun didn't disappoint. Beautiful place. Magical. I was fortunate enough to be taken there by locals and that just makes the whole experience even better.
Wonderful and inspiring. It is wonder to see and on every tour so it is hard to miss. It is a beautiful site both day and night.

High, Scary but worth it. This Wat is very impressive to see, you can see it in passing from boat or the other side of the river, however I do not think this does it justice. It is an amazing view up close. This is one of the few Wats I have been to where you are also able to climb a significant distance up it. The steps get very thin and steep, but the view of Bangkok is most definitely worth it. Just take it slowly coming down (they have a hand rail at least!!)
wow!!!!. beautiful temple. not so big like the grand palace, but really beautiful. in here you can also rent a thai costume and take picture around the temple.

The most beautiful temple in Bangkok. I know not everyone will agree with the title, but I just love this structure. From afar the Khmer-style tower is unique as it stands very majestically on the shore of the Chao Praya. Near it is just beautiful, covered with ceramic mosaic made out of the strangest thing, ceramic which was dumped ballast from chinese ships that arrived in Bankgok. If you brave the very steep steps to the second level. You will be rewarded with great views of the river and Bangkok.

Great Temple.. This was a wonderful temple next to the river.If you are using the Express River Boat to travel up and down the river then you'll need to leave the boat and catch another to cross the water as the Express only stops on the other side. Not a problem as the additional cost to get across is tiny.This was my favourite temple in Bangkok. Difficult to explain why I guess but the temple is very "photo-genic". The climb up and down the temple is steep but it's not too bad. Just watch out for those people who can't understand signs and walk up the down stairs or down the up stairs. If you're there, you'll find out what I mean here.Best idea is too look for pictures on the internet and decide if you want to see this up close. In my opinion, definitely worth it.

Watch Wat Arun at sunset from the river bank. Wat Arun in itself is pretty interesting and is a recommended visit but the real attraction is to watch the sunset from the opposite side of the river.The sun sets behind (i.e. West of) the temple and you see Wat Arun as a silhouette in the middle of an orange sun.There is a bar that offers a nice view (I think it's called The Deck by the River) while sipping on a nice cold beer.The Tha Tian market is also an option.
wonderful place. It's a wonderful place. Beauty of art and culture; settle near the river with the sunset on background.I'm very impress it.

AWESOME!!!. Wat Arun is absolutely beautiful. You can take the 3 Baht boat across the river and spend as much time as you like there. The stairs up are hard and VERY steep, but the view from the top makes for some beautiful pictures. (Coming down the stairs appears MUCH SCARIER than it actually is, just walk sideways). The detail in the decorations of this temple are magnificent and the whole area is very nice. Make sure to wear TEMPLE appropriate clothes, otherwise they will charge a 100 Baht to give you some cover ups.
Unique Place.. Certainly the place to visit if you are in BKK. Really challenging to climb. Good place on the river bank.

Beautiful views & location. The 'chedi' or corn-cob shaped spire is studded with porcelain & decorations cemented into place. Every glance at it is an eyefull, both on the macro level of the large structure itself, and on the micro level of all the tiny details adorning it. The stairs are steep, but worth the small hike to the 2nd level where you can see across the river at the Wat Po complex and the city itself. Keep in mind for the ladyfolk, this is a temple and proper attire is required. Sari rentals can be done in a nearby stall, and I wouldn't suggest high-heels for the ascent.

A Bangkok Icon. AKA Wat Arun Rajwararam, located on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River one may arrive by water taxi or by land. The small admission price of 50BHT is required if you wish to acend to the upper levels of the pagoda. If you can handle the narrow steep stairs you will be rewarded with most amazing views of Bangkok and the River. Remember to dress conservative as this is a temple and bring the camera for sure. The temple also looks great when lit at night.

My favourite Wat in Bangkok. It is just magical in the sunrise the sun set or at anytime of day. The simplicity of the stup and the broken china decoration really make it what a temple should be for the believer.

Good views from the top. A highlight for tourists and it is free. We climbed up the steep stairs to enjoy the magnificent views. Fortunately, we visited on a sunny day when it was not too crowded. We wore the right clothes (long pants, shoes and a shirt) to respect the local culture.

Stunning views and more. Well worth a few hours of one's time to take a leisurely stroll around the many magnificent buildings and statues. The climb to the top may scare some, but is worth it for the views of Bangkok over the river.
Nice temple. Nice temple, no entrance fee and nice view from the top of the temple. You can see Bangkok and the big river.

so serene. so beautiful. a must-see stop!. this is an amazing place to visit (in fact, we visited here 3 times in our short stay in bangkok!) ... such a serene and special space, for folks of every age. there is a great beauty and reverence to experiencing wat arun, at any time of day. and special to see others practicing their religion in this peaceful place. be sure to take long pants and a long sleeved top with you for entry.the design & architecture are thrilling!be sure to visit!
Really nice. Get your best pics of it from the river ferry. Up close it loses some beauty but gains some charm. The stairs to the top are steep, but the views are great.

Great views by day - stunning by night. Probably my favourite Wat in Bangkok. It's a nice experience getting there crossing the river, walking around and climbing the steps to get to the top and see amazing views of Bangkok. The steps are VERY big and steep, be careful climbing there. To all ladies I recommend to wear shorts rather than skirt :-). It's magic to watch it from across the river at night.
crowded. I'm sure its a nice sight, but all the chinese (and other) tourists just swarmed the place and ruined the experience for me. I was there at 9 in the morning, but it was already packed.
stunning. This is a must visit whilst in Bangkok. Such intricate design - absolutely stunning and beautiful gardens too. Make sure you take something to cover your shoulders and legs.

Spectacular. It is about a 10 minute walk from the pier. Worth a visit but you must make sure you wear long trousers and a long sleeved top. A shawl will not allow you to get through. They do rent out clothing if you find yourself stuck.

Great site!!. We pass by this place, and I find the structures here are quite well maintained for us to appreciate it although we did not climb up as it just rained and it might be too slippery....and the architecture is really great .....

Amazing Mosaic Temple. I live in Japan, I have seen thousands of temples... but this might be one of my favorites. Go and check it out. Don't stick your head in a cut out for a picture unless you want to pay a couple bucks.

An enchanting temple in Bangkok with different personalities at various times of the day. We stayed at a hotel on the river & so Wat Arun was a short riverboat ride away. My first visit to the temple was in the evening to capture the golden light hitting one side of the temple. The intricate carvings really came alive in this light. We didnt climb up to the top to get views of Bangkok (not easy with two small children in tow), but did go one level. Next I saw Wat Arun at night lit up in all its glory from a boat on the river. This was a sight not to be missed. Views from the Tha Thien pier at dusk were also quite enchanting. Didnt get a chance to see the temple at Dawn which I would have liked. The Khmer influence on this temple is obvious especially if you have been to Angkor Wat before.

A hands on temple. This is a smaller complex than those across the river, but unlike many monuments in the UK you are able to climb (the rather steep steps) up to two separate levels. Worth doing for the views across the river. Also interesting to see the pottery used on the monument, some of them are whole saucers.

A must see in Bangkok.... Wat Arun is free to Thais but "foreigners" must pay a small fee to enter. Not bad at all considering what you're about to experience.Bring comfortable shoes and be prepared to walk up the narrow temple stairs to the top. Definitely worth doing and make sure you bring your camera too. Wat Arun is smaller than the nearby "Grand Palace," but in my opinion just as nice and a must see in Thailand. Near the temple you'll also find places to eat, shop for souvenirs and even take a picture in traditional Thai dancer outfits.One thing women should know is there is a restriction on what type of SHORTS you can wear when climbing the stairs of Wat Arun. Make sure you have longer type shorts or pants or be prepared to rent a sarong (about 2 dollars)

Wat Arun. It's one of the symbols of BKK. You need to cross from Royal Palace to the other side of the river Chao Phraya from Tha Tian pier. The entrance fee is not too much (60 baht) and the experience of walking up the stairs of this pyramidal temple is great. The steps are high and narrow ... is that the effort of reaching a higher spiritual position? I think so. It's a wonderful place to be seen when the sun goes down.At a slow pace it takes you about one and a half hours from the entrance of the Royal Palace. Not to be missed.

very spiritual & unwinding. Compared to other temples, this one takes more getting to as its on the other side of the river, but it makes up for this in there are less tours. It is also not heavily restored so you get a better sense of antiquity. The short ferry across to get to it is full of character & colour
at dawn. get there from 4, the heat is more bearable and then you can have a wonderful view at dawnbe careful as well because of the stairs, some are really huge
Wat Arun. If you go there do the climb to the top of the pagoda. It is a little steep but the view is worth your effort.

Stunning, Must See Bangkok Temple. Every tourist has a favorite among the many temples seen in Bangkok; for me it is Wat Arun. I was fortunate enough to arrive by boat, but it's not necessary to do so. Wat Arun's Cambodian-style architecture differentiates it from the others, as does the incredibly amazing (there really are no words) ceramics that decorate its exterior. There's so much to take in ---- the colors, the designs, the extraordinary figures, the serenity and the humor in its style. As you walk around the Temple your eye will take in different perspectives at every turn. Yes, you can do a lot of steps, with great views as your reward, but if you're not a climber (or if the heat has already fried you) you will still have plenty to take in and enjoy.
