Go one direction and pass a row of golden-colored Buddahs, another and discover a small garden.If you are visiting the site on a tour, as most do, try to do some advance reading so you'll know exactly how you want to use your time here. (wishful thinking from this reviewer.) Also, I've read reviews that claim this to be a worthy 20 minute stop; for me, I wish I'd had a day.

Beautiful and should see. This one is like a big temple with gardens, spirals, multiple places to go. This one has high stairs and one should have good walking shoes. Unlike in India, people do walk in with shoes and you would need them if you are there during the hot season.

Temple of the Dawn.... Really lovely place to visit, not for those with medical problems as there are heaps of very steep stairs if you intend to go up it. Go early in the morning or later in the afternoon to beat the heat.

Breath taking view. Loved everything about this place, Thai culture at its best. We travelled to the temple by River boat and also visited the grand palace the same day as you can by a day pass which allows you to get on and off as much as you like. I heard this place was one of those that you have to visit and it did not disappoint. The detail and craftsmanship was amazing

Awesome!. You need to get a long boat or a ferry across. Its a beautiful building and you can climb it, but its not for the faint of heart. Steep stairs look good on the way up, not so comforting on the way down. Awesome views of the city from the top make it all worth the trip though.

Stunning Temple. Very Beautiful Temple on the river, definitely worth a trip to see.Take the local ferry and cruise down the river, you will definitely spot it from a mile away.Dont get roped into the ridiculous tour at unreasonable prices.

Sneak peek. My travel book said this temple opened at 7am when it really opened at 8 so I sat outside for about 5 minutes before a monk let me in. I got to wonder around by myself without any other visitors and it was amazing.

Beautiful Place. The temple is beautiful and huge. You can see it from the Grand Palace, on the other side of the river. It is even more beautiful at night with the spot lights. Need ferry boat to the other side. Fee is cheap with few baths.

Wat Arun. The Wat really looks better from a distance than close up, and you're not missing out too much even if you only view from across the river. The grounds are fairly pleasant and peaceful though, with good murals and a main Buddha image supposedly designed by King Rama II. The mythical guardians here are also quite impressive, though very similar to those at Wat Phra Kaew. Despite its name the best views and photos of Wat Arun are in the evening with the sun setting behind it.Wat Arun is a little unusual as it's really the only major tourist attraction on the Thonburi side of the river. Due to its location, by far the best and most common way to get to Wat Arun is on the river.

Another great site in Bangkok. AKA the "dish temple", this is a most amazing temple entirely covered with broken dish ware. The stairs up are more difficult from level to level up to the top, meaning that it get more difficult to reach the Gods as you get closer to them in heaven... Be aware that they do get very steep and getting back down can be a real challenge if you are not careful...A must visit place.Note: A visit to this temple is usually included with river boat tours on the Chao Phraya river in the heart of Bangkok. Worth looking into these since they often include other sites like the Royal Barges Museum and you get a tour guide that provides information along the way.

Amazing Counstruction. Wow, it is amazing construction that you can see from the other side of the river. It is look like a small Pyramid. To come to the temple from the Grand Palace you have to take the ferry boat to the other side of river. The fair is very cheap price (3 baths). It is the religious place so it requires proper cloths. But don't worry for your shorts because there is also sarung hiding service.

One of my favourite temples in Thailand. Take a public river bus to the temple and just wander round. This temple is quite unusual in its design and it never fails to impress with its intricate tiling. The views from the top over the river are great on a sunny day too. In one of the temples the children received a blessing from a monk in return for a voluntary donation, but it was a new experience for them and this is what makes Thailand special. They kept their string bracelets on for the rest of our holiday, so it meant something to them.

Might be worth a drive by. My wife and I went in for a hike up the huge temple. It's actually quite an adventure to both get up and get down the stairs as they are very very steep. I was hoping for an impressive view or something, but did not find one. I would say its good to just see this temple from the river shore

Stunning views and amazing architecture. The other option on the boat ride down the Chao Phraya is to stop on the opposite side of Wat Arun for a nice Photography stop in the evenings or you could also pay 3 Bath and get the local river boat across to Wat Arun. There is a 50 Bath Entrance fee to Wat Arun and climbing up the vertical steps to the top is not for the faint hearted and going down is an unforgettable experience. The view is stunning and the architecture of the building which is made from pieces of Chinese porcelain is amazing. A must for Photographers : )
worth crossing the river. I went there after dawn as I wanted to catch the sunset from the other side of the river. I really want to go back as I had to rush my visit. The temple was closing.
Beautify. One of the most magical parts of the temple is the fact that from a distance it appears grey and somewhat uninspiring, but as you approach the intricacies of the tile work are amazing.

It took me half an hour to get down!!!. Wat Arun is something you should not miss on a trip to BKK.It's easily reached by using the express boats that go up and down the Chao Phraya River and taking a quick 3 baht transfer boat accross to the dock leading directly to Wat Arun. The temple itself has a 50 baht entrance fee and strict dress code (esp for women), the ticket seller is located in a little wooden kiosk amid all the hawkers just east as you approach the temple from the dock. On entering, you'll see an old thai lazing on the side of the wall in a lounge chair as if he were taking a break (this is the ticket man, so don't make the mistake of trying to duck him, or he'll start yelling at you as if you mooned his mother).The Wat itself is is pretty colorful and impressive (according to many histories, it was decoraged with salvaged porcelin from the balast of chinese junk wrecks in the river), it depicts all sorts of Hindu deities and budhist iconography, but the most impressive thing is the view. Climbing up the near vertical steps is an experience (the steps are well over a foot and a half tall with only thick hardened hemp rope as hand holds) and there are three tiers of this (only two are accessable), but once you're up it is well worth it for the view and the light breeze (the latter so rare in BKK).After that crowning achievement there's not much to do except to go down again...that's where I had a problem. I'm not at all that afraid of heights, but facing a near vertical climb down, made me hesitate (i hung around the top pretending i was having a religious experience so i wouldnt feel that bad about my newly discovered achrophobia). It took waching a 90 year old Chinese lady shimmy down the stairs like a mountain goat to gather enough courage to leave the top.If you're only going to see a few temples in BKK, see at least Wat Arun, and once you're at the top, remember, a 90 year old Chinese lady made it down, so you can do it too you big baby!

Great Wat to view from the river. Take one of the river boats after dark for a wonderful view of this temple. Beware of unofficial riverboat scams that charge too much, so take one from an official pier...
Marvellous. One of the iconic sights of Bangkok and one not to be missed. Easy access across the river by river bus and not too busy when we went.
Best views of Chao Phraya river, steep climb!. Great views, steep climbing, not for those in poor shape, fun to ride the tourist boat along the river and stop off at any point all day for 150baht.
A definite must. We had young kids and thus made a decision to only see the grand place, and temple of dawn due to the heat - we loved it. Go early and try to beat the hordes of tourists.

Beautiful Temple. I think you will appreciate this temple more if you are into visiting this sortof stuff. For me it was an ok experience. We visited the place at noon so you can only imagine the heat. the steps leading uo to the temple was realy steep and i only dared climb to the first level as my attire was too flowy and distracting (wearing long pants is the best option as if you wear shorts you will have to rent a 'sarong' to cover your legs for girls)I think the most unpleasnt thng about this place other thn visiting in the heat is the lady at the ticketing counter. she was very unpleasant and gave us nasty looks ( even cought her rolling her eye at us).This place i think will be even more senic at night and will be good for picture taking

Amazing temple. I got here by walking through a buddhist monk's neighborhood, and was amazed when I got there. So tall, so perfect in its details, so impressive, I was really glad I took a long walk to get there. This is a must visit site when visiting Bangkok!
Amazing old temple. Cover those shoulders girls - they will give you a shawl but it is a temple and youmust be covered knees and shoulders.

Perhaps I am being a little unfair, but after three days of visiting temples, they all seem very similar.. Like many other temples in this city. Nothing out of the ordinary. Very busy but close to the river, so easily reached by the long tailed boats or the public boats on the river.

Loved it!. As a female you might want to wear trousers or shorts when visiting here as some very steep steps to climb up so might be better in short. Only cost 50 Baht to get into, get views along the river. You can hire traditional Thai dress and get your photo in the gardens here - not sure of the cost.Was a lovely setting and glad I went to visit this. Doesn't take very long to visit here.

It was temple like any other Budhist temple.You could skip it if you are not very religious or in case you have visited. Did not like the idea of release of birds on payment which are subsequently trapped for similar purpose.

Scared of heights...don't climb up. It is a beautiful temple with great architecture. Women should wear long pants or capris while men can do away with shorts. Personally, I don't agree to this discrimination but then... Climb up the temple, it has high steps so people with knee problems and vertigo don't climb up. Coming down will give you goose bumps but is fun.You can get dressed in the local costume and click photos; just see the entire temple complex and admire the sculpture and history. There is a ticket for entry and if you don't want to wear capris and pants then rent it out for THB20 at the entry.

Drink plenty of water. Was 38°c when i came here and climbing to the top was a struggle but the views are incredible. Was here for about an hour and half im a solo traveller so if theres more than one of you you'll probably be here longer.

Wat Arun - the temple of Sun (buddha). As it's name suggest, it is Arun (Sun) temple (but symbolically Buddha) on the bank of a river passing through the city. As an Indian I could see the seemless fusion of Hinduism & buddhism here. All Hindu Gods including Buddha (after all buddha is also one of the avatar of Vishnu - Guardian God).Good architecture, Dont buy anything from the tiny market place near this temple as you won't find it qualitatively worthwhile.May click some photograph with local dress clad females in 50 baht... upto you!!!Go only early morning ... latest by 9:AM, the scrotching heat would rather take all your energy & enthusiasm away if visiting hours are between 11:00AM - 4:00PM
Beautiful Temple near the River. Very Nice, on the River with great view of Bangkok if you dare to climb the extremely steep steps. It was worth the work though and enjoyed the gardens and grounds.

Magnificent. We took the tourist boat from Sapak Takshin, and got down at Tha Tien. That is the stop from where you can cover Grand Palace, Wat Pho and Wat Arun. For Wat Arun you have to cross the river, 3 baht a person each way. The temple is tall, and view from top is magnificent. First flight of stairs is what you can do easily. Second flight is narrower and difficult to get down. Best time to visit would be early first half of the day as noons are fairly warm and humid, and there is not much shade there. Right next to the temple, right if you face it, there is another temple which is good to visit, and cool down if you are exhausted.

Awesome Temple.... Must visit temple. Best would be through a ferry ride which takes you all the way from New Bangkok to Old Bangkok. Although a bit expensive but the ferry ride gives you a nice experience. Although the climb to the top is quite difficult due to the steepness of the stairs but the view from the top of the temple is simply breathtaking and worth all the efforts.

Very beautiful river temple. This temple is only a quick stop off place down the river, but it is a must do. Very beautiful ancient site, with excellent views from the top - though it's a very steep climb! Also really nice to see at night time when lit up
a nice historical wat and reclining stair. a nice view in the top of wat with a nice stair that make you scary.a good architecture and nice scenary when night.

Very beautiful, but very hot!. Because you have to cover your shoulders and knees, this is a hot tour. I would suggest going early or later, but not at the height of the heat. We enjoyed learning about all the different areas of the temple.

One of most recognizable landmark!. I suggest to get *there* by foot and *leave* by canal ferry! That way you can first experience the narrow streets of the old Bangkok. And just before Wat Arun complex you can visit Wat Kanlayanamit. And after you finish enjoying the View - you can take ferry boat and have a distant clear look at the magnificent temple!The best time to visit is 2-2.5 hours before sunrise. You will have enough time to watch the whole complex and then, just when the sun is setting, take beautiful pictures!Admission is cheap. While inside you can climb to the highest tower and take a panoramic pictures. This place is a must-see for anyone visiting Bangkok!

good to see (just not that easy to find!). we enjoyed it here; just found it a tad difficult to find, as we went by ourselves. didn't cost much to go in and was worth it to see the Reclining Buddha. You get a free bottle of water with your entry ticket, which is worth it in the heat! Enjoy all the strange statues!
amazing. must be seen, easy to reach and not too busy, spend time here as well as venturing a bt more off street to check out the local bars, shops and street markets
Unique. Brilliant location and exuberant design, blending Cambodian style prang with Thai style design and Chinese porcelain

Worth seeing. With temples everywhere, unless you are really into learning about Buddhism, you have to pick only a few to see. This should be on your list. Having been to Cambodia just a week ago, this is almost as beautiful as Angkor Wat! Many tourists there on the day we visited. You must pay 30baht to boat dock people. Only 50baht admission! Good bargain tourist site! Put this place on your list when inBangkok. We arrived by private long tail boat after cruising through canals and stopping at one of the many floating markets for best pad Thai I ever ate! Definitely do this! Any long tail driver should be able to help you,but either get a guide, or learn to speak Thai because they will probably not be able to speak English! What a wonderful day!

Breathtaking!. Breathtaking! Wat Arun was our favorite attraction in Bangkok. Very steep steps are not for the faint of heart, but the views from the top are nothing short of spectacular and the design and architecture are simply magnificent. Every square inch of the temple is covered in a mosaic of colorful ceramic pieces, which is truly unbelievable to see up close. I wish we had visited at dawn or dusk when it is said to sparkle in the sunlight. Definitely a must-see when visiting Bangkok. Visit by long tail boat for a hassle free way to get there and a fun ride on the Chao Phraya river. Hint: be prepared to shell out a few baht upon arrival for “dock fee” – the assertive Thai lady there will not let you pass without it.

verry nice. in my opinion is one of the most beatifull temple in the world, better to see it in the evening when gets lighted. the entry was cheap to, 50bath, and you can get a nice view from the top. the stairs can be tricky, be carefull.

Magnificent!!!. Your trip to Bangkok will not be complete without a visit to this temple. Everyone knows Wat Arun and it's definitely a must to go there and climb it. It's located right next to Chao Praya river and best viewed during dawn. After all, it is Temple of Dawn :-)The architectural designs are beautiful! If you look closely enough, the temple is actually made of porcelains which Thai people received as gifts or from bartering in the past, and they didn't know what to do with some of it, so they broke it up and made it into shapes of flowers or all sorts and used it to make the temple. As the results, the temple is filled with colors and shapes that are just so creative and resourceful. Magnificent!!!Make sure you climb up the temple too. The view at the top is beautiful. The stairs are quite steep, but it's doable. Just make sure you take your time and climb up/down slowly.

Loved seeing the ceremony. Our visit to the temple happened to be at a time when there was an induction ceremony so it was full of families,music,and excitement. Beautiful buildings and surrounding gardens. This temple holds a special place in my heart. Loved feeling the reverence and hearing the chanting of the monks.

Worth to visit Wat Arun. Temple of Dawn really 100% make of wood. The temple near beach, It really need a lot of times and money to preserved the temple n completed all the wood handcraft. It very fine architectural wood temple.

Do climb those steep steps. It was almost 5 PM by the time we reached Wat Arun, having begun at 9AM with the Royal Palace, Emerald Buddha, Reclining Buddha and finally Arun 9, in that order. Fortunately, unlike the Royal Palace which was overflowing with tour groups, Wat Arun was almost empty. Maybe because it was almost 5, the closing time, or maybe because it is not on the tour-group itineraries, I don't know.However, we really loved our visit and are glad that after the initial hesitation looking at the steep steps to climb, we climbed right up to the top. One gets a close-up view of not only the temple, its carvings and embellishments but one also gets a fantastic view of the river-front. Even though it was a hot day, a cool wind was blowing to cool us down.The access to Wat Arun from Wat Pho is also easy. Just walk 3 minutes to the pier, on the way browse the touristy shops if something catches your eye, take a public ferry - for 3 Baht - and get down on the steps to Wat Arun.As a structure Wat Arun is really beautiful and one of Bangkok's major attractions. Don't be daunted by the steep steps - climb them but be very careful. You will definitely enjoy it.

via the river to Wat Arun. Grab a river boat and visit this lovely Wat. You can combine it with other drop off points along the river. If you have any problems you can always grab a taxi. The drivers are normally good and do not try to trick you.
Best view in the evening. Sitting by a resturant near the Chao Praya River and watching the sunset near the temple is a must. No one should miss this opportunity when come to Bangkok.

By far the best Temple in Bangkok. This place is so serene it will take your breathe away.
Many people miss the opportunity of the many fantastic views. .. catch a taxi for this may visit place.

Must See. I've been living in Bangkok for the last 2 years and this one of my favorite place to visit and relax. Every time I see this temple it bring me a sense of inner peace. A definite must see for all who visit Bangkok in my opinion.
A taste of Buddha. We arrived at Wat Arun across the river. It's just an incredible experience and can't be put in words. Spiritual. A must for any visitor to BKK.

A Unique Treasure. Visiting Wat Arun is an experience. Not only is this a lovely old temple decorated with bits of ceramic, but climbing up the steep and tiny steps to the top is an adventure! The views of the city from the top can't be beat. I would definitely recommend visiting Wat Arun, though my favorite temple to visit in Thailand is Wat Phra Kaeo There is very little shade here, so try to come in the morning, and keep in mind you can buy slushies at a little shop near the huge tree next to the temple.

Good for photo-session. A photo session treat with good view of the Chao Praya and Grand Palace. It would have been nice if there was someone to explain what the place was all about. Try going up the 3rd flight of stairs to test whether you have altophobia. Though it is recommended to go in the early morning as the afternoon is really hot and takes away the fun of sight seeing. Wear light clothes.

Beautiful Place. It looked so good from the opposite bank of the river by which it stands, its as good from close. Take the steps up to the top, although its excruciatingly difficult due to the height of the stairs, but its worth it. Walk up after visiting the reclining Buddha temple, do not miss the view from the opposite bank, there are number of places you can grab a coffee and just stare at this magnificent work

We saw many temples and I loved this place allot. We saw many temples and I loved thus place the most. It is definitely worth visiting this place in Bangkok and you can just ask the local taxi to come here as its not that expensive I would recommend people come visit this place worth the effort

you need to be fit. lots of tiny steps to get to the top and need to to at dusk to see the best sunset. you do not have to pay if you stay at the deck side where you get off the boat. You do get a better view form across the river
Climb the stairs if you can. Climb the stairs if you can, great view. Stay in the shade during the day. Check out the other buildings as well.

Unusual and Special. I loved that the Beaty of this temple was created with broke and reshaped china. The steep climb to the top allows you to have a spectacular view up and down the river. You have a wonderful view of the Grand Palace on the other side of the river. I especially enjoyed seeing this temple as the sun began to set and the clouds gave me a chance for some really wonderful photos. One of my favorite temples in Bangkok. Steep climb but you can come down backwards and it is easier.

Watch from other side of the River. Watch the temple from the Other Side of the River and then cross the river in ferry , climb the stairs to get inside.
At night the temple looks just awesome from distance when you can see the Golden Temple illuminated with Light

The Most Beautiful Temple in Bangkok. This is by far my favorite temple in Bangkok. I visit it every time I visit the city and always make sure I take travelers new to Thailand. The beauty of the broken china mosaic artwork takes my breath away every time - as does the steep walk to the top. I also find getting there "romantic" (albeit a bit gritty) as journeying the waterways in Bangkok always makes me feel as if I'm another world.Additionally, I always find the best bargains from the vendors here. Who'd have thought?If you have kids, definitely buy some food to feed the fish.

A Most Beautiful Wat. Wat Arun looks so impressive as you cross on the ferry to go for a visit.I found this Wat very different to all the others as it was less showy in its decoration however still very impressive.It is only 30 baht to go in and see and climb the Wat and it is well worth it.We visited late afternoon as there is very little shade around and less heat helps with the climb.I think it is great you can climb this Wat as the views from the top are fantastic. A word of warning this climb is not for the feint hearted and it was easier getting up than getting down. My friend and I certainly got a sense of vertigo from the top.Please don't let this put you off, take you time and do the climb is well worth it.Another must see if you are in Bangkok.
A must see. Likes:Amazing view of bangkokBrilliant architectureCheap souvenirsDislikes:waiting for the boat for just 3 minutes ride in scorching heat can be annoying

Really enjoyed this temple!. I thought Wat Arun was really worth visiting. This was the first temple I visited on that day and had I known about the others, I would've spent longer here. Entrance is not expensive at all and the temple is really very impressive!

Interesting but very busy. A lot of history up close, scary climb to the top, and very busy. Took memorable pictures of wife and kids in full traditional Thai costumes outside temple (rentals 200 baht each). Very hot & humid in March.

Amazing Stupas. Wat Arun has an amazing collection of colorful mosaic covered stupas! There are many similarities in structure to Angkor Wat, but the ones at Wat Arun are better preserved and beautifully decorated with colored tiles and broken ceramics from China. Visit when the sun is not at a high position to see the full glory of the colors. We went a mid day, so the colors were somewhat washed out with the hot direct sunlight.
1st temple in Bangkok. Worth a visit don't forget ladies cover your shoulders and your legs and the steps are very steep but great views of the city

Go early. go early, if lucky you can get very nice city view from the top (if no smog-day).watch out for very steep stairsentrance fee 50 baht + 3 baht for ferry (from Tha Tien cross river ferry pier).

Amazing to Wander Through. Nothing can prepare you for the detailed mosaic work in this temple. This was the first temple I visited. I enjoyed taking my time just walking around and admiring the architecture. Making the climb up the main pinnacle provides an amazing view of the city and Grand Palace.

Great Temple to visit among many. This temple has got to be the highlight of all the temple visits in Bangkok. I made my way there via a ferry ride from Wat Pho.The temple is situated in the middle of a fairly large complex which also houses a few other smaller temples. I happened to spend some time in one of those which comprises of a courtyard whose perimeter is marked with golden buddha statuettes and in the middle is the main shrine which has a large Golden Buddha. Seemed like a nice place for some quite meditation and prayer.Unfortunately i couldnt climb the main Wat Arun temple, but the views from outside were quite fantastic. I would recommend this as a must see.
What a climb. arrive in the heat of mid via river taxi and at the ripe old age of 50th odd i climbed up as high as yiu can go, the only problem is getting down again, the step are more like ladders.
A must see in Bangkok. Climbing up the temple stairs - very steep and not for those afraid of heights - was amazing. It was the highlight of our trip.
Steep steps!. If you go remember to cover up as a temple - blokes included!Steep steps as well to get to the top - most people seemed to shuffle down on their bum!
great view. entrance fees is 50baht. its across the river from the wat po. you can take the boat shuttle service which cost 3baht (every 15 mins) one way. very very steep stairs but worth the view.

Best to visit after 4pm or 5. It is really hot in bangkok and we land on this temple around 2:30 to 3pm which that time the sun was super hot via boat from the canal station near khao san rd. we pay our tuktuk driver 40baht from our guesthouse named sivarin and the boat ride was another cool expirience. I paid 100baht for entrance even if i didnt climb the temple due to my previous sprain but my girlfriend did. She manage to reach the end of the very steep stairs way up but not the most top coz you can only go there using rapel with assistance..she said its worth trying but it could have been better if we went there around 5pm or before sunset to avoid super hot temperature which drained us. The temple looks good and somewhat different althought all temples in bangkok are almost the same. Another good tepmle near bangkok.

Really nice Temple. This is a nice temple - we got to it on a 10bht boat trip. This Temple can get busy, which will make the climb to the top a little slow.Make this a Temple to visit and make the climb to the top for a good view of Bangkok.I cant remember how much it was to get it, but it wasn't a great deal - probably about 200bht for 2 of us.
Go early very busy and hot. This is a lovely temple but very busy and hot ,there is a coconut drink seller in the grounds .try the small white coconut to drink surperb.

Wat Arun. We only had time for one temple visit and chose Wat Arun so we could combine it with travelling on the river. Sensational to see and appreciate the labor involved in the building. Will be hot, steep stairs if you want the views, lots of tourists make it hard for photogs, worth the trip. Pay 150 baht and take the tourist boat, 3 baht gets you a ferry ride over to the Wat. Jump on and off the boat as you fancy for more sightseeing on the same trip. Good and cheap eats and drinks if you jump off at the furthest point and go looking.

Worth the Ride. For a short water taxi ride across from Wat Pro, this is well worth the short water taxi ride across the Chao Phraya river. The ceramics used in this site are stunning works. For those so inclined, steep stairs provide a look on to the city of Bangkok that you can't get anywhere else. Water taxi costs are minimal and the admission price of 50 baht is well worth the time.
A breathtaking view. Took the boat to come here. Beautiful view of the chao phraya river.steps are steep but it is a pilgrimage of some sort to do tjis climb
Nice temple. The temple is nice but very hot with very little shelter. Bring an umbrella! The boat ride there was very confusing. They should have more english guides.

Amazing temple, and amazing views, but not for the acrophobic!. Absolutely stunning temple and an amazing contrast to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Different style of architecture, different period, different experience all the way around. You can climb most of the way up the time spire, but the stairs are steep (almost like a ladder near the top), so definitely not for the fainthearted.

Spectacular. What a beautiful place. To think that this was built without benefit of cranes or mechanical equipment defies logic. The craftsmen who worked here were truly masters. Decorated almost entirely in porcelain. The climb up the stairs to the top is a good one, but not for the faint of heart, as they are very steep. However, there is a goo handrail to help you. The views from the top are spectacular, at least on a clear day. Very impressive as you approach from the river. It takes about an hour at most to visit the site. It's really too bad about the damage done by pollution, as you can easily scrape the soot of the whitewash with you finger.Well worth a visit to this historical and religious site.
Interesting. Great view from top of stairs. Heavy to climb. Interesting arcitecture and history. Were there 24march 2013

Careful with those stairs.. Worth the climb for the views at the top. Stairs are really steep and tiny.Pay a tiny fee of 3baht to get to the other side to see Wat Pho.Got a little lost about how to return to the BTS. Apparently, return boat trips are based on schedules timings placed near the piers.
very impressive!. Great temple with an amazing vew over the city! Recommend to visit and dont forget to bring something to cover your sholders not to pay 50 Baht for rental.
A must. Wonderfull temple at the river containing 4 typ of architecture stils. Due to the popularity plenty of visitors. Should be there 9 am - not later
Great views from there. Easy to get to and interesting. You need a guide to get the most out of it.Views from the top of the stupa over the river to the Grand palace were great!

Beautiful. A bit too much Disneyland though.. This is a really beautiful temple in a wonderful location and even the getting there is an experience. But it has been turned into an amusement park a bit too much. It's hard to blame the people for building shops, more shops, a ticket booth, some more shops etcetera. But it does make it a less peaceful and real place.
Closed. unfortunately you can no longer climb to the top of this Spectacular icon which is a great pity as the view across Bangkok was always stunning from here

Magnificient. Wonderful, magnificient, incredible, charming place. Khmer-style architecture makes Wat Arun look different, not as usual Buddhist temple. Oh man, there were so much scrupulous hand work while they had been building the temple. It is all decorated with porcelain flowers and interesting chinese statues. When you are on the top, you can check a nice view but be careful - climbing to the top is quite dangerous, stairs are steep. Wat Arun is perfect in night time especially when you see it from Chao Phraya.

A Must see. Very pretty temple. It exhibits beautiful architecture and very detailed knowledge about Budhha's philosophy. The local guide will also tell you about its renaissance and history. When it was built, by whom and why.

Awesome. For THB50 per person this temple is a must visit! If you are fit you can climb the extremely steep steps to the middle of the temple and get some great pictures of the Bangkok skyline and the river! We went during the day but we imagine at night this place looms phenomenal! 100% worth a trip! Once done oly THB3 (abut 6pence) to go over the river to Wat Po (temple of the reclining buddah)! 100% must see in Bangkok!!

Beautiful - watch out for con men. Wat Arun is a lovely site on the Banks of the Chao Praya river. It is not large and there's not a lot of sun shelter, so ensure you've lotion if you burn. The stupas and mosaics on them are simply stunning - take a Nikon with you. The only drawback is getting to it as you may be open to con-men - as you are at any major Bangkok attraction. Some even wear a uniform style outfit (light blue tops I've noticed a couple of times) and best be aware of them. they'll be outside or on the water transport.The only place to buy your entry ticket is at the actual entrance to Wat Arun - not on the ferry coming to it from across river, or on the boats going up and down river. it's worth going to - don't let my words of advice put you off!

Magical and tranquil place. We were lucky to visit on a clear sunny day. The temple is beautiful and well deserves a visit. There is no need to pay a fortune to go simply catch the express boat up the river from central pier (a skytrain station is 50 yards from the pier) to pier 8 for 15 baht then catch the cross-river ferry for 3 baht to the landing next to Wat Arun. The temple is quite steep and I would not recommend climbing the temple if you are a bit unsteady on your legs but it is still worth the visit to walk around the compound and see the sun shining off the different features of the temple. All-in-all a must see if you are in Bangkok.
True Thailand. Very interesting but you need a guide to really explain the history and how it was built so long ago.

Worth the visit. A must see and give yourself a few hours to see everything and enjoy the sites! You can make it a short visit by spending as little as 45min but I would recommend giving yourself at least 2 hours to see everything. Some people saylonger but I think 2 hours is enough time or take 3 hours to take your time...

Very majestic. We didn't go inside, but it was lovely to look at from the outside. We went at dusk, which meant we visited outside of business hours, however, it was so nice we didn't mind. You can see a few Thai residents keeping fit in the grounds, going for jogs, practising Muay Thai moves. It's a very serene location.

Amazing!!!. I visited Wat Arun in the evening, and I can't imagine a better time for going there, considering the amazing views of the city and mainly the great lighting system they have for the structures. It´s definitely a must see whilst in Bangkok.

Nice view of the river and the rest of Bangkok. We had to cross via ferry for 3 bahts per person. It was really scary to go up but worth it. Everyone should try to go here especially if they've been to Angkor Wat since the style of this temple is the same as Khmer temples.

Nice and peaceful!. Wat Arun was a very nice temple and very quiet. Easy to get there, and easy to get around area. Also a nice visit to combine with nearby attractions which are within walking distance (over the river with a boat for a few baht)

Wat Arun. Magical.The khmer-style tower (prang) is decorated with colourful porcelaines, which is something you won't see from the distance.As always, dress in a appropriate manner: it's a temple.There are steep stairs to climb, and it can be scary when you have to go back: climbing the tower might not be the best thing to do of you suffer from vertigo!
a must visit. This quiet temple on the other side of the Chao Phraya river is an wonderful destination. A must visit for any traveller.

Worth a visit but watch the stairs. The temple is amazing, definitely worth a visit. The ceramic mozak is just simple beautiful. Do climb the stairs to the halfway point of the temple. Good luck if you are wearing heels or mini skirt. Do dress up comfortably for your own sake of climbing the stairs. Once you get the stairs out of the way, enjoy the 360 view of Bangkok from the top. The sunset is just amazing. Entrance fee is 50 BHT.To get there: Take the BTS train to Saphan Taksin station. From there, take the exit 2 and walk to the Central pier. Take the orange flag Chao Phraya Boat that cost 15 BHT one-way. You can take the Blue flag tourist boat but that costs 40BHT one way. Get off at pier N8 (Tha Tien). Wat Arun is situated across the river, so get the ferry crossing for 3BHT one way.
good representative of bangkok sights must see. a good place to visit if you are visiting one day or one month when you are in thailand. immerse in their culture and be amazed.

Breathtaking. Well worth visiting! Ladies, be sure to bring something to cover your shoulders if you're wearing a sleeveless top to avoid having to rent at the entrance. Stairs up are steep, but the view is breathtaking!
Touring without a net. The climb to the top of this temple is not for the timid. But if you get over your fear of heights the views of the river and the city are amazing.
great view. the stairs is really high and steep.. but your effort for going to the top of the temple will be so much worth it..

Awe inspiring!. It was very hot and humid during our visit but the Temple has a calming atmosphere. I did not climb upt to the top and neither did my husband but we did go half way. The little bells blowing in the breeze were magical.
beautiful. went late afternoon close to sunset and was really nice and not so busy... beautilful place to visit in bangkok

Quiet spot across river from grand palace. we enjoyed it here,quiet after the hustle and bustle of the grand palace and much cheaper.
Just get the river crossing and go straight in there
the steps up are steep mind you so be ready!!

Wat Arun...Impressive Pagoda. How to reach..if using Skytrain(BTS),get off at Saphan Taksin(silom lIne) station..walk down to Central pier(CEN Sathon).Here you have two choices either board a Tourist express boat with blue flag(ticket is 40baht) or Public express board with orange flag(ticket is 15baht),get down at Pier 8 ( N8 Tha Tian).From Pier 8 use a ferry for 3baht to go across the river...and here you are,at Wat Arun.It is an impressive wat with a wonderful view from the top of the pagoda...good spot for photography.Stairs are very steep and become more steeper as you go up. A word of caution,while climbing down ..dont look down the stairs as it can make you dizzy.Entrance fee is 50baht. Worth a visit!

My favourite in Bangkok!. Like many of other attractions in Bangkok the whole place is very different and exotic, however there is something spacial and attractive in this place...maybe even mystic....

See Wat Arun First. In the daylight it is not golden at all, but gray - until you get closer and see all the inlay. Quite impressive, but not like all the gold & glitter of the other temples! So see it first to appreciate it, then go see the other wats. (P.S. You can climb the outside, by stairs, but you can't go in.)

Amazing Trip to Temple of Dawn in BKK. Before talking about Wat Arun, I want to introduce the long tail boat ( a kind of tourist boat) to you. Approach some hotels located near BTS Station named Saphan Taksin, you can find this boat which can carry you touring inside the city of BKK. Believe me, it is a amazing experience to take a look inside Bangkok city on a river. Wat Arun, The Temple of Dawn has the highest Budda Tower in Thai. It is the most elegant pagoda, landmark of Thailand also. Besides, I find it's very attractive because of its outlook. Covered by ceramics and shells with different Budda stories in each floor made Wat Arun very special. You can take many beautiful pictures there. If you have power and energy, please climb up those stairs to take more wonderful pictures. Don't miss it!

Impressive. Interesting. Its a must when in Bangkok. If you are affraid of heights just dont't climb on it. Behind it it's a nice green park in shadows, so you can drink fresh coco and relax from hot temperatures.
You shouldn't miss it. Easy to get to by riverboat. I don't know why but we had missed it on our first 3 trips to Bangkok. If it's a hot day and you're not in shape don't try climbing to the top.

Impressive. Impressive temple that was especially beautiful at sunset. 50 THB entry. You are able to climb a fair way up the temple, providing a fear of heights isn't an issue and you have a little 'mountain goat' in your ancestry (the staircases would not be legally passable in the EU)!! Great view of BKK once you are up there, providing you are not consumed with wondering how you are going to get back down (as some people were). TIP: wear trainers or good sandles rather than flip flops.

Riverside discovery. avoid the totes, pay your entrance fee and enjoy wandering around this riverside complex. From afar it looks dull & grey but up close you see the intricate mosaics made up from old broken china & porcelain that came from ship's ballasts. Climb the steep steps and enjoy amazing riverside views.
Nice temple but not entrance fees should be less than 100 THB!. Very nice temple. But please make sure that your shoulders are covered up, else you'll end up paying 20 THB for a sarong.
Wats. I found it interesting that I never tired of viditing the Temples. I think I visited 15 or 16....each one had it's own unique message and they are not just cookie-cutter houses of worship

Beautifull day or night. gold looking nightime or marble effect daytime ! a sacred temple in bangkok ! ladies no shorts respect it is a temple ! i could spend a whole day here a photographers dream ! go early nearly all tourists go here ! u can climb the temple be warned its scary as hell ! not free anymore :)

Great place to take a break. After a tiring journey back and forth the many temples & Grand Place located in the area, Wat Arun should be your last stop. If you still have the energy, you may climb the steps to the top of the Wat like most people do, but I don't think it's a crime if you don't. Another option would be to just hang out around the Wat grounds. The grounds are well-kept with a nice garden nearby where there are benches to sit and rest. So you can take a break enjoying the afternoon breeze while sipping an ice coffee from the little stall next to the garden (actually saw a few monks buy some drinks here), which is really nice.
worth the visit. The place is really nice and offers a very nice view of the city and the river , don't be lazy and climb to the top.

Need to be a mountain goat!!. Another impressive building right by the river on the west bank. You can climb halfway up the monument, but be aware that the steps are very steep and not suitable for people with mobility problems. All round a great piece of architecture.

beautiful in night. Wearing this graceful temple located on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River, I want to look at from the middle of the river on a chartered boat means. Appeared that ineffable and sunset orange mix of golden.

Excellent. Very good attraction for a very good price, Sri lanka temple entrance prices are very high. I found the temples in Bangkok are very reasonable priced and a lot more attractive than Sri Lanka

Boat trip to Wat Arun. We decided to take a long boat from the central pier and travel down the canals to Wat Arun. It was just 2 of us and we "splurged" on a private boat. It was interesting to see where people lived on the canals - some nice places and mostly not so nice places. At one point there was an older lady in a small boat selling trinkets and drinks and she encouraged us to "buy a beer for the boat driver", which we did!We arrived at the spectacular Wat Arun and climbed the steep steps as high as we were allowed to for the beautiful view. I bet it would have been lovely at night-maybe next trip? If you have short shorts, you can rent a sarong to wear, right beyond the gate. My daughter did this and I think she received a deposit back when she returned the sarong. We stayed for about 45 minutes-it was very hot and quite a climb, so bring water and stay hydrated. Don't forget your cameras.When we were ready to leave, we spotted our boat driver and waved him over to pick us up. It was a short, direct ride back to the pier. I think the entire trip was 2 and 1/2 hours, including the time at the temple.

A "must see". You can climb several levels up very steep stairs, which affords and outstanding view of the river and nearby sights, including the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. Easy to get to by a 3 baht ferry ride from the Wat Pho pier. And the rows of demons that appear to hold up the upper levels are worth seeing.

What a Wat!!!. No trip to Bangkok would be complete without visiting Wat Arun. Taking a ferry across is no problem. You have to climb the steps to the top for the most amazing view. A little narrow climbing up the stairs but worth it. The Wat is decorated by seashells and bits of porcelain. It is incredible to see.
Amazing. A must visit for anyone headed to BKK. An imposing structure with steep steps. Being right next to the river lends it ever more picturesque view.

Very Difficult to Climb..... *) Opening Hours: Open daily, 08:00 -17:00 Location: Located on the west side of Chao Praya River (opposite Tha Thien Pier) *) At the river take a boat to wat arun.*) To get there by boat, take a cross-river ferry at Tha Tien Pier, which costs 3 Baht. Once there enter the grounds and climbed the temple stairs. Great views from the top (about half way up) but stairs are very very steep. *) Admission Fee - about 50B*) This temple is considered to be the most famous and photographed temple in Bangkok, which features a soaring 70-meter-high spire decorated with tiny pieces of colored glass and Chinese porcelain.*) Once you start visiting this places you have to very careful, people keep misguiding you. Take a tourist group and go, then you will not waste time searching for this place.*) The stairs are quite steep and you really have to hold on to the rails to ensure you won’t fall. However, be warned that climbing up is the easy part. Climbing down is quite scary since the stairs are really that steep. I found it is much better for me climb down facing the stairs. However, we cannot discredit the beauty and history, not to mention architecture of this site. It was truly breathtaking. All I'm saying is, if you don’t like heights, it might not be for you. You have to earn those memories with a steep climb up stone steps to the first level which provides lovely views over the river and surroundings. The real test awaits those who tackle the climb up to the second level. Beyond any question whatsoever, this is not for the faint-hearted.*) There wasn't a very strict dress code and we didn't have to remove shoes. *) Try to shoot this from the river so you can get it all in. Fabulous in the daylight, amazing at night.*) It is easy to go this temple just crossing river after visit grand palace and Wat Pho. *) Tip: Visit after being to Wat Pho, and if possible in the evening when lights add up a magical aura to the place. you really don't need to spend long hours when you come to visit this attraction - an hour would be more than enough.*) My Verdict – Must-Visit. For a detailed trip list feel free to visit http://bangkokandpattaya-itinerary.blogspot.in/

Stunning. One of the most beautiful temples I ever saw in Bangkok really worth to go and see it. The best way is to go there with boat so you can enjoy the beautiful view of Chaopraya river. Wat Kalayanimit temple is near to this one so if you are there go and see this one too. Its very nice with a huge Buddha statue
Wat Arun. We liked the freedom we had to climb this great building the way people have done for centuries and the view is great also all the visitors there are so amazed by it and happy to be there
Xmas new year trip Bangkok. The temple faithfull were performing as it was the anniversary. Great culture. Climb up the temple for spectacular view and sore calf muscles next day

temple is world attraction. access by boat, is possible to climb on second teracce and nice view is benfit for you. Very close on river side is statue of founder (Taksin) third of historical capital of Siam - Thonburi. Buri is mean town near river, lake. On the opposite side of river is Temple Wat Pho, accessible by boat.
Awesome. It was our first temple and it's structure was just so eyecatching. Ladies make sure your shoulders and uper legs are covered or you won't get in.

Beautiful sight, very steep steps!. We visited Wat Arun in the middle of the day, it is a beautiful sight, especially as you get the ferry boat across the river (this costs 3BHT) the temple itself is not huge but quite tall. you can climb about half way up, and from here the views over the river and over the city are very nice, the steps get steeper as you climb towards the top, I am a 26 year old man of average fitness and was fine reaching the top but i think it would be a difficult climb for anyone elderly or anyone with a fear of heights. Overall well worth a visit.
Beautiful Wat. Couldn't do Wat Arun justice because we couldn't climb the stairs but if you can, you would get an amazing view of Bangkok. It is glorious seeing it lit up at night.

Must see when in BKK. Jump on the ferry to cross river (cost a few bahts). Enter Wat Arun cost 50 baht. Climb the steep stairs to top level. Nice view of river/city; sunrise and sunset would be excellent there. But they close around 6PM. Visit time: 30 minutes to 90 minutes.

nice viewpoint. niceviewpoint
not so crowded
bad location on second side of river. you have to take another boat to get on second side
Beautiful. Great fun but a steep descent, if you have a bad fear of heights maybe think again. Architecturally stunning. Take a good pair of walking shoes.

Worth for the architecture. It's not as crowded as the other famous wats and has a splendid architecture (hindu). The best view is from the other side of the river - be sure to take a picture before you cross it.
Must See. Very touristy, but it's a must do in Bangkok! The temples are grand, very beautiful and spectacular!

A Must See. It is a very impressive view to approach via the river. When you finally get right up to it "Its a Wow"Yes very steep if you want to climb up, and worth it. But if you are not so agile you still will be impressed. See my review on the Grand Palace for information re getting around by the ferries.Ferries are very cheap and a good experience to meet locals going to and from work.Ignore the Touts Politely. I am sure your hotel will give you good information. Again go independently via the sky train and public Ferries.
lovely place. Great place to visit. If you like to travel then you will be templed out after a few weeks in Asia but great place to visit.
Amazing place. There are so much to see in Bangkok that I just wish I could stay one more week. Nice boat trip to cross the river, great temple, amazing sunset. Definitely a place to return.

Symbol of Bangkok.... Wat Arun is a must see in Bangkok...from it's location long the west bank of the Chao Phraya River it is something you will see often if you use the river to do any kind of travel or sight seeing. Because it is so visible it is a busy tourist site and the boat loads of tourists can really crowd the temple making it difficult to take pictures or climb the narrow stairs. My one regret is not going to see the temple or at least view it from a closer distance at night.
Face your high fobia. If you are afraid with heights, don't try to go to the highest platform in the temple. The ladder is very steep.

Awesome. Catch the river taxi to peir 8 and change, don't get conned into spending out on private long tail boats and cruise boats, Its so cheap its not true,
Just enjoy it it is amazing

First Wat to visit in Bangkok. The best part of visiting this Wat, is getting there! As series of boat shuttles, and we finally made it. It's quite impressive. The colors stand out, only to find out they are pieces of broken dishes.
I nice view of the city and water way if you walk to the top.
A must visit if visiting Bangkok.
Don't Miss It!. After visiting temples all over Asia, I must say that this one is truly outstanding. It is the most beautiful I've ever seen.

Trip round Bangkok. I like the look on Wat Arun from Chao Phraya River, when we were closing to it. Actually it is pretty huge, stairs are bit steep, tight and tiny, so be careful. The entrance fee was 50 baht, but it is worthy. What I dislike - a lot of rude tourist. Otherwise nothing, it was one of the best thing I have seen in Thailand.

Excellent !!. This Buddhist temple is located on the west bank of Chao Phraya River..The architecture is just fabulous and is a real treat to your eyes..Best time is to visit during sunset with the sun in the background and river in the front,this temple gives you a never forgetting view ...The main attraction is the tower in the temple which is made up of broken porcelain pieces,, You can climb the tower...However the climb is pretty steep...The garden surrounding the temple is also very nice..You can sit there and enjoy the view of river Chao Phraya.Also there are traditional dresses available for girls on rent,,You can wear them and get your pictures clicked...We were really happy to see Thai girls wearing their traditional dresses and getting the photo clicked in front of the temple...Its a must visit if you in Bangkok ...

Temple of Dawn. A trip along the Chaopraya River is just one great reason to visit the Temple of Dawn. At night its beautifully arrayed with a light display. During the day, its a short version of making a trip to Ayutthaya, which in itself can take all day. Wat Arun is a beautiful reminder of the history of Thailand and also gives you a great view of the Chayopraya River. Climb to the top and enjoy magnificent views of Bangkok and the river! On top of that, the cost for a river boat ride is 15 baht. Wow!

Taxi instead of Boat. Getting there to and from by boat takes soooo long! But of course you have to ride the boat as an experience, so we tried to cut down the travel time by only taking the boat on the return trip. We had a limited time so we chose to take the BTS there. Get off at the last stop at Wong Wan Yai. Go down to the street on the Exit C side to catch a taxi, which there are plenty, so you can easily make a left turn toward Wat Arun. It should take about 10 minute in a taxi. Very easy!On the way back, taxi isn't easily accessible, so you'll need to take a boat across the river, then wait for another boat back to Saphan taksin. We waited forever for the second boat, as many boats pass by, none were going south. By the time the correct boat arrived, it was packed. If you don't get on then expect to wait another 15 minutes on the rocking dock and smell the fume from all the other boats passing. The boat ride itself was long too, which you can read about in other reviews, including how magnificent Wat Arun is.

Great views of Bangkok. The views from the top are very good but requires a climb up some very steep set of steps. You can see the Grand Palace across the river. This is a very different temple and is much smaller than Wat Pho. Not apparent from a distance are the ornate floral mosaics made from broken, multihued Chinese porcelain instead of glass.Not a must see sight but still worth a visit.

worth the climb for the view!. Im not going to say this was easy for me since I have a slight fear of heights, but the view was amazing and the pics of us climbing up and down were fun! Definitely check this place out!

Religious place. Temple of Dawn is a religious place. Thus, if you are not this religion, you may want to go in and take a look! You will need to take a boat before you can reach Temple of Dawn. It is a fast ride of about 5minutes. Take the chance to enjoy the breeze of the sea. You may get the chance to see a boat sailing items! Definitely an eye opener for Singaporeans like me. You will need to pay a small fee if you would like to climb. However, becareful as it is very steep. If you are afraid, best to stop at first level. It's easier to go up than go down. Thus, I did not climb because I was with elderly people. If you were to walk further in, you could see stalls selling food and some accessories. If you have intention of purchasing a Souvenirs or clothes or even bags from there, do remember to bargain!! You don't get to bargain a lot in Bangkok so take the chance to bargain!! The place before you take the boat sells a lot of roadside food and dried food. Not everyone would dare to eat it as you can easily see flies around! I would suggest that Singaporeans don't purchase the food as our stomach may not be able to handle it.Before you leave for the boat back, you may also buy some food and feed the fishes in the water! Food cost around 10 baht! Birds will also come flying to eat the food!Gentle note would be: Don't purchase Naraya Bags outside Naraya shops because high chance is that, you will be purchasing it at a higher rate.

Interesting place. This place is cool to visit. Its interesting up close of a day but dont know if I would actually say that it is a must do while visiting Bangkok. That said seeing it lit up of a night is seriously beautiful.

Wonderful place. One of Bangkok's great sites, and a must-visit - not only because of the great views from the top of the tower, but also because of its interesting architecture. The tower is called a prang, which is in fact a Khmer-style religious construction, symbolising the mythical Mount Meru. This one is very beautifully designed and decorated. Recommended.

Worth the climb to the top. Take a boat ride across the river and visit this temple, a good stop before you take a boat ride up the canals. Tough climb to the top, but you'll enjoy the view of downtown Bangkok.

Great temple...but a tough climb!. The Temple of Dawn is superbly situated right on the bank of river. The boat ride to the temple is itself a treat! The complex is far smaller than other attractions like the Palace but the views from the top are very good. The God Indra on a 3 headed elephant at the peak is striking...but be warned of a very steep set of steps to take you to the last level.
Lights Up in the evening. One should not miss the temple being lighted up in the evening, we sat next to river to see the lighting

Excellent view. Beautiful view when you climb up to the top of the temple. Scary staircases though. But worth it. Tips, plan your itinerary to have a day to visit all the nearby temples. It's just a short walking distance/ tuk tuk ride to one another.
Beautiful Wat. Fabulous Wat. There were ladies in Thai costume outside when we were there, Very friendly and eager to have their photos taken. Wonderful views - steep steps so wear good shoes

"Adrenaline" temple.... Easily one of Bangkok most striking landmarks, the Wat Arun is a lovely temple to visit. Most access the temple via the watertaxi from Chao Phraya River Express (just about 10 baht one way) @ Central Pier near Saphan Taksin BTS, that plies the waterway regularly and 30B temple entry fee (foreigners only). To take note of the following tips when visiting Wat Arun:1) There are steep steps up the temple...for ladies wearing skirts, you will "entertain" fellow visitors below you as you climb the stairs. So to preserve modesty, jeans or other covered bottoms would be well advised. 2) The daytime view from atop Wat Arun is lovely...you can catch the Chao Phraya and the surrounding areas panorama. That is if you do reached the highest allowed point.3) When going down Wat Arun, do descend slowly with your body facing the stairs (like in a cramp yacht stairway) for safety and to avoid the jitters (especially those with acrophobia) 4) The edges of the temples are constructed of pieces of broken ceramics and can be rough...move around with care to avoid injury.5) The jetty at Wat Arun has shop selling leftovers bread, etc. You might like to feed the tons of catfishes that inhabits the pier area..of course, the pigeons will drop by to compete for the food. Makes for interesting holiday videos :) 6) There's a few Thai heritage costumes shop just at the temple foreground that rent out costumes (the type you see worn by traditional dance performers)...shoot with the temple at the background for keepsake... about 100-200/per session. Bring your own camera. Prices subject to change. Do haggle a little. 7) Visit at night for a different feel as the temple is lighted up at night..Best viewed at Tha Tien pier...the temple closes at 530pm Have a great time at Wat Arun...
Sensational temple. Wonderful structures in great condition. Make sure you walk part of the way up the pagoda for the excellent views and to see the detail of the building

Wear nice underwear!. This was my favourite bangkok temple, really unique with its 3D mosaics, and much less crowded than the temple of the emerald budda.The climb to the top is difficult (I admit I gave up about half way to the top!) but I think you'll regret it if you come all the way here and don't at least try! If you climb the huge stairs in a skirt (and you'll need to wear a skirt if you're visiting the grand palace on the same day and you don't want to swelter in full length pants!) everyone will be able to see right up it, so make sure your undies are in decent condition!To get here, take the 3 baht (finally, a use for 1 and 2 baht coins!) cross river ferry from wat pho.

Must See. One of the most beautiful wats in Bangkok. Though full of tourists it is really enjoyable. You have to climb to the top (watch your steps !!). To really appreciate the artwork involved you will need some binoculars as some artifacts are somewhat far.
Fantastic. We had a private guide that took us to the temple when the lights were being put on at sunset and it was gorgeous!
Very large gounds, excellent place to visit.. Wat Arun is one of those places you can spend hours exploring. There is a lot to see there, and the structures are truly amazing and highly detailed.

Beautiful view to downtown. I visited this temple after the ancient city Ayutthaya where stands similar shape temple, only abandoned - so the steep stairs didn't impress me much. But I really enjoyed the view to city enter - you can see the Grand palace, Golden Mountain and other objects from top. As I had shorts that day, I had to rent skirts for 20 bath (100 bath deposit) to enter. We went there by usual ferry which went every 5 min from opposite side of river, it was extreme cheap - just few baths.

See Wat Arun at night. This is my favourite Wat in Bangkok... however it's beauty only really becomes apparent at night. And the best way to see it is from the river. During the day it looks a little grey and unimpressive.

Great Place If You Have A Head For Heights. This place is well worth a visit but wouldnt recommend climbing to the top if your afraid of heights or have mobility problems. There is an entry fee but very cheap and well worth it, once you enter the main temple is surrounded by statues and gardens - very pretty. The actual temple itself is beautiful, decorated from bottom to top with sea shells and carvings. If you are brave you can climb to near enough the top, get great views from the top and see more of the temple however to there the first third is normal steps but from then on it is very large, steep steps all the way 70ft up with only a rope handrail. For me being afraid of heights getting up was okay but attempting to get down was difficult as its a sheer drop from the stairs. If you dont mind heights and have energy to climb go for it but if in doubt think about it before you get stuck at the top contemplating how to get down!

Not as busy as Grand Palace better view more fun!. Was worth visiting due too it being far less busy then the grand palace. Climbing the steep stairs was fun if you like more of a challenge. The view was good. Catch the boat across

stunning. We hired a long boat from the hotel reception and our friendly non english driver stopped here for 30minutes for us to look around. The temple is amazing, only downside I wish we had had more time.

Gorgeous - Worth a Visit. We spent a short time visiting the Temple of Dawn as part of a longtail boat ride down the river and through the canals. This is a beautiful temple, and one can climb virtually to the top, though we did not go that far! However, I am glad that we took the time to stop and see it.

Steep climb not for the faint hearted. Spectacular temple next to the river. Cheap entry. Well worth the climb up onto the temple but beware steps are steep and nearly vertical in places. Great if you can stand heights and are happy to climb.

Memorable experience. The thing about bangkok is that there is no other place like it. It has its own identity and it is original and exotic. In an age where most cities are rapidly becoming all the same piles of tall steel buildings, bangkok has amazingly beautiful, unscarred by time temples right amongst the tall steel buildings. It feels as if you entered a time long gone by. There are many such temples and I didn't see all of them but wat Arun is probably the best one. It is the most different one, no doubt. The others tend to get a bit repetitive. It is situated on an amazing location next to a river. It is visible from across the river, from boats giving many tremendous angles to view it. It is spectacularly beautiful at night, I know that from pics but I went there in day only. But one thing I learned from my trip is that such beauty cannot be captured in pics and you have to see it to experience it.

Great to see and walk up. This Wat is in the style of the Khmer and is well worth seeing. The stairs are almost straight up on the upper levels but I am 150kg and had no problems.The view over the river is worh it. The ferry to get to it across the river is 3 baht once you have walked the short distance from the palace complex.
Unforgettable. Nice setting and perfect scenery (especially at night) for travellers to visit.With the lightning settings, it enlightens the area around it.
View from the river. Our group accessed the site from our river cruise. Great history - beautiful location. Clean washrooms. The "gift shop" vendors were not aggresive.

5 star photograph from the Outside-average inside. This is a beautiful building along the Chao Phraya river but need not be entered to be appreciated. Once inside there isn't much walking around to do. There is a steep climb to the top that affords a nice view but maybe not worth the money to get in.

Great View, great iced coffee...time to relax.. Finished our hectic day at "Wat Arun"...nice setting surrounded by a park with trees and with a cafe selling the biggest iced coffees you could ask for. It was dusk and climbing to the top of the Chedi you have an excellent view acroos the river to Wat Pho , Wat Phrae Kaew and The Royal Palace.I would recommend taking a private Long Tail Boat trip up the canals in Thornburi during the heat of the day and ask to be dropped off here to finnish the day as we did.
Don't miss!. Incredible. Words can't describe the beauty. The climb to the top is optional but if you can do it you will be glad you did. I am not overly athletic and I had no trouble.
Getting worn out. Getting worn out due to all the visitors. Not too easy to get to since one normally would be on the other side of the river (depends of course).Worth visiting.
next time will go again.. nice place but the stair so steep so next time need to prepare nice shoe go. beside the temple have some nice place to take photo.
Great place. Easy to get to via river boat and it wasn't too busy. We were able to climb up a few levels and take some rather good pictures.

A place you should see!. There are many Wat's (temples) in Bangkok but this one has a different feel to many of the others. It's on the opposite side of the river to many key sightseeing places, maybe hence why it's less visited, but a must see. Buildings are beautifully crafted and seeing them closer helps you truly appreciate them You can scale the heights of the towers if you're brave enough for a great view. Remember to cover up appropriately, it'll be hot but worth it.
Worth a visit. Very good, really steep steps! The water taxi across the river was great and really cheap. Amazing to see and not too busy.
Great. Go by boat. The BTS (metro) and boats were an inexpensive and easy way to see this global treasure. The stairs look steep, but it is worth the climb.
Beautiful. Easy to get to by water taxi or by car. There are many vendors around this temple, so you can cool off with cold water. Plan on stairs for the best view.
Steep steps!. Great temple on the river, however not for the faint of hearted if you don;t like going up and down steep steps!
BEAUTIFUL and AWE STRUCK!. We visited many sites in Bangkok and this was #1 on our list in the city. Despite my paralyzing fear of heights, every step was worth the amazing experience!

Great view. Wat Arun is located just next to river. I highly recommend going to the top of the temple if you are not afraid of the high places. The stairs are very steep. You really need a comfortable shoes to go to the top of the temple. The views at the top of the temple is amazing.
Wonderful place. I loved the boat trip to Wat Arun and climbing up the temple was fun too. Be careful, it's very steep and the steps are quite narrow. The site from the top of the temple is amazing.

Best temple for a view over Bangkok. This Khmer-style temple is very nice and worth the steep climb up to its summit for one of the best view over Bangkok and the Chao Phraya. Remarkable mosaic work covering the structure.

Getting Here Was Half The Fun. Because of the way our day was planned, we went to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha, and then took a middling jaunt down the road to a water ferry dock. From there, we paid 3 baht or something and got on a launch that took us across the river directly to the Temple of the Dawn. It was amazing. I've been to Mexico and seen Chichen Itza and Uxmal and this rang some bells. To see the really old carvings in their current state of natural aging really gave the age away and added to the trip. There are parts that are newer, but the oldest parts of the temple were my favorite. We were there on a day when youngsters were being honored or admitted to something (we couldn't get an explanation, but stayed respectfully out of the way) and it was fun to watch. Smiles all around by proud family members so I expect that it was a big day.Definitely a must see in my book. If friends do actually commit to making the trek here, I think this is one of the places I'll take them.
Nice place. It's a nice place to visit. It's not too crowded and it offers a nice view of the chao praya river and bangkok.

One of the best temples to visit. Great temple, very picturesque. Not glitzy and tizzy like the rest of the gold covered temples. Access by cross-river ferry from Tha Tien for a whopping 3 baht! You can catch the express boat from Sathorn Pier (BTS Saphan Taksin) or from near Khao San.

Awesome and adventurous. Wat Arun temple is near to Wat Poh temple and best way to go is take ferry, basically need to walk from Wat Poh to ferry for 5 mins then pay 3THB per person to reach other end. Then 5 mins walk to Wat Arun temple Best time to go there is morning or evening (sun rise or set set )While going up and coming down from temple, need to go with cool mind and please do not rush because it could be dangerous

Up up the stairs. Finally, I go here on my 3rd trip to BKK. This time, I specifically choose the hour before it close 17.00, because I don't want to climb in the heat of the sun.. At my 2nd visit I almost went here but considering it's 40 C and it's still 10.30, I cancel it. (I suggest evening hour for people who doesn't want to get too much sun and tan like me, since for me it would take 6-12 months to back to my actual skin colour)It's great that this temple has Khmer style and there are many porcelains (or ceramics, I'm not sure on the temple)... so it's different than the other new BKK temples. there are 3 parts of steps. the 3rd one is very stiff (My mum only went until 2nd one).But the view from the top is really good.... the river bank, houses, temples, and colourful boats..Make sure you touch the rail on the way to the top or downward.entrance fee cost 50 bath and the crossing boat is 3 bathI cross back to Pier 8 and wait till sunset...but at 18.30 it's not yet beautiful as the picture here and we must get in boat since boat service only until 19.00But the tourist boat guide announced that starting March 2013 (he didn't say the date), the tourist boat is available until 11PM. Well, finally you can watch this beauty at night without have to take dinner cruise...

Superb Wat Arun. Amazing temple covered in millions of pieces of broken porcelain set into the structure. Superb views over the city, the river and Wat Po and Grand Palace from the upper levels. Stairs are very steep near the top. No provision for buggies or wheelchairs to do anything other than wander around the base. There are market stalls around the base, but no-one hassles you. Well worth the trip.

Been many many times. This is an easy temple to get to and to get out of. I always take ferries to get to the secondhand market down the river.Really it's easy to just walk into the temple. There are multiple entrances without fee booths, AND if you just walk through, very rarely will someone come and chase you demanding an entrance fee. I always went with my Thai friends, and they said just keep walking.Do not wear skirts here if you're planning on climbing the steps. I wore a dress one day and that was a bad idea. I looked cute, but had to fidget and make sure people weren't staring at me from the bottom of the steps. It's a good workout.I've done the touristy photos in Thai clothes twice. Don't be like me and intimidated by the speed. Take a little bit of time to choose which color you want, don't let the ladies pressure you. Also make sure you get the pictures you want. I got bad pictures, but it's because I chose really bad colors for myself. They try to rush you, but if you insist on taking good pictures they will adjust to what you want. I'm intimidated and a big pushover :PIt's a very neat and beautiful temple. There are beautiful views from the top. Going in the middle of the day is not suggested, unless it's cloudy out.It has a very clean bathroom!!!!
very lovely place. Good art and having very big Buddha inside temple. good place for tourist who want to see unique design and interested to take good pictures.

Beautiful. We stopped off on a hired long tail boat. Better to do the trip your self. Use the corss river ferry and then spend as much time as you want on this site. There is a jetty landing fee as well as an admissin charge.
Amazing cultural/historical inheritance.. Amazing cultural/historical inheritance, huge and amazing. One of the top 5 things to see in Bangkok. Nice ride by boat for only 3THB.
Best at dawn. You will appreciate the temple at dawn when the lights in the temple are open. You can climb in the temple but the stairs are stiff.

We saw so many temples i didn't log the names or keep our tour documentation. i liked all the tours and sight-seeing arranged by our tour guide Donna who was very positive knowledgable for she was a local Thai lady from a province outside the city called Utaia i think that is how it's spelt lol...

Steep stairs!. Very steep steps but the view is worth it if you dare to climb! The temple is quite beautiful with all of the mosaic work. The view of the river from the top makes this temple worth seeing
Impressive. Beautiful example of the Buddhist temple. Memorable to climb above and preview surrounding monastery and have panorama of Bangkok.

A place not to be missed. Built in the 17th century, with Burmese design, this temple looks amazing from afar, but even better near. To get there, stop at Tha Tien Pier and take a cross river boat for only 3 baht/pax. Entrance to the temple is 50 baht/pax. To get to the 2 tiers of the temple requires climbing steep steps, but the climb was totally worth it. The view of Chao Phraya River and her surroundings was fantastic! And we could take a 360 degree view while walking round the temple on both tiers. Hence, we also had a nice view of Thonburi grounds, around the temple. Coming down from the temple was a little scarier but it was managable, with some caution. I was amazed by the tiles and mosaics that line the entire temple and stupas. Absolutely beautiful!

Oh the stairs!!!!. In my opinion this is the most magnificent Wat in Bangkok. As you come across the river to take in its beauty it is truly amazing. Up close it has not had the same attention that the other Wat's and temples may enjoy in Bangkok. It has become a little grey and discolored, but to me that enhances it authenticity and beauty. And it is only when you start to climb the Wat Arun that you really start to appreciate its position aside the river.It is also once you start climbing the stairs that your legs start to ache and your fear of heights kick in. Try at least to get half way up, the stairs are solid, its just their angle. It like you are climbing a ladder. Up at the higher stairs there is at least a handrail. There is really no graceful way of getting down- but hey everyone is in the same position. holding onto the rail for dear life.
