(ha) It was a lot less crowded than the Grand Palace & reclining Buddha. there is also opportunity to "dress up" in traditional clothing for photos down in the gardens. We didn't have time to do it, but it looked like fun. The Wat Arun was high on my list of things to see and it did not disappoint. Sore legs aside, it is just magnificent.

My fave wat!. This wat is very different from the others. It's easy to get overwhelmed touring wats in Thailand but this one is definitely worth the visit. To get there you have to take a boat. It runs pretty frequently and cost couple cents! Wat decoration is made out of colorful ceramic tiles and plates originated in China. You can walk up its super steep stairs for better view, but I don't recommend it if you're scared of heights. To get up and down you need to use the railing and it feels more like climbing a mountain than stairs.
Iconic. This temple is not that old, 19th century, but the archetecture is so different it gives a much older feeling. There is a good view from the top!
Facinating. A bit difficult to get to but using the ferry is so cheap and great fun. Entry inexpensive. Many less visitors than Grand Palace. Take care climbing the steps!!!

Remarcabe decoration of Wat. A nice temple on the other side of river than Royal Palace. You can climb up and there is a great view! I like the ceramic decoration of the outside walls very much. A lot of colorful plates and bowls used for decoration!

Great and spectacular temple. Great spot to visit and feel the vines of history..Gigantic stone temple right next to Bangkok river. When claiming the stairs outside the temple you really feel the greatness of this temple.

most beautiful wat in BKK. i think this is most beautiful wat in BKK. best time to see is afternoon, you can see a beautiful sunset there. the entrance fee is THB100, quite cheap comparing to what u found inside. u can go up to the wat and see beautiful city of BKK from above. i think it used to be the highest point in BKK before they have lots of skyscrapers.
Must see!. It's an experience you should not miss. Go ahead and make the climb to the higher point. It's worth it!

Great place..from a distance!. Impressive temple when viewed from the Chaopraya River on a boat but a bit underwhelming inside the actual area!The bathrooms are not that well-maintained, Use a nearby hotel and tip the doorman 20 baht

More than you expect. Initially and from a distance, this temple looks uninspiring. but it is not until you get up close that you can appreciate the intricate detail and colour. We stopped off on the way back from a longtailed boat trip from Saphan Taksin to the orchid farm. Wat Arun is well worth the visit and the walk to the top. Part of the spectacular night scenery along the Chao Praya river too.

Absolutely scenic. This temple looks so beautiful while traveling towards it from the boat. The architecture, the designs are fantastic. It's a place where you find so much peace and a great place for photography too.

Very busy because it was a public holiday, it made it more interesting to see locals praying. Very good, make sure you cover up and wear short sleeves. Comfortable shoes are a must . The Buddhas are amazing, people were decking them with flowers and small gold leaf, one local person gave me some to put on a Buddha, how kind.

Amazing..!. Our boat tour of the river included a 20 minute stop at Wat Arun. This wasn't enough time do do the visit justice but enough to realise the painstaking workmanship that went into the construction of this amazing temple.Well worth the visit.

Must see. The temple, it's design and the views from the top. The boat ride is a delight in itself. however, the pubic ferry is good enough unless you want to be ripped off by the longtail boat operators

Beauty and Vertigo - what a combination!. Wat Arun is an amazing construction on the banks of the river, quite unlike any other temple I've seen in South East Asia. And unlike many of them, you can climb up on it. Be warned, though, the steps are very steep and it's best to ascend backwards, as you would a ladder. But the view from the top is worth the pain! Take a close look at the mosaics which stud every facet of it - and take a camera with a good zoom lens!
steep. great view from the second set of steps but very steep if havnt got a head for heights don't go easy going up not so easy whe coming down .

If you're not scared of heights, this would be perfect. Wat arun was my last temple to visit during my 1 day city tour trip. It was a very fun experience. I was pleasantly surprised when I have to climbed the steep stairs all the way to the top and it's actually quite scary, but you'll do okay if you climbed it carefully and people usually wouldn't rush you (beware if you wear skirt!).Anyway, the temple complex itself is not that big, entrance fee is the cheapest among 3 places I visited, but the experience is the most fun I had, highly recommended! :)
very picturesque at night-time. this is a womderful place to see at night time. I didn't go the site, but went on a dinner cruise that overlooked the temple. very beautiful with the lightings.
All Buddha'ed out. Contains relics and has a bit of a view of the city. Not the most essential place to visit in my view.

love it. My favorite temple in Bangkok, so beautiful, and early in the morning they were only few tourists so it was very pleasant to visit. Be careful when you go down of the temple, the stairs are tricky and dangerous. But no doubt, for me the most beautiful temple in Bangkok. ( sorry for my english, I'm french)

One of the Best Temples. This is one of the best temples to see in greater Bangkok. A better way to reach it by long tail boat. Take the time to climb to the top and look out over the river and city. A not to miss site on your trip.

Very nice, especially at night. The template is worth to see, but not to stay for long (you will need to pay for entrance). The very best is the high balcony on the central tower, where you can observe the city. It is easy to get there by boat or ferry, as the template is situated on the west bank of the river. A nice idea is to take a river cruise in the evening and see it at night, as the illumination of the temple is magnificent, in my opinion it looks much better at night than during the day.

Wish I'd had more time. Unfortunately, only had 30 minutes to look round temple (as boat collecting us). very impressive. Might be worth seeing if your hotel does or can recommend any tours that go there and give you more time. Beware of the hawkers who tell you places are closed - most of the time they aren't and they just want you to go on an expensive tour!
A tall ancient monument in Bangkok. If you want to have a better view of the Chao Phraya river, try climb up the monument. Beware it is not easy climbing up and climbing down this structure
Wonderful Wat Arun. This was my favourite temple in Bangkok. There were less visitors and it had a wonderful peaceful aura around it. Well worth a visit!!

An Unforgettable Sight. This temple is one of the most stunning sights I have ever visited. While the views of it are awesome from far away, there is nothing like turning the corner after getting off the ferry from Wat Pho and seeing the towers with their porcelain adornments up close. You truly feel as though you have been transported to another land when you arrive. The first chamber you see when you first visit is very relaxing and peaceful. After exiting, you can ring the bells and then climb the towers in front of you. If you suffer from vertigo, you might think twice, but actually getting to the top of the stairs is completely worth it. The view of the Chao Phraya and its boats is very nice, but being at the temple itself and looking down the vertiginous staircase you just climbed is the best part. It is definitely worth suffering through the heat and riding the various ferries required to reach this place.

Walk along river at Wat Arun. Clean, Well management, calm place.The fun thing is adventure claiming up to Pra Prang. Yes!! It is free to climb up.Highly recommend : All you need is flexible pants with not much stuff held on hands and brave heart.Earning : Good wind and view of Chao PrayaTips : Climbing up is not bad, the worse is climbing down. My hands were pale and cold. The better way to getting down is sitting on every stairs and let your bottom sit and go down single stair. or look only the next stair, don't look down at ground.Free for Thai, Foreigner fee is THB50

If youre afraid of heights don't climb the steps. Really nice site located just across the river. Nice piece of arcutecture in the middle of a concrete jungle. If youre couragous enough to hike the steps to the top, you'll get a great site line of Bangkok from the west side of the river.
Nice. We made the mistake to go there with children at noon. It was too hot!Impressive but as a non-Buddhist I could not appreciate it so much.

Even better up close!. My wife and I had seen the sun go down on Wat Arun and couldn't wait to get there the next day. It's not as "refined" as Wat Phra Kaew in the Grand Palace complex, but it is by no means run down. Full of character, in fact, and relatively uncrowded. The real treat, of course, is being able to climb up the main prang - about halfway up its approximate 250-foot height. Also, be sure not to miss the rows of golden Buddhas lining the walls surrounding the ordination hall to the north of the prang. I would include pictures, but for some reason I keep getting locked out of "Add a photo." I select a picture to post and eventually an exclamation mark appears in the middle of the window where the photo should be. I'll try again later...

A different kind of temple. I've been in Asia a long time and I've seen a lot of temples. I enjoyed the beautifully unique architecture of Wat Arun. It looks great from the river during the day and looks even better from the river at night. I skipped the dawn views, but it's also a nice place to watch the sunset. Face your fear of heights and take the ridiculously steeps steps up to the 3rd level. The view gets better and better.

Good for massaging and scenary. It's near the main river of Thailand. There are so many temples around this area. You can just cross the road or the river to the other temples. This one has a traditional spa for Thai massaging. You can try the original one at Wat Pho, but here is also fine.

Climb if you dare. Very high temple and plenty of photo opportunities. If you go at night the view is amazing. Go in the day and climb the highest part of the temple, not for the faint hearted mind you. The stairs are steep here so probably not suitable for the old or very young.
Serene.. A must see. It's a very calming and relaxing place.Tip: take the ferry along the river..super cheap and you will see all the great sites (wat arun, grand palace, reclining buddha).

See it at night. We visited Wat Arun as part of the night tour of Bangkok by Grasshopper Adventures (reviewed elsewhere). It made for a very different experience from the usual temple visit in Asia. Most obviously, there were very few other tourists around. On the other hand, there were many people gathered and seated to listen to the monks chanting. We were told that this was a rare event, connected to the Chinese New Year and the chanting, together with the dark night sky, certainly added a wonderful ambience to the visit. Wat Arun itself was brightly illuminated and looked spectacular. The passing party riverboats were garish in comparison but provided an interesting contrast. Wat Arun looks spectacular at any time of day but do yourselves a favour and visit after dark.
beautiful. A beautifully created temple. Ideal place to while away a hour or so. If you're fit you can climb the steep steps.

What a sight!. Its always good to see historic structures withered with time. They call it the Temple of Dawn for a reason. While, you cannot go inside the huge structure, u can sure climb up the steep steps if ur knees are wit u on that one. Your jaw with drop in awe if you view the temple at sunset from the other side of the river from a hotel top like The Deck by Arun Residencies or better still The Eagle's Nest at Sala Arun.
Always fine. Ina group or on your own, Arun is a favourite. Climbing up in the hot sun is a must and if you can a picture on a clear day it really is a treat. A not miss from BKK.
Fantastic temple. Really different style temple...interesting pottery all over the temple. Worth a trip...go by boat. Shopping market right as you get off the boat with some nice souvenirs.

Worth the Uphill Climb. Less crowd and a great temple. That's what Wat Arun is all about. if you take a closer look the wall is made up of chinawares-shiny and well arranged. Most part of the temple is free except if you want to enter and climb the tower to get a good view of the river and Bangkok. I've been to this temple like 4 times and i have yet to go there during sundown as they said the view is awesome.
It dawned on me to climb, climb. Take a cross-river boat after seeing Wat Pho. Make sure you climb the temple. This is the highlight if you can stand heights.

Stunning Views. Beautiful views of the Bangkok riverside at the top of a very steep staircase.Even with all the tourists who turn up here, the temple feels quite peaceful.You have to go see this, it is the landmark that defines this chaotic, confusing city.

Very interesting and great for photos!. This temple is very near the grand palace, just across the canal. (1 minute boat ride is about 3 baht). You can climb up the structure and take great photos. It is beautiful and well worth seeing.

A must see in Bangkok. The Temple of Dawn is easy to get to via taxi or via the river options. Take a long boat cruise and many will include a stop at this great location. The tower stairs are steep but the climb is worth it. The temple is small and an hour should cover it. In typical asian flavor, the temple should be viewed in layers. The closer you look, the more surprises in store for you - take the porcelain decoration for example. Bangkok offers a unique cultural experience - the Temple of Dawn is a key component. Photo ops abound.

Good view. This temple gives you a good excuse to take a ferry to the western side of the river. It has three levels that you can climb, with the stairs getting progressively steeper with every level. I would definitely recommend coming here at sunset time, to both avoid the heat and watch the sun set over Bangkok. Once you get to the top, you can watch the city across the river as you peer out from between the buddhist gargoyle-like figures.

Worth a visit for the climb alone. We went on fantail boat tour of the river that included stops at Wat Arun (the temple of the dawn) and Wat Pho. I liked Wat Arun better - beautiful temples, wonderful views and less crowds. You can climb up the outside of the main temple for 50 baht via very steep staircases. The incline feels close to 90 degrees (I don't know what it really is - maybe 70?) and the climb is exciting, especially coming down. It was fun.

Amazing attraction, amazing views and design.. To get to Wat Arun, hop onto the BTS and alight at Saphan Taksin. Follow the signs to the river taxi pier which is located on the left exit and hop onto the river cruise (should cost not more than 40baht per person). Get off at Tha Tien pier - first pier after the bridges; spot the Wat on the opposite bank or the unmissable crowd at the pier itself - and get onto the Wat Arun ferry (3baht per person). Dress appropriately to visit - covered shoes, cotton shirts for the generally blazing weather, long pants or skirts preferred and no bare shoulders would do fine. The temple halls is a great place to leave your mind behind, there will also be a monk there if you need blessings. Once you've conquered the Wat's steep steps, you'd be greeted by an amazing 360deg view around the Wat - so remember your cameras and snap away! Also note to bring along some bottled water. Plenty of touristy shops surrounding the Wat but you will find the same stuff everywhere. Dont miss the coconut guy though - his sweet cold refreshing juice is definitely a savior after the climb. To return, get onto the same ferry back to Tha Tien at another 3baht per person and your adventure continues!

Amazing Views and Amazing Architectural Structure. To get to Wat Arun, simply hop onto the BTS and get off at Saphan Taksin. Head to the river cruise counter (simply follow the signs towards the left exit) and hop onto the river taxi which should cost not more than 40baht per person. Get off at Tha Tien pier (look out for the Wat on the opposite bank or just spot the unmissable crowd of people) and hop onto the Wat Arun ferry which is another 3baht per person to get you to the opposite bank where the Wat is. Dress appropriately when visiting - covered shoes, long pants or skirts preferred and no bare shoulders. The Wat, if you manage the steep steps, features an amazing structure which gives you good 360deg views around the Wat and the river - remember your cameras! Do also note to bring along some bottled water; you're gonna need that after you conquer the steps. Loads of touristy shops around the Wat but i'd say just give it a miss - you wont miss much. The only thing you shouldnt is the coconut guy selling the sweet cold refreshing drink. To get back, simply hop back on the ferry for another 3bahts per person and you will get to Tha Tien where the adventure continues.

specially after sunset nice. wat arun is a very frequentated place in bankok and the tourists visit that area during the whole day. we visited wat arun two times, one time around noon to to visit the area inside of the wat, which was not so interesting for us, and one more time in the evening after sunset to walk around the area, because the wat was closed. after that visit in the evening we went to the opposite side of the khao praya river to watch the wat in distance. this was the nicest moment we had in relation to wat arun, we can recomment the panorama view from this place. the rest is is thai styled average.

What a fun, steep climb!. I loved climbing Wat Arun! I suggest going first thing in the morning to avoid the heat and crowds. We got there right after opening and had the place almost to ourselves. Great little souvenir shops all around the base, too. Be sure to bargain to get a good deal. This place may not look like much from afar, but up close it is very, very unique. Well worth the scary climb up the steep steps!
Beautiful. We rented a boat to go here. It was awesome! The detail is amazing. They rent clothes here to cover legs and shoulders. The climb is high up but the view is beautiful
One of the Top Attractions. This is a must do in Bangkok.Really impressive to see and worth adding to your day trip plans.Very popular Tourist spot

a must to see. Easily to reach by boat from the BTS Saphan Taksin (15baht), the river crossing from wat Arun to wat Pho is just 3baht. Its a must to see...the reclining buddah (100baht) and the climbing of the Wat Arun (50baht).

Clime the steep stairs. I don't know how come that there aren't many accidents, because the stairs are super steep.. and all those old people. Beautiful, beautiful place. The ferry to get there is super super cheap!

Awesome!. not for folks that are afraid of heights! the second set of stairs is extremely steep, make sure you go up the "up" stairs and down the "down"!Have a Coconut in the courtyard before taking the ferry across to the Grand Palace.
Beautiful. Very beautiful temple. Climb up to the top of the Wat Arun. The stairs were scary because it is so steep. But it is an great experience! Don't miss it!
Take the Steps!. One of the highlights of Bangkok and if you are adventurous enough to go up the stiff steps you will be rewarded with a great view.

Don't leave Bangkok Till You See Wat Arun. This was my fourth visit to Bangkok and I thought I had seen all there was to see. My wife pointed out we had not seen Wat Arun yet. Don't get me wrong. I love all the Buddhist temples in Bangkok but after seeing about five I thought the rest would be pretty much more of the same.Then I saw Wat Arun. What a temple! Such imposing height, such sculpture, such location. This is the most amazing place in Bangkok. The view of the city and the river you get when you climb up the forbiddingly steep steps are simply unbelievable. That's why I tell you don't leave Bangkok till you have seen Wat Arun!
oxford tailor. Very nice temple when we there with my family we fell really better inside the temple. We fell very lucky we have change to go there. strongly recommended to go there thanks you.

Worth the visit IF you go Early. This place is worth the 50THB, but only if you go early and can avoid the crowds. I was able to capture some great photographs of the temple without having too many people get in the way of the photos. To set the expectations from the start, you cannot enter this temple. This temple is solely for climbing purposes and to view the details of the design engraved into the stone. As mentioned in other reviews, it is a steep climb and I highly recommend you wear sneakers to climb this one. Women, you must cover your shoulders and cannot wear shorts. Gents, shorts and sneakers are fine and highly recommended as it will get very warm with the sun blazing. We went really early and managed to avoid the crowds that followed and crossed the river from the Reclining Buddha temple. I suggest going to Wat Arun first then heading over to the Reclining Buddha. You can avoid the crowds from Arun but still run into some crowds at the Reclining Buddha.Tip: If you arrive to the pier by ferry from Central Pier, you must pay 3THB to cross over to the Wat Arun side of the river and 3THB to cross back over to the Reclining Buddha side. Take bottles of water!ALSO! Read ALL signs around these tourist attraction areas. We took a photo of something and then a Thai woman appeared and pointed to a sign next to it stating we had to pay to take a photo of it.

Fascinating place. Good value and worth the visit. The amount of towers was incredible all plastered with ceramics. You could do a VERY steep climb to the top, not for the faint hearted or those with knee problems ! Views at the top worth it though. Great visit.
Very impressive. Wished we had more time to take a boat ride from there as well. Very, very impressive, steep stairs, but worth to climb in order to get the view.

A fantastic one!. We visited this beautiful temple at noon. The weather was hot but somehow bearable. The four of us, including my nine years old daughter who was previously scared of height, managed to climb every single steep steps of Wat Arun. The scenery on top was fantastic. Don't try to look down as you descent as that would make your legs go weak and strength-less! Believe me, the steps were very steep!! Just look and concerntrate on the steps below your feet as you walk down side way!We enjoyed the visit.. Must go!! Must climb! I think it will look even better at night with all those lights
Average. If you're afraid of heights, this is not the place for you. But if you were only going to visit Bangkok, this is worth a visit. Take the ferry that gets off right at the Wat -- very cheap.

I just love the place. If you can see only two sites in BKK, the palace and this are the two you should visit. If you are able - climb up the steep stairs for the view and the experience. You don't need a guide , although there are plenty offering their services. spare two hours for the visit.

Loved, loved it.. Gorgeous temple. A lot of them can be 'repetitive'. If you don't have much time, this should be on your Top 3 list. Be sure to wear tennis shoes if you want to climb the steps. The city view near the top is breath taking. We really enjoyed our crowded experience on the Chao Phraya boat express to get here.

Pretty easy to get to.. It is a stunning temple across the river from the boat stop of Wat Pho. It is relatively easy to get there. You pay 3 baht and get on this white boat that takes you across the river. It is very quiet there and the entrance fee is quite cheap. You can also climp to the top of Wat Arun and see the city from a nice vantage point. It is definitely worth a visit probably only 30 to 45 minutes should suffice. You could then move on to other temples and sites across the river.

Beautiful view, Beautiful Temple.. Wat Arun is a must go attraction in Thailand.The porcelain encrusted temple domes are beautiful and the sight from on top the domes are breathtaking. With the Chao Phraya river and Bangkok for you to survey.Worth the cheap entrance fees. :-)
Amazing Wat. Use the Ferry ,to go here more exciting.Wear your comfortable shoes,a lot of stairs to climb.It is a Temple ,so wear decent clothes.
Don't miss this one. Really interesting and benefits from being on the other side of the river so not as busy as Wat Pho.

My Favourite Temple. This was my favourite temple of all in Thailand, it stood out from the others and didn't feel like 'just another temple'. We visited on a Monday and was much quieter than when we visited others temples on a Saturday. The climb to the top is a bit hair raising, very steep, but totally worth it. The view over the river was breathtaking. The markets nearby on the riverside are well worth a look too.
Pretty but a tourist trap. Pretty and very different from the Grand Palace. We took a long tail boat here, and it cost us 30 bath extra to embark the pier. Furthermore it's a 50 bath entrance fee.
Great view. Worth climbing to get a good view of Chao Prayo and the river banks. I enjoyed meditating in the side temple and just enjoying the quiet small room
AMAZING. For westeners is so unique, so amazing, so genuinly asian, that you should not miss. Totally different for our christian culture "catches" your attention in every aspect
You must visit!. Most visitors approach this temple across the river by boat. It is really fantastic and worth the effort. Climb up (very steep steps) if you can!
Spectacular. Take express boat and then ferry across the river to get there. Very unique and definitely worth seeing also looks amazing at night when lighten up

Amazing! A must-see place in Bangkok. I'm really impressed by the wonderful architecture of the Temple! I wish I had more time there! I climbed the stairs and yes, they're quite steep and scary! Next time I'll try to get its dawn moments! Temple of the Dawn!
nice. this was an interesting day and well worth a visit. steps were very steep going up and down but the view was great.
You need a head for heights!. To get to the top you need to go up very steep steps and I saw grown men struggle. Great view from the op and lots of tourist stalls around that area
Climb to the top !. One of our favorite temples in Bangkok and we enjoyed climbing the steps to the top and seeing the city . Must see!

Great and Worth a visit. Great monument and sure is worth all the effort that you take to climb up and the boat ride ( if you are staying on this side of the river).
Go for it. It is beautiful.
Beautiful. Spectacular architecture - and you don't need to climb up the crazy steep steps. Beautiful viewed from just off shore from a long tailed boat.

pretty little thing by the side of the river. of the 3 major Wat in bangkok i like this the most. as a prof photographer i find this one to be the most picturesque. the fact that it sit right at the banks of chao phraya river is definitely helping. view of bangkok city from the top of this wat is not too shabby as well. go at the late afternoon and then wait untill the sun is setting and the floodlight come alive

might be my fav temple just cause you can climb it. Go to this temple for the sheer fact of climbing the stars. Take the ferry from the reclining buddha port. Across the river. Go to this temple then when you are done go to the river and ask where the canal boats are. Tajke this. its incredible.
Outstanding Temple. This really is a "must do" in Bangkok. Go early, do not go on Saturday, bring your camera, and be sure to climb the stairs. Sunday early morning is actually a great time to go.

The best wat in Bangkok. I really enjoyed Wat Arun. We spent the day just traveling around the city looking at wats and toured the Grand Palace. They were all so lovey and beautiful. We visited Wat Arun last because you have to cross the river to get there. There was just something so special about it. It had a different vibe from the other wats, and it had different architecture. Wat Arun is very tall and you can climb the very steep stairs to about half way up. I put my fear of heights aside, and I am so glad I did. Once at the top you have amazing views of the river and downtown Bangkok. It was so worth the boat ride!

Nice View. I see this pretty picture of the Wat Arun at night and I am a little disappointed I went during the day. The temple itself is not that large in width or height although it does offer a very nice view of the city. There are a few different tiers you can walk around, the top two offering nice 360 degree views (if you walk all the way around the Wat Arun). I notice people commenting on the stairs or the steep climb. Some of the climb is steep, I think it is a little misleading to say the whole thing is. There are three sets of stairs, one that sits perpendicular to the other two and two sets that go straight up the side of the temple. The first set of stairs that sits perpendicular to the other two is not steep at all, perhaps what you would find on a normal staircase. The next ascending staircase is steeper, it may make some who have height or vertigo issues a little uneasy. The last set of stairs is very steep and this may be what people are referring to. To say your body is parallel with the temple would not exactly be true but it feels like it. Again, that last set of stairs is very steep. Some of the people who I saw when I was standing at the top of the temple took one look at that last set of stairs, climbed up a couple and then climbed back down refusing to go any further. Too steep for them I guess.My wife and I went to the Wat Arun with a tour group so I do not know if they was any sort of entrance fee. A good place to go for a view and if you enjoy climbing up things that are rather steep.
Beautiful Temple. I went there in the afternoon. But it's lovely. And if you are not really fit, do not try to climb up. You might not be able to get down later. Steep steps.

Pretty and not too crowded. Interesting enough to be worth crossing the river. Great views though steep steps up and down. A bit different to the other temples too, not just focussing on gold and Buddha statues.
Amazing in the night. We went to Wat Arun on the day, and its very steep to climb and gives you a good panorama once you are on top. At night it was breath taking.
Such craftsmanship. great to visit grounds - though we were too tired at end of our day to take the many stairs up for the view....great to see at night on supper cruise

Amazing.. Plz do not go there during the daytime. Try to be there just before sunset and watch the temple glow ! Alight at Saphan Taksin station, take the Orange flag Boat (15 B) , get down at the Ta Tien Pier and use the cross river Boat (3 B) to walk into the temple complex.

find the right way to this place!(tips). the problem is searching for the boat pier!50 baht for entrance. Reach it by boat for a short sail. This was my second time coming here.I came to this place after exploring the Grand Palace(crowded), and Wat Pho (Wat Phra). The pier for the boat to Wat Arun is Ta Thien, the pier is hidden behind market and crowded area. Using the boat will cost only 3 baht.Traveler must beware for the people that try to offer you boat trip with high price (thousands baht) and bring you to private pier (not government pier, the boat own by private owner). Also beware of tuk-tuk driver offer you small fee (10baht) ride that he said will drop you in pier to Wat Arun (but what really happened is he drop you at the private pier with high price). I experience this on my first coming to Wat Arun, but i avoid it by rejecting the private boat owner offer (although i got that 10 baht tricky tuk-tuk).tricky gang just try to take benefit from the hidden Ta Thien pier, by making tourists get confused and trick them to use the private boat. If you confused to go to Wat Arun, ask the staff in Grand Palace or staff in Wat Pho, dont just ask about the direction, but which pier you must take .Wat Arun itself is beautiful to see. The place really comfortable. You can hear the sounds from little iron that touch the body of the temple when wind comes. The building is in a very good shape. If you want to take photo in the stairs to the top of Wat Arun, just be patient (if you want to take clear photos without people behind you).the place isnt really suitable for children or senior citizen, because the stair step is high. If you go with them, just watch them carefully, especially when taking stair to goes down from the top place.There is also place selling souvenir with good price, its near the toilet area.

Small temple with lots of handicraft on the outside. Wat Arun is a pretty temple, cluttered with pieces of beautiful porcelain, I loved this! From Tha Tien Pier it cost 3 THB per person to cross the river towards the entrance of the temple and another 50 THB each as an entrance fee. You can also climb the wat for some great views of the river and surroundings. Surely worth a visit!

Quite the climb. Going up was great - coming down - it was steep, but worth it. The views from the top were spectacular and the washrooms were unbelievably clean. Careful where you buy the water, though. At one end they were selling them at 10 baht and the other end at 20 baht. When we commented on the cost and started to walk awya, "Oh no we will sell for 10 B."

beautiful, over-crowded for trinkets hunter & not for the faint-hearted. Temple of the Dawn or Wat Arun is a great stop for any tourist. Do take the river boat route as you can experience Chao Phraya & other beautiful landmarks along the mighty river. To get on top it cost around 500.00 baht & do climb upstairs. But the steps are quite small & ii is 90-degrees slop so do follow the UP & DOWN sign. On top is a piece of yellow cloth for anyone who one to leave marks on their visit there (I forgot to bring a pen).The temple may look creepy, dilapidated from afar because it has no gold-leaves covering but upon closer look, the colorful Chinese porcelains create a beautiful mosaics reflecting the colorful Thai history. And the view from above is AMAZING!!!TIPS: If your tour-guide takes your there & claim that the trinkets, souvenirs inside is cheap, they are RIGHT. But we were there on weekends & there are so many shoppers that day. The stalls outside of the temples also offer stuffs at the same price so do bargain around.

Gorgeous!. The trip up the Chao Phraya from the Saphan Taksin BTS station was beautiful. Getting to Wat Arun was easy and cheap. The climb to the top was a lot of fun but a little crowded. The panorama from top was beautiful.
A must see sight. You can't one to bangkok without seeing wat Arun.best way to visit is via boat.......take the local one and not the more expensive tourist one !!
Amazing. This was a glorious temple - walking over the memorial bridge and along the water to get here was an adventure in itself. What a wonderful temple and garden. Do not miss.

Neat site. This was a really neat location. The stairs were incredibly small and it felt like we were climbing a mountain. If you have fears of heights, I would recommend not climbing to the top. The climb wasn't too bad but coming down could be troubling to some.

Go for the view. Temple isn't that spectacular, but the views trom Wat Arun on the Thonbury side towards Bangkok, the Chao Phraya river and the Grand Palace are spectacular from the top of Wat Arun. You'll get great shots if you have a panorama mode on your camera!
Exhilarating Climb with Great Views. Much more peaceful than the other Wat's over-run by tourists... and a superb and exhilarating climb to the top for some great views.

Worth a stop. Wat Arun is definitely a good stop in Bangkok, you can walk halfway up the 70-meter temple (steep climb) for a nice view of the river & city skyline. The intricate tile and stone details are impressive. Take the Chao Phraya river taxi from downtown for 20 baht, not a taxi or tuk tuk, then cross over to Wat Po by ferry for 3 baht.
Amazing. Must see Temple in Bangkok. Definitely worth the climb up the steep stairs. Beautiful mosaic work, a lot of history.

Fun climb; Great view. Beautiful temple. Go at Dawn if you can to see the sunrise and avoid the heat of the day. Not sure if it is open to public at Dawn though. Kinda scary to climb all the way down after climbing up... but that adds to the excitement. Our favorite of the temples in Bangkok, along with the reclining Buddha across the river. Take the ferry boat to get there cuz it is also an interesting experience.

simply breathe taking. i usually dont like going to temples/momuments but this one was excellent. breath taking view and good fun. we went for a boat trip which was included in the package and it was great over all. highly recommended.

Beautiful and unique temple. Lovely temple, quite different than other Bangkok wats, Wat Arun lookss more like Cambodian temples and is covered in porcelain mosaics. A real work of art. A very steep climb to get up to the higher level but the view is worth it. Also a great place to pick up a boat ride into the canals (make sure you bargain and you'll get a great ride for low cost). Definitely one of Bangkok's must-see attractions.

A must see temple. A stunning white temple on the west bank of the river. Easy to get to by public river bus as it is a standard stop. A few stalls between the jetty and the temple selling food, refreshments and some cheap souviners. Fascinating carved stones and some very steep steps
GOod place. See this temple in sun set from river side. Just good to visit and see the culture of Thailand. Use Boating around river side and you can have good time.
WOW. Cultural experience for the family, amazing architectural wonder, very busy and a melting pot of folk from all over the world.
Awesome. This is on place you are not allowed to miss when in Bangkok, don't forget to take your shoes off and enjoi this masterpiece of art and architecture

Much better than the grand palace!. Eat Arun is not as popular as the grand palace, but it's much better in my opinion. For one thing, it's not crowded, which gives you a sense of peace in the historical site; for another thing, it's got very high stairs, which is fun to climb. In addition, it gave you the view of the river and the palace on the other side. I highly recommend this place!

Awfully Dirty and not as pretty as the pictures. We took the advice of other travelers and just took pictures from out river taxi as we were leaving Wat Pho. The pollution has made the structure almost black but you could tell that it was a magnificent building.
awesome. At the top of the must see list - go to Central pier and get ferry/longtail and go to Grand Palace. Fantastic
historical visit.. To enter the temple ,u need to pay 50bhat,which is very reasonable,but to snap a picture by wearing thai traditional dress,u hv to pay 200baht.

A Beauty. See the Wat Arun before you visit Wat Pho and the Grand Palace. Start your visit with Wat Arun and enjoy its understated beauty (compared to Wat Pho and Grand Palace). It is also less crowded and therefore more serene with a nice garden area. The views from the top (if you can manage to climb the very steep steps) are amazing.

Breath-taking archeticture under sunset. We went to Wat Arun nearly 16:00PM, we take the shuttle boat which is extremetly cheap(3Baht), only 5 minutes the Wat become closer and closer, it looks like solem statue under the glooms of sunset. Breath-taking archeticture, worth of going

Wat a temple!. I love Wat Arun, it has a magical presence about it and when its all lit up of an evening it just gets better.... well worth a visit, take a river taxi to get there it just adds to the whole wonder of Bangkok

Nice Wat & trip. Have to take the 'ferry' to the other site but it's worth to do.
Nice view from the top of the Wat. Steep stairs to the top :-D
Another world. The Wat Arun just has to be experienced. It is totally different from anything us Europeans have seen before. Be there, take time - and do your homework before you come.
take the ferry. The temple is obviously really impressive and felt very tranquil, the gardens are lovely and travelling by skytrain and ferry makes the whole day really enjoyable.

great views. This was my least favorite of the three temples in the area, but was still amazing. The main draw here is that you get to climb up it for some amazing views. As other reviewers have said it does get steep in some parts. Easy to access by boat.

Must see for those wanting to appreciate beauty of refligion and culture.. An awe inspiring visit. So beautiful. Look out for the Angels and the Soldiers. Watch how the soldiers dress changes as you look higher up the main temple. You can take a walk up to top of temple but I personally think they should stop this idea as it can only cause harm to the temple exterior which is over...


More

Beautiful, unique, and a work out!!!. After going to the grand palace we took a quick boat ride to wat arun and were pleased we did. There are stairs that you can walk up on which were a little steep but worth it. We went in the morning which we recommend because as we were leaving(around noon) you can see the crowds coming in and it...


More

Climb the stairs. Climb the stairs, but be ready to sweat out. Don't do it if you are afraid of heights or have balance issues, as the stairs are very steep.
However, if you make the climb up to the top, be stunned at the beauty of Bangkok and the views. Simply stunning!!

You have to go in the morning!. This temple reaches up to greet the morning sun. The stones sparkle in the rays of the rising sun, thats how it was designed. The steps are VERY steep so if you have any dissabilities, walking up the temple is not an option. I got Vertigo coming down the steps...that being said what a beautiful stone structure, it is inlaid...


More

Great View of the river, but very steep steps!. This is a very old temple. It's worth seeing as "if" you can make the climb up, there is a wonderful view of the busy life of the river. It doesn't compare to the Grand Palace, so if you go, take it for what it is, a part of antiquity. After you leave there, walk to to river and pick up a Long boat for about 1200 bhat and take a trip to the long boat museum and a ride back in time to the james bond movie through the canals of bangkok. It was a fun ride. We even had the boat drop us off in Chinatown where we were staying.

The temple of dawn. A great temple easy to get to by river ferry, late afternoon is best a lot cooler, the climb to the top can be a little scary as it is so steep in parts, check out the many fish that surround the temple.

Be aware of pickpockets!. I loved the temple even though it was terribly hot and crowded. Our friend got rid of their money and documents so be warned and look out to your belongings when you are taking photos!
Architecture par Excellence. Excellent location on the river front, with the best from of designs used for constructing the monument and the surrounding areas.

Best temple in BKK. Can be seen from the river, but the detailed stone work is worth a close up. And for 50 baht, you shouldn't miss it. Best thing to do is go near sunset and see Wat Arun when they light it at night. Take the Chao Phraya Express Boat, and then a cross river ferry. Try not to go the tour/taxi/tuk tuk route. What makes this place special is its proximity to the river.
Another temple!. Took the ferry across the river to visit this temple, not too much to see but the views from the top are nice. Be warned that the second level of stairs is very steep!

Wonderfully preserved.. Great views across the river from a balcony level about 15m above ground, but steps to get there are very steep! Perhaps best not to try if you suffer from vertigo.Wat Arun is another excellent example of how well Thailand has preserved its cultural heritage. Definitely a must see in Bangkok, then hire a long tail boat from the jetty just outside the temple grounds for an exciting trip!

Especially nice at dusk. This is a magnificent temple to see. Very steep stairs lead up to about two-thirds of the way. Nice views of Bangkok. Make sure you stay on the other side of the river until the sun sets. the temple lit up is a sight to behold

Not as pretty as the postcards but thrilling nonetheless. Follow the crowd and you will find the cross points across the river and to the entrance of the wat. Enjoy the grounds, wait for a break in traffic, then make your ascent. The first two levels are rather normal, but the third is surprisingly steep, and even slightly strenuous. It is almost treacherous descending facing forwards. Not for the faint of heart, especially those who are afraid of heights!The view up there is interesting, but really not as pretty as the grounds themselves. My opinions will likely change if I got to see this wat in dusk or dawn.

Impressive Charming and Well Maintained. One of the oldest if not the oldest temples in Thailand with great views.Getting there can be tricky but fun filled also, as best is to take a boat ride.Climbing up its stairs is not for the fainthearted nor those with chronic fear of hights, but the views are absolutely worth it. Don't go with high heels nor slippery shoes though!Leave before 4pm/rush hour as the river is sort of a high/express way in Bangkok and the boats can get very busy.

Unique temple in the City. Of course we are not comparing this to those World Heritage site like Angkor Wat, but this temple have its beauty, its character in the City. Worth to go, it is just total 6 bath to pay for cross the river, go and back. Some tips to share with, the cross-river pier is located after the market which opposite the Wat Pho, there is plenty of dried food like dried fish, etc. You might walk to fisherman's pier and they might offer to send you to Wat Arun, but you just need to smile and reject them, then go to find the right one.
Beautiful!. Do not miss this historic landmark on the Chao Phya River! Take time to climb the steep steps and take a good look at Bangkok's skyline. The shops beneath are cheap.

outstanding temple. I saw it by boat which for me was the way to go. Its beautiful. Many visitors prefer to go a sunset for the views of Bangkok. And you can climb the steps and get some good pics. Its crowded. The boat was the only way for me. 500 baht for an hour. 650 baht for 1.5 hour round trip. To me this was the number one attraction in Bangkok. The temples in Ayutthaya to the north are more impressive.
Unique. This is one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. The steps climbing up may be a little bit scary for some people, but it is safe.

Impressive landmark!!!.... Wat Arun is top reference when visiting Bangkok, either crossing the river by local boat -- a nice ride along the lively Chao Pra river is a must, I always do it, and land on the pier close to the temple to climb up step by step to the top -- or watching it from the river, specially by night, amaizingly iluminated.It worth the visit but the most spectacular sight of the temple is really from the river, day or night, as it usually appears as theworld best known icon of Bangkok. Don't miss it from the river too!!!...

Don't look down. Been visiting BKK for the past 10 years and this was our first time at Wat Arun, can't believe we left it so long as it's beautiful!! The climb to the top is quite scary and tiring up the steep steps and the stairwells can get packed but you're rewarded with lovely views of the riverside and surrounding areas once you get there.
Loved it. Easy to get there from the Tha Tien pier, near WAT Po Enjoy the river views from the top! And the stairs down ;) a little steep

Amazing. we didn't had much time for temple hopping in Bangkok, and I think Wat Arun was a great choice. The site is magnificent, with its elaborate decoration and high towers. To get there,I recommend getting down at the Wongwian Yai metro station and getting a tuk-tuk to drive you there, it costed about 100 baht for two people, quite a deal compared to the 300 baht every driver asks to get you out of there.
Great !!!. Actually its a temple of dawn as I been there in the late evening, temple lited gave a great view. But climbing on the top is really tough as the steps are very steep.
for those who like a steep climb. Great views, and for the children a dressing up opportunity in traditional Thai clothing.The return ferry ride is 0.50 baht extra for some reason .

Across the river from Wat Pho.... Anther amazing temple which there are no shortage of in Thailand!
This temple with it's chedis decorated with intricate pieces of porcelain in-lay. A very steep climb and not for the faint of heart.
reminded me of climbing ruins in mexico.

My favorite old tourist attraction. Just across the river from other famous sites, such as the Palace, very photo-genic, and although I didn't do it, you can climb up it a fair way at a small cost I assume. Views across the river could be good from higher up
great for pics. great for pics, be careful steep steps to climb !!! alot history also here, also good idea to get boat cruise and drop u of at water front of temple (wat)

A Must See On A Trip To Bangkok. The stairs to clim the Central Prang are very steep, almost vertical, with some people having to come down backwards, so pretty much a no goer for people who have difficulty with stairs, or are scared of heights.However, one you get to the top, the views along the River and across too the Grand Temple are magnificent.Purchase a ticket for day travel on the River and just jump on and off at your leisure, which allows you to visit Grand Palace, Wat Arun, Chinatown and all the other famous attractions of this fabulous city.

If you need to try traditional costume. If you visit Grand Palace Of Thailand then Wat Pho So you must make it to this temple too.From the exit of Wat Pho then you turn left walk along to Ta Tien Pier.. (the boat fee only 3 baht) This temple have the a beautiful Mosaic Pagoda, a bot older than Wat Pho.. Best thing that a it difference from Wat Pho is You can try Thai traditional costume only 200 baht and take a photo in this temple :)It's should be very fun if you with your friends doing this thingI wish everyone enjoy BKK, ThailandNo FREE ENTRY...

Best Attraction in Bangkok. The Grand Palace can be quite crowded, the surrounding temples are typically surrounded by touts and roads that can be difficult to traverse, but Wat Arun was the perfect contrast.The view from the top of Wat Arun is magnificent! Make sure you include a trip to this wonderful monument as part of your trip in Bangkok.

Excellent. While at a certain moment you have the impression that all temples are the same, there is suddenly a temple which allows you to have another view on the Thai temple architecture. I had more the impression that it is more a construction than a temple where Buddha statues are located. Furthermore, the temple gave me a South American impression whereby the middle temple was something you could climb on (big steps so watch out!). once you have climbed somewhat, you have an impressive view on the river banks and the Grand Palace at the other side of the river. If you want to get there, don’t be mislead by any kind of taxi driver who wants to take you over one of the bridges, just go to the pier located next to the grand Palace and in just a few minutes and for a limited amount of money you are just in front of the Wat Arun.

History and culture. It gets to a point where one feels "all burnt out" there is only so much one can take! Thailand is full of temples, monuments and markets. Getting to these attractions through Bangkok traffic, with the exception of the excellent BTS sky train is an experience in itself.
A must See Wat. They all started to look the same after a while, but this was on of the first that saw and it blew me away. If you're making a list, this one should be a top Wat.

Great chance to climb up and get close to a beautiful Temple. We went a trip on the local ferries up and down the river before finally getting off and visiting Wat Arun. The main attraction here is the chance t climb the central Prang. The stairs are quite steep and it is actually more tricky going down than up. That said it should not be difficult for any able bodied person. The Prang is fabulously decorated and by climbing it you get the chance to see this up close and also an opportunity to view wider Bangkok and the river area. The wider Wat site is nice without being anything special. Cost is 50bht. Wat Arun is a very nice site to visit. It gives the chance to get up close to the architecture and you should combine a pleasant boat trip over the river on the local ferries.

Steep Steps. Taking a boat across the river to this temple is worth it.
Just be careful of the steep steps from level 1 to 2. Step sideways.
The architectural details are very intricate. A nice view of the grand palace and the bangkok skyline across the river as well.

Impressive!. My husband and I did this tour on our own and really enjoyed the experience of the shuttle boats to get there. It is very impressive and the climb to the top was extremely steep. Not for the faint hearted, but well worth it if you can manage it!
Must go. perfect location - combining old and new architecture. very good experience from Bangkok. take a guided tour for explanation about the site

Refreshingly free of tourists. Take the Tha thien pier ferry for 3 baht (one price for everyone,which was refreshing) pretty awe inspiring temple with some amazing views in the early morning and definately worth the climb and 50baht entry

Beautiful temples i've ever seen. As we went to wat pho, we're lucky there's a festival in Wat arun that the boat can stopby here for 20 minutes. That's was so terrific and interesting big temples. Really great and amazing..

Beautiful View of the Bangkok. Outside the downtown (Ratankosin) this is the site I liked the most for its architecture, carvings and beautiful view of Chao Phraya river and Bankok. It has very steep steps, dress code applies (and so does entrance fees) but it is worth doing.
must see. a must see in bangkok! you don't want to miss Wat Arun - its beautiful! you can climb to the top but be ware it is very, very steep!

Simply Stunning - especially at night. We did a night bicycle tour of Bangkok (Grasshopper Adventures) and stopped here at night, when hardly anybody else was around and the Wat is beautifully flood lit. So beat the crowds and take in a beautiful Wat in the cool of the evening. We had teenagers in our party and it is definitely the way to ensure they appreciate the temple. Highly recommended!!!

large and nice temple. it's quite large, it takes quite a while to explore all of the temple, the sleeping budha is so gorgeous. nice architechture, and in some part so quite so you can feel calm and refereshing
Excellent complex. The temples are great. I was able to hear the monks chanting at the largest temple. The temple of dawn is worth the climb up. It is very scary but quite rewarding.

Amazing Architecture. A beautiful temple with amazing architecture, statues and dragons.
Free bottled water available, as well as cool moist tissues.
The experience was only marred by one western tourist climbing up the sacred site for photographs, despite being asked to respect the Thai culture.
magnificent vertical spire. You can climb up for views of the surrounding areas. It is quite crowded but it's a big name temple. Taxi from my hotel was about $3
Wat Arun. Love the architecture here makes for some great pics, short trip across the river on a ferry boat, nice half day of sightseeing

Wonderful sight. It's a fine sight from dusk till dawn. Visiting this wat quite early in the morning (8.30 am) before the flock of tourists are there is amazing. The sun is not that high so you will still have the energy to climb the steep stairs up to the "top" floor of the temple. It's a wonderful view from there. And don't forget to really look into the elaborate details of the wat. The porcelains and the glasses are really beautiful.
Panoramic Views. Easily accessible, great climb and breathtaking panoramic views of the old city. Also see the beautiful gardens next to the Wat.
A must visit. A very unusual type of temple, nice views of the river, a bit of excitement with the vertigo at height..

View from the river. Wat Arun looks so pretty when you are on a boat and you can take really good pictures of it. It has a different architectural style than Thai style of temples. It is Cambodian style if I am not mistaken. It is one not to miss when you are in Bangkok.
Lovely...but.... Such a beautiful temple but marred by the presence of very persuasive touts. It;s a shame, as this temple is so lovely and has a very peaceful demenour.....

Fantastic. This Temple looks nothing from across the river but close up it is amazing. We climbed the steps, which are shallow and steep but it was worth it for the view. Lots to see in the small park around the Temple as well

Stunning temple on the banks of the river. Try to arrive by boat its the best approach. The stonework is magnificent and the surrounding gardens/buildings are also worth a look. When climbing the main pagola be prepared for a steep ascent and even steeper decent, the climb is not one for the vertigo sufferers out there.

Awesome!. We visit Wat Arun after we visited the Grand Palace (it is across the river). It was very easy to get to from the Grand Palace, and only cost a few cents. The views were spectacular, the architecture was amazing, and it was cool because you actually can climb up the stairs. We were really hot, so hats came in handy! Also, be sure to cover up before going to the Wat.
Great climb to the top!. Try to climb to the top, nice view, and interesting experience! Be careful when you go down and warm yourself up before getting to the top, so that you won't get cramps

Worth a Visit. This was a great spot, not as crowded as the others. You can take a water taxi across the river for 3 bhat and entry is 50 bhat. You can climb up pretty high which is neat and gives good views. There is also a market and a nice park on the river next to the temple.

One of my favorite thing in the world.. Wat Arun is surreal. I've been to Bangkok on several occasions but I did not have the chance to visit this temple and boy am I glad to have finally visited Wat Arun. The temple absolutely stands out in the city of Bangkok like some sort of fantasy, like a mirage. It gave me the goosebumps.Oh, remember to wear clothes which cover your shoulders and long pants or trousers which go all the way down to your ankle. Leggings/ripped jeans/low-cut/scarfs/shawls will not do.

really a nice place. The style of it is Angkor Wat style, and if you have booked the tickets of Grand Palace and Jade Buddha Temple, the Temple of Down is free.when you standing in the top of the temple, you will have a full view of the Wat Pho Temple.

Ancient beauty. We saw a lot of the bangkok historical sites in one day and each one was wonderful. I loved the respect that is shown for the temples and the traditions that are part of it all. The Temple was beautiful.

So blessed me...just great!. I was there with my whole family and I can say that its a place that you should see close one time in this life! Not just because nice view surrounded you when you stand on the top of Prang of wat Arun but you can feeling of spirit, feeling blessing, also what you should not miss is to go inside Ubosot ( Building in the center of Arun Temple ) You will see one of beautyful Buddha form that stay in the middle and people give their respect as a Buddish way around. One time in a life... you will love this place not less than Grand Palace also.

Must do for any tourist. Visit the palace, the reclining Buddha and then pay 3 THB to get to the other side of the river to visit the temple of dawn. Impressive, and go up all the stairs, unless you fear height.
have to see. it is an amazing temple...definitely wort to see just be careful of a very steep steps while you go down :-)

Unique with great views. This temple/stupa is beautiful and only 50 baht to get into. The architecture and art is stunning and unique to many of the temples and stupas that I saw in Myanmar and Thailand. You can climb almost halfway up for views of the city.
Great as usual. Great place and if you not afraid with the height climb up the stairs and go the peak of the temple, very good view to look at Bangkok metropolis

Beautiful temple to visit. If you're interested in buddhist and Thai temples, you will love Wat Arun. It's position right on the river means that at twilight the silhouette of the temple is beautiful. Once you get up close you can see the intricate detail of all the tiles. If you want to climb to the top of the Wat, remember that it's really steep and looks even steeper from the top looking down! It's worth it though. A vibrant place with lots of visitors.

give it a climb. the climb sounds like a bit of a joke from other travellers. the first flight makes you laugh and feel like its nothing. the second flight of steps makes you a bit nervous and the final climb to the top makes you worried about dropping you camera and realising the both hands are firmly on the handrail. the view is ama-zing and worth every bit of nervous laughter. loved it until i had to go down and had to do a sideward crab walk
Chinese tour groups. Too many massive Chinese tour groups. Noisy and get in the way. Arrive early and move away from the crowded areas to get some peace.

Must go. I have gone to several temples in Thailand and I would have to say this is one of the best. It went though it with a guide, and it is really amazing. Having constructions of different cultures as Thai and Chinese, amazing paintings and it gives you the chance of being able to go through the ritual of thanking with the lotus flower and the whole process. Don't forget to buy water outside as inside it is really expensive. Yes, I really think you should go.
Beautiful temple on the river. Beautiful little temple on the river. The temple is in excellent condition considering its age. I really enjoyed my visit to this temple which was part of a canal tour.
good place to visit.. have guide explain to you what each architecture and design represent. I went there on a bicycling night tour and had a good guide to brief me the history,

The temple of dawn worth a visit. There are so many Wat's (temples) in Bangkok, that it can be difficult to choose among them. But Wat Arun is one worth to pay a visit. It is very different from the other temples.

Gorgeous!. Definitely worth a visit. Stopped by here when we had a guide for the day - good excuse to get across the river. The entire temple is made from old porcelain used as ballast on otherwise empty trade boats returning from China.
Do not miss... Do take the river taxi/ferry across. And do climb up the amazingly steep steps for the experience and a wonderful view of the city and river traffic. A must visit.

A must see!. This is a must if you are heading to Bangkok, it's an amazing sight.
Ladies remember to cover up, a shawl wrapped round your shoulders isn't enough, you must wear a TShirt that actually covers your shoulders.
Beautiful. You need to hike to the top to see the magnificent view of Bangkok. Absolutely beautiful! I highly recommend you visit.

Beautiful!. The temple and its grounds are beautiful! Go here before or after going to the Palace and Reclining Buddha (take the city ferry across the river for 3Baht to get to the palace and reclining buddha-dont try to avoid the crowds and take the long boats- very rocky and splashy and hard to get in and out of at the doc and 100baht each).

probably the number one sight in BKK. Often done in combination with a river trip, Wat Arun is a beautiful temple building on the banks of the Chao Phraya river and allows for great views and photo ops if one can be bothered to climb up the steep stairs. But do it and you'll be rewarded with a fabulous view across the river and a real feeling of spirituality and otherness...Incidentally, don't forget to buy some fish feed or bread from the old women next to the ferry walkway. Just watch what happens when you throw the bread into the river and the monstrous feeding frenzy starts below with giant catfish and other huge fish start leaping across each other for food. Fantastic!

Remarkeble. Remarkable trip from Nana BTS station to Saphan Taksin BTS Station, then pay 100 bht for the boat direct to the temple. (It might be cheaper in another way). The temple is well protected and still in good condition.

I love the boat trip. A nice temple with not much to see. After you walk around the best photo ops are from the boat going to or leaving the temple. I liked the lack of people selling crap at the site. It's a quieter place to go.

Nice views and mosaics. This temple has a great location right on the river offering great views from the top. The steps are steep but fun. Wear appropriate temple-worthy clothing or they will force you to rent a set.
Must See. We arrived on a water taxi with a tour group. This is a must see, breath taking! If you are up for it, you can walk up the 3 levels or just enjoy from the bottom.
Beautiful. A river taxi is used to get there and back. This is an absolutely beautiful temple with great views across the river once you climb up.

Lovely to enjoy at sunset. This was a fabulous temple to climb and enjoy the views of the city across the river. It is best enjoyed at sunset from across the river in a clean and grassy park behind the pier

Must see!. I'm not one for much culture, not too interested in history, etc.... but this place is amazing. We didn't spend long there but it is spectacular and I would definitely say visitors must see it.

Nice old temple by the river. We rented a longtailed boat for 1.5 hours and the driver made a stop here for 30 minutes, which is more than enough to see the place. One of the few temples you can climb up the steep steps.
a bit scary climbing up but nice view of bangkok. fromw at pho ride a ferry boat to wat arun , costs 3 baht. steep climb up the temple. admission fee 50 baht.

AWESOME!. a must visit place in Bangkok. a magical experience! loved it!
idol of lord Ganesha was surprising. good to see people respect Hindu gods and Hinduism!

Wat Arun. Beautifully situated on banks of river and easy to get to via the ferry. Read up about it before you go, because there is not much information for visitors. You can climb up the structures, although beware as you get higher up the stairs get steeper! Gorgeous place, tranquil and not particularly busy considering it was Christmas and Bangkok is full of tourists.
A must. Not so many tourists as in some other temples, very nice porcelain covered shedis.Nice view of Bangkok if you climb all the stairs.
Majestic. Wow, the climb up is steep, and the views are amazing, the souvenir shop near the exit has great Ts to be picked up at amazing prices!!

Good. Go to teh temple via teh river if you can, take aright at teh end of teh parking lot and keep walking. Be carefull of people telling you it is closed becaus eof a sopecial service taking place or for other reasons, they are trying to get you into a taxi and to take you to another temple. Just ignore them it is open every day. The temple is impressive and great for photos.

Majestic. If you are in the area you must see this beautiful pagoda. You can climb a considerable way up, though the stairs are very steep. Among the temples in this area, this one has a very different look and feel.

Beautiful at night. Interesting temple. Good views of Bangkok from the top. If you stay in the area long enough to see it at night from the river ferry, it (and all the other temples) are beautiful at night. I'd definitely recommend one night trip on the river ferry.

Favourite site!. This is my favourite site in Bangkok.It is best to visit in the morning. The sun is very strong so the AM and a bit cooler air helps. The stairs up the temple are very steep. Must wear good closed shoes. All of the sites have lots of tourist, I would recommend to do this one before the Grand Palace.The best photo is from pier.

Amazing detailed temple by the side of the river. This temple differs from others as it's central towers (prangs) are covered in broken porcelain pieces, each one unique. You could spend hours looking at them allIf you are feeling fit, climb up the tower and enjoy the view of the river and the city.Catch a boat over to the temple and then, after spending a hour or so there, hail a long tail boat and explore some of the nearby canals and backwaters.
Great view. Very impressive. Easy access by boat (just 3 BHT crossing) from a pier where the tourist boat stops as well. Great view. Not for people with fysical handicap.

love the architecture and view from top. there is nothing much to enjoy around the temple except the architecture and if you in good condition to climb the stairs up, the view is worth the climb. architecture is amazing on the details of each pieces on its wall. the stairs up is very very very steep - so always be careful especially when u climb down. there is fee to get closer to the Wat or if you're not into climb the stairs up - the view from outside is enough to get a good picture of the Wat. there is small coffee shop at the compound where you can buy a coffee or cold drink and sit at the bench enjoying the Wat view.to get here is by transfer ferry from across the river pier - it cost only THB 15 (if i remember it well).
Worth a visit. It is something to go and see while in Bangkok. Scary stairs. I was terrified going up, and almost died coming down, but I am a little scared of heights! Overall worth the trip.

Challenging Climb. Awesome structure, not easy to reach from the business district, but definitely worth it. The less fit (or those with small kids) will find the climb up the Prang (tower) challenging. Once you have made it, the vistas are breathtaking.

What a view. On a clear day you can see a huge part of Bangkok from the top of Wat Arun. The view is probably the most important reason for going there. From an architectural standpoints it's fairly interesting but wouldn't overwhelm you.Still, pick up a clear day and enjoy the sunrise (or alternatively the late afternoon when the sun lights Bangkok's skyline)
Amazing!. Wow. The temples are just beautiful and unexpected. Worth spending the day walking around. Would definitely recommend seeing as many as you can as they are all so different.
My favorite. You have to take a feryy to it; the river express does not stop on the Wat Arun side. Great to see in the morning and the evening for the right light

Wat Arun, yet most beautiful at sunset!. Even though I am Thai and I've lived in Bangkok for most of my life, I do not recall visit Wat Arun. Though apparently I have visited there once when I was a kid according to my parents, as I did not recall it (at all nor there were pictures), this visit in January 2013 is my first experience. Always hearing friends mentioning it, I've always wanted to go to Wat Arun, but I didn't put in too much effort. But I really regret it now, because it turns out to be one of the most amazingly beautiful temples I've ever visit. On top of the Phra Prang you can see the skyline of Bangkok and the outline of the Chao Phaya river from North to South. It was a beautiful scene. Furthermore, hiking up those steep stairs are challengingly fun. Going up makes me laugh for a while. Looking down those set of steep stairs gave me a fright, and actually going down was simplier than I anticipated. Don't recommends from young kids, people with knee injuries or older people with joint problems though. Anyway, I think it's definitely worth it. Coming from a Bangkok-er

Temple nice but beware of theives. I was ripped off by a boat driver who said he would take me and a companion to several sites, etc along the river. He dumped us off at the Wat and never finished the tour. The ferry is only 5 cents. Learning the system in Bangkok is a nightmare and G-Adventure tour guides don't help at all.There really isn't anything "inside" the temple since it is all outdoors with lots of climbing. It is beautiful however.

Great different temple. Very nice temple - and very different to the others. BHT 50 pp to get in and you can go up the steep stairs along the side. Great detail along the temple with the statues and mozaics. It's great to catch a transfer across the river and see this temple on the same trip as Grand Palace (river transfer BHT3 pp one way).

Wat Arun. A must on the to do list.. just before boarding the boat there is alittle food spot to sit and eat Great food by locals and quite awesome .. Just know when at the Wat they all want money if you take photos and you can also pay for fish food to feed the fish.. Oh yes look around the grounds The Amazing Race was filmed here ..Great free photo opp.. ..
Temple of dawn-the only one. Great and beautiful.Note: be careful of your steps,,ascending seems easy but descending a bit of steep...

Wow!. This is definitely not a "seen one temple, seen them all". The work on this -- all pieces of ceramic porcelain and glass, leave you standing there wondering, how did they do this? It is so amazing! Climb and climb -- but keep in mind, the stairs are steep so be careful -- good views the higher you go plus you are surrounded by a most colorful array of art. A definite must see while in Bangkok.

BEAUTIFUL!. Breathtaking- a must see! The intricate designs of the temple are unbelievable. You can walk up the steep stairs of the temple and visit Buddha inside. GIRLS- make sure you bring a scarf and/or wrap skirt to cover your legs and arms.

A Must on Your Itinerary. Very ornate temple, and lovely grounds. Climb the STEEP steps up for a 360 view of Bangkok. The whole temple is amazingly covered in a mosaic made of bits of porcelain. The temple and grounds are landscaped and include many interesting statues. It all sits right on the river bank, so there is lots and lots to see. Don't miss it!
climb the steps. worth visiting just to climb up the steps for the view. they are ridiculously steep but you do get a different view from the top. oh but then you have to get down again...
Ancient temple. The Khmer-era Cambodian temples are impressive, but I prefer the more modern wats such as Wat Pho. Crazy, steep steps--too steep for me!

Loved it, worthy of steps. My fave wot in Bangkok. It was well worth the steep steps you take to go upend down. Very intricate design. Great view of the city from the top. We really liked it and nearly didn't go as we had seen a few wots and this was further away form our hotel. Must visit.

Must see. This should be on top of your list. One of the highlights of our trip. Brilliant view from the top of the temple. Just be extra careful when you walk up the steep staircase (do not try this drunk). You can then take the ferry across to the other side of the river (5 baht) and visit Wat Po (reclining buddha)

Vow!. This is gradient teaser! Have never seen such steep architecture! Very very beautiful. The experience of crossing the chao praya river to see the wat arun is like the journey of life to reach the ultimate! Not to be missed! The aerial views from the top of the spires are vow!
great views. not as busy as the other temples. grat views if you are willing to climb very steep steps to the top!!

A Don't Miss Attraction. From the river the central tower of Wat Arun looks kinda gray. But get up close and you see it's a riot of color from embedded ceramic chips, discs, etc.The place is different than any other wat in Bangkok. Admission, at only 50 baht, is 1/2 that for Wat Pho across the river

Must-see wat!. Intricate detailed showcase of Thai Buddhist temple architecture. Dates from the 1600s, although some parts go back older. Must see: pieces of Chinese porcelain used in floral motifs as temple exterior finishing. Caution: some climbing of steep steps may be involved.

One of the best temples I have seen in Bangkok.... The main temple is quite steep and it may be challenging for people with leg problems. Make sure you hold on tight to the rail. Going down is twice harder and may be horrifying for those who are afraid of heights. Right outside the arched doorway, you'd find a stand where you can have your pictures taken wearing traditional costumes and head piece at 300baht. The results are promising and the price is average -not a rip off in my opinion.

Incredible temple, watch your step!. This temple is gorgeous from a distance and we knew we had to see it up close. The steps are incredibly steep and dangerous but well worth the trip when you climb to the top and experience the view. It was one of the best temples we saw until we went to Angkor Wat in Cambodia. My legs are still feeling the burn lol!

Worth the effort. Wat Arun is unlike any other temple. It is extraordinary close up as it is covered in pottery and ceramic mosaic. It's a steep climb to the top, but the views are expansive. It will take about 40 minutes to take the short boat ride, climb the Wat, walk around and return. Locals pronounce it as Wat Alun. Handy when directing a taxi driver.
Impressive. Impressive but older and not as beautiful as the Grand Palace and Wat Poh - looks more impressive when seen from the river at night

A great place to visit. From faraway you don't imagine , the treasure of this architecture .The temple is cover of porcelain plates and mirrors, with fantastic statues, as well you can climb the tower central, just be careful with the stif steeps. The fee is only 50 baths, but it is worth to pay to get in.

Not the one to be missed or excused. Even though there are 4000+ wats around bangkok, this is a very distinct temple. if you planning to Visit the Grand palace include this too in your list. You can atke a ferry to reach this place to cross the river which would cost you just 2THB. Also, from this place you can take boat to all across chao Phraya river and have the fantastic view of the city all around

Awe inspiring. This is extremely unique, fantastic design and decor, way too tall to get in one good photo. You can also see it from Google Earth, but you need to go there in person. After viewing in awe from a distance, you can go up close and walk almost all the way up. Lots of pathways to look at the decorations, say a little prayer, or take in the views when you get higher up.Don't leave Bangkok without seeing this unique and fascinating temple.

MY favourite... Quieter than WatPo and the Royal Palaces. Lots of time to look around without the queues, hustle and hassle of the main attractions. Nice boat ride to this and feels much more personal...
The Essence of Thai Buddhism. I'm interested on Buddhism and this place and buddhist of Thailand people made me calm
