Great view and lovely architecture. Great showcase if Thai culture and architecture.. Must visit. You can take a ferry or take the train and then can it up. Entry fee is 50 baht. Dress moderately.

A must see. Fabulous temple, awesome sight on the approach from the river. Quite easy to see The Grand Palace, Wat Pho and Wat Arun all on the same day if you take the river boat express between them (about 35 bhatt per boat journey). A lot less busy than The Grand Palace yet still stunning. A must do.

Best Temple. Avoid the crowds at the grand palace and instead stop at this very old and very cool temple. Easily accessible by ferry (3THB to cross) from the Grand Palace side of the river, this temple has a great view from the top, is very accessible, and far less crowded than the Grand Palace. Definitely would reccomend for anyone in Bangkok.
very cool climb. many recommend it as a dawn or dusk visit, i went midday, was my favorite venue of the Grand Palace, Wat Pho, Emerald Buddha complex. the climb is steep but worth it.
A must go temple. Climb up to level 1 & 2 of the temple, the view down are beautiful. Temple structure and design are perfect

Climbing to the top is Awesome!. The steps are awesome. You have to walk sideways coming down because the steps are a bit higher than what you might be used to climbing. Nice view from the top and you can take a lof ot photos!
worth the time. Architecture of building is nice, quite a big area, nothing much there just a temple . travel by boat service over to the temple.

Mystical. Make sure you see this place, even if you just have time to see one attraction in Bangkok. And if you can, try to climb the stairs - which is hard since they get taller as you ascend - to see how amazing Wat Arun and Bangkok are.

less cared. We have visited this temple 9 years ago, and to our dismay now it looks more damaged, comparing it to the emerald budha temple (inside grand palace) this looks like neglected, too pity as this is a temple with different view, it only looks great now unde the spotlight at nite as you take cruise with the boat for dinner or something like that

Hard walk up but worth it!. This wat is a lot smaller than some of the others so you don't need as much time to make the most of it. What is amazing about it is that you can walk up and get a fantastic view of Bangkok. Hard walk up but definitely worth it!
Worth the visit. Yes the climb is not for everyone but we loved being there lat in the afternoon and catching the views too

Is a must for you to go!!. This is a temple that not crowded with tourists, therefore I found a sense of peace over there. Climbing up the staircase to the highest peak is a bit scary, but you can see the entire view which is worth for it travelling so for to here!!!

Well worth a visit. Well worth a trek to the top of the temple if you have strong legs and a head for heights! beautiful ornate structure with ceramic tiles, buddhas galore and crumbly stone work.Grab the ferry for a few cents and also see the Reclining Buddha.

A pleasant way to spend an hour. There is a danger of becoming temple, palace or Wat fatigued in Bangkok as there are so many and after a while they all look the same. However, when you're in Bangkok, you can't miss the Royal Palace, Wat Po or Wat Arun

really nice. take the cheap boat just across the river, it goes every few minutes, don't go there by guide. The tempel is great and high, the steps are really big so be prepared to climb. Visit the tempel by daytime and go back by evening or night to the other side of the river, there a great view of the tempple

One of must see when in Bangkok. Took the trip by boat. Tool few pictures, the temple was one of must place to visit when in Bangkok when it's your 1st time there.Took 2 group of my friends & they were happy.

beautiful monument. imposing chedi on the banks of the Chao Phraya. Fascinating to wander around, and seemingly not one of the places canvassed by "guides". Also a nice scene from the river at sundown.

Beautiful at night. Passing by at night, this iconic temple truelly stands out .
During the day, it appears to be bland in comparisson to the other tourist temples nearby. There is not alot of activity until dusk.
The staircase is very steep and offers the climber the reward of superb scenic views across Chao Phraya river
from the boat. We saw this temple from our long tail boat but it was so pretty seeing it from the river, especially at sunset.
Climb the Mountain. A classic temple with great views. Don't miss it. I liked going their just before closing at 6 PM. Great night views of the city. Free admission at 5:45 PM.

very impressive. This Temple is famous for its high bell shape structure and you can climb on it to have a good view of Bangkok city. The stairs are high and little difficult to climb, but once you reach up, you forget the pain when you see the beautiful sunset from here. Fee is 50 baht.To reach to this temple, you have to cross the river (pay 3 baht) from Wat Poh (Temple of Reclining Buddha) side. The garden is huge with beautiful lawns , and lots of flowers, specially colorful lotus flowers, bloom in it. Must wear proper fully covering dress and remove your shoes to enter into the Buddha Temples any where in this country. Photography inside the shrines is not allowed.

Great from afar, less impressive close up.. From a boat on the river this temple looks amazing and very grand. When you actually get up close to the temple the paint work is very old and and it looks dirty compared to others we visited. The view of Bangkok from the top is good.

Lit up at night this is a major Bangkok landmark. Ancient and grand this is a superior temple design, with spectacular detail, it dominates the riverside especially at night, good to pass it by on a riverboat at night.

Beautiful. Extremely beautiful temple, although less interesting than Wat Pho in my opinion. Still if you are in Bangkok for a couple of days or more, and have an interest in temples or historical monuments, you should certainly make the effort to do Wat Arun.

Amazing with great views. A nice place to visit across the river 50 b entry fee with 3 b each way on the ferry. I liked it the steps were steep! Great views. You need to be moderately dressed t shirts and shorts. Shorter skirts are not allowed or singlet tops.

Beautiful temple. I really liked the style of this temple. It looks great from the river. For 3 baht, you can get the boat across the river to this temple. The temple is surrounded by some nice gardens and the entry fee is very reasonable at 50 baht. The stairs to climb up this temple are huge and my legs were aching for days afterwards but its worth it for the view.

Great views - but not for the fainthearted. This is must is you are in Bangkok, just across the water from Wat Pho and truly magnificent. Get the ferry accross from Wat Pho and you are there. The temple complex is large, but the main attraction is the tower. You can climb up to the 3rd level, but it is not for the fainthearted, the steps are incredibly steep, but the view is worth it. Plan your trip, so that you get here before sunset, then you can stay on the other side of the river after dusk and see the temple lit up.
beauteful place. The altitude of the Wat is impresesd. It is located opposite the Grand Palace and Wat Pho - on the other side of the River.The entrance costs 50 BatThe ferry to pier - 3 Bat
Great river cruise to a lovely Temple. Its a beautiful temple, facing the river. The details on this temple is amazing. Its great to learn the history here

Great to look from a far. If you think of visiting Temple of Dawn. You should cross the river and take photo from the opposite side as well, it is beautiful to at from some distance and best to look at dawn. A great place to observe and chill out is at a small bar called "Amerosa" on top of "The Deck" Thai restaurant located exactly opposite the temple. Recommend to make reservation for table near the river.

A serene and beautiful temple.. YOu get to it from the Wat Pho dock on the shuttle boats that ply between the two temples. The fare is a whopping 3 Bahts each way. WE also liked the lack of trinket vendors here unlike around Wat Pho.
Don't miss it. Authentic and less touristy than the wats on the main side of the river, often full with monks in session. Great climb to the top

breathtaking. Looooved the boat ride to the temple, and the view from the top. The climb up was pretty easy, coz I didn't look back... but coming down was scary as hell...not in a negative way, in a thrilling way... I'm not really scared of heights, yet, this was a steep climb down and I was scared out of my wits especially coz I went there alone, and there were just 3-4 fellow visitors around.But it was gorgeous and definitely a must-see.
Great view!. The view from this temple was awesome. It was fun to climb the stairs but less fun on the way back down. Not for those afraid of heights!
Beautiful View from across the River. Take a long boat ride down the river and view it close up...then travel the canals which have earned the title of Venice of Asia...don't miss this!

Mini Angkor Wat?. It is just alke Angkor Wat and maybe that's the reason I really liked it. I walk around the temple and the tower every lawyer. Be careful esp, you're big in body shape and got problem on knee or dizzle at height. Best visit time is sunset, not scorching and you can enjoy sunset. Nothing much worth seeing nearby so take round ferry (3B) to No 8 Pier station.
Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun). especially at sunrise and sunset you'll have some great moments oposite the temple watch out from the docks where the boats stop by
Beautiful.. Beautiful. Simply art. Another excellent showcase of Thailand's beauty. Remember to dress well, bring a shawl and cover your knees.
serenity now. Temples in general are a flavor of Thailand that you should not miss out on. No matter what your religious beliefs are Temples in Thailand offer serenity and exoticness.

Serene!. Instead of dawn, we reached the temple at dusk and absolutely loved it! Great architecture - takes u back in time.. The place is very quiet and calm and you can sit here for hours and hours.. There is something spiritual about this place which makes you love it instantly.. The view is also spectacular! The steps are really steep and definitely not recommended for the week knees! As it is a religious place, they expect you to have your legs and shoulders covered.. In case you don't, then they have clothes that you can rent for just 20 baht..The prayer time is 3 PM.. We missed it, but am sure it must be worth attending!

Really amazing to see up-close but think carefully about the steps!. Seeing Wat Arun was truly amazing, particularly seeing the scale of the building and the style of the decoration up close. We did make the climb up the steep steps and found it difficult on the way up and VERY difficult on the way down! The rope handrail is hardly any help at all. If you have any doubts about your safety on the steps, just don't take it on. The view from the top is pleasant but you can get nice views from other places. The main thing is to see the building itself, and the trip across the river is cool too.
Avoidable. Nice temple, but why is there an entrance fee of THB 50? Also very steep steps, so cant climb really...could be better maintained...far from city. so avoidable

Beautiful, awe-inspiring. Across the Chao Praya river, its towers look majestic though dirty (because of the colour of the stones/rocks used). Very cheap to cross the river from Tha Tien Pier- 3 baht/pax. Just a mere min away too. Low entry fee- 50 baht/pax. No strict dress code. Compact temple. Up close, the structure is truly awesome. Take extra care going up and coming down the steps as they are very steep, esp the second tier. Not for the faint-hearted as knees would go weak coming down. Leave bulky items eg prams at the entrance to pick up again later.
Very specific and qiuet place for such a megapolis. You can reach this temple only boat and it makes the adventure more romantic. The dawn there is beautiful !

Thailand. I was just looking at my pictures of Thailand and thinking how lovely the buildings like Wat Arun are and would like to go back and see more. The ticket in was one of the more expensive places we toured but with the exchange rate its basically not a big deal and well worth going to Wat Arun and other area temples.(Did not going in Jan 2012 but the site doesnt give you options for other dates.)

Beautiful! But beware of touts.. This is a must-see in Bangkok. Do beware though of the almost countless Thai men who will approach you on your way to the temple to tell you that it is "closed for Buddha day/king visit/cleaning etc" as this is NOT TRUE and you will be robbed/scammed.

The must see Temple in BKK. Wat Arun is like Angkor Wat in Cambodia or the Great Wall in China...it is a must see for any traveler. I was lucky enough to see the temple complex with menacing storm moving in. The temple with the backdrop of the dark clouds made for some amazing pictures!

Excellent view and details. One of the temples I really enjoyed.. You can see this temple when you are in the Chao Phraya River, but nothing compares with the experience when you get to climb it. The stairs were very steep but the view from above was amazing. The temple was really breathtaking. 50 THB entrance when you want to climb it.To get to this temple, go to the Tha Tian Pier just across Wat Pho. There is a designated boat to Wat Arun. The fee is just 3 THB. This is a must see (and experience) in Bangkok :)

Amazing even after the Grand Palace. Although you can see this temple from the other side of the other side of the river, it is worth the trip across to see it up close. The unique and varied ceramic tiling that covers the temple is mesmerizing up close and the climb up, although a little terrifying, provides an excellent view-point to watch the chaos on the river and look back on the Grand Palace.Tip: Women should be sure to bring a covering for shoulders and either pants or a long skirt/dress. Otherwise you will be forced to rent a wrap around skirt and scarf at 20B each with a 100B deposit.

Steep steps but worth the view. Simple pretty temple on the banks of the river, fun to get to (by boat) and will get the metabolism working if you decide to climb the steps up the sides to see the city view

river cruise in Bangkok. I really like that place. I thought Wat Arun was well worth the trip. This temple is also accessible by boat, so if you are taking a river cruise in Bangkok or a river ferry on the Chao Phraya, it will bring you directly to the temple entrance.
great views, steep climb. beautiful ceramics coat the surface of this khermer style temple in the heart of bangkok. climb up to the top to get great views of the city.

Very interesting!. Took a tour boat ride over to this temple! Great view from the top across the river to the city! Temple had interesting architecture, was different then something I have seen before! really Enjoyed this temple!

Absolutely wonderful. Having been to Bangkok 14 times, this was my first time at the Wat Arun. Boy do I regret that! This is the most wonderful place in Bangkok and almost no other tourists at all :-) If you only have time to visit one attraction in Bangkok, go here!

Fantastic Khmer's architecture. Really worth to see this. Build in the khmer's style, different from Thai style (the small temple is adjacent to Wat Arun so it is easy to compare). Be extremely carefull with the stairs, i would even call them ladder rtaher than stairs. do not expect "safety first" there as well...

Magnificient Ayyuthaya era monuments. We just loved our visit to Wat Arun including the ferry crossing of Chao Phrya river, the monument grounds, the climb up the various layers, the decorations on the wall, the view from the top . The shops doting the grounds made an impression too and I enjoyed the coconut water drink after visit. Please note that the steep climb is physically demanding and might not suit every one. Please note that here is dress code too and if you are wearing shorts and exposing your shoulder , you can hire add on garments to fit you in. . It is outside the normal tour group route but I fee it is a must if you are on your own while travelling in Bangkokj.

I can climb to that temple with mas Ridwan and pak Irwan. At the first trip of my visit to Thailand was to this Temple at Wat Arun. We will cross the river with a special "ship".It is good experience because before we crooss the river we can take foto with the MONKS there.. If you finish crossing so you reah the temple.. My experience was great because I could climb the temple and give motivativation to some friends to join climbing the temple. It is really high. You must brave and strong if you decide to climb it.

definitely worth a visit. Spending time around Thailand and especially Bangkok you can become a bit "templed out", if you are trying to decide which temples to visit then this one is definitely worth it. It is different because you can climb up the outside and although the stpes are extremely steep it is well worth it. You get good views over the river and city. We paid a small fee to get in, only a few quid. It is easy to get to if yous using the main tourist boats down the river you get off opposite the temple then get a small ferry over. The building is much older than many others and is fab for photography
go prepared to climb!. you can go at any time of the day, you can wonder around, relax and have a drink before or after climbing the temple. The short journey by ferry is nice to and really cheap!

One of my favorite temples anywhere. Wat Arun doesn't look like much from a distance because it isn't covered in gold like almost every other monument and temple in Bangkok, but upon closer inspection anyone will appreciate the intricacies of the tile work that went into this grand temple. The views from the top are worth the steep and somewhat sketchy climb up the stairs. The boat ride across the river to the temple is also a nice experience. Another highlight is that it isn't crowded with tourists or at least it wasn't when we visited the temple. The place is lit up at night which also makes it a great place to visit near the sunset.

Ancient and breathtaking. Getting to the Temple was a reward after having an adventure getting off the boat we rented which docked on the pier only by sheer human force, which will be ok on calmer waters.

You need a head for heights!. Great ride across the river (2 baht!) and a lovely temple to spend some time at. The steps you can climb up are steep but well worth doing as the views are great. Not the biggest of temples and probably best known for pictures of it. Best place for getting your picture taken in traditional thai dress though!!
Watch out. Once you start visiting this places you have to very careful, people keep misguiding you. Take a tourist group and go, then you will not waste time searching for this place
Just perfect. It's a very unique temple! The architecture is awesome and it's very close to the city center! Definitely a must see sightseeing...
Wonderful. Sadly there was building work going on when we visited but the best view was from the river at night when all signs of scaffolding were obliterated

Another must see for Bnagkok Temples. Another Temple to tick of the list in Bangkok, they are just stunning, and so colourful. For me the age of these monuments, and the care taken over them to keep them good, is fantastic.
Amazing Structure Temple. Although walking under the hot sun, but when seeing the structure of the temple so great and looks amazing, it is worth, so marvelous!

Cool, but Creepy.. This was a must see, but Im not going to lie, it was a little creepy climbing the steepest and highest stair case ever. Literally made me cry trying to come down because I was so scared. However, we cannot discredit the beauty and history, not to mention architecture of this site. It was truly breathtaking. All I'm saying is, if you dont like heights, it might not be for you.
emerald buddha nice, but very small. The emerald buddha turned out to be quite small, but we enjoyed visiting the many temples on the grounds.

Great architecture and amazing views. The temple is of easy access and you'll be amazed by the complex and breathtaking architecture of this beautiful temple. You could climb up the stairs although they are very steep, to get a better view of the chaya prao river and surrounding areas. It can be a bit too hot. The entrance is 50 baht a ticket for foreigners which is a bit too high when you are paying for a whole family. There's nothing much except for the amazing architecture so you could get bored quick and feel the entrance ticket money was not worth the stay. If you haven't visited any other temple then this could be a great experience. There wasn't a very strict dress code and we didn't have to remove shoes. Was planning on having lunch at the famous ree ree kaosan restaurant nearby which we unfortunately didn't have time to.

Fantastic Temple is Iconic Image of Bhagdad Tourism. Amazing location with multiple spires, and great views once you climb up a few levels on the exterior. Bring extra batteries and a large memory card. Shot after shot that you will want to capture. Some gift shops on site (of course) but their prices were lower than other stops along the journey. You can deal with them. Ignore first price, of course. Try to shoot this from the river so you can get it all in. Fabulous in the daylight, amazing at night.
great views. I visited this temple back in 2007; the steps are steep but the view from atop is worth the climb! the river taxi ride over to the temple is also good for pictures.

Worth the trip across the river. After a morning at Wat Pho and the Emeral Buddha, we had lunch by the river. For 3 baht (10¢) we took the water taxi to the temple. Once there we entered the grounds and climbed the temple stairs. Great views from the top (about half way up) but stairs are very very steep. Would recommend as you can do the whole trip with r/t water taxi for around $3

Should go if you have extra day. The boat ride along Chao Phraya itself is enjoyable and soak in all the sights...it's really lovely. Go Wat Arun during late afternoon, arrive there about 4pm is great.

interesting and nice temple. One of the most popular place to be visited in Bangkok.everybody who goes to bangkok should see this temple.it is easy to go this temple just crossing river after visit grand palace and what pao.
Viewed at night. Very beautiful to see this temple at night. If you are sick of temples this one really does have to be on the list to view.

Heady Heights. This elegant pagoda on the banks of the Chao Phraya River in Bangkok provides a true test of just how far a person will go to fully enjoy an attraction such as this.Anyone in Health and Safety should not read on because their blood will run cold.The majest of this Royal temple is not in question, but this is a landmark which allows visitors to take away breathtaking memories while at the same time exacting a price.You have to earn those memories with a steep climb up stone steps to the first level which provides lovely views over the river and surroundings. The real test awaits those who tackle the climb up to the second level.Beyond any question whatsoever, this is not for the faint-hearted.The first climb is at least 45 degrees but I'd put the angle of the second climb at closer to 70 degrees, perhaps even steeper.You can quite literally have a person climbing directly in front of you and have their feet at the same level as your eyes. It is that steep and tickets carry the legend: "Do not dangle any doll. Do not climb the rail." Anyone who does must be certifiable.Climbers hang on to supports for dear life because one slip and it is an awfully long way down.The reward at the top is a chance to make a full circuit of Wat Arun, The Temple of Dawn, while enjoying views of the highest order.This site is one of the "must visit" attractions in Bangkok, but watch out for the entrance price of just £1 because it is the only reality you will meet. Everything else is just like some fantasy adventure. Great viewing.

Beautiful temple. Beautiful temple with very detailed decoration. Its worth the climb to the top for the views of bangkok. the steps are very steep but if you have been to the temples of angkor or the like i'm sure it won't pahse you!
Impressive. Wat Arun was one of the more impressive sights of my entire trip by there isn't much more to it after you have a look and take a few photos.

Ancient but not very beautiful up close. This is an ancient temple much revered by Thais and worth seeing if you are in the area; however, it's more attractive from afar than up close. It is really in need of maintenance and restoration, in my opinion. Nevertheless, it is an interesting variation on the more typical archetecture found in Bangkok temples. Good to combine with a long tailed boat tour.

Highly Recommended. Wat Arun is one of the more interesting temples in Bangkok. It is situated across the river and you will have to take a short boat trip to get there. Once you enter the area, you can take creative shots on traditional Thai costumes. The architecture of this 17th-century edifice is highly impeccable!The steep stair climb (and descent) is very much worth the trip! You can even see the old royal palace once you get to the higher part of the temple.

Glorious at Dawn, awe-inspiring at sunset, and a must see in between. Wat Arun's neighborhood is lovely, the market around it is fascinating, and the iconic pyramid and prangs are only the beginning of its stunning architecture. If you're male, sit with a monk (most speak some English) and watch him weave a wrist cord right on your arm. Climb the main structure for wonderful views. Definitely walk through the Wat buildings too!

A 'must do' in Bangkok. This is one of the better historical sites in Bangkok and more architecturally interesting that many of the other Wats around. We particularly liked the use of old pottery and plates as part of the facade. It reminded us very much of the Spanish architect Antoni Gaudi's use of broken ceramics in his works, of course Gaudi came later! When here spend a bit of time to explore the local area, why not? It is only a few Bahts to get the local ferry shuttle service from the other side of the river at Tha Thien pier which is the southern pier of the Grand Palace area.Personally I did not like the steepness of the steps at the Wat, but the view was great. My problem was not going up, but coming down as I suffer with some vertigo. I had to go down the steps backwards, and it was very stressful. However, I will not mark any place down because of my problem with heights.

A must visit in BKK visit. Right on the river, steep stair climb that is totally worth it! It's a short visit and not a large area, but right on the river with temple spires around you make you feel you're really in Bangkok!

Worth seeing close up. Although the temple looks beautiful from a distance (and is an iconic sight), it's even more special close up when you can see all the detail of the porcelain decorations on the walls. You can climb up it and get a nice view from the top - the steps are quite steep though! There's a little garden area at the bottom which was quite pleasant. There's not much else to see there but it is definitely worth the visit and quite easy to get to (there is a boat constantly crossing the river, for only 3 baht).
High up!. I don't like heights and it seemed that I wasn't alone, the climb up is easy but there's only a railing and it's a long way down.. Beautiful view if you manage to do it though!

Details..... At first you think, "oh, that's pretty nice." However, once you get closer to Wat Arun, you realize that there is a lot more detail to the facade than you can see from afar. Wat Arun may not be a large complex and there isn't much else to see there, but it definitely is worth a few baht to cross the river, climb up the steep steps, take in the view of Bangkok from across the river, and marvel at the precision detail that went into creating this temple.

Must see in Bangkok. A beautiful temple to go to. If you are scared of hights don't climb to the top. You must come down.You can cross the river with the boat for three bath. Entrance fee is fifty bath. Never seen this before.

Worth the trip. Great temple, really a sight to be seen. One of the only temples that display the prominent Khmer influence. It really differs from the others and is a great place to go to experience the cultural variety that Bangkok has to offer. Walk all the way to the top if you dare!
Use boat 2 come c dis temple. Its beautiful temple decorated from ceramic fraction.....so unique n pretty. There r market nearby dat U can buy souvenir.
Challenge climbing up. Don' t miss Wat Arun. It is a symbol of Bangkok and if you dare to climb the steep stares of this Wat you will get great views from the river and the Royal Palace.

Beautiful, must go. its beautiful, next to the river, you can climb it so you get a nice view on the top, the entrance is only 50 Baht (1.67 US$), its a big piece in bangkok's cultural side. Must go, TIP: dont accept any tours from outside offering you a boat trip on the cannal its just gonna cost you more, move around in taxis, cabs are cheap in thailand, 5km=1US$, and request the use of a taximeter

Marvellous!!!. It is soo beautiful even with the scaffolding that currently (Oct.2012) has. Reminds of some of the Ayutthaya temples, and the panoramic view to Chao Praya and part of Bangkok just adds invaluable prize for the ones brave enough to climb the steep steps to the top level.Tip: Visit after being to Wat Pho, and if possible in the evening when lights add up a magical aura to the place

beautiful view from the top. beautifl view expecially during the sunset. you can see the Menam River from the top, just be care ful when claimbing the stairs. I think this is the no.1 Wat worth to go in Bangkok.........................

Stunning. This was more impressive when up close. The stairs up are a little daunting and even scarier on the way down. Certainly worth the effort though. Didn't like the tacky tourist dress up photo thing at the entrance though.

Exotic, Beautiful, Historic. I loved it. Walk up the steps to the balcony, it feels like something out of an Indiana Jones movie. The place sits on the river and number of boat tours and taxis can take you hear. There was not large crowds when I went around 8am, I basically had the place to myself. I loved it because I did not need a guide to tell me I had walked into another world. I was there looking out over the Chao Phraya River toward the Royal Palace and Bangkok.

A Must-See For Tourists!. the temple of dawn, or the wat arun, is definitely a must-see for tourists who visit thailand... it's such a unique architecture that gives you a feel of the thai culture. you really don't need to spend long hours when you come to visit this attraction - an hour would be more than enough. to make your wat arun experience more exciting, i recommend first-timers to rent thai costumes available in the area (they're all over the place), and have your pictures taken with the temple of dawn as your background. it would be a perfect souvenir! :) the locals charge 150 to 200 thai bahts per person, for a full costume with complete accessories. but as for me and my family, we were able to haggle for as low as 3 for 200 thai bahts :) it's because we are nine in the family. remember: just be kind and polite, when asking for a discount... and oh, please be mindful of your personal belongings... enjoy! :)
cambodian style pagoda. sunset view with pagoda is breathtaken moment... alfresco air... thai people lifestyle along river :)

Always quiet, which is good. Another must see in BKK and only a short, very inexpensive boat ride across the Chao Praya.Wat Arun's main feature is the steps up to the top of the temple. They are as near vertical as you'll find and, if you have difficulty climbing stairs, or have a fear of heights, you can still view from the ground.Very intricate tiling on the temple is worth a view. Only require around 15-20 minutes here.
magical. very beautiful, especially during sunset! watched it from the loy nava cruise and got some good clicks.. visited next day and was delighted to see it

Ceramics on the Go !!. My eyes stick on its beauty when I first see this temple, a huge and high temple made from ceramics. Every details were used ceramics on its surfaces. Very beautiful spot of view. Many traders here knows Indonesian, so they sell their goods in Indonesian. Very funny !! :D
Touristy again!. With the crowd, it can be dangerous climbing up the steep stairs to mid section. I wouldn't go again.
Great place to visit. This was another wonderful Buddha temple to visit, lovely decor and trimmings and people about. You can worship here if you want too.

Mesmerizing architecture and design. If you are in Bangkok for a short duration. This is definitely one landmark you should not miss. It really is a great spot for taking photos, as well. I suggest leave a day for this location and the royal palace.
Must See. The Temple of Dawn is very beautiful and you must climb to the top. The view is just increase. Watch out on your way up and down the steps are very steep and small!

if u get there just before sunset and are already on top, you get the good photos. the staff will be calling you down before sun set. but remember" you don't understand" any of the languages they are saying, and just speak jibberish when you speak. can only do this if you are a good climber on those steep steeps.
A nice calm temple. The calmness and neatness with a pious atmosphere - a really marvelous one.It is approachable through river cruise also.

Fantastic View on the Top. After the Thb 3.00 ride from Wat Pho, my sister and I walked towards Wat Arun and admired the chedis as we go along. Entrance fee is Thb 50.00.The stairs are quite steep and you really have to hold on to the rails to ensure you wont fall. However, be warned that climbing up is the easy part. Climbing down is quite scary since the stairs are really that steep. I found it is much better for me climb down facing the stairs.The view from the top is fantastic for you are able to see the chao praya river and surrounding structures. If you are afraid of heights do not look down. the view is dizzying.

Uniquely beautiful. So many temples, so little time! Wat Arun has its own unique character and special beauty. Lots of detail. You can climb very steep, tall steps for a great view of the city. The climb to the top may not be for everyone, its a little tough. You will probably have to take a boat to get here, which is fun too. Definitely add this to your list of Bangkok even if you are there for a short while.

Love the structure.. A really superb place to visit and the structure is amazing. Climb up the steep stairs to go up to the temple and you can see the view of Chao Phraya River from here. Worth a visit!
Awesome. It worths the visit, beautiful and peacefull but be careful with the very steep climbing to the top. But the view compensates the effort...

Wat Arun/Temple of Dawn. Probably the most stunning Wat in the world, outside of Ankgor Wat in Cambodia (by the way they even have a "scale model" of Angkor Wat here). It is overwhelming to see in the daylight, and when it is lit up at light, gleaming across the Chao Praya, it will be etched in your memories forever! YOu cannot see Bangkok without seeing this.

The broken crockery wat!. A beautiful setting, with the improbable detail that the entire wat is decorated with pieces of broken plates. Beautiful from a distance...and amazing close up. Climb to the top for impressive views.

Beautiful. We left at around 4am to see the temple at sunrise, and were not disappointed. The place is amazing, and climbing to the top was quite an experience (no OHS in Thailand!).My partner and I were even lucky enough to be able to give a food offering to the resident monks and recieve a blessing for good health and prosperity.A must see if you are in the area - just please be sure to respect the local customes.
A place to see. If you are in Bangkok do not miss it. It is a beautiful temple and it in an oasis of calm and silence.
Memorable. I think it got it's name since it possibly the highest temple in Bangkok and if you climb to the top you will be the first to see the dawn. One of the better temples to visit.

Great view. Easy to get there on a small ferry across the river from Wat Po. Or ride BTS to Wongwian Yai and take a taxi from there. After renovation in the past years the temple is open again to climb up the steep stairs. Super good view to the other riverside. Usually not too many people there, so good for taking nice photographs. Go there in the late afternoon and later watch it from one of the small restaurants on the other riverside at nighttime.
A miniature version of Angkor Wat. This is an impressive example of Thai history and culture in the heart of Bangkok and easily accessible by water ferry from the river

High Expectations but slightly disappointing. We took a taxi ride early in the morning to be there before sunrise. We went to the riverside where the temple is located (for the sunset, you need to be on the opposite shore). The temple was closed to visitors but you could walk around the grounds. The sunrise was average and the temple itself (whatever we saw of it) was nice. I am told the sunset is nicer because you see the sun setting behind the temple. Another pointer-there were no other visitors when we went.

What an art...imposing!. The high prang, totaly covered with porcelain, gives everybody a deep feeling of admiration. And it's really worth to climb carefully almost on top of the prang where you have a splendid view on the busy and crowded river and on the Grand Palace on the opposite side.

Temple by the River. A great temple that you can get to by taking a river ferry. Beautiful temple, entrance price was not high and is was easy to get to. At night it is spectacular if you take a dinner cruise on the river

Visit at Sunset!. Visit at sunset or sunrise to really enjoy the beauty of this temple. Wear shoes that will let you walk up the steep stairs to the second level. Some folks were a little scared of the stairs; but it is definitely worth it. Some folks have said that they don't have water there; but we were able to buy refreshments at a small stand.I recommend visiting this temple.

Scary and Amazing. Climbing up the steep steps is a little scary, going back down I was sent into a panic, clinging like a mad-woman to every last piece of rope and step...gosh I felt silly! But.... it was rewarding -amazing views across the city, river, and the temple complex itself. Gorgeous. Well worth visiting -it feels very old and magnificent. This Wat is very different from the others in my opinion.Also the incredibly cheap and quick boat ride over is lots of fun too.
Impressive. Good views but if you are scared of heights don't climb up. I went up the steep stairs and had a bit is a problem due to the difficulty of getting down!

Riverside majesty. I really enjoyed clambering around and about Wat Arun. The pagodas are encrusted with decoration and endlessly fascinating. The stairways to heaven brought Angkor Wat to mind, but this is no ruin.

Under wowed.. We went on a long tail boat to see the temple. For me the best part of the trip was the boat ride. the temple is big but there is not much else there. I had to use the restroom, I wouldn't recommend it.

Great leg workout!. Love Wat Arun, this was my 4th visit. I'm sure it gets steeper! Ladies should be sure to have covered legs (knee length or below) and shoulders or you will have to rent the sarang and shawl- not flattering on the many that were wearing them! A deposit and a small charge, but forever on your photos!Worth the steep climb up, great views, and get to see up close all the tiny ceramic pieces. Take a stroll around the base too, great photo opportunities with the many pillars.

Beautiful details. One thing that really really caught my eyes was the beautiful details of ceramic pieces on top of every side of the temple. They were very beautiful and colorful and have a very interesting story behind it. Well, like most of the outdoor site in Bangkok, don't forget to bring an umbrella and sunnies with you since it's very hot. Also when you go to places with "Wat" or "temple" in their names, you have to wear a decent and not revealing clothes.

A Bangkok favorite!. I took a river boat tour and visited this with several other staples of Bangkok. Don't go to Bangkok and miss seeing this as it is worth seeing such a grand place with its uniqueness and well kept grounds and bonsai trees.
magnificent place, must see. this is a place you cant miss if you visit Bangkok, you must go and see this, very rich the decor like all thai temples

great view from steps. Got the river boat train from central pier which connects with the overhead railway, get off at stop 8, take the little ferry straight across to Wat Arun the ferry costs 3 baht which is about 6p!The steps up Wat Arun are very steep and big tread - my thighs ached for 3 days, great views of the city and river worth the £2 to get in

Amazing. My husband loved this temple the most of all we saw. it was fun to take the ferry across the river, and well worth it to go see. BZe careful climbing up the very steep steps of the temple...it was an easy up but scary dow...VERY steep.
Lovely access by boat. Something to see by those interested in the culture of the country. Spectacular and intriguing, Very memorable and makes up for a lovely trip on the river.
Heaven. Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) Like a Heaven for me in earth. Unique and incredible place, so beautiful place, I really enjoyed it.
Night boat ride. I took a late night long tail boat ride. It looked amazing and took some awesome pictures. I brought a snack and some Singha and enjoyed the ride

Get adventurous and cross the river!. Take the ferry across the river for a peak at Wat Arun--VERY different than Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaeo. The ferry leaves every few minutes and only costs 3 Baht (~ 10 cents). The stairs up to the top are VERY steep and may not be for the acrophobic (fear of heights). The view from the top offers a stunning sweep of Bangkok and the Grand Palace and Wat's across the river.

Interesting. Hope you have a stomach for heights if you visit here. The steps leading up the side of the tallest temple are really steep. Not too bad going up, coming down can be a nightmare and I don't mind heights at all. Also difficult to get to, best to go along the river and ask which jetty is the best to get off. We got off the wrong one and had one hell of a walk.

Best seen at Dawn or Dusk. Wat Arun was a bonus as it was a small ferry ride across the river from the Wat Pho. We did not climb up the face of the temple, but many did. The face of the temple is unlike many others in Bangkok and was well worth seeing even in the middle of the day.

Fanastic. This temple is incredible. The location off the river is beautiful and easy to get to by ferry. Be mindful of the steepness of the steps especially the second set as its pretty difficult to walk without a grip on both sides. The going down is the hard one as you will experience having your knees weaken at the sight of the descend. There are no guides/facilitators up there, and you are on your own. Be sure to have the guts to climb down when you do decide to climb up the temple
Beautiful. This place is so beautiful and unique. Go with comfortable shoes and you could go up the stairs and have a great view of the river and the area.

Amazing architecture. This is a must-go place if you want to enjoy the dawn. In addition to this, we have to be a bit wary about the steepness of the steps especially the second set as its pretty difficult to walk without a grip on both sides.
Amazing. i think this was my favorite temple. you can climb the temple and get an amazing view of the city. a must do.

Best seen at night - wow. This temple is incredible, in a beautiful location and so detailed it blows your mind. I have visited during the day and at night, on a Grasshopper Bike Tour (well worth checking out), and all lit up this temple is just stunning.
Magic. Wat Arun was the most beautiful temple, I visited in Thailand. The multiple statues and the size of the grounds are simply amazing.

Beautiful and holy temple. The temple can be easily reach by taking the Chao Phraya river boat, once there you will never miss the stop as it is a fairly tall temple, do tell the boat attendant that you intend to get down at Wat Arun temple then you should be told when you are there, but keep your eye open. Regarded as holy place, ladies are not suppose to wear sexy skirt so travelers who wore sexy clothing need to cover your body by renting a Sarong, it is just a small fee. Also you need to pay for entrance fee to enter into the temple of Dawn. Tall temple of course involve some climbing as well, and staircase for this temple is quite small and you need to make a big step to climb up but when you reach the highest part, be fascinated of the scenery it can offer you, a good view of the river plus some other temples nearby. Make sure you stay back until night time, the temple will turn on its light and the scene is so beautiful, you can view this when on the boat as well if you pass by the temple during night time.

amazing Thailand. I like Bangkok far better than Siem Reap, Cambodia, esp. the food... a lot more beautiful places in Thailand than in Siem Reap. the hotel we stayed in Bangkok is far clean than the hotel we had in SR, Cambodia... and generally, Bangkok is also far clean than SR, Cambodia. i enjoyed the train going to places tho' at first i don't appreciate it because of the links that i feel i would easily get lost the fact that the thai language is really hard to understand and esp. the writings... but speaking of the temples, they're so great and really amazing... the hotel where we stayed was really that far in going to downtown Bangkok. tho' they have airport service but you still have to pay 150 Baht everytime you'll have their services except when arrival and departure at the airport. but generally, Bangkok is really a nice place...

Nice Temple !. Great architecture and very nice. The location off the river is nice and easy to get to. The temple is very steep, I mean really really steep. So I went up one level for some pics, but if you want to go to the top it should be an adventure. This Thai temple is a nice place to visit. You won't need more than 45 minutes.

A little run down since last time. We thought it was a little run down since last time. Always hot, always busy and always someone to take your money but is a must do for first timers. Easy to get there and easy to get around
Beautiful place. Beautiful place, with a gorgeous garden surrounding the exquisitively decorated temple. The variety of colours and shapes is enticing.

a definitely must-see!. really impressed by this temple, very different from other ones that i'd seen before. best part of it is that you may climb to the half-top of the temple tower and you may see the beauty of the city in a panoramic view. very nice details on and around the temple. sculptures and engravings are really nice. you may take a chao phraya boat from saphan taksin and reach to the opposite side of temple. another boat takes you to the temple for 3 baht ! (10 cents) entrance fee is 50 baht (1.7 dollar app) it's worth seeing, ideal place especially for photograph taking.

Beautiful and well maintained. With the kind of foot traffic that Wat Arun sees each day, I'm impressed to see how well it has been maintained. Lovely temple by the river. The climb is worth it, because the view from the top is lovely.
Steep steps to the top.. Our river boat allowed us to stop here but remember woman need to have a covered top to enter. Only needs to be a short stay but worth a look.
Awesome!. just on the banks of the river this mega structure is a beauty. it's so peaceful and a great view from the top. worth each moment at the place

Adrenaline Rush!. There are two ways to experience this: climb it, or witness it during the sunset.I was able to do the first, and it was a struggle --for all the good reasons. Adrenaline will kick in, and even though the climb is steep, you can still manage. The going down is the hard one as you will experience having your knees weaken at the sight of the descend. There are no guides/facilitators up there, and you are on your own. Be sure to have the guts to climb down when you do decide to climb up the temple. This, for me, is definitely a must try, at least to the first level of the temple.
A different kind of temple. It's god to visit here very early or late in the day - as you can see it's very steep to climb - amazingly so - but gives a nice view back over the old town

not for the faint hearted.. This was so worth it, i have a fear of heights so was thouraghly tested here, managed to crawl up the steps to the very top and it was so worth the effort, coming down posed more of a problem for me as it was so steep, but i did it and was so happy. A great spot to visit

A fantastic sight in the city. This is truly a landmark site in this bustling city. First noticed when on the river taxi and it is a great picturesque sight. I was told that this is also as good if not better at night when lit up but I was not able to see that. If you are across the river you an easily cross for 30THB on the river boat. Inexpensive to enter and the price reflected that there was not mug more to see inside than what you see from the outside. When within the grounds you can walk about and climb, if you are brave, to the top. The climb however is very steep and more like rock climbing. Not for those afraid I heights. Still a great landmark and temple and worth the trip.

Big Climb. Climbing the main tower is a chore, and possibly unsafe for people without skill. Never mind. Those who don't want to go up the steep steps can still enjoy this temple from the ground up. I found this place to be more interesting and less touristified than other major temples in Bangkok.

Worth the climb to the top!. We visited early in the morning so it was still quite quiet. We climbed to the top of the Temple - it's a long way up, the steps get narrower and steeper the nearer to the top you get, but the views from the top are stunning - well worth the climb!

One of Bangkok's Must Sees. A truly stunning temple/chedi. Best visited in the morning before 10am. Great views from the top, particularly on a clear day. Don't neglect exploring the neighbouring Ubosot (prayer hall) and temple grounds which most visitors skip but are a beautiful (recently resorted) and serene. Best views of the temple are at sunset from the opposite side of the river. You can see my image here: http://www.flickr.com/photos/iprahin/6978751191/in/set-72157622548626235
Dissapointing. Wat Arun was easy to find via the river express boat but no as good or as extensive as many other Wats in Bangkok.
A must see in Bangkok. wonderful temple on the banks of the river. a little steep climb but worth the views.An important part of the history of the countryA must see.

Majestic. Absolutely aw inspiring temple, even from afar. The climb to the top is a bit trying on the nerves, just don't look down. As with all other temples, it was a true testament to man's skills and ingenuity just times 100! I am still left with a sense of amazement when I think back about it.

A must see when in Bangkok. Wat Arun is a wonderful and unique temple in a style that you won't see in many other places anywhere else and the view from the top is stunning. There is lots of climbing involved and the stairs steep, but the experience is a great reward! Don't miss..a short trip on a regular water taxi brings you right to the temple from the waterfront close to the Royal Palace.

I will explore next time. I was able to see this beautiful temple at night and did not have an opportunity to explore or climb around it, but it is a sight to behold all lit up. The mix of the modern light with the old archetecture is captivating. next year i will visit in the day light.

Best spot for us. Went there around 10 in the morning and there was not so many people, could enjoy the surrounding and the view of river. The place is big and the gardens are well kept, with excellent statues and wall paintings. You can take a ferry to downtown from the pier in front of the Temple. It will leave you very near to the Temple of the Emerald Buddha

Bangkok Jem. Very unique temple and although not as popular as the Grand Wat Pho, I still think this place is worth seeing in Bangkok. No personal guides to walk you around, but you can still see the beauty of the architecture and design. Another accomplishment my wife and I did was climbing to the top and when you do, there is a big banner so you can sign your name. This is pretty crazy when you consider how high the building goes and how humid Thailand can get. Take lots of pictures, I recommend this place to visit in Bangkok if you have time.

Great landmark, nice view. Fascinating temple across the river. There are two sets of very steep stairs. The upper one is more steep than the bottom one. Getting back down is very scary. Not for the faint hearted. Though nice to visit even if you dont climb to the top. Very close from the Grand Palace. Just need to take a boat ride, which is pretty cheap.
Best way to see the sunset. Get a seat at the hotel on the other side of the river, grab a drink and watch the temple do it's thing... Perfect

Incredible sight...WOW!. A really incredible sight, should be top of the list of things to see (and take a photo of) in Bangkok, I went in the morning which was probably wise as it is quite exposed so I guess scorching hot later.

Nice to walk around, but not much more.. It photographs well from the boats on the river, and it's the iconic representation of Bangkok. Up close, the temple is really made of broken crockery and is very dramatic and very different from the ever present watts of Thailand. The good news is that there's a lot going on there. The day we went there was some sort of celebration, chanting, talks via loudspeaker, food, etc., but we were observers only so had no clue as to what was going on. You can climb fairly steep stairs to an observation area, but the combination of heat, humidity, and overcast skies let us off the hook for the climb.

Overrated. Its pretty ordinary. went by river boat as it is supposed to be faster than the traffic jams, but not a good experience, boats are difficult to get into and get out of for old people, not very comfortable and very noisy with the diesel engines. no guide accomapnied us and the driver does not speak thai.also you have to pay more money every time you dock at an attraction and the dock attendant is ready to fleece you .

Beautiful. When you visit this temple, make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes and trousers. The steps that you walk up are extremely steep, so you want to be comfortable. This temple is fun because you can walk around and explore a bit more, and you can see the city from the top.
magical. take the ferry across the river at dawn, its magical and not too touristic. beatiful at sunrise but gets hot after 10 a.m.
A must see!. But even better is the view from Arun Residence at the opposite side of the river. Be sure to go there during sunset :)
A big Monument. This is 2nd. time I climbed up Wat Arun. It was beautiful at the top and you can see BKK all around you. I strongly recommend to those who have not climb Wat Arun.

Overated. A very pretty temple but...
1. You don't go inside only climb around
2. 50 baht to enter. 20 baht to rent a skirt (guys can wear shorts)
3. The place is not very clean. Not filthy just not what I expected from a holy place.
I assume it is much nicer at night by the photos I saw online...
Nice to,see it. nice to see it. We have wisited it during a rainy time so it was not so hot and we enjozed it well. Despite lot of turists all arround. Like the site

Amazing and a bit terrifying!. This temple is lovely, the grounds are beautiful. Going up the temple is fine and there are great views of the Bangkok, however coming down is a bit more difficult, it's very very steep so make sure your wearing good foot wear!
Must see. An ensemble of typical thai architecture. Colors of the ceramic tiles and the size of the building are astonishing. Must climb on the highest terrace for a fantastic view of the river

Can't miss it in Bangkok!. Wat Arun is one of the best sightseeing there is in Bangkok.On the pier in the back of te Royal Palace, you can take a boat that takes you across the river, straight this temple for only 3 bat.Once in the temple, it is something really different from all the other temples in the city, it's a great place for pictures, and a great view from the top.You have a 50 bat ticket to go in, and remember you need to wear long pants and covered shoulders.

A floting temple in Chao Phraya River. This temple is very famous among tourists because it is built on the Chao Phraya river. If you want to visit the temple, you can start your journey fromvictory monument. From here take busno 48 or 508. If you are confused ask the bus driver, be prepared with the temple's name written in Thai languange. When I was in Bangkok, I prefer to use public transportation because it makes me more connected to the local culture and local people. However, most of the Thai bus driver can't speak english so, it is kind of challenging to take bus if you are not familiar yet with the place you visit. But, this can be anticipated by writing all the addresses you want to visit in Thai language. Also, learning some Thai expression will be helpful to make the communication easier . Otherwise you ca just take a cab but u have to pay more...if u have unlimited budget so u can just use cabs :)
A different temple indeed. The temple is covered in China. And that is literally: the stuff you find in your grannies kitchen, used to protect the stone underneath.
Amazing sight. Our taxi driver took us there and I was amazed such a beautiful sight such details in the building and I could have stayed there all night to admire the temple

Interesting but only if you're not afraid of heights!. The best way to get to Wat Arun is to take a river boat from the BTS Saphan Taksin station (either the river taxi, or hire a private long tail boat which will stop at Wat Arun.) You pay a 20 baht landing fee (for the boat to dock there). You only need about 30 minutes at Wat Arun. There's not a lot to do in the way of activities, and the actual structure you climb up is fairly limited, but it is a spectacular sight and the view from the top is amazing. As it is a temple, females must remember to wear a long skirt or pants to cover the legs. No spaghetti straps or tank tops, though they seem to be okay on t-shirts. Best to bring a sarong which you can wrap around your shorts and maybe another one for your arms. It depends on who stops you. I wore a t shirt and a sarong around my shorts to cover my legs with sneakers and they were okay about it. Men should also cover up, either with pants or a sarong over their shorts. You should wear sneakers or hiking sandals, definitely no heels! Also the ascent is extremely steep and the stairs are very narrow and thin. This is definitely not a place for anyone who is afraid of heights, and I'd also not recommend it for very pregnant women or the elderly who have knee or walking problems, as you can slip and fall on the ascent, or worse, the descent which can be challenging. If you're sporty and love hiking, it will take you 3 minutes to climb to the top. It really is a must-see and a fabulous destination for both locals and tourists. Try to make it part of the whole boat experience and Wat Arun as a stop along the way.

BTS Convenience. Always take the skytrain, it is clean and fast. At peak hours it can become quite full but better than sitting in hours of Bangkok traffic! Now that they have expanded the lines the service is more comprehensive.

wonderful destination. well, I think my trip was very interseting and useful. I explored mysterious and beautiful attraction in Thatland. when I come here. I dazzled with sparking and monunmental temple. woa. So greatful destination. surprise, I see I was so small and want to cgo to to the highest top off temle.
Interesting. Intriguing architecture for one of the oldest temple here. There is also ???chapters on the story of buddha here.
amazing. You must bring pants and long sleeves to visit temples like this,if you are female. Boys should wear long pants.

beautiful. I think that this is one of the most amazing sites in bangkok. While we were here we were treated to a rain/wind storm. I think that the inclement weather added to the beauty of the site. There are bells on the top of each tower that ring beautifully in the wind amazing site. Girls, make sure you cover your shoulders and knees otherwise you will have to rent clothing.

Beautiful view. The steps are very steep: almost as high as my leg, so take it easy. I had to hold on to the rail to pull myself up! They have an area at the bottom where you can try on Thai dancer clothes (for a small fee). Very fun!

Very nice complex. Very nice temple, easy to go there with the use of the river ferry boats. Impressive complex but if you have a walking problem of are scared of heights, do not climb the stairs as they are very steep and quite scary to descend. Take your time at the complex and let the temple come to you.

One of the best temples in Bangkok. Is very easy to get there taking the water taxi that goes all over the Chao Praya River. Is very cheap and convenient, plus you'll get to take great pics from the water. The temple has amazing views, specially when the sun goes down. It is located near Wat Pho or the Reclining Buddah and China town. The Sky Bar at the Lebua Tower and MBK shopping center are very close too. Is a very small temple but worth to see, plus you can also take pics in traditional thai costume, a great souvenir to bring back home! Remember to always wear proper clothes when you're going to a temple. Knees and shoulders covered.

Beautifull decorated. Nice views if you come by boat. Also don't miss it in the evenings, beautifull lights. Climbing is for the adventures type, bit steep, don't forget if you go up, you have to come down too.

The most spectacular of them all. Make the trip before the crowds get there so go early. Wear sensible walking shoes since the steep climb up the steps needs care. The experience of taking the short boat ride across the river also makes this overall experience top all others in Bangkok. If it rains however, you may not want to climb the steps, so again time your visit to avoid being there in the rain. You need both hands to hold on to the rails as you climb and the ancient steps are very steep and very narrow so if you had to hold an umbrella or avoid slipping in the rain, it would not be quite as pleasant.
temple of dawn. the temple was small but at night it seems nicer , very impressed the work done by thai people. the top floor is very dangerous to get up better do not go up there.
Well worth it. Well worth a visit first thing in the morning to see the monks going about daily business and travel down by boat well worth the journey
Spectacular. It is very intricate in design which leaves you in awe of the temple. You have to be prepared to walk up the steep steps to the very top though.

Beautiful View. I like temples so I enjoyed visiting here. A monk also blessed us and gave me a bracelet. What I don't like is when a guy asked us to take a photo behind a painted cardboard w/o telling us that we need to pay 20 baht each. Every move they ask for money. Make sure to wear pants or a long skirt because you'll be asked to pay and deposit 100 baht to get in and rent a long wrap around skirt.
Beautiful. We actually didn't go in, it is more beautiful from far off. We sat at a restaurant on the water and watched it. Lovely.

awesome!. we took a long boat from our hotel, to Wat Arum, it was just stunning to be there, after having read a lot about it.How they build them, is beund us, just absolutly glorius.my h/band whent to the middle, of the temple, very steep !!the parks around the temple was very beautiful too , could have spend hrs. there, very interisting. will be back again!

Thin Edge Of The Wedge. very elegant building ,but nobody told us their would be stairs to climb ,we thought their may have been a lift ou helicopter to take you to the top.my wife is not so young or good on her feet these days so we did not go to the top.i feel we missed out and got the thin edge of the wedge.

Small but nice. Once finished with Wat Pho (Reclining Buddha), we walked 2 minutes to the river and took ferry to the other bank. It cost only 2 BHT per person and took 5 minutes to cross river. Don't let private companies rip you off. Take public ferry. Once we disembarked, we walked 50 meters to Wat Arum temple. Entrance fee was 50 BHT (half of Wat Pho but also smaller and less to see). We climbed the middle section for nice view of river and Bangkok. The stairs are very steep but the view is worth it. Good place to take photos from. You'll see Bangkok skyscrapers to the right (in the distance), Wat Pho across the river (although covered with trees) and you'll also get nice shot of Grand Palace if you have good zoom. It was breezy on the top which was also refreshing. The bathrooms next to the temple were clean and cost few BHT. Ferry back to the other side of river was also 2 BHT. It runs every 5 min. Overall you'll need about an hour to cross river, see Wat Arun, and cross back.
Lovely. A quiet ride down the Chao Praya river past this beautiful temple will take one back several hundred years. Don’t miss this. It’s amazing.

Breathtaking!. I had many pictures of Wat Arun before going but the pictures couldn't do it justice!A must see!Climbing the stairs was not easy. Coming down the stairs was even harder. But in the end it was worth it. Spectacular views!
A Must see!. You simply must see this lovely Wat Arun. See if fromthe river boat or actually go to it and see how the whole thing is covered with small mosaic tiles. Amazing.

Different. I have never seen anything like this. very serene, architecturally stunning. Take the time to climb up both sets of stairs on the main spire but the second set is almost straight up like climbing a ladder. going up is easy, coming down is considerably more difficult. from the second landing you can see over the river, the Grande Palace and downtown Bangkok. Well worth the trip as well as the tour through the canals on the local river boats.

Don't miss it. You cannot visit Bangkok and not visit this national Thai Landmark. You see it on coins, on the tourist office logo and lots of other signs. If you climb it, please be beware of the very steep stairs. Mayby not every one's cup of tea.

Part of bopping up the Chao Phraya, but there are better Wats nearby. This is one of the bigger sites along the Chao Phraya. But after seeing the National Palace and Wat Pho, it is definitely a poor cousin. The temple lacks the fine detail of many of the other sites. Pressed for time? Skip it, but take in Wat Saket (the Golden Mound) or one of the other distinct temples in the area.
A must. Defintiely worth a visit. But do make sure you have long sleeves and No Shorts!! we were turned back and had to get cover ups.
A must if in Bangkok.. Great place to visit and the views from the top are amazing. One word of warning the steps are very steep but definitely worth the climb.

Great temple visit!. Wat Arun is a great to temple to visit if you're in Bangkok. We went this past fall (during the flooding, actually) but still found it accessible and very much worth the visit. We took the public ferry across the river. It's very cheap but a little rocky. When we got to the other side, we decided to climb up the stairs of the temple. It's steep but not too bad of a climb up. The view is great from the top. To give you an idea of how steep it is, you go down the way you came up (facing the stairs). Anyway, definitely see this temple!

Worth a visit. The temple is somehow different from the other temples and well worth a visit. Take the small public ferry from pier 8 (3 thb) and spend 1 hour here. There is a very steep climb up the temple, but you're rewarded with a nice view. Remember to see the temple area besides the Tower. We experienced some people bringing gifts into a temple, getting some payers from a monk
Small but nice temple accessible by cheap ferry boat. didn't make it at dawn but enjoy the site, steep stairs but nice view once on the top.take a small boat to and from, to cross the river.

good good. The temple very good I have never known for such a historical and religious templeThats not nice for me.Other than that it is OK.The temple for magnificent views asross Bangkok and the chao Phrya river.

Beautiful. A beautiful place to visit in the centre of Bangkok but be warned, the stairs are many and steep (quite scary actually...especially on the way down) It is worth theough for fabulous views of Bangkok.

Nice place. Liked- Place along the river
Disliked- They are barbecuing meat just in front of the temple. Thats not nice for me. Other than that it is OK.

A rare experience. To climb up a temple such as Wat Arun is a rare experience in any walk of life. I have never known for such a historical and religious temple, to allow visitors to climb up the many steep stairs on the outside of the temple for magnificent views across Bangkok and the chao Phraya river. Take the chance while you are still allowed access!This is a must visit when in Bangkok, and is far greater than the royal palace or Wat pho.

one of the best tempes in Bangkok. Wat Arun is near by Chao Prayay River, on the right bank.You can combine with Royal Palace or Wat Po and i can recomend you just rent the private boat or use water-taxi,or some public boat.There is extelente view to the left bank , river, specialy before sunset, very romantic place, still not ,,terribly turistic,, dont forget to visit)
Gorgeous!. It's definitely worth a visit. Remember to cover your sholders and wear at least knee-lenght pants, otherwise you will have to rent pants/sarongs.

Porcelian decorations. easily accessed by river express boat. Very interesting wat that is decorated in a different fashion than most. This is decorated with pieces of old dishes that make beautiful patterns on everything. Nice view from the river as you approach it and nice view from Wat Arun when you climb it. Plenty of areas to roam around to see different types of buildings.

Amazing Architechture. This Indian style temple is absolutely the best place to visit in bangkok. Its build in ancient aryan (Vedic) style and shows Indra and other gods in the hindu mythology, on mount MeruThe view of the river, once you climb the central spiral, are quite breathtaking. Early evenings are a good time to visit. The layout around the main temple shrine are also worth a quick visit. Its recommended to get a guide, and wear clothes that cover your legs and arms.
Worth the climb. The temple is lovely, but the best part is the view of the river and Bangkok skyline from the top - be warned, the stairs are incredibly steep.

nice place, very spiritual, the stair climb is insane!. get there when it's EARLY to avoid the crowds. ideally before 10am. pray it's a cloudy day so it's not too hot! bring water and pocket change for the boat ride there and back.

A poignant shrine. Per my wife: "It's pretty cool." However, that is pretty major, as she doesn't really dig visiting churches, temples or shrines on holiday.Bangkok is full of Wats; however, this one is unique. It has a great view of the city and you are allowed to climb it, with few restrictions, to partake of that view. The detail is amazing. It is inexpensive to enter this temple. Sadly, it is wearing away. Like much of the city, the acid rain that plagues it is degrading this truly beautiful site.We left on an hour long tour boat for the canals that ended up at the grand palace dock across the river. Six people for a total price of 900 baht. Not bad.
its worth the visit. worth the visit, the only temple you can climb, the view from the top is amazing! you get to see the old city .
Interesting and beautiful. I can recommend this temple as it is one of the oldest and most original in Bangkok. Climb up on the temple roof and look at the view of Bangkok. Amazing!

Out of this world (but not good if you have vertigo). Wat Arun is beautiful both during the day and when lit up at night. The mosaic covered Temple has fantastic statues with different facial expressions,which I noticed much to my joy. We spent a long time looking at the different ceramic plates which make up different parts of the mosaic covering the Temple. The Wat has different levels which you can stop at and gaze at the amazing views of different parts of Bangkok. The higher up you get the steeper and narrower the stairs get. I would not advise going to the top if you suffer with vertigo or have a fear of heights. However, if you have the stomach and a head for heights, the views from the top are magnificent (or so I have been informed)! The only negative I would point out, and it is a small one, is the toilet facilities at the bottom of the Wat. Plan in advice your toilet stops before reaching the Wat as the toilets are not the cleanest in the city.
STEEP STEPS!!!. Couldn't move my leg for 3 days due to the steep stairs!! Nothing a good thai massage could solve, but the steps were dangerous. Other than this - fab place!! looks amazing!!!
Good temple. Very steep climb on the stairs . Beautiful view of bangkok from top . Easy and cheap ride on ferry for 3 baht per way

Beautiful temple!. We originally planned on seeing the Grand Palace, but it was closed early to foreigners. We hopped on a long tail boat and headed across the river to Wat Arun. What a beautiful temple! Be careful, the stairs are STEEP! A group of students even interviewed us as we left! Definitely a must-see in Bangkok!
Magnificent. Found it fantastic , Beatyfull to look at and very enjoyable. This temple is great and peacefull love the serenity of it all

Serenity. A very beautiful temple with numerous artworks throughout the temple. I have come to appreciate the effort of people who express their faith in the form of art & sculpture in this temple. If you have a chance to climb steep pagoda stairs, do it - it gives you a better view of temple and Chaopraya river.

reminds me of cambodia. To reach to this temple you need you take a ferry ride.We came here after Grand Palace ->Wat Po->Wat Arun. The ferry ride itself is an experience since it's not a common mode of transportation in where i live. If you are not afraid of height, you can climb to very high but the stairs is very steep. It's harder to come down than to go up. A nice place nonetheless, minus the hot weather which is unavoidable.
amazing place. i know another temple.. but well worth... checkn it out On the river & eazy place to get to Buy the day pass so u can get on& off the riverboat
Classic & Beautiful. The Wat Arun is beautiful temple- marked with steep climb to the top, but the views from the top are so worth it, so ignore the pain in your legs the next day!

Fantastic at sunset, if you can find an unobstructed view.... Wat Arun is great up close, but really shines from across the river at sunset. Be sure to stake out a view, early, as this is a well known sunset stop.
Must see!!. You should visit this temple 2 times, once in Dawn (but across the river) and once in day time (go inside).
nice place. you have to cross the river to visit Wat Arun. Take the ferry, it's very cheap. Loved the steep climb. Get to the top and enjoy the amazing view.

Awesome. Architecturally amazing. The steep steps to the higher levels are not for everyone but a treat for the brave. Not expensive and a real photo opportunity. Get a public ferry across from the Grand Palace for 3 Baht.

Beautiful temple, but take care if climbing up its steep stairs. Wat Arun is all the more beautiful that its architecture is very different from that of all the other temples in Bangkok - it was built in a Khmer style that is slightly reminiscent of Angkor Vat. The view from the top is stunning, but be careful - the stairs are VERY steep and there is absolutely no security ramp or anything. The climb is worth it, but be VERY careful, especially if it's the rainy season.
Super!. I went to Wat Arun by boat, a bit expensive because I've no idea if there any access to be there. 600 bath worthed for a beatiful view of statues.
nice view. a must see place.take the ferry (THB 3) and climbe to the top, 1 hor gross for the whole tour. THB 50 entrence fee.
Visiting This Temple is a must.. This Temple is amazing, again you must see it to believe it.It's part of my 9 Temple ritual. I visit 9 Temples on Birthdays and special ocassions.

Go at Dawn. Fewer people are visiting this temple since it is a bit outside the main sightseeing area. This only add to its charm. Definitely go there and then cross the river by boat, a nice experience in itself

Try to go when monks are singing. Different architetture and small, easy to visit. Steep to climb though. I've been there before, but at this time, at the end of the day, the buddhist monks were singing their chants and it was a totally different experience. Much more enjoyable.

Nice Temple but very steep. This temple was very beautiful once you get to the top. The only problem is getting to the top. The stairs are ungodly steep and only get worse, I do not recomend this to anyone with bad knees and trouble climbing stairs because you wont be able to get half way up. However the temple itself is still beautiful to walk around. I recommend hireing a boat to take you and your party around for a bit and have this be one of you stops as it is right on the canal. There is a fee to get in but its pretty cheap and well worth paying.
Nice but unaccesable. Be aware that you have to pay the entrance. Too many turists around and is open only until 5pm. Very beautiful building .
Tourist attraction. well worth the look and walk up, watch out for vertigo, amazing views, make sure you have the appropriate clothing.

War Arun, A must stop on the river, climb it and descend, it is steep and beautiful, reminding you of the Mayas. Wat Arun, A must stop on the river, climb it and descend, it is steep and beautiful, almost reminding you of the Mayas in Mexico
worth visiting but not too special. to my taste I don't really like the style of the temple, except for the pagoda where sits the buddha image.

A very nice place!. You can walk through the very steep stairs of the main prang which will give a very good view of the Chao Phraya River.  There are lots of souvenirs on the side of the main attraction.
