There are key chains, shirts, pens, caps, hats etc. Actually, I find the souvenirs here less cheap than those of mini stores near the Platinum Mall.  The best way to come here is by boat, to the Tha Tien by the Chao Phraya River Express boats. You can just transfer from 1 boat to another, fare is 50Baht.The grounds are perfectly manicured and beautiful. Ensure your arms and legs are covered otherwise you will need to borrow clothes as it is a buddhist place of worship.
Amazing Architecture. Amazing Architecture. Real treat for photographers. See this from the other side of the river in the night. It looks fantastic.

Fantastic. Fantastic sight... this should be close to the top of anyone's list of things to see or do while they are in Bangkok. You probably don't need more than a couple of hours to allocate to come here and it is well worth it.

unique experience. Best way to visit use ferry service across "Chao Phraya". Best scenic view at night when you see it from the ferry. If possible pay a visit if not at-least get a view of it from ferry

Favourite Temple in Bangkok. I loved everything about Wat Arun - the little boat across the river is adorable and costs something ridiculously small like 3 baht, and then the hair-raising climb all over the temple feels adventurous and kind of wrong, being used to fenced-off European monuments. Beautiful facades and much quieter than some other temples in the city centre. Loved! Be careful on the steps though, it probably is quite dangerous especially for children.
really great. we visitied this temple whilst on a temple crawl for the day,admittidly you get very templed out but this place is great!!!! worth the visit

Better From the River. The temple is best to admire from the river. The night view in particular. Decided not to visit, climb personally as I have seen it was too crowded and expensive to the experience. It is best to make a stop there once travelling on the river taxis.

Iconic. If you visiting Bangkok even just for a couple of days en-route to somewhere else don't miss Wat Arun, it is beautiful and great for photos (in both directions) so make sure you don't forget your camera. Make sure you wear sun-cream too as its is quite exposed here.

Wat Arun. The best way to visit this temple is by taking the ferry from across the Chao Phraya. Be careful with the stairs at it is steep and narrow and there can be a lot of tourists going both ways.
Great views!. You can climb up this temple (up some quite steep steps) and you get really good views of the city and can see the grand palace. It's worth a visit but you wouldn't spend long there.

Classic Bangkok tour. Visited this attraction along with the Grand Palace, with a private guide who also offered to take us shopping, which I managed to persuade my wife we didn’t have time for. After the day’s activities the guide dropped us off at our river dinner cruise on an old rice barge, which was excellent, my favorite part of the day. The daytrip was a private one organized by Andaman Sky as part of a 2 week holiday, not sure if you can book it if you don’t also do a tour of the Andaman coast with them, we did and had a blast, full creds to them.

Special Experience. It was a special experience to come here as not much of travellers come to here because you need to take a short boat ride from Wat Pho. However you get to have a different experience from others if you climb up this Wat Arun (the pagoda that have on Thai Coins)!

expensive. this place was good but having to pay extra to see everything while you were there meant the price soon added up. you have to pay to get into the complex then pay extra to get into the temple, pay to hire clothes. there is little shade so in the day there is nowhere to shelter
outdoor sight to climb the tower. this is not a temple as we think of it as it is an outdoor sight so be prepared in sun or rain. incredibly lovely

A must see. This temple has an incredibly decorated chedi and has a slightly different atmosphere than Wat Pho and the Grand Palace. You can climb to heights where you get great views of the river and Bangkok. This temple completes the triad which, if ambitious, you can visit all in one day.

Worth to Visit. This temple looks amazing and absolutely breathtaking. It's beautifully decorated with multicolored ceramics and many detailed ornaments. The stairs were super steep though. But it's worth it since it looks fantastic and you can take lots of good picture there. There's a market in front of the temple and they sell many traditional stuffs for souvenir. Getting here is easy, you can take a taxi cab - it's located across Chao Praya River- with a really low fare.

Beautiful Temple. The temple on itself is a masterpiece. There is a charge to enter and climb the stairs of the temple. Cheap souvenir stores, water and light snacks available on the site. It is just a short boat ride to cross to the other side where you may find the Wat Pho or theTemple of the Reclining Buddha and the Grand Palace. The sites are accessible via public transport and is cheap so do away with hiring tuktuks or locals on the streets offering boat tours. We went midday and the sun was really hot. Better to visit early in the morning or late afternoon, but check the opening and closing time on the website of the temples when scheduling your visit, some nearby temples may be closed during lunch hours.
Temple from the river. I was not able to visit Wat-Arun in person. The splendid view of the temple in the nightime was one of the great things that I had gone through the river cruise in Bangkok.
Beautiful. One of the most beautiful temples I have ever seen. We walked up the steps which was well worth it. Got some lovely photos that we will treasure forever. I definetely recommend it.

Great for a sunset photo. This is right on the river bank. Just a couple of Baht to get across from the other side. I don't think there was an entrance fee. Much less crowded than the Grand Palace or Wat Pho. If you're scared of heights or your balance is a bit dodgy then don't climb up the top of the prang. It gets very steep on the 2nd set of steps!

Beautiful Architecture. Take a river taxi across the rive to Wat Arun - a nice experience. The temple is nicely conserved and beautifully constructed. Dressed up with long pants if you want to visit this temple, if not you have to rent a 'long skirt' for 20baht.

Beautiful and impressive. Wat arun can be reached by a very cheap ferry costing about 3baht. The grounds are perfectly manicured and beautiful. Ensure your arms and legs are covered otherwise you will need to borrow clothes as it is a buddhist place of worship. The prang is very steep. My friend climbed to the top and she was worn out. A very nice place.

Just like the pictures you see!. Absolutely brilliant. We arrived here by boat (on a tour arranged by Tour East - they were excellent) and approached the temple. It is just like all the pictures you see at home. Truly wonderful! Climb the steps - they are steep - but well worth it for the sights and photographs.An absolute must if visiting bangkok.

Beautiful Temple. Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn is one of the popular and easiest to locate through the Chao Phraya River Express boat. The temple is decorated by bits of multi-colored porcelain and consists of 20 story prang or pagoda. Entrance fee: 50Baht, opens 8-5pm.You can walk through the very steep stairs of the main prang which will give a very good view of the Chao Phraya River. There are lots of souvenirs on the side of the main attraction. There are keychains, shirts, pens, caps, hats etc. Actually, I find the souvenirs here less cheap than those of mini stores near the Platinum Mall.The besy way to come here is by boat, to the Tha Tien by the Chao Phraya River Express boats. You can just transfer from 1 boat to another, fare is 50Baht.
an absolute must see. for those who are tired of temples, listen, this one is very different and special, an absolute must see and of course must climb to have a view overy Bkk.
Beautiful. Totally amazing and definitely worth a visit. I actually prefer this to the Grand palace as it is smaller, older, more unique and calmer.

Beautiful Wat Arun. The View at Wat Arun is breathtaking.
Climb the Wat Arun and Enjoy the ChaoPhraya River View
The stair at Wat Arun not for the faint hearted, but if u dare enough to climb to top of Wat Arun, the View will be Incredible.

Beautifully located along the river. This temple was quite amazing due to its construction using porcelain from ballast. The stairs leading to the upper levels are very steep and if you are afraid of heights don't even attempt climbing it. I did this on my own but wish I had visited it with a tour guide. Since it is a distance from the city center I had to take a cab there and I returned via a tuk tuk. There is no way you can walk it. Water taxis and longboats are available.

Be enlightened. This is a very tall stupa, so high that it almost touches the sky. hahaha just like the song. But it's true! It is even said that if one is able to reach the peak, you must have been enlightened already. But I may have been dizzy and tired. :) The stairway gets narrower and narrower each time you go higher. Entrance fee is 100 baht. You get here by boat which you can pay for a minimum of 300 baht per person. Landing fee is 20 baht. If you take a photo at the holed images outside the stupa, beware, you will be charged 40 baht per person. ew! too many to pay for. the Buddha may not be happy about this business-making. But the trip is worth doing. Go for it
Interesting place. Travel through river was quite exiting. Bring your hat to reduce heat stress, and drink lots of water.

Amazing view. This another must see Temple in town, just across the river opposite side of the Grand Palace.Besides Wat Arun there is groups of small temples with buddhist monks, be aware that this side is generally closed after mid afternoon.

Great view, especially at sunset. The temple is accessible by boat, which is very charming especially at sunset. From the top you can see a great view of the city, but watch out because the stairs are really steep.

Iconic building on the banks of the Chaophraya. I came across this temple while on a boat ride on the Chaophraya river. You can not really miss the peaks of the temple from the river.There is a 50 THB entrance fee. You can climb up the temple using increasingly steeper steps. Not suitable for the mobility impaired. The views of the city at the top are quite amazing.The stairs down look harrowing, almost a vertical drop, but once you start, it is not really so bad.The usual dress code applies. Knees and shoulders to be covered. You can buy suitable clothing to cover up just by the temple.
Different. Be ready to climb one steep temple. The way to the temple is interesting and the surroundings are pleasant but to climb and reach the top is a daunting task.
Temple of dawn. One of the most beautiful Thai architect,Good form and proportion with great decorative item in traditional Thai style.

probably the nicer temple in BKK. if you needed to choose one temple to visit in BKK, I would pick this one. I think this is the most original, interesting and surprising, for a farang. And coming by boat just adds to the experience.
Amazing. A must see it Bangkok. Take the river cruise and see them all in a single afternoon. Even the long boats are not too expensive.

Nothing to see.... There is not much to see. When we reached the temple it was pouring and there was absolutely no one to tell us which way to go. We were asked to climb the steep stairs along the temple sides to "enter" to which I refused, my husband however managed the climb. There is nothing on top except the beautiful views of the area around.
Impressive place. Beautiful place to visit, especially by boat. Amazing view from the top. Beware that the steps are very steep! Best to in the morning or evening when it's not boiling hot!
Wonderful Sunset. Great temple, not a lot of expensive frills involved. Great view of the sunset. The stairs are tough, but worth it!

Wonderful!. I enjoyed Wat Arun so much that I visited several times in one trip. The temple is beautiful and the location offers many wonderful views of the city. We always went later in the day when most visitors have gone and it was nice and quiet. Take the ferry across the river for something like 3 Baht and enjoy a relaxing time wandering around this place. Bring a wide angle lens!

Beautiful Place - A Highlight of Bangkok. The Wat Arun takes a little more work to get to in that it is on the far side of the river to the Wat Pho and Grand Palace but it it literally three mins on a water taxi and is utterly worth it.You get to climb it for a start and the views are the best I saw in Bangkok. Incredibly ornate mosaics, statues and carving, it is my favourite sight in Bangkok.Do not miss.
Favorite temple in Bangkok.. The artwork is very different from the other temples and you are able to climb to the top for a fantastic view of the old city
Beautiful. Beautiful place, nice craft work on the temple walls, with mosaic porcelain details. Cheap admission fee too, however you can finish it in 15 minutes, as its quite a small temple.
Lovely but not if you get vertigo.. Another beautiful temple but a lot of steps, it was very hot and the Steps looked like hard work and daunting but the view from the top was worth the climb.

Watch the sunset over The Temple of dawn (Wat Arun). Get a water taxi to Wat Arun around 4pmGet off at Pier 8 (Ta Tien) get ferry to Wat Arun enjoy the Fabulous Temple When you return to Pier 8 there is a small bar on the right of the walkwayHere you get magnificent views of the Temple across the river here you can get a simple deliciousthai meal a cold beer cheap cheap and watch the sunset over the temple across the river for freeI have been going to Thailand for 30 years and that beer and sunset is one of my favourite places in the world to be just try it

Bring your climbing shoes. Interesting temple on the "other" side of the river. Take a ferry to get there and enjoy the tall and very steep Stupa. Climbing up gives you great river views, climbing down is another issue. Not recommendable for people afraid of heights

Good View, Classic Temple. It is beautiful from afar and so-so when you look closely. Not as grand as Wat Phra Kaew and Wat Pho. It is the ancient landmark of Bangkok and you can expect very beautiful scene in the evening.

Beautiful and ornate. Situated directly on the river, this temple is a must-see attraction in Bangkok. Although it is quite touristy, you really must pay the 50 baht and climb to the top as the view is wonderful and the experience is good for the soul.

Don't Miss It. I ended my Khlong tour at this attraction, and you really can't get an idea of how amazing it is until you get up close. The detail on the building is absolutely incredible, and there are stunning views from the top. If it's monsoon season, though, don't be like me and forget to bring some waterproof gear! It started pouring as soon as I reached the top!
Incredible. You could spend the entire day exploring and relaxing by the picturesque temples! We climbed the steep stairs to the top and took in the incredible architecture and city around us.

Amazing Thailand. I was really in awe at this temple. I had been looking forward to seeing it and it didn't disappoint. We got some great photos and even better memories (really have to see it to believe it). Fantastic.

Amazing!!!. Our first time to Bangkok and we were recommended to go to the Temple of Dawn! its amazing!!! we got a local guide who walked us around and told us the history. We went up to the top where we got great views! The architecture is just amazing. A must visit place for those visiting bangkok!
Must See. best time to go if you want grat pics is just before sunset,you will get great shots of the temple as the light changes

Stunning. Absolutely loved this place. Even if religion isn't your thing, the setting and architecture will amaze you. Make sure you go up the steps! Yes, they're outrageously steep and narrow, but the views are worth it :-)
Worth the boat ride. It was well worth the ride across the river to reach this Wat. We walked up the stairs to the top of the Wat and there were great views.

Worth A Short Trip. I had a day to spend in Bangkok.
The Wat Arun is worth a visit. Almost one of those places to pick of the list. However, it is a very short trip. Maybe 30 minutes. Peaceful place when I visited. The climb to the top is steep but fun. Views are OK.

A Must..... Located on the river Wat Arun is a highly recommended stop for the Bkk traveller. A nice way of doing it is to rent a long tail boat to take you up the river and through the canals for a local Bkk perspective. The long tail boats can stop and let you walk around Wat Arun for 30-45 minutes which is good for a quick tour of the historic temple. Long tail boats can go for 1500-1800 for 1.5-2 hours respectively and can be found on the pier left of the Sheraton which is near River City.

Beautiful!. Definitely worth a visit. We took the short boat ride from the pier on the other side of the river. Great little restaurant on the pier as well with yummy pad Thai noodles. Temple is beautiful, some steep climbs but worth persevering to the top!
amazing during sunset... it changes its color during sunset..its an ordinary looking temple during the day but when the sun sets the color changes to pink. that's the best time to watch the temple

Must See at Night from the Deck/Amaroso. It seemed strange that all the guidebooks say to go to see Wat Arun from the opposite side of the river in the evening from a restaurant bar call "The Deck"/ Amoroso. It was one of the bets things we did in Bankok. Dont forget your camera! Get there early to get a good seat with a good view. Also, the nachos at Amaroso are surprisingly good!
Stunning. The temples around Bangkok are stunning and this was my favourite - the work that has gone into the decoration of this place is so impressive and the water taxi to reach it was fun.

Remains the most beautiful temple I have seen, to date. Wat Arun is not as large as some of the other temple complexes that Bangkok has to offer, but for me, it is definitely the most beautiful. The short and very cheap hop across the Chao Praya river on a ferry boat is well worth what awaits at Wat Arun. The detail is stunning: the flowers that adorn every exterior surface are actually made from decorative pottery which was used as ballast in boats, back in the day. Close up, this feature is breathtaking. The height and shape of the different temple buildings are slender and take a little bit of effort to climb up but provide gorgeous views. Wat Arun is charming and well worth a visit during the day or the evening, when so many surfaces seem to sparkle, and I have made a point of visiting on 2 out of 3 trips to Bangkok. Beautiful.

Temple of Dawn. Stunning buildings, the decoration looked like Gaudi had gone mad, but of course the broken ceramics pre date Gaudi. The only draw back that I can see is that it was so hot that I didn't want to climb up the stairs to see the views. Make sure you go with your shoulders covered. I was warned not to wear sandals, but changed out of my shoes at the Royal Place because everyone was wearing flip flops

Wat Arun is architecture marvel! Must visit. WAT Arun is one of the major attraction of bangkok temples. You can reach there using boat/ferry which you can catch from Sathorn Pier. You have to get down at N8 and then take a ferry across N8 to WAT Arun. Temple is worth the visit. Only thing I found is that this one is not maintained like other temples like Wat Pho and all for some reasons. Don't know why (Temple of Dawn, is it because of that). But its a must vist place

Travel here by boat!. Awesome temple. I love how you can climb up it and get a first-hand feel for the intricate detail. Plus, the view from the top is sensational.
Traveling by river-taxi is definitely the way to go if you can plan to do it in a trip with other water-front sights.

A must see sight in Bangkok. Amazing place to see and walk around take the 30 baht ferrythere is a peir opposite the Wat on the otherside. This wat can be closed on Wednesday Check. Never get scammed by English speeking Thai men telling you A wat is closed and they will take you to see something else. Every site in Bangkok is open don't be told anything diferent. Be strong and say no, I am still going.

Must visit. This is an excellent temple to visit, and minutes away from Wat Pho. I recommend you walk across the street, in the direction of the river, and board a river boat ( 3 bhats) to the opposite side. The climb to the top is a bit steep, but offers good views of the surrounding areas. The entry fees to the complex is 50 bhats.Good place to visit along with the emerald Buddha complex and Wat Pho.

Fun side trip. Wat Arun is a nice place to visit. It is a little out of the way and is relatively small, but it is beautiful and fun to climb the steps (going down is definitely not for the faint of heart).The architecture is really spectacular, and from the top you have a nice view of the river and Bangkok. Well worth it.If you are going after visiting the Grand Palace, you can reach the ferry in a 10 - 15 minute walk (the ferry pier is a little difficult to find, but you can take a tuk-tuk). The ferry will take you across the river for 3 baht (that's ~US $0.10) and it's fun too.Although there's a booth with a sign that says "TICKETS" (50 baht or US $1.60), these are voluntary; I presume they use this for maintenance, so I happily paid anyway.

A short ferry trip to view this temple. On my sight seeing day, took a short ferry trip from one side of the Chao Praya river to the other to view the temple. A worthwhile place indeed to include on your itinerary some time at.

Beautiful temple. One of the best temples to visit in Bangkok. Be careful climbing the steps - they are very very steep. The grounds are nice to walk around. The fee is 50 baht but you can usually sneak in the back without anyone noticing. The detail in this place is incredible. It's also lit up at night which is beautiful.
Beautiful. Like many Thai sites the Temples are beautiful. To have the full effect of Wat Arun, you must climb very steep steps.
Well worth a visit. Close to the Siriraj medical museum. The corn cob prang of this temple is very distinctive. There is a small entrance fee and keep hold of your ticket for readmission.

The nicest temple in Bangkok. I really liked Wat Arun especially for its architectural style, teh same as you can find in the Ankhor Temples in Cambodia. Every single part of the structure has its own meaning and it is related to another part. Its location facing the river makes it a spectacular view from the river and from the area around it. Next to the temple you can find a nice market where to buy souvenirs and where you can also try to be dressed with a typical costume and make a photo in front of it.

Impressive construction. Took some really nice pics and the history behind the Temple is also impressive. Climb to the top of the main temple and get a great view! The stairs are kind of scary though...

My Favorite Site in BKK. I went later in the day on a Saturday, just before sunset. It was not very crowded at that point and so I could wander and take photos without being rushed or disturbed. Admission is a reasonable 50 Baht and well worth it. Remember to bring clothes with you to cover your legs and arms so you don't have to rent any (I have gotten in the habit of roaming BKK in linen pants and a tank top but with a long sleeve shirt in my bag for these cases). The climb up the temple is steep and the steps are narrow but the views from the top are beautiful and it feels very calming up there. You can really get a sense of appreciation for the devotion of those who built the wat.

Worth a visit!. Need to get a boat/water taxi across the river to get to Wat Arun, but it's a beautiful temple. Climbing up is a little scary as the steps at the top are so steep, but you get nice views of the river and Bangkok up there.

Do not forget Wat Arun for gods sake. Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun) is situated on the other side of the river comparing to China Town, Grand Palace, National Museum and Reclining Buddha. Do not take that for a reason not to visit this beautiful temple.If you take a boat with orange flag, 15 bath per person and you pay on the boat, to the Tha Thien Pier, from there it is easy and cheap, 4 bath per person, to reach by Wat Arun with a seperate boat.If you take the opportunity to first visit the majestic Reclining Buddha and the area around, do that, you also have something to compare with. The two piers, 8 and 9, are enough for a days adventure without too much stress and impressions.I found Wat Arun smaller, more genuine and serene, less visitors, an architecture different from the Tha Thien side and therefore a place to love and calm down a bit.

Not for the faint hearted ,,a good workout ,,if you enjoy hikes. A cultural must see this cultural monument is intrically decorated with tiny bits of broken Asian pottery ,,and mirrows ,,making it an unique art form in itself ,,but like many Thai attractions bring good walking shoes ,,but as its still a temple make sure your attire is respectfull and modest ,,making the climb to the top ,,is a journey in itself ,and can be quite ,,the workout ,,,some consider it a spiritual journey ,,to have succeeded in making it to the top ,,the not so physically fit may opt to wait at the bottom and take pitures rest .early in the morning it's cooler that's defiantly a plus the best way to get there ?...I'd take the tourist or local river boats at the bottom of the skytrain stop ,,added note riding the large river boat is very romantic ,,and the best way to get there ,,

good view of bangkok and worth the climb!. We visited the Temple of Dawn early afternoon after Grand Palace and Wat Pho. After a long tail boat across the water, we entered Wat Arun and climbed the steps. The view from the top of the climb was brilliant, although the climb back down with such steep steps was a bit daunting!
Amazing. This is a very beautiful temple. Try climbing the steps all the way to the top for a great view. This temple is also very nice at night certainly if you see it from the river.

Don't Miss. While there are quite a bit Wats in Bangkok/Thailand, Wat Arun has got a little more history to it. It is from a much older period and has the combination of Thai, Cambodian and Hindu culture. It is the sun temple and best visited early in the morning or later in the evening.I used public transport from Sukhmvit to get to Wat Arun. For those interested, here is the run down..Take the Sky train from Asok or Nana station( depending on where you are) to Siam. Siam is the interchange line. From Siam take the train to Central. Once you get down on Central, you are on the east side of the river. Wat Arun is on the other side. Unfortunately I haven't see a ferry that can transport you directly to the West Side. You will have to take a ferry that goes along the banks and get down at Pier 8 and for 3 bhats take a ferry that crosses across.While it seems a lot of work, the connections are pretty quick and it only takes about 35 mins. It cost about 90 bhats one way.Parents traveling with small kids might want to take turns as it is not safe to climb with the kids. Quite steep.

Lovely, unique Anklor style Pagoda with China plate decorated. If you notice, Buddha immages, temple wall and pagodas in Thailand follow syle of Sukhothai, Ayuthaya and also Ankor style. But the Vihar (hall) of this temple decorated with ceramic pieces from China, the Khmer style pagoda decorated by pieces of China plates and bowls. The view of Chao Phraya River and the city from the top of the Pagoda is stunning. You may go at Sunset or Sunrise (not sure when it opens though). Giants are the gate keepers to this vihar, your children will love them as much as they will love the Chinese figures in the Vahar area. Visiting Wat Arun before the Emerald Buddha Temple will enhance the knowledge of those who are interested in history of early Krung Thep. The temples have the same architectural style and also decorated with items from China. It's just lovely, a fun temple for the family :) Climbing up the Pagoda is challenging. It's almost as high as climbing up a pagoda in Angkor Wat. I think this is a collective culture that should be promoted for the solidarity of the region and humankind :)

Beautiful views from the top.. This is a lovely temple and it's well worth the climb for the view from the top. If you don't like heights I think it's safer to come down the very steep steps backwards (like a ladder).

the highest mozaic architecture (i've seen so far). first entered into the temple, I was immediately attracted to photograph in front of the tower mozaic, besides its very high, the weather was extremely good (so hot), so the sky is blue and wat arun was a beautiful combination to take some picture.Many say wat arun beautiful views over night, but during the day we must once again impressed with the details of the temple itself, just imagine porcelen and ceramic fragments exist throughout the tower with a height of 70 feet over it. Not to mention four other tower side. I can not imagine the workers who made ​​this shrine in the old days, they certainly had high taste of art.There is one side of wat arun that I can not enjoy, that is a very steep staircase to the top of the tower, but I extremely want to go on but my guide forbade to go up there because she afraid something tragic will happen. its surely really steep stairs.after a tired sightseeing and taking pictures you definitely will not feel tired when looking at the back of temple area there are so many souvenir thailand that can be obtained cheaply.
Great Place, one of the oldest tamples in Bangkok. This is one of the oldest and most beautiful tamples in Bangkok, that you shouls defenatelly visit in Bangkok!

a quiet place in the early morning. Wat Arun and it's neighboring temple are beautiful and peaceful early in the morning...few tourists at that time and you can stay and linger rather than being "pushed through" by the crowds at other sites. Incredible detail work on outside of buildings, better appreciated with sunlight due to the colors used.

The leaning tower of china. I had already been to quite a few wats (temples) when I went to Wat Arun but it is absolutely unlike any other! The main stupa is made of pieces of china and amazing sculptures. You can climb very high up and although it is scary, it's pretty safe and the views are amazing. You can see where the Royal Palace is (right across the river) and up and downriver for quite a way. Although the rest of the grounds are uninteresting, the stupa is definitely worth seeing and climbing! Take a water taxi home and bargain hard with the driver for a good fare.

Quite the place to see in BKK. One of the most beautiful temples in BKK. The ride to the temple is a story on its own. Try to see the flower market nearby if you plan to take a large boat for yourself. Spend sometime to go to the top if you are a photographer!

Amazing temple. This temple is quite incredible to look at. It is a very peaceful place. From the river it looks quite small but when you are right there next to it, you realise that it is a big structure. Very popular with tourists and Thais alike. Some great photo opportunities here.

Wonderful!. We loved Wat Arun, it is so ornate. We went there first thing in the morning and it was so peaceful. You can get a cool drink at one of the small cafes, but 3 times more expensive than outside, but worth it, especially in the heat. The climb up the Wat gives amazing views over the river, but are very steep, some without hand rails. It is a must see place!We got a Tuk Tuk from outside which gave us a good price, we didn't feel at all ripped off!

Beautiful - in the distance and close up. It's a fascinating construction, like a giant mosaic of ceramic bits making fantastical creatures and patterns. You can climb up for a great view of the river and grand palace.

Well worth the short trip. A short walk from Wat Pho through a group of food and trinket stalls to the Chao Phraya riverside dock brings you to a THB3, yes THREE Thai Baht, ferry boat that makes the two minute crossing to the Thornburi side of the river continuously lets you off at the Wat Arun. This is one of the most holy places in Thailand and only a short walk around. Stop bye the small cafe on the Bangkok side of the ferry and have a cold beer... and tip our Thai friend Noi who seems to run the place and always be there with her big friendly smile and little English beyond "tip box"... the menu does have pictures and pidgin English.

Not much to see or do. Paid 50 Baht entry, information booklet only available in Thai.Climb the stairs for a picture with a view, not much else to do or see. there is another small temple in front of wat Arun where you can see the History of King Thaksin, some statues of him, his bed and some buddhas.Take the ferry to and from the pier for 3 Baht each direction which takes about 4 minutes per crossing
great. wat arun is a must see when visiting bangkok.looks beautiful at night as its all lit up and only costs 3 baht to cross river from other side

Perfect at night time. I went to this temple at night time as part of a tour run by Grasshopper Tours, Bangkok at night bicycle tour. Our tour guide Tic, took us here first, and at night time its so peaceful, whne we arrived, we could even hear the Monks chanting. There was lights on all of the temples, which allowed you to see the great workmanship that went into making them, and allowed for some excellent photos. If you wish to escape the crowds, then the best time to see this Temple is at night, plus its a lot cooler.If you can, get Tic as your tour guide, as his knowledge is immense.I would recommend this to everyone.
Nice place, great sunset. Take the boat close to the Wat Pho to cross the river and visit it, and don't miss the sunset (on the Wat Pho side) facing the Wat Arun.

Beautifull temple complex, don't miss. Beautifull temple complex, which can be climed by very steep stairs. We did this in late afternoon other wise it woul be to hot.Simple take the std ferry for a few bat to other side of the river and enjoy

The symbol and the must see of Bangkok. You definitely have to go there! The ticket is not expensive, but the experience is spectacular.Be attentive at the stairs, going up is easy, but going down is a scary experience for many visitors.
wonderful. What loverly detail and so beautiful to look at I was amazed at the stone structure and the wonderful gardens
Beautiful Wat. High temple, make me feel kind of dizzy. A temple from stone, and it is very beautiful to see this temple in the afternoon... when the sun is going down.

A Wonderful Place. Wat Arun is simply breathtaking. We came off the river ferry into this tranquil enclave where the ancient temple rises spectacularly skyward. It is stunningly beautiful and there is a wonderful tinkling of hundreds of small bells in the background. We could have spent all day just soaking up the atmosphere, it was just so unrushed and relaxing....quite unlike Bangkok!

A tourist oasis high above the Bangkok bustle. The centrepiece is the monolithic spire-like tower, which - if you're up for climbing the steep stone steps - affords excellent views (on a sunny day) over the Chao Phraya river and Bangkok cityscape. Be warned - the climb up is NOT the difficult bit. The climb down is! If you suffer from vertigo, think twice - the steepness of the staircases looking down at them is enough to make a mountain goat giddy! But the tower is a marvel of intricate design and inlay - almost like a fractal, if you look at it long enough. The tiers of human figures caught my eye - and the trio of elephants' heads on each side are a feature. The whole site is calm and tranquil, and from the tower you are well above the bustle of Bangkok. Worth a boat trip over - a bit of a tourist oasis.
Climb the stairs if you dare. Looks cool from the river, and up close it's very ornate. Climb the extremely steep stairs for a good view of Bangkok across the river.

This is best seen at the beginning or end of the day. I have been to Wat Arun twice and loved it. Yuo may be put off by the sellers of wares all around but take some time to look at the structure and where it is. The climb up is hard and step, so if you arent in good shape or suffer from acrophobia, you might not want to do it. But I enjoyed the view and the ambience.

one of the main attractions in bangkok. Its visible from the road as you are getting closer , its acually quite a big temple .... the views from the top are good .. overall a good visit if you are with you family........... most tours can take you to this on a stop over to other attractions................

A must for first time visitors. Thats all there is to it....don't be lazy and just go! Climb up and then take your time. My thought is you can get out of this visit whatever you want. At least itbis far and across the river from the hustle of BKK. My advise is to go relatively early and take a boat across the Chao Praya river and enjoy. Take the boat from the flower market which is really mind blowing and if you have the patience just ask prices there. At War Arun please take your time and respect that despite it being a major tourist attraction that itbis an important place to the residents

Nice ceramics and view. Easy to get to navagate from BTS to Saphan Taksin, walked to ferry terminal via the Express boat (15 baht) to stop #8 and nipped across the on the ferry (3 baht) to Wat Arun. 50 baht entry... great view of Bangkok...very interesting the amount of broken ceramics all over the wat.
Amazing. Loved it. So tall, a bit high for kids so they stayed down and we took turns going up. Great view from top. Was a great half hour - nothing much else to do. (was a stop on the boat ride)
Go early in the morning. This is an awesome sight. To see it at its best, go early in the morning or just before sunset
Amazing Climb. I loved that you were able to climb this temple. It was a little scary coming back down but such a cool temple!
Wonderful. The Scenery is good but while on the long boat make sure to confirm if the snake farm is open, we missed out on that as our tour guide informed it was being washed.

Amazing view. Wat Arun is a must visit in Thailand. You will be climbing up a very steep staircase to the top, but the view from there of the river and the city is fantastic. A quick boat ride from Bangkok to the other side of the river where Wat Arun is located also gives you a sense of the river culture in Bangkok.
simply amazing place. please visit this place if you have time in BKK. its awesome

Excellent views and majestic in all ways. This is a definite must-see for anyone visiting Bangkok. We went by water taxi and it was an easy ride. The temple is just breath-taking; the intricacy and sheer amount of work that must have gone in to building the temp,e and facade is incomprehensible. I tried to go up the stairs, and as others have noted, looking down will just take the courage right out of you. I ended up going back down on my rear! Excellent place for photography, and overall, it is another reminder of the great lengths that people have gone to for religion.

nice 'wat', steep stairs. You have to go by boat to get to the other side of te river (3 TB).To get in the 'wat'itself you pay a fee of 50 tb. Nice wat with a beautiful view when you climb up the steep stairway.A lot of people (who are afraid of hights?) have problems when they have to go back. You dont realize how steep it is when you go up.
What a wow. The special sense of Buddha entrances you with the Temple of Dawn..

Just a fun visit!. I have visited this place for several times the last years, I always managed to visit Wat Arun while making a tour through the Klongs.It is just fun to visit, it is a beautiful temple and it is also great that the stairs are intact, so you can climb up pretty high.While climbing you have an amazing view of that part of Bangkok, including a view over the river.So, everyone who is making a tour on the Chao Praya, take the time to visit this temple, it is worth it.

Delightfull temple - good views over Bangkok. Never been there before, although already fifth time in Bangkok: make a better choice and go her the first time you are in Bangkok. The temple is delightfull, rather quiet if you consider that it is one that this is one of the major sights of Bangkok. Climb the steep stairs of the temple all to the top and enjoy the views over the river and (part of) Bangkok. Go with the express boat to the pier opposite of Wat Arun and take the small ferry that crosses the river (3 Bath each one way).
Not for the faint hearted. Well worth the trip to the other side of the river, the views were amazing. It was absolutely terrifying climbing back down the steps.
Magnficient Temple. I love it more than the palace. The view was excellent when you made an effort to climb up the temple.

Very nice place but not for the Acrophobic!. Great place to visit, especially if you are visiting Grand Palace and Wat Po then you should not miss this. Its just across the street from Wat Po, take the ferry which is only 3Baht/person and takes about 5 mins to cross Chao Phraya and you are there.It gives a fantastic view from the other side of the river, and the temple itself is also very nice. If you are able and fancy climbing the stairs, then do go all the way up. A word of caution - the steps of the stairs are really steep and it probably is harder to come down than to go up. But once you are up you get a fabulous view of the city with sky liners and the riverside, worth taking the risk and pain to clim all the way up.The entrace is only 50 Baht/person, so one should not miss. Liked it thoroughly!
Make the climb!. What a beautiful temple. Worth the visit. Make sure you make the climb up the steep (very very steep) stairs, if you can. It's a spiritual and physical challenge worth taking.

lovely attraction but mind the steps!. I really liked everything abiout this site, it is well kept and the temple is amazing. you can climb on it but steps are quite high, expecially when you go down you have to be careful. However it is worth doing it.
worth a visit. Beautiful place built with amazing detail. The views from the top of Wat Arun are worth the climb, just do not go to the top if you suffer with vertigo.
Boring. Repeatativ statues. Boring, only one small building
Acrophobia? Not for you!. Dont miss the chance to climb the huge prang for an amazing view of Bangkok!
Worth the trek to the top. Low entry fee for foreigners, and a great view from the top. But it will be some adventure climbing up.

Beautiful place. Tranquil place. Mesmerized by it's beauty.
The view from the top is amazing if you make it up those steep steps!
Very fun to climb. Super view. People I take here always enjoy it. Some are a little scared by the steep stairs, especially on the way down but always enjoyable.
good view. it's very beautiful temple and very nice sunset.near chaophraya river can take by boat
a MUST to visit. visit Wat Arun in the morning when u have the best light, its not too hot yet, and - it is the temple of dawn, thats its time!
A Peaceful Oasis in a Bustling City. A very peaceful place. Have been there many times and never very crowded.
Amazing. It was amazing to both see the detail of this beautiful Wat and to be able to climb up it and see the view
Plan to see it at dusk.... I have only seen this Wat from an Express Boat on the Chao Praya River & I think the best photo can be taken at dusk. (Last seen Jan 2011)
A must see!. This is the wat to visit, climb, explore. It's fun getting there (on river ferry)... and a wonderful place to spend some time.
Beautiful. Make sure you go if in Bangkok - this is not to be missed

Beautiful Wat Arun. One of our party was a first timer to Bangkok,and he was very taken with Wat Arun,we found the best view was from a longtail boat and the photos took in the river life as well .Stunning!!
Not be missed. You should also see in in the evening when they turn the lights on. However, it does close early so need to see it in the day as well.

Amazing Temple decorated with mosiacs. Inexpensive entrace fee. I think it was ~10 bat? For women, come with a shawl maybe if it's hot to cover the shoulders. It was REALLY hot hiking up the stairs mid summer day.
Going up the steep stairs and looking around the temple made the hot worth it!

Great night view. This is one of the historic temples in bangkok which has an excellent night view. They are lit up well and the best time for viewing is night and while on a dinner cruise. so you save good time as well.
Worth The Climb!. A steep climb to the top but worth the view! Lots of good photo opps as you approach from the water.
Nice view when passing by on the river boat. One of Bangkoks most impressive monuments. Passing by on the river boat gives a very nice view as well in case you're short-timed.

It's not bad being number 2. After the palace walk around to the river and take the ferry. Make sure that your camera has plenty of memory as you will snap multiple shots as you go across the river. It doesn't take an Olympian to go up the temple, do not talk yourself out of it!!! The surrounding grounds and other shrines are great, so it is not just about going up the temple. And don't forget the cheesy trinkets.

good architecture. very traditional design.needs more maintenance.the steps are really steep.but the view from the top is very good.they must provide guides to explain the history.needs more promotion as many tourists do not know.

Good place to visit. This is a temple where you should visit, you need to use the traditional boat to go there and at the pier you may find cheap souvenirs, the temple located near the river, try to get photo at the evening looks awesome

What a sight.. A great sight to see but very difficult to climb! Easy to get to using the tourist ferry and a small local one. Be careful about what you wear, especially ladies, but you can rent cover ups.

Fun to explore. This was the first time I visited, and over 12 years since my husband first went. We had previously visited the other Wats/Palace over a few years ago and missed this one due to the additional boat ride. It is easy to get there and very cheap to get the second boat across the river.The Wat itself reminds you more of an Egyptian or Cambodian structure. It is both interesting from afar and near...near I loved looking at all the pieces of ceramic. The climb is a bit steep, especially if you don't like heights. But with the handrails, it is actually much easier than other temples you climb in SE Asia.
Just a temple. Nothing much to see. Just a normal and small temple. There are stalls outside if you wish to buy souvenirs. A 5Baht charge for the entrance.

Well worth a visit. I can only recommend a visit to Wat Arun just opposite Wat Phra Kaeo on the other side if of the Chao Phraya river. What makes it interesting is that Wat Arun is so different from the 'typical' Thai Wats as this temple has a lot of Hindu elements. Climb up the steep stairs and you will be rewarded with a nice view over the Chao Phraya river

Good, but not excellent. Nice architecture, but there's almost nothing to do except climb to the top and back down. It isn't half as old as other temples I've been to in this part of the world (especially Cambodia), but nevertheless impressive in itself.

Great riverside attraction!. Take the Orange flag water taxi from sathorn pier to Tha Tien station. Do not take the tourist boat - it is a rip off! An encellent temple. There is a steep climb in a tall wat inside the temple. Difficult climb to the top but once there it gives an amazing view of the riverside bangkok,

Nice to visit. If you want some historical and religious trip the it is must to visit. Though instead of taking small ferry take taxi and reach the Grand place and from there take boat to reach same place.Nice place, nice view of river and surrpodings.Thanks

old world charm. i saw wat arun during the chao praya river cruise. therefore couldnot go inside. but the temple is simply magnificient from outside !! we saw it during the day and hence it wasnt lit up. but at night the temple becomes all the more beautiful... the reflection of the temple in water makes a marvellous view which one shouldnot miss!!

Breathe taking view and stairs. Be careful with the scam!. Highly recommend! This temple cannot be missed if on a trip to Bangkok. Entry fee is 50 Baht. 3Baht per person to ferry across the Wat Pho pier to the Wat Arun station. Beautiful temple with detailed paints and cravings. Although the stairs look scary, you have to climb it as you will be awarded with a wonderful view above the river and Bangkok city. Don’t try to take picture with the board cutouts (Thai-style dancer with the face cut out) that place near the pier. It’s a scam! The famous Wat Arun photo scam. We witnessed a few other tourists were being asked by some local to paid 40Baht once they taken pictures with the cutouts.
a must see for traveller. i visit this temple many times and never get bore, it is so beautiful,
Must see. Definitely worth the climb to the top for the views and experience......so peaceful here compared to Grand Palace, LOVED it!

A mystique temple. Without any restoration it is a place to inhale the Thai religion, to have an amazing view of the city but must of all it is inserted in the middle of the city creating these mix between modernity and history. Small stores with warmth people and beautiful souvenirs, a place to pray and being with yourself

Try to make it see this one... This temple cannot be missed if on a trip to Bangkok. The temple can be approached from the land (Taxi -if you are in Thon Buri BTS side and adjacent areas) or if you are in Wat Pho/Grand palace areas then you need to take the ferry-shuttle service. It costs 3 B per person to ferry across the Wat Pho pier to the Wat Arun station. The service operates once in about every 20 minutes or so.Entry fee is 50 B. I think it is free for Thais. There are a few souvenir shops around the ticket counter. You may be approached by a tout, we were not - maybe Indians know how to treat the touts and the locals already know about it by now. The temple can be explored in about 30 to 40 mins. The main tower of the temple is huge and you can climb up all the way to almost the top to see the Bangkok city. It is a stunning view of the river and the building of Bangkok. The walls have very detailed paints along with some cravings.At night, if you are on a river cruise, be sure when heading north, you have a look at your left to see the illuminated temple.

Challenging stairs!. One of the must-visit places in Bangkok. Once you climb the steep stairs you get an awesome view above the river and part of Bangkok. Details and decorations of the temple are impressive! Easy to get there, boats, ferries crossing the river frequently...

Awesome temple and climb. Visited the temple after taking ferry for 45baht from Centrel Pier. I took my 5yr old son up the temple which although is a steep climb to the 2nd level was well worth it.Awesome views of the river, Bangkok skyline and across to the Grand Palace. The temple is a marvel in itself and the detail in the jewels/coloured stones all over the temple is amazing. When we visited it was rather hot (around 42degrees) but there is plenty of small stores to grab water etc. Again make sure you pay the 50baht and take the time to climb up.

Very beautiful. This temple is very different to the other temples we visited – the architecture is beautiful and unique, especially the use of different broken pieces Chinese porcelain to decorate the structure with floral designs.It is certainly worth it to climb up the temple structure to appreciate the beautiful architecture of the temple, and views over the river.The temple complex is lit up at night, providing a spectacular sight – especially if viewed from the river.
Great first Wat. The architecture was beautiful. We didn't go inside and climb the structure, but we were on our way to Wat Pho.
Amazing. The visit to the temple will be memorable due to the fastinating structure
Just an average but good to see. Its interesting to visit this temple. Different, but if you have been to Angkor Wat, this is not as interesting as Angkor.Just another temple. Something new to see
Reminds me of Angkor wat .... The wat arun was probably inspired by angkor wat as the architecture is similar. nice and worth the visit.

Amazing!. Use public boat from the pier near Wat Pho, its very cheap. The temple is decorate with white marble, and so beautiful.
Worth to visit.
Gorgeous. We took a Klong tour and Wat Arun was the last stop on our list. Make the effort to climb to the second level, It's so worth it! Dont bother with the markets, its waaay cheaper at Patpong!
The best. This is the best temple you can visit in Bangkok. Lots of details on the towers of the towers and a nice view from the top.

Wat Arun, no shiny Grand Palace but a jewel in itself. Great view of the river and Bangkok from the top of this temple. If you go to the Grand Palace and Wat Pho then I highly suggest including Wat Arun, it is so close by. It is a very cheap and short trip across the river and well worth it. The boat is very frequent as well so you will not be stuck there for any lengthy period of time...The temple is not as shiny as the Grand Palace but it had it's own magic and there was no disappointment for me in this visit...
Very good peaceful. Like so many things in Thailand,you have to experience it to relate to it.

Great view of Bangkok and river. Once you complete the steep climb up the side of the temple, you enjoy a great view of the River and Bangkok city - and all for just 50 baht (under $2). There is also a neat little coffee shop in the gardens on ground level where you can also enjoy watching life as it goes by on the River. Top spot

Fantastic experience, make sure you have ample time there is a lot to see and do suggest at least 2 hours. Avoid the guys at the gate who are trying to tell you the place is closed and offering to take to other points of interest
Fantastic Views. Great views across the river towards the Grand Palace. Be careful as steps are very steep & high!

Brilliant. It is very convinient to take a ferry from the pier near Wat Pho to the river side of War Arun. The ferry costs 3 Baht. The entrance to Wat Arun costs 50 Baht. There is good suvenir market nera Wat Arun. Also the wat is very beautifull during the evening.

Fantastic at Night. It looked fantastic at night with lighting when I saw from Chao Praya dinner cruise. Was good during the day but would give it a miss if am short of time and have to choose over other options
Great view, beautiful architecture.. Well worth your time and money. For 3 baht you can take a ferry across the river from the grand palace. Climb to the top by way of impossibly steep steps.
Incredible views. The temple itself is incredible - one of my favourites! - and the effort to climb it has an amazing reward! as the view of the river and the Great Palace across is breathtaking!!
A temple with a difference. A really unique temple covered in pieces of pottery. It sparkles in the morning sun. The best way to reach it is from the river.
Amazing. Another amazing Temple in Bangkok with such history.

Wat Arun has great views but not as well kept as the Palace. You have to catch a ferry to get across from the Grand Palace. It is a great opportunity to climb up and see some river views but this temple is not as well kept as the others.

Favorite Temple !!. The view is breathtaking & the incredible detail of everything is INSANE. Absolutely worth it and if you go later in the afternoon, it is very quiet (a lot quieter than the other two temples across the river). Also, there's a little park outside the temple with a little drinks hut that sells the BEST Thai Iced Tea I've ever had.
It dawned on me. One of the absolutely most beautiful temples in Bangkok. Easy to get to from cross-river ferry at Wat Pho, beside the Grand Palace. Beautiful views from the top.

Temple of Dawn - Great. You must be visiting the temple by dawn at dusk. The view is absolutely fantastic. The temple is 70-meter-high spire decorated with tiny pieces of colored glass and Chinese porcelain. There are steps to climb so if you are old/lazy avoid this place. Nice view and architecture. I loved it.

Amazing architecture. If you can it is well worth climbing the three levels of steps to admire the view and the use of broken ceramics to adorn this monument There is a small ferry that takes you across from the main city side of town.

Part of the Day Tour which most tourists will go to. Like - the architecture, the temple surrounds.
Dislike - nothing.

Sheer beauty. Wat Arun is considered one of the most well known of Bangkok's many landmarks. You can marvel the brilliant temple as your boat approaches pier N8. Entering the temple ground, you can offer your respects to Buddha, and receive blessings from the monk. Thereafter, head to the mighty central tower or prang, and make your way to the top. Certain steps are steep and narrow, so may have to walk sideways. However, the view from the top is one which will leave you breathless, literally and figuratively!

Most beautiful Pagoda in Thailand. You need a boat to get here. There are boats near the river banks so you can tour the river. A shot from the river will give you a very nice view of the Temple of the Dawn. Wear lots of sunscreen if you are visiting in the afternoon or late in the morning. The heat can be pretty intense. You can get a nice view of the river and the city from the top, just watch your step and hold on the hand rails. I find the details on the entire structure quite interesting as it has porcelain encrusted all over it. Looking up you'll see the God Indra riding a three headed elephant. There are giants supporting the main prang. I like everything about this structure simply because it describes a lot about Thai architecture, very grand and exotic. Lots of details on this structure which I find very interesting.
so high and steep. my mother and i did not continue going inside the temple because you have to climb up so high and the stairs are steep. it is not friendly for my old mother.

Beautiful.. Wow...what a beautiful temple this is.The carvings,the intricacies in them,the views from the top make this a great experience.We took the 3B ferry from across the river at Wat Pho ...The entrance to the temple is 50B/pp.Suggest coming around 5pm to climb up the stairs to the top and get a glimpse of Bangkok entering twilight.It's stunning!

Wear Pants!. Brilliant view from this temple and definitely worth the visit. We had not planned this stop on the particular day we visited and it was quite windy - I was wearing a dress. A little uncomfortable climbing the stairs! The Temple was worth it though!
Beautiful inside and outside. One of the most beautiful temples in Thailand. Definitely worth a visit.

saw this from Chao Phraya Express boat. Just saw this from Chao Phraya Express boat. No opportunity to visit this temple, hence, the average rating. You can't miss this structure as the main prang is visible from afar.

The best sunset view in Bangkok. For 50 Baht you can enter this Temple with a very high altitude. I counted 100 very steep stairs till you get to the top. You cross the Chao river by riding a boat from the stop of Wat Pho, the boat ride costs 3 Baht and will only take 2 mins. The Temple of Dawn has an amazing presence. It is bigger than life, literally and although unlike Wat Pho. It is only one Temple and no other attractions around the place. The best time to visit this place is during the afternoon, as you will get the sunset view of Bangkok and it will a memory that will last a life time!
amazing. You'd be simply mad not to do this. It was hot, but absolutely stunning- like nothing you get in Europe.
You have to see this up close to appreciate it.. It is entirely decorated/ mosaic with Chinese porcelain plates cut into flowers and decorations. You can see the original china pattern. Really cool.

My Favourite Wat. My subject title tells it all, if you only go to one Wat in Bangkok, make it this one. Great architecture and very steep steps to get up to the top but make sure you go right the way up because the view is fantastic and worth the effort. We were lucky enough to be there on Buddha Day (June 4th) so saw all the rituals and prayers taking place, it was very interesting. All is all, this is a must see.

Worth a Visit in Bangkok. Wat Arun is a tall temple that is hard to miss on the west bank across the river from the Palace area. It can be climbed to the halfway point. It is also an interesting sight in the evening.
Beautiful temple, great cheap handy crafts. Great photo taking place. Have many cheap handy crafts for sale behind the temple.
Interesting place to visit! Too scared of its hight!. Amazing temple with all tiled up building construction. Liked the first platform having a great view, but second platform was very scary!
Great visit, and a must if you in Bangkok.. Very beautiful place to visit and take photos, very details architectural structure.

Colourful and interesting. As with all Thai temples it was colourful and interesting. Lots to look at and can spend some time sitting and contenplating. Nice ambience inside (but take your shoes off first).

High climb, great view. Wat arun temple was impressive from the boat ride and fantastic up close. It is a beautiful piece of art from every direction. Take the boat for 3 baht to cross from the palace if you are on the wrong side. Be aware that a steep climb is ahead of you but it is worth it
The temple with a unique exterior finish.. This temple, as we were told is finished with the broken crockery of the royal family's dining halls. Isn't it amazing.

We were conned!. We were at the pier waiting for the bus boat to come... we told that today was 'Big Buddha Day' and that Wat Arun could only be visited by taxi boat and it would cost £40... but once we got there, it would be amazing because different parts of the temple were open on this special day... how exciting!Hmmmm.... it sounds silly as I am writing it, was all a con! The wat was beautiful but not as impressive as Wat Pho and tainted by our experience.
breathtaking!!. GO AT SUNSET!! and its so worthworth climbing to the top but dont forget your bottle of water... its a bit scary coming back down cause the stairs are really steep...
Beautiful. Temple of Dawn is beautiful in the day but will be at its best at night when all lit up
Night time view.. The night view of this temple with all the brilliant lighting is not to be missed.

Beautiful Wat!!!!. Despite the extreme summer heat at 9am... visiting Wat Arun is the highlight of the trip. It was beautiful looking far while on the ferry and even more beautiful when we get there. One catch is after you arrived to the wharf, walking toward Wat Arun, there are 2 faceless frames of Thai people where you can put your face in to take pictures, please don't get too excited and take photos with it because you will be rip off and charge 40baht, once your camera click there will be someone walking towards you and collect the money immediately. So beware.For people that are afraid of heights, the steps are very steep and children should not be left alone, recommended that children should not be taken up those steps because it is very dangerous. However, if you can get up all the steps, you will get an awesome view of Bangkok from the top. Be careful with all the electrical wires, some of them are exposed. Based on the previous review, getting there is very easy. Depend from where you stayed, example we stayed at Centara World, we catch the BTS skytrain from Siam station to Saphan Taksin---> get off and walk to ferry wharf and take the ferry to N8 (15baht per person) get off and catch another ferry to cross the river to WAT ARUN (3baht per person)Overall it is a must see attraction, highly recommend for everyone.
Busy ancient Krungthep. For me the Chao Phraya is the bloodstream of Bangkok and the Wat Arun is amazing part of it.
Scorching hot!. No, seriously. Don't forget your hat, water and sunblock.And you can also reach Wat Arun from Wang Lang if you don't want to cross the river with a 3-Baht ferry from Tha Thien pier.
Well worth the effort. Beautiful temple.Maybe best to go early in the day,as walking up all the steps( o dear,and down them!) is scorching,but worth it for the view.
Beautifl at night. We saw the temple of Down from the Market side (across the river) it was beautiful. We went back during the day and walked up the pogada. It was worht a visit!

Wat Arun. It is a site to behold especially if you like historical ancient temple. I visited it around 6pm, it was windy and very less tourist around. If you get the chance to see this place at night dont miss it. I manage to view it at night as I was on the river cruise boat...it was magnificent...

If you have more time to spend. Great place to visit, but I would say as second priority if you don't have much time. The view of the river from the top of the monument might be the best; if you go, getting up is a must.Geometric repetition following its square base up its quite eye catching.

Great temple and view. Wat Arun is definitely worth to visit. Easy to get there by ferry and explore the temple. The entrance fee is 50THB/person.
The stairs are really steep and it´s difficult for elderly people to climb up. Mainly on the way down several couples had a problems getting down. However the view is fantastic.

Temple of Dawn. This was amazing - the only problem was the heat that was so intense and the stairs that are very very steep so that we did not try and get to the top - the furthest we managed was one level up.The ceramics are unreal and the whole wat is just beautiful.If it is cooler it would be possible to climb to the top - I would recommend that it is visited early in the morning as the views from the top must be great. We also saw the wat from the river and it is a beautiful sight.

Favourite temple!. Temple of Dawn is without a doubt my favourite of all the temples we saw in Thailand...and we saw a LOT! Part of the temple is made from beautiful porcelain, which is stunning in the sunshine. It's pretty steep to climb up the steps, but worth the view once you're up there. It's a little hairy going back down in flip flops!Make sure you have something to cover your shoulders / legs when you visit.

Really worth seeing. 995 of tourists arrive by boat, but if you can be bothered it's much better to come in by road and arrive at the proper entrance and walk through the whole complex before your come upon the main temple.

Beautiful Temple with the best view of Cao Phraya River. The temple is very beautiful with fantastic ornaments, if you climb to the top, you will get a best view of Cao Phraya River. Take a picture around them and you will have memorable time especially during sunset.

Nice temple. Beautiful temple! If you're going to climb to the top, keep in mind that the stairs are extremely steep and walking down is much more difficult than going up. On the way down, hold the railing and hold it tight.. and perhaps walk backwards. It helps. lol :) Definitely worth a visit. Brilliant photo-op!

Worth the climb. I thoroughly enjoyed this temple. The statue and guards at the entrance are in fantastic condition. The views from the top are not to be missed if you don't mind the very steep climb.
Climb to the top. Although the stairs are steep, I loved walking up and down the various levels of this temple, looking at all of the details and views. It is definitely worth the trip.

Interesting site. We visited Wat Arun as a part of a cruise in the Chao praya river. It is a beautiful impressive temple, a bit difficult to climb all the way up and down with steep steps, but the view is really great. It is not allowed for women to enter without proper clothing, so they have pareos etc at the entrance. I believe it worths a visit.
Amazing!!. After grand palace and Wat pho. cross the street and take a taxi boat to wat arun. It's amazing place.

In my view the most interesting temple to visit. Take the ferry from the dock opposite the Grand Palace for THB3 to cross the river and you will find a most interesting temple in Bangkok. The detailed handwork is just amazing. Climb the VERY steep stairs to the second floor (not recommended for people scared of heights) and you will have a fantastic view of the river and central Bangkok. Take a rest afterwards on one oft the benches in the shade with a bottle of water to finish off this enjoyable part of your culture trip in Bangkok

Awesome at sunset. It was one of the last temples I visited and I was glad I had the time to go here. I took a small boat to cross the river to get to this temple. There was a bit of a challenge to exploring Wat Arun - the visitors were allowed to climb the steps to get to the observation 'area' and the steps were very steep and narrow. But once I got there, the view was awesome. It was late in the afternoon when I went there and spent quite a lot of time taking in the wonderful view of the sun getting ready to set. Not a lot tourists here. There was also a place there for young monks. Running around in their robes, no trace of worry in their faces. Wonderful sight. I left the temple just when the sun was about the set. It was glorious.

A must include. From a distance it does not have the bright color like so many other places in Bangkok. But when you get close and look at the detail it is nice. At night it is illuminated and looks spectacular.

Both thrilling and calming. We approached the temple from across the river and it was pretty impressive from that vista. As we approached, the temple became more impressive. The Happy Buddha greeted us upon entry. The temple is guarded by both demigods and demons (statues). Because it is a temple, we had to be in proper clothing. No shorts or uncovered shoulders are allowed. ...then we started to climb.The climb upward was a little difficult in the beginning then became downright challenging as we climbed higher. This was steep and sweaty work! There was one way up and two ways down the square tower. The tower itself was beautiful with mosaics and stones. The monks were also insightful enough to put up a graffiti wall in the highest part of the tower. Tourists do after all, like to leave little souvenirs of themselves. From the highest climbable level, the view of the river and the city was pretty impressive.The climb downward was definitely the most difficult part. It was probably a 70 degree incline. Our party tackled the going down different ways--some doing it backwards ala stepladder, some using our arms more than our feet, some at a diagonal. Going down was just as sweaty as going up but for an entirely different reason.I surmise the going up and down the temple tower must have been a test of one's will. I am not Buddhist so I really don't know but I can attest that it is truly a test of wills.Worth it? Yup, yup, yup!

Wat Arun - vertigo. Very cheap to visit. However, if you suffer from vertigo, do not go up the steps to the top level of the monument! Fine going up but very scarey looking down the steep steps when its time to go down. Several visitors were nearly in tears with fear.
Beautiful. But annoying to get to- had to take a ferry on very choppy river.
Interesting place to visit. I enjoyed visiting Wat Arun... Lots of stairs that are a bit scary for those afraid of heights. Great view from the top though.
Awesome!. Such a cool site and beautiful setting. Careful if you are afraid of heights, but otherwise it's well worth it!
magnificent. never seen anything like it.only dislike the tax collector on the landing a little gruff
Calm and peace are here. We love this place, we got into there a bit late of afternoon, almost close. But they let us went inside and climb to the top. Brilliant Thanks !@

Beautiful Temple. Beautiful temple on the other side of the river. Worth climbing the stairs to get fantastic views of Bangkok. Cost 50 baht to enter and you can buy tickets on the gate.
Take the boat over the river to Wat Po - cost 3 baht per person!

Different from other wats. I really enjoyed visiting this wat as it looks very different from the other ones, not as full of gold as the rest. We came during noon time and it was not busy at all. The climb up the steps is very steep especially if you are not 6 feet tall as the steps are very high. The views are lovely but I was not very keen on climbing down as it seemed even steeper. The entrance fee of 50 bath is worth it. My favbourite wat.

Busy, but a "can't miss". This was by far the most beautiful of all of temples we saw on our trip. Even getting there by boat across the river was a beautiful journey! It's worth it to make the extra effort to go there at dawn.
cool view. didn't get a chance to see it when the sun was going down but it's a cool view once you get to the top.
Worth the trip across the river. Worth the short trip across the river. Great views of Bangkok and beautiful in itself

LOVE, LOVE, LOVE Wat Arun!!. We are living in Bangkok for two years and we cannot say enough that is good about Wat Arun! It is one of our favorite places to take visitors and we highly recommend it to visitors. Not only is the Wat itself beautiful, but the experience on the water taxi and the view itself are highly worth the visit!

Interesting construction. We took a ferry boat from Taksin and got off on the side oposite the temple. A small ferry took us across. The temple is quite impressive and one can climbe the staircases to high level for a good view of the city. Absolutly worth while

Very Nice. One of the oldest Wats in Bangkok if not the oldest. Beautifully decorated with bits of pottery and semi precious stones. A must visit while in Bangkok. Especially impressive when lit up at night.
Don't miss it.. Wat Arun is beautiful at night. Take an evening dinner cruise and see it all lit up. It's lovely. If you go during the day, be sure to climb all the way up and enjoy a wonderful view.

Great view at the top. Clean temple grounds and I enjoyed climbing the stairs up to the mid way point of the temple. Offers a great view of the area. Yes the steps are extremely steep but there is a good rail to grip while climbing

must see. Awesome temple much different to everything else, very steep steps especially at 22 weeks pregnant but felt great to reach the top, do the circles and make a wish... Coming down, hold on for dear life.
Beautiful views from the top!
A most. This place is different to all other Wats - the river crossing is great to get to it and the steps to climb it are so steep.

Very very beautiful. I went there during the day and it has the most spectacular view from the top.
Take a night cruise boat night, the temple is beautifully lit-up..
Amazing. This temple is fantastic, being able to climb up and wonder about it is great. I also recommend taking a cruise at night to see it lit up. Even more special.

My favourite temple in Thailand. There are prettier temples around but it is totally consuming. The approach to the temple from the river is more stunning than being on the grounds as the area is quite small. Getting an angle for a photo can be quite hard but it is an awsome structure and a true credit to the Land of Smiles.
Beautiful. One of the less chaotic beautiful temples in BKK. The river ride across adds tk the fun. A must see.

A place not to miss. The temple is amazing and the view from there are great. To complete the experience take the ferry boat. Nice place to take photos. Another nice view of the city.
Note: The stairs are very steep!

Worth a visit: take your photo of it on the East side of the river. You can have the choice of only seeing this from a distance and avoiding the entrance fee or actually visiting it on the West side of the river. But you certainly should visit the Grand Palace, Wat Pho and the City Shrine in about three hours or so because they are all right near each other on the East side of the river. However, as I mentioned, Wat Arun is on the opposite side of the river across from the Grand Place and this will add at least an hour to your trip for a total of four hours or so to see all four attractions. As far as Wat Pho itself, there is not much to see there if you have seen a few Thai temples. However, Wat Arun offers something different than the average Thai temple: a pagoda covered in porcelain that was taken from a sunken ship. To be honest, I feel that the temple looks better from a distance. Once you get up close, however, I feel it kind of loses the magic you saw from a distance. TIPS:1. You can avoid the traffic by taking the BTS to Sapan Taksin and then get off and go down to the water's edge to take a cheap boat ride (great scenic views) to Tha Chang. Then take a ferry across the river. Ignore the touts who will try to get you to buy their boat service rather than the very cheap ferry service that the locals use. 2. Before you get on the ferry or as you are going across the river, take pictures of Wat Arun. Once you get there, it is not as easy to fit the spire of this pagoda into your pictures. 3. Be careful on the steep stairs! You are not allowed to climb all the way up anymore.4. Once you finish, take the ferry back across the river. You will get off and you will be right in the back of the Grand Palace and Wat Pho. The City Shrine where you can see the city's pillar is just across the street from these two temples. This attraction, unlike the other two I mentioned, is free. Make sure you wear formal clothes and that your feet are covered or Thai guards will not allow you in as you are. However, you will have to take your shoes off to go inside the temple where the giant Reclining Buddha is.
Worth it. Its definitely worth going to see! Just hop on the river bus and go across. Amazing how they can build all these things.

Definitely worth a visit!. beautiful temple which just gets better and the better the more you see of it and the views of the Chao phraya River from the top are stunning. If you only have time to choose a couple of temples to visit in Bangkok, make sure this one is on the list.
Nice temple by the river. Not as crowded, beautiful...nice view of the Chao Phraya
Must see!. Get the local boat over, it's a must do - prepare for some steep steps but the view is great!

Beautiful. In my opinion, this is one of the most beautiful man-made structures in the world. This temple is best appreciated from a bar or restaurant across the river at sunset. The view is further enhanced if you have a cold beer in your hand.
Beautiful river view from the top. This temple is the best place to have beautiful view of river as well landmarks like Grand Palace and Wat Po.

Always liked this place. Temple of Dawn is a great place to go and see. And besides, if you are booked on those cheap Free and Easy Packages, they throw this in as a freebie.
