But do pay the 50bht entry free to get inside the temple. Its worth it and treat that as a donation to the buddhist cause.Architecture is excellent, reminds me of the Wat designs in Angkor. Steep climbs on stairs to the next level. I won't spoil the fun with more descriptions. Recommended Go. Located on the Chao Praya. You need to get on a river boat to get there. Go visit in the Morning (yes, becos it just too hot to climb the levels in the heat) Ladies, of course you need to dress decently. or be prepared to rent a Sarong to enter into the temple premises.

Phenominal detail, views and atmosphere. Be prepared for many steep stairs to get to the upper levels. Stairs not designed for the physically impaired, strollers or squirmy toddler-toting. Much you could see from below as well, but the detail of the craftsmanship goes all the way to the top. Views of the city from above. Temple bells. Chanting. Incense. Go.

Must see temple. We went during the Songkran Festival, there was food, people, Thai dancing, offerings, Monks and pray everywhere, The Reclining Buddha was amazing both in size and how gold it looks. We also were able to see this Temple at night when it is lit up and it is quite beautiful.
unique temple, great view. the temple has wonderful architecture and the view from the top is really good
Put it on your must do's. This Wat is well worth the visit it is just beautiful.
exciting. First temple of our tour started here. I really liked this one because after seeing all temples this was a different one in architecture.
Serenity. Amazing beauty and craftsmanship. The serenity and peace built into the temple needs to be experienced

Absolute must see so worth it. This place is amazing. We started atthe grand palace then walked over to wat pho ( reclining buddah) after lunch we went to the pier along the river and paid 3 baht or ten cents to cris the river to wat Arun You can see this eldest wat in Bangkok is gorgeous. So original. The climb up is worth it. The view of the city an the view of all the inscriptions and carvings are priceless. It's such a spiritual placeReturning down the temple can be tricky and my friend was freajing out all the time but it's so worth it.
Awesome. Fantastic views once the near vertical steps have been climbed. Not for those with a fear of heights

Great temple on the other side of the river. This temple is on the other side of the river of the Grand Palace and Wat Po. A pleasant ferry ride across and you can start exploring. The stairway to the top of the temple is quite steep and any little kids or older folks will find it a struggle. Once your up there though you will love the views and the cool breeze in the shade.Highly recommended and great to be at either in the morning or the afternoon.
Temple of Dawn, the light in your life.. If you find some light in your life, go to this wat.
Beautiful Wat. I didn't catch this one at dawn, but it was still impressive. Ornate designs and patterns keep your eyes moving all over. A do not miss spot if you are out Wat hopping.
Too hot and expensive for travellers. Not worth the time and effort. I expect value for money
Great photo ops. This is an impressive temple and offers morning and sunset photo ops.

One of Bangkok's Most Famous Sites. This temple is magical in that it looks different depending on which time of the day you are lucky enough to visit. My favourite is dusk, especially in December around the King's birthday, when the sky is lit up with fairy lights. When in Bangkok this is a MUST see temple.

good cruise destination. I took a boat cruise to this templeThe cruise was breezy and cooled me off. The temple was interesting and worth a look. I took the ferry back across the river.Be sure and put a few bhat in your pocket to buy a trinket from the lady in the paddle boat who'll pull up to your cruise boat!
A Most beautiful Temple. This temple is stunning particularly in the evening when lit up. As an attraction it is up there with the best of them in Thailand. Close to Grand Palace and Wat Pho .
Interesting. It was a hot day, but we climbed to the top! great views.

beautiful place. make sure you got fully charged batteries in your camera when you go there, it's in a very pretty spot by the river, great views from the top (very steep stairs though), a very classic postcard-pretty place to visit in bangkok!

Worth the walk. We were energetic and walked to this sight from the Grand Palace. It must have taken about an hour but we walked along the river and then through narrow streets filled with locals. Was not as busy as the Grand Palace and the mosaics were absolutely beautiful.

Impressive. Seen Wat Arun many times previously on river cruises but had never stopped to look around. From the river it looks quite impressive if a little grey. This time we decided to take a closer look and wow...it is anything but grey. I was amazed at the beautiful colours and detail on each prang(?). Took some fantastic photos on the day and am very happy I took time to visit this time round. Recommended.
Another Wat. Yes, its another wat. Honestly, I have pictures but I do not remember this one too well.
Wat Arun. Just love the ornate detail and love that has gone into this.
a good sight to see. a nice sight to see close to the palace if i remember so it can be combined with a tour of all the cultural sights in bangkok
impressive and so steep. brilliant tiny little mirrors and ceramics adorn this maginificent temple. The view from the top of the steps is amazing although pretty exhausting getting there!
River cruise at evening. Difficult to climb up for those who afraid of height.I prefer the scenery during evening.

Don't miss. After you go to the Grand palace, Wat Pho, don't miss to go to this temple because this temple is the one of most famous temple in Bangkok and the best view of this temple is the time of sun set on the Chao Phraya river, very beautiful.

Like a birthday party cake!. It is a lovely positioned temple, the stairs are very steep and recommend comfy shoes! We took the ferry to cross over and it is a very cheap and efficient way to travel.
The temple is quite quiet and the least busiest of the temples we visited.

Excellent view from the river at sunset /sunrise...inside is not much thing to do. It is truly beautiful when you look from another side of the river or in the cruise especially during the mentioned times. Inside , it quite not well maintained and not show significant fineness as some other temples.

Climb to the peak!. Climb all the way up to the peak!!! It's not too easy as the steps are steep and really narrow but you'll get a great view up there. Nice place for photography.No fee to get into the temples on the ground floor but a fee is required for entrance to climb up the stone monument. They will also provide you with a long sari cloth if females are wearing shorts.
Best sunset in Bangkok here. Go opposite the temple on the other side of the river to "The Deck" for great sunset cocktails and the best view of Wat Arun

Don't miss this. This temple is across the river on the west side of the river. It shouldn't be missed, but you will need to take a boat across the river to get here. One can climb the exterior of the temple, which will give you an awesome view of hte river and the Grand Palace.

Magical.. Best views of this temple are from a river boat on the Chao Phraya river but you still need to visit the temple to take in the wonderful architecture. Its one of the oldest in Bangkok and on the opposite bank to the more famous temples of Wat Pho and Emerald Buddah. At the right time the sun sets..well go and find out for yourself...won't spoil the surprise.

lovely temple on the river. This is a nice temple to visit. You can get there by car or river taxi. You can also get a nice work out climbing up the many steep steps. Be careful if you are out of shape because coming down the stairs is as challenging as climbing up. But of all the Temples inBangkok, I prefer this one best. Add to your places to see at least once.

Stunning? It's far more than that .... My Thai girlfriend wanted to go here over Songkran to make her devotions, and seeing as I needed an injection of real Thai culture, I enthusiastically agreed to this. We decided to go by taxi, me as usual at this time being a total coward and pandering to my Songkran hydrophobia, wanted to remain dry. .We crossed the Chao Phraya river by ferry (3 (or was it 30?) baht per person - a bargain) and were on the opposite bank in no time. A word to the wise though; watch out for the 'guides' (touts) trying to get you to go on an over-priced river trip! Once on the other side, we did the 'ethnic' number (well, for me anyway ... ) and dressed up in traditional Thai costume to pose for photos at 100 baht each. Well worth it, and she looked gorgeous as usual and I - well, I just looked like a total prat, but there you go. I have the photographic evidence of this, but I'm not sharing it with you lot that's for sure :-)So - the temple; well, I will let you see some photos we took as my clumsy, mere words cannot do it full justice, but seriously folks this place really is something else. More proof, were it needed, of why I love this country so much. The architecture is aesthetic eastern baroque, and almost touches the sky such is the elevation that the principal edifice attains. The carvings that adorn the exterior are intricate, highly artistic, and a fitting testament to the devotion of the Thai people to their religious beliefs. Now, for those of you who fancy themselves as ace clamberers, climbing up the precipitous steps can be a bit daunting as it's almost like going up a sheer cliff face so steep are they. But, me being me and in reasonable physical shape, myself and my companion got to the top to look out over the river and beyond. Absolutely breathtaking views of old and new Bangkok; ancient building set against the steel and glass fingers pointing upwards to a pure azure sky. Beautiful. All that said, I had to get back down again ... If you want to know what the real Thailand is all about, then Wat Arun is one of those places to visit. I cannot recommend it highly enough. A treat for the senses and the soul, this temple is truly magnificent. I know that i will go back, that's for sure.
Beautiful Temple, nice view of the city.. Clean, and nice, very beautiful view of the river and the city, sometimes there are too many people, but it's ok anyway.
Awesome temple. Far east temple situated near the river that you can see as a Bangkok landmark
Historical. Built in 1800s, really a marvel to look at. Such a work of astronomically accuracy.

Bangkok's Best Temple. Wat Arun is simply stunning.
This is one of those special places a traveler never forgets.
Marvel in awe at the impressive main structure and the beautiful adjoining buildings and statues.
Easily reachable by river taxi from the Khao San Rd. area.

Often forgotten but definiately worth a visit.. This is a lovely temple on the opposite banks of the river to most of the city. You can walk up to the top of the temple and see the city across the river. It really is worth a visit. The Ferry terminal which is close to Wat Pho takes you across the river for about 30p.

Legs suffered afterwards!. Great monument, very beautiful detail on temple - decorated with very pretty pieces of ceramic. Beware though, I climbed the steps while feeling adventurous - great views from the top, but couldn't walk properly for about 3 days afterwards!!
Nice view. Not as breathtaking as Grand Palace or other temples, but still worth visiting as it provides nice view of Chao Praya river.
Amazing. Great and sweet view from the top! hand made walls and colours are unique!

Wat Arun. Wat Arun, the Temple of Dawn, is one of Bangkok's best know landmark. It stands on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River in Thon Buri. Wat Arun is best seen from the opposite bank of the river; it glistens in the sunlight during the day and stands dark and noble at dawn or dusk. A visit to the beautiful, peaceful monastery complex surrounding the familiar towers is very worth-while.I visited Wat Arun on a weekday in April and the day was oppressivley hot but once inside the narrow streets around the temple it seemed cooler, there are many shaded and cool places a visitor can sit and contemplate the beauty of Wat Arun. The beauty of the Wat and the surrounding buildings is breathtaking and it is hard to imagine this was all built using ballast from ships. I found the staff working here to be helpful and very respectful, this is a trait found in most Thai people I had dealings with.A word of warning if you decide to climb the central prang be prepared for a very steep climb, perhaps this is not a good idea for those with vertigo. The view across the grounds of the Wat and the river are breathtaking.There are places to take refreshments in the Wat and they are moderately priced.

best historical item in bangkok.......... unfortunately the temple its delf is not mantained well and the terrocotta etc is becoming broken, faded and lost. however remains the best temple history wise in bangkok when you think that others have only recently been built,
Steps, steps, steps. Beautiful Wat. The steps seem very steep climbing up. They seem even steeper coming down. Go early am or late pm to avoid crowds and excessive heat.
Special. Climb the temple is very interesting and dangerous. The temple is very beautiful

Wish I wasn't afraid of heights!. We came here as part of our Day Tour. It was the last sight of the day and, although I could only make it to the first level of steps, it was worth the view. It's very humble, and ladies you will have to cover up your legs (they will let you rent a sarong for a few baht) but I'm glad it was on our list. Just such a strangely peaceful place in the middle of the hussle and bussle of Bangkok. Not ideal for younger children or those who would struggle with VERY steep stairs (I struggled just wearing my sarong!).

A symbol of Bangkok. This huge Pagoda complex can be seen stained alongside the great Chao Phrya river. It is worth a visit to see the intricate work on the structures. You can climb the big ones, but the steps are high and it is quite steep

Interesting and quiet. When we visited it, the Wat was relatively quiet and we enjoyed strolling around. The garden is nice. The temple-watchmen are impressive, and the Prang also. In the temple is a nice set of buddha images and old wallpainings. There is a convenient cheap and simple ferrry between Wat Pho and Wat arun.
Worth a trip BEFORE Angkor Wat. I was pretty impressed until I got to Angkor Wat. Be sure to see this before.

Fun but... The temple is surely beautiful. Although it's actually temple of dawn, I came there about afternoon. I think it will more enjoyable about later afternoon because usually it can be so hot if you come about noon. Also be careful with the stairs, they were so steep.

AMAZING AND GIGANTIC!. Wat Arun is gorgeous and even larger than you imagine. I knew Wat Arun would be huge but I guess I underestimated Thailand's old architecture! The whole wat is so intricately handcrafted with china-like tiles. The steps are a bit daunting as they are so tall and so steep but it's worth the view of the river and the city to really put you into perspective. I dressed up like a traditional Thai woman outside of Wat Arun and just loved it!

Make time to see this unique temple. As previously stated your experience begins as you board the ferry for the short crossing, giving you time to take in the beauty of Wat Arun. It's main feature is the Nearly 300ft central prang. The central prang and those surrounding it are made up with beautiful bits of porcelain and shells, an architectural masterpiece. Get there early, it will be cooler, quieter and very peaceful.

Exquisite. An incredible sight - aesthetically stunning. The detail is phenomenal. The steps are steep and having got to the viewing point I started to worry about getting down but it wasn't as difficult as it looked - so don't be put off.The area around the temple is busy and interesting too.
Worth a visit. Pick 2-3 of the biggest temples, you can take some great pictures, but unfortunately it is a case of, seen one seen them all.

small but beautiful. take cross river boat cost 3 bath from N8 to wat arun. entry fee 50 bath. architecture is different. you night think that the pieces from the walls has come off. take the stairs to the top where it goes and you ccan have a good view of the grand palace accross the river
very beautifull. something not to be missed,the surroundings and the interrior is something out off a book.it is busy but this makes the place a very warm (not temprature) and gentle place

Must Visit in Bangkok. I do not disagree much with the contributors who find Wat Arun to be the best wat in Bangkok.The experience starts right from the boat pier on city side, when you get the first overwhelming view of the temple. Boat ride of 5-10 min takes you across the river to the temple (you will obviously enjoy the boat ride more if you are not done with Bangkok river cruise yet). The entrance area, with gardens/ foyers is very pleasant. Entrance fee is 50B.Climb to the main temple (and descent thereafter) may be arduous, especially for aged persons/children. The visit, however, is still worth a lot without a climb to the top.View from the top is breathtaking.A 'must do' in Bangkok.
beautiful is the word!. Awesome place to be at, very nicely scultpred art form :)

Unbeliveable!. This has to be the best of the Wat's in Bangkok. The size of the place and the detail in it's construction at a time when there was no cranes to lift things is just amazing ... well worth a visit!
One of the most beautiful temples. Wat Arun is one of the most beautiful temples in Thailand, not only in Bangkok
Magnificent. Thai art at its peak. Love the jade Buddha.........
Favorite temple in Bangkok!. This temple was my favorite as it was older and the grounds were just beautiful. I also liked the quick boat ride across the river to see it.

Another marvel to marvel at. A short cross river ferry, 3 baht. Get absorbed in history. Not all temples are created equal. Another must do it on your own as tour groups tend not to allow you enough time to take it all in.

Skyscraper for the Gods. This site has to be one of my favorites in Bangkok. The first time i saw it approaching it from the ferry i had flashes of the temple in Mortal Kombat. Architecturely detailed it boats of multiple galleries flanking the great central tower. Access can be through a 5 min ferry ride across the Chao Phraya River from Tha Tien Pier on Thai Wang Road. There is a big market and bus stand there and you can cover the Grand Palace at a near distance. You can get there directly by bus or private hire as well. The gardens are open to all but the inner temple has a nominal entry fee. You can also get flowers as offering for the diety. There are a lot of photo opportunities and the river makes an amazing backdrop (try getting some pics on the boat itself with the temple behind....nice......). The main tower has different levels which run around circumfrence of the monument where you can rest during your climb up. The steps unidirectional for climbing and descending with handrails for grip. Distinct Memories:Feeding the ever hungry fishes bread at the pier.Climbing those almost vertical steps to the near top, a view worth the climb.The monk cells with the 2 giant guards at the entrance.Watching the temple during a thunder storm
visit in the early morning or late afternoon. Wonderful place to stroll and take pictures. can get crowded later in the morning or mid afternoon. Right by the river - easy to get to

Steep steps. Beautiful steeples and sculptures. A short boat ride from the other side of the Chao Phraya River. The steep steps could be a challenge for most people, especially when scaling down. It shouldn't be a temple visited first on the itinerary cause the climbing can really take a toll on your legs and they become spaghetti after you get down.
wow. The view was very good. you can see the river and wat saket. if you afraid high, it is not a good choice.

Must see in Bangkok!. This is something every traveler to Bangkok should see. It's a quick boat ride across the river (which is fun in itself), and the temples are absolutely breathtaking. There are usually a few monks walking around which only adds to the feel of the place. It's also conveniently located right across the river from the grand palace and the reclining Buddha, so you can combine all the sites into one day of sight-seeing.
disappointing. ok; probally better at dawn and during the middle of the day.
One of the "must see" temples in Bangkok. Do take the time to climb the stairs for a great view of the river and city.
A must visit. Unlike any other Wat. This and the Temple of the Golden Mount are great complements to the larger, better known temples.
don't miss it. Less crowded compare with others but the building is unique and good place to take photo. Take the ferry and you will have different experience.
Beautiful especially on sunset. Can be visited or purely admired from a 30 baht chao Praha river ferry jaunt.

Necessary visit while in Bangkok. Great temple along the Chao Phraya river...a definite must while in Bangkok. It's an easy river ferry ride and then a quick 2nd ferry across the river. It's not complicated once you see the layout. Prices are very cheap and the architecture is amazing. Watch out for the steep step!! :)

Wat Arun,worth place to go.... We all really enjoy our boat trip to Wat arun and after we got there we see a really,really high temple and when you look up there you cant imagine how you gonna climb out there and you know what?Everyone on my tour group dont care about what the leader says anymore,we were just ran to taking pictures and after that we just straight ahead to the market which is we could buy something unique and take home for our relatives,we were so excited n having fun
have 2 do this go c this via the river. go c this via the river then go c it again on a dinner river criuse when it all lit up its amazing
THE CLIMB. all travellers be prepared to climb the steps. If going up was difficult, those suffering from vertigo are advise not to take the step up.... because the steps downs are much worse.
A must see attraction.. This is definitely one of the must-see attractions when in Bangkok.
Magnificent. It is worth your time to take a ferry across the river. This temple is less crowded than some of the others and just as fantastic.
Vertigo!. We almost overnight on top Wat Arun because my Wife was dizzy. Different than the other temples in Bangkok. Khmer Arquitecture.
nice view. You should try and go up the scenery amazing. The way there or back should you do with a river taxi.

Excellent Temple with a View at the Top. We visited Wat Arun while in Bangkok and it was definitely worth the trip across the river. We had visited the Grand Palace earlier in the day and Wat Arun was just a very inexpensive ferry ride across the river. There is a small charge to enter and walk up and make sure you are dressed appropriately, meaning no exposed shoulders for women and you must be wearing pants. The view from the top is very nice as you can see around the area and across the river over to the Grand Palace. It's one of the most photographed temples in Bangkok and is even featured on some of their coins. Just as a side note, there are a lot of stairs to climb, so be prepared as it can also be very hot and you must be fully dressed while visiting.
Temple of Dawn. Very peaceful and surprisingly not full with tourists.

Steep! But worth the climb!. We stopped here during a boat trip along the river which is for another review...The temple is one of the temples which I’d seen featured in many guide books and tourist guides so I knew that I wanted to see it for myself. The temple is very ornately decorated but one of the main attractions is to climb to the top and see the view! But be warned this is not for the faint hearted, at the top the steps are steep and I mean steep! They take a real effort to climb up to the very top level but if you can it’s really really worth it! (Also if you take a Sharpee then you can sign the orange cloth at the top which thousands of others have done already)We both really enjoyed it, frankly we aren’t the fittest people out there by a longshot so don’t be put off from there, but it is steep and a little bit hairy if you don’t like heights coming down!

Beautiful structure. A beautiful ancient structure, easily reachable by ferry from Wat Pho. If you climb the stairs of the main prang, you'll get a beautiful view of the Chaopraya river. Has very colourful stunning mosaics and figures within a tranquil environment. Entrance costs only 50 THB.
Amazing-must see!. Its only a 3 baht water taxi across from Wat Pho and the grand temple. Dont miss it!

Cool but Scary Stairs. This is a must see for anyone going to Bangkok. You have to take a ferry across the river to get there, but it's really easy and cheap. Be careful on the stairs - they are completely vertical so hold on tight as you go up and down! When you're finished, jump on one of the longtail boats for a tour through the canals. Should cost around 1000 baht and worth it.
Beautiful Temple and Great Views. This is a Must-Do on your trip to Bangkok. The Temple has nice grounds and the Temple is stunning. It's worth the climb up to the top for great views
check your vertigo at the gate. steep climb, wear sunscreen, amazing views take the cheap ferry across the chao phraya probably better to go early morning we went at noon and it was just too hot
Must see at Night. We went on the White Orchid River Cruise at night which included dinner. This was ve3ry very well organised and thoroughly enjoyable.

Amazing - very beautiful with great views. Entry fee 50 Baht. Tall central spire which you can climb to the top. Handrail is there to hold on to but steps very steep so would recommend shoes that won't come off easily. We went in the afternoon which was quieter. Smaller site than Wat Po. Decoration of tower quite unique - they have used plates imported for China and turned into flowers as well as sea shells and mosaic tiles. Result is stunning. Only made it to the first level as my camera died but great view from there. Am determined to make it to the top next time! Plenty of stalls nearby to buy both food and drink and souveniors. 2 smaller shrines outside - 1 dedicted to Buddha and 1 to a King which you can lit a candle or joss stick at (donation requested). Again, remember dress code.

Walk to the top. Even though it's a steep walk, make sure you climb all the way to the top. You will be rewarded with great views of the river and the Grand Palace.There is a cheap and convenient ferry service between the Wat Arun and Grand Palace river banks.
Beautiful. It's beautiful, exotic. Plus there's a very refreshing cool young coconut to drink in their hot weather....

Temple of the Dawn (Wat Arun). This wat is right next to the Grand Palace and both can be seen in one day. This wat has the largest reclining Buddha, and it is impossible to get a picture of the whole statue. Drop some coins in the wishing bowls.
Odd style makes it great. More in the style of Khmer architecture, we really enjoyed this temple. You can climb on the temple for awesome views of Bangkok.
Must See. Traveling to WAT ARUN might be a pain, as tuk tuk's usually tend to take to you unwanted shops. Hence the 20 Bhats ride!

Impressive by day and glowing by night.. Perhaps the most unusual of all the great temple designs, Wat Arun is located on opposite side of the river from the Grand Palace and Wat Po. There are frequent ferries across the river, so you have time to visit all temples in a day. Keep some small coins to pay for the fare.

Far reaching views. If you struggle with heights give this one a miss. The steps are very steep and I felt safer coming down backwards. You can see quite a distance but all you see is the dirty river and a smoggy Bangkok.

Great view careful on the steps.. Located across the river from Wat Po this temple is much more ancient than the Grand Palace. It offers a great view of Cho Pia river and the various colorful buildings around the area. The steps are very steep but the hike up is well worth it. The Wats facade is made of many multi colored pieces of glass and fired clay. Do not be afraid to interact with the throngs of students you find around most of these places, they are just practicing their English. Also with a little planing you can cross the river for 14Baht versus paying a Tout boat 1000 Bant for a "Canal" tour. These "tours" are a waste of money and a complete scam best to be avoided. Touts are easy to spot just look for the nice jewelry and snake oil salesman pitch about how they are trying to help.

Nicer from a distance. A pleasant historical Wat with a good view of the river. After climbing the dangerously difficult steps to the top and looking about for a few minutes, the only thing to do is climb down. No one on site to explain the history of the temple. At least you get exercise.

AMAZING!. Wat Arun is one of my favorite places to visit in Thailand. I was a bit to chicken to climb to the top because the stairs are very narrow, but my husband said the view is excellent. We could have stayed here all day.
Beautiful at Sunset. We found a bar across the river to watch the sunset over the Temple of the Dawn at and it was the perfect way to end a hot, busy day of sightseeing in Bangkok.
amazing. Very special, unlike all the rest of wats, more like Angkor
Worth a see. Pop over the river on one of the ferries, about B8!

A Must See Temple. If you are in Bangkok for more then a day or two, you will almost certainly want to see some of the major temples (Wats). Wat Arun is one of the "big three" that most tourists visit (along with the Grand Palace and Wat Pho). The good news is that they are all in the same area of the city. For me, Wat Arun was the most memorable. It has an odd Cambodian style to the design which made it different from anything else which I saw in Thailand. Great to climb up (note that the steps are very steep). You also get great views of the river and surrounding area. If course, everyone will have their personal preferences in terms of design. But I highly recommend that you visit this Wat if you are in Bangkok.In terms of how much time to allot, most people would probably spend an hour or 2 at this site.

Beautiful mosaics. The Temple of Dawn is very famous and considered one of the most beautiful in Bangkok. It is located on the waterfront and we visited the channels and the Royal Barge Museum by boat in the same afternoon. The many steps are somewhat difficult to climb and is not recommended for people with vertigo, but if you can reach the top, you'll have a beautiful view. The temple is beautifully decorated with mosaics made ​​of pieces of porcelain and glass. It is not so easy to go down, you have to hang onto the railing and go slowly. Have one hour to visit the temple.

Gorgeous!. We only walked up to the first level (very steep steps, be careful!), but this was an amazing view. We also got blessed by a Buddhist monk here, which we were extremely lucky to experience. A must-see in Bangkok.

Very beautiful and a great view from above. The Temple of the Dawn is great, a must if you are in Bangkok, you also must take the boat to cross the river, is funIt is a bit difficult to climb up, but if you can is really great the view, not so easy to climb down
Nice place to see. Go up to see the Bangkok river from top, stairs are scary and a nice adventure

Its best feature is the silhouette at sunset. Actually visiting the temple was somewhat disappointing. The buildings are not very special at close range, and the silhouette you can catch e.g. from a river boat. If you cannot stand visiting an infinite number of temples, you won't miss much if you omit this one from your itinerary. We got caught up in an apparently long-running scam while visiting: one spot has wooden Thai dancer figures with cut-outs for faces. An obvious photo opportunity. Once you have taken the photos, a number of Thai people mobs you and starts demanding money, pointing to the really small text "photos 50 baht" painted on the figures. The price may have gone up since then. :-(
Temple of the Dawn. This was a lovely temple, you were able to climb up the main building with lovely views over the river. A beautiful temple.
Well worth the visit. Compact, interesting area with great views and picture opportunities. No hassle shopping. Great place to visit by boat.
great!!. one of those places you must see beeing in Bangkok! you will have to claimb a few steps, but its worth it!!easy acces by boat.

temple of the dawn.. worth seeing. the architecture is quite impressive with great variety of shapes and colors. Also a lot of opportunities to make donations to your favorite Buddhist charity. If you have someone in your family trying to get pregnant, you may get lucky.

Wow what a Wat. Beautiful and in constant use by monks and tourists. If you're lucky you'll catch the monks chanting. The steps are not for those with vertigo!! Just hang onto the railing and look one step ahead of you, especially coming down.

Must see temple. Its called the temple of Dawn for a reason. Try to be there for the sunset, its absolutely magical. Besides if you go late in the afternoon you wll avoid the noisy tourists.Easiest way to get there is by boat, we cought the public boat but you could hire a private tour. You can also get there by taxi, but you will miss a beautiful view from the other side of the river.

A Must See !. Wat Arun is a must see. Be prepared to climb steep steps if planning to go all the way up to the top and wear comfortable shoes. The intricate detail on the Wat is amazing. Do yourselves a favor and go see this place.
Definitely worth a visit. Slightly difficult to get to, being on the ThonBuri side of the river, but well worth it.Amazing details to be seen, if you brave the steep climb.

A disticntive landmark along the Chao Phrya river. This Wat complex is known for its wonderful glass mosaics and really steep steps. Good for exploring by the curious and the nearby shops in the complex are pretty good too. Easy to combine with a visit to the Royal Barge Museum.

Worth the Trip. Usually find lots of cats here, and often there are monks about in their saffron robes eager to practice some English. There are trinkets for sale and a river breeze. No need to climb it!

Aamazing temple. Steep and narrow steps - scary climb. A really amazing temple, it is located across the river from Wat Pho (Temple of the Reclining Buddha). The best way to reach this temple is by boat crossing the chao Phraya River, from the piers next to the Wat Pho. The temple grounds are big, and in the middle is the tall building overlooking the river, and the royal palace on the other side, Although tall – the view is not amazing – as Bangkok is covered with smog, but the view of the river and palace is nice. The main thrill of climbing up is the climb itself. The steps are very very steep and narrow, and climbing down is as scary as the climb up.
An unusual sight on the river. From the river it looked like a big concrete building but up close the detial was incredible. Its a must see. Allow about an hour to tour
Temple of the Dawn. This is clearly a living temple, not ruins. The tile mosaics are beautiful. You can go up and inside the temple on top. Stunning view.

Quite a climb!. A beatifully decorated Temple on the other side of the river to the Grand Palace. You will need to haul yourself up to the higher parts of the temple, but it is worth the effort for the view.As with most Temples we visited they have trousers or wraps to cover up available, so no need to wear long trousers to travel around in.

Amazing view of Bangkok. The whole complex is a little dull and we were actually going to leave early, that was until we began to climb the main temple. It is an absolutely exhilarating view and we spend ages sitting at the top drinking it in. Climb down was very scary with the stone steps almost ladder like steepness.
The symbolic of Bangkok. The temple of the dawn is a amazing temple in Bangkok. You will see a Ceramic pagoda here. Very nice and beautiful scenery in Bangkok.
Great views from the top. Best part of our day in Bangkok. Great fun riding ferries to get to it and fabulous views from the top. A must-see.
It's beautiful.. You can get blessed by a monk. Make a donation. And woman must cover up. Do not physically touch monks.
Beautiful. Entrance fee 50 TBt, worth every penny, when in front of the temple don't miss the part on the right side.

Impressive Temple. Wat Arun is an impressive temple close up, though not so much from across the river. We didn't climb it as it was so hot and humid, we lacked the energy! I would recommend hats and comfortable walking shoes if you attempt the climb. It's certainly one of Bangkok's must-sees.
Steep steps. Get the local boat over (3 Baht!) and make sure you climb the steps as the view is ok. However the steps are very steep!

Awesome by daytime, dramatic at night. We had the opportunity to view Wat Arun during the day and at night. Both instances provide an impressive view of the temple although the view from a dinner riverboat cruise provided more drama and impressed us more - with its lights illuminating the whole structure. If you go during the day, make sure you make a stop from your river cruise and (try) the steep climb. Its not for everyone but its recommended.
You should make a stop here.... This is an amazing temple. Lots to see and if you have the energy, very cool to climb.
Classic Bangkok. Best seen from the river. It's not so interesting when you are close up.

very steep to go up. if this is the temple with very steep stairs it is scarier to go down ,be ready before you climb. all around average ground, if ou will not climb or sight seeing from the height do not bother!t is nicer from far.

Will take your breath away!. An absolute must for any visitor to Bangkok. Definitely the best temple that we saw. Take a parasol or hat to protect you from the sun and climb up the steep steps to get a great view.

Inspiring. Dominating the western horizon of the Chao Phraya River, Wat Arun Khmer inspired towers soar up into the air. As we stood on the east side of the river, those spires seemed to beckon to me. Once there, the highlights are the colorfully decorated spires themselves, as there is not a truly significant Buddha image such as the Reclining Buddha, Golden Buddha or Emerald Buddha found elsewhere in Bangkok. Once the steps are scaled that take one a good ways up the main spire, a great vantage point is gained to look out across Wat Arun, and across the river to Wat Pho and the Royal Palace. Well worth the journey.

Beautiful place for a river cruise!. Stopped over here during our river cruise. It is beautiful. They don't let you inside if you have shorts and tanks. You can rent a sarong for 500 bhats but we decided to skip going inside and walked around instead. There's still plenty of temples and ruins outside. It's worth a visit.

Nice view from the top of the temple. the easiest way to get here is to take teh fairy (7BHT) from Wat Pho or the Grand Palace. it takes 3-5 min to cross the river by boat and it is a nice experience as well. Temple of Dawn is a nice temple (as all teh Thai temples) where you can take teh stairs to the top of the temples and enjoy the view. it maybe a challenge to get up as teh steps are very steep.

Nice place, good views. This temple in Bangkok is on the other side of the river, but there is a ferry for 3 baht you can take it across. There is a fee of about 3 USD to go inside, then you can climb the pagoda made from broken glass of Chinese merchants. Photographers should go in the morning or the evening for nice shots.
A Must See!. This is a magnificent temple! The architectural design is beyond the imagination.

A must see in Bangkok. Probably the most impressive temple in Bangkok. Excellent way to get there is by water taxi (costs about $1 each way from most stops. From the water taxi, you will have a full view of the temple and its surrounding smaller temples. Women should carry large scarfs with them when in Thailand to cover their arms when visiting temples. Be prepared to climb lots of stairs too.
The best temple in Bangkok?. Surely a favourite of many, a great temple to visit and excellent views from the top.

I skipped seeing this place for so long.. When I lived in Bangkok, I never went to see Wat Arun because it looked like a grey temple spire. However, one day I was on the boat and decided to get off and check it out. I really liked it. Up close it is not grey at all, but has lots of colored tiles embedded in it. I think from a distance, all the colors combine to form grey. I'm glad I finally saw it.

Amazing Temple!. Though the stairs are absolutely one of the scariest things ever, it was one of the most memorable and amazing places we saw on our trip. Hire a long tail boat to take you along the Klong and stop here. What a great time! They will rent you a scarf to cover your shoulders for 20baht, or bring your own as the dress code is strictly enforced.
Beautiful!!. Love this place..it has the best architecture ever!!
Beautiful. Going there is fun but not a must do once you are there, there is not much to see. See it from a boat on the river.

So beautiful. Of course the main temple is juist wonderful and nice. The higher you climb the better view you'll get and it'll be quiter. Do visit the lesser temples on the premises, you can see young men being ordained as priest,with proud relatives surrounding .
Very steep. An awsome structure to view, especially from the river. I couldn't believe how steep and tall the steps were. It was a lot of fun climbing up and down.
Impressive. First the river crossing, then the quiet place and the temple ...a nice atmosphere

Amazing. Beautiful and historic temple right on the river. Definately worth visiting while in Bangkok. Just be careful climbing the stairs to the top because they are really steep and a little scary. But the views from the top are great for pictures.
A good stop along the river. Great temple and interesting adornments to the construction. Climb the stairs to the top for a nice view.
Unique temple made of ancient Chinese porcelain. Worth a visit to this old temple along the Chao Praya river if you like heritage sites.
Got to see it.. When in Bangkok one of the high lights. Don't miss it. Easy to get to.
Very special. A good experience to make me feel really small! Amazing that monks can cliimb those steps daily. Beautiful views from the top.
Well worth a visit. Amazingly decorated with bits of broken china embedded into the outside. Go there by boat. From afar it doesn´t look like much but close up it is fascinating.

a place which you must see!. It's much more magical place than great palace. Not so many tourists. Just take a boat from the pier near Wat Pho and you will find yourself in the other world. If you are lucky you can see monks walking on steep stairs. There is not much to do, just buy cold water melon shake, sit down and feel the place :)

Astonishing. We would have missed this if we'd not arrived 2 days early for our organised tour of Thailand and Laos as it was not on our itinerary. Instead we arranged a local boat to take us up river and we just wished we'd had even more time at Wat Arun. It's one of the most amazing buildings we've seen anywhere in Asia and should be an absolute must alongside the Royal Palace and Reclining Buddha for any trip to Bangkok.
steep steps. worth the climb if you can do it. Get the ferry from Wat Poh across the river

My favourite Bangkok temple. We visited in Feb 2012. As my Fiance is called Dawn I promised to take her to "her" temple while in Bangkok. This was a deliberate ploy as having been to the City numerous times I have always found this temple to be my favourite. The ferry ride across the river to get here costs a few Bts and the boats go from a dock close to the Temple of the reclining Buddha so its not out of the way.The big attraction is the huge central Stupa which one can climb ~ although the steps are quite steep. Some stairways are for going up - some for coming down (A fact lost on some). The views across the river back to the City are wonderfull and its nice to get some fresh air if one has been visiting the larger temples previously. I have never been here when it has been too crowded like some other temples.Outside the temple there are the usual collection of vendors selling water, pop and souvenirs and its a nice spot to stop for a dring and a rest. Certainly well worth coming across the river for.

Best sunset in Bangkok. Make sure you get here by 5:00 (or before it closes) and climb the various levels. The top areas are steep so plan accordingly (maybe rubber soled shoes). My wife decided not to go to the top, though I did.The best suggestion I can give is to time your visit with sunset. The views are absolutely breathtaking and you'll be happy you did it. Also, they still have a service so you can see locals pour in and monks prepare for the evening service.If you are interested in visiting temples while in Bangkok, don't miss this one. It was our favorite on our visit.

56 Steps - does not sound like a challenge until you descend. In pleasant and varied surroundings, the Wat Arun, on the banks of the river and easily reachable by public ferries, is worth seeing.If you have problems with vertigo or knees, do not ascend the steps - the descend will be too much for you. Otherwise, go up and overlook the whole complex from an elevated position.
a must visit. standard call in bangkok part of the hop on hop off ferry srevice on the river which costs 150 baht.

My favoriate spot in Bangkok. Lovely old Buddhist temple on the shores of the river. I absolutely love it. You can climb up and see everywhere. It is very fun to take the boat across the river to get there.

After going to The Grand Palace, this seems less impressive. The stairs leading to the top was, oh my gosh, STEEP! And each step is high too! It is almost like climbing a mountain. So if you are wearing high heels, you should not attempt it unless you like calluses & blisters on your feet. This is not a gold-studded temple like the one at Grand Palace but its ornamental artwork all around the outside is still very impressive, though it is dirty.

Great location to stay a while..... Don't blast through this temple complex to simply check off the box, this is a place to take some time and quietly explore. If you are fit enough, make the climb to the top for the excellent views of Bangkok and the Chaya river, stay up there for a while and soak it all in - you are standing in one of oldest spots in Bangkok, yet viewing one of SE Asia's most vibrant and modern cities, ancient temples and glass skyscrapers fill the scene. Don't book a tour, just take the river taxi and ferry boats on your own both to save money and to get a far better local experience.The main pagoda is covered with Chinese porcelains and decorated lavishly with statuary and brass bells.

Steep steps, but wonderful view. We visited Wat Arun after the Grand Palace and Wat Pho (reclining buddha) and thought it was amazing. Trip on the ferry across the river is only 3 baht and entrance 100 baht. Well worth climbing the steps to get a wonderful view across the city - the trip back down isn't so easy and is more like climbing down a ladder!

Cool Place. I liked the short ferry ride across to get there ( 3 Baht ).I recommend climbing the stairs ( not as bad as it looks ). Great views once you get there. We just had a short visit so I cannot comment on much else but I feel it is a must see if you are in this area

Impressive!. Firstly we thought we were in the wrong place as there were NO touts out the front ;) but we had indeed arrived at the street entrance of Wat Arun. Very impressive and not nearly as busy as the Grand Palace! We did this and then the reclining Buddha straight after. You can't come to Bangkok and not see this iconic place. You can take a lovely riverboat to the entrance, and a very low cost ferry to get to the other side of river to reclining buddha. Recommend!
Beautiful. Take the ferry across the river for 3 baht. Go here to climb up 3 levels on the temple and get a panoramic view of the city but be careful the steps are very steep.

amazing place. If you are visiting BKK, this temple is a must thing to see. It is a complex of temples and buildings that will make you busy to admire the beauty of exterior finishing for at least 3h. The crowd of visitors is huge but to see all those visitors from all over the world is also interesting.
best view outside during sunset. best view outside during sunset. the color changes to gold and the night's lights are just awesome

Another great tourist attraction. Take the boat across from Tha Tien Pier after visiting Grand Palace and Wat Pho to visit Temple of the Dawn, Nice and peaceful on the river. So cheap to get across the other side. From memory it is around AUD$1 to get across the other side of the river. Plenty of great photo opportunities at life on the river.

Prayer to Aurora. My first introduction to Wat Arun was through the Japanese writer Mishima - and from that moment I yearned to set my eyes upon the Temple of the Dawn - and it was a memorable experience. It is my favorite spot in Bangkok, and possibly Thailand - there is this spiritual aura about that place, and I can only imagine what it must have been like set on the other side of the old city, and before the modern city grew up around it.

Stunning. This temple blows you away, literally if you climb up the amazingly steep steps for the incredible views across the river to the Grand Palce and Wat Po. from a distance the building looks grey but its actually made up of coloured mosaic work. Fantastic!
Different to the other temples. To reach this temple you go by boat at 5.30am it is a very interesting temple worth going to see you can have your photo taken with a snake
Beautuiful. A great experience to see this temple. You can climb up the stairs to get a nice view.

Fascinating. Said to be the most photographed Wat in Bangkok. How can I argue? It is simply one of the best there is to see in Bangkok. Steps are very steep though and I think we went there on the hottest day in Thailand! Whew!

Beautiful views, chilled temple. Beautiful temple overlooking the river just across from The Grand Palace. Its costs only 3 Baht to cross and it's the most chilled area to visit. One of the best places I found to meditate.
No wonder it is Bangkok's most famous image. Not only is the porcelin used for the prangs lovely, you can walk up the central prang and get sweeping views of the river and Bangkok looking East.

Fascinating alike, whether seen from the river and up close. Take a (longtail) boat trip on the Chao Praya River towards sunset and admire this temple from afar, or find out what effect the sparkling mosaics have in the daylight by exploring the temple grounds up close. While Wat Arum might look slightly unassuming from a distance, it's definitely worth looking at more closely. Crossing the river by shuttle boat is easier than getting a taxi driver to find it, by the way.

Make sure to go here...and wear comfortable shoes!. This is a beautiful wat....and one that is well worth the visit. Make sure, however, to wear shoes you can climb stairs,heck, a ladder, in! The climb up the chedi is beautiful and an important part of your visit, but not for the faint of heart, the out of shape, or the high heeled woman! After your climb, stop at the little coffee shop in the grove of trees, just to the right of the chedi with your back to the river and enjoy a Thai iced coffee...it was great!
Needs a clean-up. Wat Arun is a must-see, but I was very disappointed to see how dirty it is right now (early 2012). I hope that a clean-up will be done soon.

Great views. This a more low-key temple located across the river from the Grand Palace. There are some wonderful views if you climb all the way to the top, just make sure you have some water. It's a hot climb!

Good stop in Bangkok. We visited right after Chinese new year and it was neat to see all of the followers give their alms. Climb to the top of the temple it gives you a pretty good view of Bangkok if its not too cloudy.
Old and charming!. Beautiful temple located next to the river with wonderful views. If you are fit, try getting on to the top of the temple. warning: the steps are very very steep.

Late afternoon is beautiful. Watch the dress code!! Late afternoon is a great time to go as the sun is beginning to set. The colors begin to pop. Wear your good walking shoes...there are some interesting stairs to climb for great views of the city.

beautiful. It's a beautiful temple.
Has very steep and narrow stairs.
People afraid of heights should avoid climbing the stairs.
What a wonderfull place. I loved this place the sense of peace and history envelops you as you stroll round this lovely site

Best of the Bunch. Far better value and much less crowded than Wat Pho and the Golden Palace just across the river. For of 50bht you can scale the tower of Wat Arun (careful though, it's steps are rather steep) and have a top view across the ancient sites of Bangkok.
Arun is a letdown unless you vist it before wat Pho. We saw it arter the Wat Pho expierience and anything would be not as goog.I suggest going to this attraction before Wat Pho.

Incredible structure. This temple was across the Chao Phraya river, so I took the express boat across, and walked around the Temple. I climbed up the steep steep staircase, and walked around the top of the temple, as far as they allow you to go that is. The details and sculptures are incredible and beautiful. There is a School of Meditation outside of the temple that children attend and you can also go at 4:30pm and meditate if you wish. Beautiful area.
Beautiful. Really nice. The views of Bangkok are pretty splendid too. The temple itself deserves a fair amount of exploration and the boat ride to get there is fun too.

Slightly overrated.. The temple is beautiful from a distance, but the closer you get to it, the uglier it becomes (no disrespect...).Still, it's well worth the climb, as the view of the river and the palace are great.
It's a Big Climb. If you go, climb up. If you don't want to climb it, the best view is from the river!!

Worth going to just for the scenery. The Temples itself is rather underwhelming, but going there, across the river is quite nice...
Maybe spend 30 minutes-1 hour walking around the Temple itself... And then enjoy the boat ride and market on your way back...

Amazing tempe. Though it may sound kitsch to have broken dishes and pottery inset in the face of a temple, it works at Wat Arun. An amazing structure and a one of a kind place. If you have the energy to climb the steep steps to the highest level, you will have a great view up and down the river and overlooking the city. Walk around the grounds and see Buddhism in action. Stay for sunset (or come before sunrise, it is the Temple of the Dawn after all) and watch the changing light on the structure. Beautiful.
Better seen from the river at night.. Have been to Wat Arun several times, and find it quite amazing. But the temple is most beautiful at dawn or sunset, seen from the river.
a must. I liked the free water bottles to tourists and the cleaness of the place even with so many people there
Beautiful. A wonderful place, stunning temple so intricate - couldn't get to the top as I had a bad knee, but the surrounding gardens and atmosphere made the trip well worth it.
Beautiful!. Very pretty to watch during sunset while having early dinner on the boat at Chao Phraya river

Worth the boat ride. What makes Wat Arun special is the absence of glitz. It is a beautiful piece of architecture and covered with pieces of ceramic that came to Thailand from China when used as ballast for the ships. The stairs are really steep but the view is a great reward for your brave ascent. After all the gilded, mirrored Wats around Bangkok this was a down to earth surprise. Loved it.

Well worth the trip across the river. Evening is nice but it closes about 6.. Wat Arun or Temple of the Dawn is a beautiful and relativly quiet old temple. It is across the river from most of Bangkok sights but you can get there for just a few baht if you take the river taxis. I caught my ride at the popular river taxi terminal just across from the Grand Palace.Wat Arun is rather quiet and peaceful especially when compared to the Grand Palace so it might be a nice thing to do after seeing other busier sites. I've never been there in the early morning but have been several times just about sunset and the views are lovely.

Stunning. Crossed the river from the Grand Palace to visit - well worth the trip. Actually would say come here first and then cross the river - I loved it !Yes the steps are very steep and a bit scary but the view is worth it . I actually started climbing the second set of steps and hesitated but it was easier to keep going up than try to turn around. Glad I did though as the view was spectacular.
Beautiful temple. Interesting temple. Would recommend getting there early to miss the masses! It is really beautiful and a guide is useful for the context and history.

Go at night time to see it lit up. Go here at night time; the air is cooler, its completely tourist free, and the temple is lit up beautifully, it's truely a sight to be seen. It can get so crowded here in the day it can feel like the magic is absent, but at night time when you don't have to fight your way through hoards of other tourists, the magic is well and truley surrounding you.
Beautiful in the night..... Its magnificient in the night with the lightings around the Temple.

Ceramic temple. Combine a visit to here with Wat Pho and Royal palace, they are all very near.This temple is built completely out of Chinese Ceramic, which was brought back as ballast on boats trading with China.

Watch those steps!. Really interesting place but watch out for the steps to the top. Getting up isn't a big problem but they are very steep so getting down is a challenge. In my mind, the steps are not really suitable for small kids and the elderly. There is no other way down so be careful. There is a nice snack place here too.

Worth the climb. Take the opportunity to climb, and you won't be disappointed. The view is great. It's really interesting to see how it was made out of all the porcelain pieces. Careful on the way back down :-)

Beautiful ...... Even if you choose not to enter the grounds of this temple it is worth standing close and admiring. Some of the stairs are quite steep if you decide to climb up. I saw a few people struggle to get down so choose wisely.

A good site for 50BHT. If you have the stomach for it, climb the steep steps to the top of the central tower and take a peek at the Grand Palace. That alone is worth the 50BHT. Beware the cardboard cutouts where you think you can take some complimentary photos...it will cost you 40BHT to stick your head through and snap a photo. Be warned. You can often take pictures of the inner sanctuaries of Buddhas, but you have to do it from outdoors through a window. There are a lot of Chinese statues and painted wall murals that are interesting if you wander beyond the main tower. Worth the stop and often you can do it best in conjunction with a long tail boat tour.

Must See. The Temple of Dawn is spectacular and I highly recommend making a trip out to see it. Its about 20mins away from the city and was the original temple of the royal family. You actually can climb the stairs up the main tower and I say climb because it is very very steep. Remember to wear short sleeve and longer shorts or pants other wise you will have to rent garments. You also can dress up like a traditional Thai person and get photographed which is pretty cool. You can also catch a canal tour for 800Baht from this location as well.

A must do. You need to take a boat across the river to Wat Arun. The temple looks beautiful when you look at it from the boat. We went there in the evening, the setting sun in the background, lovely breeze blowing. It was a fabulous experience. The temple is similar in architecture to the Ankor Wat in Cambodia. There are steps that you need to walk up. Hence might be a problem for those who have difficulty in walking, yet one can just sit outside and enjoy the beauty. Once on top you have lovely views of the river. On the whole an enjoyable trip.

Great Culture,Great Thai People. what i can say,is that all bangkok temple are a must visit:) i took a day tour just to get to 4 places:) all temples were amusing:) you really feel that your touching the thai culture in a different way:)
i would recommand that for all of you folks
Good view from the top. Definitely one of the temples to be visited. Take a boat from across the river for only 3 baht. The temple has very steep stairs up to a good view of the city
Great River side Temple.. Great place and views from up top on the temple. Bring your camera.

Quiet, serene Temple acroos the river from the main section of Bangkok. You can take an inexpenive ferry across the river to get to this lovely, quiet temple and religious area. There are a number of chapels,statues and a very high tower that you can climb. Be aware that the steps are very steep and narrow. You can walk around the grounds for free but it costs 50 baht (about $1.60) to enter the main area. You get the ferry at Th Tien pier and the ride is about 5 minutes.
Great. Watch out if you are a bit afraid of hights.. I am and had to breath twice before stepping down. Quite steep but worth it. Great views of the Palace from here
unique. really amazing, different buildings, use express boat to reach it..

Stunning. From afar it looks beautiful and up close it is even better. Definitely one of the top attractions you have to see in Bangkok. Climbing up can be steep and coming back down -hold on! Amazing views so well worth it.
Another beautiful temple. Beautiful from afar and close up. Very unique shape and lovely location on the river. Be sure to see the full name of Bangkok displayed on the river bank.

Beautiful. This is one of the top 5 temples to visit in Bangkok. It looks definitely beautiful mainly when crossing the river. It seems that it´s built of sandstone. Once you get there you realize it´s covered with multicolor pieces of ceramic. What I didn´t like about it is that there´s no guide service or pamphlets on sale at the place so you have to trust entirely on your guidebook. You can get an amazing view of the city (both the old and modern sectors) from the top of the main stupa.

Def worth checking out !. We took a boat ride up the canal after checking out the Grand Palace and dropped by to see Wat Arun, or the Temple of Dawn. The boat waits at the pier where it drops you off to see this magnificant structure. The Entracne fee for the ticket is 100 Bahts and after checking out the outer parts of the temple grounds, we proceeded to the main Temple itself. First thing that hits you is the intricate workmanship and sheer size of the temple, which by the way, is actually a pagoda, and atleast 6 to 7 stories high. (my guess ofcourse). Another thing thing you will notice very quickly is how steep the stairs are. Infact, I could only reach the first level. I woudl recommend atleast making your way up there because you will be rewarded with a wonderful view from the pagoda looking onto the Chao Prayo river and beyond. I could only imagine what a monumental sight it must have been for visitors hundreds of years ago when they would ply down the river on their boats and witness this magnificent buiding. One caution I would like to pass onto my fellow travelers is there is isn't much room to walk around and secondly, mind your steps when descending. I noticed a gentleman almost slip as he misjudged his steps. Neverthess, if you can make it to the very top then you will be greatly impressed with the view looking out. So I hear !The visit took us about 20 minutes and we walked back to the pier and found our boatman. Here you have the option of crossing the river and visiting another famous Temple the Wat Pho (Reclining Buddah) or turn back and get dropped off at the pick up place. We decided to oroceed onto Wat Pho.
Amazing.... If in Bangkok... a real Must see. Really Amazing! Wear good shoes to go up to the top. Careful very uneven steps. Fantastic sights.

Not miss it; best Thai temple, located on the main river. Great place to visit, just one free tip how to get there, since it's located on the other side of the main river. You have to take a large boat from main peer (15 bat each), make just one stop and take a little toy to go on the other side of river (3 bat ecah).We miss the stop and we ride till last stop and the we had to get back (almost 30 min.) back and forward.A part from this, Wat Arun temple is best in town, because its architecture is recalling a Cambodian temple like Angkor Wat. It has been buil it up on 3 levels to vhich you can climb and get an incredible city and river overview. We has the cahnce to stay there during a Chinese Gragon event and it was really great looking to watch at the performnace. Absolutely not to miss.

Go early ........ Smaller than thought can do the whole thing in 30 mins ( wats are extremely steep def need trainers if your going to attempt to climb up . The boat across is 10 baht and takes 30 seconds I got there around 8.30 and the was a couple of other people around which was fine .....
Go at dawn!. Beautiful temple, scary stairs up to the top! but well worth a visit - try and take the river boat if you can to get there.

old golden era. grand and imposing, the temple structure is by the river and has very steep steps on 4 directions. Glorious view from the top, just be careful going down you could feel dizzy.Well looked after.

wonderful at sunset. Wat Arun offers both excellent views of the river and the bustling boat traffic, and at the same time a wonderful, quiet, enchanting athmosphere. It is most recommended to come in the late afternoon when tour groups have left, and you have the temple (almost) to yourself (unless it starts to rain - but even then...)
Be prepared to climb high!. Excellent scenery and a lot of fun climbing the temple to the top! A must do on the list!

Unreal scale and unbelievable detail. This was one of our favorite places in Bangkok. The combination of the size of the Wat and the detail of its surface was what really struck us. It also provides a great vantage point of the Grand Palace and Wat Pho from the top. Definitely a can't miss in Bangkok.

Watch out for the photo boards. Great temple - very beautiful. Won't repeat everything everyone else has said. Just want to tell you to watch out for the photoboards in the grounds where you put your head in a wooden cut-out of a thai dancer. Thought this would be fun for a photo but as soon as we had finished we were jumped on by a man demanding 40 baht per person. There are no signs, but apparently if you want a photo taken you have to pay him 40 baht. We were most surprised and tried to explain that we did not know but the man just yelled and abused us wanting money. Not sure if it was a scam or not but beware!

River taxi. Take the river taxi to the Wat Arun stop, then it's only a tiny THB3 to catch the ferry back to the other side of the river to carry on with your sightseeing of the reclining buddha, etc...

amazing view. so worth making the trip to this temple, its completely different to other temples in Bangkok and just as much fun getting to it as going up the stairs. If you go dont forget to go around the back to the court yard slight off to the right behind, its not to be missed.
Fun boat ride to Wat Arun (3 baht) and neat temple. Visitors can climb the stairs of the temple - I only made it to the first level - too steep for me to head higher. Worth a visit.

Memorable and beautiful. Watch it at sunset - it comes alive. We had cocktails at the deck across the river and then took the river ferry to the opposite bank to watch some of the Chinese New Year celebrations.
Definitely worth the trip across the river. This was my favorite temple: less crowded and very nice view from the top!

Another great temple. this one is old and also worth a trip.Learn a bit about the history and you will understand why the thai people are so friendly and why their reigion and icons are so important.PLEASE REMEMBER if you are not buddhist, do NOT walk in the middle UP to the Buddha staure / Icon as this is disrespectful the same as you would not walk in fron of an altar in a christian church.Walk around the sides.The sites of these famous landmarks are also worth exploring for little gems and bargains.
Enlightening. Jut an inspiring location. Take the public water taxi to save money. Long boats cost 1000~1500 baht but it will stay with you for your journey like a chauffeur.
Lovely views from the top. Lovely temple, less crowded. Make sure you climb up to the top as the views are very nice. Worth crossing the river for.
Interesting Temple Complex. Built after the Cambodian Style rather than Thai this is located by river and is a great photo opportunity.

Well worth a visit, unique temple covered in china. Foreigners will pay B50 to visit this temple and it is worth visiting early in the morning (just before sunrise) or early in the day before it gets too hot. Steep steps may be a hinderance for some people with difficulty walking or climbing but you can just go to the first level and look up and admire the artistic placement of all that china!

Sunset point. Awesome view of the temple from the Chao phraya river. Went there during the last phase of floods. The river was high but still took the ferry to the other side. Had a quiet time in the temple. Very beautiful!

Impressive temple. The Wat Arun is worth a visit. We visited with a private tour guide, which is definitely worth the (minimal) cost, because he explains the significance of the temple and other great facts about Bangkok. The climb up the temple is scary, but worth it for the soaring views of Bangkok.

Not much to see really. I always thought that Wat Arun would be huge temple area but in reality it is almost like any other temple in Bangkok. The main exception is that you can climb to the temple with very steep stairs. View is ok, but the place itself otherwise was little let down
Our day out. Wow a great place to visit, would highly recommend

Gourgeous. The construction might not have all the ostentation of most other well known temples in Bangkok, but it is one of my very favorites. The Wat enshrined the emerald Buddha image before it was transferred to the Grand Palace in 1785 A.D. It is covered with Portuguese porcelain and at sunset the reflection of the sun it lights up in a beautiful way.It is very steep (very) and you must wear comfortable shoes.
such a very nice temple. try to go up to the chedi , and u can see stunning view of Bangkok ;)

An interesting complex. This is a very large complex iwth a lot to see. People climbed up the very steep steps to get to the top of the highest building, but we didn't risk it. Those who did said the steps are very high and very narrow as one gets toward the top. Not for the faint of heart.
wow! what a Budha!. crowded but dont miss it for the world! the massage school is an added bunos
Forget health and Safety. A monument like this in UK would be well cordoned off for fear of accident. Common sense approach is all that's needed no need for accidents if you take reasonable care.
To see and to visit is the difference thing. You can admire the view from the opposite site with the sunset. But you need to walk around and climb up the Chedi. It worth visiting.

Wonderful and peaceful location. We visited Wat Arun on our second day in Thailand. You can take inspiring camera shots of the architecture and surrounding river. We visited in the evening and during the boat ride home we took some beautiful sunset photos.
Pretty. amazing, stairs VERY step, wear stuff on shoulders as they happy to charge extra if you dont
Astonishing. Amazing and jaw-dropping construction surrounded by another stunning buildings and domes. Probably one of the most important places in Bangkok
Huff and puff. Do climb up those stairs as the views are great. Reached by taking the ferry across the river for 30 baht.

Don't go at dawn!. The sun rises behind the temple; of you are there at dawn you see nothing. For sunrise pictures stay across the river and shoot across. The shuttle is cheap and cheerful, don't be scared.I can't add to the temple reviews but want to add that the small market/shophouse area is delightful, especially at early morning or dusk. Stalls selling hand-made donuts, noodle soups and a myriad other dishes do a roaring trade to locals are I've tried most of them many times without disappointment. I've also found some of the friendliest locals in Bangkok there who will chat and even show you hidden places in the area.From there, if you are staying in Sukhumvit area, the really intrepid traveller can take a tuk to a major klong that will take you all the way. The photo ops along the way are fantastic and almost no-one will have done it! Ask a local how to get there

You'd be crazy to miss it. If you're visiting the Grand Palace and Wat Pho (as you're bound to be), you'll need to cross the river to get to Wat Arun. Don't let that deter you, this is a wonderfully original structure that is a delight to explore.What looks like a stone Khmer structure from a distance turns out to be heavily inlaid with ceramic decorations. The close-up appearance is very different from the vision you get from a distance but I found both very appealing and the contrast rewarding.You can clamber to the top up some very steep steps although coming down again is a struggle for some.The rest of the temple grounds are also well worth exploring with various structures and statues that would be worthwhile even on their own. I particularly enjoyed all the Chinese statues, many of which I didn't see in any other Wat.

chinese new year. If you decide to climb up the stairs you will have rewarding view of Old Town Bangkok. When we've been there there were Chinese New Years Festivities, which make the place even more unique, with lots of decoration and music
Favorite Wat. Don't miss this. You can climb the steep stairs and look out over the river.

Great views of River and City. We stopped at this temple as part of our river tour. It definitely is one of the more interesting places along the river and worth the stop although an hour is probably enough time to visit it. We climbed to the top and got great views of the river and city. Know that the steps are extremely steep and difficult to climb because of that. Also, there were plenty of signs around warning of pickpockets so caution on that too.Just outside is a collection of stalls to buy souvenirs and snacks, bathroom facilities are also available. While recommending this attraction if you have enough time in Bangkok, I would not make it in my top 10 things to see in this city.

lovely old fashioned buddhist temple. Wat Arun- also known as temple of dawn is a very old but beautiful temple in Bangkok.We made a day trip , combining this with the reclining buddha temple which is bang opposite this across the river.We took the tourist boat from the pier( after taking the ferry to the pier from the Hilton)Abt a 30 min pleasant ride brought us here.A nominal fee is charged for the local ferry and entrance fee is cheaper than the emerald buddha one.There is a main building and a spire which is fun to climb.My hubby and my older son enjoyed the climb while my younger son and I soaked in the calm of the surroundings.Less touristy and more spiritual than the emerald buddha.Restrooms were decent.
Interesting. It's worht the idea of crossing the river to visit this temple. But you have to be on shape to come up all the stairs.

Worth the climb. Well you have to get the ferry across the river from the Imperial Palace but for starters the toilets are clean.A great photo opportunity and far quieter than the Imperial Palace.Now the steps to first and second level are at least at 50 degrees to the horizontal so not for you if you suffer from vertigono and whilst you can only climb approximately half way up the monument, the river view and surrounding area are very pleasant but not high enough to be astounding. The Buddhist idea is that you climb up on all fours and approach God with a bowed head and carefully. It is a physical depiction of humility and it works. You have also achieved something on the short climb. No one too old to make this short climb just reasonable fitness and a slow pace required. There are handrails and your hands can reach both of them, but expect to use both hands to cling to one of them! Being tall is no advantage here. The same applies to coming down but you do it backwards (far safer) looking at your feet, one step at a time, and a little like Christ, carefully as it safer to arrive intact albeit slowly. Some good stalls at the bottom right next to the jetty but you have to get across to the East bank of The Chao Phraya to catch the express or Tourist Ferry.
Amazing ceramic inlays .... I've been here a few times - I recommend the climb to the top, however be warned that the stairs are STEEP - but the view is definitely worth it.

Another Must see temple !. The temple is very discreetly set in the heart of bangkok, apart from the other statues people worship and light incense sticks, and after climbing a few stairs you can enter the silent room where the Emerald Buddha is placed in all peace and tranqulity ! Its really a wonder to see the Buddha and feel a wave of calmness spread across. One needs to keep moving in the queue. Just dont miss !
Lots of stairs. lots of steep stairs to enjoy the view and features of the temple.Nice at sunset

Climb the steps...great city view. Beautiful stone tile work around the temple area. We were glad we chose to climb up to the top. There was an amazing view of the city. We also chose to rent a private boat to see the river and neighboring khlongs. We saw things we won't soon forget.
Excellent!. Beautiful temple, easily accessible from the river.

Gorgeous!. Beautiful to see from an Express ferry down the Chao Praya but also wonderful to see up close and in person. We didn't get a chance to climb Wat Arun - but many do and I've heard the view is incredible.
A beautiful site. We saw this on our boat ride during the day...I wanted to see it in the evening where it sparkles in the images I have seen.

worth going. We caught a boat to here & that was fun in itself - be warned when you arrive there even though you have paid your baot fee you have to pay a landing fee & then you have to pay to get in to the Wat (it's not expensive but make sure you have baht on you). It is an amazing Wat & it is very high to climb, but worth it. We went in the middle of the day & there were lots of people & it was a bit hot for climbing, if we were doing it again we'd go early in the morning or later in the day - a must see though.
