Our favorite wat. Wat Arun, across the Chao Phraya River from most of the city, is a truly amazing wat that defies easy description. It is an awe-inspiring wat, among many others that are incredible in their own right. Well worth a visit. Take the Chao Phraya boat (yellow or orange line), to the Tha Thien (N 8) stop. Then take a cross-river boat to the wat.

An ornate cheddi. Unless you get there at the peep of day to watch the first sunrays on the thousands of glass bits, which ornate the stupa, it is not really worth a visit. It is as good to see it from the Chao praya River on your way to the Royal Palace. However, the sanctuary premises are different. So, some people may find it interesting to see anyway.

The landmark of Bangkok.. If you travel to Bangkok, this landmark cannot be missed. The architecture reflects the Ratanakossin era. On top of the landmark, you can see the panoramic view of Bangkok city.

Great architecture and detail. Excellent attraction with great features and architecture. Very easy to get to by boat across the river. Shame about the hoards of tourists so try and go early in the day if you can.

Ok. Be aware of the fake guides who will try to take you on a boat trip to see Wat Arun. The boat costs 800 Baht/person and the entrance on the dock is 20 Baht. The entrance fee for Wat Arun is 50 Baht.
Amazing Temple. Its very unique architecture, not seen very often. Beautfiul setting, just by the river.
Must go.. Great construction. Beautiful place to visit and take photos, day and night. An icon of Bangkok.

Spectacular site of History and Meditation. One of the oldest Temples in Bangkok. A peaceful spiritual place with interesting architecture. Spent the entire afternoon until sunset. Don’t miss going inside the Temple to meditate. Easy to go on the public boat from central pier under Saphan Taksin Sky-train station. Large boat with yellow or orange flags. Go to pier number 8 for Wat Po. Come off the large boat and u-turn through to a smaller ferry. Cost 3 Baht (about 10 cents US). Just follow the Monks in orange robes. Visited Wat Po with the giant reclining Buddha and the Grand Palace the same day. Better to take two days to see all three, if possible.
Nice. Worth a visit although not really that much to see, we managed to get some great pictures as the sun went down and the boat back across the river afforded some great vies with the sun setting.
do it. just a short hop across the river, a must climb to get a lovely view of the river, relaxing & quite compared to bangkok bustle.
Views of river. Wonderful views of the river, dont go if you are afraid of heights
Fantastic Value. So cheap to enter and although the steps are a little scary (scarier coming down!) the views are amazing.
Breathtaking views. Climb to the top of the temple if you have a head for heights and you will be rewarded with fabulous views across he river.

Well worth working out how to get there.. Wat Arun is on the opposite side of the river from Old Bangkok, and the river boats don't stop there. Don't ask me why, However if you get to the river boat terminal called Thien, you can take a ferry across the river - costs the princely sum of 3 baht. Don't whatever you do try to take a taxi, it would cost a fortune. Anyway, the Wat is fascinating. You can climb up three secrtions, with the steps getting steeper and steeper to symbolise the increasing difficulty of making spiritual advance. The carvings are astonishing and the atmosphere impressive. However, do be careful over the price of water, if you are going to be thirsty, take some with you. For me, this was the most impressive temple after Wat Phra Kaeo (in the enclave of the royal palace and where the emerald Buddha is to be found).

Some must sees in Bangkok. Well, you should do some temples and I chose Wat Arun. Nothing really amazing but when you have seen mainly catholic churches before your trip outside Europe, you enjoy different temples. :)
Temple of Dawn (Wat Arun)...my place. Nothing can say.....it's in my heart. Everytime I see this temple, I'm feel good in the day or night time, the feeling is always good for me.
Another Thai icon. Great way to further appreciate Thai culture. Very beautiful. Can be nicely appreciated from river

Wat Arun = Amazing!. Wat Arun was one of the prettiest and tallest temples we visited while in Bangkok. It is very different from the other temples as it is decorated in porcelain instead of gold and jewels. You are allowed to climb to the top of the temple by very, very steep stairs. I have climbed temples in Mexico made by the Mayans but this one takes the cake! You will definitely need to hold onto the railings! :) Also, remember to wear a long skirt or pants with something to cover your shoulders out of respect.

Wat Arun, Exercise with a view. This is one of my favorite places to visit in Bangkok and I have visited this place 3 or 4 times. You arrive by a bargain ferry for pennies or bhats which is simply across the river from the tourist boat landing port near the main temples and Grand Palace.When you arrive, you pay a small fee and then admire the ceramic architecture of this old temple. Then you find the Up Stairs (do not climb up the Down stairs as I did once!) and hold on tightly to the rail. Prepare for a very steep climb. Hold on tightly to the rail and climb slowly and carefully. You will be rewarded with a great view and usually a nice breeze at the top viewing area. You have a great view of the Chao Praya River and the Temples on the other side of the river and the surrounding modern and ancient architecture mixed together. After enjoying the view and taking photos, take the Down stairs set slowly and surely, but be careful looking down at the precarious steep steps below you epecially if you have a fear of heights! The steps are STEEP and a challenge if you have knee or ankle or hip problems. IT IS NOT FOR CHILDREN! The steps are actually too high and steep, and one could literally die if you fell from the high steps. You must hold on to the railing. If you are not in decent cardiovascular shape you must go slowly or abstain.In addition there are nice shops which have some decent souveniers on the grounds. There are also vendors who sell ice cold Cokes or Coke Zeros and Magnum Ice Cream Bars, etc. which are much appreciated after a climb in the humid Bangkok heat.

Huge. Gold. Huge.. Awesome. When you first see it you'll be trying to figure out ways to take a picture. I suggest a wide-angle lens because its just huge. The mother-of-pearl inlaid feet are something to marvel at. It's like fingerprints (well, toe prints) made of pearl. Worth seeing.
awesome. Wat Arun is much smaller than the other temples nearby, but it is definitely worth the visit.

loved all the ancient ceramic architectures and view from the river at night of the Wat is magnificent.. History of the Wat and culture and all the ceramic tiles from hundreds of years ago. Very impressive during the day time but even more spectacular at night; especially from the river cruise dinner that we were on.

A must visit although more beautiful from a distance. Visiting Wat Arun is a must for the visitor to BKK. I've been here many times and it never gets old. The view of the temple is actually better from the river than on the temple itself but don't let that stop you from visiting. A sunset view of Wat Arun is a classic photo opportunity in Bangkok.

Stuppa with a View. When in Bangkok, we always take the boat down the river, and when we do, we always get off for a stroll around Wat Arun. The main stuppa is an amazing structure embedded with shards of broken china, and if you climb to the top, the view is 360 and fantastic. Besides, when you debark on the other side of the river to transfer to the ferry which takes you across to the Wat, go outside first and find the lady who makes the best Pad Thai in Bkk. right on her little wagon with her charcoal fired wok. She is right outside the station, and her daughter who sells drinks, speaks some English.

nice but other temples were more impressive to me. It is a sight to see but other temples were more impressive and incorporated more structures and images but if you are going to be in Bangkok anyway you should see this.
Intricate work. By far the most interesting structure, on account of the sheer work on the walls. Plus nice views of the Chao Praya river and the city from the topmost section.

Amazing Temple. Wat Arun, the Temple of Dawn, is one of Bangkok's best know landmark. It stands on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River in Thon Buri. Wat Arun is best seen from the opposite bank of the river; it glistens in the sunlight during the day and stands dark and noble at dawn or dusk. A visit to the beautiful, peaceful monastery complex surrounding the familiar towers is very worth-while. These towers, the "Phra Prang," although best known, the only part of Wat Arun. It also contains narrow lanes; elegant, old white buildings; shrines, pools of turtles;and two fine giants, " Yuk Wat Jaeng," mortal enemies of the " Yuk Wat Po" across the river. Wat Arun figures in one of Thailand's most colorful festival, the Royal Tod Kathin. Then His Majesty the King travels down the river in a procession of Royal barges to present new robes to the monks after their three-month lent period.

Freakin' awesome views.. Go to the Central water taxi station, pay 15 baht (50 cents), get off at dock #8, take the cross-river ferry for 3 baht, climb the Temple for an amazing view of Bangkok and the river! The boat ride is half the fun!

Sunset picture. Went there early but crowds were already pouring in. Climb the steep stairs to the top. Impressive building and especially photogenic at sunset from the other side of the river. Bring water along!

Amazing site. This amazing attraction is just a short boat ride across the river from the Royal palace.In addition to what has already been said, I would add...Wear shoes you can climb stairs in - There are quite a few stairs if you want to go to the top. Climbing to the top level is not recommended for anyone that is not in decent shape, children or seniors. The climb is VERY steep but coming down is even more treacherous. If you can make it to the top, do it. Great view.Leg and shoulder coverings are supplied at entrance for a small fee.Ticket price is worth it.Dont miss even if you cant climb to top.

Beautiful setting on river. This is by far my favorite Wat in Bangkok. Majestic, by the side of the river. As always, go early to avoid crowds and sun. Take the ferry across, avoid the tourist trap boats. Climb to the top, watch outnformthe steep stairs, and enj a beautiful ire of he city.

Dream like palace.. You can get there by tour, ferry or longboat. On the river it is a photographers dream. Unlike the other temples and wats it has a charm of it's own. Worth a stop if you are on the river

The great Pagoda and the Landmark. The original name of the temple was Wat Ma - kok, then in 1767 the name was changed to Wat Chaeng in according with General Tak-Sin ( later he became King Taksin of Thonburi, 1767 AD.- 1782 AD. ) who fought and chased away the Burmese Army from Ayutthaya ( 1350 AD. - 1767 AD ) , he want to found the place to built the new Capital and Palace , with his small group of army , he arrived at this temple and wanted to pay repect to the Buddha here at Dawn ( Dawn = Chaeng in Thais ). For the great Prang , it was built in the reign of king Rama II , finished in the reign of king Rama III , it has 76 meter high, decorated with the broken chinese porcelain, another interesting is the mural printing in the main Bot ( ordination Hall ) which describe about the Life of the Buddha from the Buddha as Prince Sitthatta went into Monkhood untill Nirvana and the most important ten former Life of the Buddha ( describe the ten virtues which lead the Buddha to Nirvana )
WOW! Beautiful at sunset. First time here and I loved it! Beautiful grounds and spires. Too expensive to get into temples anymore though.

Beautiful Outdoor Temple but Steep Climb. I always visit Wat Arun along with Wat Pho and the Grand Palace when my visitors are here. It is one of my favourite tourist sites - a beautiful outdoor structure decorated with colourful pieces of ceramics. Bring a hat as it can get very hot. The climb up (from any of the 4 sides) is challenging. I suffer from fear of heights so I usually stand below while my guests and sons negotiate the steep narrow stairs. I climbed up once and found that coming down 'backwards' (i.e. facing the steps) helped. It's a nice view of the Chao Phaya River from the top.The entrance fee for an adult is Bath 50 and children go free. There is a market selling souvenirs next to it. You can rent a Thai costume and have your picture taken on your way to/from the pier.To get there, from Pier N8 (Tha Tien), take a small boat which marks 'Tha Tien-Wat Arun-Tha Tien', costs only Baht 3 one way once you pass the turnstiles. To get to Tha Tien Pier, depending on where you are coming from, I usually take the BTS all the way to Saphan Taksin BTS station and take a tourist boat (going right - upstream) costing Baht 25 per adult from the Saphan Taksin pier just next to the Saphan Taksin BTS station. Tickets may be purchased onboard.
interesting to look at. interesting to look at but not as great as Wat Phra Keo, Wat Po or Wat Benchamabopit. Great locationon the river with good views of town.

Stunning architecture with a great view. Wat Arun was a pleasant departure from the dozens of traditional Wats that we've visited. The grounds are meticulously maintained, the environment serene, the temples well cared for and the fact that the site is on the river provides a cool breeze and great backdrop for exploring and contemplation. The biggest attraction to this site has to be the giant main pillar temple which rises 75 meters. Constructed out of stone and adorned with ceramic and shell pieces, this climable temple not is not only an attraction but provides brilliant views of the river and distant downtown core of Bangkok. You can also negotiate inexpensive hour long boat excursions and book tours through the ITAT government site. Wat Arun also offers a foreigner-friendly mediation program in English which you can inquire about while you're there. Getting to Wat Arun is very easy. Just walk across the street from Wat Phra Kaew to the ferry terminal. By-pass all of the tour operators go to the end of the terminal, hang a right then a left and you'll see the ferry entrance. 3 bhat gets you across and another 3 to get back. An absolute must see when you're in Bankok!
Thai temple..unique one. Arun come from the word, morning. You will find clam and peace in this temple ;)

Insane!. I had never climbed a Khmer-style temple before. The experience is tiring but beautiful! I was about to miss this masterpiece but I was happy that I didn't eventually. Everyone should go there when visiting Bangkok
Very beautiful. Unique architecture, a little harder to get to with the extra ferry but worth the effort

excellent view. This place is wonderful because it is not too crowded. It is easy to get around on the water ferry and visit all the temples (which I recommend) and then take a separate one that goes across the water from the other large ones. This temple is a bit expensive compared to others; but still cheap by American standards. The architecture is really special. I went in the early morning but going at sunset would probably be just as magical. Great panoramic views of the city from the top, but the stairs are steep!

You c this you've seen them all. If you are looking for Thai royalty heritage, this is the place. I would skip the grand palace, and the emirald buda. This place has it all and it is in my mind, one of the best attractions of Bangkok.
Trip up river is quite pleasant.
Beautiful Temple. but i didn't climb to the top of the pagoda because the stairs is too steep.
Stunning Architecture, especially at sun down. Part of the real Bangkok, right alongside the bustling river is a place of calm and serenity.

One of highlights of trip. Maybe because I didn't expect it, but this Wat was beautiful and different. You have to climb up to see the view but it is very steep! Just a great experience. And don't forget to pay the money to dress up in traditional garb...fun memory!Tip...be careful as only time on entire trip but vendor tried to scam me out of money.
Go at night. We went here on a night bike ride and it was spectacular
Nice. Very picturesque temple with observation view. Easy to get by boat
Impressive. It makes impression to go up the temple and especially go down (not for visitors with fear of heights).
Super. Don't miss this temple across the river from Wat Pho
ver very nice. except the crowds of scared turists walking up and down the steep stairs of the temple
sun set. I like Wat Arun, You can see Bangkok 360 degree on Wat Arun. Wat Arun setting near Cha Pra Ya River. You go to Wat Arun by boat. That a good idea for go there.

stay covered and have fun... impressive from the river or up close. You can climb to a certain level on Wat Arun. Be sure to stay covered it is a temple. There's a small market where you can over pay for water (20 baht) but they have some other items that are reasonably priced and they'll bargain to a degree. No real place to eat the temple, just snacks and drinks.

Climb to the top for an awesome view. We didn't do many cultural visits this time since we had the children with us, but this was worth the visit. Climb the steps to the top for an awesome view out over the river. Take a boat to this temple for a unique experience.
Interesting history. The temple is decorated with Chinese? Crockery salvaged from a shipwreck many years ago.

Go for the climb. Thw steps are steep but if you are up for it, you can walk 360 degrees around and take some nice pictures, besides it's fun as well. There was also some vendors outside which offered to dress you up in traditional garbs, crown and all to take pictures in.
One of my favorite places in Bangkok. I live in Bangkok and finally made it to Wat Arun and loved it! Went around sunset so it wasn't too hot and the lighting was pretty.
Loved it. Took a small ferry across from the Chao Phraya tourist boat stop. Great views from the top of the stairs along the river. Loved the seashells and the array of demons and monkeys

Really nice peacfull place to visit.. Wat Arun is a great place to visit on the opposite side of the river to the Reclining Buhda.You can climb the large stairs to the top of the main Temple,but be warned you'll have to climb back down,it is very high & coming down will have to be done backwards because of the steepness & you will have to use the railing all the way,it doesn't look much of a climb from the bottom but it is & a great view across the river to the City.
Magnificient architecture. Well worth the visit! Steep steps to climb to the top. Great to see it lighted up and when the sun sets behind the temple

nice from afar. It's a very nice wat from the river, but not really worth visiting. Whatever you do, don't fall for the trap of the little cutout Thai dancers. I was with a friend, we saw these cutouts and took each others' photos with our heads popping through the little holes. Next thing you know, a man appeared out of nowhere and wanted money. Of course we paid, but it was a total unmarked scam.

A Must not miss in Bangkok. I suggest that you integrate the Temple of Dawn into a Longtail boat excursion of the Chao Phraya. Be sure to include the Grand Palace and the back canals around the area. Learn the history of the temple... It is a wonderful place and will leave a lasting impression.

Best to visit in evening. The temple of the Dawan is located on the other side of the Chao Phaya river which means you have to go by boat/ferry. The ferry cost THB 6 one way per person (if my memory doesn't fail me). If you would like to climb up, then it's best to visit before 5pm, because the last admission into the temple is 6pm. When the sky turns dark, the lights turn on at the temple which make it a beautiful place for night snapshot of photos. The temple is always open for public, so do not believe if someone come to you on the street and tell you that "the temple is only open today, once in 500 years", you might be tempted to visit since the local said so and you will be paying THB 2000 per person for the so called "special discount ride". There is no such thing, so just be aware of what local said. For transportation, always check online or check with hotel counter, they would quote you a rate for the ride to anywhere you want (you can use it as a benchmark to negotiate with taxi drivers/tuk tuk outside)

Worth the Climb. I loved Wat Arun...very different from the other temples but worth the trip (I think I paid 3 baht) across the river. Make sure to climb the stairs to the top which gives you a great view of the river and city.

Fun and unexpected. The temple was great to visit. One of its most fun characterisitics was the fact that is was extremely steep. This proved to be a bit difficult when climbing, but pretty scary on the way down. The temple was also filled with monks, and had an adjoining market where tourists could buy souvenirs as well as many other traditional things

Fabulous Pagoda right on the river bank!!!. One of the most attraction we need to se when we visit Bangkok, this beautiful Pagoda situated on Chaophaya river bank, really beautiful when we travel by boat there...

Wonderful Sparkling Monument. Take a boat here and climb up the steep scary steps. Great "symbol" of Bangkok (OK actually in Thonburi). Note the millions of pieces of smashed porcellain which make it "sparkle".

Great city views. Great temple to climb up, not if your scared of heights or steep stairs... Not advisable for older people, very young or with a disposition.. However views of the city and surroundingg temples and river are excellent.... Makes we're wearing shorts but females had to cover up legs...t shirts were fine.... Some areas to get drinks and food on sight and only 50thb per person.....

Good day out. Wat Arun is a really nice morning out - beautiful gardens and the temple itself is really lovely. It is not as busy as the Grand Palace, so you can get right up close for some great pictures. Climbing it, even to the first level, is a must - for the photos alone! Entry is quite reasonable. Make sure you wear appropriate clothing (cover your ankles and shoulders). It can be a little tricky to get to in the middle of the day with traffic and small back roads etc - would recommend using the ferry, which is a lovely day out in itself.
My preferred one. I love this temple most... Build up from recycled porcelain cups, a small temple on the other side of the river bus easily accessible by boat.

Fabulous!. Amazing detailing and architecture. The views across the river is so beautiful. A must visit for anyone who wishes to explore the culture of Thailand. My partner and I enjoyed this place. If you walk up to the pier you can see the actual name of Bangkok in full..

Sunset. This is a must see in Bangkok! You take a short ferry across the river for about 3 baht and then pay 50 baht to see the temple. It was beautiful at sunset. Nice picture time. Then we paid 3 baht again to go back across the river.

Climb up and see bangkok. wonderful temple next to the river on the oposing side of the palace and the temple of the reclining budda
only worth the visit if you are able to climb up the stairs
Buddhist temple ... lovely architecture. its on a river bank..... might be fun to reach by some boat cruise

Gorgeous temple and should be visited if you go to Bangkok.. It's good to spend a day to visit Wat Phra Kaew, Grand Palace, Wat Pho and go across the river to Wat Arun. Best time to visit this temple is before the sunset. See the beautiful view of the temple & river area surrounding from the top of the temple. Please be careful if you're afraid of height.
Verynice. Very nice and fun to get too with the boats on the river,a nice excursion again done with private tour eddy at thailandvoyage.com

Great view. The main thing is the view of the Chao Phraya River and across the city. The site is simple, but very interesting. You get easy access to the river, with a very cheap ferry crossing from one side of the river (station opposite the Grand Palace) to the other. Do not miss.

Must See. Cheap entry ticket
Excellent heritage with rich history and gorgeous architecture

Great views!. * Usually very quiet because it is on the other side of the river and hardly any tour buses go there (a big plus!).* Catch the ferry from Tha Tien and back.* Ensure you cover up as a dress code is enforced (especially women wearing singlet tops etc.).* Look carefully at the amazing frescos and tiles all over the wat.* Climb carefully as the steps are steep - but the effort is worth it as the views are great (360 degrees).* Have a look around at the temples behind Wat Arun as they are also well worth it.
do it. enjoy the culture and history of Thailand. Enjoyed my time in the Temple

Impressive!. On the other side of Chao Praya, this temple is impressive. If you are brave, you can climb up and check out the view. It is made of little pieces of china or porcelain, and there is a nice garden around you can use for relaxing.

A very steep climb to the Top. So great to see this most beautiful temple from the Chao Praya River. Do go up and try to get to the top on these very steep stairs. You be awarded with the most fantastic view of Bangkok.

Loved the view!. I loved the look from the second level of the climb up. This is super precarious as the stairs are steep and not for the old or kids but if you're up for it the view is really nice. This temple seemed very serene to me. I liked kneeling on the inside and watching the worship.

Worth the trip across the river!. Apparently there's lots of scams that go on around most of the Wat trying to lead tourists away from the Wat, saying its closed etc or trying to direct you for a boat trip on their friends boat. Dont listen to the scammers!! Just smile and walk away if someone seems too friendly, they are!We made the trip across the river to see the Wat, definitely worth seeing! It wasn't as busy as some of the other Wats we visited, I think due to the fact its slightly out of the way, not as easy to get to as some of the others, but its just a short taxi/tuk tuk boat ride away!Again, you can spend quite a while wandering about and seeing all the artifacts, but its definitely worth climibing up to see the view across the river from the top!
Temple with a view!. Climb up the stairs and you will have a nice view overlooking the river and parts of the city.

A worthwhile monument to visit as well as view from the other river bank.. One can climb up two levels of this monument, however these would NEVER pass ANY Health & Safety regulations. The steps are large and very steep. It was very scary and dangerous according to those brave enough to venture up. I stayed firmly on the ground!

The Temple of Dawn. Excellent! Worth the trip on the ferry across to see this wonderful temple which just takes your breath away as you turn each corner. You need a good head for heights to tackle the very steep climb to the top. One false move and you good be in trouble!

Brought back memories. of our visit over 40 years ago. The grounds are beautiful and not mobbed with people.......while comments have talked about it being more interesting from far......we adored the ceramic chip mosaics from being up close and personal.AND it's another excuse to be close to the river!!!!!!Do go......you will cherish the moments.

another temple but the best in Bangkok. Nothing incredible - but if you are visiting the Grand Palace (which you should be if your are in Bangkok) then you may as well take the short boat trip across the river to see Wat Arun.

Another Bangkok Must-See. Take the ferry across the Chao Praya River for just a few Baht to check out this Cambodian-style temple. Climb to the top for a terrific view! It also looks great at sunset, if you can arrange to be on a boat going by.

So much prettier than you expect from the pictures. Having been to the more famous Wats on previous visits we decided to try Wat Arun as it looked very different style-wise, and we could combine it with a river trip. 100 Baht on a taxi from Siam Square and then 200 baht to get in makes it a cheap date - and its absolutely stunning close up. You really need the sun to be out to experience all the gold glinting, and the gentle sound of the tiny bells ringing all over the site. You also need to be reasonably fit and steady on your feet to climb the steep stairs to the top - the view is well worth it. When you're done it costs all of 8 baht to cross the river to the other side where the Chao Phraya Express operates.
Unbelievably amazing Wat Arun. Beautiful, absolutely amazing. The detail and hard work that was put into making this temple is out of this world.
Also great. Walk to the top on the crazy-steep steps. You'll be proud once you do it.
Average site. Not very exciting to spend alot of time here, if u have the time to climb all those stairs then great...you can get the aerial views of BKK from many other places.
Beautiful beautiful!. a very beautiful and calm place, worth visiting for sure.
Beautiful at night. For the best view of this temple, watch it from rivertaxi / longtailboat.

Special Place. I have been many times and it is a special place but is being spoilt by building work nearby. It is easy to get a ferry from close to Grand Palace and still spectaular to see from the river for the first time.

Beautiful park and Wat. Visited this site on our last day in Bangkok. We got there about 4:00 after spending a couple hours at the National Museum. Remember to wear appropriate clothing - no shorts or sleeveless shirts. You can rent clothing for 20 Baht, but why not just be prepared! Climb to the top to see great views of Bangkok and the river. See this at sunset. It is a beautiful sight. The park around the Wat is also very peaceful and charming. Perfect end to our trip.

Go for it.. Very high and steep stairs. I was afraid to climb up because the steps are very steep and short. If you go up you could see the river and city view. Watching to the details are interesting of walls. When you use the toilet you should pay some money which is up to you. The memorial shop is a little expensive.
Beautifully Serene Place. A peaceful sactuary just on the opposite side of the River
Beautiful temple.. Really beautiful temple. Interesting & well worth visiting.
Fantastic. This place is on the opposite of the river...it's great! The stairs are very steep to climb up for the view...but it's worth it!

super.... Another must-visit Buddha temple in Bangkok... this one is on the other side of the Chao Phraya river.. I recommend first visiting the Wat Pho and then walking to the pier from where you can take a short ferry across to Wat Arun. It takes less than 5 minutes and costs just 3 THB.
Majestic. Awe inspiring sight. I liked that there were no hordes of street hawkers and con men lying in wait for tourists. The ferry ride to cross over the Chao Praya added tp our enjoyment.
A Favorite Wat!. This Wat is on the river and has amazing photo opportunities. The Wat is decorated mosiac style and very colorful. You are allowed to climb the stairs to the top and enjoy the views.

A less visited temple that is worth the climb. Most people see Wat Arun from across the river but few people actually make it across. That is quite sad as the view from the top is wonderful and the decorations on the temple are very nice. I recommend taking a ferry across from the Wat Pho area to see Wat Arun (just make sure to go early or late as it gets hot).
Awesome. You won't believe how high you can climb and the views of the river! Only 50THB to get in. Wroth it.

Arun means The sun in Sanskrit....Wat Arun: Wonderful architecture. This is really a masterpiece of all the wats in bangkok......This Khamer style architecture is very impressive...it is across the Chao Phraya river...... There is a nice ground in this temple premises..... entrance fee for this wat is 50 bhatt....you can get a boat from a pier to and from the temple in just 3 bhatt (one way).....the pier is few minutes walk from the grand palace....Should not miss it.!!!
Very steep stairs, beautiful buildings, peaceful. definitely very thai-ish, great for pictures and soaking in the atmosphere
My favorite Wat in Bangkok. Great Views from the top. Worth crossing the river
Beautiful Temple. It's fun to get to this temple by ferry and then the temple itself is just lovely.
river view pagoda. Beautiful View of River from Pagoda. The pagodas are pretty tall and the climb is steep but worth the view

Amazing. The trip across the river was almost as exciting as reaching the temple. Girls remember to take a cardi or you will have to pay to use some manky old shawl to cover your shoulders in the temple.

Amazing view and attention to details. The stunning main spire of the Wat Arun is enough to impress travellers due to its elegant structure and the chance to climb the steep stairs to the wind-buffed viewing level. As a materials engineering student, I was fascinated by the detailed ceramic decorations that have stood the tests of time. Every surface is dotted with individually crafted pieces: glazed plates, flowers, leaves, and other shapes, some coloured, some patterned. It is amazing to see these temples that have stood for hundreds of years, and the dedication of the visionaries who created them, and those who restored and continue to maintain them.

Amazing.. Though a little crowded, but the experience was worth the visit. Only the photograph sellers trouble you insisting that you buy your photographs embossed on to plates and cups. The statue of Buddha was awe inspiring.

BURMESE TEMPLE IN THAILAND. A terrific example of Burmese design, along the river in Bangkok. My favorite view, next to the Grand Palace. Take the ferry across the rive, so you can walk on it and around it.. So beautiful at sunset. Don't miss this beauty.
Another must. From the Grand Palace, walk to the river (have an iced coffee on the way from the old auntie - delicious!) and then catch the ferry across the river. Only 2 Bht!
Nice Artistic architecture. It amazes me what those of the ancient world were able to do with so littleWorth the trip on land and from the river
Gorgeous. I first saw it from a river boat cruise, then up close. The tile and detail work was intricate and beautiful.
Nice spot, right at the river. Be sure to come here around sunset. Romantic treat.. Not to many tourists here. Nice location and the river

A beautiful place to see at sunrise.. The Wat Arun is on the opposite banks of the river Chao Phraya from where is the Wat Po. This white temple, made of a tall stupa covered in white ceramics, is very famous for the beautiful reflections that it has at sunrise. It's buth beautiful to see it from the opposite banks of the river and to be there at sunrise.
Energy. There's a peaceful energy in this Temple, its good for meditation and morning prayers.

Beautiful!. We visited Wat Arun on our last day in Bangkok. The temple is beautiful. If you climb to the top of the temple you can get some great views and pictures of the city. But be careful as the steps are very steep and even made me feel a bit nervous!To get to the temple you have to take the boat which is another lovely way to see the city! Travelling by boat along the river is a must on your visit to Bangkok!

What a Sight. I didn't expect to enjoy this place but I did. This is a sight to see in the middle of Bangkok ... I kinda got scared climbing the stairs though as they were really steep.One suggestion too is that you come properly dressed, else you will have to rent proper attire before they let you in. You can't come in shorts or shirt without sleeves.
amazing. beautiful, should take a water taxi there and get out, i wish i did

Beautiful Temple. Located across the Chao Phraya River, it's a beautiful temple complex. There is a cheap ferry to another beautiful Wat. Must do for visitors to Bangkok. We went there purely by chance, on the recommendation of our taxi driver, but after the Grand Palace, I would rate this as # 2.
everynice temple. I have been one time i like it so i think i'll visit again

A must see - and make the climb up. As you have read in every tour book, this is a very famous and amazing site. Do take the time to go and don't rush your visit. Also, go up to the top and enjoy the sites. Going down can be a bit trick, but take your time - it very worth it. Also, be prepared to take lots of pictures.
Just beautiful!!. One of the most beautiful temples I've seen the mosaics are stunning.
Easy accessible by boat and peaceful!. Wat Arun is incredibly easy to get to by boat. Once you are there, it is a peaceful place to give merit and to view the beautiful architecture.

Beautiful temple, even better at Sunset!. This was a really beautiful temple which I visited twice. The first time we had missed the opening hours so I just lingered around the garden where we were invited by a monk to join a prayer session held in one of the side temples (serene and very authentic experience with the locals - and you can leave any time). The second time we visited we made sure we arrived just before closing so that we can stay for sunset. At night the entire temple lights up giving it a really nice aura and the view from above is just fantastic.
Wow. Really nice temple. Amazing architecture, very mayan-meets-thai. Right on the river, best to take a water taxi to it.

Artistic Temple in Chao Phraya riverside. Why I called artistic? Because this temple was built using porcelain pieces, and it was "glued" at the temple. Outside the temple, there is a cheap marketplace, but you must do bargain to get the best price.
very beautiful. well kept for its age. It was fun to get to by boat. We even had some excellent som tum and grilled chicken there. Vendors were very polite and no one was pushy.

Fantastic!. Great piece of architecture; so many little details and history. Superb views of the city. A good deal and worth a look around! The steep steps to the top are great cuz they'd never allow you to do that in other countries! :)

This is the only touristed temple that I revisit.. Generally, I prefer the less-hyped temples. A test: if the temple has an admission charge for foreigners I tend not to visit more than once (and maybe skip the place entirely). I prefer older or more unique temples outside BKK, such as are part of the Angkor-era archaeological sites in Thailand and Cambodia. And there are the semi-regularly reported scams operated around the periphery of the Wat Arun grounds (so be careful about doing anything aside from visiting and enjoying the temple itself).That said, quite a few visiting friends want to see Wat Arun. Where we put friends on a tour bus to the Grand Palace and Wat Phra Kaeo, we will personally escort them to Wat Arun - as it's structure is fascinating (and its appearance varies quite widely in differing lighting).

Climb to the top of this beautiful Wat for great views!. Wat Arun is on the other side of the Chao Phraya river to most of the other tourist attractsion which means you have to take a short ferry trip (5 mins, and costs about 20 Baht, I seem to remember) from Tha Tien Pier (Pier Stop 8)…located close to Wat Pho. Don't make the mistake of getting on the Express Boat (which operates from another pier at the same terminal) by mistake! Wat Arun is a very beautiful "temple mount" spire and the climb up the very steep steps is rewarded by stunning views across the river and city as well as a cooling breeze.Be aware; the steps are very steep, almost like a ladder and once youre up you have to get back down as well!

This one is my favourite.. This is a beautiful temple located by the cho Phraya river. You go there by ferry. The temple is adorned very beautifully. One thins that particularly catches my attention is the golden peepil leaves that adorn it.

Wear some clothes to climb in!. I loved this Temple. We took a boat across the river to get to it. Upon arriving, there were GIANT fish you could feed... so bring some small bills/change to get some food. I know this seems stupid, but it was a lot of fun. We walked around this gorgeous temple towards the end of the day so we were tired. It had great views of the river and a variety of interesting areas to walk around.One of the things I wish I knew in advance was that climbing the temple was difficult. It was extremely steep AND slippery. Make sure to wear some sneakers to get up there. I had walked around in sandals all day to get into and out of the temples easily. It backfired here.There were some services going on that were very cool to witness. There were also a few "scam" artists on the way in so just keep walking! Enjoy!

Include it in tour itinerary. Wat Arun is another must-see temple in Bangkok. Its main attraction - the center pagoda, which is about 80m high is very prominent even from the ferry boat. One can climb this using very steep exterior steps and get very nice views of the area. Just be ready for that exercise!

a Beautiful temple. i think this is a beautiful temple seen from the river, as there are quite a number of interesting temples in Bangkok, seeing all of them can be an overdose. It is the architecture of the temple that got me and its a beautiful temple to do photography and surprisingly, you can get a great sunset shot from here.

Spiritual. You got be there to believe it, From the day of Indiana jones Movies, the temple is laid and decorates in Glass & Porcelen with a magnificant architecture, admist the chao phraya river its amonst the most photogenic Temple achitecture of its kind!!!
Scene straight from the books. My friend wanted to see Wat Arun because it's often described in the books she read. According to her, it was exactly how the author described it, very romantic.

A must for all visitors. Very impressive try and climb up the stairs and see how far you make it ( it is very steep with a difficult angle / pitch ) You will have to visit by long boat, so take one of the river cruise trips and include it as one of your stops of visiting interesting temples etc.
Excellent. Peacefull, quieter than Grand Palace, and the cross-river ferry (from Tha Thien) is good fun as well
Not a lot to see in the Temple. What you can see in the temple is all that you can see from the outside...

Spectacular. I'd never heard of Wat Arun and what an amazing spectacle it is. We climbed the steep stairs for a breathless view of the river and the city. The wat itself is very different from others, encrusted with ceramic pieces - ancient, colorful. Not to be missed.

Breathtakingly beautiful. We went to Wat Arun during our night cycling tour with Grasshopper Adventures. The temple grounds were emptied from all the day-time tourists and it was just our little group. The temple and statues are all lit and made for an eerie atmosphere. It was quiet and beautiful. When it eventually started raining, we all stood under the eave of one of the structures staring at the majectic tower in front of us. A must-see from anyone in Bangkok. Try to book the Grasshopper Tour for a more unique experience!
Must see. It is part of Bangkok history and is a must see. Also talke a long tail boat on Chao Priya river (forgive misspelling)

Well Maintained Temple!. We visited Wat Arun during our bangkok river boat trip for half a day. Wat Arun was one of the stop during that Trip. An amazing, huge, well maintained temple where one can see the history and tradition of Thailand. Overall, Wat Arun should be on must visit list if you are history/ historical places lover!

Words Can't Explain. This is a place that words and pictures just don't do it justice. This is a must see place on the west side of the Chao-Phraya River just opposite of the Grand Palace. You can take a long-tail boat tour and see both The Grand Palace and Temple of Dawn on the same tour. Well worth the trip.

wat arun. On the other side of the river it gives you one of the best views of bangkok. The temple itself is very high, with amazing detail and more quiet than most of the other monuments in bangkok. the boat to cross the river is very cheap and the temple is definitely worth seeing.

worth a visit. Due to the current flooding in Bangkok, I did not visit this trip due to the high water level. very pleasant to visit Wat Arun if you take the river ferry and stop off at various places

Breathtaking!!!!!!. We were amazed at the beauty of the temple from the boat approaching the temple and even more so after getting close to it. The entire temple is made from little pieces of ancient pottery!!!!! The details up close made us search the entire surface looking for little differences and neat little unique pieces. Truly an amazing temple like no other we have seen.
nice. nice to see, There is always something different, to discover
Aamzing!. It was quite an experience to step off the ferry and climb the steps of Wat Arun. Steep, old, ornate and airy. Beautiful view of the city and an impressive vantage of the Grand Palace.

Wat Arun - The Temple of Dawn. I visited this fine temple on a business trip with colleagues arranged by Thailand International Tours back in August of this year. We were picked up by our Thailand International Tours’ driver shortly after breakfast, and arrived when the temple was still quiet. Wat Arun is one of the best known landmarks in Bangkok, and easily recognized with the high pagoda in the centre which is almost 100m. It is possible to climb the prang, using some very steep steps, to two terraces giving excellent views. Your legs will surely burn the next day!! Phra Prang is decorated with a mosaic of multi-coloured Chinese porcelain, which surely adds to its majestic beauty. The decoration reminded me of some of The Taj Mahal in fact. The outer four corners hold statues of the God of the Wind or Phra Phai.This temple is classified as a principal class Royal temple. It is a fairly old temple, being built in the days of Thailand's ancient capital of Ayutthaya and originally known as Wat Makok. It has changed its name a few times. King Thaksin changed the name to Wat Chaeng. King Rama II restored the temple and gave it a new name as Wat Arunratchatharam. King Rama IV also made some additional restorations and again changed the temple's name to the present one as Wat Arunratchawararam. However the most famous name is Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn.Wat Arun is best viewed at sunset if viewed from the Bangkok side of the river. Take a boat trip on the Chao Phaya when you are next in Bangkok, and make sure you visit Wat Arun, you will not be disappointed. Alternatively, there are several restaurants and coffee shops across the river which make fine viewpoints of the temple. Probably a good idea is to take in the magical sights of Wat Pho, and the Grand Palace on the same trip, and if you have the legs for it, perhaps Wat Pho all in the same trip.It was an impressive day for all the members of our group, and a big thanks must go to Thailand International Tours for their professional organisation throughout the whole day.

Out of the ordinary. Just imagine: a temple built of fragments of broken pottery. That way a few centuries ago a garbage became the work of art . Wat Arun is amazing and really differs from other temples. I would recommend it as one of the essential sights of Bangkok.
Lovely. Worth the trip! It was all that the guidebooks said. Very nice!

Impressive. The location of the temple is impressive, right by the pulsating river. The nice thing about the temple - albeit a lazy one - is that is quickly done. By that I mean that you arrive, you climb the different buildings and admire the view. This is an understandable temple with little fuss. We arrived and left by commuters ferry, which was nice. If you want to see something special this is a good recommendation. Entrance fee was nominal.
A must see..... An intergral part of thai culture that must be visited

Lima Puluh Ribu Rupiah. " Lima Puluh Ribu Rupiah Saja (IDR 50000 )(speaking Indonesian language) " said the woman who offered to lend a complete set of thai's traditional clothes, and you might have a photograph with the most thai's authentic dressing in front of the temple, nice....I'm a bit surprised, I just get off the boat and people there welcoming me with speaking Bahasa Indonesia :D Just before you get the entrance of the temple you will find several people offering you a photograph, including rental some thai's clothes, and also selling some souvenirs. They might take a candid shot of you, but don't be too afraid, they will make a nice decorative porcelain plate with your face on the center, just wait couple of minutes, and the cool souvenirs is done. They will charge you for about 100 bahts if you want to get the plate, but if you don't, that will be ok, they will let you enjoy the rest of the temple. Well I can say the front yard is the 1st best photograph spot in this area, I suggest take about 10 minutes enjoy the scenery there, take photograph as much as you can. As you enter The Temple you'll see many statues figuring Budddha, just like other Budhist religious site. Some of the statues covered with gold finished, I'm not sure if thoose are real 24K gold plated. The temple is Pagoda shaped, and the largest one lies in the center, this also the highest buildings in the temple. I didn't know exactly what is the main materials of the temple, while the solid cement concreted wall covered with mozaic piece of colorful ceramics as the finishing touch looks very stunning and beatiful. I agree with many review before me, is quite difficult to climb up to the top level, either when you climb down. The stairway are very steep, although they provide steel handle along the way up, you must very very careful. Just don't be afraid of that, if you like to dare yourself , just try to climb up to the top level, no matter how hard it is, your sweat won't be wasted, there are a very worth stunning views waiting for you up there. This is the 2nd best spot in Wat Arun for me, take about 10 - 15 minutes there, enjoy the scenery while you can resting, you'll see The Grand Place on east side accros Chao Praya river and the shadow of bangkok's busy sourrounding. Before leaving, if you still want to buy some souvenirs, t-shirts, hats, and etc there are several small store inside the temple area. Once Again, I found Indonesian language there, many of them can't speak english well, but Bahasa Indonesia is more popullar. They wrote down a label with Bahasa, like " Diskon " in english we said " Sale " , " semua kaos sablon putih @ 99 bahts " in english " all white printed t-shirts @ 99 bahts ", how nice is that, they will give more discount if you buy up to 5 pieces. Bargaining is OK, but just ask them to lower the price 5-10 bahts. Sun block cream, hats and sun glasses is necessary. If you plant to get on the top floor, prepare your shoes, especially after rain the stairway can be slick, you do not need to hurry, just take it easy and slowly, be safe. Bangkok can be very hot in mid day, you'll always get thirsty, I suggest bring enough drinking water. As we must put respect to this sacred place, do not ever try to get in there wearing short pants or mini skirt, tank top or sleeveless, wear a proper dress. We must obey the rules, mean while they will charge you 20 bahts for renting " Sarong " , you will need it to cover up your bottom piece if you wear short or mini skirt and still want to get in. :) :) :)
Fantastic the best temple I've been to. It was not too crowded. 50 bahts well spent as this is one of the best temples. I watched the people that were renovating and painting the decorations by hand.
Must Visit. Unique temple and stunning views from the top. Very conveniently located on chao phraya river.

The third palace in Thailand. Wat Arun was the third palace in Thailand so it was worth going to for comparison with the other two I was able to visit (A. was out due to the flooding). The use of pottery/ceramics was definitely different.
There is a nice view of the river.

Temple of the sun. Its a beauty to behold at sunrise and sunset especially from the river. The view from the opposite bank is just awesome. The temple itself is a sight to behold.I would recommend that you hit Wat Arun first thing in the morning before you cross the river to see the rest OR at the end towards sun-down to get the best views :)River crossings to Wat Arun are from the No.8 pier.

Pray and Shop ^_^. if you afraid of high please don't try to climb up until the top of the temple. because it is very narrow and easy to climb but not easy to go down :)This is the best place to shop Thailand Souvenirs. Cheaper than MBK or Chatuchak. Friendly and polite seller also. Love to shop here indeed.

Beautiful - Scary climb to the top with amazing views over Bangkok. This is a beautiful temple !! Ornately decorated with pottery pieces in different colours. It is very steep steps to the top. I was a little too afraid to climb up to the top however, my husband climbed it. Worth several hours of sightseeing even if you don't climb. the Temple complex is gorgeous. There are vendors on the shore of this temple where you can get some pretty awesome one of a kind souvenirs There are even local clothing vendors to buy the dance costumes.
A must-do Wat. Well worth the short ferry ride across the Chaophraya to get there and explore. Very photogenic and do climb up to get the best views.
quiet and impressive. just see it and experience the calm afforded by the historic architecture

Amazing. the temple was so beautiful exquisite with buddhist carvings. Its not a place for elderly people or people who have a fear of height since the go-up stairs was so steep. I didn't climb it since I had to use my glasses due to an eye infection. I was so afraid that I might fall. But my friend who went up the stairs said the view was amazing. Definitely will visit it again!

Stunning. Wat Arun is located on the west bank of the Chao Praya river and it sits across from the Grand Palace. Can be reached By bus or boat. This is a must see while touring Bangkok. This place lights up in the evening which an eye pleasing spectacle. You should try to climb the temple, but beware that it can be steep at certain parts of the temple.

simply amazing!. i got to the temple right when it opened and it was worth the early rise to avoid the crowds. seeing the temple in the sun as i approached on the boat was incredible. i can see why it is one of the gems of Bangkok. what an amazing place!if you have knee problems be sure to take good care when going up or down the stairs as they are incredibly steep.when you cross the river, exit at Tha Tien pier if you want to go to Wat Pho. i took the express river boat to Tha Chang and had to backtrack to get to Wat Pho.

Definite, must-see attraction in Bangkok!!. For anyone visiting Bangkok for the first time, this is a must-see place. This Buddhist temple was constructed in the 1800's and is a simply beautiful sight to behold from the river. Best way to get here is to take the river taxi and get off at this stop. Probably one of the best views for this temple is from the river taxi.The temple itself is name after the Indian God of Dawn (Aruna). It is a magnificent looking temple. You can climb to the second level, although getting from the first level to the second has some very steep steps! But definitely worth the effort. You can get a really great view of the city from this level. All of the designs and stone statues on the temple are just something else! You do not want to miss this place!There are also many other smaller temples that you can see here as well besides the main one. Plus, lots of good souvenirs can be found here and at reasonable prices. Good variety of souvenirs too.

A must do!. Beautiful grounds and there are many buildings to see. No fee to see those. The main temple itself (the tall structure that you see from the river) is amazing. Entrance fee to see the main structure is 50baht. Dress appropriately - T-shirts and long pants, or shorts (but must cover your knees). If you are not afraid of heights, claim up the steep stairs for the views. Go early morning. You know how it gets hot later in the day!Take BTS to Saphan Taksin station, take exit 1 or 2, then walk to the pier. You then take a boat to Tha Tien dock (dock #8). You can buy a ticket for a "tourist" boat which is 30baht. Or you can just stand inline and wait for a semi-express "local" boat (with yellow flags) heading up the river. After the boat departed, they will ask you for the fare, which is 15baht.Once you get to Tha Tien and disembark, you just walk up the dock around to the right and pay 3baht (yes, 3!) to board another boat to cross the river to the other side where Wat Arun is.To go back, you just reverse the trip.I would not buy anything at the Wat. It's over-priced! You can get food/drinks back at Tha Tien dock at better prices (or bring your own).
Beautiful Scenery. Steep stairs but well worths the challenge. Beautiful scenery giving you opportunity to have good shots.
Fab views. Careful what you wear the steps down are really scary and steep

Good for pass time and first time visit. Climbing up the stairs is really killing. LOL. But the view is worthwhile!Entrance fee to temple is 50bahtTo get here, we took BTS to Saphan Taksin , bought a boat ticket to Tha Tien and take a small boat across the river. You will need to wear attires covering your shoulders (t-shirt will do) and covering your legs too. No short skirts and pants allowed especially got girls. If not you will need to pay 100baht for the attire rental (rental only) So be prepared! There are shops around but their price is pretty high and unwilling to negotiate, so don't suggest to buy anything there. The temple is pretty unique if it's your first time visits and those girls who are very long skirts even climbing the stairs is pretty hard for them. Basically i saw a few man peeking up at them because the climbing was really steep! After visiting the temple, do try and go to the corner and search for this noodle store which is quite tasty too! It's 50baht per bowl but it's delicious. Unless you're dying for water or coconut juice, i suggest you don't buy from there too. Bring your own water because across the river at Tha Tien station there's a mini market which sells cheaper stuff and cheaper drinks and coconut especially!

Broken Dishes as Decoration! How cool is that!. Bangkok has 500 temples. We saw the palace and this one (and many from our motor boat tour down the river). This was so cool! The outside has broken china that was repurposed into decorative flowers on the temple! You have to go up to the top for the experience. I've never climbed such steep stairs! The view is really cool up top and on all the levels. It's a quick stop, but such a cool memory!

Great - but be prepared for steps!. Great temple to visit (don't forget to dress appropriately).Amzing views from temple and also the temple itself is fascinating. However be aware that there are some very steep steps (best tip is to come down backwards!) and some people who are afriad of heights seemed quite freaked out by the climb!

One word...Amazing. The temple is claim as the most photographed and famous in Thailand and its true. When I get there I took a lot of picture and all is beautiful. This temple is breathtaking, and its not hard to reach just using a public boat at 3 bath one way per person. But at that moment the weather is really hot so me and my friend not climb until the top only see from the close. But is amazing to see some tiny porcelain put together and become that temple. It is really beautiful, absolutely recommended.

Breathtaking. This temple is worth the visit. It's on the other side of the river, and a bit of a trek to get there, but upon close inspection it's full of wonderful architectural treasures. The entire wat is essentially a glorious mosaic. Just remember to wear appropriate attire: ladies need to cover their shoulders and their knees. If you do find yourself arriving at the end of a day where you didn't plan your dress accordingly, they'll rent you sarongs and scarves to cover yourself- but it'll cost you!

Amazing. We climbed Wat Arun in the midday heat of an August rainy season day. Amazing to see how apparently recycled tiles make up this nice monument. The stairs are steep, and it takes some breath to climb them but the reward is a beautiful view of old Bangkok, the river and the temples underneath. Take a camera and good shoes (I would not advise flip-flops, barefoot would be better, but the stones can be hot when the sun is out).
must do. you can't visit bangkok without visiting wat arun. it is the city.
Impressive!. Very impressive architecture. A true symbol of the Thai culture and heritage. Worth the visit.

Best temple in Bangkok. Though Wat Pho and the Emerald Buddha are the most visited ones my personal favourite is Wat Arun. The pagoda is in Cambodian-style and and is not easy to climb up (not recommended for small children or people with high-sickness), the viwe above there is great and the pagoda itself is worth a visit. Best way is go there is to take the boat ferry for 3THB from nearby the Grand Palace. I would recommend to take the boat tour on the Chao Phraya River. The boat tour takes you to canals where still people live nearby the canal. It reminded me a bit of Amsterdam.

Not as Impressive. Access>>Visitors can board the boat from Tha Tien (pier #8) to cross to Wat Arun's pier. The boat ride cost 3 bath and has frequent departures. From the pier, the ticket booth is a further 200m walk.Tickets>>50 bath per adult for entry to Wat Arun.Dress code>>For those who wear shorts, sarong rental is available at ticket inspection booth at the gate (20 bath for rental and 100 bath for deposit).First impression>>From the river or from across the river, the temple looks awesome and interesting to visit (you can find the pictures from many tourism book of Bangkok). Just take a look at the photo that I took from the boat ride, it's impressive and makes you want to put it into your top of the list of "attraction to visit"Temple ground>>Basically there is 1 main temple; which has lots of staircases and the steps are rather steep. Not recommended at all for those who have phobia of heights. The temple ground is maintained and clean. However, I'd rather disappointed to see that many of the paints are faded. The difference is very noticeable on how the temples and building inside Grand Palace complex have colourful hues while the one at Wat Arun is left to be desired.For 50 bath, I felt it was rather more value for money to go to Wat Pho (which has same entrance fee) instead.Facilities>>Bathroom are located outside the temple ground. Souvenir stalls and food stalls are mushrooming on one corner near the ticket booth.

Exquisite Beauty. We were lucky enough to be able to see Wat Arun both by day and night. By day, we visited the grounds and took our time visiting the buildings and climbing the central monument. We went to Tha Tien pier and then took the ferry over directly to Wat Arun for only 20 baht each. The entrance fee for tourists to the Wat is 50 baht each. The Wat is open from 7am to 5 pm daily. Please remember men need to wear long pants and women need to wear pants or skirts that cover to just below the knee, shirts that cover the shoulders and back and shoes that cover the ankles and toes, (ie no flips flops!)The stairs on the central prang are very steep and one must be very careful when climbing and descending. the steep stairs do have meaning though- they represent the difficulties of reaching higher levels of existence. The view of the Chao Phraya river and the rest of the grounds is very beautiful when you do get up there. Also, the popular view of Wat Aurn, as seen from the river appears on the ten baht coin. there are 4 other minor prangs that flag the central prang.It is amazing as you walk around the grounds and look closely at all the prangs and see all the small pieces of ceramics and porcelain that were used to complete this amazing temple.If you get a chance to see this exquisite beauty lit up at night like we did on our river cruise, take the chance, it is incredible.

Very cool temple. I have seen this temple in photos, and did not realise that it is covered entirely in small pieces of china.You get to it by riverboat and after you have passed through the touts selling tourist-tat, the temple arrives and is very impressive.It has very steep sides and very steep steps, I guess very dangerous for kids, but for us adults, was a lot of fun :)Definitely a highlight of Bangkok.

Tranquility accross the river. from tha tien pier take a ferry (there's a sign and a ticket vendor, you won't miss it) for 3 thb/way to accross the chao praya river. it costs 50 thb entrance fee.The place is not so full with tourists, it's refreshing and calm. a very nice get away from grand palace or wat pho.Be carefull when climbing the prang, since it has small steps and quite high.

Beautiful ancient temple in the heart of Bangkok. While wandering the streets of Bangkok near the Grand Palace, we came upon a woman offering boat rides on a pier at the end of an alley. We figured what the heck, and hired a boat for a tour of the canals and a stop-off at Wat Arun (1000 bhat for the 3 of us, definitely negotiable). It turned out to be a fantastic way to get to see some wildlife (numerous monitor lizards, fish, etc.) and experience a less well-known part of the city. Wat Arun, I believe a Khmer-era temple, is beautiful and worth climbing up the dizzying stairs for a good view of the city. There are also some gardens with a few impressive statues around the temple and of course the ubiquitous shop selling cold drinks and trinkets (also bathrooms!). Admission is a modest fee, and non-natives are encouraged (required?) to wear appropriate clothing as this is a sacred site. I believe there are options to see other sites from these boats including the Snake Farm, where they make antivenin, but we didn't partake.

Definitely worth the cross-river trip. The Wat Arun or Temple of the Dawn is located at the west side of the Chao Phraya River. To get there, take a cross-river ferry from the Wat Pho stop (Tha Tien N8). The ferry takes off every fifteen minutes or so, and costs about THB4 per person one way. The ferry operates from six o'clock in the morning to ten o'clock in the evening daily.The dress code for visiting Thai temples applies in Wat Arun, which means no shorts, mini-skirts, tight-fitting trousers, tights, sleeveless shirts, see-through shirts, sweatshirts and sweatpants, quarter-length trousers, and sandals without ankle or heel straps. Better bring socks just in case because bare feet is not allowed. All shirt sleeves also cannot be rolled up.Although there are various structures of note in the Wat Arun complex, such as Wat Mahathat, which is one of the six royal temples of the highest class and was built during the Ayutthaya period, the central prang of Wat Arun is the main highlight of the trip. There is a fee of THB20 per person to enter the prang compound. Be prepared for a steep climb up the central prang -- those who have fear of heights should not attempt to go all the way to the top lest they are unable to go back down. The steps get narrower as you get higher up the prang, but even the halfway mark shows you breathtaking views of the river.

not an easy climb but fully worth it. As others mentioned you can easily reach this Wat via a ferry from the other side which costs only cents, the entrance is also pretty cheap and while it looks pretty impressing from the other side of the river (or the public transport boats, stronly recommend them for getting around in Bangkok, no jams) it is also fully worthwhile to see it up close.As most Wats in Thailand is is full of statues, full of decorations and colours and also full of details. Some general knowledge of the religion and culture will enhance your visit there greatly so you can identify better what is what. The climb up is pretty steep and narrow (as well as the climb down) and in the Bangkok heat and humidity this can be exhausting and you need to be able to use such stairs (think ladders). The view from up over Bangkok even to the grand palace is pretty much worth it anyway. It is different from the other Wats in Bangkok, no big central Buddha, more of the Camobodchian (khmer) style so you have a unique thing to see here. All in all you can have a good visit in about one hour so if you are at Wat Po and Grand Palace it can be easily included.P.S. As somebody already mentioned, the grand palace is always open so if somebody approaches you telling otherwise he is trying to scam money from you.
happy trip. if u visit wat pho just find a market behind. it connected to jetty that allow u across the river to wat arun. nice place, but not so big like grand palace.

Temple with a difference. As the pictures clearly show a temple that is somewhat different to the standard fare in Bangkok. Much quieter that some of the bigger attractions across the river, dirt cheap. and offers great views back over the city. Be warned - the stairs are incredibly steep. Water 'taxi' across the river dead easy.

Great Wat, But Thai Costume Photo opportunity-Even better!. My family of 5 (Hubby and three teenagers) were dropped off at Wat Arun after a long boat tour through the canals. Straight away it is an incredible sight but also, you get a chance to be photographed in traditional ancient Thai clothing, one of my families favorite thing to do. The charged us 1000 Bht for the 5 of us which was about $33. I could have probably talked them down but it was great fun and we now have a pretty swell souvenir. Afterwards we walked around the Wat and climbed to the incredible views. Then,we took a water taxi back across the river for 5 BHT each and got back on the water taxi to take us to the Saphan Taksin Sky train stop. Very easy and very cheap.

Another magnificent Wat. While some tourists and guides say that Wat Arun is best seen from across the river and may not be worth visiting, I disagree. Yes, the view from across the river is fantastic, but so are the views from the temple. Moreover, the Wat is unusually high (about 104 or so meters high according to the Thai Tourism board), and you can climb it up through rather narrow steep steps. The views even climbing half way are fabulous. The structure itself is worth seeing up close. Don't miss it. We went on the Express Boat on the river, up and down, and made several stops, but our destination from the start was the Wat Arun, and don't regret it. We paid about 20 bath to enter, and 2 bath per person each way to cross the river from the Express boat stop on the other bank. You can go easily across the river to see Wat Arun when you visit the Grand Palace, which unlike another review mention is NOT closed on Wednesday or any day for that matter. The people who tell you that the Palace or Wat Pho are closed (even temporarily closed) are just scammers trying to redirect you (and transport you for a fee) to another place. Please don't pay attention!

Well worth the river crossing. This is a less updated temple around bangkok but one of my favorites. You can climb the steep steps of the Prang for a great view of the city. The overall feel is less touristy and more of a temple. For sure a must visit on the temple lists of Bangkok. Take a look at the official webpage for more information. http://www.watarun.org/index_en.html

wat arun. Wat Arun is not far away from the Grand Palace and Wat Pho, you just need to get to pier 8 and pay 3 baht to get across the river. You will already be able to see Wat Arun before you get on the ferry. When you get off follow most of the other people to the 'front' of the temple. I think it's 50 baht to go into the temple. You can climb the stairs and get a good view of Bangkok and Siam City in the distance. If you are going to Wat Pho and the Grand Palace, go to Wat Arun, it will not take up too much of your time and if you are able to climb the (steep) stairs it really is worth it.

Least impressive of the Big 3 but that is not too shabby. Plus you get Great views across the river. This temple looks more like the kind you would see in neighbouring Cambodia. This temple is nowhere near as ornate as the other two in the area (Wat Po and the Grand Palace) but feels like it has more history for this reason. It almost has a neglected air to it? There are great views across towards the Grand Palace and along the Chao Phraya River. Only a few pennies to get the boat across the river to/from the other temples in this area.Worth stopping by certainly, but not an all day thing. Good to combine with the Grand Palace. The other; Wat Po maybe deserves a little more time; but all three can certainly be done on the same day.We did all three in one day and returned to Wat Po at a later point for a second visit.Wat Arun is not at the stop off point for the local water boats or the tourist boat but as mentioned you can get a boat from where they stop, across the river for a few pennies. I have never been too spiritual; but Thailand and places like Wat Arun have turned my way of thinking.

there are better things to do if you have limited time in bangkok. we wanted to see the grand palace, but it's closed to tourists on wednesday mornings due to religious ceremonies. a guy near the palace redirected us to this temple. it was cool to see- took about 40 minutes to see the whole thing. everything was gilded and beautiful. i kind of get the feeling that if you've seen one or two wats in bangkok, you've seen them all. steep stairs and a lot of them. definitely not for people who can't climb stairs easily. view from the top was nice but i got just as good a view from my 18th story hotel balcony.

A Beautiful place. From the river Wat Arun looked a bit grey and dull- but it is not!I was there for the chinese new year so I was in for a treat- I guess the place is not that festive all year.But a visit is highly recommended and if you want, make the climb to enjoy the view of the other side of Bangkok. Dont forget to see the royal prayer room and get a blessing from a monk.

Great Wat with Impressive Views. I think this Wat is one of the oldest in Bangkok and is very impressive if not as glitzy as the grand palace. As it is over the river the crowds are a lot less which means you can take your time and it has a chilled out feel to it. You are able to climb the largest building and the views are great but be warned if you dont like heights you wont like coming back down the steps as they are very steep.

A Peaceful Haven. My wife, sister-in-law & I visited Wat Arun on the morning of 16th Dec 2010. We took a taxi from our hotel, Twin Towers, to Si Phraya pier, then the orange-flag Chao Phraya express boat to Tha Tien & finally the cross-river ferry to Wat Arun. We said a short prayer at Wat Arun, received beautiful wrist bands from the temple monk, took photographs & then headed back the way we came.

Wat Arun Temple is an ideal destination when visiting Bangkok. Wat Arun Temple is an ideal destination when visiting Bangkok. BaThe Wat really looks better from a distance than close up, and you're not missing out too much even if you only view from across the river. The grounds are fairly pleasant and peaceful though, with good murals and a main Buddha image supposedly designed by King Rama II. The mythical guardians here are also quite impressive, though very similiar to those at Wat Phra Kaew.

It's worth to visit in Bangkok!. I Visit this place twice! the most beautiful time is in the afternoon. I like taking photos at that moment. It's hard to climb to the top because the steps are very small and high, but when you reach to the top you will have very good feeling...especially a great view to Bangkok city and river.

A tough climb up and down, but outstanding cultural site.. Visited on 16 September 2010. GPS coordinates are N 13 44.629 E 100 29.334 Entrance fee is 50 Baht ($1.63 US). There are only two (2) legitimate entrances to the temple grounds—one each on the East side and West side. There are warning signs not to pay anybody who approaches you.Caught a ferry from Central Pier (East side of river) for 14 Baht ($.45 US) and rode it about 7 stops to Ta Wang Lang (West side of river). Then, I walked due south on a road parallel to the river, followed the signs to the temple grounds. Taking my time, it took about an hour and some of the streets were a little questionable. Instead, cross by another ferry from Tha Tien Pier (East side of the river) adjacent to Wat Pho temple. It only costs 3 Baht ($.10 US) to cross the river. Arrived at approximately 1700 and was amazed at how empty it was. Maybe 10 other people wandering the grounds. There was a family with 3 children under the age 10, but I would not recommend climbing for anybody under 13 years and those afraid of heights. Beautiful artwork and amazing construction done with fairly primitive technology. This is the type of cultural site that one expects to see in Thailand. Wish there were more signs or a handout to help explain the significance of site.There are 2 fairly steep flights of steps going up and another set of stairs going down. As soon as I entered the grounds, it started to rain, but I still climbed the steps. There are steel rails on each side of the stairs, but recommend using both hands on just one side of rails. Going up was challenging, but coming down was borderline scary. On the way down, I highly recommend you walk down the stairs backwards, using both hands on a single rail. Found it easier to control my center of gravity because if you feel as if you are going to fall, you can just lay on your stomach or drop to your knees. Glad I made the trip, but climbing to the top would be a challenge for the majority of my relatives. Even if they did not actually climb it, it would be worth the 50 Baht to just walk around the temple grounds. Of course, when I attempted to buy a ferry ticket at the Central Pier, was told my only choice was to buy an all day pass for 150 Baht ($4.88 US). Having fallen for that trick on my last trip, told them I only wanted a one way ticket. Surprise, but he still my only choice was 150 Baht even though the tourist standing right next to me was charged 35 Baht. Just buy the ticket on the ferry for 14 Baht ($.45 US). Have no problem paying the fair price, just hate being cheated. Where are the Tourist Police when you need them?
Beautiful and Unique Temple. Really liked it. had never seen anything like it. Try to eat on the other side of the river and enjoy the views at sunset.

Great views from the top. Situated by the Chao Phraya river (opposite to the Wat Po) and otherwise known as ‘Temple of the Dawn’, this temple is one of the early homes of the Emerald Buddha with four Khmer style prangs centred around a main prang.Ornately decorated with broken porcelain, is the central prang rises to 220ft that is assessable via a series of three steep staircases, to three different levels – allowing aerial views across the river of the Grand Palace and around the Chao Phraya River itself.
