Note: If it is a very wet day, they will not allow anybody to climb up the Phrang as it can be quite slippery. There are a couple of ornately decorated buildings in the temple grounds to be visited, but much of your time will be spent trying to photograph the infinite designs of mosaic porcelain covering almost every inch of the prangs!Open daily 07.30 a.m. - 06.00 p.m. Admission 100 Baht for foreigners.Easiest way to get there – Catch the Sky Train to S6 Saphan Taksin Station (Silom Line). Leave via Exit 2 and walk straight ahead to ‘Central’ boat pier. Buy either a Day pass or single journey ride on the Chao Phraya Express Boat and get off at Tien Pier (N8). Side by side is another pier from which you have to catch the River ferry that will take you directly across the river to Wat Arun. (3 Baht each way). The river ferry is every 10mts if that.

High point of the temple triangle. Take a ferry accross the river from the main temple area; it's cheap and easy and adds to the Bankok experience. The temple tower is pretty from afar and even prettier up close when you see the detail of the pottery decorations. This is a physically demanding temple and if you are not in closed shoes I'd suggest going barefoot up the steep staircases. Those inclined to vertigo should admire the temple from below and ladies in short skirts should be careful too! The whole experience, including ride accross the river, walk through the grounds from the pier and queueing to climb the temple takes 90 minutes max.

worth a look. We took a ferry (very cheap - 3 baht per person) from the Wat Po (reclining buddha) boat stop to get there. Steep steps, but worth the climb. We went around sunset (6:15pm, January 13, 2010) and they were in process of closing up. At night, wat arun is lit up with lights, so when we crossed the river back to the otherside, it provided a nice picture opportunity of the temple.

great for views of the river !. we caught local ferry across to Wat Arun (very cheap indeed) and did manage to hike up the very very steep steps - well worth it too! It was great to be able to get somewhat of a birds eye view of the river area and bangkok.

Beautiful temple by the river. It's a beautiful temple to visit. If you take the boat to get here, be aware that you need to pay a 'landing fee' when you got there.
The steps going up the temples are steep - do take care! If you're not fit just stay on the ground and enjoy the intricate details of the temple.

Disappointing in reality. Like a small part of Angkor Wat, and looks good from the river despite some of the surroundings. Bit in truth closeup a little dowdy compared with all the hype in the guidebooks. Older people were struggling getting down the steep steps.

Ornate enough for a closer look. Directly across the river from Wat Pho is this 5 spired Khmer styled tower. The corners are surrounded by 4 smaller prangs. The towers are decorated by seashells, porcelain and ceramics and fashioned into an array of flowers and other images. The central prang is topped with a seven-pronged trident.If you visiting the river by the water taxi you will need to take a separate taxi to go across the river. There are steep steps that you can climb and enjoy the views of the city. However on the day we visited the weather was so hot, we opted to have a fresh coconut drink instead and watch others struggle to reach the top.

Wonderful views of Bangkok!. We finished our tour for the day at Wat Arun – The Temple of Dawn (50 Baht / person)–a very steep climb but a great way to get a bit of a bird’s eye view of the city. It is so worth the climb to the top, as the views of the city skyline, the river and the Grand Palace are wonderful. One tip --- it’s a very steep climb, so coming down, you’re better off going backwards. You’ll want to use the hand rails in both directions!

A beautiful temple but what a walk down!. I have been to Bangkok several times and during this recent trip, I finally got to see Wat Arun. It was stunning! The craftmanship is amazing. It was very ornate. The view was breath taking once you make it up the steep stairs. Walking down those stairs was very scary. It was steep. I don't recommend walking up the temple for anyone who is afraid of heights and with bad knees/hips.

Cool view- wat arun. It is easy to get to wat arun. Ferry station No 8 Tha Tien is the stop off point for the Grand palace, Wat pho and Wat arun. Directions: If u are visitng wat pho. Face the entrance of wat pho. Turn to your right and keep walking straight. You just have to cross one street and then go through this alleyway passing stalls selling spices and dried fish. Catch the ferry to wat arun is a 2 min ride across the river. Price: You have to pay 3 baht to go there and when you are on the other side 3 baht to come back. Entrance fee is 50 bahtI found the temple beautiful and loved the architecture. Once on top there is a cool view of the river and grand palace.
Wat Arun, Bangkok Thailand. I went there with my mom, really good place, so high and so clam I like this place very much

One of my favourite Temple. This is a must visit for first time visitor to Bangkok or even people who have not been there. If you are not planning on other stops along the Chao Phraya River, the best way to do is to go to end of BTS station (Silom Line) -- Saphan Taskin station and take any of the free hotel shuttle (Mandarin Oriental is probably best). Get to the other side of the river and then take a taxi. If you use the Chao Phraya River Tourist boat, it is a long wait for the boat and then when you get to Tha Tien ferry pier, you still need to take another ferry to Wat Arun.Make sure you are wearing proper shoes so that you can climb all the way up to Wat Arun and then see the view from the wat. It is truly beautiful.

Beautiful attention to detail. Wat Arun, how beautiful it is. Everyone says you must go but until you see it upfront and personal you have no idea. Got there quite easily on the tourist Chao Praya River boat on a day ticket that is now BAHT150 for the day. You get off at stop 8, or Tha Tien Pier, you then get on another smaller boat to take you to Wat Arun. Remember to have your BAHT3 ready each way as this is what you have to pay before getting on the cross river boat. It cost BAHT50 to get into the temple. If your clothing is not deemed appropriate there are shawls to rent at BAHT20 with a BAHT100 deposit. I am aware that there are cheaper boats to get you to Wat Arun but this is what we did.The temple was looking its best and in a particular WAT a man was completing one of the columns with some fine detail. The others had been completed and looked beautiful. We saw many people take the walk up the steps and it was a reminder to us to take it easy. It was 32degrees celcius at about 10:30am and the possibility of falling and hurting yourself was there. But if you take it easy and pace yourself you will be fine. We took our time but saw lots of people rushing about. We read up on the history before we went and read up again when we returned as you get a better understanding as there is soooo much to take in.Enjoy Wat Arun. We certainly did.

Overcast day but still worth the effort. Was a bit overcast and threatening rain in sept when I did the Klongs and Wat Arun tour. Had a very good guide/hostess, very informative and pleasant. As mentioned before watch those stairs. But check t-shirts and cold drinks available on site. Worth getting out of bed to do.

A definite must-see, up close and from afar. This is one of the three must-see temples in Bangkok, and can easily be combined with Wat Pho and Wat Phra Kaew (in the Grand Palace complex). If you only have 1 day in Bangkok, I suggest that you finish all three, and you're good to go! Wat Arun is the most photographed structure in Bangkok (especially during sunset), and understandably so. It is simply gorgeous up close and from afar. I took the Chao Phraya "cross river" ferry from the Wat Pho stop. The maps for Chao Phraya is everywhere in Bangkok so it's impossible to miss this. I also have my Lonely Planet: Thailand book which has good recommendations on walking tours, which includes this temple. When you enter the Wat Arun compound, you'll be amazed by its stunning design. It's simply majestic! And, you get to climb the temple too. Be careful though, the stairs are pretty narrow, and steep. However, your effort climbing up won't be left unrewarded. The views from the top is amazing and gives you a panoramic view of the Chao Phraya river and the old Bangkok. This temple should definitely be a part of any itinerary in Bangkok!

Exotic Sighting. Visiting Wat Arun is one of the highlights schedulle that should've been done in Thailand. Wat Arun is a historic landmark in a very huslte-bustle Bangkok city. It reflects the spirituality of Bangkok's people.There so many things to do in Wat Arun's Area which are (of course visiting the main temple), climb so many stairs to reach the upper storey of the temple and enjoy the view over there, and shopping various Thai souvenirs or foods in the area. We can find so many cheap but nice things in Thailand ~ also in Wat Arun. I bought a pair of wallet made from stingray leather, it costed me only 250 Baht (Approx. 9-10 USD) and if you are a good bargainer (and i'm not) maybe you can get lower prices than that.There was a bad experience happened during my visit to Wat Arun. All travelers especially foreigner should be aware of some irresponsible local people. In my case, I happened to be tricked with my money ~ when i wanted to pay the bill about 100 Bath (I took a photograph with a Sriraka statue and i haven't got any idea if should pay for that, they put so tiny sign about the prices so that if we weren't aware, we could not see it... geez) and opened my wallet, they took my money 100 dollars but they took the Singaopore dollars not the Thai Baths. I had a little argument with them and at last then they returned the money and i gave the real bath (100 SGD = 2000 THB).So to all travelers, enjoy your visit to Wat Arun and also be aware of yourselves. Eventhough, Thailand is still the land with smiles.( ' ' )V

Watch those stairs!. This is a great Wat to see up close. From afar, its very majestic and probably the most iconic image of Bangkok. To get there, simply take the Tha Tian express ferry across the Chao Phraya river. It will drop you off directly in-front of the Wat. There is an entry fee for non-Thais. Wat Arun is simply a sight for the senses. Look up close to the bits and pieces of the Wat - they are decorated by seashells and bits of porcelain which had previously been used as ballast by boats coming to Bangkok from China. They form many images - many of them floral in shape. You can easily climb up half way without much of a problem. However, if you want to go to the top, be warned, the stairs are narrow and steep! Going up isn't so much the issue, it's coming down. So please secure all lose bags and make sure those shoe laces are tied! It's a nasty fall. The views are very lovely and it makes the climb up all that much more worthwhile.If you do a dinner cruise along the river, you will see the Wat all lit up - and it looks quite pretty! This Wat is quite a nice change from all the glitz and gold from some of the other Wats in Bangkok.

A Must see in Bangkok. The Wat Arun temple in Bangkok is a must see. It is relatively easy to get to with the river ferries. Its architecture is amazing. The temple is made from 1000's of pieces of broken porcelain. It is a small temple and no more than 30 minutes is needed to see it all.Although shorts are allowed, women must cover their shoulders. My wife just tied a shirt around her neck and draped it over her shoulders.

Not a typical Thai temple. Easy to get to - just take a ferry across the river from the same place you get off for the Grand Palace. It’s a pity more people don’t visit it.Not a typical temple in the Thai style, which is quite refreshing if you’ve been in Thailand for a while. It consists of a central prang with stairs up to two levels. There are four smaller prangs at the corners. There is no temple building with a Buddha image inside, so no need to remove shoes at any time.Broken pieces of porcelain and small bowls are used to decorate the temple so it’s certainly colourful with lots of demon ‘yaksha’ figures for decoration.Be warned the steps are very, very steep to climb to the two levels. They are supposed to symbolise the difficulty of ascending to the heavens.
